text: Rejecting a recommendation by its own chief administrative judge, the Drug Enforcement Administration has refused to relax restrictions on marijuana.
title: U.S. RESISTS EASING CURB ON MARIJUANA

text: The agency's decision, issued in an order by its Administrator, John C. Lawn, that was published Friday in The Federal Register, means marijuana will continue to be listed under Schedule I of the Controlled Substances Act, which lists substances with a high potential for abuse and no accepted medical use. Marijuana has been classified under Schedule I since the act was passed in 1970.
title: U.S. RESISTS EASING CURB ON MARIJUANA

text: The National Organization for Marijuana Law Reform sought three years ago to have marijuana reclassified to Schedule II, which would keep it unavailable to the general public but allow it to be prescribed. Comfort in Chemotherapy
title: U.S. RESISTS EASING CURB ON MARIJUANA

text: The D.E.A.'s chief administrative law judge, Francis L. Young, recommended a year ago that marijuana be placed on the less restrictive schedule, as ''one of the safest therapeutically active substances known to man.''
title: U.S. RESISTS EASING CURB ON MARIJUANA

text: He cited a number of medical experts and patients as saying marijuana helped suppress nausea and vomiting experienced by cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy and was effective in controlling muscle spasms of patients with multiple sclerosis.
title: U.S. RESISTS EASING CURB ON MARIJUANA

text: ''The evidence in this record clearly shows that marijuana has been accepted as capable of relieving the distress of great numbers of very ill people and doing so with safety under medical supervision,'' Mr. Young wrote. ''It would be unreasonable, arbitrary and capricious for D.E.A. to continue to stand between those sufferers and the benefits of this substance in light of the evidence in this record.'' Impartiality Is Challenged
title: U.S. RESISTS EASING CURB ON MARIJUANA

text: But in his order Mr. Lawn, the Administrator, said Mr. Young had ''failed to act as an impartial judge in this matter.''
title: U.S. RESISTS EASING CURB ON MARIJUANA

text: ''He appears to have ignored the scientific evidence, ignored the testimony of highly credible and recognized medical experts and, instead, relied on the testimony of psychiatrists and individuals who used marijuana,'' Mr. Lawn said. He also said Mr. Young, in his findings, ''ignored any evidence presented by the Government.''
title: U.S. RESISTS EASING CURB ON MARIJUANA

text: A D.E.A. news release said the Administrator ''found that there was a lack of credible evidence to support a conclusion that safety, efficacy and acceptance had been demonstrated for the medical use of marijuana.'' Ruling Called Capricious
title: U.S. RESISTS EASING CURB ON MARIJUANA

text: Mr. Young could not be reached for comment.
title: U.S. RESISTS EASING CURB ON MARIJUANA

text: Donald Fiedler, national director of the National Organization for Marijuana Law Reform, said: ''The ruling is arbitrary and capricious because it means doctors now don't have that tool available to use marijuana as a medicine.''
title: U.S. RESISTS EASING CURB ON MARIJUANA

text: The D.E.A. said physicians and scientists could still file proposals for further research on the medical aspects of marijuana.
title: U.S. RESISTS EASING CURB ON MARIJUANA

text: Drug abuse by junior high and high school students in New York State declined between 1983 and 1988, according to a study released by the State Office of Mental Health.
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: The survey of 7,611 students in 53 public and private schools was the first to detail systematically the use of the powerful cocaine derivative known as crack, said Denise Kandel, a Columbia University professor and mental-health researcher who conducted the study.
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: ''The declines are really dramatic,'' she said. ''I think they're greater than what one has observed on the national scene.''
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: Ms. Kandel said the study, which was released on Thursday, indicates that use of illicit drugs by students in grades 7 through 12 declined by about 50 percent over the last comprehensive survey, conducted in 1983 by the state Division of Substance Abuse Services.
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: There is no easy explanation for the decline, she said.
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: ''I think there's been a change in young people's attitude about the risk and harmfulness about using drugs,'' she said. ''But it's difficult to pinpoint one thing.
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: ''Obviously, drug education and drug prevention has increased,'' she said, ''There's been increased attention in the media to the harmfulness of drugs. Parents and communities have come together to fight the problem.'' Cause for Concern
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: Ms. Kandel said the survey also showed cause for concern. An early start in the use of illicit drugs, for example, often leads to the use of more dangerous drugs like crack at a younger age, it found.
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: ''Students who get involved in cocaine, and especially crack, have started using drugs, including marijuana, at an earlier age than those who have not used cocaine,'' Ms. Kandel said.
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: According to the survey, marijuana was the illicit drug used most commonly (by 28 percent of those responding) followed by stimulants (11 percent), inhalants (6 percent), cocaine (6 percent), psychedelics (5 percent), crack (1.49 percent) and heroin (1 percent).
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: The use of illicit drugs increases substantially as students get older, the survey showed. Ms. Kandel said that just under 7 percent of the seventh-graders surveyed said they used an illicit drug, but nearly 54 percent of the high school seniors surveyed said they used them.
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: Overall, 84 percent of those surveyed said they had had an alcoholic beverage - all are below the state's legal drinking age of 21 - and 58 percent said they had smoked cigarettes. The survey showed that 32 percent said they had used an illicit drug and 18 percent said they had used an illicit drug other than marijuana.
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: The confidential surveys were filled out by students at their schools in the spring of 1988. New Study Is Being Performed
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: Blanche Frank, chief of epidemiology with the State Division of Substance Abuse Services, declined to comment on the Kandel study or whether the division has similarly detected a significant decline in drug use among New Yorkers of school age. She said her division is currently conducting a similar survey of students and said preliminary results would be released in the summer of 1990.
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: * Students were an average age of 12.5 years old when they first smoked cigarettes, 12.9 years old when they first drank alcohol, 14.6 years old when they first used marijuana and just under 15 when they first took crack.
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: * The quality of teen-agers' lives deteriorated in proportion to their intake of illicit substances. They did worse in school, did not get along as well with their families and are in poorer health both mentally and physically than their peers who do not use drugs, the survey showed.
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: * No major change in the level of alcohol use was noted between the 1988 survey and the 1983 survey.
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

text: * More boys than girls drink and take all kinds of illicit drugs. More girls smoke cigarettes than boys.
title: Study Finds Fewer Teen-Agers Using Drugs

title: News Summary

text: LEAD: Joseph Hoberman grows orchids for a hobby. On Oct. 25, he was tending them when four cars stopped in front of his home.
title: Marijuana McCarthyism

text: Joseph Hoberman grows orchids for a hobby. On Oct. 25, he was tending them when four cars stopped in front of his home.
title: Marijuana McCarthyism

text: Six men and a woman got out, and three started up his walk.
title: Marijuana McCarthyism

text: ''I knew they were police from the way they acted,'' he says, ''but I didn't think anything of it.''
title: Marijuana McCarthyism

text: He imagined they were going to ask him to teach his course in forest orienteering to the new Raleigh, N.C. police recruits, as he'd done before. Instead, the lead man flashed a State Bureau of Investigation badge and asked whether they could come in and take a look around. ''For what?'' he asked. ''Marijuana plants. And if you say no we'll come back with a warrant and we won't be in a great mood.''
title: Marijuana McCarthyism

text: Intimidated, Mr. Hoberman admitted them. The search turned up only orchids. When he asked why the officers were searching, he was told he'd received three shipments from a store that sold indoor growing equipment through High Times, a pro-marijuana magazine. ''It was a light meter for my orchids,'' he says. ''I'd gotten the store name from the American Orchid Society. There were three shipments because I got two defective meters.''
title: Marijuana McCarthyism

text: Afterward, Mr. Hoberman became angry. ''Two things bothered me. There was an assumption that I'd done something illegal because I'd bought a light meter from a store that advertised, among other places, in a pro-marijuana magazine. Second, the implication was that if I made them get a search warrant they'd come back and tear my house apart.''
title: Marijuana McCarthyism

text: The following day, the Federal Drug Enforcement Agency coordinated and conducted raids on retail stores specializing in indoor garden supplies in 46 states. The operation was an attempt to shut down the indoor production of marijuana.
title: Marijuana McCarthyism

text: The raids resulted in the confiscation of books, merchandise and records from more than three dozen stores and the padlocking of several others. An official report states that 11 store owners were arrested.
title: Marijuana McCarthyism

text: Aside from the untold damage -financial loss, injury to reputations -done to the raided businesses, several legal issues have been raised.
title: Marijuana McCarthyism

text: First is whether the Government has the right to seize records from entrepreneurs conducting legal businesses for the purpose of investigating their customers. Second, has the Government the right to ask thousands of citizens to submit to searches because their names appear on store records? Third, all the indoor gardening supply centers investigated advertise in High Times or Sinsemilla Tips, another pro-marijuana magazine. The equipment targeted by the operation, however, can be purchased from thousands of nurseries, electrical supply outlets and department stores nationwide. The question also arises whether there was an attempt to shut down those magazines by scaring off advertisers. If so, the possible infringement of First Amendment rights violations crops up because there is nothing remotely illegal in publishing a pro-marijuana publication.
title: Marijuana McCarthyism

text: There are also moral issues. Should the Government go into shops without enough evidence of wrongdoing to arrest the owners or padlock the doors, then effectively shut them by seizing merchandise and records necessary to the operation of those businesses?
title: Marijuana McCarthyism

text: For the Government to suspect that those who do business with a particular type of store are involved in an illegal activity, when the stores deal exclusively in legal products, is McCarthyism.
title: Marijuana McCarthyism

text: The fact that the Government can target publications' advertisers, investigate consumers and disrupt the lives of thousands without evidence of a crime is an obvious misuse of judicial authority.
title: Marijuana McCarthyism

text: As for Mr. Hoberman, he plans to reassess his interest in orchids. If his equipment can land him in hot water, who knows what trouble the orchids might bring?
title: Marijuana McCarthyism

title: News Summary

text: Drug use inside prisons across the United States has become a major problem with a variety of consequences, including threats to prison order, violence among inmates and corruption of guards and other employees.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: After years of denying or overlooking the existence of illicit drugs behind the towering walls and ribbons of razor wire that encircle their institutions, prison administrators, as well as academics, have only just begun to study the precise scale of inmate drug abuse.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: But a series of interviews, visits to prisons and reviews of the professional literature in recent weeks indicate the problem is more widely acknowledged. Controversial steps are already being taken to combat the surprising ingenuity of prison drug smugglers. And many prison officials express resignation that the problem will never be solved without Draconian measures that American society seems unwilling to impose.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: ''There's been a real explosion of drug use in prison,'' said Dr. Harry Wexler of Narcotics and Drug Research Inc., a nonprofit company that does considerable research with Federal grants. ''The explanation is simple: There's been a real explosion of drug users going to prison.'' William Flower, a spokesman for the Connecticut Department of Correction, added, ''What you have on the street is what you have on the inside.''
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: More than three dozen states are operating under some kind of court order controlling overcrowding, and tough enforcement of drug laws has worsened that problem as more men and women have been convicted of drug violations. Estimates of the prisoners personally involved with drugs now range from 40 to 90 percent.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Thousands of new cells are planned or under construction, costing billions of dollars. President Bush's new anti-drug program contains an 85 percent increase in Federal money for prison construction.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Never in the nation's history have so many of its citizens been imprisoned. As of June 30, state and Federal prisons contained 673,565 prisoners. That was an increase of 7.3 percent, or 56,004 prisoners just since January, a larger increase in six months than the nation has ever experienced in a whole year.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Formal drug rehabilitation treatment within prisons is just in its infancy, and many of those facing long sentences for drug offenses like trafficking were drug abusers themselves.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Often during their daytime rounds of noisy prison common rooms, guards detect the familiar glazed look of an addict intoxicated on drugs. They tell of coming upon inmates shooting up in the private shadows of their cells, and at night, the guards say, they routinely smell marijuana smoke drifting out from the darkness behind the bars. Inmates, too, tell of witnessing frequent drug use.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: ''I've seen more drugs in here than out there,'' said Charles Capers, a 37-year-old, six-time convict in the Connecticut penal system.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Sharon A. Williams of the National Criminal Justice Reference Service, said, ''The prison drug problem is beginning to emerge now,'' adding, ''You couldn't talk about it before.''
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Not every prison system admits to a major problem. Greg Bogdan, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Prisons, whose institutions hold about 7 percent of the nation's prisoners, said 49,936 random urine tests of Federal prisoners in the nine months ending last June 30 found only 2.2 percent testing positive, half the 1986 rate.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: It is generally in the far larger state and county prison systems that the problem is detected and now openly discussed.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: ''Prisons are an incredible captive drug market,'' said Bob B., a former New York prison counselor and onetime heroin addict who asked that his full name not be used. ''Drugs inside can bring three times their street value.'' He told of counseling prisoners fearful for their lives because they were caught in wars among inmates competing for control of drug sales. He himself admitted smuggling in some drugs on occasion.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Indeed, announcements of arrests of prison staff for drug smuggling have become frequent. In Michigan, some prison personnel were charged with accepting bribes to arrange for some inmates to transfer from one institution to another to expand the prison drug rings. The Smugglers Liberalized Visiting, Ingenious Conduits
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Though prison staff involvement in drug smuggling and sales is a serious problem, the principal transporters of drugs into prisons, the officials say, are visitors. And the increasingly large numbers of visitors make thorough individual searches unrealistic, if not impossible, given current liberalized visiting policies and procedures. Drug deliveries by visitors and payments to drug suppliers are easily arranged from inside by unmonitored pay phones, the officials said.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: The drugs arrive in prison in many imaginative manners - squeezed into the bindings of books, hidden on the back of stamps, inside a girlfriend's bra or a baby's diapers and stuffed into rectums or vaginas.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Searches are often prohibited by courts unless there is good reason for suspicion. To establish such probable cause, all visitors to New York City's Rikers Island prisons, for instance, are assigned numbered seats on special buses. After a short ride, visitors are removed from the bus while trained drug-sniffing dogs check each seat. When the dogs, with names like Curley, Melvin, Major and Roscoe, indicate strong interest in a particular seat, the occupant is required to undergo a thorough body search or his or her visit is canceled. Thick Glass Is Gone
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: The scale of the problem in checking visitors is evident in the crowded New York City jail system. It has 20,300 prisoners in its 15 institutions, 2,810 more than last December. It has 12,293 employees, including 10,210 correction officers, or guards. Each year the system must also process nearly 400,000 visitors, or several visitors for each prisoner.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: And while visitors are screened by metal detectors and a handful of guards monitor the visiting rooms, security is nothing like the popular image from old movies, with prisoners and families separated by thick glass and conversing by telephone.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: In the last decade or so, prison philosophy has emphasized helping prisoners maintain family ties as an integral part of their long-range rehabilitation. So most institutions now allow what are called ''contact visits.'' Typically, dozens of prisoners sit across open tables from visitors, holding hands. Embraces and kisses are allowed at the beginning and end of the visit.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: One popular means of transmitting drugs is to exchange a balloon packed with drugs during a kiss. Some prisons videotape visiting rooms, and guards replay tapes of the initial embraces to spot suspicious kisses. Those prisoners will then undergo a particularly rigorous examination by guards after the visit before being returned to their cell.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Some prisoners have been known to swallow the balloon before such searches and to recover the drugs later either by induced vomiting or retrieving the container from their own excrement in a day or two. 'Sit Around and Connive'
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Another exchange method is for a visitor to deposit the drugs in a designated prison washroom, which is then very promptly ''cleaned'' by an inmate crew. Still another is for the visitor to flush a bag of drugs down a prison toilet for waiting inmates to fish from the institution's sewage treatment plant.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Michael A. Chernovetz, warden of the Community Correctional Center in Bridgeport, Conn., said most citizens are unaware of how prisons are run today. ''They think every institution is always locked up tighter than a drum,'' he said. ''But the fiscal reality is that I've got to have nonviolent inmates performing many maintenance and caretaker jobs - sweeping driveways, cutting grass, putting out garbage. That inmate earns 75 cents a day. A staff member earns a little more than that. I can't have one staffer stand behind every inmate who goes outside for a few minutes.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: ''And all it takes is a phone call to a girlfriend to tell her to leave the bag in the third bush from the corner. We even have mothers bringing in the stuff. We try to get as much as possible. But these guys have a lot of time to sit around and connive.'' The Impact Inside Corroded Order, Imported Hostility
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Warden Chernovetz and others say the impact of drugs in prison is not so much that prisoners intoxicated by drugs are likely to assault officers, although that has happened. It is more the danger to the institution of importing wholesale into prison the violent, grievance-filled, debt-ridden drug culture of the streets. A more hostile environment results, with the inmates more prone than ever to argue and fight among themselves.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Prison authorities say the underground drug economy creates a generally unsafe environment that corrodes order, reduces the effectiveness of academic and drug treatment programs and can create staff corruption.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: ''Sometimes,'' said Bob, the former New York prison counselor, ''these inmates were counseling me like an out-mate. They thought I was a fool, coming into prison every day voluntarily for my $23,000 a year and getting high only on the weekends. They arrived in cuffs, were high seven days a week and had a definite date to get out and start making their 100 G's a year dealing drugs.''
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: ''The guards and the bad guys in prison come from the same neighborhoods,'' Bob added. ''The nice guys became guards going to work every day and the nasty guys became occasional inmates. But, you know, if you go to the zoo every day, when you come home, you begin reeking of the zoo.'' Problems in Local Jails
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: The Illinois Department of Corrections reported earlier this year that 66 employees had been arrested in the previous three years on drug and other illegal contraband charges. In one recent six-month period nearly 650 inmates and 100 visitors were involved in such contraband cases.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: ''We have a bigger problem than society in general,'' the Cook County Sheriff, James O'Grady, said in Chicago after three deputies were among 19 charged last spring in Federal indictments with running a drug ring to supply inmates in the county jail. Two Connecticut guards were arrested for drug smuggling this fall. In Michigan, a Federal-state study group is investigating reports that state corrections officials allowed visitors to smuggle illicit drugs and protected inmates from searches in return for payments of up to $1,000 a week by dealers.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Ruby Ryles of New York City's Department of Correction said that in the last 18 months, 17 department employees had been arrested on prison drug charges. ''Inmates are very creative finding ways of getting drugs in,'' she said. ''But we're creative in finding them, too.'' In Search of Solutions Stiff Enforcement And Interdiction
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Phil Seelig, president of the Correction Officers' Benevolent Association, which has 9,000 members in the city penal system, said that guards who had been arrested on drug charges had been enticed to participate and that the ''widespread drug problem'' in city jails resulted from lax security procedures for visitors and failure to properly prosecute prisoners found with drugs.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: ''We'd also like to see contact visits abandoned and more thorough regular searches of cells,'' he added. As a result of manpower and time constraints, he said, guards can search the accommodations of only about 50 inmates a day out of 2,000 in each unit. ''That doesn't even make a dent,'' he said. ''The drugs just flow into the unsearched area for a while. And those found with drugs should get more time, not just disciplined.''
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Wisconsin has stressed enforcement within prison over interdiction. It uses random announced urine tests to discourage drug use, with progressively stiffer disciplinary penalties imposed with each positive test result. Positive test results shrank over three recent years from around 30 percent to the 3 to 6 percent range, with higher rates in the higher security prisons. Officials say this has meant the removal of 1,150 drug users from the prison market in the same period. Rare Searches of Guards
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Search procedures vary. Most systems use metal detectors on visitors, and some use them on guards. South Carolina does a pat-down search of all visitors, but other states hesitate without probable cause, fearing lawsuits. Many systems rely on random inmate strip searches after visits.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Guards could be searched but rarely are without a solid tip. ''That would be really awkward, officers searching officers,'' said Mike Van Winkle of California's prison system.
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Mr. Chernovetz of the Connecticut system said: ''Sure, some officers are camels. It would be naive to say that some are not drug-involved.''
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: Many systems are subjecting newly hired officers to rigorous investigation and drug testing. And Florida has begun stiff prosecution of staff members found with drugs. ''Our best deterrent,'' said Bob McMaster of Florida's Department of Corrections, ''is to let our own people see that we're going to be very tough on our own people.''
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: ''Sure,'' said Mr. Flower of Connecticut, ''you could stop all drugs getting into prison. You'd clamp down so hard - no human contact, no visits, no exchanges - it would create an inhuman, explosive situation probably worse than what we've got.''
title: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

text: A man prosecutors called the biggest single broker of Southeast Asian marijuana pleaded guilty on Tuesday in Federal District Court to smuggling nearly 200 tons into the United States over four years.
title: Man Admits Smuggling Tons of Marijuana

text: The defendant, Brian Peter Daniels, pleaded guilty to one count of operating a continuing criminal enterprise and two counts of conspiracy to import and distribute marijuana.
title: Man Admits Smuggling Tons of Marijuana

text: Mr. Daniels, a 43-year-old New York native who had lived in Thailand for about 10 years until his 1988 arrest in Switzerland, could be sentenced to life in prison and fined up to $6.25 million.
title: Man Admits Smuggling Tons of Marijuana

text: Sentencing was set for May 25. Mr. Daniels is being held without bail in the Pierce County Jail. He has admitted masterminding some of the biggest marijuana shipments from Southeast Asia to the United States from 1984 to 1988. Among them was the shipment of 72 tons of high-grade Laotian marijuana seized in June 1988 aboard the Encounter Bay, an oil-supply vessel, off the Washington coast.
title: Man Admits Smuggling Tons of Marijuana

text: The guilty plea was part of an agreement in which some charges in Seattle, San Diego, and Reno were packaged into a single plea agreement filed in Seattle.
title: Man Admits Smuggling Tons of Marijuana

text: By Philip Shabecoff, Special To the New York Times
title: Experts in U.S. Doubt That Noriega Is Entitled to Vatican Asylum

text: Citing policies that have traditionally been pursued in the United States, legal experts questioned today whether Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the deposed Panamanian leader, was entitled to sanctuary or asylum in the Vatican's embassy in Panama City.
title: Experts in U.S. Doubt That Noriega Is Entitled to Vatican Asylum

text: The United States recognizes the right of asylum in cases where those seeking refuge can show a ''well-founded fear of persecution.'' General Noriega, however, ''would not be entitled to asylum because he was clearly a persecutor, not a persecutee,'' said Randy L. Levine, who was the ranking Associate Deputy Attorney General from 1986 to 1988.
title: Experts in U.S. Doubt That Noriega Is Entitled to Vatican Asylum

text: ''If this were the United States, he would be denied asylum,'' he added.
title: Experts in U.S. Doubt That Noriega Is Entitled to Vatican Asylum

text: David Runkel, spokesman for the Justice Department said General Noriega ''does not have well-founded fear of persecution, but he does have a well-founded fear of prosecution in the United States.'' The former Panamanian leader has been indicted in Florida on charges off shipping cocaine and marijuana here and laundering money through Colombian drug dealers. Legally Vatican Territory
title: Experts in U.S. Doubt That Noriega Is Entitled to Vatican Asylum

text: Mr. Runkel said the United States recognized that the Papal Nunciature, as the embassy is called, is legally territory of the Vatican and that ''any activity concerning Noriega would take that into account.''
title: Experts in U.S. Doubt That Noriega Is Entitled to Vatican Asylum

text: Administration officials said today that there had been several contacts with the Vatican by the United States and Panama concerning General Noriega's status.
title: Experts in U.S. Doubt That Noriega Is Entitled to Vatican Asylum

text: Mr. Levine said the former Panamian leader could be arrested by either the United States or Panama as soon as he stepped outside the grounds of the Papal Nuncio's mission. If Panama takes him into custody, however, it has no legal obligation to send him to the United States because there is no extradition treaty between the two nations.
title: Experts in U.S. Doubt That Noriega Is Entitled to Vatican Asylum

text: On several occasions in the past, the United States has granted refuge in its embassies to foreign nationals. The Embassy in Beijing is now sheltering China's most prominent dissident, Fang Lizhi, and his wife, Li Shuxian.
title: Experts in U.S. Doubt That Noriega Is Entitled to Vatican Asylum

text: Perhaps the most famous instance was the protection given to Joszef Cardinal Mindszenty in the American Embassy in Budapest for 15 years after the Soviet invasion of Hungary in 1956.
title: Experts in U.S. Doubt That Noriega Is Entitled to Vatican Asylum

text: Earlier this year, while discussing the refuge granted to Mr. Fang, the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said the United States had a policy of not offering asylum within a foreign country. She added that it did have ''a longstanding practice of granting temporary refuge in exceptional situations of immediate personal danger.''
title: Experts in U.S. Doubt That Noriega Is Entitled to Vatican Asylum

text: Latin American countries, however, have a long tradition of granting political sanctuary. Otto Reich, a former American Ambassador to Venezuela, said in a telephone interview today, ''Politics has been so unstable in Latin America that all politicians have feared they'd have to use the right of asylum, so they all allowed their political enemies to use it,'' he added.
title: Experts in U.S. Doubt That Noriega Is Entitled to Vatican Asylum

text: Legal experts say there is no broadly accepted international statute or code governing the right of asylum. While several conventions have been drafted seeking to regulate the granting of political sanctuary on humanitarian grounds, none has ever been ratified. Accordingly, individual nations devise their own rules and practices.
title: Experts in U.S. Doubt That Noriega Is Entitled to Vatican Asylum

text: Judge Robert W. Sweet suggests legalization of crack, heroin and other drugs (front page, Dec. 13). It is a complicated social, political and economic issue. However, from a psychiatric perspective, legalization would be a mistake. Cocaine, opiates and stimulants such as amphetamines cause physical addiction and medical complications.
title: War on Drugs Must Begin on the Poverty Front; Nothing Like Butter

text: Judge Sweet states that ''If our society can learn to stop using butter, it should be able to cut down on cocaine.'' Unlike butter, these substances cause a dangerous disruption of behavior, mood, judgment, an intense neurobiologically mediated craving and physical dependency.
title: War on Drugs Must Begin on the Poverty Front; Nothing Like Butter

text: Judge Sweet suggests that under legalization, ''no one without a doctor's prescription would be able to buy a lethal dosage at one time.'' He doesn't seem to understand that even small doses of cocaine can cause serious cardiac complications and even death. (Damage is especially severe to unborn fetuses.) Furthermore, as use of cocaine and stimulants progresses, the amount needed for the desired pleasurable effect increases. With increased use however, dangerous medical and psychiatric side effects, such as psychosis, depression, suicidality and violent and impulsive behavior, also increase. Italy, where heroin (arguably more benign than cocaine) has been legalized, now has the highest incidence of death from overdose in Europe and a burgeoning of human immunodeficiency virus infection.
title: War on Drugs Must Begin on the Poverty Front; Nothing Like Butter

text: Judge Sweet compares the state of drug policy to the failure of alcohol prohibition in this century. But cocaine and heroin are much more addictive than alcohol. And, from a public health perspective, Prohibition was a success. During Prohibition, the incidence of cirrhosis of the liver and alcohol-related admissions to psychiatric hospitals decreased dramatically. All, including Judge Sweet, seem to agree that legalization would lead to increased use; consequently, legalization would lead to an increase in the medical complications of use.
title: War on Drugs Must Begin on the Poverty Front; Nothing Like Butter

text: It is estimated that half of the mentally ill have had problems with substance abuse. Many patients with other primary psychiatric diagnoses attempt to treat their symptoms with cocaine, amphetamines, marijuana and opiates. Ultimately, this self-medication leads to severe worsening of symptoms. Recovery becomes impaired by addiction and poor judgment. The most effective deterrents to abuse seem social sanctions against drugs and their subsequent limited availability.
title: War on Drugs Must Begin on the Poverty Front; Nothing Like Butter

text: Our drug policy, with its focus on interdiction, is a failure. However, there are many options other than legalization. Our resources would be better spent on education and treatment. CHARLES H. SILBERMAN, M.D. New York, Dec. 18, 1989
title: War on Drugs Must Begin on the Poverty Front; Nothing Like Butter

text: The writer is a senior resident in psychiatry at the Payne Whitney Psychiatric Clinic, New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.
title: War on Drugs Must Begin on the Poverty Front; Nothing Like Butter

text: LEAD: DRIVERS on Long Island highways who are stopped for sobriety tests this holiday season are more likely than ever to be checked by police officers also trained to tell if the drivers are under the influence of drugs.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: DRIVERS on Long Island highways who are stopped for sobriety tests this holiday season are more likely than ever to be checked by police officers also trained to tell if the drivers are under the influence of drugs.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: In Nassau County, where about 30 highway patrol officers have completed a three-month course in drug-detection techniques pioneered by the Los Angeles Police Department, arrests of drivers charged with drug-impaired driving have more than tripled in the last two years.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: ''We were probably missing some of these people in the past,'' said Deputy Inspector James F. Garside, commanding officer of the Nassau County Highway Patrol Bureau.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: The New York State Police, who plan to mount four sobriety checkpoints on Long Island roads during the holidays, include in their ranks more than 10 troopers with drug-detection training, according to Thomas R. Collins, a spokesman.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: And the Suffolk County Police Department, which began mounting sobriety checkpoints in July and plans at least one for the holidays, will send eight officers for training in February, according to Capt. Michael D. Puritis, executive officer of the department's Highway Patrol Bureau.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: At the sobriety checkpoints, which are generally set up during late hours at locations where arrests for drunken driving have been high, the police will stop cars for brief, window-down checks of drivers. Those who smell of alcohol or marijuana, or who speak with slurred speech and fumble with registration papers and licenses, may be pulled over for further scrutiny. Stops by Rotation
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Guidelines for the checkpoints, which have been upheld by the courts, require that police standing in the roadways flag down cars according to a predetermined rotation. For example, they may stop all cars, or every third or fourth car, but they may not take a car out of rotation.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Police said that the checkpoints, which are not used in Nassau County because of fears they will worsen traffic congestion, are intended to ferret out drinking drivers.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Even with illicit drug use elevated to a leading national concern, and despite the presence on patrols of officers trained in drug detection, officials in Nassau and Suffolk Counties concede that police and local prosecutors remained far better prepared to detect and convict drunken drivers. The war on drugs, they said, has barely begun to take to the road.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Although few officials doubted that drug-impaired drivers were a growing road hazard, they said that drug testing was difficult, expensive and vulnerable to challenge in court.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Last year, for example, county police charged 150 drivers in Nassau and 93 in Suffolk with driving while under the influence of drugs. But according to the State Department of Motor Vehicles, there were 86 convictions in Nassau and only 18 in Suffolk in 1988 among the 198 drug-related driving convictions statewide.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: The Long Island convictions also stemmed from charges made by state, town and village police forces.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: In the same year on Long Island, there were 4,681 convictions for driving while intoxicated and 8,136 convictions for driving while ability was impaired by alcohol. The lesser offense of driving while impaired by alcohol often results from plea bargaining by motorists initially charged with drunk driving.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Driving patterns associated with intoxicated drivers are well established, officials said, but far less is known about the impact on drivers of commonly abused drugs that have varying behavioral effects.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Although the use of cocaine, including crack, has spread, police and other officials in the two counties could offer no clear picture of how a driver under the influence of these drugs might negotiate traffic. A Naive Assumption
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: ''It would be naive to assume that these people aren't driving,'' said Christopher A. McLaughlin, assistant to the Commissioner of the Suffolk County Department of Substance Abuse Services. ''But it's a very poorly studied area.''
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Mr. McLaughlin said that drivers who had recently used cocaine would be more likely to take risks behind the wheel.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: ''Then, as the high wears off, you would have the reverse of the initial effects,'' he said.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Such drivers, he said, could become fatigued and agitated, and find it harder to pay attention to the road.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: More studied, Mr. McLaughlin said, was the effect of marijuana on drivers, and its tendency to produce a mental state of exaggerated caution and enhanced but narrowed concentration.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: A marijuana-smoking driver, he said, risked losing the generalized sense of traffic flow that underpins normal driving. Marijuana also slows eye movement and reduces peripheral vision, he said.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Marijuana and alcohol, a frequently found combination, tended to increase risk taking by drivers whose peripheral vision was at the same time reduced, Mr. McLaughlin said. Attention and Balance Tests
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: At sobriety checkpoints that the Suffolk County and State Police have planned for the holidays, drivers with alcohol on their breath may be required to perform attention and balance tests.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Those who fail may be transported to central sites, where Breathalyzer tests will be administered to determine alcohol content.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Both the Breathalyzer testing and the content level that makes a driver legally drunk have been upheld and codified in the courts. The same cannot be said for drug testing. ''There is no instrument comparable to the Breathalyzer for drugs,'' said Deputy Inspector Garside of the Nassau County Highway Patrol Bureau.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Instead, before an arrest can be made, police trained in drug detection must establish probable cause that a driver has used drugs by employing the same set of tests.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: One, a divided attention test that requires a driver to count while hopping on one leg, may detect marijuana users, the police said, since marijuana has been found to reduce the ability to perform more than one task at a time.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: But more and more officers with drug-detection training will look into a suspect's eyes for an involuntary fluttering of the pupils, a condition produced by drugs or alcohol. Urine Analysis Is Costly
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: By a process of elimination, drivers who do not have an odor of alcohol or show other signs of inebriation may then be suspected of drug use and taken to central testing areas, where they may be required to give urine samples.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: But officials said that the analysis of urine for the presence of drugs was costly and of limited effectiveness for some drugs, such as cocaine, whose chemical traces rapidly disappear.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: ''The drug testing is still very new, and we're still in the experimental stage,'' said Clifford M. Riccio, executive director of the Nassau County Traffic Safety Board. Mr. Riccio also said he hoped that a legal challenge would give the county a chance to prove that the testing met court standards.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Mr. Riccio, who is coordinator of the county's Stop D.W.I. program, said that drug testing methodology also included measurements of blood pressure and body temperature.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: He said that 28 percent of all fatal accidents in Nassau in recent years were alcohol related, or only about half the statewide average. But he said there were few statistics on the role that drug use might have played in accidents.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Officials attributed the higher number of drunken driving arrests and alcohol-related traffic fatalities in Suffolk County, compared with Nassau County, to Suffolk's larger size, younger population and the greater reliance of its residents on automobile travel. Arrest Rates Have Declined
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Although arrests for drunk driving in Nassau County appear to be up this year, both counties have otherwise shown declines in arrest rates since 1985.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: ''People are getting smarter,'' said Eileen M. Kremers, the Stop D.W.I. coordinator for Suffolk County, who said drivers had gotten the message that the county would deal harshly with drunken drivers.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: But she also said that, because of understaffing in the county's Police Department, a contingent of 14 officers assigned to patrol for drunken drivers had been cut to 7.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: ''The arrests are really a function of how many officers you put on the road,'' Ms. Kremers said.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Success in combating drunk driving has the paradoxical effect of reducing the amount of money the counties have to finance the battle. Under a state law that went into effect in 1981, fines collected from drivers convicted of alcohol-related offenses are routed to Stop D.W.I. programs in every New York county. As arrests decline, so do revenues.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Money collected from fines is spent for advertising, public education and to defray the costs of prosecution, probation and alcohol treatment programs, among other uses. Spending plans must be filed annually with the Department of Motor Vehicles for approval. Use of Red Ribbons Suggested
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Mothers Against Drunk Driving, a national organization pledged to fight drunken driving and aid families of victims killed in alcohol-related traffic accidents, is a leader of private efforts on Long Island to draw attention to the peril that drinking drivers pose to the public.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Golda Levitan of Cedarhurst, the organization's state chairwoman and the head of a Long Island chapter, said that members were urging drivers to tie a red ribbon on their cars during the holidays to promote safe driving.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Mrs. Levitan's daughter, Stacey, 22 years old, was killed with a companion in August 1987, when they were struck by a car driven by a 22-year-old driver whose blood-alcohol content was twice the amount to make him legally drunk.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: Mrs. Levitan said that the driver had been sentenced to a maximum of seven years in prison, but was released after nine months under a special program.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: She remembered that the driver's lawyer had pleaded in court that his client had already suffered by being jailed during the holidays.
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: ''His lawyer said he had to spend Christmas in jail,'' said Mrs. Levitan. ''I find that absurd. Every holiday, we just go to the cemetery.''
title: Drug Tests Increasing At Road Checkpoints

text: THE day is still not over, but shadows and the temperature have begun to fall quickly as Dave Stewart drives slowly down Center Street, turns left onto 15th and then finally pulls to a stop at Cypress Avenue. There are old, tired houses to his right and to his left, a barricade of yellow police tape in front of him and then a strange wide expanse of leveled earth beyond that, as if a bulldozer had suddenly pushed everything aside.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: Stewart surveys all of this, points toward a winding piece of concrete that looks like part of a freeway on-ramp and then shakes his head.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: ''It's all gone,'' he said in the cool afternoon air. ''The whole thing. Gone.''
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: For nearly two miles stretching east, there is little but rubble where the two-tiered Interstate 880 once stood. But staring down at him, its shadow growing longer as the sun drops, is the only thing remaining: a massive slab of the fallen freeway resting limply against an upright section of the structure, a reminder of what used to be and what had happened to change it.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: More than two months have passed since the Oct. 17 earthquake rattled northern California and sent the World Series into a 10-day holding pattern. But the memories are still strong for those who live in the Bay Area, including Stewart, the Oakland Athletics pitcher.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: In baseball history, Stewart will always be recalled as the pivotal performer in the A's four-game sweep of the San Francisco Giants, the winner of the first and fourth games and the most valuable player of the Series. In reality, he was one of the players affected most by the quake's resounding destruction, his nights spent driving to the Cypress structure to watch rescuers pull bodies from the rubble.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: Stewart still does not know what caused him to lay awake, then inexplicably visit the freeway site in the nights that followed the tremor. But he knows that it was his city that buckled, that few could feel the sense of loss and concern that he did.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: ''I'm born here; I'm raised here,'' he said one day last week. ''That's the difference. I wouldn't expect a player born in Mobile, Ala., and playing in Oakland to care as much as I do. Part of my character comes from this city. It's my roots.''
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: So as Oakland continues to rebuild, Stewart watches with special interest. He points to buildings ruined by the earthquake but also drives through areas that signal a rejuvenation of the city of more than 300,000: Jack London Square, the downtown area along Broadway, and old Oakland, where Victorian houses are being carefully restored.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: The double-decker 880 freeway was a part of Oakland, too, carrying commuters north and south in almost constant congestion. Stewart rode it to the Oakland Coliseum in the summer's early afternoons, then rode it home at night.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: ''My sister was supposed to be coming to the ball game at that time,'' he said, remembering the moment the earthquake struck, 5:04 P.M. Pacific time, about a half hour before the first pitch of Game 3. ''I had no clue what happened to her because there was no phone communication. If she'd been on time, she would have been a part of that damage. But she hadn't even left the house at 5 o'clock.''
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: Perhaps it was his familiarity with the devastated area - the fact he drove regularly on I-880, or the fact he spent idle hours in the neighborhood as a youth - that drew Stewart to Cypress Avenue for several nights afterward.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: ''I still don't have the slightest idea,'' he said. ''People have told me they think it was the security of knowing that people were out there working to get others out. I don't know.''
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: Stewart is more certain of his need to play a role in Oakland's revival. He willingly attends business functions that go toward helping the redevelopment of the community, he serves on the board of directors for the Oakland Boys Club and he speaks on behalf of the local Just Say No campaign against drugs. Equally important, he spends one week in early January calling more than a dozen schools throughout the Bay Area and addressing the drug problem with students.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: Stewart, who is 32 years old, said he has become keenly aware of Oakland's problem because, in part, it contrasts his own memories as a youngster, days when there were alternatives to crime and drugs.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: ''You see the amount of athletes to come out of this area, and you know it's because there were a lot of recreation and park facilities,'' he said. ''Now you take it 15, 20 years later, and there aren't as many opportunities for kids to develop. I built my self-esteem on the baseball fields. They don't have that anymore, and so they look to other avenues.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: ''Drugs aren't new; they've been here a long time. But people see them as a way to make money, and so they start selling marijuana in high school, then go on to bigger things.''
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: In Stewart's mind, the best way to solve the dilemma is to bring back playgrounds, programs and positive alternatives.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: In a significant way, Stewart has become Oakland's own ambassador. His pitching brings him notoriety, his community work satisfies a need to give back.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: He might be the city's best-known resident, even though he spends part of the winter in the southern California town of Claremont, east of Los Angeles. In his car, motoring through the suburbs and then back into downtown, strangers recognize Stewart and honk. He always waves back. ''A lot of people identify with me,'' he said. ''Being from Oakland, the comment that's made most often by people is that they appreciate what I'm doing for the community. They know I'm trying to do something about things, not just making my money and getting out.''
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: About money: Stewart, despite three consecutive 20-victory seasons with the A's, suddenly ranks as a baseball pauper, his $1.075 million salary running far behind the contracts signed recently by Mark Langston, Mark Davis, Robin Yount and his own teammate Rickey Henderson.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: But Stewart, who has one year remaining on his current pact, is in early negotiations with the A's on a two-year extension that could pay him $7 million.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: ''For me,'' he said, ''it's not a question of making more money. It's a matter of being recognized as the best. If I have to make more money than Mark Langston to be recognized as the best, then that's what I'll have to do.''
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: There has always seemed to be a shortage of recognition for the right-hander, who has never won the Cy Young Award and whose accomplishment in the post-season - becoming the first pitcher to go 2-0 in the league championship series and 2-0 in the World Series - was largely overlooked.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: ''Nobody talks about it,'' he said of his 4-0 streak, which gave him 25 victories for the season, ''but then it might be just another part of my career. I've gotten used to it.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: ''Yes, I've won 20 three times, but it's been my misfortune that somebody else has pitched as well or better and won the Cy Young. All I can do is pitch consistently. That's the thing people respect. Dependability. That's the best I can ask of myself.''
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: In Oakland, Stewart has been undeniably dependable. Now, when he looks at the streets, he sees a part of himself.
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: ''Heck, I grew up here,'' he said. ''This city isn't any different from any other city. There's drugs and crime, and people talk about wanting to move out, but I'm not that way. It's a good place to live. It's my home.''
title: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

text: What happened? Morning in America, hole in the ozone, Oliver North, AIDS, terrorists, contras like Founding Fathers, $640 toilet seats, triumph of democracy, just say no. 1980 It's America vs. the Soviet Union, Khomeini, Castro, inflation and Jimmy Carter.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: January: The U.S. embargoes grain and high-technology exports to the Soviet Union in retaliation for its occupation of Afghanistan at the end of 1979. President Carter warns that the U.S. might boycott the summer Olympics in Moscow.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: After criticizing Moscow's move into Afghanistan, Andrei D. Sakharov, the most prominent Soviet dissident, is arrested in Moscow and ordered into internal exile in the city of Gorky.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: February: In a sweeping inquiry into suspected bribe-taking and other corruption, 31 public officials, including a U.S. Senator and seven representatives, are reported to be subjects of an F.B.I. undercover operation called Abscam.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: March: A sniper kills the outspoken Archbishop of San Salvador, Oscar Arnulfo Romero. The country's polarization intensifies and soon turns into civil war.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: April: President Carter breaks relations with Iran after Islamic militants continue to hold American Embassy employees taken hostage in November 1979. A rescue mission fails.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: After 90 years of white rule, Rhodesia becomes the independent nation of Zimbabwe, led by an elected leader, Robert Mugabe.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: May: Fidel Castro allows a flood of Cubans to leave the port of Mariel for the United States. Mr. Carter welcomes them with ''open arms,'' but the mood changes after it becomes known that criminals and mentally ill people are included.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Mount St. Helens in Oregon blows its top, spewing steam and ash 60,000 feet in the air.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: August: Caving in after two weeks of crippling strikes, the Polish Government agrees to give workers the right to strike and form independent unions - the first time such a right has been granted in the Soviet bloc. The strikes were led by Lech Walesa, an electrician.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: September: Iraq, taking advantage of the turmoil in Iran to strike a blow against its hated neighbor, attacks Iranian oil and air fields, and war begins. In November oil prices reach $43 a barrel on the spot market, the 1980's peak, as Persian Gulf tanker traffic is threatened.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: October: Ronald Reagan, who capitalized on frustration over double-digit inflation, a gasoline crisis and the failure to rescue the hostages in his campaign for President, has the most memorable line in the debate with Mr. Carter: ''Are you better off than you were four years ago?''
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: November: Mr. Reagan wins in a landslide, carrying 43 states, and is the first candidate since Franklin D. Roosevelt to defeat an incumbent. The Democrats lose the Senate for the first time since 1954.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The world learns that Saturn has scores of rings, not six, from the spectacular pictures sent back by Voyager 1.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: In China, Deng Xiaoping enjoys the trial of his hard-line nemeses: Mao's widow, Jiang Qing, and other members of the Gang of Four.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: December: Three Roman Catholic nuns and a lay worker from the U.S. are murdered in El Salvador. Right-wing death squads are blamed. The U.S. halts new aid and calls for a reshuffling of the military-civilian Government. Jose Napoleon Duarte becomes its leader.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Violent deaths: Dr. Herman Tarnower (shot by Jean Harris); Anastasio Somoza Debayle, deposed Nicaraguan leader (shot in exile in Paraguay); John Lennon (shot by a disturbed fan). 1981 Enter Reagan, 'Dynasty' and brief notice of an unusual malady among homosexual men.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: January: ABC introduces ''Dynasty,'' a celebration of glamour and greed. It becomes a huge hit.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: On his last day in office, President Carter says an accord has been reached for releasing the hostages. Criticizing the deal, a Reagan adviser says, ''This Administration will not negotiate with barbarians or terrorists.''
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Mr. Reagan, sworn in as 40th President, promises an ''era of renewal,'' and warns of tremendous ''upheavals'' if the deficit continues to grow.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Minutes after his inauguration, the hostages are released, after 444 days in captivity.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: March: John W. Hinckley Jr. shoots President Reagan and his press secretary, James S. Brady, in Washington.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: May: Pope John Paul II is shot in St. Peter's Square by a Turkish terrorist.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: June: In what will later be recognized as the first official notice of AIDS, the Centers for Disease Control prints a short report on the ''unusual'' occurrence in five homosexual men in Los Angeles of a deadly form of pneumonia.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Baseball's first midseason strike begins. It lasts until July 31.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: ''We love your adherence to democratic principle,'' Vice President George Bush tells Ferdinand E. Marcos after the Philippine President's re-inauguration.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: July: Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer are married and for a brief time even the London tabloid press believes in fairy tales.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: In a masterly triumph for President Reagan, Congress approves the deepest tax and budget cuts in American history.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera of Panama is killed in a plane crash. In the struggle that follows, it is clear that Col. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the country's most feared figure, is the ultimate arbiter of power.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: August: MTV, cable television's first 24-hour music channel, goes on the air.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: President Reagan dismisses striking air traffic controllers, breaking their union and dealing a devastating blow to labor.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: September: Responding to cuts in the school lunch program, the Agriculture Department says ketchup can be counted as a vegetable. After an uproar, the President withdraws the plan.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The Senate raises the Federal debt limit to $1.08 trillion, the first time the ceiling is raised over the $1 trillion mark.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The Senate confirms Sandra Day O'Connor for the Supreme Court. She becomes the first woman to become a justice.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: October: Anwar el-Sadat is killed by Muslim militants. The Egyptian presidency passes to Hosni Mubarak.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: November: David A. Stockman, the White House budget director, pays ''a visit to the woodshed'' for statements undermining Administration policy that appeared in a magazine.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: December: After a year of unrest, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski declares martial law in Poland. Solidarity is outlawed, and Lech Walesa and other oppositionists will spend months or years in prison, or go underground. 1982 In a recession year, Dr. Koop and Jane Fonda are ascending, and stocks are up, too.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: January: The White House says it approves of giving tax-exempt status to Bob Jones University of South Carolina and other schools that are accused of racial discrimination.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: February: In his budget address, President Reagan calls for less social spending and a lot more military spending.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The Surgeon General, C. Everett Koop, calls smoking the most important health issue of the day and warns of the dangers of ''passive smoking'' - breathing someone else's tobacco fumes.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: April: Argentina's governing junta announces it has seized the Falkland Islands from Britain, which sends a flotilla of warships the next day.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: May: Jane Fonda's aerobic exercise book is a hit and the fitness craze goes into its ''no pain, no gain'' phase.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: June: Israel invades Lebanon in a campaign that will drive Yasir Arafat and the P.L.O. from their base in Lebanon, while failing to secure a friendly Christian government. Syria, not Israel, will eventually be the power broker in Lebanon.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The Government announces stiff penalties on steel imports in an attempt to help struggling American steelmakers.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: An estimated 750,000 people demonstrate against nuclear arms in Central Park in New York. The freeze movement becomes a cause celebre.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Argentina is humiliated by Britain and surrenders in the Falklands. The defeat hastens the demise of the military dictatorship.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The deadline passes for the Equal Rights Amendment, which falls three states short of the number needed for ratification.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: September: Bashir Gemayel, Lebanon's Israeli-backed President, is assassinated. After Israeli troops move into West Beirut, Christian militiamen massacre hundreds of Palestinians in the Sabra and Shatila refugee camps there.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Princess Grace of Monaco dies after an auto accident.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: October: President Reagan announces a war on drugs.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: John Z. Delorean is charged with cocaine trafficking and racketeering. Prosecutors say he was trying to raise money to save his automobile company. He is later acquitted. November: Recession and high unemployment help the Democrats pick up 26 seats in the House and seven governorships during the midterm elections.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The so-called Volcker recession reaches a painful climax when unemployment hits 10.8 percent in November, the highest since 1940. But interest rates have fallen, inflation is down and the stock market is bullish.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Leonid I. Brezhnev dies at 75. The Soviet leader's rule was marked by increasing stagnation and corruption and a huge military buildup. He is succeeded by Yuri V. Andropov, the former head of the K.G.B.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: A black granite memorial etched with the names of the 57,939 soldiers killed or missing in Vietnam is dedicated in Washington.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: December: Dr. Barney B. Clark becomes the first recipient of a permanent artificial heart, but dies less than four months later.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Congress approves the Boland Amendment, prohibiting the C.I.A. and Defense Department from financing the overthrow of the Nicaraguan Government. 1983 The 'evil empire' and 'Star Wars' appear and Grenada winds up the year, with hostilities between.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: January: Michael Jackson's ''Thriller'' joins the Billboard Top Ten, where it will stay for a year and a half, becoming the best-selling album in history.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: February: Under Congressional investigation for conflicts of interest and mismanagement, Rita M. Lavelle, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency's Superfund program to clean up toxic waste, is fired by President Reagan. A month later Anne McGill Burford, the E.P.A. Administrator, is forced to resign. Miss Lavelle later serves four months in prison for lying to Congress.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The final show of ''M*A*S*H'' displaces the ''Who Shot J.R.'' episode on ''Dallas'' as the most watched segment of a television series.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: March: Mr. Reagan tells an evangelical group that the Soviet Union is ''the focus of evil in the modern world'' and ''an evil empire.''
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Two weeks later, he proposes a space-based missile defense system and ''Star Wars'' is born.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The digital compact disk player makes its debut in American retail stores.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: April: Chicago elects its first black mayor, Harold Washington.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: May: In an 8-to-1 ruling, the Supreme Court decides that the Administration policy of granting tax exemptions to private schools that practice racial discrimination is illegal.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: June: In a smooth flight of the shuttle Challenger, Sally Ride becomes the first American woman in space.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: July: Economic recovery is gathering steam, with jumps in the gross national product and unemployment falling to under 10 percent.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: August: Benigno S. Aquino Jr., an archrival of Ferdinand E. Marcos, returns to the Philippines and is shot to death as he leaves the plane.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: September: Korean Air Lines Flight 007 is shot down by a Soviet fighter after it strays into Soviet air space; all 269 people on board are lost.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: October: Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt, who fought to open Federal lands to private drilling and other exploitation, quits in an uproar after he is heard describing members of a coal-leasing commission this way: ''I have a black, I have a woman, two Jews and a cripple.''
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Nancy Reagan, who is fighting an image as a maven of fashion and wealth, unveils a slogan for her anti-drug campaign: ''Just say no.''
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: A suicide terrorist in a truck full of explosives blows up the U.S. barracks in Beirut, killing 241 Americans, most of them marines on a peace-keeping mission.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The U.S. invades the Caribbean island of Grenada after a power struggle in the Marxist leadership turns bloody and, the U.S. says, threatens the lives of American medical students.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: November: ABC airs ''The Day After,'' a dramatization of a nuclear holocaust; afterward, Secretary of State George P. Shultz tells viewers that the movie does not represent the future ''at all.''
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Stores are running out of Cabbage Patch dolls, the latest rage in toys.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: December: A year and a half after its military rulers were disgraced in the Falkland war, Argentina returns to democracy with the swearing in of an elected civilian, Raul Alfonsin, as President. The move from military dictatorship to democracy sweeps South America.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: In a new twist on Japan's penetration of the U.S. auto market, Washington decides that General Motors and Toyota can jointly build Japanese-designed cars at a California plant without violating antitrust laws. 1984 Yuppies and Bernhard Goetz become news; bad foreign news includes Ethiopia and Bhopal.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: January: In response to a court order, A. T. & T. is broken up into seven regional companies.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: February: Yuri Andropov dies after only 15 months in power; Konstantin U. Chernenko, a doddering Brezhnev loyalist, takes over.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: March: The word ''yuppie'' becomes part of public discourse, often used to describe the young, upwardly mobile supporters of Gary Hart, a Democratic Presidential candidate.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: April: Dr. Robert Gallo of the National Cancer Institute announces that his team has shown a new virus to be the cause of AIDS. Outraged French researchers say they had previously discovered the virus and linked it to AIDS. Later the two groups agree to share credit.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: May: The Government rescues the nation's eighth largest bank, Continental Illinois, a victim of bad loans.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: In Salvadoran presidential elections, Mr. Duarte beats Roberto D'Aubuisson, an ultra-rightist linked to death squads.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: June: Bruce Springsteen's ''Born in the U.S.A.'' hits the Top Ten, and politicians steal its best lines.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: September: NBC trounces the competition with the premieres of two shows. ''Miami Vice'' makes network television seem avant-garde, and ''The Cosby Show'' becomes a fixture.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: October: Doctors transplant the heart of a baboon into a 12-day-old infant known as Baby Fae. She dies 20 days later. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India is murdered by two bodyguards, both Sikhs. More than a thousand people, mostly Sikhs, are killed in the ensuing sectarian violence. Her son, Rajiv, is elected two months later.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: November: President Reagan and Vice President Bush win in a landslide over Walter Mondale and Geraldine Ferraro, the first woman nominated for vice president on a major-party ticket.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: A heart-rending BBC news clip on the Ethiopian famine airs on NBC, finally focusing American attention on the vast tragedy.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History
