text: December: Bell Laboratories says it has perfected a one-megabit chip, which can store an unprecedented amount of information on a tiny piece of silicon.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: December: Toxic fumes from a Union Carbide insecticide plant kill more than 3,000 people in Bhopal, India.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Britain and China sign an agreement transferring the colony of Hong Kong to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Madonna begins her ascent to pop culture's pinnacle when ''Like a Virgin'' zooms to No. 1 on the charts.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: U.S. leaves Unesco, calling the United Nations agency wasteful and anti-democratic.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: In a case that stirs debate on crime and civil liberties, Bernhard H. Goetz, who is white, shoots and wounds four teen-age boys - all black - who he says were trying to rob him on a New York subway. Mr. Goetz later serves eight months on a gun charge. 1985 The year the Soviet Union gets a new leader, an agriculture expert named Mikhail Gorbachev.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: January: In his second Inaugural Address, Mr. Reagan says the nation is ''poised for greatness.''
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: February: Two Senators reveal that the Navy paid $640 each for toilet seats. An investigation of defense contracting uncovers widespread fraud.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: March: Mr. Reagan, in a bid to win military aid for the Nicaragua contras, calls them the ''moral equals of our Founding Fathers.'' A few months later, Congress bars use of American aid for arms and ammunition, setting the stage for White House efforts to supply the contras in secret.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: British scientists report a giant ''hole'' opening in the ozone layer over Antarctica each spring. The thinning of protective ozone is later linked to chlorofluorocarbons and other products.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Capital Cities Communications buys ABC -the first takeover of a television network. In December General Electric acquires RCA Corporation, owner of NBC, and in 1986 Laurence A. Tisch takes over CBS, which fought off a bid by Ted Turner.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: After the death of Mr. Chernenko, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a 54-year-old agricultural specialist with no experience in foreign affairs, becomes the Soviet leader. He promises to follow in the path of his predecessors.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: April: Coca-Cola says it is replacing its 99-year-old formula for Coke, the world's best-selling soft drink, with a new one. But the public protest is so great that the company brings back the ''old'' Coke as ''Coke Classic.''
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: May: In West Germany, Mr. Reagan visits the Berlin wall, a concentration camp and, to a chorus of dismay at home, a cemetery at Bitburg where 49 Waffen SS officers are buried.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: June: Mr. Gorbachev indirectly criticizes his predecessors and calls for sweeping economic changes.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Shiite Muslim extremists hijack a T.W.A. airliner. A U.S. Navy diver is killed in the 17-day standoff.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Karen Ann Quinlan, who has been at the center of the ''right to die'' debate, dies in New Jersey. Courts had allowed removal of the comatose woman's respirator in 1976, but she lived nine more years.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: July: Mr. Reagan undergoes surgery for colon cancer. His doctors say his recovery is ''spectacular.''
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: A marathon rock concert, Live Aid, raises $70 million for starving Africans.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Summer: Depressed farm prices and high debt focus attention on the plight of the American small farmer. Many farmers are forced to give up their farms in the mid-1980's.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: September: Pete Rose passes Ty Cobb's 4,191 career hits.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: A quake measuring 7.8 on the Richter scale causes devastation in and around Mexico City. More than 5,000 people die.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: October: Palestinian terrorists seize an Italian cruise ship, the Achille Lauro, in the eastern Mediterranean, and kill an American, Leon Klinghoffer.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Rock Hudson, 59, dies of AIDS, forcing the new disease into public consciousness.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: November: A volcano eruption in Colombia kills 25,000 people.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: In the largest civil judgment ever, Texaco is told to pay $10.53 billion in damages to the Pennzoil Company. Pennzoil had charged that Texaco induced the Getty Oil Company to back out of a deal to merge with Pennzoil and accept Texaco's offer of a higher price. 1986 Americans witness disaster (the space shuttle) and the birth of two interesting scandals.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: January: Scientists at I.B.M. laboratories in Zurich discover a material that is superconducting, able to carry electricity without resistance, at temperatures much higher than ever before. Their discovery, quietly published in a European journal, sets off furious international competition to improve on the new materials and grandiose dreams of levitating trains and cheap energy, but commercial applications remain elusive.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Martin Luther King Day is observed for the first time.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The shuttle Challenger explodes, killing all seven aboard, including Christa McAuliffe, a teacher. The space program comes to a halt.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: February: Jean-Claude Duvalier of Haiti flees into exile, ending his family's 28-year dictatorship. Violence blocks steps toward democracy.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: In the Philippines, President Marcos is forced into exile after he tries to steal the election from Corazon C. Aquino. Riding the crest of ''people power,'' she becomes President.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: April: The U.S. bombs Libya after President Reagan blames Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi for an attack on American soldiers in West Berlin.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Tears flow when Vladimir Horowitz performs in the Soviet Union, which he left in 1925. Under Mr. Gorbachev's glasnost, Soviet intellectual life has begun to flower.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: A reactor at the Chernobyl nuclear plant in the Soviet Ukraine explodes, spreading a cloud of radioactive debris. The Soviets do not acknowledge the disaster until after high radiation is reported in Scandinavia.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: June: Len Bias, a top college basketball player, dies of a cocaine overdose.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: July: Oil prices bottom out at $7.20 a barrel.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: August: Lethal gas erupts from a volcanic lake in Cameroon, killing some 1,500 people.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: A surrogate mother, Mary Beth Whitehead, goes to court in an unsuccessful attempt to keep the baby girl - known as Baby M - whom she agreed to carry to term for $10,000. The father, William Stern, and his wife later retain custody.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: September: The Senate confirms William H. Rehnquist as Chief Justice and Antonin Scalia as an associate justice of the Supreme Court.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Congress overrides Mr. Reagan's veto of sanctions against South Africa. The United States and Europe act after Pretoria declares a state of emergency because of unrest.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Mergers and economic troubles disrupt the airline industry, which is still adjusting to the new age of deregulation. Frank Lorenzo of Texas Air announces a deal to acquire People Express.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Congress overhauls the tax system, changing brackets and eliminating many deductions.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: October: The rapid spread of crack prompts Congress to pass new anti-drug legislation.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: At a summit meeting in Iceland, Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev come startlingly close to agreeing on deep limits in nuclear arsenals.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: November: A Beirut magazine reports that the U.S. sent spare parts and ammunition to Iran. A subsequent investigation reveals that other arms sales were made to Iran and the profits were diverted to the Nicaraguan contras, and the Iran-contra scandal is born.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Portending the end of a free-wheeling era in finance, the insider trading scandal climaxes with news that Ivan Boesky agreed to pay $100 million and plead guilty to a criminal count, and aided prosecutors by taping his conversations. Other indictments follow, including that of Michael R. Milken, the junk bond king at Drexel Burnham Lambert, who is awaiting trial.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: December: Mr. Gorbachev calls Andrei Sakharov to tell him he is free to leave Gorky, where he has been in internal exile. 1987 The stock market crash, and Robert H. Bork's Supreme Court nomination; the intifada begins.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: January: The nation's first trillion-dollar budget is proposed by President Reagan.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: February: Signaling a worsening debt problem, Brazil, the third world's largest debtor nation, suspends interest payments on loans from foreign banks.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: April: In a field near Monterey, Calif., scientists spray a strawberry patch with bacteria to prevent frost, the first experimental release of genetically altered bacteria in the United States.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: June: Margaret Thatcher is re-elected, becoming the first British Prime Minister in the 20th century to win three consecutive terms.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: July: Three Congressmen bash a Toshiba radio with sledgehammers on Capitol Hill after revelations that Toshiba sold sensitive technology to the Soviets.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Millions watch the testimony of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North during the Congressional inquiry into the Iran-contra affair. He is later convicted of destroying Government documents among other charges, He is sentenced to community service and fined.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: August: Five Central American countries sign an accord intended to resolve the region's conflicts. Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica will win the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: September: In a victory for the global environment, many nations agree in Montreal to protect the ozone layer by phasing out chlorofluorcarbons and other chemicals.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: October: The stock market crashes. The 22.6 percent plunge in the Dow Jones Industrial Average is the largest one-day decline since 1914.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The Senate rejects Mr. Reagan's nomination of Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court; critics say he is insensitive to individual rights and liberties and supporters see an unfair campaign against him. A second nominee, Douglas Ginsburg, will withdraw after acknowledging that he smoked marijuana. A third nominee, Anthony M. Kennedy, will be confirmed.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: December: At the White House, President Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev sign a treaty to eliminate the superpowers' medium-range intermediate nuclear forces.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Rioting breaks out in the Israeli occupied territory of Gaza after a truck driven by an Israeli kills four people near a Palestinian refugee camp. Unrest spreads to the West Bank. The intifada - or uprising - begins. 1988 Politics takes up the year, and there is a time when it doesn't look good for George Bush.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: February: Federal grand juries in Miami and Tampa indict Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, charging that he protected and assisted the Medellin drug cartel. The United States tries to oust him with economic and military pressures.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: March: Jesse Jackson's upset victory in the Michigan Democratic caucuses is the first triumph by a black Presidential candidate in a big state, establishing him as a serious contender for the nomination.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: April: Pakistan and Afghanistan sign agreements in Geneva calling for the withdrawal of Soviet troops.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: As safety in the sky and aging aircraft fleets become concerns, a gaping hole opens in the fuselage of a 19-year-old Aloha Airlines Boeing 737 over Hawaii, sweeping a stewardess to her death.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: May: On the last day illegal aliens can apply for amnesty under a new immigration law, more than 100,000 people rush to submit applications, which could lead to legal status and eventual citizenship. In all, nearly 1.4 million illegal aliens seek amnesty.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: June: Congress approves legislation aimed at protecting the disabled and the elderly against catastrophic health costs. A year later the program is repealed after an outcry from elderly people who objected to paying the surcharge.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: George Steinbrenner fires Billy Martin, ending Mr. Martin's fifth term as Yankee manager.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: July: A missile fired by a U.S. Navy cruiser in the Persian Gulf destroys an Iranian airliner, killing 290 people. Navy crewmen say they thought the plane was an Iranian jet fighter.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Iran and Iraq agree to a cease-fire in the eight-year war.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: After his nomination as the Democratic Presidential candidate, polls show Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts with a double-digit lead over Vice President Bush, who awaits the Republican nomination in August.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: August: In Pakistan, President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq and the United States Ambassador are killed in a plane crash, apparently an act of sabotage. Three months later Benazir Bhutto, Zia's sworn enemy, becomes president.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: October: RJR Nabisco is bought by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. At a price of $24.9 billion, it is the largest leveraged buyout ever.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: November: After the campaign in which he pledges not to raise taxes - ''Read my lips'' -George Bush is elected the 41st President, with 56 percent of the popular vote.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: December: An earthquake measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale devastates Soviet Armenia, killing an estimated 25,000 people.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Pan Am Flight 103 explodes over Lockerbie, Scotland, killing 270 people. Investigators say a bomb was in the luggage compartment. 1989 The wall falls and freedom spreads at a dizzying pace, despite a setback in China.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: January: George Bush is sworn in as the 41st President. In his Inaugural Address, he calls for ''a new engagement in the lives of others.''
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: February: Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, Paraguay's leader since 1954, is ousted and sent into exile.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: A 20-year-old man is the last person to be shot trying to escape across the Berlin wall. The last Soviet troops leave Afghanistan. Ayatollah Khomeini denounces the novel ''Satanic Verses'' as blasphemy and calls for the execution of the author, Salman Rushdie.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: March: Time Inc. and Warner Communications announce a merger that creates the world's largest media conglomerate, with interests in books, magazines, television, cable and movies.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: For the first time in 70 years, the Soviet people are given a choice of competing candidates. The winners make up part of the new Congress.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The tanker Exxon Valdez strikes a reef in Prince William Sound in Alaska, resulting in one of the worst oil spills in history.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: April: Thousands of Chinese students mourn the death of Hu Yaobang, a deposed reformist leader. The protests grow, and students camp out in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: After a year of unrest, the Polish Government legalizes Solidarity and sets elections. Lech Walesa and General Jaruzelski shake hands.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: May: General Noriega engineers a fraudulent election, and his forces beat up oppositionists.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: In a reflection of Washington's new concern over Congressional ethics, House Speaker Jim Wright announces he is resigning after a long-running dispute over a lucrative book deal.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: June: The Chinese military, on orders from Deng, launches a savage assault on the demonstrators in Tiananmen Square, killing an unknown number and crushing dissent.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Ayatollah Khomeini dies; his funeral turns into pandemonium as frenzied mourners try to kiss his corpse.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Poland's first free election since the Communists took over brings overwhelming victory for Solidarity. In August, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a Walesa associate, will become Prime Minister in a Government with the Communists. In Hungary, Imre Nagy, the leader of the 1956 uprising, is given a hero's reburial.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Testimony in Congress paints a lurid picture of influence-peddling and political favoritism in the Department Housing and Urban Development.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The Supreme Court decides flag burning is protected by the First Amendment, causing a political uproar.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: July: By 5 to 4, the Supreme Court rules that states can put new restraints on a woman's right to have an abortion, though it does not overturn Roe v. Wade.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: August: After gunmen kill a popular politician, Colombia declares war on drug traffickers. The next month, Mr. Bush declares war on drugs in a strategy that emphasizes law enforcement.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Congress passes a 10-year $166 billion package to rescue foundering savings and loans.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: President P. W. Botha of South Africa is pushed aside, and F. W. de Klerk succeeds him. Mr. de Klerk promises change but opponents of apartheid press him to move faster.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Pete Rose, the Cincinnati Reds coach, is banned from baseball after a 225-page report chronicles his gambling activities.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: September: Vietnam says its forces have left Cambodia, 10 years after occupying the country. The withdrawal creates fears that civil war will explode and that the dreaded Khmer Rouge may fight their way to power.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Hungary opens its border with Austria to allow the exit of East Germans gathered at the West German Embassy in Budapest.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Hurricane Hugo devastates part of the Caribbean and the Carolinas.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The Sony Corporation, which had acquired CBS Records in 1988, buys Columbia Pictures.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: October: As a World Series game is about to begin, San Francisco suffers an earthquake measuring 7.1 on the Richter scale. Sixty-seven people die, many of them in the collapse of a freeway.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: As East Germany celebrates its 40th anniversary, huge protests break out and thousands of refugees flood routes to the West. By the end of the month, Erich Honecker is out as party chief.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The Hungarian Communist Party changes its name and Parliament decides to allow a multiparty system, with elections in 1990.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The Rockefeller Group, owner of Rockefeller Center, Radio City Music Hall and other mid-Manhattan office buildings, sells control of the company to the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Tokyo for $846 million in cash.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: November: After defeating Mayor Edward I. Koch in the primary, David N. Dinkins becomes the first black to be elected mayor of New York.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: East Germany opens the Berlin wall, on which ecstatic Berliners dance and drink champagne. In Czechoslovakia, demonstrations force the Communist Party to cede its absolute power. A vote in Hungary forces revision of the party's schedule for elections, and in Bulgaria a Stalinist leader, Todor Zhivkov, is forced out.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: December: President Aquino of the Philippines survives a coup attempt, thanks in large part to American military assistance.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Upheaval continues in East Germany, where revelations of corruption at the highest level disgrace Mr. Honecker and force his successor, Egon Krenz, to step down.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: For the first time since 1970, Chileans freely elect a new leader, Patricio Aylwin, and the Pinochet era ends. In the first direct elections for President in Brazil since 1964, Fernando Collor de Mello, a free-market crusader, wins.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: Andrei Sakharov, at 68, dies of a heart attack after a grueling day in the Soviet Congress; Mr. Gorbachev laments the loss of ''a man of conviction and sincerity.''
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: After a U.S. serviceman is shot by Panamanian forces, the United States invades Panama, asserting a right to protect citizens and defend the canal. General Noriega flees into hiding and a new President is sworn in on a U.S. base. Chaos consumes the country as thousands of American troops struggle to establish control.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: In Rumania, the last holdout against reform in the East bloc, angry crowds of pro-democracy demonstrators, backed by some army units, force the hard-line leader, Nicolae Ceausescu, to flee Bucharest. Thousands are reported to have been killed in unrest days earlier; fighting continues between rival security forces.
title: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's; Selections From 10 Years of History

text: The owner of a pit bull that mauled a 2-year-old boy to death was acquitted of second-degree murder today but found guilty of involuntary manslaughter and other lesser charges.
title: Manslaughter Verdict In Mauling by Pit Bull

text: The case was the first in the nation in which a person was charged with murder for the actions of his dog, although there had previously been a similar manslaughter conviction.
title: Manslaughter Verdict In Mauling by Pit Bull

text: Today's verdict, by a jury in Santa Clara County Superior Court, means that the 39-year-old defendant, Michael Berry, could be sent to prison for up to four years and eight months when he is sentenced in January.
title: Manslaughter Verdict In Mauling by Pit Bull

text: Mr. Berry's 53-pound dog attacked the child, James Soto, after the boy had wandered into Mr. Berry's yard one day two years ago.
title: Manslaughter Verdict In Mauling by Pit Bull

text: The Soto family was awarded damages of $3.5 million in a civil suit earlier this year.
title: Manslaughter Verdict In Mauling by Pit Bull

text: According to testimony at the criminal trial, Mr. Berry had chained the dog in his yard as protection for 243 marijuana plants.
title: Manslaughter Verdict In Mauling by Pit Bull

text: A former president of the Indianapolis League of Women Voters and her two sons were led to court in chains today, two years after they were charged with running a large marijuana-smuggling ring.
title: From Women's League to Chains

text: Less than 24 hours after their extradition from Austria, the woman, Linda Leary, and her sons, Richard and Paul Heilbrunn, appeared before Federal Magistrate John P. Godich. Afterward they returned to the Marion County Jail to await a hearing on Friday. Judge Godich is to rule then on a Government request to hold the three without bond until their trial, scheduled for Feb. 13.
title: From Women's League to Chains

text: Before leaving the United States in 1985 the 58-year-old Mrs. Leary had been president of the Indianapolis League of Women Voters and the local chapter of the National Council of Jewish Women.
title: From Women's League to Chains

text: Paul Heilbrunn, 35, was a commodities broker and columnist for a local business journal. His 38-year-old brother lived with his wife and two children on a farm outside Indianapolis. #34 People Were Indicted Mrs. Leary and her two sons were among 34 people charged in a 1987 indictment with smuggling at least 250,000 pounds of marijuana in Indiana, California, Connecticut, Washington, Alabama, Mississippi, Georgia, South Carolina, Florida, Michigan and Virginia. The three were arrested in May in Austria under the International Convention of Narcotics. There is no extradition agreement between the United States and Austria.
title: From Women's League to Chains

text: Of the remaining 31 people indicted, 20 have been convicted, two are in police custody awaiting trial, 5 are at large, charges against 2 have been dismissed and 2 have been acquitted.
title: From Women's League to Chains

text: Paul Heilbrunn's lawyer, Linda Pence, said the three would probably agree to waive formal arraignment because they had previously pleaded not guilty to the charges.
title: From Women's League to Chains

text: Ms. Leary is charged with 12 counts, including conspiracy to distribute marijuana, money laundering and interstate transportation in aid of racketeering. She could be sentenced to 30 years in prison.
title: From Women's League to Chains

text: Paul Heilbrunn is charged with 26 counts, including conspiracy to import and distribute marijuana and running a continuing criminal enterprise. He faces possible life imprisonment.
title: From Women's League to Chains

text: Richard Heilbrunn is charged with nine counts, and faces a maximum sentence of 60 years in prison.
title: From Women's League to Chains

text: The authorities say Paul Heilbrunn and an escapee from a Florida prison led the marijuana-smuggling ring. Richard Heilbrunn was one of three lieutenants under the two partners, said Assistant United States Attorney Jack Thar. Ms. Leary helped manage money laundered by dummy companies in the Bahamas and Panama, he said.
title: From Women's League to Chains

text: Just after midnight, exhausted after another day of tramping the streets, Kevin Williams was killing time aboard a Brooklyn-bound No. 4 subway train. There were a handful of other passengers, including three young women talking together in the seats opposite him. Mr. Williams, who is 28 years old and homeless, fought back the urge to stretch out.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: ''If you're lying down, everyone knows you're homeless,'' Mr. Williams said. ''I don't want people judging me and looking down at me. And I never lie down when there are young women on the car.''
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: It is impossible to know how many homeless men and women are on the city's streets, but on Monday night, when the temperature fell to 16 degrees, Mr. Williams belonged to a group whose number advocates estimate at from 40,000 to 60,000.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: As it has in years past, the number of people in city shelters is expected to grow in the coming months. Last winter the number peaked at 11,061 on March 19. On Monday night, more than 9,000 men and women spent the night in public shelters, some in cavernous armories where hundreds of people slept in rows of beds with their shoes on to guard against thieves. Another 1,300 men and women spent the night in small shelters in churches and synagogues run by volunteers from the Partnership for the Homeless.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: The rest sought refuge in subway cars and in public spaces and on the streets, with only blankets and strips of plywood and cardboard boxes between them and the wind. There were people on the plaza under the Brooklyn Bridge, on the heating grates across from the United Nations, on the sidewalk outside housing court in Lower Manhattan. Others tried to sleep sitting up on the wooden benches of the Staten Island Ferry Terminal, on benches on the malls in the middle of Upper Broadway, on the tile floor of a bank lobby on East 86th Street.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: There were no reports of homeless people freezing to death on the streets Monday night. But three men and a woman died on subway trains, platforms and underground passages Saturday and Sunday, when it was even colder. Two men died of hypothermia and a third man burned to death after he set himself on fire with the hot plate that was apparently his only source of warmth. The cause of death of the fourth victim, an elderly woman, is still undetermined.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: For Mr. Williams the night began in the usual way, waiting in a noisy school gymnasium near Grand Central Terminal with 300 other homeless men for his dinner - spiced ham and cheese on a kaiser roll, an apple, milk and juice from the Coalition for the Homeless.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: It was 7:45. The midtown church where he usually eats breakfast and lunch and puts in volunteer duty serving meals and cleaning up is closed on Mondays. Mr. Williams, a thin man with a wispy beard and a crooked smile, said he had spent the day in a library in Crown Heights. Did Time on Rikers Island
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: ''I was reading my Bible,'' said Mr. Williams, who has been homeless for two years.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: He pulled the Bible out of the small canvas bag that also held a comb and a flip top can of tunafish that Mr. Williams said he had been given at a soup kitchen in Brooklyn.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: Mr. Williams said he was raised by his mother in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, one of five brothers and sisters. He said he had received his GED high school degree in 1980.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: ''I was going to go to college for accounting,'' he said. ''But I never signed up.''
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: He said he had worked as a file clerk in an abortion clinic and then at a series of construction jobs.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: Mr. Williams, like many young men on the street, said he had been jailed on Rikers Island. He said he had recently served about two years on several different charges, which he said included the sale of marijuana and possession of a gun. 'I Got God With Me Now'
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: ''I'm striving,'' he said. ''I got wrapped up in the wrong situation. I used to mess with crack. My drug situation caused me a lot of problems.''
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: An alert, sober Mr. Williams added: ''Two months ago I just stopped. I said, 'Lord, there's got to be a better way than this.' I got God with me now.''
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: He said he had spent four months at the Atlantic Armory Men's Shelter in Brooklyn, where on Monday night 988 men slept. ''I regret every bit of it,'' he said of his time in the shelter. ''It's too wild. Most of the guys are on drugs.''
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: Now, Mr. Williams said, he prefers to take his chances on the street. Some 25 homeless men and women on the street and in public spaces who were interviewed randomly Monday night all said they were there because they found the shelters too frightening, too overwhelming or too regimented. Advocates for the homeless have been directing similar criticism at city shelters for years. 'Like Being Incarcerated'
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: ''They treat you like a dog,'' said Irving Beane, 34, who was inside Pennsylvania Station. ''It's like being incarcerated.''
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: ''We've been through the system,'' said a man in blue jeans and a woolen cap who was with about 18 others under the Brooklyn Bridge. ''That's why we're here.''
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: Two other disaffected refugees from the shelter system, who gave their names as Harry and Suzanne, rested on blankets inside the lobby of the Citibank building on 86th Street and Lexington Avenue.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: ''The people who tell me to go sleep in a shelter, I just want to say, 'You go sleep in a shelter!' '' said Suzanne, who says she has AIDS. ''It's like Ebenezer Scrooge saying, 'Are there no poorhouses?' It's the same thing, 150 years later.'' Free Concert in Grand Central
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: At 8:15 P.M., about 40 blocks south, Mr. Williams walked the two blocks to Grand Central Terminal to listen to the free music, as he said he does most nights now. He took a seat on the plywood stage that stands beneath the Kodak color photograph of the Manhattan skyline at night. Other than the floor, the stage was the only place in the terminal where Mr. Williams or any other homeless person could sit down. Only passengers holding tickets are allowed on the six benches in the waiting area upstairs.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: Mr. Williams gave his full attention to the New York City Brass Opera, which was performing jazzy renditions of Christmas carols. ''They're my favorite group,'' he said. ''I love music. I write gospel songs myself.'' All around him, commuters hurried to catch their trains, carrying briefcases and bags of takeout coffee and pastries for the ride home.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: As the hours passed, dozens of homeless people wandered through the terminal. Mr. Williams said many were waiting for 11 P.M., when he said the transit police change shifts and it is easier to slip onto the subway platform. Homeless people are not allowed to sleep in the terminal, which closes at 1:30 A.M. 'Helping People in Need'
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: ''You got anything to eat?'' an old man with a gray beard asked Mr. Williams, who gave him his can of tunafish.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: Mr. Williams opened the inspirational pamphlet a passer-by had given him earlier and found the part advising readers to write down their dreams. On a piece of paper, he wrote:
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: ''Money - $10,000 (''It's for my mother - she's sick,'' he explained); Home - 3 rooms with 19 inch color TV, record player, couch - brown and beige; Peace with God and self; Love for my fellowman; A job helping people in need.''
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: At a little after 11 P.M., Mr. Williams got on the Brooklyn-bound No. 5 train. He planned to get off at the Wall Street stop, where he said he has been sleeping for the last month or so on a bench at the far end of the platform. A Bench of His Own
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: ''I rode the trains for awhile,'' he said. ''One night when the train got to Wall Street I said, 'It's empty here.' So I got off, and it was warm. I laid down on the bench and slept and the next night I went back. It's my bench. I've got to be in an area where there are very few other guys sleeping. I don't want any crackheads wandering around, looking me over to see if I've got something they can take.''
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: At the Wall Street stop, Mr. Williams got off. But on this night he would not be getting to sleep when he had hoped. Transit workers were cleaning the station, hosing down the platform with disinfectant.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: ''It's going to take them at least two hours,'' Mr. Williams said. ''They do it once a week, but they switch days.''
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: During the next two hours, Mr. Williams rode the No. 4 train, uptown to 125th Street, then to Brooklyn, and back to Manhattan. At 1:45 A.M. he returned to Wall Street. The station was deserted, except for the cleaners who were still working. He chose another bench, where they had finished. He wiped the bench with a tissue, took his shoes off and put them at the edge of the bench near the wall. Pulling the hood of his thin blue windbreaker over his head and face to block out the bright lights, he laid down.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: In four hours, he would be up, on his way to the Lamb's Church of the Nazarene, on West 44th Street, where he would help serve breakfast to other homeless people.
title: Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City

text: By John H. Cushman Jr., Special To the New York Times
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: Millions of privately employed transportation workers are about to join the swelling roster of people who are routinely tested for illegal drug use, fueling debate about whether random drug tests are an unwarranted invasion of privacy.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: The Transportation Department, which drafted new testing rules last year, expects their advent to provide startling evidence about the extent of illegal drug use, and also expects the courts to rule that safety considerations compensate for any infringement of civil liberties.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: Nearly four million transportation workers will face drug tests for the first time beginning Monday, when the rules governing more than half a million people in aviation take hold. In coming days, the rules will begin to affect mass-transit workers, commercial mariners, interstate bus and truck drivers, railroad workers and pipeline workers.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: The Transportation Department has tested its own employees for illegal drug use for two years, in a program that affects 32,000 people, mostly air traffic controllers. The military uses drug tests extensively, as do other Federal agencies and some industries. Fewer Tests Are Positive
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: The results vary widely. When the Coast Guard, along with other military forces, began random testing of its personnel, Transportation Department officials said as many as 10 percent of the service's members used drugs. Now, with the deterrence of testing in place, Coast Guard tests find only 1 percent or 2 percent drug use. The Federal Aviation Administration has found even lower drug use, about a half of 1 percent, in random tests of its employees.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: ''I think we're going to see an alarming amount of drug usage and positive testing in safety-related jobs,'' said Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, ''and I think that will just demonstrate why the program is so necessary, and why it's a top priority.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: ''I have been told by some very knowledgeable people who operate rail properties, for instance, mass-transit properties, that they expect a significant usage rate once the random testing begins.''
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: The most notable feature of the new drug testing program is its requirement for random testing of employees in safety-related jobs. But the rules also call for drug tests to be administered in several other circumstances: before employment, after accidents, when there is reason to suspect drug use, and at fixed intervals, like when pilots take mandatory semiannual medical examinations.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: The tests are meant to detect the use of marijuana, cocaine, opiates, amphetamines and phencyclidine, or PCP. Sampling urine, not blood, the tests do not detect the use of alcohol or prescription medications.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: Anybody whose work is related to transportation safety can expect to be tested. For example, the aviation industry will test pilots, flight engineers, navigators, aircraft dispatchers, mechanics, flight attendants, security guards and instructors.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: Employers will collect the urine samples, which will be analyzed by federally licensed laboratories, at a cost of tens of millions of dollars each year to the companies. Half of any company's employees should be tested each year. Unions Fight the Tests
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: Unions representing the workers who will be tested have been fighting the tests in court for a year. About two dozen lawsuits, consolidated into six cases, are under consideration by lower courts, and the challenges appear likely to be resolved ultimately by the United States Supreme Court.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: So far, the Court has not ruled definitively on the question of Government-ordered random drug testing of private-sector workers. But its recent rulings in other drug testing cases concerning Justice Department employees and railroad workers, along with several subsequent decisions by lower courts, suggest that the tide is running in favor of tests.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: Politicians and the public also appear to support expanded testing. The Bush Administration has repeatedly endorsed widespread drug testing as a cornerstone of its fight against drugs.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: A poll released last week by a group of corporations that are members of the Institute for a Drug-Free Workplace suggested that employees in the private sector are fairly tolerant of the prospect of drug testing. The poll was based on telephone interviews with 1,000 adult workers across the country, conducted by telephone in November. The Gallup Organization said the margin of sampling error was plus or minus 3 percentage points.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: Fifty-three percent of those questioned by the Gallup Organization said they support random testing in the workplace. More than 97 percent said some form of drug testing at work is appropriate under some circumstances. Ninety-four percent said they thought it a good idea to test pilots, and 91 percent favored testing truck drivers. Safety Board Disagrees
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: Not all safety officials agree. The National Transportation Safety Board considers drug and alcohol tests after accidents to be an important investigative tool, but has opposed random testing, saying there is not enough evidence of widespread drug abuse to justify the invasion of privacy. But the board's acting chairman, James Kolstad, favors random testing.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: Even the Federal Aviation Administration, in proposing its new rules, has said that drug use is neither ''widespread'' nor ''overwhelming'' in the aviation industry. But the agency, which is part of the Transportation Department, said there is ''concrete evidence'' of drug use in commercial aviation, including occasional cases of accidents involving drugs.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: Richard B. Stone, the executive chairman for aeromedical resources of the Air Line Pilots Association, a national union, said the union's experience suggests there is relatively little illegal drug use among its members.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: ''We have been watching with trained peers and company supervisors and F.A.A. officials for those kinds of problems,'' he said. ''We run across them, but almost always purely alcohol. We have a good handle on it, and we don't see much evidence of it in our group. We just think pilots are different.'' Successful Rehabilitation
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: In the first two years of the F.A.A.'s random testing of its employees, more than 20,000 tests were conducted and only 118 people, or half of 1 percent, were confirmed as having used drugs. Most of them successfully completed rehabilitation and are back at work.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: The Transportation Department, in cooperation with the Department of Health and Human Services, has imposed elaborate requirements to ensure that the results of drug tests are valid. One technique is to split urine samples into two containers so each can be independently tested. Another is to check up on the performance of testing laboratories by sending in a small number of urine samples known to be ''blank'' or ''spiked'' with drugs.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: For the pilots union, one of the major worries about the new testing is that many airlines, unlike Federal agencies, appear not to be offering any treatment to those who test positive. Once drug abuse is confirmed, through follow-up testing and personal interviews, drug users will simply be fired. 'We Have Seen the Steamroller'
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: Mr. Stone said the union, which is awaiting a ruling from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, has little hope that the new rules will be rejected by the courts.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: ''We have seen the steamroller coming,'' he said. ''The random testing is here. We are going to get it on Dec. 18.''
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: Most of the court challenges have sought to overturn the drug testing rules under the Fourth Amendment to the Constitution, which prohibits unwarranted searches. One challenge has met with initial success. A Federal District Court in San Francisco enjoined the use of random and post-accident drug tests on interstate truckers, in a case which the Government appealed. The new rules affect three million interstate truck and bus drivers, who despite the injunction will still be subjected to pre-employment tests and to tests when employers have probable cause for suspecting drug abuse.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: But in two important drug testing cases earlier this year, neither involving random testing, the Supreme Court held that safety considerations can outweigh the privacy rights of individuals. The cases involved testing of Customs Service employees and of railroad employees involved in accidents.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: Since the Supreme Court's rulings, lower courts have on five occasions ruled in favor of random drug testing, in cases involving police officers, prison guards, Justice Department employees with top secret security clearances, and nuclear plant workers.
title: Private Transportation Workers to Join Ranks of Those Tested for Drug Use

text: DRIVING THE SIDEWINDING ROADS OF THE Kentucky knobs, even the casual observer notices islands of prosperity among the jagged limestone cliffs and river valleys. Many of the peeling clapboard farmhouses of my childhood have been torn down and replaced with brick ranch-style homes. A new truck or car sits in the driveway - at times of day you'd expect the owner to be away at work. A few of the old farmhouses have been lavishly restored, their orgy of Victoriana (beveled glass, wicker porch furniture, gingerbread trim in contrasting colors) standing in jarring contrast to the stark, frugal lines of the houses themselves. Accompanying me along these roads, an elderly friend points. ''Pot houses,'' she sniffs.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: For most of the last five years, the rural counties of Kentucky, Tennessee and Missouri have been among the national leaders in marijuana production. This usually surprises outsiders, but surprises no one who grew up or lives among these hills. ''Used to be a hell of a thing to find out your next door neighbor grew,'' a local farmer said to me. ''Now nothing surprises you.''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: Once most of these farmers relied on tobacco, a high-yield, low-acreage crop that has been the ideal moneymaker in a countryside where flat land and salaried jobs are about equally scarce. In recent years, given the instability of the tobacco market, they were faced with some hard choices: sell the farm (or lose it to the bank) and move to the city; commute two hours and more to an assembly-line job in a small-town factory; or grow pot.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: Some of these people would never grow marijuana; others would grow it if it were legal. And there are others, with a long tradition of making their own laws, who have turned to it readily. This is whisky-making country, after all, where people survived Prohibition and the Depression by making moonshine for Midwestern cities.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: There's a complex struggle going on here, between the farmers' strict ethics and what they need to do to make a living; between those who grow and those who don't; between the farmers who grow to survive, and those who grow to get rich; between the law and people who have never had much use for it; between and among all these groups, whose members are usually related to one another by blood and by the intricate interweavings of small-town Southern life.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: I know those interweavings well, for I grew up in this country - where 60 years ago nearly every family (including mine) was involved with moonshining; where today marijuana production and distribution are a part of the local scene; where a way of life is changing. Or, as many argue, staying the same.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: MARIJUANA HAS not always been illegal. Throughout the 19th century, marijuana, then known as hemp, provided an important cash crop in those same South Central states that currently lead in its illicit production. The fiber of the hemp plant was (and is) considered at least the equal of other fibers, natural or synthetic, for rope and cord. Kentucky built its first public roads to convey the hemp crop to market.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: In 1937, the Marijuana Tax Act outlawed marijuana. Since then, the cultivation of hemp has been illegal, except during World War II, when the shortage of petroleum-based synthetic fibers led the Government to issue permits to grow hemp.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: After the war, the permits were revoked, and hemp retired to the fence rows of middle America - where, as ditch weed, it grew in abundance. Then, in the 1960's, hemp - a k a marijuana, pot, dope, grass - came into widespread use for another of its properties, this one known for years among jazz singers and old country folks suffering from rheumatism: smoking it got you high.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: The 1960's generation of college-age pot smokers looked abroad for their stash - first to Mexico. Then, after the Ford Administration began to destroy Mexican fields with chemical sprays, attention turned to Colombia as a source.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: During the 1980's, the Reagan Administration undertook a high-profile law-enforcement program to embargo the importation of marijuana. Mark A. R. Kleiman, lecturer at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government and author of ''Marijuana: Costs of Abuse, Costs of Control,'' calls this ''the only successful piece of agricultural policy of the Reagan years.''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: In fact, the policy's success had at least one unintended side-effect. Facing intensified Federal enforcement, Colombian drug lords turned from exporting bulky, difficult-to-conceal marijuana to vastly more portable - and more lucrative - cocaine. The Reagan Administration's efforts had indeed closed off the importation of marijuana; domestic producers moved in.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: At the time, many farmers needed a lucrative new crop. During the 1970's, the Government had promoted expansion on the farm, financing purchases of expensive equipment, construction of outbuildings, and acquisition of land. During the 1980's, the Reagan Administration abruptly tightened farm credit and reduced commodity supports, leaving farmers saddled with debt and facing a bleak market.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: As one Kentucky farm housewife told me: ''In the early 1970's, banks were eager to loan money. Then, in the 1980's, Government policy changed, the banks called in the loans, the bottom fell out of the tobacco market - all at once. Lots of people were close to foreclosure and felt the Government had betrayed them. So why not grow a little pot?''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: Country boys returning from Vietnam and an influx of counterculture, back-to-the-land hippies, had already popularized marijuana smoking among the area's young people. All that remained was for times to get hard enough for their folks to consider growing it.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: ''The typical guy we see growing marijuana is a 55-year-old farmer with a 20-year-old son,'' says a chaw-chewing lawman, a ham of a man with a huge paw of a handshake. ''He's got maybe 150 acres, he's trying to farm, he started 30 years ago when he could make a living at it. Now he's got kids in college or about to go there and is hard up. Some are about to lose their farms, some have already gone on their son's notes for their farm.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: ''Then the 20-year-old son comes home and talks about planting 20 marijuana plants here, five plants there. He tells the father, 'Let's grow $20,000 worth,' and they do it and it works. The son provides the connection. If the old guy grew it, he wouldn't know how to get rid of it.''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: These are tobacco farmers, experienced in working with a plant that requires intensive labor and individual attention. They grew, made money, put that money into the local economy. ''We'd hit September, early October, the slowest time of year in a tobacco-based economy,'' says a local bank official. ''And you'd walk down Main Street and see all these people buying clothes and extra food and supplies - the pot crop was in.''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: How much money we're talking about depends on who's talking, though nobody doubts that directly or indirectly pot has financed many of the new homes and businesses in the area. This is a farm economy, after all; people are accustomed to dealing in cash and asking no questions. A local bank official says assets in his bank dropped $5 million - a sizable sum for a rural bank - when he began asking depositors to complete the forms required by the Internal Revenue Service for cash transactions of over $10,000. A bank teller talks of counting a pile of bills that was still frozen in the middle - ''deep freeze money, we call it around here.'' A local lawyer tells of being called to a farm auction to help count the down payment - $24,000 in small bills.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: ''It don't hurt to spread that money around in the community,'' one grower said. When asked whether an indictment on marijuana charges was impossible in the local courts, a judge studied the ceiling. ''I think you could say that's a fair statement,'' he said. Several other judges I spoke to, as well as a number of lawyers, agreed.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: During the 1970's, that policy was consistent with the national trend toward reducing penalties for marijuana possession. Federal efforts to eradicate marijuana were spotty and half-hearted; state and local police usually looked the other way. If a property owner and longtime community citizen was arrested, juries and judges were lenient. In Kentucky, first-time growers routinely received a fine of $500 and a suspended sentence.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: Under the Reagan Administration, the Federal Government did an about-face. It began to underwrite state police search-and-destroy efforts. Federal district attorneys began to pursue marijuana convictions, and Federal sentencing guidelines became so strict that judges have virtually no discretion in sentencing. The grower who only a few years ago faced a fine and a year in prison may now be looking at 20 to 25 years without parole. Last August, the state Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service sent Kentucky farmers a letter notifying them that ''if marijuana is grown on your land the law provides that the U.S. government may TAKE YOUR FARM unless you can affirmatively show that such unlawful conduct was carried on without your knowledge.''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: It is difficult to prove one doesn't know something, so this in effect empowers Federal agents to seize property on which marijuana is grown, even if the property owner is unaware of its existence - even if, according to the United States District Attorney for the Western District of Kentucky, Joseph M. Whittle, the property owner is acquitted of marijuana-growing charges.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: In other words, this is hardball. One local law-enforcement official reflects a wide-spread view when he insists there's a hidden agenda here, with Federal agencies searching for heads to prove that they're making progress in the war on drugs. What better place to crack down, he argues, than in the rural countryside, free from the entanglements of international law and the violence of city streets?
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: IN OCTOBER 1987, FEDERAL, state and local officials converged on a farm outside New York Mills, Minn., and seized 62 dump-truck loads of marijuana. The raid was the first of a series attacking what the Justice Department calls ''the largest domestic marijuana-producing organization in the history of the United States.'' The final tally came to 182 tons of marijuana seized from 29 sites, including farms in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Missouri, Kansas, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Nebraska and Kentucky. The farms were managed by a loosely connected group called the ''Cornbread Mafia,'' a name coined by the police, the press or the growers themselves, depending on who's talking. Of the 78 persons arrested and charged so far in the Cornbread Mafia case, 59 are from Marion County, an enclave of 17,000 people tucked in the knobs of south-central Kentucky.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: According to Assistant United States Attorney David P. Grise, who helped publicize and prosecute the case, the Cornbread Mafia growers rented, or purchased, farmland across the Midwest. They planted the land in alternating rows of corn and marijuana (corn grows faster, helping conceal the pot but letting sunlight through). To minimize contact with local communities, imported laborers, most of them from Kentucky, tended the plants. Once the harvest was in, the growers disappeared, leaving only a caretaker to look after the farm.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: Grise insists that the name ''Cornbread Mafia'' originated with the growers themselves. Local journalists scoff at that assertion, pointing out that such headline-hype terminology hardly comes naturally to rural Kentucky farmers. These local observers describe the ''Mafia'' as a group of guys who had known one another since childhood and operated largely independently, sharing (and concealing) information like any cagey farmer. If they constituted a mafia, it was in their absolute loyalty to one another and their roots. As Grise says: ''Elsewhere in Kentucky, people will reveal information as part of the plea-bargaining process. Not in Marion County.''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: NOT EVERY RURAL area that engages in marijuana production has a history of encounters with the law as troubled and thorny as that of Marion County. In most of the Midwest and much of Kentucky, the pattern falls closer to that described by a farmer in a neighboring county: a farm economy gets sidetracked when farmers and their children, with only a high school diploma from poor, rural school systems, begin searching for some way to make money that will allow them to stay near their families and to work with their hands. But Marion County, though not the most isolated, or the poorest, or the least developed of marijuana-producing counties, epitomizes the phenomenon. Here some locals have developed lawlessness into an art, while family, friends, and the local business community have acquiesced in looking the other way.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: ''Well, Marion has always been a wide-open county,'' says Dee Davis, executive director of Appalshop Films, a division of Appalshop, eastern Kentucky's widely acclaimed cultural center. He hails from Hazard, a town 200 miles from Marion not exactly known for its law-abiding ways, but still he has heard of Marion County. ''What about that stolen-car fence? Is that still going?''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: ''That stolen-car fence'' - actually, a stolen-goods fence - was a notorious ring of thieves that operated during the 1950's and 60's out of Raywick, a Marion County town of maybe 300. People point to one man as the brain behind that operation - the ''Robin Hood of Raywick,'' Charley Stiles. Charley terrorized the state and the region. A judge told me how he had bought a new car for his son, then realized he had no room for it in his garage. Though he lived miles from Raywick, he was afraid to park it on the street, a fear he confided to a friend. A few days later, a stranger showed up at the judge's door. ''Charley said to tell you to park that car wherever you want,'' the man said. ''You got no need to worry about that car.''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: The police arrested Charley again and again; just as often, juries let him go. Days after the jury let Charley off, a brand new refrigerator would appear on some poor widow's porch, or a struggling farmer would get a hefty, interest-free loan. ''He would do anything for you, Charley would'' - this was the refrain of Charley Stiles stories.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: On Sept. 10, 1971, Charley was gunned down in a cornfield several counties removed from Raywick, shot once, or a dozen, or more than a dozen times, in his chest or in his back - depending on whether you believe the state troopers who shot him, or the people who tell the story now. The troopers contended they fired in self-defense, a story that hardly anyone believed, then or now.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: ''I hate to see it get to the point,'' a local judge said, choosing his words carefully, ''where the police feel they have no recourse in the courts.'' Another chronicler, after an hour of telling Charley stories (how Charley helped this person out, or pulled the wool over that cop's eyes), shook his head. ''He was one hell of a guy,'' he said, and paused. ''But it was a good thing they took him down.''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: As I grew up I heard multiple versions of Charley Stiles stories. When I visited last month, I heard them retold in spades - this time by the marijuana growers, for whom Charley is a folk hero. His story is a crucial piece of this jigsaw puzzle, not because he inspired the Marion County growers to go interstate (though there may be some truth to this), but because he is the latest in a series of outlaw heroes - the best role model going in this neck of the woods.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: One grower's 6-year-old son, asked by his teacher what he wanted to be when he grew up, piped up, ''I want to be a doper, like my father.'' I heard that story more than once, but from the grower's friends, not from the grower himself; he's in jail, denied bond, facing 20-plus years for his role in the Cornbread Mafia case. ''These guys are the robber outlaws - you'll hear all the moonshiner stories from them,'' said one ex-grower, formerly of the Cornbread crowd. ''Years from now you'll hear the same stories, except they'll be about the pot growers.''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: Or so they hope. These are people who will do just about anything for the sake of a good story; for the sake of fame, however local. ''If they don't talk about you,'' an 80-year-old moonshiner told me, ''hell, you ain't no count.'' As for the risk of going to prison, one ex-grower said, ''When your father has been in the pen, and most of the people you know, their fathers have been in the pen, well, there's not anything wrong with it.''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: LAWLESSNESS IS THE common thread between the years of moonshining and the years of marijuana growing. And not the least important question this raises is how, as an outsider who now lives in Marion County put it, ''people can go through such rigid moral training and not know right from wrong.''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: Some part of the answer to that question lies in that remarkable Southern talent for sustaining a double standard. ''Now, I don't know anybody that grows,'' one farmer told me. He dug at the dirt with the toe of his boot. ''Well - in my heart I know they grow. But I don't know they're growing. Understand?''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: I understand. Around here no one grows pot - just as no one's daughter gets pregnant before she gets married, no one's son is gay. The facts of the matter may contradict this (25,000 plants eradicated last summer in a single raid, to cite only one such fact). The demographics may stand in contradiction (among a stable, intimately connected population of 17,000, how can there be secrets?). The geography may stand in contradiction (in a county where there are no secrets, how can you hide 25,000 marijuana plants?). But only by accepting the contradiction between what is said and what is done can the outsider begin to understand how it is possible to sustain such a large illicit economy in such a very small place.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: But the answer to the question ''How is it possible?'' goes deeper than that. It finds its roots in a deep-seated instinct to preserve family and self in the face of hindrance from the law. For people raised as farmers, for whom welfare is a disgrace not very much better than prison, there is pride in growing pot.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: The marijuana raids, with their low-flying helicopters and camouflage-clad state policemen, represent the most visible federally supported effort this area has seen since the Civil War - or, perhaps, since the invasion of revenue officers during Prohibition. And local people view these raids together with more broadly harmful Federal policies: local farmers hear the politicians extolling family virtues, but they also can see in their grocery stores - stocked with products from American and foreign agribusinesses - evidence that Government farm policy is not working to benefit them and their families.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: ''From their previous experience with moonshining, there's a historical attitude that those who control the legal system do not represent them,'' says Ronald D. Eller, director of the University of Kentucky's Appalachian Center. ''The legal system became something to get around. . . . This translates into an attitude of 'us versus them,' 'them' being the rest of America, or the America they see on TV. 'We' live here and have to survive. There's a certain pride in the ability to survive and beat a system that's not equitable.''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: Of course, not all growers are upstanding farmers driven to pot by desperation. A lot of them, as one ex-grower put it, ''just can't stand prosperity'' - they made their first bundle just to get over a rough spot, then can't stand to leave that relatively easy money behind. Others get caught up in the mystique of rural machismo, in a long-running game of cops and robbers. Speaking of the Marion County growers, Grise said: ''They don't see this as a crime. They see themselves as doing their job, which is to grow pot; they see us as doing our job, which is to bust them for growing pot.'' As one grower said, ''Where else can you have the chance of making this much money with this much excitement?''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: Though the growers are a minority of the Marion County community, the county has profited from several years' vigorous cash flow, and the last people to welsh on that are those who have benefited: the bankers who look the other way when large cash deposits come through the window, the lawyers who joke with the sheriff about allowing defendants to harvest enough of their crops to pay their legal fees.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: Then there are those just entering the job market, who face the choice of earning a minimum wage cooking hamburgers at a fast-food joint or earning $100 a day for working outside, working with their hands - working marijuana.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: ''Young people are very bitter about not being able to live on the farm, not being able to have the kind of life their parents had,'' said one local lawyer. That bitterness translates into a loss of respect for institutions, into a sense that it's every one for himself, and don't get caught. A young law officer I spoke with - whom a lawyer identified as ''very actively looking the other way'' in his dealings with local growers - put it this way: ''I don't give a damn. I just don't give a goddamn.''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: TODAY, THE LARGEST open fields of pot are gone from Marion County; all parties on both sides of the law agreed on this (though the 25,000-plant bust occurred only a few months ago). But nobody thinks pot cultivation has disappeared. ''We'll just go underground,'' said one grower, speaking literally - caves and basements are being turned into greenhouses. Outside, plants are now scattered in bunches of two and three, making detection difficult and lowering the chances of losing an entire crop to thieves or the police. ''This is America,'' one grower said. ''If there's a demand for a product, there'll be somebody to produce it.''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: That same ethic drove moonshining in Prohibition times, and the view seems prevalent in Marion County that history is repeating itself. Once again the Government has outlawed a previously legal substance. Once again the courts are allowing the police greater leeway to seize property, search individuals and breach privacy, in an effort to eliminate consumption of a widely used drug.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: So far, at least in Kentucky, the Federal crackdown has not led to open violence. Local law-enforcement officers and growers alike agree that growers are far more likely to run than shoot.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: This is not to say the growers never use violence. Stories of extortion are common - a grower might offer $5,000 to a farmer, say, if he doesn't venture onto the back few acres for four months. The farmer who refuses can expect retaliation: barns burned, equipment vandalized. And the county has seen an increase in unsolved murders that everyone attributes to quarrels among growers. But during the last few years the Government has raised the stakes dramatically. Now that growers face 25 years in jail and the loss of the family farm, many people believe they will decide, as one lawyer put it, to hold on to the guns they've been dropping.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: ''I sense a strong analogy between the marijuana phenomenon of central Kentucky - and the crime that comes with it - and the crack epidemic in New York,'' said the Rev. Thomas P. O'Dell, a Kentucky clergyman who has worked in Manhattan's Bellevue Hospital. ''Hopelessness, bred by changing local economies and neglect, is a common thread . . . the decline of tobacco as a meaningful cash crop hereabouts has left behind folks who likely find themselves in circumstances similar to New York City youths now that the industrial jobs are gone.''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: NOT LONG AFTER THE Federal Government started seriously prosecuting marijuana growers, Kentucky game wardens began pulling from the murky rivers scuba divers who were illegally scooping up thousands of washboard mussels. The shell of these mussels, ground into bits and introduced into Japanese pearl oysters, provides the perfect catalyst for the formation of cultured pearls. The divers truck the shells out of state, where they're sold to Japanese buyers.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: Moonshining, marijuana, mussels. In those parts of the world that the 20th century has more or less left behind, people find ways to get by.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: How can this be changed? Some people around here think that the answer lies in education. ''You're not going to break the grandfather -he's too strong, and it's in his blood,'' says one law-enforcement official. ''But you can get to the kids, or the kids of the kids.'' Others say that changing the way these people work will require, more or less, the end of the family farm. ''The only way you change the animal is to change the environment,'' a local teacher said. ''Bring in industry, new jobs, new blood - that'll change the countryside. The way they live will follow.''
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS

text: And there are others, the older people from the moonshining families, who have seen it all before; they have a different view, more cynical or realistic, depending on your perspective. Sixty years from now, they say, different Federal agents will be here, cracking down on a different product or substance, trotting out a different story for different reporters. And the same people, or their children, or their children's children, will find themselves on the other side of the law.
title: HIGH IN THE HOLLOWS
