text: A recent spurt in corruption cases at the Drug Enforcement Administration has undermined morale and crippled many investigations at a time when the agency is all but overwhelmed by the illicit drug trade, agents say.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Pending trials in four cases in Los Angeles, Miami and Washington involve seven veteran agents accused of becoming deeply involved in the drug business themselves when they were pretending to be fighting it.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: In the Los Angeles case, for instance, agents are said to have confiscated drugs from drug sellers or stash houses, then taken sick leave and traveled the world first class, arranging narcotics deals and hiding the illegal profits. Cases Are Disturbing, Agents Say
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: All seven agents have pleaded not guilty, and the full stories of their actions will not come out until their trials. But D.E.A. agents and managers say that just the fact that seven agents stand accused of participating in illicit drug operations run in part through their own agency hampers the fight against narcotics. Considering that only 10 agents have been convicted of felonies in last seven years, D.E.A. officials find these new cases especially disturbing.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Known among drug agents as ''crossing the line,'' corruption has always touched the criminal justice system, from courts to prisons to street patrol officers who succumbed to the lure of easy money. And state and local law-enforcement authorities also report a rise in corruption cases. But the D.E.A., the front line of the nation's attempt to enforce the drug laws, has long been regarded as relatively clean, attracting generally honest and dedicated agents.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Agency officials emphasize that illegal activity is still the exception among its nearly 2,800 agents worldwide, but say their people are demoralized.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: ''We go out and are willing to give our lives for what we're trying to accomplish,'' John M. Zienter, special agent in charge of the agency's Los Angeles office, said in an interview. ''And when we find one of our own is willing to do the opposite it can annihilate you, not only internally, but in the way it reflects on people who are willing to give their lives.''
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Mr. Zienter added that even without convictions of the agents, cases they were involved in could be jeopardized. Not only would that be ''a tremendous waste of taxpayer money,'' he said, ''it's very disheartening.'' 'Escalated Our Concern'
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: David L. Westrate, chief of operations for the drug agency, agreed that the corruption cases have damaged investigations and affected morale.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: ''The amount of money involved has escalated these issues, escalated our concern,'' he said in an interview. But, he added, the agency has addressed those problems head on by making it a priority to root out internal corruption with ''good management and a good, solid Office of Professional Responsibility.''
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Still, the potential for corruption has increased along with the volume of drugs entering the country, agency officials say. And for seriously overworked and often underpaid agents, the temptation can prove to be too much, the officials say.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: ''There are cases when we'll seize more resources in one case than what an agent and his colleagues will ever make in their entire career put together,'' said Dale W. Schuitema, who heads the Office of Professional Responsibility, which has 13 senior inspectors to investigate internal corruption or misconduct. Rise in Misconduct Cases
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: The agency recently reported a 176 percent increase in pending instances of agent or employee misconduct in 1988 over the previous year, according to the Justice Department's Office of Professional Responsibility. There were 82 internal cases opened in 1988, 45 cases closed and 80 cases pending. In 5 of the cases, the employee resigned or retired, the D.E.A. said.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Some misconduct cases were relatively minor, like the one involving an agent from Atlanta who was in Washington to attend agency training classes when undercover police officers watched him buying two packets of marijuana from a street dealer. He soon resigned.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: But an estimated 40 percent of the misconduct cases were for activities like bribery, fraud, obstruction of justice and selling drugs. Coping With Job Pressures
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: The agency has developed elaborate internal regulations and even hired psychoanalysts to help agents cope with the pressure of the job and the effect on their personal lives.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: And while agency officials say that low pay does not necessarily breed corruption, they insist that it can be a contributing factor. In Los Angeles, for example, agents who are college graduates can start out earning $24,000 a year, while the Los Angeles Police Department pays new recruits with high school diplomas at least $10,000 more.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: ''As the temptations increase, the potential for problems increases,'' Mr. Zienter said. ''Logic tells me that will happen unless we get our head out of the sand and start doing things to enable us to prevent it from increasing.''
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Others in law enforcement argue that despite its generally favorable public image, the D.E.A. has, in fact, been plagued with an ineffective management and red tape and that this is catching up with it, enabling agents to turn bad without anyone noticing.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Prosecutors say that was the case with Jorge Villar, a D.E.A. agent in Miami who is charged with selling protection to a drug smuggling ring. They say that was also the case with Edward K. O'Brien, an agent at D.E.A. headquarters who was charged with transporting cocaine from Miami to Boston, and with Alfredo Iglesias of the Miami office and Drew Bunnell, based in Ecuador, who are accused of accepting money for providing protection to drug smugglers.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: But it is the Los Angeles case that stands as a symbol for problems that many critics of the agency and several officials within it say are widespread and exist to one degree or another in D.E.A. offices throughout the world. A Case Study From Agents To Defendants
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Back in 1983, prosecutors now contend, three agents in the Los Angeles office - Darnell Garcia, 42 years old, John Jackson, 40, and Wayne Countryman, 46 - began to work secretly with the drug dealers they were supposed to be tracking down.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Records assembled for the trial, now scheduled to begin in April, show that the defendants flew thousands of miles first class and put in for frequent-flyer discounts. On those trips, the three enjoyed the good life, according to court documents, which include a letter written by Mr. Garcia to a German hotel, praising its service. Through their lawyers, the defendants declined to talk about the case.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Court documents portray the lives of the three in this way: Mr. Garcia and Mr. Jackson were distinctly more flamboyant than Mr. Countryman but all three led a frenzied life, working on D.E.A. investigations by day and flying off to New York, say, for a night of illegal drug negotiations. And in spare moments they might be off to Luxembourg or the Cayman Islands or Switzerland to hide their illegal profits. The three communicated among themselves with electronic pagers, mobile phones and public phones, seeking to peddle their product - much of which was cocaine and heroin they or their colleagues had seized from other traffickers - and help hide the activities of those they were dealing with.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: ''There was a pattern of stealing drugs whenever they could get their hands on them,'' said Joyce A. Karlin, the assistant United States attorney prosecuting the case.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: The court documents established these and other specifics:
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: * Mr. Garcia and Mr. Jackson entered the D.E.A. evidence vault one day in October 1984 and stole about one kilogram of heroin.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: * In several instances, Mr. Jackson and Mr. Garcia stuffed cocaine and heroin in express mail packages and sent them to New York.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: * In performing his duties as an agent in January 1985, Mr. Jackson took custody of 15 pounds of heroin seized from Thai traffickers, submitted 12 pounds to the D.E.A. and kept the rest.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: * Mr. Jackson and Mr. Countryman carefully structured their currency transactions to keep each one under $10,000 so their banks did not have to file reports with the Treasury Department.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: In retrospect, other agents wonder why the three did not arouse suspicion sooner. Mr. Garcia, for one, was certainly conspicuous.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: ''Darnell was a wheeler-dealer and a high-roller type,'' said Donald E. Hugh, who retired from the Los Angeles D.E.A. office in 1987 and worked several cases with Mr. Garcia. ''He used to irritate guys because he used to do things the rest of the guys wished they could do.''
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: He was a black belt karate champion who appeared in karate movies, his friends say. Government documents show that he drove a Mercedes-Benz 190 purchased mostly with cash and paid $580,000 up front for a new home in 1987.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: During much of his nine years as an agent, he was at odds with management, particularly after he sued the agency on racial discrimination charges and won. In late 1985, he had been dismissed for refusing to accept a transfer from Los Angeles to Detroit and was reinstated in June 1987.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Thomas G. Martin, a retired agent who was on the review board that first hired Mr. Garcia, said Mr. Garcia at times displayed an off-putting personality and that that was actually an asset. ''You take somebody and ask him to strap a gun to his back and a second weapon to his leg,'' he said, ''he'd better be a little cocky and confident.''
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Mr. Jackson, an agent for 14 years, was also known around the office for the energy and enthusiasm he devoted to outside business enterprises, like selling Amway products and owning Pac Man video games in arcades in downtown Los Angeles. He, too, was flashy, driving a Corvette and buying a $750,000 home in 1988. But, unlike Mr. Garcia, Mr. Jackson was considered a top-flight undercover agent and far easier to get along with.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Friends describe Wayne Countryman, on the other hand, as altogether different. He was thought of as a solid but not flashy agent with an easygoing personality. He was an agent for nine years.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Mr. Countryman is now out on bail. Mr. Jackson on Thursday was granted $1 million bail, which his lawyer says he will probably post later in the week. Mr. Garcia, a fugitive for seven months, was arrested in Luxembourg in July and is expected to be extradited to Los Angeles in January. Seeking Causes When Rules Aren't Enough
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: The Drug Enforcement Administration's agent personnel manual contains dozens of regulations intended to prevent corruption. There must be two agents present to count money, for example, and agents must agree to random drug tests.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Why, then, did it take years for the agency officials, trained to break these cases, to document the activities of these men?
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: It was information supplied by an outside informer that led to the indictments, Federal officials say. Why did the internal regulations and internal precautions fail?
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Ralph B. Lochridge, director of public information for the Los Angeles office, said officials were simply too busy with drug cases to notice what was happening.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: ''One of the compounding problems was the fact that Los Angeles became overwhelmed in terms of the amount of drugs and the amount of money and the amount of work that hit us here overnight,'' Mr. Lochridge said. ''The Government takes a long time. We're not a guerrilla-style operation. You're running a hundred miles an hour being concerned with your own informants, your own cases, the U.S. Attorney's office. You don't have time.''
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Gerald V. Scotti, a 10-year veteran agent who has been at odds with the D.E.A. since he left the Los Angeles office in 1983 and then testified for the defense in the drug trial of the automaker John Z. De Lorean, was less charitable. Before Mr. Zienter took charge of the office three years ago, he said, it had a history of management troubles.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: ''I can tell you right now a dozen schemes I can devise to have skirted out as much drugs as I wanted out of that office,'' Mr. Scotti said, adding that agents are reluctant to turn each other in because there is a strong ''us against them mentality'' against the narcotics traffickers.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Whatever one says about the internal inquiry of the three agents, there is no disputing that their arrests proved devastating to pending investigations. ''These agents,'' Mr. Zienter said, ''or has-been agents, were involved in a number of investigations that are certainly tainted now.''
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: The result, he said, could be ''violators that should go to jail not going to jail, or a tremendous waste of taxpayer money because an investigation completed will no longer be of value. It's very disheartening.''
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: D.E.A. officials were reluctant to cite the specific cases that may have been compromised, but acknowledged that there were many. One of the agents indicted in the Washington case, Mr. O'Brien, had supervised agents in Europe and the Middle East. It is believed that he may have obtained information about important investigations spanning the globe.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Mr. Schuitema, who supervises the agency's internal investigations, said the hardest thing is retracing an investigation that has been worked by a corrupt agent. ''You always have fallout,'' he said. ''You have to review what the individual has been working on, what they are working on now and how much damage control we have.'' The Outlook Looking for Ways To Help Agents
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Whenever they are asked about corruption, D.E.A. officials repeat the issue of their relatively low salaries as a contributing factor. They note that the average starting salary for agents is several thousand dollars less than what new Federal Bureau of Investigation agents make. And they note that there is no pay differential for working in expensive cities. In Los Angeles alone, where there are about 100 agents, officials report that more than 20 of the agents have resigned in the last three years, most for higher-paying jobs.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: And they are not alone in that view. ''I don't know how D.E.A. agents even make ends meet, especially in places like New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco - unless their whole family works,'' said Representative Don Edwards, Democrat of California and a former F.B.I. agent. ''We're inviting real trouble if we don't take care of these people.'' Mr. Edwards is a member of a Federal commission that early next year is expected to propose sizable pay increases for Federal law enforcement agents, and higher salaries for those based in expensive cities.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: But the pay problem is only one element of a general picture of frustration. Lack of sufficient resources to wage a stronger fight against the major drug traffickers and the demoralization or depression that stems from having a colleague ''cross the line'' to corruption are other important factors, agents say. The D.E.A. has hired outside psychotherapists to help the employees cope with the sagging morale. One who counsels agents in Los Angeles, speaking on the condition that she not be named for fear of compromising the privacy of her patients, said the case of the three agents has come up several times in her conversations with clients.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: ''There are a lot of agents here who are newer and they don't know these people,'' she said. ''So what they're dealing with is not personal, but that this happened in our organization and it reflects on me. For older agents who knew these people there's a different issue, what you might expect: anger, betrayal.''
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: The therapist also said some agents have told her they sometimes feared they could be put in danger by colleagues who have ''divided loyalties.''
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Despite the general reputation of D.E.A. agents as honest and diligent, Mr. Scotti, the former agent, noted that the agency does attract some raucus ''cowboy types'' who may be more susceptible to corruption than those in the staid F.B.I. These are, he said, ''a bust 'em up, shoot 'em up group.''
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: Others argued that it was inevitable that the leading agency dealing with drugs would be touched by corruption. When J. Edgar Hoover was running the F.B.I., he made it clear he did not want his agents to have anything to do with drug cases because of the temptations.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: In the end, D.E.A. officials said that although they are doing their best to cope with the recent spate of corruption cases, they have not radically stiffened internal regulations because there is only so much they can do.
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: ''We're dealing with people here: agents, cops, lawyers,'' Mr. Schuitema said. ''You can have systems set up so that it's hard. But if somebody wants to go bad, there's nothing you can do to stop it.''
title: AGENTS ACCUSED: THE DRUG FIGHT'S DARK SIDE - A SPECIAL REPORT: Corruption in Drug Agency Called Crippler of Inquiries and Morale

text: A United States Marine Corps reconnaissance team, which has been quietly patrolling the Southwest border since Thanksgiving, exchanged fire with drug smugglers for the first time late Wednesday night along the Arizona border, Administration officials said today.
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: The Marine unit was part of a contingent of about 50 marines assigned to assist the Border Patrol. While the Defense Department announced in October that it planned to deploy marines to help halt drug smugglers crossing the border from Mexico, direct conflict has been avoided until this week.
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: The border clash comes as Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is moving ahead with plans submitted by his 10 top military commanders for greater involvement in drug-fighting missions. The effort is a marked contrast to the attitude of Mr. Cheney's predecessors, who avoided military involvement in anti-drug efforts. 'Discretionary Authority'
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: Military officials said the plans include wider use of planes to detect aircraft carrying drugs, and naval combat ships, among other things. CBS News reported Thursday night that Mr. Cheney had authorized military units to capture fugitives, wanted on drug charges, in foreign countries.
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: While not confirming that report, a Bush Administration official said today that American special operations forces did have ''certain discretionary authority in dealing with drug traffickers.''
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: Officials said the Marine unit, believed fewer than a dozen men, suffered no casualties. The officials said the smugglers fired first on the marines, who then fired back over the heads of the smugglers. The smugglers, on horseback, escaped into the darkness, eluding the marines, who were on foot. The smugglers left behind a horse and 535 pounds of marijuana, officials said.
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: The Defense Department and Marine Corps Headquarters in Washington refused to comment on the clash, but Pentagon and other officials said that it came in a night patrol and lasted less than a half hour.
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: The plan calls for Army, Marine Corps and National Guard units to support civilian drug law-enforcement agents. The troops are to provide information about the location and movement of smugglers on the border with Mexico.
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: The Southwest border is the overland entry area that Colombian drug organizations use to ship cocaine to the United States. It is used by Mexicans to bring marijuana into the United States. Army Planning to Send Troops
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: The National Guard began surveillance patrols early this year; the Marines began patrols late last month. The Army has plans to send in patrols. The patrols move secretly into their areas of operation and conduct reconnaissance and surveillance of suspected smuggling routes for up to a week. The services previously announced plans for routine military training in the Southwest to help deter narcotics trafficking, but plans to conduct reconnaissance missions to locate smugglers were not widely known.
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: Pentagon officials say the patrols do not violate prohibitions that bar the military from acting as a law-enforcement agency. Patrol members are armed and authorized to fire in self-defense. But the officials say that intercepting and apprehending suspected drug smugglers is left to civilian narcotics agents. Cocaine at Tens of Millions
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: One official said the combined teams have already seized cocaine with ''tens of millions of dollars in street value.'' While the exact number of marines involved Wednesday night has not been made public, similar clandestine reconnaissance patrols by the Marines in the Vietnam War usually consisted of a team of four to eight men.
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: An official outside the Defense Department said that while on patrol the marines, with by a Border Patrol officer, spotted a group of horsemen in the barren region of southern Arizona not far from the Mexican border.
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: When ordered to halt, the horsemen turned and galloped off. The marines then launched illumination flares to light up the area. At that point the horsemen dismounted and fired at the marines. The marines returned fire, but, directed by the Border Patrol team, they fired over the smugglers' heads. Three Headquarters on Coasts
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: The Pentagon has established three headquarters with personnel from all services in the South and on the West Coast. These headquarters direct and coordinate military support to civilian drug law-enforcement authorities.
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: One is at Key West, Fla., under Vice Adm. James C. Irwin of the Coast Guard. That command seeks drugs coming in by sea and air via the Caribbean and the Gulf of Mexico.
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: A similar task force in Oakland, Calif., headed by Rear Adm. William P. Leahy Jr. of the Coast Guard, monitors drug traffic in the Pacific. The newest task force, the one that coordinates military activity along the Southwest border, is at Fort Sam Houston, Tex., under Lieut. Gen. George R. Stotser of the Army.
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: The task force headquarters plan and coordinate military countering operations with the headquarters for Operation Alliance in El Paso, where plans to seal borders to drugs are drawn up by officers of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the Drug Enforcement Administration, the Customs Service, the Border Patrol and sheriffs' departments. Services' Change of Heart
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: In mid-September, after President Bush announced his national drug strategy, he ordered major military commands to draw up plans to help stem the flow in the countries that are the sources of the drugs - and along the transit routes from those countries to their markets here.
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: The military plans, requested by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and including proposals on intelligence collection, electronic surveillance with early-warning aircraft and logistic and operational support to Colombia, Peru and Bolivia, were submitted to the Pentagon in mid-October.
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: The services, at first reluctant to become involved, are now willing participants, providing technical assistance to the three Andean Governments.
title: Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots

text: The television drama was hardly sophisticated, but the point was clear: A young man writhes on his bed, howling from drug withdrawal, while his family agonizes and finally decides to go to the authorities.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: Malaysia's war on drugs is an intensive effort of education, advertising, testing, rehabilitation, harsh mandatory penalties for drug use and the death penalty for possession of relatively small amounts of heroin, cocaine or marijuana.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: But results from the Malaysian program, put into effect in 1983, and a similar one adopted in nearby Singapore in 1975 have been mixed.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: Malaysian officials can report only that the country's addiction rate rose again last year, though they believe that over the last six years it has started to stabilize. The number of addicts in Singapore has decreased from a high in 1976, but the problem is by no means solved there either. Decline in Singapore Studied
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: Still, experts are looking with interest at the programs - particularly Singapore's - since it is one of the few urban centers in the world where addiction appears to be declining over the long term. Paradoxically, Amsterdam - which takes the opposite approach and permits the use of heroin in some cases - is another.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: It is the death penalty in the Singapore and Malaysian programs that has received the most attention in the world's press, especially when foreigners are hanged. Since Malaysia imposed the death sentence for trafficking, 235 people have been sentenced to death and 81 have been hanged. The rest await appeals or execution. In Singapore, 37 people have received the death sentence, and 25 have been hanged.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: Kerry Lane Wiley, a 37-year-old Californian, was arrested on Nov. 4 on grounds of possessing 18.2 ounces of marijuna, and he thus became the first American to await a hearing on the Malaysian drug charge that carries the mandatory death sentence.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: With drug use rising rapidly in the early 80's, the Government of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad identified ''dadah'' - the Malay word for drugs - as a threat to national security on a par with Communism and as a major incitement to violence. Whipping for Smaller Amounts
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: Malaysia and Sinapore both impose capital punishment for ''trafficking,'' which is defined as the possession of 0.53 ounces or more of pure heroin or morphine, 7.05 ounces of marijuana or hashish, 2.2 pounds of opium or 1.41 ounces of cocaine. Those caught with lesser amounts get a whipping with the rotan, a bamboo cane.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: Officials of both nations believe that without the death penalty and without rehabilitation efforts their drug problems would be far worse.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: This, they say, is especially so because of both countries' proximity to the ''Golden Triangle'' of Burma, Laos and Thailand, where much of the world's heroin poppies are grown. They contend, too, that their drug programs have discouraged the use of Malaysia and Singapore as transit points for international smuggling to the West.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: ''Punishment must be strict, or otherwise the penalty has no meaning,'' said Poh Geok Ek, the director of Singapore's Central Narcotics Bureau.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: The view in Malaysia is as harsh, if less polite. ''We hang anyone convicted who exhausts their appeals,'' said Tey Boon Hwa, assistant director of the Anti-Narcotics Task Force. ''We also hang old ladies, even if we don't normally publicize it. If you get caught, you face the music.''
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: Both countries also use a British colonial legacy, preventive detention without trial, to imprison those strongly suspected of involvement in drug trafficking when sufficient evidence cannot be obtained to guarantee conviction. History of Opium Use
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: Opium use has a long history in the area, especially among migrant Chinese laborers imported by the British, who controlled the opium trade early in this century. But with the increased popularity of drugs during the 1960's and the Vietnam War, the number of those addicted to heroin grew sharply.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: In an interview, the Prime Minister of Singapore, Lee Kuan Yew, said: ''Death is the best deterrent we have. We have fewer addicts now than five years ago, and fewer then than we had 10 years ago.''
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: According to Mr. Poh, Singapore, with about 2.6 million people, now has roughly 9,000 addicts, about 85 percent of them using smokable heroin.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: From 1974 to the end of 1976, Mr. Poh said, the number of heroin addicts exploded in Singapore from about 100 to 13,000. As part of a plan to reduce demand as well as supply, Singapore then decided to incarcerate as many addicts as possible for treatment and rehabilitation. By the end of the next year, 9,000 people were taken into custody, and those who tested positive for drugs were immediately sent to treatment centers by executive action; the courts were bypassed entirely, a practice which continues.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: Singapore now arrests about 4,000 addicts a year, about 70 percent of them repeat offenders, and about 300 traffickers, of whom 20 to 30 are subject to the death penalty. Situation Is 'Stabilized'
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: Malaysian officials, who began their campaign eight years after Singapore in a much larger territory of 17 million people, say that at best they have ''stabilized the situation.'' Mr. Tey estimates that the number of addicts in Malaysia now is something under 100,000, though Western diplomats think the figure may be as much as twice that.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: Although 9,710 new addicts were detected last year, the highest figure since 1984, Malaysian officials contend that the 1988 experience was temporary and that drug use overall is leveling off.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: Malaysia's main problem is money. Roughly $22 million a year is being spent on the drug war, but even by the end of this year, there will only be about 4,000 beds in rehabilitation centers for the 100,000 addicts.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: Singapore is richer and much smaller and thus has fewer budget constraints. Given its labor shortage, it can promise jobs to addicts who have been through rehabilitation.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: Singapore's problem is different, and it goes to a concern about ethnic tension that beats just beneath the skin of a Chinese-dominated city-state surrounded by Malays. The Chinese make up 76 percent of the population, Malays only 15 percent. But 52 percent of the addicts arrested now are Malays, a trend that began three years ago. Mr. Poh worries about racial stereotyping, and in fact Singapore is making significant efforts to engage Malays, from political leaders to religious ones, in helping with the problem. Addicts Not Called Criminals
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: In Singapore, addicts, though arrested, are not given criminal status. They are put into rehabilitation centers and segregated by their pattern of drug use. All who are fit and under the age of 55 are put through ''cold turkey'' detoxification in spare rooms for a week. There is medical supervision, but no medication is provided to ease withdrawal. The point, said Mr. Poh, is to remember the pain. Drug maintenance programs, he said, merely perpetuate addiction. Nor are addicts regarded as patients; they are seen as people with behavioral problems.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: A week of recuperation from detoxification follows, plus orientation to a regimen of paramilitary discipline. Once they are judged ready and able to quit drug use, the first-time addicts are put into two weeks of intensive physical training in the tropical sun and equally intensive personal, group and family counseling.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: The entire experience is designed as ''a short, sharp shock,'' to wean them from drugs and to make them afraid to try again. Between 30 and 50 percent of first-time addicts are then sent home, and for two years they must report to the police for urine tests on a regular schedule, undergo counseling and be subjected to surprise urine tests.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: The others are at this point put in a two- or three-month course at another, harsher center. They then enter a four-month day-release program, during which they are permitted outside employment. The two years of urine tests and counseling come after that for this group. High Rate of Repeaters
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: For those who fail these programs or who are repeat offenders, there is a longer program that can keep them incarcerated up to three years.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: About 70 percent of the Central Narcotics Bureau's annual budget of $11 million is spent on treatment and rehabilitation. Even so, Mr. Poh said, about 70 percent of repeat offenders go back on drugs - ''but at least 30 percent kick the habit.'' Among first-time addicts, he said, only about 35 percent currently relapse, though he admits the program is still new.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: The figures on repeat offenders for Malaysia are about the same, Mr. Tey said. Malaysia does not isolate new addicts from the others.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: In addition to rehabilitation and harsh law-enforcement procedures, both countries also stress preventive education in the schools, the press and the temple or mosque. Pain of Rehabilitation
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: At Singapore's center for first-time addicts, it was not hard to see the pain of rehabilitation at work. A man of 30, older than the average, squatted in the regulation blue shorts and white T-shirt, his hair shorn boot-camp style. He had been smoking heroin for three weeks when he was caught with five friends. Because he had probably not yet become addicted, the detoxification period was not hard, he said, but the physical training was.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: He had worked for the subway system, a semipublic agency, and would now lose his job. Why had he started to smoke heroin? He could not explain, except that he was divorced and bored, and his friends were smoking.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: Did he have any children? Three, he said, his voice breaking. How would they react? ''I don't want to think about that,'' he said. ''I just feel so stupid.''
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: Outside the room, the supervising officer smiled. ''I think we can save him,'' he said.
title: Intensive War on Drugs by Malaysia and Singapore Shows Mixed Results

text: In a rare statement by a member of the judiciary, a Federal judge in Manhattan called last night for the legalization of all drugs that are now illegal, including marijuana, heroin and crack.
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: In a speech at the Cosmopolitan Club in Manhattan, the judge, Robert W. Sweet of Federal District Court, called the war on illicit drugs ''bankrupt.'' He said 11 1/2 years on the bench had convinced him of the futility of sentencing criminals convicted of violating drug laws and the frustration of ''seeing our justice system overwhelmed by a social phenomena.''
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: Judge Sweet, a former Federal prosecutor, became the first Federal judge to propose publicly that illegal drugs be made legal, according to the Drug Policy Foundation. The foundation, an international nonprofit research organization in Washington, is devoted to exploring alternatives to the current national drug policy. Public Support by Others
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: The 67-year-old judge also joined the ranks of a small but growing number of former and present government officials, commentators and academics who have argued that the present policy, of aggressively prosecuting drug sellers and users, be reconsidered.
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: Others who are making this argument include former Secretary of State George P. Shultz; the economist Milton Friedman, who has received the Nobel Prize; William F. Buckley, the conservative columnist, and Mayor Kurt Schmoke of Baltimore. Legalization has been promoted most vigorously by Ethan A. Nadelmann, who teaches at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University and who has been credited by public figures with opening their minds to the idea.
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: The White House and Congress have opposed the idea. The Bush Administration has said that legalization would be an ''unqualified national disaster'' and would create many more addicts. Earlier this week William J. Bennett, the National Drug Policy Director, accused proponents of legalization of advancing ''morally scandalous'' arguments.
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: When Congress addressed the issue last year, it passed an anti-drug law that declared that legalization would be an unconscionable surrender in a war in which ''there could be no substitute for total victory.'' Public Opinion Not Supportive
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: Public opinion appears to support that position. In a poll of 1,537 adults conducted in April by the National Opinion Research Center, respondents said by a ratio of 5 to 1 that marijuana should not be made legal.
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: Judge Sweet, appointed by President Jimmy Carter in 1978, was a Deputy Mayor of New York City under Mayor John V. Lindsay from 1966 to 1969. He helped supervise treatment programs for addicts.
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: He is considered by colleagues and lawyers who have appeared before him as bright, diligent and moderate, but not among the most influential of Federal trial judges. Nonetheless, his speech reflected the frustration of a number of Federal and state judges who, in recent interviews, said they have come to believe that too much reliance is being placed on the courts to solve the nation's drug problem.
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: Judge Sweet's speech at the Cosmopolitan Club was not a public event; only members of the club were permitted to attend, although the judge provided a text of his speech shortly before delivering it. Comparison to Alcohol
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: The judge argued that illicit drugs should be treated like alcohol: they should be taxed and made illegal for minors. He added that if the drugs were legalized, drug use, like alcohol consumption, should take place outside of work.
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: While many of his arguments in favor of legalization have been made by others, the judge's remarks were nonetheless extraordinary, coming from one who regularly helps enforce the nation's drug laws and orders the incarceration of those convicted of narcotics possession and drug dealing.
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: The judge said that the enormous increase on the docket of criminal drug cases, which by law must generally be heard within 10 weeks of indictment, was forcing long delays in civil matters. The problem has become so severe, he said, that in September no juries were available in the Federal District Court in Manhattan to hear civil trials.
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: He proposed that the state set the prices of the legalized drugs and the amounts that could be sold, and set up or license outlets for their sale. People should be able to buy quantities ''at will,'' he said. But he added that no one without a doctor's prescription would be able to buy a lethal dosage at one time. The drugs would be made by pharmaceutical companies, he said, and any sales outside of the state-recognized system of distribution would be considered a crime, as it is with the consumption of alcohol in some states.
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: The speech did not address where the pharmaceutical companies would purchase the raw materials, like coca, which is now harvested mostly in the Andean nations in South America. Present Efforts Found Wanting
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: Judge Sweet said that efforts to combat the spread of illegal drugs had failed to put a dent in trafficking or use. Instead, he said, these efforts had proved to be onerously expensive and had ''come close to causing foreign excursions, subversions and caused us to reconsider whether or not, as a nation, we wish to employ assassination as an expression of policy.''
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: ''From Dionysus or Noah's vines on, mind altering by alcohol has been part of Western culture,'' Judge Sweet said. ''Not so marijuana, cocaine, heroin and crack. However, these substances, to a greater or lesser extent, and in varying degrees, do alter one's consciousness, one's view of the world. Even as alcohol dulls the suppressor and enhances one's view of oneself, cocaine gives a sense of exhilaration, heroin a glow, a warmth, and marijuana a sense of relaxation and ease. What then is wrong?''
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: The judge compared the current state of drug policy to the prohibition of alcohol earlier this century and said that the abolition of drug laws would eliminate the profit motive, the gangs and the drug dealers. He added that it would make it easier to identify and treat people with drug addiction problems, especially through the use of the almost $9 billion now going to criminal prosecutions and tax revenues generated from drug sales.
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: He said it would be illogical to legalize some mind-altering drugs while continuing to deny more potent or addictive substances, like crack. Crack Would Be Legal, Too
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: ''To draw distinctions on the degree of addiction may not be empirically possible, nor does it appeal to logic and symmetry. In my view, you don't outlaw 120 proof while permitting 80.''
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: He said research might soon yield an andidote to crack addiction, adding that the increasing numbers of crack cases flooding the family courts, where judges are being forced to supervise abandoned or crack-addicted children, ''demonstrates the failure of our present prohibition.''
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: ''We should identify those at risk and reach out to provide alternative services and ultimately hope,'' he said. ''There is no present evidence that prohibition has, or will, break this vicious cycle of dependence and abandonment.''
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: The judge conceded that society must anticipate that legalization would lead to increased use of narcotics, as the repeal of prohibition initially led to greater consumption of alcohol.
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: ''The gamble,'' he said, ''would have to be that addressing the underlying causes, providing safe narcotics and treating the users, would ultimately result in a healthier America. If it is otherwise, it will be because our citizens have lost the capacity to act affirmatively and to control their individual addictions.
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: ''The present climate seems to me to be optimistic: there is an emphasis on health, diet and what one ingests,'' he said. ''If our society can learn to stop using butter, it should be able to cut down on cocaine. If it cannot, no prohibition can be effective.''
title: Federal Judge Urges Legalization Of Crack, Heroin and Other Drugs

text: Two of Mexico's most powerful drug traffickers were found guilty today of the 1985 murder of a Federal drug agent from the United States. Each was sentenced to a prison term of more than 100 years, and millions of dollars in personal property was ordered seized.
title: Mexican Drug Leaders Guilty In the Killing of a U.S. Agent

text: After more than four years of often tangled legal proceedings, the traffickers, Rafael Caro Quintero and Ernesto Fonseca Carrillo, were convicted, along with 23 people said to be members of their cocaine-smuggling operations, of killing the Drug Enforcement Administration agent, Enrique Camarena Salazar, and a Mexican pilot who worked for him, Adolfo Zavala Avelar.
title: Mexican Drug Leaders Guilty In the Killing of a U.S. Agent

text: The sentence was handed down this morning by a judge in the city of Guadalajara, the drug trafficking center where the two men disappeared in February 1985, and was announced here this afternoon by Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo. A Major Diplomatic Issue
title: Mexican Drug Leaders Guilty In the Killing of a U.S. Agent

text: Mr. Camarena's slaying has been perhaps the largest irritant in recent relations between Mexico and the United States. His badly beaten body was recovered in March 1985 from a grave on a ranch near Guadalajara.
title: Mexican Drug Leaders Guilty In the Killing of a U.S. Agent

text: The Reagan Administration at one point brought traffic along the border to a standstill by stepping up inspections and also complained on several occasions of what it called a lack of vigor in the prosecution of the case. Mexican officials angrily rejected the accusations as unwarranted ''Mexico bashing.''
title: Mexican Drug Leaders Guilty In the Killing of a U.S. Agent

text: ''Mexican justice has complied with its obligation,'' Mr. Alvarez del Castillo said at a news conference. He described the case as ''a crime of great transcendence'' and the verdict as a blow against drug trafficking in Mexico.
title: Mexican Drug Leaders Guilty In the Killing of a U.S. Agent

text: In the course of the investigation, 12 police officers and former police agents in the state of Jalisco, whose capital is Guadalajara, were arrested and charged with involvement in the murder and kidnapping of Mr. Camarena and his pilot. Mr. Alvarez del Castillo today read a list of all those convicted in the case and their sentences, but did not say whether the police officers were included. The Sentences
title: Mexican Drug Leaders Guilty In the Killing of a U.S. Agent

text: Mr. Caro Quintero, who American and Mexican officials say headed a billion-dollar drug trafficking operation that cultivated and smuggled tons of marijuana into the United States during the early 1980's, was sentenced to 40 years for the murder of the two men. He was also convicted on kidnapping and drug trafficking charges, for which he was sentenced to an additional 76 years in prison.
title: Mexican Drug Leaders Guilty In the Killing of a U.S. Agent

text: Mr. Fonseca Carrillo, described as a major marijuana trafficker who also assisted Colombian drug cartels in shipping cocaine through Mexico into the United States, received a 40-year sentence for the murders of Mr. Camarena and Mr. Zavala. In addition, he was sentenced to 104 more years in prison on charges of kidnapping, drug trafficking, arms smuggling and criminal association.
title: Mexican Drug Leaders Guilty In the Killing of a U.S. Agent

text: Lawyers for Mr. Caro Quintero and Mr. Fonseca Carrillo are expected to appeal the decisions.
title: Mexican Drug Leaders Guilty In the Killing of a U.S. Agent

text: The sentences were the most severe permitted under the Mexican penal code, which does not include the death penalty for capital crimes. Luxury Suites in Prison
title: Mexican Drug Leaders Guilty In the Killing of a U.S. Agent

text: Since their capture four years ago, Mr. Caro Quintero and Mr. Fonseca Carrillo have been held at a top-security prison here in the capital. Mr. Caro Quintero tried to escape in 1987. A scandal erupted here this summer when it was disclosed that the two men had been permitted to build private suites in the jail, complete with elaborate video and stereo systems, private kitchens and bedrooms, luxurious furnishings, air-conditioning, telephones, a sauna and the right to overnight visits by female friends.
title: Mexican Drug Leaders Guilty In the Killing of a U.S. Agent

text: The verdicts today are likely to increase the credibility of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who took office in December 1988, warning that the drug trade had become a national security problem and vowing to combat it ''no matter who falls.''
title: Mexican Drug Leaders Guilty In the Killing of a U.S. Agent

text: Donald Glenn was unemployed, deep in debt and stealing money from Karen, the woman who loved him. His life had become crack. Starting Karen on the drug made him feel better, but then he felt terrible about that, too.
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: Things got to the point that Mr. Glenn, now 35 years old, was stealing money meant for their baby's milk to buy crack. Then, while Jessica cried in her crib, he went into the bathroom to smoke it. On paydays, he would bring Jessica along as he cashed his check and raced to spend it on crack.
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: The girl talked early. This is the first sentence that Mr. Glenn remembers her saying: ''Daddy do crack.''
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: Soon afterward, Mr. Glenn found himself leaning against a church door - shaking with convulsions, hating himself, staring at rock bottom. ''I'm really losing it,'' he thought.
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: So he prayed, and two years later, Mr. Glenn's life is better. But the work was his. He entered a drug program, dug deep inside and somehow, somewhere found strength. You can see him today in maroon blazer, starched white shirt and regimental tie at the Studio Museum in Harlem, greeting visitors at the front door. He is a personable, articulate man.
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: He seems to have done what some think is nearly impossible - overcome crack addiction. But Mr. Glenn acknowledges that the struggle is never over. He goes frequently to Narcotics Anonymous meetings. When a close friend dies, he thinks of crack as a comfort. On the streets of the
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: Harlem where he lives as well as works, he sees people using the drug everywhere. On three occasions, he has dreamed that he was on a binge and ''back to being an animal.''
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: ''The addiction is with you every day,''
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: Mr. Glenn said. ''If you forget where you came from, you can go right back to it.''
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: But the signs of ''cure'' are unmistakable. He and Karen (who quit crack on her own) married last year. He has received two promotions at the museum. Their debts have been reduced from $10,000 to $3,000, and he is scrambling toward a better future, testing for government jobs from mail carrier to jail guard. He agreed to tell his story in the hope that it would help others.
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: His boyhood home in Harlem was racked with turmoil, and he reacted defiantly. ''I started being like a little gangster,'' he said. Part of his motivation for getting into trouble at school was that he would then get to see his father, a policeman.
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: His first drug experience, in elementary school, involved nodding out on some kind of pills. A dangerous beginning. ''Stay awake, boy,'' someone snarled. ''If you go asleep, we're gonna do terrible things to you.''
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: The youth participated in what he called ''wolf packs.'' He recalls ripping the trousers off a man that he and a dozen other youths had mugged. He was expelled from one junior high. In high school, he hung out in the men's room, smoking marijuana and gambling. Sometimes he brought a dollar and left with $30 because, he says, ''I'd become so proficient at cheating.''
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: By age 17, he was living with a woman and her infant child from another relationship. He had dropped out of school, and was half-heartedly looking for office work. Then he got a job with the federally financed Model Cities Program, working as a school-crossing guard, among other things. A pattern was developing: Mr. Glenn would go crazy with wild living and drugs, then pull himself more or less together.
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: That became harder and harder. At his next job, managing city-owned buildings, Mr. Glenn was making $12,000 - more than twice what Model Cities paid. He was juggling five women, including Karen. ''It was like they were on a conveyor belt,'' he said. And so, it seemed, were drugs: He progressed from heavy marijuana use to cocaine.
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: After being dismissed for absenteeism, Mr. Glenn lived on unemployment. He then found work as a guard at an emergency shelter. There, at a time that Karen was pregnant with Jessica, he had a torrid affair with a fellow worker. Crack, just emerging, seemed the ticket to keep libido steaming. ''I needed all the sexual enhancement I could get,'' he said.
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: Things then really deteriorated. ''I was on the verge of losing my wife and child,'' he said.
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: Finally, Mr. Glenn entered a four-month program run by the National Recovery Institutes and stayed an extra three months to make sure. But the weekend he was released, he visited an old girlfriend and smoked crack with her. He says he has since been clean and now detests crack. ''It ate a generation of young people,'' he said.
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: His dream is to move from the one-room apartment that has been his and Karen's home since 1982. He'd like to find a place where Jessica - he says she's 5 going on 15 - has room to dance. He said, ''I've been trying to consolidate my family.''
title: About New York; A Man's Struggle With the Siren That Is Crack

text: Sgt. Norman Horowitz waved through the window of the blue police van at the elderly neighborhood beautician. ''Hi, pretty lady,'' he boomed. She flashed a gap-toothed grin and waved back.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: ''She rented out her apartment to a woman who subletted to a junkie,'' the sergeant said. ''We got him out.''
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: The sergeant and his 10-member team, working in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, are part of the Community Patrol Officer Program. The program is the Police Department's newest old idea, or oldest new idea, a five-year-old back-to-the-future effort to turn traditional neighborhood police beats into more forceful weapons against crime.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: Designed to restore people's sense of safety, build good community relations and prevent crime, the CPOP (pronounced SEE-pop) teams, one in each of the city's 75 precincts, get to know residents and merchants to exchange information, plot crime patterns to devise solutions and coordinate efforts with other agencies. Unlike most of the other 26,000 police officers, they have the luxury and responsibility of working on problems over time.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: But they are also responsible for stopping crime wherever they find it.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: Just that afternoon, a landlord came into the CPOP office in the station house on Union Avenue near Broadway to complain that one of his tenants and his mother were running a thriving drug business out of their apartment on South Second Street.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: ''Can we get a key to the building?'' Sergeant Horowitz asked. ''Here,'' said the landlord, gladly taking one off his ring. ''You will surprise them,'' he said with a wink.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: That is how the program works. ''We do it the old-fashioned way,'' said the sergeant, a 46-year-old street crime and narcotics specialist with 23 years on the job, not counting a restless retirement when he realized nothing but police work interested him.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: The program is similar to others tried across the nation. While some of its goals, like a greater sense of security, cannot be measured, it seems to have caught on with the public, judging from comments like ''I love my CPOP cop,'' which Assistant Chief Raymond W. Kelly of the department's planning office says he hears. An Idea Around for Years
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: But although Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins is among the program's many supporters and has called for its expansion, other needs - the four million yearly 911 emergency runs that consume nearly 90 percent of patrol force time - have taken precedence.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: ''There are not 750 police officers available now to expand CPOP,'' Police Commissioner Richard J. Condon said recently. Doubling the number of 10-member teams in the precincts would allow for more concentrated patrols.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: The idea of special community patrols has been around for years under one name or another. In the 1970's, it was called the Neighborhood Police Team Concept in New York and other cities. In 1979, it was called ''problem-oriented policing,'' by Professor Herman Goldstein of the University of Wisconsin at Madison.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: As outlined in a report by the Police Executive Research Forum and the Government's Bureau of Justice Assistance, Dr. Goldstein sought to show how the police could be more effective by grouping incidents to identify problems and then deciding how to attack the reasons for them.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: The nonprofit research forum and the Justice agency are running a two-year experiment to apply problem-solving techniques to drug enforcement in Tulsa, Okla.; Tampa, Fla.; San Diego, Atlanta and Philadelphia.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: New York City's variation, CPOP, was devised with the Vera Institute of Justice, a research group, and begun as a pilot project in 1984 in the 72d Precinct, in Brooklyn's Sunset Park.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: As of a year ago, the program is in every precinct and includes 800 officers. All volunteer for the duty, decide their own hours and goals and operate semi-independently of the precinct commands through their own station house offices with their own phone numbers and civilian administrative aides.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: Most precincts are divided into nine sectors. Usually, one CPOP officer's beat is a sector of dozens of blocks, so the patrols are spread thin. Staying Close to the Community
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: The officers often patrol on foot, another way of staying close to the community, but each team shares a van like the one Sergeant Horowitz and two of his officers used recently to check some chronic problems in the North Brooklyn precinct stretching from the East River to Newton Creek, Metropolitan Avenue to Flushing Avenue.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: One of the problems was ''the hole,'' a fire-ravaged ruin at 221 South Second Street, which the community patrol officers know to be a drug hideout.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: Inside, it was eerily quiet. A makeshift plastic bucket dangled from the ceiling on a string. When the drug sellers were in residence, customers placed their money in the bucket and it was hauled up and lowered with the drugs, usually crack. The sergeant and his men, Officers Anthony Burgos and Philip Dominguez, partners who patrol a particularly large and dangerous sector, searched the wreck with flashlight beams but found no one. They tore down the bucket and string.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: Soon after, they watched three men walking down South Second Street toward the hole. One of the men stopped to urinate against the building wall.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: ''Let's check these guys,'' said Sergeant Horowitz. The van pulled to the curb and the officers beckoned them over.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: ''Hey you, you,'' the sergeant called. ''Tell us the truth,'' he said, asking whether the men were looking to buy drugs.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: They denied coming for drugs and had no needles or other contraband. They were let go. But one in the group, a man from the neighborhood, lingered to confide to the officers that he had indeed come for drugs - only marijuana, he insisted - and wanted to pass on complaints about the drug sellers.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: ''Some of the guys who go in there say they put money in the can, but they never send nothing down.'' Making Use of Tips
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: ''Gee, that's a shame,'' said Sergeant Horowitz. ''You better go to the Better Business Bureau.''
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: Tips from the community, usable or not, are always coming to the officers, the sergeant said.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: Not long ago, he said, complaints from neighbors alerted the officers to a vacant lot on South Fifth Street that was strewn with abandoned cars being used by prostitutes. The officers pressured the Sanitation Department to remove the wrecks and the prostitutes drifted elsewhere.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: Similar tips and pressure from patrol officers, he said, drove drug dealers out of neighborhood parks and dispersed gangs of youths who were intimidating younger children in schoolyards. Fighting Drug Traffic
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: Other intelligence allowed the police, working with the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, to shut down several grocery stores that sold drugs. Cooperative residents were assigned code numbers so they could call in information without giving their names.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: With Sergeant Horowitz trailing them recently, Officers Burgos and Dominguez checked out another drug spot. By the time the sergeant caught up with them at Hooper and South Third Streets, they had a young woman with long brown hair and a man in a military-style jacket standing spread-eagle against a car. The hood was sprinkled with unopened crack vials and glass smoking stems that the two had turned out of their pockets.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: ''He was passing to her, Sarge,'' Officer Burgos said.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: ''Put everything on top here,'' Officer Dominguez said. ''Take it all out. Make sure you don't have any needles. If I check you out I don't want to get pricked with your needle.'' 'I'll Talk to You in the Station'
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: He turned to the woman. ''You shoot?'' he asked, referring to heroin.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: ''Occasionally,'' she said. ''But I've slowed down. I have an appointment to go for drug rehabilitation.'' She began to cry.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: A crowd formed. A child stopped, eyes wide, before her mother fearfully pulled her away.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: ''I'll talk to you in the station house,'' Sergeant Horowitz told the arrested woman, ''not out here.''
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: Officer Burgos ran to get the van and the two were driven to the station house. Officer Dominguez began the paperwork for the trip to central booking.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: ''I'll lose him now until tomorrow,'' grumbled Sergeant Horowitz.
title: Oldest New Idea for Policing: Walking a Beat to Stop Crime

text: BIOLOGISTS from the United States and Guam are ready to release six Guam rails, an endangered bird that has been preserved only in zoos, into the wild.
title: Endangered Bird Seeks New Haven

text: But the small, flightless birds will not be going to Guam, once their only home. It is not safe for them there because of the brown tree snake, which arrived on the island shortly after World War II as a stowaway or as a misguided attempt at rat eradication.Instead, it virtually wiped out the Guam rail in the early 1980's. The population plummeted from 80,000 birds in 1968 to fewer than 100 in 1983.
title: Endangered Bird Seeks New Haven

text: On Thursday, the rails will be introduced to Rota Island, 31 miles north of Guam, where none of the snakes have been found. The Mariana Island chain, which includes both Guam and Rota, is in the western Pacific about 1,000 miles east of the Philippines The brown tree snake, which eats both birds and eggs, exterminated three of the five bird species that were found exclusively on the United States territory island of about 200 square miles, said Scott Derrickson, curator of birds at the National Zoological Park here.
title: Endangered Bird Seeks New Haven

text: The snake can grow more than 10 feet long. Its mildly poisonous venom is strong enough to kill a bird. It also kills by wrapping itself around prey.
title: Endangered Bird Seeks New Haven

text: In late 1982, biologists began a campaign to save the rail and the other remaining indigenous bird, the Micronesian kingfisher, which is not yet ready to be reintroduced into the wild. In a program called the Species Survival Plan, biologists from Guam and 12 zoos in the United States captured and bred the few remaining rails. Today there are 138. Strong Eater and Weak Flier
title: Endangered Bird Seeks New Haven

text: The dusty brown bird resembles a grouse and grows to a foot high and half a pound in weight. It eats snails, insects, fruit and carrion. Flapping its stubby wings, it can flutter several meters into the air.
title: Endangered Bird Seeks New Haven

text: ''We ran blood reviews, fecal screens and DNA analysis on each of the birds that we considered releasing to make sure they were in perfect health and that their genetic variety would be preserved in those birds that stay behind,'' said Carolyn Emerick, lead bird keeper at the National Zoological Park's Conservation and Research Center in Front Royal, Va.
title: Endangered Bird Seeks New Haven

text: The six rails to be released have spent about a week in aviaries adjusting to Rota's environment and foods. They will haveharnesses to carry tiny radio transmitters so that Gregory Witteman, a graduate student in biology at the University of Tennessee, can monitor their progress. About 30 more are to be released in February.
title: Endangered Bird Seeks New Haven

text: ''It is very rewarding to get the rail back into the wild,'' said Robert Beck, a biologist with Guam's Department of Agriculture. ''But the real success will of course be when and if we can get it back on Guam. If we can do something about the snake.''
title: Endangered Bird Seeks New Haven

text: The Department of the Interior is working with $1 million provided by Congress to develop a program to eradicate the snakes on Guam.
title: Endangered Bird Seeks New Haven
