text: For the two and a half years since he mauled a toddler to death, a pit bull named Willy has lived in cage No. 214 at the Humane Society animal shelter here, pacing his narrow enclosure, gnawing his rawhide bone or romping in the exercise yard with kennel attendants who have come to love him.
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: Now the attendants are mournfully counting the days until Willy is put to death with an injection of sodium pentabarbitol, which will happen at the end of his owner's trial now under way in nearby San Jose.
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: Less clear is the fate of the dog's master, Michael Patrick Berry, a burly laborer who is thought to be the first person in the United States charged with murder because of the acts of a pet. Mr. Berry is free on $20,000 bail and faces a maximum prison sentence of 15 years to life.
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: Precedent will be established in Santa Clara County Superior Court, and Judge John A. Flaherty is proceeding carefully and has ordered all participants not to comment on the case.
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: There has been one previous felony conviction in a similar case, experts say, when a Georgia man was sent to prison for involuntary manslaughter in 1987. In Mr. Berry's case, the charge was upgraded to second-degree murder after the deputy district attorney, Dale Sanderson, said he could prove that Mr. Berry failed to adequately restrain the dog even though he knew it was dangerous.
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: Mr. Berry knew ''everything he needed to know about the propensities of that pit bull,'' Mr. Sanderson told the jury on the opening day of the trial, showing them a series of exhibits regarding Willy's viciousness.
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: The exhibits included letters to Mr. Berry from Willy's breeder, who said that the animal was ''the monster biter of the world'' and that ''no dog would be able to go an hour with him and live.'' Also found in Mr. Berry's house were dog-fighting publications and a wooden treadmill advertised in the magazines to keep pit bulls in peak fighting condition.
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: When the attack happened, Willy was guarding 243 marijuana plants, and Mr. Berry is also charged with cultivating marijuana.
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: Willy was wearing a heavy collar and chain and was padlocked to an automobile axle sunk into the ground when he attacked 2-year-old Jimmy Soto, who bled to death in moments. Philip Pennypacker, Mr. Berry's lawyer, said the rusty metal devices, caked with dirt, were an example of ''the type of care Mr. Berry took.''
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: The child's parents, who have three other small children, are expected to testify on Monday.
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: Mr. Pennypacker told the jury that there was ''absolutely no question'' that Jimmy Soto, who lived in a house behind Mr. Berry's, ''tragically died at the hands of that dog.'' The lawyer also said that there was uncontradicted evidence that Mr. Berry was ''interested in dog fighting at one time in his life.''
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: ''Those are the dark-side facts,'' Mr. Pennypacker said solemnly, but both man and dog had ''left that type of activity'' behind them. What happened on June 13, 1987, he said, was ''a horrible accident,'' not a murder.
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: According to the Federal Centers for Disease Control, at least 157 people have died from dog attacks nationwide in the last 10 years, and more than 40 percent of them were killed by pit bulls. Here in California after Jimmy Soto's death, several communities, Santa Clara among them, drafted laws regulating pit bulls that have been superseded by a new state statute.
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: The state law defines dangerous and vicious dogs without reference to breed. Dangerous dogs, those that have biten someone or killed two domestic animals in the last 36 months, must be penned. Vicious dogs, those that have seriously hurt someone or been trained for dog fighting, must be put to death.
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: The Humane Society is not involved in the trial here, except for boarding Willy and two other pit bulls Mr. Berry owns, Blonde and Buttercup, who will also be killed when they are no longer required as evidence.
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: Staff members at the shelter have become attached to the dogs and are angry that they will soon be killed. ''They've been loves, sweethearts,'' said Jim Kelly, the kennel supervisor.
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: Mr. Kelly compared a dog trained to fight to a youngster who knows a foreign language and then forgets it if it is no longer spoken. Even if Willy was once a killer, Mr. Kelly said, he is no longer.
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: ''It doesn't make sense what they're going to do to him,'' he said. ''What he was and what he is are two different things.''
title: Santa Clara Journal; Its Owner on Trial, A Pit Bull Awaits Death

text: Near the edges of Times Square, new office towers and hotels are climbing toward the gray winter sky - an image of progress wrapped in glass and steel.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: But in the neon heart of the neighborhood, especially along 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, life and the skyline have been frozen in place as the delay in developing the area goes into its ninth year.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: The area, traditionally a hub for everything from the legitimate to the marginal to the outright criminal, remains a gathering spot for runaways and tourists, for longtime shop owners and young immigrants, for theatergoers and security guards, for drug dealers and their customers. All this is bathed in the blazing lights of huge electronic billboards, movie house marquees and book stores that call themselves ''adult.'' 'Exciting' and 'Disgusting'
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''It's exciting,'' said Leonard Washington, a 14-year-old from the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. ''It has a lot of games and cheap movies. You feel protected because there are so many cops around.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: But for Marcia Bell, 37, who works in the area as a legal secretary, the bright lights illuminate decay - trash swirling down the street, streams of urine in the doorways, shattered liquor bottles on the sidewalks and legions of hollow-cheeked men whispering about drugs for sale as police officers stand nearby.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''It's the most disgusting seven minutes of my day,'' she said, describing her walk along 42d Street from her job to the subway. ''You're always stepping between the drugs and the money.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: The pace and face of Times Square could soon change. Work on a $2.5 billion 42d Street development project -delayed for years by court challenges - may finally begin by the middle of next year, according to the state agency overseeing the program.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''I think we're out of the woods,'' said Brian K. Kell, a spokesman for the New York State Urban Development Corporation. ''We think all the significant litigation has been decided.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: If the project goes according to the agency's vision, it should be substantially completed by about 1994, nearly 15 years after it was first proposed and opposed. #4 Office Towers Planned Under the plan, four office towers will loom over 42d Street, joining about 15 skyscrapers now under construction or near completion in the area. The more than 40 adult book stores and peep shows that dot Times Square will be swept away and nine once grand theaters restored.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: By the time the dust settles, 20 buildings will have been demolished and more than 400 businesses displaced.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: In the meantime Times Square remains what it has been for decades, a midtown carnival midway - both enticing and menacing.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: Times Square is a crossroads above and below its streets, said William Kornblum, director of the Center for Social Research at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York City. Mr. Kornblum's graduate students once estimated the pedestrian traffic in an hour on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues to be 3,600 people. Heavy Traffic Underground
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: The traffic flow is similar beneath its streets. Five subway lines converge under Times Square, and more than 120,000 people a day hustle through the Times Square subway station, making it the second busiest in the city. Only the Grand Central subway station handles more people.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: Above ground, people have long flocked to the area to sample its smorgasbord of restaurants, theaters and movie houses. Many of the nightclubs that were once common have long gone, but along 42d Street a customer can still see two first-run movies for the price of one.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''This is like a big social area,'' said Theo Butts, 20, a Bronxite, as he stood on the corner of 42d and Broadway, trying to decide which movie to see. ''There's a lot of different things to do here. We don't have this stuff in our neighborhoods.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: But Times Square is suffering, Mr. Kornblum said.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''Many parts of the city are getting more dangerous, and especially the segregated low-income parts of the city,'' he said. ''And the violence is spilling over into public places. That's Times Square.'' A Magnet for Crime
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: In 1988 an average of six to seven crimes a day were reported on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''I think it's probably worse this year,'' said William H. Daly, director of the Mayor's Office of Midtown Enforcement. ''Criminals gather there to plan their forays into other parts of the city and into other parts of Times Square.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: What a difference a block makes. A yearlong total of 39 crimes were reported on 42d Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, Mr. Daly said.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: Mr. Daly's agency was created 14 years ago to clean up Times Square by aggressively enforcing city building codes and business licenses. When it started, Times Square was overrun by the commercial sex trade.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''Forty Second Street has always been a naughty zone,'' Mr. Daly said. ''In the 60's it became a sex zone, a red-light district. Now the problem is crack and acts of violence.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: But he added: ''I would hate people to get a one-sided view, that it's all trouble spots. There has been a lot of progress over the last 14 years. But crack has really complicated our efforts.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: The commander of the Midtown South Police Precinct, Deputy Inspector George F. Brown, said robberies and assaults in the Times Square area were up in August, September and October.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: The inspector said he had increased the number of officers patrolling the area in uniform, on horseback, on motor scooter and in plainclothes. He declined to say exactly how many more officers had been deployed. A Narcotics Marketplace
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: In Times Square, there is little rest for the wicked or the good.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: Even on a cold night and well into the next morning last week, drug dealers were out in force. They stood in packs on the corner of 42d Street and Eighth Avenue, hopping up and down to fight the chill, and in one's and two's along the street.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: From darkened doorways that often glowed with the flicker of a cheap cigarette lighter at the end of a crack pipe, the dealers hawked their wares to almost everyone who passed, from middle-aged men in suits hurrying into the adult book shops to sandy-haired young men from New Jersey, looking for thrills and a little marijuana.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''We came over here to get some beers and maybe cop some weed,'' said a 20-year-old from across the river who said his name was Harry Kramer. ''Drugs rule New York. And this is the place to get them.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: It was shortly before 2 A.M. in front of the Port Authority Bus Terminal. As Mr. Kramer left to buy a can of beer, his friend, who refused to gave his name, said he wanted only to get out of the area in one piece. Minutes before, the two men had been chased across Eighth Avenue by an eager drug peddler.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''Another friend of mine got his butt kicked around here,'' the man said. ''They pulled out some guns and took his money.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: Indeed, violence is in the wind blowing through Times Square.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''The drug addicts come around the corner like thirsty warmongers,'' said Jeff McCalvin, 24 and unemployed, who said he ''hangs out'' on Eighth Avenue.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''Any unsuspecting cat they see, they attack,'' he said. ''They dive on him like the linebackers on the Giants.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: On Sept. 18 at 8:30 P.M. at 42d and Eighth Avenue, a drug dealer was shot and killed in a dispute with another dealer. On Nov. 25 a police officer, a suspect and a passer-by were wounded in a gunfight that started when the officer spotted a young man with a gun on Seventh Avenue near 43d Street.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: Ali Nettles, 24, has been hanging out in Times Square for 15 years. He said money drew him to its dirty streets.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''Thousands and thousands of dollars can be taken from people who don't know what they're doing,'' Mr. Nettles said. ''There are all kinds of cons you can run on the tourists, on the foreigners. If you can't get a dollar down here, there's something wrong with you.'' 'Anything for Money'
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: When the confidence games fail, Mr. Nettles said, many people, including himself at least once, turn to robbery.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''I just got out of jail for robbing somebody at the Port Authority,'' he said. ''But I only did that one time. I ain't a robber.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: Jeff Cohen earns his money not on the street, but behind the counter of The Funny Store, a novelty shop on Seventh Avenue a few steps from 42d Street. His family has operated the store since the 1950's.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: Mr. Cohen said that in the last few years he had noticed a marked difference in the neighborhood. ''People are more desperate,'' he said. ''They'll do anything for money.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: His customers are tourists and teen-agers shopping for magic tricks and practical jokes. Plastic vomit is a big seller.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: Mr. Cohen said he was opposed to the redevelopment project because it would put his family out of business. The Urban Development Corporation promises to help businesses relocate, but in the novelty trade, Mr. Cohen said, location is king.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''If you're on 18th Street and Ninth Avenue, it's not the same,'' he said. ''See the floor, it's worn out from people coming in here.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: Seven blocks away the floors of the new Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza Hotel are like shiny ice.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: The 765-room hotel, which rises 46 stories above Broadway between 48th and 49th Streets, opened Dec. 1. A week later its second-floor lobby was filled with guests waiting for rooms and a drink from the still unfinished bar.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: Daniel Risi, the bartender, said he hoped the new hotel and other buildings going up in and around Times Square would rejuvenate the area.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''It won't end crime,'' he said. ''Like prostitution won't end. But the cleaner the area, the better it'll look and, who knows, maybe it'll attract a more sophisticated criminal.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: Down the street on Broadway near 46th Street, a Salvation Army captain, Andres Lugo, and a volunteer, Clark (Shorty) Erskine, stood guard around their red collection kettle. The night before two thieves stole the kettle from a 65-year-old volunteer. Mr. Lugo retrieved the empty kettle from the police.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: On the corner, about a dozen young men circled a cardboard box playing a confidence game called three-card monte. Their laughter mingled with the sound of Captain Lugo's bell.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''They scare people away,'' Mr. Lugo said, pointing to the men on the corner. ''People don't want to pull out their money with them around.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: Mr. Lugo said the new hotels and office buildings made Times Square ''cosmetically nicer,'' but will do almost nothing to improve the lives of ''the little guys on the street.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''I feed 150 people daily at our post on 47th Street,'' he said. ''It doesn't change. It doesn't get any better.'' And Now 'Zombies'
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: At 1:40 A.M. a dozen people were sipping hot chocolate and coffee in a narrow fast-food restaurant on 42d Street. Some of the men were talking loudly and flashing wads of cash - mostly $1 bills.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: They talked about discos and guns and making money.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: ''Did you read about that dude in the paper the other day?'' one man asked his friends. ''He got busted with a whole bunch of ice.'' ''Ice?'' ''That new stuff,'' the man said, referring to a powerful smokable methamphetamine. ''What's it do to you?'' ''You don't want to mess with it,'' the man said. ''They say people walk around like zombies.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: Then the man walked slowly across the floor, rolling his eyes toward the ceiling. ''Is it like crack?'' ''It's worse than crack,'' he said. ''It kills more people.''
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: The men laughed and shook hands and then stepped into the cold, dark morning that had settled over Times Square.
title: Raw and Bawdy, 42d St. Awaits a Big Change

text: Michael Pollan asks great questions: why mow lawns? And, recently, why weed? (''Weeds Are Us,'' Nov. 5). Though the questions are fine, his reductive answers are disappointing.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: It's easy to dismiss romantic poets, marijuana cults and ''Stalking the Wild Asparagus.'' It's easy to throw out some poorly chosen ornamental seeds, watch hardier plants invade and dismiss ''natural'' gardening as a conceit of our time. However, use of chemicals (fertilizers, herbicides and pesticides) on conventional lawns and gardens is a chief source of groundwater contamination in the state of Connecticut, where Mr. Pollan mows and gardens. His articles reinforce such contamination by implicitly condoning existing esthetic conventions after only the most superficial exploration of alternatives. ASHELEY GRIFFITH Conway, Mass.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: By Jeffrey Schmalz, Special To the New York Times
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: A Hispanic police officer was found guilty of manslaughter today in the killings of two unarmed black men that set off rioting in the mostly black Overtown section of Miami. The killings, which occurred in January, have come to symbolize the ethnic tensions of this troubled city.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: The six-member jury returned its verdict at the beginning of the second day of deliberations, rejecting the defendant's contention that he had fired at the men because their motorcycle, which was being pursued by a patrol car for traffic violations, was about to run him down.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: The verdict brought cheers in black neighborhoods, where some residents took to the streets to celebrate. Twice before in this decade, white Miami police officers had been acquitted of killing blacks. Many blacks thought an acquittal was certain in this case, too, prompting predictions of more civil unrest. Appeasement Is Charged
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: Hispanic people in Miami, where 60 percent of the population is Hispanic, seemed stunned, saying the officer, William Lozano, had been brought to trial to appease blacks. A Spanish-language radio station recorded 200 calls of protest in an hour after the verdict. The 400-member Hispanic Officers Association of Miami called this ''a sad, sad day for the people of this city.''
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: By evening, the streets were calm. The Police Department, preparing for months for possible violence after the verdict, said that for the moment, it would keep the 1,100-member force on alert, with no vacations and no days off.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: As the verdict was announced at 12:50 P.M. Officer Lozano, a 30-year-old immigrant from Colombia who has been on the force five years, sat stone-faced as he had since the trial began Oct. 23. His wife, Anna, and his brother Windsor, both Miami police officers, hugged each other and wept.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: Officer Lozano faces a maximum penalty of 45 years in prison. Sentencing was set for mid-January and he will remainfree on $10,000 bail until then. The police officer, who had been suspended with pay from his $39,000-a-year job on the force, now faces automatic dismissal. He also faces civil suits for monetary damages that were filed by the relatives of the two victims.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: ''I'm going to keep fighting for my job, for justice,'' Officer Lozano said in a statement he read at his lawyer's office shortly after the verdict. ''We are going to appeal. I didn't have a fair trial from the beginning.''
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: Mr. Lozano's chief lawyer, Roy Black, who bowed his head as the verdict was announced, said one element of the appeal would be that the trial should have been moved out of Miami. He said jurors were predisposed to conviction because they feared acquittal would lead to rioting. Anti-Hispanic Bias Charged
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: Mr. Black said he would also argue on appeal that a juror, a black postal union official, Ezra Simmons, was biased against Hispanic people.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: While the jurors were being selected Mr. Black produced affidavits of that bias from two of Mr. Simmons' co-workers. Judge Joseph P. Farina ruled that Mr. Black had not proved his contention, a decision upheld by a state appeals court.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: It was Mr. Simmons whom fellow jurors elected foreman. He declined to comment after the verdict, as did the other jurors, saying only, ''I'm glad it's over.'' Two of the jurors were black, one was Hispanic and three were non-Hispanic whites. Night of the Confrontation
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: The case that has preoccupied Miami for 10 months began with a split-second decision by Officer Lozano at dusk on Jan. 16, after an afternoon of Martin Luther King Day festivities.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: As he was standing behind his patrol car, trunk lid open, a patrol car nearby, lights flashing, siren blaring, was pursuing a motorcycle that was speeding and going through stop signs. It was driven by Clement Lloyd, 23, and Allan Blanchard, 24, was the sole passenger.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: Officer Lozano testified that he saw police lights over the lid of his car's trunk and stepped into the road to see what was happening - to find the motorcycle almost upon him.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: He said he never heard it coming. He said he had no time to do anything but draw his gun and fire a single shot. It hit Mr. Lloyd in the head, killing him. There was an ensuing crash. Mr. Blanchard died the next day of crash injuries, The incident, in the primarily black Overtown section, inspired bottle-throwing, which grew into rioting. One person was killed, 11 were shot and 13 stores were burned down in three days. The Defense Argument
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: The defense argued that Mr. Lloyd was a drug dealer who feared arrest. The defense cited that as his motive for trying to run down Officer Lozano. The defense was not allowed to refer directly to Mr. Lloyd's conviction for marijuana possession, but the lawyers found ways to hint at it.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: The defense was allowed to say that Mr. LLoyd was carrying $1,504 in cash and his blood contained alcohol, marijuana byproducts and traces of cocaine.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: The defense appealed to the jurors to imagine themselves in Officer Lozano's place, with only seconds to make a life-or-death decision.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: Prosecutors, on the other hand, repeatedly used the term ''common sense,'' saying it was obvious that the officer had time to get out of the motorcycle's way. They produced half a dozen witness who, though they differed on details and sometimes changed their own accounts, nevertheless agreed that the motorcycle was not headed for the officer and that he must have heard it coming - as the witnesses said they had. Deliberate, Prosecution Says
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: The prosecution, headed by John Hogan, never formally established a motive. Conviction for manslaughter does not require motive, but only the establishment of ''reckless disregard'' for human life.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: However, the prosecuting attorneys argued that the officer had acted deliberately, not out of panic. They hinted he had engaged in ''an old trick of the Miami Police Department'' - an officer intentionally steps in front of a moving vehicle to justify shooting a suspect.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: The one witness who strongly supported Officer Lozano's account, his partner, Dawn Campbell, was depicted by the prosectution as a liar who was covering up the real events.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: The verdict today is only the latest blow to the Miami Police Deparment, which over the last decade has been shaken by disclosures of corruption linked to drug money and findings by various panels that it has used excessive force against blacks. 'The City Is the Loser Here'
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: Police Chief Perry Anderson, at a news conference after the verdict, was asked if the department needed to review its policies. ''As with any outcome,'' he said, ''we will look at our procedures, rules and regulations. If they need to be changed, they will be changed.''
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: Hugo A. Rodriguez, legal counsel to the Hispanic Officers Assocation, said of the verdict: ''This wasn't a rogue cop. This should never have gone to trial.''
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: ''This means if a cop shoots, he could go to jail,'' he added. ''But if he doesn't shoot, he could wind up being dead on the street. The city is the loser here, because cops are figuring, 'Why should I put my neck out?' ''
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: Claudia Lubrin, the sister of one of the victims, Mr. Blanchard, reflected the mood that seemed to prevail in black sections of Miami today. ''I'm telling people to be calm,'' she said. ''Justice has been done.'' A Crowd at the Scene At the scene of the shooting, dozens of residents roamed the sidewalks, congratulating one another and waving in victory at passing motorists. In other black sections of the city, some residents literally danced in the street at impromtu rallies.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: Blacks areas had been visited repeatedly over the last few weeks by officials who organized meetings to urge residents to be calm and to watch the trial on television so they could be sure it was fair.
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: ''It's a relief,'' said Francena Adams, 38, a black standing virtually on the spot of the shooting. ''I can't tell you what a relief. Justice has been served - finally.''
title: Miami Officer Guilty in 2 Killings That Prompted Rioting by Blacks

text: By Joseph A. Califano Jr.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: Washington is embarking on another drug-of-the-month war, the third since 1986. Like its predecessors, our nation's latest war is destined to be another fool's errand because of its narrow focus on illegal drugs and its failure to confront society's pervasive problem of addiction. Even the bellicose political rhetoric is misleading, for drugs come to America not by invasion, but by invitation.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: Washington's latest targets -crack cocaine, Latin drug lords and black ghetto pushers - are such obvious bad guys that the Republican President, his drug czar and Democratic legislators push and shove to fire the next shot. So the amount to be spent in the 1990 war is up by $3 billion, but for the same old programs.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: America's problem is addiction, not simply illegal drugs. Reversing its penetration of society will require more than military advisers in Colombia and street cops. It will require us to take a hard look at ourselves and our institutions, and demand a massive commitment to research.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: Addiction to alcohol and drugs, legal and illegal, crowds every nook and cranny of our nation. Its economic costs - in health care, crime, lost productivity, forfeited education, property destruction - will top $300 billion this year and, unchecked, reach a trillion dollars by the mid-1990's.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: Addiction in America gives new meaning to the word awesome: 57 million Americans are hooked on cigarettes; 18 million are addicted to alcohol or abuse it; 21 million have tried cocaine; more than one million are hooked on crack; seven million smoke marijuana at least once a week; as many as one million are hooked on heroin; 10 million abuse tranquilizers and other psychotherapeutic drugs; one million regularly use hallucinogens like LSD and PCP; and ice - smokeable speed and a likely candidate to succeed crack as the 1990's drug of the month - has already hooked thousands.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: Addiction is Public Health Enemy No. 1. Half the nation's hospital patients and most homeless people suffer from alcohol or drug abuse.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: Alcohol-related birth defects are America's largest single cause of mental retardation. One of every 10 babies born this year has been exposed to illegal drugs in their mother's womb.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: Addiction is the Pied Piper of crime in America. Drugs and alcohol are implicated in three-fourths of the nation's murders and more than half the rapes, child molestations and assaults, to say nothing of millions of related robberies and vandalism.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: A fundamental shift in society's culture is critical. A free society with modern communications is capable of such a shift. Witness the change in American attitudes toward smoking.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: A saturation campaign of information, entertainment and education is key. Here, none has greater opportunity or responsibility than those who work in the visual media.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: The potential of television and films for good has been repeatedly demonstrated. The impact of an individual film on attitudes of Americans can be stunning: ''Gentlemen's Agreement'' and ''The Lost Weekend'' on our attitudes toward, respectively, anti-Semitism and alcoholics; ''Rain Man'' and ''Children of a Lesser God'' on the way we view autistic children and the deaf.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: A major cultural shift must be accompanied by long-term investments in basic research.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: Nowhere does our quixotic quest for instant victory over drugs hurt more than in our refusal to commit sufficient resources to research.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: For the nation's $300 billion problem, the Government is investing only $500 million in all research on addiction. This includes the hunt for heroin substitutes less debilitating than methadone and new drugs to reduce the craving for cocaine and crack; finding ways to quit smoking and avoid abusing addictive prescription drugs; understanding alcoholism, multiple addiction and the genetics and psychology of addiction; and developing effective prevention and treatment programs.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: The odds against beating addiction underscore the importance of such research. Of the millions of addicts and substance abusers, no more than 10 percent will receive treatment. Of those who enter treatment, typically fewer than 25 percent complete the program. Even among those few who do finish, less than half are drug- or alcohol-free one to five years later. These treatments should be continued but recognized for the long shot therapies they are.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: Addiction is a perplexing major league killer and crippler, right up there with the diseases it breeds: cancer, heart and circulatory illnesses and AIDS. Each of these diseases has a budget at the National Institutes of Health that exceeds $1 billion. Research into addiction deserves at least that much.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: Congress should establish a National Institute of Addiction in the National Institutes of Health. This would help generate research funds, make clear our national commitment and attract more of our best scientists to the effort, just as the National Cancer Institute has done for that disease.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: Since 1980, the Government has spent $2.2 trillion on defense. Over that same period, it has spent $21 billion for its various wars on drugs. In all five years of World War II, we suffered fewer than 300,000 battlefield deaths. Each year, the death toll of alcoholism, drug abuse and nicotine addiction is almost twice that number.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: The cruelest manifestation of our refusal to confront addiction is our failure to give hope to the most vulnerable of our citizens, particularly poor blacks and Hispanics. For too long, we have condemned them to a subterranean prison without bars, from which the only escape appears to be working in the drug trade.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: Fear of punishment is not sufficient to motivate these people. Society must offer them a social and educational system that provides a realistic chance to develop their talents and share in our economic prosperity.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: Mounting a serious attack on addiction will be costly and frustrating. We will make plenty of mistakes. But fear of failure should not lead us to the despair of legalization. What we should fear above all is the judgment of God and history if we, the most affluent people on earth, free to act as we choose, choose not even to try. Particularly as easing world tensions allow us to curtail defense spending, failure to commit our energies and resources to a comprehensive and persistent effort to confront addiction in America is unconscionable.
title: Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3

text: The ramshackle encampment of the homeless in Tompkins Square Park is drawing mounting criticism from residents of the Lower East Side, a community where rioting broke out last year when the police tried to sweep the homeless from the park.
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: Park and police officials are making plans to remove the tents and makeshift shelters that have given the park the look of a nomad encampment, probably next week. Under a plan worked out with neighborhood officials, a social service office has been opened in the park with city, state and voluntary agenicies trying to move some of the homeless people into shelters or detoxification programs.
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: ''We were very surprised by the response,'' said Miriam Friedlander, the City Council member from the Lower East Side, who helped set up the new center. ''We've had about 60 direct referrals. It's been very helpful.''
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: ''The results so far have been extraordinarily positive,'' agreed Jack T. Linn, an assistant parks commissioner who is supervising the Tompkins Square operation. ''This is the humane way of addressing the problem.'' Residents' Increasing Complaints
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: The park now is a remarkable sight. Ragtag huts and tents, many of them surrounded by garbage or piles of broken grocery carts or other odd possesions, now dot the 10.5-acre park. Smoke drifts from fires set in trash barrels. Clumps of raggedly dressed people mill about. The other day a man who had built a lean-to around the park bench he slept on was grilling and selling kebabs from his perch.
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: There have been mounting complaints from residents of the blocks surrounding the park that it has become a center of drug abuse, prostitution and crime, and that it has become unusable for the neighborhood. Although the area has a long leftist tradition, almost reflexively anti-authoritarian, it appears that any police action would take place in an atmosphere different from August 1988, when rioting was sparked by a police sweep to roust the homeless from the park.
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: ''The initial sympathy many had for the plight of the homeless was sorely tested by the reality of an occupied park,'' Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said. ''We have been getting mail from people, including very liberal, very humane people who help the homeless.
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: ''As the occupiers became emboldened, they began to view themselves as the rightful occupants, and members of the public became intruders,'' Mr. Stern said. ''The situation was deteriorating, the occupation had been increasing, the shelters were becoming more permanent, park underbrush and shrubbery were being used as firewood. Increasingly, neighborhood people felt intimidated when they tried to use the park.'' A Desire for Balance
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: Ms. Friedlander said public opinion ''ranges all the way from those who want the park immediately swept clean to those who want the park untouched.''
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: ''A lot of people want the park back in balance,'' she said. ''It was getting out of whack. Day-care centers could not go into the park because of the increase in drug trade, drugs were moving in under cover of the homeless. We want to make the park a full community park.''
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: Both Mr. Stern and Ms. Friedlander emphasized that, in deference to community sentiment, even after the planned sweep, Tompkins Square would continue to be the only park in the city without a curfew.
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: ''This community voted not to have a curfew,'' Ms. Friedlander said. ''The homeless will still come and sleep in the park. But they will not be taking over the entire park.''
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: ''There will be no curfew, but no structures,'' Mr. Stern said. ''We'll see how that works. If the structures reappear, and it's a constant struggle, we'll have to see.''
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: One indication of the changing attitude on the Lower East Side is the formation of an organization called the Tompkins Square Neighborhood Coalition to press for the removal of the tents and to fight what it sees as intimidation by a group of self-styled anarchists who support the tent city. 'Park Has Become Hostage'
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: One of the leaders of the new group, Sam Turvey, said there was ''increasing concern that the park be put on some kind of even footing, as a place that is usable to people.
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: ''Before the August '88 riot, there were approximately 20 to 30 homeless people living in the park,'' Mr. Turvey said. ''While nobody likes that, it's a citywide problem, and nobody was too upset. But since the riot, the park has become hostage to a purported activist homeless group. The entire park has been taken over. Sanitary conditions are deplorable; in some areas there's obvious drug use. It's a quantum leap. People in the neighborhood think this is too much.''
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: Mr. Turvey and a number of other neighborhood residents said the anarchist group had disrupted public meetings by throwing cat feces and other objects, smoking marijuana, shouting abuse and, among other things, appearing with tires emblazoned with the names of local officials whom they said should be ''necklaced,'' like those accused of Government collaboration in South Africa. The last Community Board meeting was held under tight police guard.
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: The pastors of four churches bordering the park who minister to the homeless, however, have objected to the city's plan to remove the tents. They have urged that the shelters not be removed until the city opens at least 10 abandoned city-owned buildings in the neighborhood and helps rehabilitate them for the homeless. Clannish Groups of People
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: ''They are there because of the crisis in housing,'' said the Rev. George Kuhn of St. Bridget's Roman Catholic Church. ''There is a certain amount of truth that the park is not a park for all the people. There is a problem in that it's not a pretty scene. But it's connected with the crisis the city is in, the crisis of housing, of drugs. Because we have no housing, there is a park that is not pretty.''
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: In the park the other day, the macadam paths were spotted with frozen puddles. The homeless people were huddled in clannish groups in little clumps in various parts of the park, one group of about 15 lay wrapped in blankets near the bandshell at the southern end of the park.
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: A man who gave his name as Tony and seemed to be a leader of the group said they all hated the city-run shelters because ''its like living in a rat hole, a dog den.''
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: ''We may be homeless, but we are not helpless,'' he said. ''We cannot live in filth.''
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: The population of the park has fallen in recent days, in part because of the cold and the threat of eviction. Some longtime residents have departed because they do not get along with the newcomers. The police recently cleared the southeastern corner because it became a center of drug dealing and use. Mr. Linn, the parks official, said the census taken early each morning showed 136 people living there on Nov. 20, the day the outreach center opened, and 80 last Friday.
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: But Robert M. Hayes of the Coalition for the Homeless warned that ''outreach is little help when there is nowhere to bring people after you've reached out.''
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: ''The need is for alternative housing,'' he said. ''This is not a solution. All it does is move the battleground from this park to that subway station to that public plaza.''
title: Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines

text: The owner of a pit bull dog went on trial today in the death of a toddler who was mauled after wandering close to the animal, which prosecutors contend was guarding 243 marijuana plants.
title: Murder Trial Opens for Owner of Killer Dog

text: Jury selection began in Santa Clara County Superior Court for Michael Berry, 39 years old, of Morgan Hill who is charged with second-degree murder for the June 13, 1987, death of his 2-year-old neighbor, James Soto.
title: Murder Trial Opens for Owner of Killer Dog

text: Dale Sanderson, the Deputy District Attorney said a murder conviction is possible for someone who showed wanton disregard for life. Investigators found magazines on dog fighting and a dog-size conditioning treadmill in Mr. Berry's house.
title: Murder Trial Opens for Owner of Killer Dog

text: The boy's father, Arthur, said he and his wife had left the boy on their patio and when they returned, they found James being ''torn apart'' by the dog in their neighbor's unfenced yard.
title: Murder Trial Opens for Owner of Killer Dog

text: The prosecutor and officials of the Humane Society of the United States said the trial was the first in which a pet owner has been charged with murder because of an animal's actions. In 1987, a Georgia man was sentenced to five years in prison for involuntary manslaughter after three of his pit bulls killed a 4-year-old boy in 1987.
title: Murder Trial Opens for Owner of Killer Dog

text: Economists say the cost of illicit drugs to American society has risen substantially in the last few years, to far more than $60 billion annually. At the same time they are discovering vast new areas of additional economic impact that they are only now beginning to understand.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: The new estimate for the annual total cost is based on the first major Federal study since 1984 of the adverse economic effects of drug addiction, and according to the researchers it represents an increase since 1985 of more than $10 billion, even after discounting for inflation. Increased medical costs for crack addicts and drug-addicted AIDS patients represent a significant portion of the rising expense.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: ''It's clear that for 1989, the cost of drugs on society is tremendous, far more than $60 billion,'' said Dorothy Rice, a former director of national health statistics at the Federal Department of Health and Human Services and a medical economist who was commissioned by the Government to conduct the study. Full details of the report will not be released until next month, but officials made known its major findings in recent interviews.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: The newly detected areas of economic impact - unexpectedly large cash surpluses that have appeared in some Federal Reserve Banks and artificially altered real estate values -are being explored on campuses and at Government agencies that are trying to set drug, health, economic and foreign policies and enforcing existing laws against money laundering. The medical bills for drug abusers and victims of drug-related crimes, along with the expenses incurred in expanding law enforcement systems, are other important factors adding to the increased costs.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: Economists say the current estimates do in fact amount to a staggering price tag. Medical experts compare the drug cost to the enormous economic effects of the nation's battle against cancer, which the American Cancer Society estimates at about $70 billion annually. Offset by Cigarette Taxes
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: A recent Rand Corporation study pointed out that the price paid by society for cigarette smoking is completely offset by Federal and state taxes on cigarette sales, but there are no similar revenues generated by illegal drugs.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: The costs to some extent are offset at least in the short term by large amounts of cash accumulated by the illegal drug industry, which invests much of that money in legitimate enterprises. But no one knows how to assess that effect, and it is believed to be short-lived.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: ''The study means that narcotics is one of America's major industries, right up there with consumer electronics, automobiles and steelmaking,'' said Robert B. Reich, a political economist at the John F. Kennedy School of Goverment at Harvard University. ''Unlike our other major industries, however, the narcotics industry doesn't have a net effect of creating wealth. It makes us all substantially poorer. In fact, it is like a reverse industry, tearing things down rather than producing anything.''
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: Economists readily acknowledge that figures in economic research on drugs are always difficult to obtain. ''It's a very, very tough area to work in because of the assumptions that have to be made and the available data,'' said Al Harwood, an official at the National Institute on Drug Abuse in Rockville, Md., who has been overseeing the latest study.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: But he said the recent analyses were more accurate because of advances in gathering basic data and computerizing statistics. More specific costs of drug-related treatment are now available, for example, as well as better information on worker absenteeism and drug-related budgets for local, state and Federal criminal enforcement programs. The Cost for Addicted Infants
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: One cost growing at an alarming rate is treatment for infants addicted to drugs, said Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, who notes that intensive-care costs alone last year reached $2.5 billion. He said Federal and local governments would soon be spending $15 billion annually to prepare addicted children to enter kindergarten and at least $6 billion more a year to get them through high school.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: It is in the broader areas of international and local economies that experts are seeing effects they had not been fully aware of or studied before.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: The sudden flow of large amounts of cash in and out of the banking centers of some urban areas is believed to be related to illegal drug profits that are ultimately draining money out of local economies, though where and how is not known.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: According to a report by the Federal Reserve, for the first six months of 1989, the Miami Federal Reserve branch reported a cash surplus of $2.8 billion, Los Angeles $2.7 billion, Jacksonville $1.5 billion and San Antonio $1.2 billion. Houston, El Paso and New Orleans all experienced large increases of cash surpluses as well, from 219 percent to 56 percent. Surpluses in Miami and Los Angeles are growing by 10 percent annually.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: The Federal Reserve says it believes that these surpluses are drug related, especially since the increases coincide with record-breaking drug seizures in these cities. Hard Cash Disappears
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: A more direct effect is the disappearance of hard cash. Over all, the drug industry is contributing to the unaccounted loss of billions in currency from the economy. Experts estimate that perhaps $125 billion in American currency is ''missing.'' Much of it is said to be used in illegal drug and arms transactions, often winding up in foreign banks and markets. It forms the basis for an enormous tax-free underground economy.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: According to a study by the Treasury Department, the preferred denominations for drug transactions are $10 and $20 bills. The study, which examined the possibility of withdrawing $100 notes from the economy, says law enforcement agencies around the nation say that $100 notes account for 25 to 30 percent of the currency seized in drug raids and arrests.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: New patterns of flight capital, particularly from Peru, Colombia and Bolivia, are also being perceived by economists. Most of the cocaine smuggled into the United States and Europe is processed from coca plants grown in the Andes. Drug Profits Invested
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: The Latin drug dealers have traditionally moved a substantial share of their profits out of their relatively poor and unstable countries, adding to economic and political difficulties there, and reinvested the money in apparently legitimate enterprises in North America and Europe. A major share now, however, is going to Hong Kong, where the money is said to be easier to conceal. Indeed, officials say, Hong Kong has become an international center for drug-money laundering.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: Experts estimate that as much as $250 billion in assets owned by Latin Americans is invested abroad. A recent report by the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control concludes that most of the world's cocaine profits do not return to producer countries but are invested in tax havens, offshore bank accounts and real estate abroad.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: In those instances where some money does remain in these drug producing nations, it is not used to help build a solid economy. ''Cocaine traffickers are not captains of industry like the Harrimans, Rockefellers and Carnegies of yore,'' said Rensselaer W. Lee 3d, a consultant who is teaching at George Washington University. The way the narcotics traders ''invest'' their money locally, he added, was in bribing law enforcement officials, operating assassination squads and buying arms. A Lift for Peasants
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: Nevertheless, the report by the House Select Committee notes, the cocaine industry has ''revolutionized expectations and aspirations within Andean societies, for peasants especially.'' It added, ''Television sets, videocassette recorders, stereos and cars have become attainable.''
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: Thus the cocaine trade has spawned new constituencies that place new demands on Andean political systems. And, as Mr. Lee put it, entire regions of South America have come to depend economically on coca cultivation.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: In Boliva alone, where the export of legal goods is about $800 million each year, illegal cocaine exports may exceed that amount. As a result, the drug industry has become an institutionalized source of many jobs. It is estimated that 1.5 million people are employed in Andian production of cocaine and as many as 50,000 work in marijuana production in Colombia alone. 'A Safety Valve'
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: So for the short term at least, the drug industry clearly has some value, both economically and as a temporary relief from political tensions. ''Cocaine has acted as a safety valve for the Andean countries where the economy fails to deliver,'' Mr. Lee said. ''This substitution is most advanced in Peru and Bolivia, which have performed poorly on nearly every economic front in this decade.''
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: The broad effect of drug-money laundering on local economies in the United States is being seen by bank regulators who have discovered unusually large numbers of cash sales of real estate, automobiles and boats evidently financed with drug money. In Dade County, Fla., economists have estimated that as much as 2 to 10 percent of the area's business boom has been driven by drug profits, often transacted in cash.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: ''Either there's a lot of tourists not using credit cards or there's lots of drug money,'' said Dexter Lehtinen, the United States Attorney in Miami. Mr. Lehtinen said that in Miami, some $220 million in cash has been spent on automobiles in the last three years, while Jacksonville and Tampa had about $24 million in cash sales of cars in the same period. And in parts of southern Florida as much as 20 percent of the transactions for real estate are in cash. Inflated Prices Seen
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: Some local officials and prosecutors say that while these sales may prove lucrative to sellers, they have the effect of inflating the price of real estate and causing property taxes to increase as assessments go up. Of course, values of many inner-city properties are also seriously deflated because of the drug business.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: Real estate transactions represent only a small piece of drug investments. As regulatory barriers that had limited international investments are being removed, and as stock and currency markets become global, narcotics profiteers are finding it easier to conceal their illegally earned wealth.
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: ''The transferring of profits to avoid tax liability, and hedge and insurance trading are becoming commonplace,'' said R. Thomas Naylor, a professor at McGill University in Montreal who specializes in the underground economy. ''There has become a blurring of the line between the behavior of legal and illegal money.''
title: The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year

text: The police have charged a 24-year-old man in the slaying of Preston (Little Man) Simmons, a 14-year-old marijuana peddler, on Thanksgiving Day in the sprawling East Bronx housing project where both lived.
title: Man Is Held in Youth's Killing

text: The suspect, Sindonti Noiis of 2160 Seward Avenue, was arrested in a hallway of Castle Hill Houses where Preston had been killed in a courtyard at 8:15 P.M. on Nov. 23, a police spokesman, Sgt. Maurice Howard, said.
title: Man Is Held in Youth's Killing

text: Mr. Noiis was taken into custody at 8:30 P.M. on Friday and charged with second-degree murder after a witness picked him out of a lineup at the 43d precinct, Sergeant Howard said.
title: Man Is Held in Youth's Killing

text: The police have given this account of the events on the night of Thanksgiving: The victim, returning home from his girlfriend's apartment in the same project, encountered his marijuana supplier behind 635 Castle Hill Avenue. While talking to him, a group of at least four men approached, and one of them pulled a 9-millimeter automatic handgun from his waist. He shot the youth once in the head, once in the body and then nine more times. #140 Young Victims No weapon had been recovered as of last night, and the investigation was continuing, Sergeant Howard said.
title: Man Is Held in Youth's Killing

text: After the shooting, relatives and friends of the victim said they believed he was killed because he threatened to break with his supplier and go into the business on his own. Although the supplier was not a suspect, the police questioned him at length and reported that he had a record of drug arrests.
title: Man Is Held in Youth's Killing

text: Preston was the the latest of nearly 140 homicide victims aged 18 or under this year in New York City, the police said. Nearly 10 precent of the city's homicides were in that age group in the last three years.
title: Man Is Held in Youth's Killing

text: At Castle Hill, a complex of 12-story buildings, residents say that the low-income project had become overrun with crack dealers.
title: Man Is Held in Youth's Killing

text: The driver of a chartered bus on which two ABC executives were killed when it was struck by a commuter train last Monday had about five grams of marijuana in his possession, the police said Friday. They said the driver, Patrick Cang, 34 years old, had a carrying case on his bus that contained the marijuana and a pipe. Kurt Sanger, 50, of New York and Adele Roffis, 61, of Los Angeles died in the crash.
title: Marijuana in Bus Driver's Bag

text: By M. A. Farber With Don Terry
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: In midafternoon on Aug. 3, Randal Swanson, a 29-year-old baker from West Caldwell, N.J., steered his black Toyota along West 162d Street in Manhattan, between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue, looking to buy cocaine.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: It took only seconds, he recalled last week.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: ''As soon as they saw my New Jersey plates, they ran over to the car,'' he said. ''I said what I wanted and I got it. I had $35 in my hand and we swapped. I barely stopped the car.''
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: But two or three blocks later, Mr. Swanson was stopped - snared in a Police Department Tactical Narcotics Team operation. At a red light, he was arrested by officers who, he said, threatened to ''blow my head off if I moved.'' His car was confiscated.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Throughout the year, thousands of people who live and work outside New York City - plumbers and doctors, homemakers and laboratory technicians, clerks and tile workers - pour into Washington Heights, Inwood and Harlem in Manhattan; the South Bronx; the Flatbush section of Brooklyn; the eastern end of the Rockaways in Queens, all in search of drugs.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: They come from the middle-class or blue-collar reaches of northern New Jersey, from Nassau and Westchester and Rockland Counties, because the price or the quality of the drugs in New York City is often better than at home.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: They come because the supply of cocaine or crack or heroin is temporarily short in White Plains or Jersey City or because, at odd hours of the night, when the need for a high may be pressing, dealers in the city are still awake and doing business.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: They come because they do not want to be seen buying drugs in their own town.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: And they come, frequently in pairs and carrying knives if not guns, despite the risks from those selling drugs -and from those trying to get drugs off the streets.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: In some of the toughest neighborhoods in the city, the outsiders are valued customers, people who, for the most part, have enough cash and do not want to quibble or linger. It is easy, say both the police and the buyers, to get almost any drug in these quick, anonymous transactions.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: It is not so easy, at times, to get home. Three Who Died Violently
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: On Nov. 12, around 5:40 A.M., a 33-year-old woman from Weehawken, N.J., Janet Pierro, was shot to death while driving with her 4-year-old son near West 141st Street and Hamilton Place in Harlem. The police believe she was trying to buy heroin. The child was not injured.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Last December, a 24-year-old man from New Rochelle, N.Y., Willie Schaffer, was shot to death, and two friends were wounded, about 4 A.M. in the High Bridge section of the Bronx. The police said the three, as well as a companion who was beaten up, appeared to be seeking drugs.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: In April 1988, a 32-year-old woman from Fairview, N.J., Lidia Ferraro, was shot to death by five police officers after a chase ended at 2 A.M. at Park Avenue and 124th Street in East Harlem. A toxicological examination showed cocaine and heroin in Mrs. Ferraro's body. A grand jury concluded that although the woman turned out to be unarmed, the officers were justified in using deadly force. The Ports of Entry Over the Bridge, Through the Tunnels
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: The police believe that upper Manhattan, particularly the Washington Heights section just east of the George Washington Bridge, is a prime locus for drug purchases by suburban residents and those from nearby cities.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: In the year ended last August, the Port Authority police made 763 drug arrests at the George Washington Bridge, 694 at the Lincoln Tunnel and 146 at the Holland Tunnel. Most of the arrests occurred between 8 P.M. and 1 A.M., and most of the cars were returning to New Jersey.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Henry I. DeGeneste, Superintendent of the Port Authority police, said the people arrested ''run the whole socio-economic scale,'' with those at the lower end of the scale caught at the Holland Tunnel, those in the middle at the Lincoln Tunnel and people at the upper end of the scale at the George Washington Bridge, which is used by residents of some of New Jersey's wealthiest counties. Much of the Lincoln Tunnel traffic is bound for the Times Square area, the police say, and the Holland Tunnel is a frequent route to drug sellers on the Lower East Side and in Greenwich Village. The Arrests 3,234 Cars Seized In Three Years
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Superintendent DeGeneste said that while some drug buyers are caught at roadblocks set up to catch drunken drivers, most drug arrests by the Port Authority police begin with a car being stopped for speeding or making unsafe lane changes on the way back to New Jersey. On occasion, undercover officers who see a drug purchase in the city will radio ahead to the Port Authority or New Jersey police, giving them the buyer's license plate number.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: ''Basically that's how we come in contact with them,'' he said. ''They're in such a damn hurry to get back to their communities. It's amazing how often we find drugs just sitting on the seats. They don't think they're going to get stopped.''
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Superintendent DeGeneste added that many of those arrested appear to be high and do not have the presence of mind to conceal the narcotics they are carrying. In addition to making arrests, the police and the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration in mid-1986 began confiscating cars - usually from drug buyers rather than sellers -in which drugs were found.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: From then until Oct. 31, 3,234 cars had been seized, almost half of them this year. More than 1,500 of the cars were registered to owners living in New York City, 877 in New York State but outside the city, 621 in New Jersey, 31 in Connecticut and 135 elsewhere. About a quarter of the owners have been able to reclaim their cars, most often in cases where the owner was not the one arrested. The city auctioned off 767 cars, raising $490,545.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: While there is no complete profile of the owners of the confiscated cars, the police say the great majority are white, have no criminal records and range in age from late teens to early 40's. In the operation on Aug. 3, which has been repeated periodically, 102 people were arrested besides Mr. Swanson, and among the 82 cars seized 52 were from New Jersey.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Seventeen of those arrested on Aug. 3 were charged with felonies; the most severe sentence given so far was 90 days in jail. Of the 86 people charged with misdemeanors, the longest term was 23 days.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Capt. Robert J. Curley, commander of the Tactical Narcotics Team in upper Manhattan, said that while dealers in Washington Heights supplied wholesale quantities of drugs over several police precincts and beyond, most of the buyers from outside the city appeared to be interested in small quantities, up to a gram or two, for ''casual, personal use.'' Still, he said, ''these people help to drive the drug trade.'' A New Jersey Baker At Home, the Price Is Twice as High
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Mr. Swanson, the New Jersey baker, described himself as just such an occasional user of drugs.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: He said in an interview that he started coming into upper Manhattan to buy drugs about a year ago, with a friend who had been doing the same. The availability of drugs in the city was one factor, he said. But the main reason he came was to reduce his cost by eliminating a middleman.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: ''If I bought in New Jersey what I bought in New York,'' he said, ''the price would be twice as much. And the stuff wouldn't be as good. Getting it in New York seemed simple and easy.''
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Mr. Swanson said that before his Aug. 3 arrest, he had been arrested once before in the city for having drugs. He said he was ''let go because it was a first offense,'' and afterward he refrained for months from coming into the city for drugs.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: When he returned, he was surprised at being caught, considering, he said, that ''it's such a large market, so many people doing it.'' Mr. Swanson, who is married and has two children, agreed to plead guilty to a lesser charge, disorderly conduct. Now, he said, he plans to give up drugs.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: ''I was in the wrong, no doubt about it,'' he said. ''I was foolish. I learned my lesson.''
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: For others, especially those addicted to drugs, the lessons have come harder.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Three people from outside the city who have gone into treatment at Daytop Village recently described their experiences buying drugs in the city. Their stories illustrate the reasons for this variant on commuter traffic and the dangers in it. A Former Student 'It's Amazing I Didn't Get Killed'
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Eric Z., 24, a thin, blond former student at Rockland Community College, grew up in Rockland County. He started coming to the city to buy drugs while still in high school ''because it was fun,'' he said. He went at all hours to the streets around Yankee Stadium in the Bronx and to the side streets off Second Avenue in East Harlem. Eventually he bought heroin in Washington Heights, in abandoned buildings where ''pitchers'' would weigh out the heroin on scales and ''catchers'' would take his money.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: ''It's amazing I didn't get killed,'' he said. He was beaten up and robbed one night near Webster Avenue in the Bronx while his girlfriend sat a distance away in his 1979 Buick. He was stopped by the police on the Palisades Interstate Parkway, with syringes on the floor of his car, but managed to toss them out of sight. Another time, a friend swallowed a bag of heroin when a police car pulled alongside Eric's.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Occasionally Eric was sold tainted drugs. He lined up for drugs outside holes in the walls of buildings, speaking to other buyers only to ''find out what's good, where the best was that day.'' For protection he carried a knife. But once he was addicted to both heroin and cocaine, Eric said, he lost all fear of being in rough city neighborhoods and noticed that many of the other buyers, too, were ''more afraid of the cops than of the locals.'' At new spots, he often had to ''show my track marks to prove I wasn't a cop.''
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar
