text: Eric, who said he sometimes made two or three trips a day to the city for drugs, said he was able to support his $150-a-day habit by stealing jewelry at a store where he worked and by selling drugs, at a markup, to others in Rockland County. A Jersey City Commuter Drugs, Too, for Sale In Diamond District
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Kim P., who is 29 and has lived all her life in Jersey City, bought cocaine on West 47th Street, in Manhattan's diamond district, when she worked in the area in 1988 as a dental assistant. ''It was over one of those watch places,'' she said, ''and they only took certain people.'' When she was ''really desperate,'' she recalled, she bought cocaine along West 42d Street, near the Port Authority Bus Terminal. ''But that was mostly junk,'' she said, ''a ripoff.''
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: As recently as July, Kim drove with male friends or acquaintances - never alone - over the George Washington Bridge to buy drugs near West 134th Street or in the Bronx. ''If you saw crowds at 3 A.M.,'' she said, ''you knew they were selling.''
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: In New York, Kim said, ''you could get drugs at any hour.'' In Jersey City, at night, the dealers might themselves be in New York. ''It all comes down to convenience and urgency,'' she said. ''The risk doesn't matter. You don't think about it.'' A New Jersey Carpenter 'You Do Anything To Get That Hit'
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Dennis M., 30, a carpenter and former subway conductor in the city, grew up in Brooklyn and now lives in Sayreville, N.J. But on frequent visits back to Brooklyn, he said, he would smoke cocaine with friends. Often he took drugs home with him across the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge or through the Holland Tunnel.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: In recent months he began using crack and, finding none in the New Jersey bars where powdered cocaine was plentiful, bought crack in Flatbush. ''You do anything to get that hit,'' he said. He was soon stealing cars and was holed up in a crack house. He had, as he put it, ''hit rock bottom.''
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Patricia B., 22, is a New York City resident. But she grew up in the leafy, suburban-flavored Riverdale section of the Bronx, a world away from the streets to which drugs took her. For six years she attended one of the city's most distinguished college preparatory schools, Horace Mann in Riverdale, and graduated from York Preparatory School in Manhattan, another private school. She started classes at Pace University. But, as she recalled, she might as well having been living ''on death row.'' 'Just Wanted to Get High'
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Patricia began using marijuana at 12, was sniffing cocaine by high school, and ''just wanted to get high and be left alone.'' By the time she was in college and working in a bagel store, she had her own apartment in Riverdale. A neighbor, Patricia said, ''turned me and my boyfriend on to crack.''
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: From then on, she said, her life was governed by the need for drugs. That meant constant forays - sometimes several times a night -into the drug markets of Inwood and Harlem and the South Bronx. When she lacked money, she said, she stole from her family, and she and her boyfriend worked out a way to rob gypsy cab drivers, some of whom chased them with bats. One night, ''after a few hits'' of drugs, she said, she was brutally attacked by a man to whom she was selling a chain.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Finally, when her weight had dropped to 88 pounds and, she said, ''I was ready to crack,'' a friend who had undergone treatment at Daytop Village persuaded her to go there. She is still in treatment, but has a job. A Four-Minute Transaction A Quick Conference At a Fruit Market
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Despite the efforts of law-enforcement agencies, it still seems as easy to find an out-of-towner buying drugs in upper Manhattan as it is to find drugs themselves. And in all weather.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: At 4:10 P.M. the other day, as the sky darkened and a biting wind swept the corner of Amsterdam Avenue and West 166th Street, and ''lookouts'' huddled in the doorway of the white stucco New Jerusalem Baptist Church, ready to shout ''bahando'' - ''coming down'' - if they spied the police, a blue Toyota Supra with New Jersey plates pulled up to the corner.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: The driver stayed in the car, keeping the motor on. A gaunt woman emerged and hurried across Amsterdam Avenue to confer with a man in a baseball cap in front of Rosa's Fruit and Meat Market. The man left her for a minute, and the woman bounced up and down in the chill. The man returned. The woman dashed back to the Toyota. At 4:14 P.M., the car was gone.
title: Buying Drugs: The Commuter Customers - A special report: Out-of-Towners Find New York City a Drug Bazaar

text: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh proposed regulations today that would allow the Government to impose civil fines of up to $10,000 for possessing small amounts of marijuana and other illegal drugs for personal use.
title: Thornburgh Asks Stiff Civil Fines In Cases of Small Drug Amounts

text: The regulations, called for in the anti-drug law that was passed last year by Congress, provide an alternative to prosecuting individuals in Federal court for simple possession of small amounts of the drugs.
title: Thornburgh Asks Stiff Civil Fines In Cases of Small Drug Amounts

text: Federal criminal law provides a one-year sentence and a fine of up to $5,000 for simple drug possession, although a defendant already convicted of another crime could receive a sentence of up to two years in prison and a fine of up to $10,000.
title: Thornburgh Asks Stiff Civil Fines In Cases of Small Drug Amounts

text: But few people are prosecuted under Federal law for simple possession of small amounts of drugs. And of those who are, said the Justice Department's spokesman, David Runkel, most stand trial in connection with other Federal criminal charges. How Rules Would Work
title: Thornburgh Asks Stiff Civil Fines In Cases of Small Drug Amounts

text: Under the civil regulations proposed by Mr. Thornburgh, the Attorney General could cite individuals for drug possession and impose a fine of up to $10,000. The citation could be challenged at a hearing before an administrative law judge.
title: Thornburgh Asks Stiff Civil Fines In Cases of Small Drug Amounts

text: An individual could also appeal the civil citation in a Federal court, which would conduct a jury trial.
title: Thornburgh Asks Stiff Civil Fines In Cases of Small Drug Amounts

text: The civil penalties would be invoked on individuals possessing no more than a gram of heroin, cocaine or methamphetamine or an ounce of marijuana and smaller amounts of PCP and LSD.
title: Thornburgh Asks Stiff Civil Fines In Cases of Small Drug Amounts

text: The civil penalties would not apply to individuals previously convicted of possessing the same drug or those who have been twice cited for civil violations under the regulations.
title: Thornburgh Asks Stiff Civil Fines In Cases of Small Drug Amounts

text: Civil proceedings could not be invoked as an alternative to criminal prosecution if investigators found evidence of an intention to sell or distribute drugs.
title: Thornburgh Asks Stiff Civil Fines In Cases of Small Drug Amounts

text: The regulations will be published in The Federal Register and then put out for public comment for 30 days. The Justice Department has not said when they will take effect. But when they do, they will be carried out first on a trial basis in one or two Federal districts that have not yet been selected. Critical View of Proposal
title: Thornburgh Asks Stiff Civil Fines In Cases of Small Drug Amounts

text: Don Fiedler, national director of the National Organization for Reform of Marijuana Laws, called the regulations an ''end run around the Constitution'' because the probable-cause standard in criminal law would not apply in the civil proceedings.
title: Thornburgh Asks Stiff Civil Fines In Cases of Small Drug Amounts

text: Mr. Fiedler said the regulations raised many questions about how a person cited for drug violations could challenge the legality of a search. He predicted that they would ''create a tremendous amount of litigation.''
title: Thornburgh Asks Stiff Civil Fines In Cases of Small Drug Amounts

text: ''If you go to civil proceedings, there is no basis of authority to come in with a motion to suppress the search based on constitutional grounds,'' he said.
title: Thornburgh Asks Stiff Civil Fines In Cases of Small Drug Amounts

text: Mr. Fiedler, whose group advocates decriminalizing marijuana, said the regulations effectively accomplish that goal. But he acknowledged that a $10,000 fine is a significant deterrent to possessing illegal drugs, even in small amounts.
title: Thornburgh Asks Stiff Civil Fines In Cases of Small Drug Amounts

text: To the Editor: I am deeply grateful to Brendan Gill for detailing in public what many of us at Sarah Lawrence College privately knew all along about Joseph Campbell. Because Campbell has been proposed as a sage for our times, it is particularly important for those of us who have a different estimate of the man and his work to speak up. Mr. Gill's account of Campbell's scholarship, his politics and his views seems to me accurate. I offer a single anecdote from my experience by way of verifying his anti-Semitism.
title: Joseph Campbell Mixed Bigotry and Inspiration; His Anti-Semetism

text: I joined the literature faculty at Sarah Lawrence in 1968. With other younger faculty members, I was strongly opposed to the war in Vietnam, and I considered myself - as I do today - to be on the left. Campbell tended to keep his distance from this group, whose values he more or less correctly perceived - and disliked.
title: Joseph Campbell Mixed Bigotry and Inspiration; His Anti-Semetism

text: It was my good or ill fortune, however, to find that Campbell was disposed to be friendly to me. One reason for this was that I had, in 1967, completed a doctoral dissertation that, he had been told, made substantial use (I am embarrassed to confess it) of his book ''The Hero With a Thousand Faces.'' But I think Campbell was also disposed to be friendly to me because, in those days, I usually wore a coat and tie to teach, and this was not the costume he associated with leftists and war protesters; and because, when we happened to meet at some faculty function, I usually had a drink in my hand, and he had the notion that leftists and war protesters had sworn off alcohol for the relentless consumption of marijuana.
title: Joseph Campbell Mixed Bigotry and Inspiration; His Anti-Semetism

text: At one faculty function, in 1969 or '70, I found myself drinking with Campbell and another, older, equally right-wing teacher. At some point in the evening, Campbell, responding to a remark I can't recall, said something to the effect that he could always spot a Jew. I, a Jew, said, ''Oh?'' Whereupon Campbell went into a description of how the New York Athletic Club had ingeniously managed for years to keep Jews out. He went on and on, telling his story in the most charming and amiable fashion, without any self-consciousness about the views he was expressing and, indeed, without any overt animus - for all that he obviously relished the notion of keeping Jews out of anywhere any time, forever. As soon as I could, I said goodnight, and Campbell and I never had much to do with each other again.
title: Joseph Campbell Mixed Bigotry and Inspiration; His Anti-Semetism

text: Subsequently, in my many years at Sarah Lawrence, I heard over and over again that Campbell was contemptuous of women and that he missed few opportunities to disparage black people.
title: Joseph Campbell Mixed Bigotry and Inspiration; His Anti-Semetism

text: As in the similar case of Ezra Pound - an infinitely more talented man than Joseph Campbell - we cannot entirely separate the views of the individual from the views expressed in his texts. And some of Joseph Campbell's views were decidedly repugnant. ARNOLD KRUPAT Bronxville, N.Y., Nov. 8, 1989
title: Joseph Campbell Mixed Bigotry and Inspiration; His Anti-Semetism

text: Vicki Sherling was teacher of the year in this small southwestern Georgia town last year, respected and honored for her winning way with gifted science students at Colquitt County Senior High School.
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: But last year's teacher of the year is out of a job this year, dismissed in May on charges of ''immorality'' after being charged, along with her husband, Michael, with possession of 22 small marijuana plants that were growing in their backyard.
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: In spite of her acquittal on the criminal charges in a September trial and her husband's guilty plea and testimony that he had cultivated the plants for his own use without his wife's knowledge, the Colquitt County school board has refused to reverse itself and Mrs. Sherling is now going to court to try to get her job back.
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: The issue has thrown the town of about 15,500 people into turmoil, pitting neighbor against neighbor. Some argue that Mrs. Sherling is being unfairly punished for something that a loved one did, and others argue that she failed to live up to a responsibility to do something to end her husband's marijuana use.
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: Lawrence Chitty, a local roofing contractor, said the incident had served to highlight the intensity of fear and hatred of drugs. For others, including Mrs. Sherling, it has shown just how fragile a good reputation can be in small-town America.
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: ''I'm so clean I squeak, and they say I am immoral,'' said Mrs. Sherling, who is 38 years old. ''I have to fight that, and I won't be run out of town.''
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: Teachers have long been held to a higher standard of personal behavior than most people because of the presumption that they are role models and have tremendous influence on their students, said Michael Kramer, general counsel for the Georgia Association of Educators.
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: There were times when teachers who did not regularly attend church were seen as endangering their jobs. While that may no longer be the case, the privacy rights of teachers in areas from individual political positions to private sexual acts or orientation continue to be tested in court cases around the nation where community standards clash with constitutional protections.
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: Willam Norwood, Mrs. Sherling's lawyer, said: ''They have an obligation to tell her the exact immorality for which she was dismissed, since she was acquitted of the criminal charges. Immorality is such a vague and ambiguous term here, and we don't know whether they are saying she should have left her husband, turned him in to police or stayed with him and risked losing her job. That's a Hobson's choice if I ever heard one.''
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: Mrs. Sherling said her husband's marijuana smoking emerged about 11 years ago, and became ''a matter of friction in our marriage and the biggest argument of our lives.''
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: She said that he promised to stop and that although there was little indication that he had gone back on his word, she often suspected that he still smoked marijuana.
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: Mr. Sherling, who is a lawyer, testified at his wife's trial that he went to great lengths to hide his smoking from her, often driving in his automobile to secluded places and taking mouthwash with him to remove the smell from his breath and talcum powder to remove it from his clothing. He said the plants seized at his home were secretly planted in a covered cold frame while his wife was out of town with a group of students at a science fair.
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: In surveys of students, parents and other teachers published by the local newspaper, nearly two-thirds of those who responded support Mrs. Sherling and favor her rehiring. But Dwain Walden, editor of The Moultrie Observer, said a small, hard-core segment of the public opposed the idea.
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: ''I think frustration has a lot to do with it,'' he said. ''We are all caught up and frustrated by the drug problem and it touches us here in small towns. None of us know what to do about it, and Vicki Sherling was brushed by that problem.''
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: Mrs. Sherling said she knew that returning to the classroom would be ''no bed of roses.'' But she said the publicity she had received indicated that more people would accept her than would reject her.
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: Jimmy Howard, a senior at the high school who has been among the students who have put posters up calling for the school system to her rehire her, agreed.
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: ''I just know the kind of teacher and person she is, and it won't matter to most of us,'' he said.
title: Moultrie Journal; A Teacher Fights To Erase A Taint

text: By Jeffrey Schmalz, Special To the New York Times
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: In his first public comments since his killing of two unarmed blacks set off three days of rioting here 10 months ago, a Hispanic police officer testified today that he fired the fatal shot because ''I feared for my life - I thought I was going to be killed.''
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: The police officer, 30-year-old William Lozano, said a motorcyle carrying the two blacks, Clement Lloyd and Allan Blanchard, veered toward him as he walked onto a street at dusk on Jan. 16. The motorcycle was being pursued by a police car for speeding and running stop signs.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: ''As I turned my body to face the motorcycle, he just came straight at me,'' Officer Lozano testified at his trial on two counts of manslaughter. ''And he he just revved the motorcycle, and it made this tremendous noise like, 'Whaaa!' He was just aiming at me. I was just only able to just turn my body, draw my gun and shoot.''
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: Testifying a few minutes later, the officer said, ''I thought he was going to run me over, and I was going to be a dead person.'' Shooting Called Unnecessary
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: Officer Lozano's single shot killed the 23-year-old driver, Mr. Lloyd, instantly. His passenger, Mr. Blanchard, 24, died the next day from injuries in the motorcycle crash.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: The officer's lawyers contend that Mr. Lloyd, who was carrying marijuana and $1,514 in cash and whose blood contained alcohol, marijuana byproducts and traces of cocaine, was a drug dealer willing to kill a police officer to avoid arrest.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: Prosecutors say that the motorcycle was not headed toward Officer Lozano and that the shooting was unnecessary.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: Officer Lozano testified today that he was standing behind the open trunk of his patrol car when he noticed a police car with flashing lights in the distance. He said he did not realize, at first, that a chase was under way, and had stepped into the street to see what was going on, only to find the motorcyle almost upon him. Two-Hour Cross-Examination
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: He also said he had not heard the motorcyle approaching and did not notice that there was a passenger behind the driver.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: In a two-hour cross-examination, the chief prosecutor, John Hogan, noted that half a dozen witnesses said they had heard the motorcycle approaching and that it was difficult to believe Officer Lozano had not.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: After he had the officer re-enact drawing his gu,n - which included unsnapping the holster cover, the prosecutor argued that the drawing and shooting took several seconds - time enough, he said, for the officer to think and jump out of the motorcycle's way.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: The one defense witness who strongly supported Officer Lozano's account of events was his partner, Dawn Campbell. Mr. Hogan, citing photographs of Officer Lozano talking with other officers after the shooting, said the police had concocted a story to justify the shooting.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: Addressing the defendant, Mr. Hogan said, ''You asked Dawn Campbell to lie for you, didn't you?'' ''No, sir, no,'' Officer Lozano replied. ''Isn't there an unwritten rule among partners that they cover up for each other, even in the courtroom?'' the prosecutor asked.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: ''I would not cover up for nobody,'' Officer Lozano said. ''And she wouldn't cover up for you?'' Mr. Hogan asked.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: ''I wouldn't cover up for nobody,'' the defendant repeated. Symbol of Racial Friction
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: Officer Lozano, whose testimony concluded this afternoon, was the 49th witness in a trial that has heard 11 days of testimony and has drawn Miamians to their radios and television sets to hear the proceedings broadcast in full.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: The trial has come to symbolize the friction between black and Hispanic residents of the city. Officer Lozano, who spoke with a thick Spanish accent, is a Colombian immigrant.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: The officer said today that immediately after he killed Mr. Lloyd, in Miami's mostly black Overtown neighborhood, he was pelted with stones and bottles. He said someone in the crowd looked at him and shouted: ''Shoot him! Shoot him! Shoot him!''
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: Some blacks have threatened another riot if Officer Lozano is acquitted. Twice before in this decade, riots have broken out after police officers here have been found not guilty of killing blacks. The Miami and Dade County police have been critized by half a dozen panels for using excessive force against blacks. Some Witnesses Inconsistent
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: Some of the physical evidence in the Lozano trial was destroyed when rioting erupted immediately after the shooting. And most of the half-dozen witnesses who disputed the officer's account and said the motorcycle was not coming toward him were inconsistent in their testimony.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: For this reason, many legal experts believe the verdict will depend on how Officer Lozano's testimony was received by the jury. Throughout his testimony the officer, who wore a dark blue suit and vest, white shirt and red tie, looked directly into the eyes of the six jurors.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: The chief defense lawyer, Roy Black, portrayed Officer Lozano, who is 5 feet 7 inches tall, as a nonagressive and exemplary officer. He has been on the Miami force for five years, Mr. Black said, and has received a dozen commendations.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: But the prosecutor, Mr. Hogan, showed that most of the commendations were routine and that in his last evaluation Officer Lozano was rated ''average'' in most categories. Jai Alai Incident Recalled
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: Mr. Hogan, apparently trying to portray the officer as a hothead, cited an incident in May 1988 that the officer at first said he could not recall.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: ''You don't remember someone asking an officer for a badge number,'' Mr. Hogan asked, ''and you getting so angry because your authority had been questioned that you took the person's head, jabbed it into your badge and said, 'Here, read my badge number'?''
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: Officer Lozano then recounted the incident in detail, saying it occurred at a jai alai fronton where he was donating his time as a guard at a charity event.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: He said he had helped eject a ''violent'' jai alai worker who was on strike and had demanded to see his badge and name tag. Officer Lozano said he merely showed the man the badge and had not jabbed his head into it.
title: Miami Officer Tells Jurors Motorcyclist Aimed for Him

text: By Burton Bollag, Special To the New York Times
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: While the United States and other countries intensify their war on drugs, two European countries, Switzerland and the Netherlands, are adhering to a much more liberal approach to their drug problems.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: Zurich, Switzerland's biggest city, decided two years ago to tolerate a thriving drug scene in a park behind the central railroad station. Every day hundreds of drug addicts buy and use heroin and cocaine openly in the park, known as the Platzspitz, undisturbed by the police.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: A federally financed health center in the park distributes 6,000 syringes in exchange for used ones each day in an attempt to prevent the spread of AIDS.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: Zurich's policy has critics, and even supporters are uneasy with the bazaar-like attraction the open drug scene in the Platzspitz may have on the young. Trade in Clean Soup Spoons
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: Addicts, many gaunt and unwashed, congregate on a park promenade along the gentle, green Limmat River. Dealers walk through the crowd hawking ''sugar'' and ''cokie,'' as heroin and cocaine are called here.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: A small business has even sprung up in the park. Clean soup spoons, their handles bent back, are neatly laid out on about a half-dozen improvised tables in the promenade. After buying their dose, addicts go to the tables to boil their drug solutions in the spoons before straining them through a bit of cigarette filter and injecting them.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: In exchange, those addicts who provide the spoons get to keep the used filters. Five or six provide enough drug residue for one injectable dose.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: In Rotterdam, the Netherlands' giant port city, the police keep heroin dealers off the streets, but for the last four years one police commander has followed a policy of tolerating drug peddling in dealers' apartments in one neighborhood. Keeping Drugs 'Within Limits'
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: The police keep a close watch on the so-called house dealers and arrest them if they allow their clients to become a nuisance in the neighborhood or if they sell poor quality, adulterated heroin.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: Both cases represent a decision by the authorities that arresting or harassing drug users and small-time dealers is counterproductive. Those approaches lead to more petty crime by pushing prices up, officials said, and hinder efforts to reach addicts with social services like AIDS prevention.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: ''We've found out that when you leave drug users pretty much in peace and provide methadone, then the drug problem stays within limits,'' said Chief Inspector Tiebbe Reitsma, who has been named police chief of one of Rotterdam's six city districts. He was referring to the heroin substitute that is used to help users of the drug fight their addiction.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: Officials in both countries agreed however, that their drug problems occur in much more middle-class and homogeneous populations than that of the United States. Their solutions therefore may or may not be applicable to the American situation. Concentration on Big Dealers
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: In the Netherlands, although possession of narcotics in small quantities is technically illegal, the police follow a policy of not arresting people for that offense. Switzerland is considered likely to become the first European country to completely decriminalize the use and possession of small amounts of narcotics, possibly as early as next spring.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: Swiss officials do not suggest that decriminalization is a solution to their large drug problem. But many said it would stop the Swiss police and the courts from wasting their energies going after small fry.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: ''This is one step that may make it easier to concentrate the fight on bigger dealers and to help addicts,'' said Dr. Francois van der Linde, chairman of the Swiss Federal Drug Commission, which recommended decriminalization in a report in June.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: In Zurich, the police say the city's policy has attracted many drug users and dealers from outside Zurich and from neighboring West Germany. Needle Exchanges and AIDS
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: But the majority of officials and social workers in both countries appear to see no better solution. And they say their policies have had some measure of success.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: That is particularly true in preventing the spread of the AIDS virus through needle sharing. In Switzerland, the Netherlands and Denmark, health officials said they have had a large degree of success reducing the number of new infections by that route, which in many Western countries is a major way that AIDS is spread.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: For several years those three countries have had large, active needle-exchange programs, held in the places where addicts congregate. The needle exchanges and counseling are made possible by the liberal approach, supporters said. They said fear of arrest would otherwise keep addicts from dealing with health and social workers.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: Dutch officials said the number of heroin addicts in their country had declined in recent years. In Rotterdam, their average age has risen to about 30, officials said. ''The heroin addicts are aging,'' said Chief Inspector Reitsma. ''It seems the young people are more aware of the drug risks and are more careful.'' But he warned that the young may be turning more to cocaine. Support Services for Addicts
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: He also attributed the decrease in heroin use to the Netherlands' almost total tolerance of marijuana and hashish. That approach, many Dutch drug experts said, allows the soft drug milieu to remain separate from that of the hard drugs.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: Supporters of the liberal Dutch approach fear European integration at the end of 1992 will put more pressure on the country to come in line with the stricter approach of major European countries, especially West Germany, France and Britain.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: But Prof. Anton van Kalmthout, a criminologist at Tillberg University in the Netherlands, said that in several years the rest of Europe will adopt some of the more liberal Dutch approach. ''The AIDS panic is sweeping over Europe, and the Dutch policy is seen as the best to stem the spread of AIDS,'' he said.
title: Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug

text: Life has become a lot harder for East Germany's 8,000 customs service officers since the Berlin wall and other crossings were opened earlier this month.
title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater

text: The newly opened border with West Germany has sharpened already serious problems of smuggling and speculation with East Germany's currency, which is very weak and not legally convertible in large sums, said Gerhard Stauch, who is chief inspector of the Customs Administration.
title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater

text: Mr. Stauch, whose rank is equivalent to lieutenant general, said his men and women have been working 12 to 14 hours a day, seven days a week. At that, he said in an interview, ''We can control only 3 to 4 percent of the travelers,'' who number in the millions each day now that East Germany's borders have opened so widely.
title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater

text: As of today, his people are serving 61 crossing points for trains, river ferries and cars into West Germany, 41 of them new, as well as 16 crossings into West Berlin, 8 of them new. U.S. Soldiers Criticized
title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater

text: Smuggling and currency speculation have increased five times over the volume of 1988, Mr. Stauch continued, saying that statistics showed that the main offenders were Poles, followed by American soldiers stationed in West Berlin, Bulgarians, Hungarians, Yugoslavs and Czechoslovaks. He said there were also organized smuggling gangs of Poles working with East German intermediaries.
title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater

text: The smuggling-speculation spree has been stimulated, he explained, by the relative abundance here of consumer goods that are inexpensive because they are subsidized up to 45 percent by the East German Government; the scarcity of these goods in Poland, and an open market in West Berlin for the East German goods at cut-rate prices. In recent weeks the ''Polish Market'' in West Berlin, near the Berlin wall, has been lined daily by as many as 1,000 Poles selling everything from sausages and chocolate to women's underwear - all for hard currency.
title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater

text: Mr. Stauch said Poles come to East Germany and sell Polish costume jewelry and other trinkets. ''They take their earnings to West Berlin and exchange that for West German marks,'' he said. ''Then they buy mostly electronic products and sell those here to German Democratic Republic citizens. Then they buy consumer goods in the G.D.R. and take those back to Poland to vend there. It's double damage for us.''
title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater

text: ''We estimate that 2 billion to 2.2 billion marks worth of goods have been illegally taken out of the country this way in 1989 - and that is not even counting the subsidies involved,'' he said. ''Nor do we think it will stop when the subsidies are lifted.'' He noted that East German products like black pepper are being sold in Poland at a 1,000 percent markup. A Difficult Estimate
title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater

text: Asked to provide details on smuggling gangs, Mr. Stauch, a ruddy 65-year-old with a shock of white hair and a chest full of decorations and service medals, replied, ''It is very difficult to say how many professionals there are.''
title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater

text: As for the American soldiers, the customs chief said that their practice was to buy East German marks in West Berlin at rates of 20 for one West German mark, then come here to buy fine porcelain and other luxury goods at prices amounting to a steal. ''From our point of view, it is illegal,'' Mr. Stauch said, noting that the official rate of exchange is one to one between East and West German marks. ''But we couldn't stop them because they are protected'' as soldiers of an occupation power in West Berlin.
title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater

text: Last Friday the East German Government initiated measures to curb the smuggling and speculation by declaring it illegal for foreigners, including American soldiers, to purchase a variety of goods.
title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater

text: This placed an additional burden on the customs service, Mr. Stauch said, because many of his officers had to be posted in six department stores here and stores in 24 other East German cities. These officers are being helped by volunteers of the so-called Workers and Peasants Inspection, party members who perform on occasion as deputy sheriffs.
title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater

text: Mr. Stauch said he had been promised the addition soon of thousands of customs officers by the Government. Concern About Drug Traffic
title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater

text: The next level of problems he is anticipating is smuggling of drugs, which up to now have been brought here in small quantities by citizens of Arab and African countries, mostly through the Schonefeld International Airport south of here. The drugs of choice have included marijuana, heroin and a little cocaine.
title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater

text: East Germany is eager to cooperate with the United States and other countries in combating drugs, Mr. Stauch said, and has already accepted an appeal from Washington to join in the hunt for 12 internationally sought Colombian drug traffickers.
title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater

text: Is he sorry the borders have been opened? Mr. Stauch responded sharply. ''Not to let our citizens travel was stupidity,'' he said. ''You cannot govern people's desires by administrative means.''
title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater

text: The life and death of Preston (Little Man) Simmons, a 14-year-old marijuana peddler who was shot and killed last Thursday, is a story that has become dismally familiar in his part of the world.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: When he was executed in the courtyard of his housing project in the Bronx, he became one of almost 140 homicide victims aged 18 or under in New York City this year. For the last three years, about 10 percent of the city's homicide victims have been in that age group, many of them killed in drug-related incidents, according to police officials.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: That the case of Preston Simmons is so commonplace is what gives it special weight. His existence at the Castle Hill Houses, a sprawling public housing complex in the East Bronx, was typical of life in the underclass. And the legacy of despair he left behind provides little hope of a better life for the next generation.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Like Preston's mother and grandmother, his girlfriend will become a teen-age mother next month when she is due to deliver his child. The girlfriend, 17-year-old Denise Butler, doubts that her child's life will be much different from that of Preston, a personable youngster who made his spending money by selling $5 bags of marijuana.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: ''If he's still living around here,'' Miss Butler said of her expected child, ''I guess he'll be selling drugs, will be forced to sell drugs, or will have a lot of bad habits.''
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: The police have yet to make an arrest in Preston's case, but contend they have good leads. Although police officials are reluctant to declare the killing a drug hit, Preston's family and friends believe he was killed because he threatened to break with his marijuana supplier and set up a competing operation.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Although the man identified as Preston's supplier is not suspected as the gunman, he has been questioned at length by the police, said Sgt. William T. Kivlehan, a detective at the 43d Precinct in the Bronx. The man, who was at the site of the killing when it occurred, has a record of drug arrests.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Preston was killed at about 8:15 P.M. while walking from his girlfriend's apartment at 580 Castle Hill Avenue to his family's apartment a block away at 2120 Randall Avenue. He encountered the drug supplier and, while talking to him, was approached by a group of at least four men.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: One of them pulled a 9-millimeter automatic pistol from his waist and shot Preston twice, once in the head and once in the body, and then shot him nine more times as he fell to the snow. ''This kid was full of holes,'' said Vincent Pizzo, chief of detectives for the housing police.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Preston's friends said he sensed the danger in the drug trade, although he thought it came more from the police than from his counterparts in commerce. It was a risk he thought worth taking.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: ''I guess he did it for the reason all the young dudes do it,'' said Anthony Butler, the brother of Preston's girlfriend and one of Preston's best friends. ''He was too young to get a job and it was some quick little change in his pocket.'' Fear of Venturing Out
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Although residents of Castle Hill are accustomed to bloodshed, they were taken aback by Preston's death because of the coldness of the killing, particularly given the victim's age and his low position in the drug hierarchy.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: The incident has made children and elderly people afraid to leave their apartments and has encouraged community leaders to philosophize about the spiraling cycle of poverty and drugs that seems to pull each generation's youth farther away from hope.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: ''There is a growing fear that the drug cancer is metastasizing and it's really impacting on the young children,'' said Zalreth P. McCreath, the director of the Randall Early Learning Center, a few yards from the site of the shooting. ''It's clear that the whole family unit has broken down and what's caused it seems to be drugs.''
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: In Preston's case, it is hard to know whether drugs were the cause or the effect. From Shelter to Project
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Preston was the fourth of Ruth Simmons's seven children, who range in age from 18 years to 15 months. An eighth child died as an infant.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Ms. Simmons dropped out of high school in 11th grade, when she first got pregnant. Preston's father, Ms. Simmons said, was an abusive drug user who wandered in and out of her life, often entering through a smashed window or door.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: During the two years that they lived together, he regularly beat her and the children, Ms. Simmons said. Eventually, Ms. Simmons got a protective court order prohibiting the man from seeing his children.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Ms. Simmons and her family spent a number of years crowded into her mother's two-bedroom apartment. They moved into a shelter in Queens in the summer of 1988 before moving into their four-bedroom apartment at Castle Hill 15 months ago.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Unemployed for the last six years, Ms. Simmons has received a welfare check since 1969 when she first became pregnant. She gets a check for $235.55 every two weeks, which is supplemented by a $371 monthly check for one of her sons, who has a mental disability. She pays $266 a month in rent at Castle Hill. Gunfire Is Commonplace
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: About one-fourth of the 2,025 families living at Castle Hill are on full welfare, saidVal Coleman, a spokesman for the New York City Housing Authority. The average family income at the 14-building complex is $11,022. More than 7,000 people live there now, with almost half of them under the age of 21.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: The project is a complex of 12-story buildings clustered around playgrounds and courtyards. Most of the apartments are spacious, but the elevators smell of urine and the tile hallways are marred with graffiti.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Residents report that the project is overrun with crack dealers. Gunfire from roofs and windows has become commonplace and there have been four homicides this year. Life Is Cheap
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: One killing took place only a month and a half before Preston's death, when 17-year-old Jamal Graham was shot twice with a .32-caliber automatic. Police have labeled the killing a territorial drug dispute and have charged a 20-year-old man from another housing project in the shooting.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: ''People are dying over jackets, drugs, money, even the way you look at people,'' said Crystal McNeill, a 17-year-old Castle Hill resident who knew both Preston and Jamal. ''For $5, they'll shoot you in your head.''
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Before the emergence of crack, Castle Hill was a relatively quiet place, said Anthony Butler, who is 24. He remembers when his mother would plant a beach chair in the grass in the late afternoon and spend much of the evening there.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Now the Butlers, like many residents, spend most of their time locked in their seventh-floor apartment, watching music videos, preparing meals, and peering through grime-stained windows at a view of the Empire State Building framed between two other Castle Hill high-rises.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Because Preston Simmons was a broad-shouldered and self-reliant youth, he had been called ''Little Man'' since childhood. He was friendly and outgoing, often playing the role of the family clown. He also was susceptible to peer pressure, according to his sister, Natasha.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: His was a life devoid of positive role models or heroes, said his mother and friends. After learning some elementary karate moves from a friend, he lined the walls of his bedroom with magazine pictures of Ninja warriors.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Because he was hyperactive, Preston was enrolled in a special education class at Intermediate School 174. His teacher, Norman A. Washington, described Preston as an average student who rarely skipped school, who did his homework, and who showed respect for authority. ''He seemed to have a good self image,'' Mr. Washington said. ''He had an elastic ego. He didn't get hurt easily.''
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Preston began selling marijuana after meeting his supplier last summer, according to friends and family members. Along with several other boys working for the same man, he stationed himself in a playground near the spot where he was killed.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: On a good day, he would sell 20 to 30 bags for $5 each and would keep $1.50 for each bag sold, Anthony and Denise Butler said. Occasionally he would keep some marijuana for his own use, but his sister and friends said he preferred a Heineken beer to a joint.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Ms. Simmons said she was not aware of her son's drug dealing. Keeping Up With 'the Styles'
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Preston spent his money on food and gifts for Denise, and for pricey clothing and shoes. ''Young people like to keep up with the styles and it's expensive to keep up,'' said Mr. Butler. ''These are low-income projects here and your parents can't get you everything the other kids have.''
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: Since Preston's death, both his family and Denise's family have found special meaning in the coming birth of Denise's baby. They seem unfazed by the prospect of another generation of fatherless children living a life of destitution and danger.
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: ''Little Man is gone but he's left something behind,'' Ms. Simmons said. ''We hope it's a boy so he can keep his name. We loved Little Man a lot. Since he's not here any longer we all will have something to remember him by.''
title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

text: A suggestion appeared in this space on Oct. 3 that a ''war on drugs'' emphasizing ''combat, arrests and jailings'' could produce a ''wartime mentality'' - the spirit that ''anything goes,'' including the sacrifice of constitutional freedoms, in the battle against drugs. Here are two reader responses (names and addresses on request) only somewhat more extreme than others:
title: Rights vs. Testing

text: ''I say suspend the Constitution. Round up, and execute, all of the pushers, and runners. And while we're at it, all of the Mafia members, bikers, known terrorists. Clean out all of the murderers in prisons across the country, and execute them. For good measure, I might throw in lawyers, liberals, and social workers. . . . Hard core users should all be sent to labor battalions. . . . All others should have all of their property and bank accounts confiscated.''
title: Rights vs. Testing

text: ''Yes . . . for the sake of the future of this nation - our children - we'll have to give up some liberties. . . . Never mind, if one out of ten cars stopped for drug searching failed to reveal drugs or arms in it. What really matters are the rest of nine cars and their loadings with cocaine, marijuana and crack. Never mind if one out of ten houses searched by the police will not reveal any illegal drug possession. . . . Never mind the search of high-school students. If only one out of ten is caught having dope, his life and many others' has been saved. . . .''
title: Rights vs. Testing

text: The second response seems particularly relevant because a Washington Post/ABC News Poll showed that 52 percent of respondents were willing to have their houses searched and 67 percent to have their cars stopped and searched by police without a warrant. Fifty-five percent supported mandatory drug testing (a particularly intrusive form of search) for everyone and 67 percent favored it for all high school students.
title: Rights vs. Testing

text: Two warrantless and even suspicionless drug testing programs, moreover, already have been upheld by the Supreme Court, supposedly the guardian of constitutional rights. One, a Federal Railroad Administration program, required certain railroad employees involved in train accidents to submit to alcohol and drug tests; in the other, the Customs Service required drug testing of employees who sought transfer or promotion to positions involved in drug interdiction, or requiring a firearm to be carried.
title: Rights vs. Testing

text: The correspondents quoted above and no doubt most Americans probably approve of these programs, but the Customs Service requires nothing to trigger a test of the cited persons - no probable cause of any kind, not even a suspicion of drug involvement; and the F.R.A. requires no probable cause but only a vague trigger described by one authority as ''somewhere between individualized suspicion and purely random inspections.''
title: Rights vs. Testing

text: ''What happened to the Fourth Amendment?'' Yale Kamisar of the University of Michigan Law School inquired at a recent constitutional law conference in Washington. ''How can the Court uphold searches where no warrant is required, no probable cause is required - not even any level of suspicion is required?''
title: Rights vs. Testing

text: The Fourth Amendment prohibits ''unreasonable searches and seizures'' and specifies that ''no war-rants shall issue but upon probable cause.''
title: Rights vs. Testing

text: Mr. Kamisar described previous Supreme Court decisions leading to the F.R.A. and Customs rulings, and the Court's rationale that ''reasonableness'' can be determined not just by the Fourth Amendment's provisions but by weighing the interests involved - the individual's rights against the Government's claim to a ''compelling interest'' in some cases, such as drug testing, in conducting warrantless and suspicionless searches.
title: Rights vs. Testing

text: For himself, however, Mr. Kamisar argued that ''a 'reasonable' suspicionless search is a Fourth Amendment oxymoron'' - a contradiction in terms. Justices Marshall and Brennan have pointed out in dissent that ''there is no drug exception to the Constitution.'' And Justice Scalia, dissenting in the Customs case, noted that there was no evidence or claim of a drug problem in that service. Its testing program, he wrote, is ''symbolism'' to show that the Government is serious about fighting drugs.
title: Rights vs. Testing

text: But, Mr. Scalia wisely insisted, ''the impairment of individual liberties cannot be the means of making a point'' and mere symbolism ''cannot validate an otherwise unreasonable search.'' Nor should fear, even justified fear, about the scourge of drugs; the Supreme Court's task is to resist such panic, not to further it.
title: Rights vs. Testing

text: More on this subject in another article.
title: Rights vs. Testing

text: In many ways, the beginning sessions of Bill Granville's Granville Academy resemble an introductory class in business administration, with the emphasis on accounting. Indeed, the class is held in a large lecture room at Rider College here, in the glistening new business administration building.
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: ''A woman owns a car worth $1,500,'' the instructor said. ''So what is that?'' ''An asset,'' several in the class answered. ''Why is it an asset?'' ''Because she owns it!'' ''But she owes $750. What is that? ''A liability.'' ''Why?'' ''Because she owes it!'' ''So what's the owner's equity and how do you arrive at it?''
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: ''Seven hundred and fifty dollars, by subtracting liabilities from assets.''
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: The lesson is rudimentary, but grows more complex, easing into balance sheets, ''a snapshot of where you are financially at a particular moment in time,'' and on to gross and net profits, sales and operating expenses, other overhead and the like.
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: The instructor, Joseph S. Marrow, is the accounting supervisor for the marketing division of British Petroleum in Keasbey. He is teaching the class because he is an old friend of the founder of the five-year-old academy, William Granville Jr., who is also an oil executive, vice president of a division of the Mobil Corporation in New York City. Mr. Marrow, who is 42 years old, entered the oil business because of Mr. Granville, 48. Mr. Marrow met
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: Mr. Granville in Trenton, in the inner city, where Bill Granville, called just Bro' in those days, led a gang, the Whips East Trenton Trotters. Bro' was good with his fists. The Whips wore blue-and-yellow jackets with a snake on the back. They fought, stole and used a fair amount of dope.
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: ''I saw a man who was very angry in those days,'' said Mr. Marrow, who also saw a transformation in Mr. Granville. ''Someone who was looking to prove himself as a man. That was the impression you had - a man who was tough.''
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: That was a long time ago. William Granville did well in math, found out that he was smart and earned a cum laude degree in mathematics from Delaware State College, which also recently awarded him an honorary doctorate in humane letters. He started climbing the corporate ladder, but he has not forgotten.
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: The students at the Granville Academy are black teen-agers, 13 to 15 in this class, and they are mostly from the inner-city areas of Trenton. ''They don't think of black businessmen and investors at this level,'' Mr. Granville said. ''To them, the inner city is it, and success in business in the inner city means owning a barbershop or a beverage store. Business does not mean planning, economics and corporate structure. It isn't a negative image they have. It's a non-image.'' Mr. Granville's academy meets two evenings a month at Rider or the Princeton Theological Seminary. The surroundings are intended to defeat a ''ghetto mentality.''
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: The ad hoc four-year program enrolls 20 to 30 students a year. The academy has had four graduates, all of whom went to college in business disciplines.
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: The students - recruited through churches, schools and word of mouth - enroll for different reasons. Coltrane Stansbury, 14, said the academy offered ''long-term benefits, communication skills and learning to deal with people in the realm of business.''
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: Marwan Malloy, 13, said she wanted to know ''the fundamentals of business.'' Camille Roberts, also 13, said that she wanted to be a doctor, but that ''I also sort of want to have my own business, too.''
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: The president of Rider, Frank N. Elliott, was so impressed with the academy that he arranged for up to eight scholarships, worth $15,000 a year, for its graduates.
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: After attending a class on insurance, he said, ''I can truthfully say that my daughters,'' who are both college graduates, ''are not nearly as sophisticated about insurance as these 8th-to-12th graders.''
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: Mr. Granville suggested that the successful executive might provide an alternative role model to the ''other entrepreneur,'' the inner-city drug dealer. ''The dope dealer has income, bags of cash and gold chains,'' he said. ''The investor has property, marketable securities and is on his way to a better life.''
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: A 15-year-old in the class said that he sold marijuana when he was ''in the seventh grade'' and made $100 to $150 a week, but that he then thought about his situation.
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: ''I just looked around and saw more and more people getting arrested, more people falling off, dying,'' he said. ''I just started thinking about it.''
title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

text: The idea of legalizing drugs is emphatically rejected by the Bush Administration, by Congress and by huge majorities of Americans in opinion surveys. But it has gained surprising force in recent months, propelled by growing doubts that the Government can win its war on illicit drugs.
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: Some of the strongest doubts are being raised by people who can usually be counted among the Administration's strongest allies: leading conservatives and even some officials who are veterans of the war on drugs. With crime linked to drugs rising despite the Government's best efforts, they say, it is time for a national debate about the alternatives, including full or partial legalization.
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: ''We should at least be willing to debate these issues,'' said George P. Shultz, who as Secretary of State led the Reagan Administration's effort to eradicate drug crops abroad. Mr. Shultz, who teaches at Stanford University's School of Business, said in an interview that President Bush's program is ''conceptually no different'' from past Government efforts that ''have not achieved the result he's seeking.''
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: The Administration, which has said legalization would be an ''unqualified national disaster'' in the words of William J. Bennett, the Director of Drug Control Policy, brushed Mr. Shultz's suggestion aside. ''Whoa, he's been out on the West Coast too long, hasn't he?'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary. #5 to 1 Against Legalization Public opinion is on the Administration's side. In a recent poll by the National Opinion Research Center, five-sixths of those surveyed said marijuana should not be legalized. And when Congress last spoke out on the issue, in last year's anti-drug law, it declared that legalization would be an unconscionable surrender in a war in which ''there can be no substitute for total victory.''
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: But if anything, the debate on legalization has intensified since Mr. Bush announced his anti-drug strategy to the nation on Sept. 5. It has become a staple of editorial pages, letters to the editor, public lectures and talk shows on television and radio. And many who do not go as far as advocating legalization show a new interest in the subject.
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: Charles Murray, the policy analyst whose 1984 book ''Losing Ground'' was the source of many Reagan Administration ideas on overhauling the welfare system, said in an interview that although legalization would be a ''leap into the unknown,'' he has been edging toward it as he grapples with the implications of cracking down ever more heavily on drug users and street dealers. ''Exactly how many people are you willing to put in jail?'' he asked. ''Is it really feasible? Do you want that kind of police state?''
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: And William F. Buckley, the conservative columnist who is a longtime advocate of legalization, predicted that it would ''inevitably prevail because the alternatives are becoming increasingly discredited.''
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: A sizable minority of the law-enforcement officials, judges and scholars who attended a conference on money laundering last month in Miami said that although they did not necessarily support legalization, they agreed with many of its advocates' arguments. Efforts Seen as Failures
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: One of those officials was K. Brooks Thomas, the regional counsel in Miami for the Customs Service, the principal Federal agency responsible for keeping illegal drugs out of Florida. Mr. Thomas said he did not support legalization but was ''appalled when members of Congress indicated it would be unthinkable to debate such a thing.''
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: ''The methods we're applying simply aren't working,'' he added.
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: Until last year, the advocates of legalization were a tiny minority relegated to the fringes of the national debate on drugs. They included Mr. Buckley, who is editor of The National Review; Milton Friedman, the free-market economist who won the 1976 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science; the Libertarian Party, and the American Civil Liberties Union.
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: But in April 1988 Kurt Schmoke, a former Assistant United States Attorney who had just become Mayor of Baltimore, stunned a meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors by declaring that the nation was losing the war on drugs and urging, ''Let's at least have a national debate about decriminalizing drugs.'' Mayor Schmoke's speech attracted national attention. ''When politicians put their electoral future on the line,'' said Ira Glasser, the executive director of the civil liberties union, ''people pay attention.''
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: The advocates of legalization favor a variety of approaches. Some would experimentally remove criminal penalties on marijuana, then gradually decriminalize other drugs if the experiment seemed to work. Others favor wholesale decriminalization, even for dangerous and highly addictive drugs like crack. Treatment as a Health Problem
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: As bad as crack is, said Arnold S. Trebach, a professor of criminal justice at American University who is president of the Drug Policy Foundation, a nonprofit group in Washington, ''keeping the drug within the control of an absolute criminal prohibition makes the situation worse.''
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: The advocates are united by two convictions: that drugs should be treated as a health problem, not a problem for the criminal justice system, and that the war on drugs cannot be won. By keeping drugs illegal, they say, the Government has created a black market that drives prices - and traffickers' profits - sky high.
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: ''The greatest beneficiaries of the drug laws are organized and unorganized drug traffickers,'' Ethan A. Nadelmann, who teaches politics and public affairs at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University, wrote in the Sept. 1 issue of the journal Science. If drugs were legal, he and other advocates argue, the criminal violence surrounding them would fade as it did when the Prohibition against alcohol was repealed in 1933.
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: The proponents concede that overall drug use would probably rise if criminal penalties were dropped, just as consumption of alcohol about doubled in the decade after the repeal of Prohibition. But they argue that expanded treatment and education programs would help keep people away from drugs.
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: Advocates say that if the Government legalized drugs and taxed them as it does tobacco and alcohol, it could save the billions it spends on enforcement and earn billions more in revenue. That money could be applied to treatment and prevention. Predictions of More Drug Use
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: To opponents of legalization, such arguments betray a dangerous naivete and an unwillingness to come to grips with the nature of drugs like cocaine. ''Cocaine is clearly much more addicting than alcohol,'' said Dr. Herbert D. Kleber, a Yale University professor of psychiatry who is Mr. Bennett's deputy director for demand reduction, If it were legalized, he added, ''I think you'd see a five- to sixfold increase above the present level of use.''
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: If the Government taxed drugs heavily, opponents say, traffickers could still undercut the price. If the price were reduced to avoid that problem, they say, drug use would rise.
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: Dr. Kleber said the legalization advocates were ''intellectually dishonest, playing cruel games with the American people.''
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: And Mark A. R. Kleiman, a lecturer in public policy at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government who worked in the Justice Department under President Ronald Reagan, says he doubts that anyone can develop a plausible argument for legalizing the most dangerous drugs.
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: He said no one should ever assume that the future cannot be worse than the present: ''In a singing contest, never award the prize to the second soprano until you've heard her sing, even if the first one was awful.''
title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate

text: THE POWERS THAT BE By Mike Nicol. 176 pp. New York: Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95.
title: LAW AND ORDER COME TO PARADISE

text: In countries with repressive governments, even writers who have little to fear from their rulers are frequently driven to writing in parable. Thus we come by the modern allegories of Franz Kafka, Mikhail Bulgakov, Ryszard Kapuscinski, the magic realists of Latin America and a lengthening list of South Africans, including Nadine Gordimer (in the novella ''Something Out There'') and J. M. Coetzee (in virtually everything he writes). Mike Nicol, a poet and journalist from Cape Town, joins this roster of distinguished political fabulists with ''The Powers That Be,'' a fiercely lyrical first novel about an isolated, unnamed fishing village on the sparsely settled west coast of South Africa.
title: LAW AND ORDER COME TO PARADISE

text: Although not a long book, ''The Powers That Be'' supports, with little apparent strain, a large cast of characters and a profusion of subplots. The main narrative traces the efforts of Capt. Sylvester Nunes, a customs and excise officer, to impose his version of law and order on the village, which unaccountably survived without it before his arrival. Nunes is consumed with hatred and suspicion. ''Here,'' he tells a villager, ''here in my gut is the evidence that you are all committing a great crime.'' Nunes uses familiar South African police methods - interrogation, beating, a curfew, arbitrary detention, even the classification by ancestry of every villager and the introduction of racial segregation - but he finds no relief from his intestinal fires. ''He could feel the flames reaching into his chest, scorching the soft fabric of his lungs. In the darkness he could see sparks on his breath.''
title: LAW AND ORDER COME TO PARADISE

text: The resistance of the villagers is, for the most part, passive. They suffer the captain's abuses, and they tell him long, strange stories that drive him wild. In their tales from the whaling era, the Anglo-Boer War and the genocidal campaign of the German general Lothar von Trotha against the Hereros (in what is today Namibia), the history of South Africa is interleaved with the history of the village. And the true ancestral mix of the place is revealed in accounts of successive settlement by early hunter-gatherers, Portuguese shipwreck survivors, Norwegian whalers and Filipino fishermen.
title: LAW AND ORDER COME TO PARADISE

text: While the violence of South African history is an ever-present menace - the terrible tides of contemporary repression wash mutilated corpses onto the beaches - the village itself has long been a haven. The most recent immigrant, now the village priest, fled the war of independence in Namibia, where he served as a South African fighter pilot. When he reached the coast in his plane, he ''parachuted into the settlement while his abandoned craft described a graceful parabola into the distant sea.''
title: LAW AND ORDER COME TO PARADISE

text: Although the villagers like to think of their home as ''paradise amidst mayhem,'' it is really a more complex and interesting place than that. It has its share of stormy and unpleasant characters, and the sharp alternation of good times and lean strains the community's fabric. In fact, it is a cycle of unparalleled prosperity, and the consequent arrival of modern consumer goods to the village, that ultimately bring Captain Nunes down on the heads of the inhabitants. From these events Mr. Nicol spins a parable about the perils of commodity fetishism that is at least as compelling as the more pointed allegory about the apartheid state, represented by Captain Nunes. When the village soothsayer warns against replacing the local marijuana and sweet melon wine with imported liquor and inveighs against ''tinned peas, dark chocolate, sherbet, jams, tea that is not made of hard leaves,'' the literary resonances reach all the way to Genesis.
title: LAW AND ORDER COME TO PARADISE

text: The fact that the source of the village's wealth - and the object of the captain's investigation - turns out to be not only illegal, but precisely the illegal activity that anyone who knows southern Africa would expect it to be, is oddly disappointing. The literalism of this part of the plot sits awkwardly beside the great leaps of imagination that grace most of the novel.
title: LAW AND ORDER COME TO PARADISE

text: The folkloric world Mr. Nicol creates actually resembles the Latin America of Gabriel Garcia Marquez or Jorge Amado as much as it does the South Africa of Nadine Gordimer or J. M. Coetzee. Mr. Nicol's work does not possess - at least not yet - anything like the intellectual authority that Ms. Gordimer and Mr. Coetzee, in their separate ways, command, and yet he goes farther in ''The Powers That Be'' toward embracing and evoking the magic-saturated, non-Western worldview that many South Africans retain.
title: LAW AND ORDER COME TO PARADISE

text: Cultural and intellectual tension between radically diverse epistemologies is a major theme, of course, in many third world societies. It's a tension that lends such writers as Salman Rushdie some of their special vitality, and it's bound to surface increasingly in South African writing. In ''The Powers That Be,'' Mr. Nicol's artful immersion in the superstitious, provincial universe of upcountry villagers has wrought a strange, somewhat faux-naif, but affecting and original voice.
title: LAW AND ORDER COME TO PARADISE

text: There are, it is true, occasional lapses into loose, derivative language - such as a straight-faced reference to a ''rags to riches fairy tale'' - and one or two tirades, including an interior monologue by Nunes, that go on too long. One might also quibble with some of Mr. Nicol's structural choices - the decision, for instance, to withhold the secret of the village's prosperity until long after most readers will have guessed it. But these are small flaws in a rich piece of work, and they do not detract from the many pleasures of its imagery.
title: LAW AND ORDER COME TO PARADISE

text: This is from a description of the grandest house in the village: ''The floors were reputed to be of ships' timbers and the beams of driftwood, the fireplaces of burnt brick from the dinosaur clays of the lagoon and the door handles carved from the ribs of a hundred southern right whales.'' And a few pages later: ''Every eye in the village followed Captain Nunes from Lady Sarah's gate, down the sandy path into the smell of lamb chops and fried eggs, his lunch. He walked unhurriedly, inscrutable behind dark glasses, the badge on his cap glinting a random semaphore, his spider hands hardly moving at his sides.''
title: LAW AND ORDER COME TO PARADISE

text: Read cold, this may seem like mere fancy writing. In context, it is lyricism with a sure moral center.
title: LAW AND ORDER COME TO PARADISE

text: John Kaplan, a law professor and author best known for his legal analyses of some of the country's most distressing and controversial social ills, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 60 years old.
title: John Kaplan, 60, Law Professor Who Analyzed Social Ills, Is Dead

text: He combined his training as a scientist with his trial lawyer's experience and took a scholarly look at private behavior, like the use of marijuana and alcohol, and how the criminal laws deal with it.
title: John Kaplan, 60, Law Professor Who Analyzed Social Ills, Is Dead

text: For the past 24 years, Mr. Kaplan taught at Stanford University, where he held the Jackson Eli Reynolds Professorship of Law. The 1989 graduating class of the Stanford Law School voted him the school's John Bingham Hurlbut award for excellence in teaching. The award is given annually to a law professor who endeavors to ''make teaching an art.'' His peers in the Stanford University Senate elected him their chairman for 1988-89. Teacher and Adviser
title: John Kaplan, 60, Law Professor Who Analyzed Social Ills, Is Dead
