text: A generation of Stanford law students was introduced to criminal law in Mr. Kaplan's first-year course on the subject. He taught advanced courses on evidence, criminal procedure and criminology, and a popular undergraduate course on criminal justice and the justice system.
title: John Kaplan, 60, Law Professor Who Analyzed Social Ills, Is Dead

text: Mr. Kaplan was often consulted by government groups on drug laws and similar subjects. He recently served on the committee of the National Academy of Sciences and National Research Council studying the use of animals in medical experiments.
title: John Kaplan, 60, Law Professor Who Analyzed Social Ills, Is Dead

text: Mr. Kaplan contended that laws and prohibitions to regulate private behavior, like the use of marijuana, will not prevent abuse and in fact may make things worse. His book ''Marijuana: The New Prohibition,'' published in 1970, was an encyclopedic analysis of the scientific, political, legal and historical aspects of the topic. Social Costs of Drug Laws
title: John Kaplan, 60, Law Professor Who Analyzed Social Ills, Is Dead

text: Trying to outlaw marijuana, he argued, does not work and poses serious social costs by alienating a whole generation and branding many millions of people as felons.
title: John Kaplan, 60, Law Professor Who Analyzed Social Ills, Is Dead

text: Mr. Kaplan was also the author of ''The Hardest Drug: Heroin and Public Policy,'' published in 1983.
title: John Kaplan, 60, Law Professor Who Analyzed Social Ills, Is Dead

text: A native of New York City, Mr. Kaplan earned a bachelor's degree in physics from Harvard University and graduated magna cum laude from Harvard Law School, where he was a member of the Harvard Law Review. In 1954-55, he served as a clerk to Associate Justice Tom C. Clark of the United States Supreme Court and went on to study criminology in Vienna.
title: John Kaplan, 60, Law Professor Who Analyzed Social Ills, Is Dead

text: Before joining the Stanford Law faculty in 1965, he also served as a Federal prosecutor and taught law at Northwestern University and the University of California at Berkeley.
title: John Kaplan, 60, Law Professor Who Analyzed Social Ills, Is Dead

text: Mr. Kaplan is survived by his wife, Elizabeth; three children, Carolyn Springer Kaplan, Jonathan Edward Kaplan and Jessica Baron Kaplan, all of Palo Alto, and his mother, Dorothy Kaplan of New York.
title: John Kaplan, 60, Law Professor Who Analyzed Social Ills, Is Dead

text: By Jeffrey Schmalz, Special To the New York Times
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: After the appearance of 28 witnesses over six days, the trial of a Miami police officer accused of manslaughter in the killing of two blacks has concluded one stage, the prosecution, and moves into another, the defense, on Friday.
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: But even as the trial progresses, drawing Miamians to their radio and television sets for the citywide broadcasts of the proceedings, new questions are being raised about the police department here and its relations with the black community.
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: An eight-member advisory panel to the United States Civil Rights Commission issued a report this week concluding that blacks in Dade County are victims of police abuse, disrespect and insensitivity. The panel was formed to look into the three days of rioting that broke out after the Jan. 16 killing of the two blacks by the officer on trial, William Lozano, who says he acted in self-defense.
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: Police officials responded that there had been abuses in the past, but that much had been done through training to improve officers' conduct. 'A Degree of Prejudice'
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: ''You're always going to have a degree of prejudice,'' said Miami's Police Chief, Perry Anderson, who is black. ''But to say that institutional racism is strong in the Miami Police Department is not true.''
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: Many blacks in Miami say the case of Officer Lozano is an example of the excessive force they say is used against blacks, particularly by officers who are Hispanic immigrants. Officer Lozano, who is 30 years old and has been on the force five years, was born in Colombia.
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: The officer shot and killed a 23-year-old unarmed motorcyclist, Clement Lloyd, who was being pursued for traffic violations. Officer Lozano says the cyclist was trying to run him down. A 24-year-old passenger, Allan Blanchard, died when the cycle crashed.
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: In their presentation, prosecutors relied heavily on the testimony of five witnesses who said the officer was not in danger at the time he fired and that the motorcycle was not attempting to run him down. Mr. Lozano's lawyers attacked numerous inconsistencies in the testimony, pointing out that at least two witnesses had changed their accounts from earlier versions. Fellow Officer Testifies
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: Perhaps the most damaging testimony against Officer Lozano came from a fellow officer, John Mervolion, an eight-year member of the force. With lights flashing and siren blaring, Officer Mervolion's patrol car had been chasing the red motorcycle for speeding and not coming to full stops at stop signs.
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: When the chase neared Officer Lozano, who had been standing curbside behind the open trunk of his parked patrol car, he fired a single shot, striking Mr. Lloyd in the head.
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: Officer Mervolion testified that the cycle had been speeding at 70 miles an hour, sometimes veering into the opposite lane and nearly running down pedestrians.
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: But when asked by the prosecutor, John Hogan, if he saw any actions that ''justified the use of deadly force,'' Officer Mervolion replied, ''No.'' But he stressed that he did not see the shooting or what occurred the few seconds before it happened. Get Out of the Way
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: Asked what an officer is trained to do when a vehicle tries to run him down, Officer Mervolion officer said he should get out of the way, not shoot.
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: ''Take cover behind your vehicle,'' he said. ''Don't put yourself in that position.''
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: The chief defense lawyer, Roy Black, sought to portray Mr. Lloyd as a drug dealer who tried to run down Officer Lozano to avoid arrest and the confiscation of $1,514 in cash he was carrying. Judge Joseph P. Farina has prohibited mention of Mr. Lloyd's record of drug-dealing and traffic arrests and his six-month prison term for marijuana possession. But the judge has allowed the jury to be told that Mr. Lloyd was carrying a small amount of marijuana and the $1,514.
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: Under questioning from the prosecutor, Officer Mervolion said the amount of marijuana was so small he doubted it would have led to arrest or confiscation of the money. But the defense lawyer then seized on that line of questioning to hint to the jury that Mr. Lloyd had a criminal record. Traces of Drugs and Alcohol
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: In other testimony, medical examiners reported that an autopsy had found alcohol, byproducts of marijuana and barely detectable traces of cocaine in Mr. Lloyd's bloodstream. The defense said this showed Mr. Lloyd was crazed enough to run down a police officer.
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: But the prosecution produced an expert witness, Dr. Herbert Moskowitz of California, a longtime Government adviser on drunken driving, who said marijuana, the primary intoxicant in Mr. Lloyd's blood, tended to make people passive, not aggressive.
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: Of the five witnesses to the shooting or the events immediately preceding it - a truck driver, a park clerk, a bus driver, a hospital receptionist and a longshoreman - all agreed on many points. They said that the motorcycle did not veer toward Officer Lozano, that the officer was in one lane and the cycle in another and that the officer took careful aim before he fired.
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: But the defense dwelled on a number of inconsistencies and hinted that the witnesses had changed their stories after talking with one another and other members of the primarily black Overtown area where they live and where the shooting occurred.
title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE

text: Walter L. Nixon Jr. left a halfway house on parole today after serving 20 months of a five-year prison term for perjury. The Senate removed him as a Federal district judge on Nov. 3. In 1986, a jury convicted Mr. Nixon of lying to a grand jury when he denied discussing a marijuana case with a district attorney. Mr. Nixon, 61 years old, of Ocean Springs, Miss., reported to the Volunteers of America halfway house July 17, after serving nearly 16 months in the prison.
title: Former U.S. Judge Is Paroled

text: In ''Crack Brained'' (editorial, Nov. 6), you suggest that ending criminal prohibitions against marijuana and heroin ''deserves discussion.'' That judgment is welcome and long overdue.
title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them

text: Americans have been led to believe that prohibition is required to prevent drugs from destroying our society. This belief is encouraged by creating the image of a devil drug - a substance so dangerous that using it would cause violent behavior in otherwise law-abiding people and so powerful that a single exposure might lead an otherwise normal American to hopeless addiction.
title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them

text: Thus we have been subjected at various times to powerful images of ''demon rum,'' ''reefer madness'' and ''heroin dope fiends.'' All these images turned out to be politically manipulative, but scientifically false. They were used to promote policies of prohibition, rather than policies to control drug use and limit its harms. It is happening again with cocaine and smokable cocaine (crack).
title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them

text: * You suggest that the violence associated with crack use is caused by the chemical effects of the drug. A recent study of crack and homicide in New York showed that three-quarters of ''drug-related'' homicides were caused by territorial disputes and other incidents relating to the criminal trafficking system. Only 7.5 percent of the homicides were related to the effects of the drug itself, and two-thirds of those involved alcohol, not crack.
title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them

text: * You suggest that if prohibition were ended, crack use would spread rapidly. There is no scientific evidence to support that assertion, and some evidence to rebut it. Studies of cocaine users indicate that the barrier created by prohibition is relatively unimportant, that the market is relatively in-elastic and that the fear that use would expand significantly if prohibition were ended is exaggerated.
title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them

text: * You also assert that crack is so powerful that, unlike alcohol and tobacco, a high proportion of people who use it will ''carry their habits to the point of serious health damage.'' There's little evidence to support that assertion, a good deal to rebut it.
title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them

text: Studies here and abroad show that controlled use of cocaine is possible and that no more than 20 percent of users ever carried their habits to the point of adverse effects, and most of those returned to lower levels of use. Such research must be considered if we mean to assess the effect of ending prohibition. Generalizing about the effects of cocaine and crack by looking only at pathological users is like trying to infer the effects of alcohol at a cocktail party by looking only at skid-row alcoholics.
title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them

text: Yes, proposals to end criminal prohibition of marijuana and heroin deserve discussion. But so do proposals to end criminal prohibition of cocaine. The goal of being drug free must be abandoned. Abstinence makes as little practical sense in this context as in combating acquired immune deficiency syndrome. We need policies to control drug use and reduce the harms associated with it. Most of those harms are now the result of prohibition, not drugs. IRA GLASSER Executive Director American Civil Liberties Union New York, Nov. 10, 1989
title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them

text: In your editorial opposing the legalization of crack-cocaine (Nov. 6), you argue that, unlike some other drugs, whose effects do not incapacitate the user, cocaine produces effects such as paranoia, which are a threat to society. A substantial body of psychological literature indicates that the reaction a person has to a psychoactive substance greatly depends on society's expectations and the context in which the substance is used. For example, in countries where drunks are supposed to be querulous and angry, they are; whereas in countries subscribing to the stereotype of relaxed and playful inebriation, drunks act quite differently.
title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them; Expected Reactions

text: Before we assume that cocaine turns people into fiends (as marijuana use was portrayed in the 1940's) it might pay to find out whether the paranoia and hostility associated with use of this drug is not the result of user expectation. It wouldn't surprise me to discover that the commonly reported paranoia is a reaction to the guilt associated with engaging in an illegal act.
title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them; Expected Reactions

text: And if the guilt were eliminated by legalization of the drug, the paranoia would not appear. I'm not sure that this is true. But before we dismiss the whol notion of legalization, which has so many obvious benefits, it might just be wise to consider that possibility. RICHARD EPRO Assistant Professor of Psychology Nassau Community College Garden City, L.I., Nov. 7, 1989
title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them; Expected Reactions

text: Your editorial of Nov. 6 condemning legalization of crack is on the mark. Crack is highly addictive and can cause violent behavior. However, your closing statement that ''legalizing marijuana or heroin or other drugs deserves discussion'' is off the mark. Legalization of dangerous drugs is not, nor ever will be, a solution to the problem.
title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them; Message of Defeat

text: Teen-agers are making their opinion on drugs very clear. Recent polls show that high school seniors consider drugs the No. 1 problem they face. Drug abuse among teen-agers, however, is significantly down. If illegal drugs are declared legal, we would be sending a twisted message of defeat to a generation prepared to say no to drugs - that ''we were wrong, drugs are O.K.''
title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them; Message of Defeat

text: Drug abuse in the workplace alone is threatening to cripple America. One out of six employees abuses drugs. Drug users are one-third less productive, 3.6 times more likely to injure themselves or another person in a workplace accident, five times more likely to be in an accident off the job and five times more likely to file a worker's compensation claim. They cost American businesses $60 billion a year, a cost often passed on to customers.
title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them; Message of Defeat

text: How would legalizing drugs improve that? WILLIAM F. CURRENT Staff Director, Institute for a Drug-Free Workplace Washington, Nov. 7, 1989
title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them; Message of Defeat

text: For Wesleyan University, a crackdown of sorts on drugs has led to the arrest of one student and public debate over the university's definition of where its responsibilities end and those of the local police begin.
title: Campus Life: Wesleyan; Student's Arrest Leads to Debate On Drug Policy

text: The student, Lisa O'Donoghue, a freshman from Westport, was arraigned Tuesday in Middletown Superior Court on charges of possession of less than four ounces of marijuana and drug paraphernalia, a pipe. She was released without bail after promising to appear for trial on Nov. 21.
title: Campus Life: Wesleyan; Student's Arrest Leads to Debate On Drug Policy

text: Ms. O'Donoghue's arrest, on Oct. 27, is the first in the five years since Wesleyan announced that the Middletown police would be summoned to a campus tradition, known as a smoke out, that began 15 years ago. Students gather in McConaughy Dining Hall on a day in late October or early November and beat drums, clang bells and smoke marijuana. The next day there is an all-campus celebration of Uncle Duke's Day, which takes its name from the writings of Hunter S. Thompson and from Doonesbury, the comic strip of Garry Trudeau, whose Uncle Duke character is noted for his frequent recreational use of drugs, particularly LSD. 'Aggressively Stupid'
title: Campus Life: Wesleyan; Student's Arrest Leads to Debate On Drug Policy

text: The event has prompted criticism from the Middletown community and the local press and the withdrawal of several students from the freshman applicant pool. The critics say the event indicates the school's relaxed attitude toward recreational drug use that could encourage disrespect for the law.
title: Campus Life: Wesleyan; Student's Arrest Leads to Debate On Drug Policy

text: In an interview last week, Wesleyan's president, William M. Chace, called the smoke out ''aggressively stupid,'' and said the university did not condone it. ''I envision a very close study of our policy in the coming weeks and months,'' he said. ''We're very concerned about the image we have.''
title: Campus Life: Wesleyan; Student's Arrest Leads to Debate On Drug Policy

text: Although Wesleyan's code of nonacademic conduct says the university ''does not condone any activity involving illegal drugs,'' campus security makes no effort to police student use of marijuana, LSD or any other drug. That is left to local law-enforcement authorities, Edgar Beckham, dean of the college, said.
title: Campus Life: Wesleyan; Student's Arrest Leads to Debate On Drug Policy

text: ''One of the messages we are trying to get across to our students is that our rules are not the law - our rules are just the rules of this institution,'' Mr. Beckham said. ''The more powerful demonstration of respect for the law is to bring the police on the campus and encourage them to enforce the law here.'' Mayor Disagrees
title: Campus Life: Wesleyan; Student's Arrest Leads to Debate On Drug Policy

text: But Middletown's new Mayor, Paul Gionfriddo, who graduated from Wesleyan in 1975, said enforcement on campus is the university's responsibility, not the city's.
title: Campus Life: Wesleyan; Student's Arrest Leads to Debate On Drug Policy

text: ''We have to recognize that the 1990's are very different from the way things were in the 1970's,'' he said last week to a reporter for the campus newspaper, The Wesleyan Argus. ''We are all going to have to cope with a society that's much more interested in drug enforcement.''
title: Campus Life: Wesleyan; Student's Arrest Leads to Debate On Drug Policy

text: Mr. Beckham said that five years ago, after a large turnout for the smoke out, the university warned the student body that it would call the police if students staged any more smoke outs.
title: Campus Life: Wesleyan; Student's Arrest Leads to Debate On Drug Policy

text: According to Mr. Chace, on Oct. 27, 100 to 150 of the school's 2,600 students took part in the smoke out. Harry Kinne, Wesleyan's director of public safety, said the university alerted the Middletown police early in the day and instructed food-service managers at the dining hall to call the police if students distributed and smoked marijuana. The managers, in turn, warned students that the police might be called, but several students lighted up anyway. When the police arrived, the hall was filled with smoke, Mr. Kinne said, but only one student, Ms. O'Donoghue, was charged with breaking the law.
title: Campus Life: Wesleyan; Student's Arrest Leads to Debate On Drug Policy

text: Wesleyan students say they are concerned that the press is portraying them as a 1980's ''hippie druggie subculture.''
title: Campus Life: Wesleyan; Student's Arrest Leads to Debate On Drug Policy

text: ''If it's a subculture, it doesn't involve the majority of the campus,'' Eleanor Worth, a sophomore from New York City, said, ''and it doesn't affect more than those who are actively involved in it.''
title: Campus Life: Wesleyan; Student's Arrest Leads to Debate On Drug Policy

text: LEAD: GOOD KING SAUERKRAUT. By Barbara Paul. (Scribners, $16.95.) This slight tale will do little to win new readers for the usually reliable mystery writer Barbara Paul. It centers on King Sarcowicz, a man who feels doubly cursed by his own name. King was thrust upon him at birth by a mother who ''firmly believed that a child lived up to or down to his name,'' and Sarcowicz is regularly and derisively corrupted to ''Sauerkraut'' by virtually everyone he meets.
title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION

text: GOOD KING SAUERKRAUT. By Barbara Paul. (Scribners, $16.95.) This slight tale will do little to win new readers for the usually reliable mystery writer Barbara Paul. It centers on King Sarcowicz, a man who feels doubly cursed by his own name. King was thrust upon him at birth by a mother who ''firmly believed that a child lived up to or down to his name,'' and Sarcowicz is regularly and derisively corrupted to ''Sauerkraut'' by virtually everyone he meets. That nickname began in childhood as a result of Walt Kelly's parody of ''Good King Wenceslas'' in the ''Pogo'' comic strip, but now it seems to leap to the mind of anyone who's angry with or frustrated by Sarcowicz - which includes just about everybody. King is the stereotypical computer nerd who has become all too common in fiction, an absent-minded fellow whose social ineptitude is surpassed only by his physical awkwardness. Oddly, it is this very nerdiness, central to the story, that strikes the falsest note in the book: we never see any evidence that Sarcowicz is in fact the genius everyone proclaims him to be. And, more important, he is all too aware of his failings, an awareness that belies his supposed lack of social perception. Compounding this problem is the sad fact that Ms. Paul's story really isn't very interesting. Several bizarre deaths do occur when Sarcowicz and his business partner arrive, together with two software developers with whom they have formed an uneasy alliance, in New York in order to obtain a massive defense contract. But few readers will care who dies, or why, or how things finally turn out.
title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION

text: The main suspect in the murder of a Federal drug agent last February was killed in a blaze of bullets fired from a blue van on a Brooklyn street Friday night in what law-enforcement officials said appeared to be an execution by local organized-crime groups.
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: The death of the suspect, Constabile (Gus) Farace, 29 years old, ended one of the country's most intense manhunts. Mr. Farace was suspected of having killed Everett E. Hatcher, a 46-year-old Drug Enforcement Administration special agent, who was shot to death eight months ago on a desolate road in Rossville, S.I.
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: Law-enforcement officials said the agent had been engaged in an undercover investigation involving negotiations to purchase cocaine from Mr. Farace. It was the first death of a Federal drug agent in the line of duty in New York since 1972, and it brought one of the largest Federal rewards ever posted - $250,000 - and provoked calls by President Bush for a mandatory Federal death penalty in cases in which law-enforcement officers are killed.
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: In the shooting Friday night, a companion of Mr. Farace, Joseph Sclafani, 24, was critically wounded. The gunmen fled in the van, the police said. Companion Fired Twice
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: Mr. Farace was killed shortly after 11 P.M. in front of 1814 81st Street in the Bensonhurst section. Officers from the 62d Precinct, who arrived minutes after the gunfire stopped, found a man, whom they identified early yesterday as Mr. Farace, near death in the passenger seat of a 1982 gray Pontiac. He had gunshot wounds to the head, neck, back and leg.
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: Officials said Mr. Farace, who was seated nearer to the van, had not had time to reach for the .38-caliber handgun he carried in a waistband.
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: Officials of the drug agency said Mr. Sclafani, whom they described as a Staten Island bar owner and ''long-time associate'' of Mr. Farace, fired two shots from his own .38-caliber pistol in an attempt to ward off the assailants. Mr. Sclafani was found on the ground near the car. He was wounded in the chest, back and arm.
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: Before losing consciousness, officials said, he told the police, ''I was only trying to help my friend.'' Appearance Was Altered
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: Residents of the narrow one-way street of two-story houses and low-rise apartment buildings where the killing took place told the police that the burst of gunfire, at least 16 shots in all, had sounded like fireworks.
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: The police said they did not immediately recognize Mr. Farace, because when last seen he had short-cropped brown hair. When his body was found, Mr. Farace had curly hair and a long beard, both dyed red, they said. He was identified about 4:30 A.M. yesterday after fingerprint checks were performed in the Staten Island Medical Examiner's office.
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: Mary Cooper, a spokeswoman for the drug agency, said: ''It is ironic that Gus Farace died in the exact manner as Everett Hatcher - sitting in a car, shot through an open window by an assassin in a van. The only difference is he was on the passenger side while Hatcher was on the driver's side.''
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: Mr. Farace was pronounced dead on arrival at Coney Island Hospital, where Mr. Sclafini remains in critical condition.
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: An assistant United States attorney in the Eastern District of New York, Jerry Ross, who headed the investigation into Mr. Hatcher's murder, said there were no immediate suspects in Mr. Farace's death. ''We are still investigating it, but everything would tend to suggest this was a mob hit,'' he said. #30 to 40 People on Case Following Mr. Hatcher's murder, Mr. Farace, who was on parole after serving seven years for a first-degree manslaughter conviction, was placed on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's list of 10 most wanted fugitives.
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: The special agent in charge of the New York office of the drug agency, Robert M. Stutman, made the pursuit of Mr. Hatcher's killer his staff's top priority. Officials said a team of 30 to 40 people, including agents from the drug agency, the F.B.I., the New York City Police Department and the United States Marshal's Service have worked ''full time, seven days a week,'' to find Mr. Farace.
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: For months, acting on the belief that Mr. Farace had never left Brooklyn and Staten Island, agents used electronic surveillance, canvassed entire neighborhoods and arrested friends and family members in their efforts to flush the suspect out of hiding.
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: Last month, Mr. Farace's wife and brother-in-law were arrested on charges that they had been part of a drug ring operated by Mr. Farace. Agents said the organization had brought large amounts of marijuana from Texas to New York since 1987. In May, a Staten Island woman, Margaret Scarpa, was arrested for arranging temporary haven for Mr. Farace in a neighbor's home. Pressure on the Mob
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: But law-enforcement officials said the most successful tactic seemed to have been pressure placed on local organized-crime families - particularly the Bonnano and Colombo groups - to ''deliver'' Mr. Farace to the authorities.
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: A police official said of Mr. Farace's death, ''It certainly appears that the mob decided to offer him up.''
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: ''There has never been as intense an effort to put pressure on organized crime, and we have had information that they were indeed feeling it,'' said Mr. Ross, the Federal prosecutor.
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: At the time of his death in February, Mr. Hatcher, a 17-year veteran of the drug agency, had radioed members of a surveillance team backing him up that he was driving to meet his target, Mr. Farace, at a Staten Island diner.
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: The five agents who were tracking the undercover operation lost radio contact with Mr. Hatcher, whom they later found dead in his car with four gunshot wounds, including one to his head.
title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death

text: THE TEMPTING OF AMERICA The Political Seduction of the Law. By Robert H. Bork. 432 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.50.
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: When President Ronald Reagan nominated Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court in 1987, it appeared the nation's highest bench was about to gain a first-rate mind, a scholar who would give intellectual substance to its decisions. Judge Bork was already well known for his conservative views, which favored judicial restraint, Congressional prerogative and local control, and it seemed he would be confirmed with the same ease with which Mr. Reagan had been re-elected President in 1984. Then the anti-Bork forces galvanized their followers effectively and liberals enjoyed a rare success in seeing the Senate reject the nomination. A victory won at the expense of truth, it was not liberalism's finest hour.
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: Senators Joseph Biden and Howard Metzenbaum had many people believing that Judge Bork held the Constitution does not protect women from mandatory sterilization or give visitation rights to noncustodial parents. Some ''Borkbusters'' took out newspaper advertisements describing him ruling on cases five years before he was named to the bench as a circuit judge. Senator Edward Kennedy claimed Judge Bork would force women to resort to ''back-alley abortions,'' reinstitute segregated lunch counters, deny children the opportunity to learn about evolution and allow ''rogue police . . . [ to ] break down citizens' doors in midnight raids,'' possibly to arrest consenting homosexuals or even married couples using contraceptives.
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: In ''The Tempting of America,'' a learned and powerfully argued neoconservative book with a Calvinist title, Judge Bork describes the ''level of hysteria'' against him, for the most part in surprisingly calm terms. In his first full public response to his critics, he depicts the nomination controversy as a power struggle between conservatives who wanted to restrict judicial authority in the name of liberty and liberals who wanted to augment it in the name of social justice. In a concluding chapter where the author's emotions heat up a bit, ''Why the Campaign Was Mounted,'' he spells out the reasons ''the intellectual left reacts with fury when its influence with the courts is threatened.'' Frustrated by a democratic process in which they have little voting power, alienated from a middle-class public and out of touch with younger career-minded students, veterans of the 60's, he charges, have become an adversarial vanguard fighting public-interest causes in the courts and law schools. Judge Bork quotes one professor who admits that ''many of us entered law teaching with liberal or even radical views and the faith that legal scholarship and law teaching would enable us to translate our values into social reform.'' Thus, he argues, the nomination battle was over not only abortion rights but also the ''class values'' of an educated elite that was determined to impress its own mind on the Constitution.
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: Yet it should be noted, as the historian Fred Siegel has pointed out, that many of the same issues that defeated Judge Bork also defeated Michael Dukakis in his bid for the Presidency: abortion, the death penalty, school prayer, affirmative action. Both Judge Bork and Mr. Dukakis displayed an impatience with banal questions, and both wanted to be judged on the basis of competency rather than ideology, professional qualifications rather than political positions. Subjected to ideological interrogation, Mr. Dukakis fared no better trying to explain why compulsory flag salutes are unconstitutional than did Judge Bork trying to explain why the right of privacy in matters of personal morality has no clear basis in the Constitution. It was a hopeless situation for both candidates, who found themselves trying to raise the level of discourse, although American politics shows again and again that the best explanation is an accusation.
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: The nomination struggle takes up only a portion of Judge Bork's book, which includes his own ordeal as well as that of his family. So negative were some newspaper stories and advertisements that Judge Bork asked his wife to hand him only the sports section.
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: The book's main focus consists of two troubling theoretical issues that have plagued American intellectual and legal history: the Supreme Court's usurpation of power and the return to an ''original understanding'' of the Constitution as the only means of restraining judges from ruling on extraconstitutional issues. Sin and salvation for the price of one book.
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: Judge Bork delights, with an element of vindictive satisfaction against his critics, in showing how the Supreme Court's meddling has violated the democratic will. He likens the 1965 Griswold decision, which struck down the right of Connecticut to ban the sale of contraceptives, to the 1905 Lochner decision striking down the right of New York to outlaw the exploitation of labor by regulating work hours. A more recent instance of judicial incursion, he says, is affirmative action, with the Court approving of reverse discrimination on the basis of a statute intended to prohibit racial and sexual discrimination.
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: Judge Bork critically examines the views of many liberal law professors (and a few conservative libertarians as well). He is particularly scornful of the Harvard professor Laurence Tribe, who, he says, has argued that the First Amendment's guarantee of free speech implicitly prohibits the Government from mind control and therefore permits the ''highs'' the mind may reach through the stimulus of marijuana or pornography. Rejecting an evolutionary or pragmatic approach to the Constitution, Judge Bork denies that judges can create new rights in response to changing conditions:
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: ''When we say that social circumstances have changed so as to require the evolution of doctrine to maintain the vigor of an existing principle we do not mean that society's values are perceived by the judge to have changed so that it would be good to have a new constitutional principle. The difference is between protecting that privacy guaranteed by the Fourth Amendment - the 'right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures' - by requiring a warrant for government to listen electronically to what is said in the home and expanding that limited guarantee of privacy into a right not only to use contraceptives but to buy them, into a right to have an abortion, into a right, as four Justices of the Supreme Court would have it, to engage in homosexual conduct, into rights, as a number of professors would have it, to smoke marijuana and to engage in prostitution. If one cannot see where in that progression the adjustment of doctrine to protect an existing value ends and the creation of new values begins, then one should not aspire to be a judge or, for the matter of that, a law professor.''
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: In some respects Judge Bork's quarrel is not so much with liberalism as with post-modernism, the Paris-inspired, Nietzsche-influenced school of thought that claims there is no objective knowledge but simply interpretations and rhetorical persuasions. He expresses bewilderment at hermeneutics, deconstructionism, radical feminism and other trendy isms that have found a home in many law schools. Judge Bork cites the University of Texas law professor Sanford Levinson, who proclaimed the ''death of constitutionalism'' on the grounds that all texts, including the document drafted in 1787, remain as open to multiple interpretation as ''Hamlet.'' Mr. Levinson has explained that ''for a Nietzschean reader of constitutions there is no point in searching for a code that will produce 'truthful' or 'correct' interpretations; instead the interpreter, in [ the philosopher Richard ] Rorty's words, 'simply beats the text into a shape which will serve his own purpose.' ''
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: Judge Bork wonders why the post-modernists do not follow their own logic and, after declaring that there are no absolute truths in the Constitution, go on to deny judicial supremacy in favor of democratic majorities. Indeed, although Judge Bork regards post-modernism as a nihilistic curse and Nietzsche as a troublemaker, both could be used to argue his case for judicial humility. The post-modernist philosopher insists that acts of judgment are simply means of domination, and Nietzsche tells us that we impose our interpretations, dressing them up as discoveries so that our claims to truth conceal our will to power. Judges, hold thy tongue! Yet Judge Bork wants judges to speak out for a strict interpretation of the Constitution that favors restraint over activism. The truthful interpretation that the post-modernist regards as impossible, he regards as essential. He remains convinced that an ''original understanding'' of the Constitution is obtainable once judges cease reading their own values into law. One wonders.
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: In the infamous Dred Scott decision of 1857, Chief Justice Roger Taney assumed he was engaging in an originalist interpretation when he concluded that the Constitution had made slaveholding a right the Government must protect. Judge Bork correctly points out that Taney offered a flagrantly twisted interpretation when he extended the due process clause to upholding slavery in the Western territories. But surely Lincoln, Taney's antagonist, was reading into the Constitution his own egalitarian values when he claimed that the Declaration of Independence radiates as the moral emblem of the Republic. In ways that a post-modernist would appreciate, Lincoln read the Constitution against itself in order to show that the framers had deliberately repressed all mention of slaves as human beings who, according to the Declaration, were entitled to equality as a natural right. In this instance an original understanding was the problem, not the solution.
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: In other examples, there is the difficulty of trying to decide whose original understanding to abide by. Even in 1803, when the famous decision of Marbury v. Madison was handed down, Chief Justice John Marshall and President Thomas Jefferson disagreed on the Constitution's original meaning concerning the bold doctrine of judicial review.
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: With regard to more recent issues, the author judges the 1954 Brown v. Board of Education ruling outlawing segregated schools as ''a great and correct decision'' but one ''supported by a very weak opinion.'' All the social science data on the baleful psychological effects of segregation on black Americans were disingenuous, he claims, because those who ratified the 14th Amendment continued to countenance racial segregation in full knowledge of the psychological consequences. But what Brown aimed to achieve ''is consistent with, indeed is compelled by, the original understanding of the 14th Amendment's equal protection clause.'' Although Judge Bork contends that the courts later went too far in outlawing discrimination by private persons rather than the Government, he says that ''the end of state-mandated segregation was the greatest moral triumph constitutional law has ever produced.''
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: The most divisive judicial issue facing the country today is abortion. Judge Bork believes the 1973 Roe v. Wade decision, which struck down a Texas law making abortion a criminal offense, was as disastrous as the Dred Scott ruling had been in allowing judges to write their private beliefs into the Constitution. On constitutional grounds Judge Bork insists the issue must be left to the community rather than to the courts, reconfirming a stand that scared many of the liberals who opposed his nomination.
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: ''The Tempting of America'' is a lucid, elegant, provocative work of legal scholarship, free of technical jargon and therefore accessible to the general reader. In view of the ordeal that Judge Bork went through, it is amazing he has emerged with a healthy sense of humor and hope for the future. But why not? He is simply asking the 60's generation to adhere to its own ''original understanding'' of where the New Left was supposed to take us: not all decisions by the courts but all power to the people.
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: Such an admonition only highlights the point that conservatism has never made much sense in America. Judge Bork seems to trust society to provide the basis for order and civility, and he asks the courts to acquiesce in the sentiments of popular majorities whose passions the framers distrusted. But some of us agree with the framers that to leave truth to the decisions of a democracy is to leave it to chance, just as leaving rights to the judgment of popular opinion could entrust them to the tyranny of the majority. Judge Bork may be correct to insist that judges have no authority to impose their views on us. But if there was one thing such framers of the Constitution as Madison, Hamilton and Adams agreed on, it was that the people themselves are not the best guardians of their own liberties and rights. Judge Bork's book reminds us that the question they wrestled with remains a question for us today: Do we leave our rights to the hopeful wisdom of the courts or to the elusive whim of the masses? A WORD FROM THE PROSECUTION
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: Until the nomination of Robert H. Bork, the Reagan Administration had fulfilled a campaign pledge of reshaping the United States judiciary. It succeeded in appointing three conservatives to Supreme Court vacancies and filling more than half of all the other Federal judgeships around the nation with little opposition from the Senate. No nominee was able to shake the nation into a meaningful debate on the role of the courts in American society. All that changed on a warm July day in 1987 with the announcement that Judge Bork was the President's choice to succeed Lewis F. Powell Jr. - who, as the swing man of the Supreme Court, was perhaps the most powerful Justice of his time. On that day, there was little sign that this nominee would be any different from the others. Aside from Senator Edward Kennedy, in a vitriolic speech, no one predicted that Judge Bork would ultimately lose in the Senate, and by the largest margin ever suffered by a Supreme Court nominee. What happened? It is the thesis of THE PEOPLE RISING: The Campaign Against the Bork Nomination (Thunder's Mouth, Cloth $24.95, Paper $13.95) that while Judge Bork ultimately did himself in - he left an ample paper trail of criticism of the Court's most important decisions in civil rights, privacy and the First Amendment - it was the trumpeting of the Bork record through a rare coalition, the likes of which had not been seen at any other time in the 1980's, that aroused such violent hostility toward his nomination. That coalition included abortion rights, civil rights, feminist, labor, environmental and senior citizen organizations, which were able to put aside their differences to forge the block-Bork movement. Michael Pertschuk, a liberal lobbyist and a former chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, and Wendy Schaetzel, a journalist, have put together a political manifesto. It weaves together internal memos with portraits of the coalition's organizers, providing an insightful guide to the campaign against the Bork nomination. ''The People Rising'' refutes the notion that Judge Bork's opponents were narrow special-interest groups lacking substantive objections, and ably shows that through some tense moments during the four-month campaign, the group was able to reach critical agreements on framing the issues, sharing lists of constituencies and avoiding testimony after Judge Bork's own fatal appearance before the Senate Judiciary Committee. The authors also attempt to refute accusations that the coalition was unfair and underhanded by documenting how carefully Judge Bork's opponents relied on controversial writings by the nominee himself. Indeed, the book succeeds in demonstrating that it was the writings and ruminations of Judge Bork, as much as anything else, that defeated his nomination. ''The People Rising'' is a useful chronicle, not only of the players who helped beat Judge Bork, but also of the manipulation of symbols used against a White House that thought it had a monopoly on that art. STEPHEN LABATON
title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE

text: By George James, Special To the New York Times
title: Possible Drug Link To Rock Fan's Death Cited by Prosecutor

text: A college student's death after a rock concert in the Meadowlands Sports Complex last month may not have been a homicide as authorities originally thought but the result of a fall or jump from a bridge while he was under the influence of drugs, the acting Bergen County Prosecutor said today.
title: Possible Drug Link To Rock Fan's Death Cited by Prosecutor

text: The Prosecutor, John G. Holl, in a news conference at the Bergen County Courthouse here, called this possibility an opinion, which he attributed to the State Medical Examiner, Dr. Robert Goode.
title: Possible Drug Link To Rock Fan's Death Cited by Prosecutor

text: Mr. Holl said Dr. Goode, after reviewing the case, believed that the student, Adam Katz, a 19-year-old University of Hartford sophomore from South Orange, had ingested LSD and smoked marijuana several hours before his body was found on Route 120 near an overpass in the complex during a Grateful Dead concert on Oct. 14. Mr. Katz, who had been attending the concert, died the next day at Hackensack Medical Center.
title: Possible Drug Link To Rock Fan's Death Cited by Prosecutor

text: Mr. Katz's father, Jay, reached at his home in South Orange, declined to comment but said he planned to ''refute'' Dr. Goode's theory. Reports of Friends Neither the autopsy report by the County Medical Examiner's office, which concluded that he had died of a single blow to the head, nor the state toxicolocal report noted traces of drugs in Mr. Katz's system, Mr. Holl said. But he said friends of Mr. Katz who had attended the concert with him had told investigators he had used LSD and marijuana.
title: Possible Drug Link To Rock Fan's Death Cited by Prosecutor

text: Dr. Goode, who did not conduct a second autopsy, concluded that the drugs might not have shown up in Mr. Katz's system after his death because they could have been flushed out during treatment at the hospital.
title: Possible Drug Link To Rock Fan's Death Cited by Prosecutor

text: Mr. Katz's death prompted many allegations of excessive force by security guards at the Grateful Dead concerts and other events. On Oct. 31, nine guards pleaded not guilty to charges of assaulting five people at concerts on Oct. 11, 14 and 15, but Mr. Holl said there was no relation between these cases and the Katz case.
title: Possible Drug Link To Rock Fan's Death Cited by Prosecutor

text: By James C. McKinley Jr.
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: In a ruling that could curb the Government's power to seize a drug dealer's real estate, a Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the seizure of an upstate New York farm suspected of being used by drug dealers violated the owner's constitutional rights because he was not given a hearing beforehand.
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: A lawyer for the owner called the decision by a three-judge panel in the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit a ''significant precedent.''
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: ''It is a victory for the principle that the Government cannot in the name of the war on drugs deprive people of their homes without a chance to be heard,'' the lawyer, Richard A. Rothman, said.
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: But prosecutors said it was still unclear last night whether the ruling would force meaningful changes in the tactic of seizing dealers' houses and apartments.
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: And although the court ruled that the seizure had not been properly carried out, it upheld the actual forfeiture of the property, which was approved nearly a year later by United States District Judge Michael A. Telesca of Rochester. 'Illegal Seizure Doesn't Immunize'
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: ''Various circuit courts have held that the illegal seizure of property, standing alone, will not immunize that property from forfeiture, so long as impermissibly obtained evidence was not used in the forfeiture proceeding,'' the judges said.
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: In a carefully worded 31-page decision, the judges said the case was the first appellate review in New York of whether the Federal Government may seize a person's home without the prior hearing usually guaranteed under the due process clause of the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution. The judges on the panel were Chief Judge Wilfred Feinberg, Judge Jon O. Newman, and Judge Edward Dumbauld. Judge Feinberg wrote the decision.
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: The 120-acre farm in Livonia, N.Y., about 30 miles south of Rochester, was seized in December 1986 under a Federal civil forfeiture law that allows the Government to take over buildings where law-enforcement officials suspect drugs are being stored or sold. The 1984 law is a powerful tool used by prosecutors to strip drug dealers of illicit profits they have sunk into luxury cars, boats and buildings.
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: The Federal Drug Enforcement Administration obtained a warrant for the seizure based on the testimony of an undercover agent, who said a dealer had sold him cocaine that apparently came from the farm. According to court papers, the magistrate who issued the warrant also took into account a cache of cocaine, drug paraphernalia, guns, and money that was found on the farm when Federal agents executed a search warrant there six months earlier.
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: The owner of the farm, Peter Serafine, was not informed of the seizure and no hearing was held. Farm Not Like a Yacht
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: Citing several Supreme Court precedents, the decision handed down yesterday said that the owner's right to a hearing before seizure can only be ignored when there is ''a special need for very prompt action,'' which would include cases in which the property the Government wishes to seize is a yacht, a car or something else that could be destroyed, moved or hidden.
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: But the decision went on to say that there had been no urgency surrounding forfeiture in this case, since the house, two barns and 120 acres in question were not about to disappear or move. In addition, investigators had already gathered their evidence - the cocaine and drug paraphernalia - so there was no danger that evidence would be lost if the seizure were delayed.
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: The United States Attorney for the Western District of New York, Dennis Vacco, whose office seized the property, said he would not comment until he had read the decision.
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: Mary Lee Warren, chief of the narcotics unit in the Southern District, said that she had not read the decision but that she did not believe it would hamper the Government's efforts to seize property used by drug dealers. She said prosecutors in her office usually obtain a search warrant and a seizure order for a location at the same time, arguing that the drug dealing itself presents an emergency. Dealer Went Straight to Farm
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: ''Typically we are getting simultaneous warrants and the reason is there is active drug dealing right then and there,'' she said. ''Often the defendant has come in the next day and asked for a show cause hearing on the seizure.''
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: If the Government were required to notify the owners that they intended to seize the property, she said, the dealers could destroy evidence.
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: In Mr. Serafine's case, court papers said, the evidence was substantial. On two occasions, in April and May 1986, a suspected drug dealer named Richard Meyering sold cocaine to an undercover agent in Livonia, Benjamin Brainard, the papers said. In each case, Mr. Meyering told the agent he needed to go to a house to get the drug and then went directly to Mr. Serafine's farm.
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: A search of the farm house two months later turned up several containers of chemicals used to dilute cocaine, small quantities of cocaine and marijuana, a scale, seven handguns and other weapons, a hand grenade, and $19,000 in cash. Some of the bills were the same as those the undercover agent had used to buy the cocaine.
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: Mr. Rothman said he was disappointed that the court did not restore the farm to Mr. Serafine. ''The question in my mind that this decision raises is whether or not what they said in upholding the ultimate forfeiture undercuts the constitutional guarantee,'' he said.
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: In justifying the confiscation of the farm, the judges said they were aware that their decision ''creates an unusual, and perhaps harsh result in this case.''
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: ''Nevertheless, this result fits squarely within the statutory framework for civil forfeitures that Congress has expressly provided,'' they wrote. ''We certainly cannot say that Congress did not intend this result in view of the magnitude of the national drug problem it was addressing.''
title: Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal

text: By Jeffrey Schmalz, Special To the New York Times
title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?

text: Ten months after the fatal shooting of a black motorcyclist set off rioting here, arguments began today in the trial of a Hispanic Miami police officer charged in the case, with the prosecution depicting him as trigger-happy and the defense calling him heroic.
title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?

text: The shooting occurred at 6:04 P.M. Jan. 16 as the motorcyclist, 23-year-old Clement Lloyd, was being chased by a police car for speeding and not coming to a full stop at a stop sign.
title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?

text: The officer on trial, William Lozano, 30, was standing on the street several blocks in front of the chase. As the motorcycle approached him, he fired once, hitting Mr. Lloyd in the head. A passenger on the cycle, Allan Blanchard, 24, later died of injuries suffered when the vehicle crashed.
title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?

text: In his 40-minute opening statement, the prosecutor, Don Horn, contended that Officer Lozano, who faces a possible 60 years in prison if convicted of two counts of manslaughter, had ample time - at least 10 seconds - to assess the situation. A Need to Shoot? Mr. Horn, an assistant state's attorney, said that no one's life had been in danger and that there had therefore been no need to shoot.
title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?

text: Mr. Horn said he would produce witnesses to testify that the motorcycle never veered into the lane where Mr. Lozano was standing. He said the witnesses would testify that Mr. Lozano stepped out into the street, putting himself in danger, and that he could easily have stepped back.
title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?

text: The prosecutor did not specify a reason for Mr. Lozano's actions. But he implied that Officer Lozano intentionally put himself into the path of the motorcycle in an attempt to justify the killing of the driver as self-defense.
title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?

text: Mr. Horn called the move an old Police Department trick but said modern guidelines specifically rule out such a maneuver. He said the guidelines require officers not to put themselves in danger and to shoot only as a last resort. Mr. Horn told the six jurors and four alternates that Officer Lozano violated those rules and thereby ''failed to act responsibly and prudently.'' Never Fired Gun Before
title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?

text: In a 50-minute opening statement, the defense depicted Officer Lozano as a model officer who had never previously fired his gun while on patrol and who had been praised by his superiors on a dozen occasions as being courteous and level-headed in dealing with the public. He has been on the force five years. His wife and two brothers are also police officers, The chief defense lawyer, Roy Black, said that Officer Lozano's vision was blocked by the open lid of his patrol car's trunk, and that he stepped into the street not with the intent of shooting Mr. Lloyd but merely so he could see what was going on. Mr. Black said witnesses would testify that Mr. Lloyd turned the cycle directly toward the officer and that the motorcycle had also endangered other people.
title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?

text: Mr. Black depicted Mr. Lloyd, who both sides agree was carrying marijuana and $1,500 in cash, as a drug dealer with contempt for the police, a man willing to do almost anything to avoid arrest. Both sides also agree that the cycle's passenger, Mr. Blanchard, turned and made an obscene gesture to the officer who was engaged in the original chase.
title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?

text: The defense portrayed the primarily black neighborhood where the shooting occurred, the Overtown section, as a desperate community plagued by armed robberies and drug dealing where a police officer was necessarily concerned about his own safety. So desperate are Overton's people, Mr. Black said, that a woman stole a gold ring from the finger of the dead Mr. Lloyd as his body lay on the street. A Symbol of Tensions
title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?

text: Throughout this city today, Miamians gathered by radios and television sets to listen to the opening statements in a case that has come to symbolize the racial tensions here. Some blacks have threatened more civil disturbances if Officer Lozano is acquitted. Some Hispanic Miamians contend that the officer, who emigrated to the United States from Colombia when he was 13, has been charged without justification to appease blacks.
title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?

text: Mr. Black, referring to the tensions, said none of the players involved in the shooting had time to realize the race or ethnic background of each other. ''Race had nothing to do with this case,'' he said.
title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?

text: But he added that since the shooting, ''race had everything to do with this case.'' He urged jurors to distance themselves from the societal concerns and concentrate on the facts.
title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?

text: So determined was Mr. Black to remove one black juror from the case that, in a highly unusual move, he hired a private detective to question fellow employees about the juror's attitude toward Hispanic people, an attitute that some of the employees said was one of prejudice, Mr. Black said. The judge, Joseph P. Farina of Dade County Circuit Court, refused to remove the juror.
title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?

text: Judge Farina has sequestered the jury to keep it from the extensive publicity about the case. He expects testimony to last four to six weeks.
title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?

text: AS a jewelry designer who sells privately through friends, Elizabeth Locke goes to parties all over the country. But in places like New York, Los Angeles and Washington, the parties are not what they used to be. ''You stand around eating broccoli and swilling water,'' she said. Mostly, people talk about their work.
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: For a wild time, she goes home to Millwood, Va., a town in a county with 9,000 people. ''The good thing about Virginia is people still drink bourbon and gossip,'' she said. ''Parties go on and on, because you know that once you leave, you're going to be talked about unmercifully.''
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: Parties have always gotten some of their kick from occasionally excessive consumption of alcohol, drugs, and felicitous meetings with friends or strangers that continue past sunrise. But with those activities in disrepute, primarily because of health concerns, parties are changing. People are getting their stimulus in different ways: from conversation, from entertainment, from games, and from dessert, which may be the only decadent pleasure that can still be enjoyed without profuse apology.
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: Laura Miller Gleason, an art consultant in Cincinnati, said people used to go to parties and wait for the marijuana. ''Now,'' she said, ''they wait for dessert.'' Few of her friends these days take drugs or drink. Even on New Year's Eve, ''everybody is drinking Perrier and iced tea.''
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: People of all ages say their friends are drinking less and generally shunning drugs. Whether in their 20's or their 50's, they usually sigh and say it must be because they are getting old.
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: Many people have ''turned down the volume'' on their appetites, but they still lust for a variety of experiences that will provide stimulation, said Joseph Smith, a psychologist who is president of Oxtoby-Smith, a consumer research and consulting company in New York.
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: Victoria Leacock, a 26-year-old New Yorker who just made her first documentary film, sometimes goes to three or four parties in a night. But for the last 15 months, since she stopped drinking, she is getting a different perspective. She still feels high at a great party, she said, but not from alcohol.
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: ''It's a contact high from being in touch with other people who interest you,'' she said. ''It's a childlike excitement at the possibilities.''
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: Partygoers say they find the interaction more personal now. ''It's really conversation,'' said Gwen Putzig, executive director of the National Sculpture Society in New York. ''Before, it was the excitement of meeting a lot of new people, but the relationships were temporary.''
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: There seems to be more effort to match people who will create sparks through compelling conversation. Jay Margolis, vice chairman of the clothing company Liz Claiborne, said that approach was not necessary when more people were tipsy at parties.
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: When the talking trails off, there is food. For his son's bar mitzvah, Mr. Margolis hired Washington Street Cafe Caterers in Manhattan, which set out a lavish display of ice creams, sauces and and other toppings. ''We thought it was just going to be for the kids,'' he said, ''but every adult went for the ice cream bar.''
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: Ronnie Davis, owner of the catering company, said many clients ask for big dessert displays. ''They love it,'' he said. ''They're like children.''
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: Indeed, he is catering a lot of parties at F. A. O. Schwartz, the toy store, for groups that have nothing to do with the toy business, like insurance brokers. People want to be reminded of their childhoods, he said, when life was simple.
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: But most of all, they seem to want chocolate. ''Chocolate is the thing,'' he said. ''Since you're not picking someone up and sleeping with them, you eat chocolate.''
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: Dr. Howard Shaffer, head of the Center for Addiction Studies at the Harvard Medical School, said there is no biochemical reason that desserts would especially appeal to people who have cut down on drinking. But, he said, ''eating often reduces anxiety.''
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: Many partygoers say today's events are not boring: they are just civilized. Valerie Gladwin, who is 29 and analyzes portfolios at Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York, frequently goes to cocktail parties where the guests mingle, talk, then pair up to go out to dinner. ''Five years ago,'' she said, ''it would have been more wild. People do drink, but nobody gets drunk. I don't think we need that.''
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: Teran Davis, a philanthropist who lives in Los Angeles and Aspen, said more people are hiring entertainers for parties, even in their homes. ''They have psychics and magicians,'' she said.
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: A recent 50th-birthday party for her husband, William Lloyd Davis, featured a group that wore costumes, performed scenes from Broadway shows and prodded the guests into dancing. ''There's not a minute,'' she said. ''You grab a sip of something quickly and you're up on the dance floor again.''
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: Caroline's at the Seaport, a comedy club in Manhattan, is doing more private parties. ''Comedy is a release,'' said Caroline Hirsch, the owner. ''It's a different kind of high.''
title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence

text: By Jeffrey Schmalz, Special To the New York Times
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: When testimony begins this week in the trial of a police officer accused of two killings that set off a riot in January, this city will again confront some of its rawest concerns - race relations, immigrants and police conduct - and, if the officer is acquitted, the fear of another riot.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: The defendant, Officer William Lozano, is charged with two counts of manslaughter in the shooting of an unarmed black motorcyclist and the death of his passenger from injuries in the crash.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: Many officials, both black and white, believe that if Officer Lozano is found not guilty there will be more civil disturbances, just as there were twice before in this decade when Miami police officers were acquitted of killing blacks. Change of Venue Sought
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: The defense, hoping to get the trial moved out of Dade County, seized on the fear and tension, pointedly asking potential jurors if they could render a fair verdict knowing that acquittal could lead to rioting. Some Miamians, particularly blacks, complain that such day-after-day questioning was not merely responding to tensions but fanning them, virtually guaranteeing disorder. A jury was selected Friday, despite a defense challenge to one juror. An appeals court is to rule on the challenge Monday.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: The Police Chief, Perry Anderson, has appealed to the judge to delay announcement of the eventual verdict so the Police Department will have time to muster off-duty officers and deploy two armored personnel carriers. The department has pushed through an emergency $72,000 purchase of 700 gas masks and other gear ''in preparedness for the possibility of a civil disturbance.''
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: Almost daily, black demonstra-tors protest outside the courthouse, some warning of violence if Officer Lozano is acquitted. Meanwhile, Spanish-language radio stations here, particularly those run by Colombian emigres, have come to the aid of Officer Lozano, a 30-year-old Colombian immigrant, appealing for money for the legal defense of ''our fellow countryman.'' Riots as a Part of Life
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: ''There's a tendency to think of something like the riot as a turning point, as the beginning of an era or the end of an era,'' said William A. Vega, a professor of sociology at the University of Miami. ''But in fact, life in this city is a continuum.''
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: ''The police estimate that one in three vehicles in Miami contains a gun,'' Professor Vega said. ''The police are just not going to risk their lives; they're going to continue to take actions based first on their own protection.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: ''There are going to be more killings by the police, and there are going to be periodic outbursts in certain neighborhoods. That's life in urban America in general today, but especially in Miami, with guns everywhere and the sense of 'them' and 'us' between blacks and Hispanic immigrants.''
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: Indeed, little has changed here to improve the lot of blacks in Miami since January, when three days of rioting left one person dead, 11 people wounded by gunfire and a dozen stores burned down. This week the voters rejected a proposal that resulted from the disturbances, to reorganize city government to give blacks more representation; it was defeated in part because Hispanic city officials did not work for its passage. District Election Plan
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: The City Commission now has five members, all elected citywide, which blacks say makes it difficult for them to win seats. Hispanic residents make up 60 percent of the Miami population; non-Hispanic blacks account for 26 percent, and non-Hispanic whites 11 percent.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: The proposal would have expanded the commission to nine members, with five of them elected in individual districts, which would have virtually insured the election of blacks in predominantly black districts.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: Not only did the proposal fail, but the one black who holds a seat on the five-member commission did not win a majority on Tuesday and will face a citywide runoff next week against a Hispanic challenger.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: As a good-faith gesture to blacks this summer, Mayor Xavier Suarez named a second black to fill a brief interim opening on the commission left by the resignation of a Cuban-American. But in a measure of how much Hispanic voters oppose yielding any power to blacks, Mr. Suarez was denounced for giving away a ''Cuban seat,'' even temporarily, and it became a key issue in the Mayor's re-election campaign, although he won. Fear of Rioting Cited
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: Officer Lozano's lawyer, Roy Black, argues that in such a charged atmosphere his client cannot get a fair trial in Dade County. He wants the trial moved, contending that jurors, fearing a riot, will be predisposed to convict his client.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: The chief prosecutor, John Hogan, says that the fear of riot is being magnified by Mr. Black and that the six jurors and four alternates will not be tainted by the case's wide publicity.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: Many blacks in Miami are increasingly angry at the constant raising of the riot threat.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: ''It's a slap in the face of the black community,'' said the Rev. Van Eubanks Sr., a black minister who has been appealing to Miamians to remain calm. ''It's saying that you're dealing with a community that's totally unintelligent and ignorant and that only knows how to express itself by rioting.'' Reluctant to Move Trial
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: Mr. Black responds that Miami's history speaks for itself. Five years ago, he won the acquittal of another Hispanic police officer here who had shot and killed a black, and the verdict set off civil disorder.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: The judge, Joseph P. Farina of Dade County Circuit Court, has put off a decision on a change of venue until Monday or Tuesday. But he has hinted that he is reluctant to move the trial.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: In the back of everyone's mind is the Liberty City riot of 1980, the worst in this city's history. The riot, in which 18 people were killed, broke out after an all-white jury acquitted five white Miami police officers in the killing a black man. The venue of the trial had been changed from here to Tampa.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: Mr. Black's case, bolstered by witnesses, will be that Officer Lozano shot in self-defense and that the motorcycle, driven by 23-year-old Clement Lloyd, was about to run him down as Mr. Lloyd was fleeing other officers who said he had committed a traffic violation. The prosecution, also bolstered by witnesses, will argue that the motorcycle was not about to run down the officer and that Officer Lozano shot unnecessarily. Marijuana Evidence Allowed
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: Mr. Black had hoped to portray Mr. Lloyd as a dangerous drug dealer with a record of drug and traffic convictions. Judge Farina ruled Wednesday that the criminal record could not be introduced. But he did agree to allow evidence that Mr. Lloyd and his passenger, Allan Blanchard, who died a few hours after the crash, were under the influence of marijuana when the shooting occurred and were carrying marijuana and $1,500 in cash.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: Judge Farina has also forbidden Mr. Black, for now, to mention police officers killed in the line of duty, a decision that has angered the defense. In his arguments in support of mentioning the dead officers, Mr. Black had said: ''We intend to show that police officers have fear and that it is justifiable, not paranoia, because in this community people are trying to kill them.''
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: Of the 226 potential jurors in the original pool, 93 were eventually questioned by lawyers. On Friday, six were finally selected: two non-Hispanic blacks, three non-Hispanic whites and one Hispanic white. The defense wants to remove one black because he represents drug-using employees in proceedings before the Postal Service, which the defense feels might make him sympathetic toward Mr. Lloyd.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: But Judge Farina refused, saying the defense merely wanted to keep blacks off the jury. A state appellate court will decide Monday whether the juror stays.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: About a fourth of the potential jurors said their judgment would be affected by the potential for riot, but most said it would not. As one of them put it, potential riots ''are just part of Miami.'' Difficulties for the Police
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: The trial has posed difficulties for the Police Department, which has been found by various panels and studies to have used excessive force, especially against blacks, over the last decade.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: It makes it difficult for the department to project a get-tough image, especially since the trial comes as six officers in the Dade County Police Department are about to go on trial on charges of killing a suspect, a Hispanic drug dealer.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: But police officials say they must project a particularly strong image now to deter rioting. They are spreading the word that they will take stronger measures than they did in January.
title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions

text: ''If a group of individuals plans on having a riot,'' Chief Anderson said, ''we will be ready.''
