Thoreau is obliged to wage a long and decidedly uncharacteristic war, ''filling up trenches with the weedy dead.'' He finds himself ''making such invidious distinctions with his hoe, leveling whole ranks of one species, and sedulously cultivating another.''
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: Thoreau is gardening here, of course, and this forces him at least for a time to lay aside his romanticism about nature - what some naturalists today hail as his precocious ''biocentrism.'' But by the end of the chapter, his bean field having fulfilled its purpose, Thoreau trudges back -lamely, it seems to me - to the Emersonian fold: ''The sun looks on our cultivated fields and on the prairies and forests without distinction ... do [ these beans ] not grow for woodchucks partly? ... How then can our harvest fail? Shall I not rejoice also at the abundance of the weeds whose seeds are the granary of the birds?''
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: Sure, Henry, rejoice. And starve.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: MY OWN TRIALS IN THE garden have convinced me ''absolute weediness'' exists - that weeds represent a different order of being, and the fact that Thoreau's beans were no match for his weeds does not mean the weeds have a higher claim to the earth, as Thoreau seems to think. I found support for this conviction in the field guides and botany books I consulted when I was trying to identify my weeds. As I searched these volumes for the noms de bloom of my marauders, I jotted down each species' preferred habitats. Here are a few of the most typical: ''waste places and roadsides''; ''open sites''; ''old fields, waste places''; ''cultivated and waste ground''; ''old fields, roadsides, lawns, gardens''; ''lawns, gardens, disturbed sites.''
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: This list suggests that weeds are not superplants: they don't grow everywhere, which explains why, for all their vigor, they haven't covered the globe entirely. Weeds, as the field guides indicate, are plants particularly well-adapted to man-made places. They don't grow in forests or prairies - in ''the wild.'' Weeds thrive in gardens, meadows, lawns, vacant lots, railroad sidings, hard by dumpsters and in the cracks of sidewalks. They grow where we live, in other words, and hardly anywhere else.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: Weeds, contrary to what the romantics assumed, are not wild. They are as much a product of civilization as the hybrid tea rose, or Thoreau's bean plants. They do better than garden plants for the simple reason that they are better adapted to life in a garden. For where garden plants have been bred for a variety of traits (tastiness, size, esthetic appeal), weeds have evolved with just one end in view: the ability to thrive in ground that man has disturbed. And at this they are very accomplished indeed.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: Standing at the forefront of evolution, weeds are nature's ambulance chasers, carpetbaggers and confidence men. Virtually every crop in general cultivation has its weed impostor, a kind of botanical doppelganger that has evolved to mimic the appearance as well as the growth rate of the cultivated crop and so insure its survival. Some of these impostors, like wild oats, are so versatile that they can alter their appearance depending on the crop they are imitating - an agricultural fifth column.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: And yet as resourceful and aggressive as weeds may be, they cannot survive without us any more than a garden plant can. Without man to create cropland and lawns and vacant lots, most weeds would soon vanish. Bindweed, which seems so formidable in the field and garden, can grow nowhere else. It lives by the plow as much as we do.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: To learn all this was somehow liberating. My weeds were no more natural than my plants, had no higher claim to the space they were vying for. Battling weeds did not bespeak alienation from nature, or some irresponsible drive to dominate it. Had Thoreau known this, perhaps he would not have troubled himself so about ''what right had I to oust St. Johnswort, and the rest, and break up their ancient herb garden?''
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: Had Thoreau brought a field guide with him to Walden, he might have noted that most of the weeds that came up in his garden were alien species, brought to America by the colonists. St. Johnswort, far from being an ancient Walden resident, was brought to America in 1696 by a fanatic band of Rosicrucians who claimed the herb had the power to exorcise evil spirits. You want to privilege this over beans?
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: It's hard to imagine the American landscape without St. Johnswort, daisies, dandelions, crabgrass, timothy, clover, lamb's-quarters, buttercup, mullein, Queen Anne's lace, plantain, or deadly nightshade, but not one of these species grew here before the Puritans landed. America in fact had few indigenous weeds, for the simple reason that it had little disturbed land. The Indians lived so lightly on the land that they created few habitats in which weeds might take hold. No plow, no bindweed. But as early as 1663, when John Josselyn compiled a list ''of such plants as have sprung up since the English planted and kept cattle in New England,'' he found, among others, couch grass, dandelion, sow-thistle, shepherd's purse, groundsel, dock, mullein, plantain and chickweed.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: Some of these weeds were brought over deliberately: the colonists prized dandelion as a salad green, and used plantain (which is millet) to make bread. The seeds of other weeds, though, came by accident - in forage, in the earth used as shipboard ballast, even in pant cuffs and cracked boot soles.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: Once here, the weeds spread like wildfire. According to Alfred W. Crosby, the ecological historian, the Indians considered the Englishman a botanical Midas, able to change the flora with his touch; they called plantain ''Englishman's foot'' because it seemed to spring up wherever the white man stepped. Though most weeds traveled with white men, some, like the dandelion, raced west of their own accord (or possibly with the help of the Indians, who quickly discovered the plant's virtues), arriving well ahead of the pioneers. Thus the supposedly virgin landscape upon which the Western settlers gazed had already been marked by their civilization.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: Those same pioneers, however, did not gaze out on tumbleweed, that familiar emblem of the untamed Western landscape. Tumbleweed did not arrive in America until the 1870's, when a group of Russian immigrants settled in Bon Homme County, S.D., intending to grow flax. Mixed in with their flax seeds were a few seeds of a weed well known on the steppes of the Ukraine: tumbleweed.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: European weeds thrived here, in a matter of years changing the face of the American landscape and helping to create what we now take to be our country's abiding ''nature.'' Why should these species have prospered so? Probably because the Europeans who brought them got busy making the earth safe for weeds, razing the forests, plowing fields, burning prairies and keeping grazing animals. And just as the Europeans helped clear the way for their weeds, weeds helped clear the way for Europeans: Old World livestock fared poorly here until the European grasses they were accustomed to eating conquered American meadows. Today, most of the native grasses have vanished.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: Working in concert, European weeds and European humans proved formidable ecological imperialists, driving out native species and altering the land to suit themselves. The new species thrived because they were consummate cosmopolitans, opportunists superbly adapted to travel and change. In a sense, the invading weeds had less in common with the retiring, provincial plants they ousted than with the Europeans themselves.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: Or perhaps that should be put the other way around. ''If we confine the concept of weeds to species adapted to human disturbance,'' writes Jack R. Harlan in ''Crops and Man,'' ''then man is by definition the first and primary weed under whose influence all other weeds have evolved.''
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: Weeds are not the Other. Weeds are us. A PEDESTRIAN STANDING at the corner of Houston Street and La Guardia Place in Manhattan might think that the wilderness had reclaimed a tiny corner of the city's grid here. Ten years ago, an environmental artist persuaded the city to allow him to create on this site a ''Time Landscape'' showing New Yorkers what Manhattan looked like before the white man arrived. On a small hummock he planted oak, hickory, maples, junipers, and sassafras, and they've grown up to form a nearly impenetrable tangle, which is protected from New Yorkers by a steel fence now thickly embroidered with vines. It's exactly the sort of ''garden'' of which Emerson and Thoreau would have approved - for the very reason that it's not a garden. Or at least that's the conceit.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: I walk by this antigarden most mornings on my way to work, and for some reason it has always irritated me. It adjoins a lively community garden, where any summer evening will find a handful of neighborhood people busy cultivating their little patches of flowers and vegetables. Next to this display of enterprise, the untended ''Time Landscape'' makes an interesting foil. But the juxtaposition has always seemed a bit pat to me, a shade too righteous, and walking by one day last summer I figured out why.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: My mind fixed on the weeds just then hoisting victory flags over my own garden, I recognized one of the vines twining along the fence from the field guides I'd been consulting. It was deadly nightshade, a species, I recalled -and not without my own sweet pang of righteousness - that is not indigenous: it came to America with the white man. Ah ha! This smug little wilderness was in fact a garden after all. Unless somebody weeds it, assiduously and knowledgeably, it will be overrun with alien species. This ''Time Landscape'' is in perpetual danger of degenerating into an everyday vacant lot; only a gardener, armed with a hoe and a set of ''invidious distinctions,'' can save it.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: Once, of course, this would not have been the case. But by now, we have made so many changes in the land that some form of gardening has become unavoidable, even in those places we wish to preserve as a monument to our absence.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: This, it seems to me, is one of the lessons of last summer's massive fires in Yellowstone. At a certain point in history, doing nothing is not necessarily benign. Since 1972, park management in Yellowstone has followed a policy called ''natural burn,'' under which most naturally occurring fires are allowed to burn freely. All those previous years of firefighting, however, had left an abundance of unburned dead wood on the forest floor - and this is why, when the fires finally came in the drought year of 1988, they proved catastrophic. Yellowstone's eco-system having already been altered by the earlier policy of fire suppression, the new policy could not in any real sense be ''natural,'' nor were the fires it fostered.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: There's no going back. Even Yellowstone, our country's greatest ''wilderness,'' stands in need of careful management - it's too late in the day simply to ''leave it alone.'' I have no idea what the best fire policy for Yellowstone might be, but I do know that men and women, armed with scientific knowledge and acting through human institutions, will have to choose one. They will also have to decide how many tourists Yellowstone can support, whether wolves should be reintroduced to help keep the elk population from exploding, and a host of other complicated questions. Today, even Yellowstone must be ''gardened.''
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: A century after Thoreau wrote, ''In wildness is the preservation of the world,'' Wendell Berry, the Kentucky poet and farmer, added a corollary that probably would have made no sense to Thoreau: ''In human culture is the preservation of wildness.''
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: Thoreau, and his many descendants among contemporary naturalists and radical environmentalists, assume that human culture is the problem, not the solution. So they urge us to shed our anthropocentrism and learn to live among other species as equals. This sounds like a nice, ecological idea, until you realize that the earth would be even worse off than it is if we started behaving any more like animals than we already do. The survival strategy of most species is to extend their dominion as far and as brutally as they can, until they run up against some equally brutal natural limit that checks their progress. Isn't this precisely the course we've been on?
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: What sets us apart from other species is culture, and what is culture but forbearance? Conscience, ethical choice, discrimination: surely it is these very human, and decidedly unecological, principles that offer the planet its last best hope. It is true that, historically, we've concentrated on exercising these faculties in the human rather than the natural estate, but that doesn't mean they cannot be exercised there.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: If I seem to have wandered far afield of my topic, consider what weeding is: the process by which we make informed choices in nature, discriminate between good and bad, apply our intelligence and sweat to the earth. To weed is to apply culture to nature - which is why we say, when we are weeding, that we are cultivating the soil. Weeding, in this sense, is not a nuisance that follows from gardening, but its very essence.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: We cannot live in the world without changing nature irrevocably; having done so, we're obliged to tend to the consequences, which is to say, to weed. ''Weeding'' is what can save places like Yellowstone, but only if we recognize that weeding is not just something we do to the land - only if we recognize the need to cultivate our own nature, too. For though we may be the earth's gardeners, we are also its weeds. And we won't get anywhere until we come to terms with this ambiguity - that we are at once the problem and its only possible solution.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: EVENTUALLY I CAME to see that my weed-choked garden was ridiculous, even irresponsible. The garden plants had thrown in their lot with me, and I had failed to protect them from the weeds. So I ripped out the garden and began anew.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: This time, I cut a perfect rectangle in the grass, and planted my flower seeds in scrupulous rows, 18 inches apart and as straight as a plumb line could make them. As the seedlings came up, I cultivated assiduously between the rows, using the dutch hoe that my grandfather had given me. I didn't worry too much about epistemology: whatever came up between the rows I judged a weed and cut it down.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: The rows began as a convenience - but I've gotten to like the way they look; I guess by now I am more turned off by romantic conceits about nature than by a little artifice in the garden. Geometry is man's language, Le Corbusier said, and I am glad to have a garden that speaks in that tongue. I know better than to think a less-tended garden is any more natural; weeds are our words, too.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: As I see it, the day I decided to disturb the soil, I undertook an obligation to weed. For this soil is not virgin, and hasn't been for centuries. It teems with millions of weed seeds for whom the thrust of my spade represents the knock of opportunity.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: Not ''nature,'' strictly speaking, these seeds are really the descendants of earlier gardeners. To let them grow, to do nothing, is tantamount to letting those gardeners plant my garden: to letting all those superstitious Rosicrucians and Puritans and Russian immigrants have their way here. To do nothing, in other words, would be no favor to me, or my plants, or nature.
title: WEEDS ARE US

text: An Air Force lieutenant colonel and his wife, both psychologists assigned to the National Security Agency, were arrested on drug-selling charges today when police officers raided their house in the Washington suburb of Crofton.
title: 2 Workers at Security Agency Face Drug Counts After Raid

text: The couple's son and daughter were also charged, a spokesman for the Anne Arundel County police said, after officers seized $780,000 worth of illegal drugs, $70,000 in cash, two machine guns, an assault rifle, various shotguns, a motorcycle and a car from the house.
title: 2 Workers at Security Agency Face Drug Counts After Raid

text: Russell James Hibler, 43 years old, and Suzanne McCabe Hibler, 43, were charged with possession of the drugs with intent to distribute them. Drugs and Automatic Weapons
title: 2 Workers at Security Agency Face Drug Counts After Raid

text: The son, James Todd Hibler, 21, was charged with possession with intent to distribute cocaine, hashish and marijuana, and with unlawful possession of automatic weapons. The daughter, Jessica Lynn Hibler, 19, was charged with possession of the drugs with intent to distribute them.
title: 2 Workers at Security Agency Face Drug Counts After Raid

text: The parents were released on their own recognizance at a hearing before a District Court commissioner in Annapolis.
title: 2 Workers at Security Agency Face Drug Counts After Raid

text: Their son was held at the Anne Arundel County Detention Center here on $600,000 bond. Their daughter's bail was set at $155,000.
title: 2 Workers at Security Agency Face Drug Counts After Raid

text: In a raid early this morning, the police found found seven pounds of cocaine, four and a half pounds of hashish and 50 to 60 pounds of marijuana, said the county police spokesman, Joseph Bisesi. He said the agents found Jessica Hibler counting $27,000 in cash in the basement and discovered about $10,000 in bills stuffed in pockets around the house.
title: 2 Workers at Security Agency Face Drug Counts After Raid

text: The raid completed a two-month investigation, which mostly entailed surveillance of the family, Mr. Bisesi said. Son Was the Target
title: 2 Workers at Security Agency Face Drug Counts After Raid

text: The son had been the target of the investigation, and detectives were surprised to find how open the drug activities were inside the house, Mr. Bisesi said.
title: 2 Workers at Security Agency Face Drug Counts After Raid

text: ''There is no way the parents couldn't have known what was going on,'' a detective said.
title: 2 Workers at Security Agency Face Drug Counts After Raid

text: Neighbors said the Hiblers were a quiet family. ''Some kids went in and out of the house, and they worked out front on their cars occasionally,'' one neighbor said. ''Nothing seemed unusual.''
title: 2 Workers at Security Agency Face Drug Counts After Raid

text: The National Security Agency is the nation's largest intelligence unit, with a work force of more than 60,000 and a budget of more than $10 billion. It is primarily responsible for eavesdropping on communications around the world, coding United States communications and trying to crack the codes of foreign governments.
title: 2 Workers at Security Agency Face Drug Counts After Raid

text: The county police said military authorities entered the investigation because of the elder Hiblers' positions. The agency spokeswoman, who would not discuss the nature of the couple's duties, said their job status was ''up in the air'' until more information on the drug case was known.
title: 2 Workers at Security Agency Face Drug Counts After Raid

text: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to remove Federal District Judge Walter L. Nixon Jr. from the bench by finding him guilty on two of three articles of impeachment.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: The 61-year-old former judge, who sat in Biloxi, Miss., had been convicted in 1986 on perjury charges and sentenced to five years in prison.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: Mr. Nixon was alongside his lawyers in the well of the chamber facing the senators as they voted on the impeachment articles forwarded by the House. He nervously pulled on his thumb, occasionally glancing at a brochure about the history of the Senate that is given to tourists as they enter the Capitol building.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: Most of the senators rose solemnly, buttoning their jackets before casting their votes. On the first two articles, accusing Mr. Nixon of lying to Federal grand juries, the senators provided far more than the two-thirds of those present required for conviction and removal from office. He was acquitted on a third article accusing him of lying to investigators. Nixon in Halfway House
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: Mr. Nixon came to the Senate session from a Federal prison's halfway house in New Orleans. He is scheduled to be released Nov. 27 and could have returned to the bench.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: He became only the seventh Federal judge to be removed from office after impeachment proceedings, but the second in the last two weeks.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: According to testimony given at Mr. Nixon's 1986 trial, he lied to a grand jury about whether he attempted to influence a district attorney in delaying indefinitely a drug smuggling investigation of the son of a friend and prominent businessman.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: The impeachment proceedings were begun in the House after Mr. Nixon refused to resign after his conviction. Federal judges have lifetime tenure and Mr. Nixon had been receiving his annual salary of $89,500. It stopped today with his conviction.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: On Oct. 20, the Senate convicted and removed from the bench Alcee L. Hastings, a Federal district judge in Florida, for trying to obtain a $150,000 bribe and lying about it at his trial. Unlike Mr. Nixon, Mr. Hastings was acquitted at his trial. The acquittal forced the Senate to deal with issues of double jeopardy and fairness raised by Mr. Hastings. An Insurmountable Obstacle
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: David Stewart, Mr. Nixon's lawyer, said the fact he was convicted in a Federal trial presented an insurmountable obstacle in trying to persuade senators to allow him to remain on the bench.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: Mr. Nixon is only the second Federal judge to be convicted of a crime while on the bench and sent to prison. The other, Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne of Nevada, was convicted of filing false tax returns and convicted by the Senate in impeachment proceedings in 1986. Before that, there had not been an impeachment conviction for 50 years.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: Today, the Senate voted 89 to 8 for conviction on the first article of impeachment, that Mr. Nixon lied to a Federal grand jury when he said he never discussed the marijuana drug smuggling case with the District Attorney of Forrest County, Miss., a longtime friend. Conviction on one charge was enough to remove him from office.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: The Senate voted 78 to 19 to convict him of the second charge - that he lied to a Federal grand jury about the same matters. He was narrowly acquitted on the third, that he brought disgrace upon the Federal judiciary by lying to several law-enforcement agencies.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: The vote in favor of conviction was 57 to 40, eight votes short of the two-thirds majority. The third article had been fashioned in broader terms by House members in an effort to gain votes for conviction.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: ''It is thereby ordered and adjudged that the said Walter L. Nixon Jr. be removed from office,'' said Senator Robert C. Byrd, a West Virginia Democrat, presiding over the Senate.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: The night before the vote the Senate deliberated for more than six hours in private session on the charges.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: At the end of the proceedings, Mr. Nixon quickly walked from the chamber and spent a few minutes in an adjacent office with his wife, Barbara, and 12-year-old daughter.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: Speaking to reporters on the Capitol grounds, Mr. Nixon said he had no argument with how the proceedings were conducted save for the outcome.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: ''We have to go home and talk about things and see about getting on with our lives,'' he said. Mr. Nixon said he persisted because he was innocent, and not because he wanted to retain his salary as long as possible. The Federal Government has paid him more than $300,000 since his conviction.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: The grand jury to which Mr. Nixon was convicted of lying was looking into his ties to Wiley Fairchild, a Hattiesburg, Miss., businessman whose son was being investigated on drug smuggling charges. According to trial testimony, the son, Drew Fairchild, was apprehended at a Hattiesburg airport with more than a ton of marijuana. After Mr. Nixon talked to the District Attorney, the case against Drew Fairchild was put in an inactive file.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: The Senate designated a special committee to consider the evidence in detail presented by the House, which had taken testimony from Mr. Nixon. Mr. Nixon's lawyers complained that he was entitled to a trial by the full Senate, but the senators voted down a motion to have such a proceeding.
title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench

text: In ''Actually, Prohibition Was a Success'' (Op-Ed, Oct. 16), Mark Moore supports his argument with data on public health, violent crime and alcohol consumption.
title: Prohibition Was a Triumph for Minority Rule

text: His claim that home production was legal is wrong, and his use of statistics overstates the benefits of Prohibition. Violent crime rates and alcohol consumption were decreasing and public health was improving long before Prohibition was enacted. Improvements in the economy, in working conditions and medical care, as well as changing demographics, can explain most of the decline in the cirrhosis death rate. The general death rate declined at about the same rate. The alcoholism death rate was about the same before as during Prohibition.
title: Prohibition Was a Triumph for Minority Rule

text: Crime rates may be the most telling statistics. Before a rash of state prohibitions, World War I prohibition and Prohibition itself, the United States experienced a long-run decline in violent crimes. But violent and property crimes increased through the Prohibition period, only to reverse dramatically after repeal in 1933.
title: Prohibition Was a Triumph for Minority Rule

text: Alcohol consumption declined during Prohibition, but mostly among teetotalers. Some found substitutes, such as narcotics and hashish. Most important, while beer consumption fell dramatically, wine and spirits consumption increased. Also, alcohol products tended to be more potent. Irving Fisher, a champion of the dry cause, noted that ''it requires only a tenth as much of bootleg liquor as of pre-Prohibition liquor to produce a given degree of drunkenness.''
title: Prohibition Was a Triumph for Minority Rule

text: While this may seem exaggerated, compare the effects of crack cocaine and black-market heroin with the cocaine in Coca-Cola and the heroin pills sold by the Bayer Company before the Harrison Narcotics Act. The potency of marijuana has increased several hundred percent since it was outlawed in 1937.
title: Prohibition Was a Triumph for Minority Rule

text: The only success that can be attached to prohibitions is the ability of one group to impose its wishes (not necessarily morality) on another. The only amazing difference with alcohol Prohibition was that a minority was able to impose its wishes on a majority of voters - the drinking class. MARK THORNTON Auburn University, Ala., Oct. 19, 1989 The writer, an Auburn assistant professor of economics, wrote his dissertation on Prohibition.
title: Prohibition Was a Triumph for Minority Rule

text: Because of an editing error, an article by The Associated Press in some editions on Saturday about a farm where marijuana was found growing last year misstated an admission made by Robert Machin as part of a settlement to keep the farm. He admitted he had grown the plants; he did not admit having done so to pay property taxes.
title: Corrections

text: A Queens intermediate school teacher was arrested yesterday after the police assigned to the Commission on Integrity in the Public Schools saw her buying and using cocaine and found marijuana in her purse, a commission spokeswoman said.
title: Teacher Is Arrested On Drug Charges

text: The teacher, Ruby Blue, 37 years old, of 52 Belmont Parkway in Hempstead, Long Island, has been a health education teacher at Intermediate School 227 in East Elmhurst since 1984, said a commission spokeswoman, Jennifer Cunningham.
title: Teacher Is Arrested On Drug Charges

text: The police were asked to investigate after the commission received a tip that Ms. Blue used drugs during the school day and regularly appeared to be under the influence of drugs, Ms. Cunningham said.
title: Teacher Is Arrested On Drug Charges

text: On Oct. 12, undercover officers saw her drive with a companion to a grocery store in Corona known by police for drug sales, Ms. Cunningham said. Her companion entered the store, came out with a package, and officers later saw Ms. Blue smoking something, Ms. Cunningham said.
title: Teacher Is Arrested On Drug Charges

text: The cigarette butt she discarded was retrieved and later found to contain cocaine, Ms. Cunningham said.
title: Teacher Is Arrested On Drug Charges

text: On Nov. 1, officers again saw her enter the grocery store. She was arrested as she left and charged with possession of cocaine and marijuana, Ms. Cunningham said.(AP)
title: Teacher Is Arrested On Drug Charges

text: Because of an editing error, an article by The Associated Press in late editions on Saturday (reprinted in some copies on Sunday about a Vermont farm where marijuana was found growing last year misstated the number of plants involved. The state police found 12 plants, not 200, on the farm, owned by Robert Machin and Joann Liddell.
title: Corrections

text: Twelve days after it removed one Federal judge from the bench, the Senate today began floor action in the impeachment trial of another.
title: Senate Opens Trial of Another U.S. Judge

text: The defendant is Walter L. Nixon, a Federal district judge from Mississippi who last year began serving a prison term for perjury. Despite his imprisonment, Judge Nixon has continued to receive the $89,500 annual salary due each member of the Federal bench.
title: Senate Opens Trial of Another U.S. Judge

text: Judge Nixon's perjury conviction stemmed from his telling a grand jury that he had never discussed a marijuana smuggling case with a local prosecutor who was an old friend.
title: Senate Opens Trial of Another U.S. Judge

text: Actually, according to impeachment articles voted by the House of Representatives last May, drug charges against Drew Fairchild, son of a wealthy contractor, were dropped after Judge Nixon discussed the case with his friend, District Attorney Paul Holmes of Forrest County, Miss.
title: Senate Opens Trial of Another U.S. Judge

text: Today Judge Nixon took the Senate floor and declared, ''I have been wrongfully convicted.'' He said that witnesses against him had lied and that prosecutors had held him to an unreasonably high standard of accuracy in sworn statements.
title: Senate Opens Trial of Another U.S. Judge

text: A vote by the Senate could come as early as Friday, two weeks after the chamber ousted Alcee L. Hastings, a Federal district judge from Florida, for plotting to obtain a bribe and lying about it to a jury.
title: Senate Opens Trial of Another U.S. Judge

text: The long history of migrant labor in America's orchards and fields has been a chronicle of debt, dependency and fear. Now the discovery of a written record of degradation and servitude among sweet potato pickers at a farm near here has demonstrated anew how little the lives of migrant workers have changed.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: Labor Department investigators, on an unannounced tour in October through the flat, sandy farms of Eastern North Carolina, picked up a secret set of accounts that complements the legitimate records of workers' wages. The record is typical of those used throughout much of migrant labor farming today, the investigators say, though they acknowledge they are a rarely able to put their hands on one.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: Investigators believe the hand-written ledger in a spiral-bound notebook records the illegal sales of cheap wine, tobacco and drugs that the leader of a migrant agricultural crew has made to his workers, with all the sales on credit.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: Although legislation has improved the lot of the migrant worker in recent years, investigators see the ledger as a sign of the continuing system in which migrant workers are confined in almost medieval shackles of dependency.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: Labor Department officials and advocates for the workers say the system binds the workers to their toil and their source of supply - the crew leaders -through both addiction and debt.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: When payday arrives on Saturday night, a worker learns that the crack a crew leader might have provided him was not a gift and that his wages are too meager to cover the charges. Investigators say these transactions, like the ''wine books'' that record them, have been widespread for decades among American migrant workers in the Southeast, especially those who are black. But the investigators say evidence of the abuse is all but impossible to obtain. The emergence of crack, displacing marijuana, simply reinforces the system, they say.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: ''That's an ideal environment for drug usage to take place,'' said James V. Witmer, assistant district director of the Labor Department's wage and hour office in Raleigh, who headed the compliance team that found the book. ''A drug dealer can develop a captive work force. We are hearing more and more about drug usage and payment for work in drug form instead of cash.''
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: Other abuses seem to be cropping up, too. Mary Lee Hall, a lawyer with the nonprofit Farmworkers Legal Services of North Carolina, said that this season she has heard reports of crew leaders' seizing documents like immigration papers and driver's licenses. ''It's a new form of coercion,'' she said. Some Improvements
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: Laws and regulations have improved some things, notably housing and medical care. Farmers are also held more accountable for the crew leaders they hire, and some bigger farmers, who have the most to lose in penalties for infractions of the law, are more vigilant than they were about workers' treatment. Even so, some abuses continue.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: This season, 30,000 to 50,000 migrant workers are toiling in North Carolina, the third-largest state in migrant employment after California and Florida. Many are Hispanic, mostly Mexican, workers who are younger, healthier and brimming with hope and show little evidence of substance abuse, officials say. But many lack the documents needed to work legally and are constrained by the fear of deportation if they complain.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: It is the black workers, recruited for generations from the ranks of the hopeless on skid rows and backwaters of the rural South with promises of travel and better lives, who are most likely to be caught up in the snares of debt and drugs recorded in the wine books, officials say. Crew leaders, themselves former migrant workers with similar backgrounds, try to hold them to the farms where they live in isolated camps, sleeping three to a room, often without indoor toilets. Rough Weeks for Workers
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: These are especially difficult weeks for the workers here - rougher, the workers say, than most of those they spend moving north with their crew leaders or harvesting citrus fruits in Florida, peaches in Georgia, cucumbers and tobacco in the Carolinas and cabbages in Delaware.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: Harvesting sweet potatoes, of which North Carolina is by far the nation's largest producer, requires stooping, kneeling and digging with bare hands into soil that is often wet and cold. Under ideal conditions, a quick and healthy worker can earn more than the minimum wage.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: To do so, he must keep pace with a truck rolling alongside him. The worker delivers bucket upon bucket of high-quality potatoes, classed as No. 1 potatoes, and chucks the lower-quality potatoes for canning into piles between the rows; he is not paid for the canning potatoes. In return for each bucket of No. 1 potatoes, the worker gets a plastic chip entitling him to 35 cents on payday.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: However many buckets they fill, the law requires that migrant workers receive at least the $3.35-an-hour minimum wage. That makes them the only sizable adult occupational group living on the minimum wage except for restaurant waiters and waitresses, and potato pickers do not get tips. Farm workers also do not have to be paid a higher wage for overtime work.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: ''I had a laborer last year make as much as $200 a week,'' said Odell Jackson, who farms 400 acres in Dunn, 250 of them in sweet potatoes. But the conditions this year are less than ideal. Bad Year for Sweet Potatoes
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: Because of an immense amount of rain in the spring and summer, Mr. Jackson said, much of the first growth of potatoes rotted. He said he expected his harvest to be half that of the best years. The potatoes are also smaller, which means the workers have to pick more to fill their buckets.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: A 27-year-old worker who called himself Clayton but like many of those interviewed declined to give his full name, works on one of Dunn's largest farms. One day last year, he said, he picked 186 buckets of potatoes, earning $65.10. ''My best this year is 80 buckets,'' he said, which earned him $30.10. He said he avoids drugs but that there are plenty around his camp.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: Whatever the wage law, some workers say they sometimes end the week without a cent. Johnny Miller, 31, said he had just escaped a sweet potato farm here after receiving no money for five weeks. ''Yeah, I do cocaine,'' he said. ''The crew leader gives it to you and tells you you don't have to pay for it.'' Then, he said, a $40 charge for cocaine showed up in his crew leader's wine book.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: Mr. Miller said he once tried to leave the farm and hitch a ride to town but was stopped by ''goons'' wielding 2-by-4's. He said he escaped, by running across a soybean field and flagging down a county sheriff's deputy. List of Numbers
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: In the wine books, Mr. Witmer of the Labor Department said, crew leaders record the claims that they make on the workers' wages, beyond the $40 or $50 per week that they charge for their meals. The name of a worker is written at the top of each page, which, except for the occasional date and odd notation, is nothing but a list of numbers showing dollars and cents. But the crew leaders know what transaction each charge represents.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: The book Mr. Witmer's compliance team found records transactions between the crew leader and his 19 workers from the time they arrived at the farm, about Sept. 20, until Oct. 9, the day before the compliance team's visit.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: The officers believe that a recurring charge of 60 cents is for soft drinks, one for $1.50 is for Doral cigarettes that normally sell in a convenience store here for 99 cents, and one for $2.50 is for pints of fortified wines that normally sell for half as much or less.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: The investigators could not identify some charges, like one for $6. Mr. Witmer said that it might be for drugs but that drug transactions might be handled separately. Drugs or no drugs, just about every transaction in the book is illegal. Selling alcohol violates one law; overcharging for it or anything else violates another.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: The investigators would not identify the farm or the crew leader. They said the inquiry was continuing and could lead to fines for the farm and withdrawal of the crew leader's license. Some Avoid Debt
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: The book also shows that a few workers steadfastly avoid debt, alcohol and tobacco. Nine of the 12 charges assessed against one worker one week were for 60 cents - soft drinks. In his case and in those of two other frugal workers, the crew leader imposed a $5 charge for light in the camp house that he did not assess the others.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: Amy Trester, an outreach worker for an Episcopal mission in Dunn, sees the health toll that drugs, alcohol and digging sweet potatoes take on the workers who climb aboard an aged white bus that stops at the migrant camps four days a week. The bus brings ailing workers to the Tri County Community Health Center near here.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: A worker from Mississippi who called himself James and said he has worked with the same crew leader for 10 years pulls himself aboard the bus in front of a camp house. He is 47, but shuffles and lists like a man much older. He declined to discuss drugs and alcohol at his camp, but suggested that he had built a dependent relationship upon the crew leader.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: ''He's a good guy,'' he said. ''He feeds me. He knows I'm not able to work much.'' He was taking the bus to the clinic, he said, because of ''high blood and bad nerves.'' 'Multiple Chronic Diseases'
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: Dr. James Misak, a youthful Chicagoan who is the medical director at the clinic, described the ailments he sees in the sweet potato workers. ''They have multiple chronic diseases, like diabetes, hypertension, asthma, tuberculosis,'' he said.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: ''The incidence of substance abuse appears to be high,'' the doctor went on. ''Alcohol is the most widely abused. And tobacco. It's been difficult to get a good determination on how much cocaine or crack there is because it is difficult to detect. They also have multiple musculoskeletal problems like back pain, slipped disks, bursitis and tendinitis.''
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: Just about everyone is blamed for the work conditions - the crew leaders, the farmers, Federal and state officials for not committing enough resources to enforcing the law, people like Ms. Hall from the Farmworkers Legal Services organization and official regulators whom farmers accuse of harassing them, and even the workers themselves.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: ''A lot of these people are in fact wine heads,'' Mr. Witmer of the Labor Department said. ''We ask, 'What is your address?' and they say, 'Whatever the crew leader's is.' ''
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: Debt servitude, he said, ''is a lot more subtle'' than it was two or three decades ago.
title: Drugs and Debt: Shackles of Migrant Worker

text: Once confined to a class session or two reciting horror stories and statistics, drug education in America is undergoing radical changes as the crack epidemic touches the lives of younger children across the country.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Rather than frightening students, as teachers often found themselves trying to do following the drug curriculum of the past, schools are now seeking to help students develop personal traits that make them resist drugs: strengthening their ability to make sound judgments, to handle the stressful times of life, to resist pressure from friends and to resolve confusing signals at home and in the community.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Visits to classrooms from the heart of Brooklyn to the heart of America here indicated that drug classes are now being introduced a great deal earlier than ever before and they are laced through a child's school career. Need for Studies Is Cited
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Preliminary indications are that the newer courses may have a beneficial effect on the students who take them. But critics of drug education programs, old and new, contend that far too little scientific evaluation has been done to know for certain. And they say the Bush Administration's new anti-drug policy does not provide enough money for such research.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: In the schools in this area, where stores stock dolls of Dorothy of Kansas innocently skipping through Oz, teachers now give 15 lessons a year coaching sixth, seventh and eighth graders on how to refuse drugs. A skit illustrates how.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: In the improvisation by eighth graders, Monica Navarro warned Danita Conway that she would tell their friends that Danita is a wimp for declining marijauna. Danita, using the ploy of ''reverse pressure'' she has just learned, snapped back that she will tell their friends ''your momma still tucks you in at night.'' Lessons Conveyed Simply
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Or, in the crack-ravaged Bushwick neighborhood of Brooklyn, Sharon Fleishman may never mention the drug to her kindergarten pupils, but she helps the 5-year-olds understand the importance of caring for their health. In a 20-minute class about prescription drugs that she enlivens with cartoons of an intoxicated raccoon, she tries to convey a simple lifelong lesson: ''Only sick people should be taking drugs.''
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: The scare tactics implicit in earlier programs, particularly those of the 60's and early 70's, were based on the notion that stark facts and figures about the intoxicating effects and health perils of drugs would speak for themselves and send the message. But the thinking now is that the presentation of simple facts without helping a child deal with them has sometimes had the opposite effect. Particularly among children of poor neighborhoods, the facts often seemed to make drugs more enticing.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: ''Children don't learn by scare tactics,'' said Anne Garfinkel, a drug education teacher in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn. Even experts who say such tactics can be effective for some children acknowledge that other approaches are needed in inner cities.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Paul J. Brounstein, senior research associate at the Urban Institute, said these tactics work best with people who have something to lose. But, he added, ''if you're dealing with older, inner-city kids, kids with an experience of failure, with few perceived opportunities, you've got to overcome a major hurdle, which says drugs are an alternative to economic success.''
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: The fact is that most students already know a good deal about the legal and health perils of crack and other drugs. What they often do not know, particularly if they come from chaotic or broken homes, is how to make important personal decisions and how to defend their values, says Ginay Marks, the drug coordinator of School District 15 in southern Brooklyn, which has one of New York's most ambitious programs.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Teachers who lead anti-drug classes are also trying to get across the idea that when children feel hopeless, as almost everyone does from time to time, there are solutions other than drugs. Gauging the Success Positive Indications, But With Cautions One persuasive study of the effects of drug education, published this year, focused on the Kansas City metropolitan area's experimental Refusal Skills program, the one taken by Danita and Monica. Researchers found that a year after taking the class, 3 percent of the students reported they smoked cigarettes, 4 percent drank alcohol, and 3 percent used marijuana. Figures for the schools where the program was not taught were higher: 13 percent smoked tobacco, 9 percent drank and 7 percent used marijuana.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: But Dr. Joel Moskowitz, a research psychologist at the University of California at Berkeley, is quick to caution that schools chosen for the Kansas City experiment were not, strictly speaking, randomly picked. They were selected because their schedules were most flexible. Nevertheless, it turned out that the students given the drug instruction and those who were not were roughly identical in economic and racial backgrounds.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Dr. Moskowitz, who reviews applications for Federal grants for drug programs, notes that other studies that seem to show favorable results are not fully conclusive. They are usually doneat well-functioning schools for middle-class children, he said. Even when they are conducted at schools with diverse populations, the reseachers often lose track of the most troubled students, and these are the ones most likely to use drugs eventually.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: ''Nationally and locally there are no well-evaluated effective models for 'what works' in prevention and education,'' said a June report by Interface, a private Manhattan research group.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Still, teachers say they must try something, even if it is based only on their hunches about what will work. ''We're the only agency that can make a difference on children,'' said Cathy L. Sillman, supervisor of drug education for the Kansas City, Kan., schools. Selecting a Program A Call for 25 Hours Of Class in a Year About 70 percent of the nation's schoolchildren get at least one class in drug education during their school years, said Zili Amsel, acting director of prevention research for the National Institute of Drug Abuse. But Robert M. Stutman, special agent in charge of the New York office of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, said more than 25 hours of classes a year that are led by teachers are needed to bring about ''attitudinal changes.'' Most programs, he said, offer six to eight hours a year, do not start until junior high school and may use outsiders unfamiliar with classic teaching techniques.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: School systems battling complaints that students cannot read and write well enough are finding it difficult to pack 25 hours of drug education into a school year. Nevertheless, many have bolstered their programs. After complaints last year from Mayor Edward I. Koch that too few elementary school children were receiving drug instruction, Richard R. Green, then the New York City School Chancellor, mandated that every student receive at least eight hours. The city now spends $34.5 billion a year on drug education.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Increasingly, instruction is starting in kindergarten. Experts have persuaded many parents that because children begin using illegal drugs in elementary school, they need to be alerted early. The average user's initiation age, said Ginay Marks, is 12.6 years old.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Most school systems cannot afford the time to invent their own drug programs, so they have adopted programs tried other places. These programs, complete with tapes, models and manuals, bear catchy titles like ''Here's Looking at You, 2000,'' ''Growing Healthy'' and ''Project Star.'' Building self-worth and rehearsing strategies to resist pressure from others are part of all the programs, along with a focus on health habits and drug information. Reaching the Youngest Drugs' Effects As a Health Matter ''Growing Healthy,'' sponsored in part by the New York Academy of Medicine, has been adopted by schools in 41 states. It tries to subtly steer children in kindergarten through seventh grade away from drugs, alcohol and tobacco.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Children learn about nutritious foods, brushing their teeth and caring for their eyes. Only occasionally are drugs mentioned. In the fifth grade, students will dissect a calf's lung and inflate the air sacs with straws. This vivid illustration, teachers hope, will buttress lessons about the harms of smoking tobacco and marijuana.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Ms. Fleishman's kindergartners in Brooklyn get a ''Growing Healthy'' lesson three times a week. Showing cartoons from a book, Ms. Fleishman told them that only parents should be giving them drugs. Walking a Fine Line
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: ''If you see your brother and sister taking some medicine, what are you going to do?'' she asked. ''Call my mother,'' one boys shouted. ''Throw it in the toilet,'' another said.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: ''My cat was playing with it,'' said 6-year-old Jason Mungen, ''and I went to my mommy and she told my brother to put it back in the cabinet.''
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Such lessons, teachers believe, are essential in a neighborhood like Bushwick where children with drug-addicted mothers are often being reared by grandmothers. Ms. Fleishman recalls that several years ago, when she first mentioned cocaine, a 5-year-old said: ''My mother takes that white stuff and puts it up her nose.''
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: ''I have to walk a fine line between teaching children not to take drugs and not condemning their parents,'' said Ms. Fleishman. ''I try to explain that sometimes adults do things that aren't good for them.''
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: For Kansas City second graders, who receive 30 lessons a year from the ''Here's Looking at You'' program, the message is more overt. Seven children in Katie Mathews's class at the M. E. Pearson School arranged themselves like the organs of a human body by standing on chairs of varying heights. In Exhaustion, a Lesson
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Walter Dobbins played the brain, his fingers pecking away in the air like someone at a computer. Mark Reyes was the heart, pumping his arms like someone inflating a bicycle tire. Nicole Rodriguez and Camila Martinez played the lungs, taking deep breaths. Crystal Stafford and Linda Davis were the kidneys, making broomlike motions to sweep away poisons.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: First, Mrs. Mathews had these organs go about their jobs at a easy rhythm, just as a healthy body would. Then she asked how they might respond if a drug were injected into this imaginary body. The actors speeded up and giggled. ''Don't stop, keep going,'' Mrs. Mathews urged. When they seemed really fatigued, she let them stop.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: ''Imagine what would happen to a human body if it never stopped and you just keep putting drugs in and the organs would keep going faster and faster and faster,'' she gently said. Middle School Approaches How 'Just Say No' Can Be Practice
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Children in more than 50 middle schools in Kansas City, Kan., and across the Missouri River in Kansas City, Mo., are learning from ''Project Star,'' a 15-lesson program that teaches ''resistance skills.'' It was begun by the local Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation after disclosures of cocaine use by four Kansas City Royals baseball players.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: ''A lot of kids want to say no, but they don't know how,'' said Glenn Schoenfish, principal of the Argentine Middle School, on the Kansas side.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: In Sally Welter's physical education class, children talked about ways their friends might entice, threaten or tease them to use drugs. Then, with prodding from Ms. Welter, they figured out ploys to combat the pressure. They decided on these methods: the Cold Shoulder, the Broken Record (constantly repeating refusals), the Good Excuse and Strength in Numbers (allying with friends who will not try drugs). 'O.K. to Be One of a Kind'
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: At Public School 32 in the drug-ridden Gowanus neighborhood of Brooklyn, Anne Garfinkel, known to her students as ''the drug lady,'' commands the classroom like a conductor, squeezing just the right shadings of meaning from students.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: ''I'm going to give you a $25 word,'' she told a sixth-grade class and wrote ''unique'' on the blackboard. ''What does it mean?''
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: After students ventured some definitions, she had them compose a three-column chart of how the class members were like all other people, like some other people and like no other people.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: All people are alike, the students agreed, in needing food, clothing and shelter. Some are alike in tastes, opinions and talents. Nobody is alike in the way they look, their voices, even their fingerprints.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: ''What have you learned?'' Ms. Garfinkel asked.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: ''It's O.K. to be one of a kind,'' a boy in the front volunteered. Ms. Garfinkel smiled. Outcome Can Be Deadly In older grades, the drug question is addressed more explicitly. But individuality and clear thinking are discussed as well.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Mark Sherman told his class of ninth graders in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, the news story of a 16-year-old Long Island girl whose boyfriend, after drinking several beers, was killed trying to beat a train across the tracks.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: ''Those people who ran across the railroad track - did they think they were going to die?'' the teacher asked.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: He wrote the word ''omnipotent'' on the board and suggested that the boyfriend might have been thinking: 'I'm quick and strong and I've got good reflexes.''
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Leaving the class, Israel Guzman, a student, said: ''It makes you think. If I do this, then this is going to happen. If I don't do this, then this is going to happen.'' High School Challenges An Emphasis On Social Skills By high school, students are given much more detailed information, but the emphasis remains on social skills.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: Gregory Faulkner, an instructor at Phoenix House, a Manhattan drug treatment organization, visits a health class at Washington Irving High School in the Gramercy Park area for a series of three lessons and informs them that the euphoria of crack lasts 20 to 40 minutes and is followed by a long depression. But his main focus is on getting students to talk about what they most value and how drugs may affect those values.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: ''Can a drug user really say he's valuing his health?'' he asked a class.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: In an exercise, Reheim Moye, 17, acted the part of a senior class president who is being urged by the vice president, played by Jacqueline Moran, 17, to allow a keg of beer and marijuana on the annual class trip. The class evaluated Reheim's predicament.
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: ''People will lose respect for him if he turns around and does the same thing she wants him to do,'' said one girl in the front row. But another added: ''If you don't do it, you could lose friends.''
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: For the most part, the students gave answers that adults would hope for. Reheim said he found the class valuable. ''It puts you in a situation where you have to deal with your emotions.''
title: LEARNING TO SAY NO: SCHOOLS AND THE DRUG WAR - A SPECIAL REPORT: Judgment Replaces Fear in Drug Lessons

text: LEAD: TUCKED among the rural landscape of Hunterdon County could be one of the answers to substance abuse that the Federal Government is seeking.
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: TUCKED among the rural landscape of Hunterdon County could be one of the answers to substance abuse that the Federal Government is seeking.
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: A treatment program intended to help abusers who have recently been hospitalized, called Early Recovery/Relapse Prevention, started this month at Hunterdon Drug Awareness, a nonprofit agency here, under the direction of a substance-abuse counselor, Harry O'Rourke.
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: Mr. O'Rourke says this type of program works. While working in Somerville at the Somerset Council on Alcoholism, he saw, he said, that fewer than 50 percent of the 50 alcohol abusers enrolled in a similar program from April 1987 to April 1988 returned to abusing alcohol.
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: But Mr. O'Rourke, who spent 21 years in the Air Force, including two Vietnam tours in air rescue, feels uncomfortable with the term ''success rate'' when applied to the battle against substance abuse.
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: ''To say there's a 30 percent or 90 percent success rate is misleading,'' he said. ''People tend to relapse less, and get well faster and more permanently, the more treatment they're exposed to.''
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: Hunterdon Drug Awareness's Early Recovery/Relapse Prevention program is convenient, Mr. O'Rourke said, for people who received their primary care in Pennsylvania or New York and cannot travel back and forth to those states for a three- to four-month period several nights a week.
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: Mr. O'Rourke, who often speaks in military terms, has worked in substance-abuse programs for seven years, including work at the Somerset Council and at Honesty House, a residential treatment center in Stirling, in Morris County. 'Basic Training for Recovery'
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: ''Inpatient care is basic training for recovery,'' Mr. O'Rourke said. ''We step back from the world we're in, focus on ourselves, and stop drinking and drugging for at least 42 days. In this so-called war on drugs, I can only tell you what I see from my vantage point. I see the individual, the family, suffering. People working in this field are making fantastic strides. To win the war, we've got to focus more on the user.''
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: Mr. O'Rourke said participants in the Early Recovery/Relapse Prevention program, at 8 Main Street, would meet each Monday through Jan. 29. The sessions, from 7:30 to 9 P.M., are open to all New Jersey residents. The fee for each session is $20.
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: ''The program is very important,'' Mr. O'Rourke said, ''because users who leave inpatient care and go immediately to Alcoholics Anonymous or Narcotics Anonymous experience culture shock. Our program provides a more comfortable, necessary transition period.''
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: One reason, he said, is that the groups in his program are kept small, usually 10 to 15 people, and the informality encourages people to share experiences.
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: Substance abusers in Mr. O'Rourke's program use guides to recovery, like the 12-step lesson of Alcoholics Anonymous.
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: A young woman, a cashier who is in the Early Recovery/Relapse Prevention program, said that substance abusers right out of inpatient treatment needed to ''get their knowledge better.'' 'Drugs Are Always Around'
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: ''Drugs are always around,'' said the woman, a former marijuana and alcohol abuser who asked not to be identified. ''I'm in this program to continue talking about my feelings. I need to do this and I need to talk to someone else who knows what I'm going through, someone who has gone through this.''
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: She said the first of Alcoholics Anonymous's 12 steps was the hardest and the most helpful. ''The first step is saying we admitted we are powerless over alcohol and drugs and our lives have become unmanageable,'' she said.
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: ''The beauty of group,'' Mr. O'Rourke said, ''is that people learn from each other's feelings, experiences and failures. It's all right for me to not be terrific, which seems easier to say when you hear someone else saying it.''
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: Adrienne Peck, executive director of Hunterdon Drug Awareness, said the agency has many other programs available to people in trouble with chemical substances. The programs include confidential, individual, family and group counseling. Counselors from the center, she said, also give classroom lectures at local high schools one day a week.
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: Ms. Peck said there was a lot of cocaine and marijuana use in Hunterdon County, some methamphetamine use and a small amount of heroin use. State health officials estimate there are 57,000 crack users and 93,000 cocaine abusers in New Jersey. Alcohol, however, is the most abused drug, she said. Financial Problem Cited
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: Ms. Peck and Mr. O'Rourke concurred that Hunterdon Drug Awareness had waiting lists in the past. One reason was lack of financing for patients who could not afford treatment.
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: When abusers' ''drinking and drugging has gotten them into a spot where they no longer have a job, no longer have medical coverage, that's where we're really hurting,'' Mr. O'Rourke said.
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: Hunterdon Awareness, a United Way member agency, uses a sliding scale, down to zero, for people who have little or no money. Still, Ms. Peck said, financing for all substance abuse programs is not adequate.
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: ''If someone needs inpatient treatment in Hunterdon County, there is only $24,000 available through the local advisory committee on alcohol and drug abuse,'' Ms. Peck said. ''That's nothing. They limit it to $2,000 per person and it's hard to find a treatment facility that will accept someone for that amount when treatment costs about $2,000 a week.''
title: New Program Begins For Substance Abusers

text: THE DARK HALF By Stephen King. 431 pp. New York: Viking. $21.95.
title: HIS ALTER EGO IS A KILLER

text: This is not the first time that Stephen King has written a dark allegory of the fiction writer's situation. ''Misery'' (1987) is a parable in chiller form of the popular writer's relation to his audience, which holds him prisoner and dictates what he writes, on pain of death. Mr. King's new novel, ''The Dark Half,'' is a parable in chiller form of the popular writer's relation to his creative genius, the vampire within him, the part of him that only awakes to raise Cain when he writes, the fratricidal twin who occupies ''the womblike dungeon'' of his imagination.
title: HIS ALTER EGO IS A KILLER

text: Thaddeus Beaumont is the writer in question. At age 11 he writes his first story. Around the same time he begins to get excruciating headaches, which culminate in a convulsion. Surgery reveals something startling - first an eye, then other small fragments of an incompletely absorbed twin that's lodged in his brain. This sort of ''in utero cannibalism,'' according to his doctor, is not unusual, although rarely is anything left undigested, as it is in Thad Beaumont's case.
title: HIS ALTER EGO IS A KILLER

text: The operation is a success, and Thad grows up to be a mild-mannered professor of creative writing, a doting husband and the father of twins, a modestly successful writer of novels with titles like ''Purple Haze.'' But under the pen name of George Stark he is the best-selling author of ferocious thrillers like ''Sharkmeat Pie,'' the protagonist of which is named Alexis Machine because he kills like one.
title: HIS ALTER EGO IS A KILLER

text: Circumstances force Thad to own up to his pseudonym, which in any case has become irksome. He has decided to go it on his own, to lay his fictional self to rest. He and his wife even hold a mock burial service for George Stark, papier-mache tombstone and all. But one morning a man-sized cavity is discovered at the site. Footprints lead away. Very soon, people begin to die horribly, in particular everybody associated with Thad's decision to bury George Stark, whose prose style governs the graphic and gruesome descriptions of the murders. For George Stark has materialized. As Stark himself puts it, ''The word became flesh, you might say.''
title: HIS ALTER EGO IS A KILLER

text: But George Stark is not content to be merely undead. He wants to be alive entirely. He wants Thad to begin another novel under Stark's name. In fact, he wants to collaborate with Thad, to learn how to write, to become independent. Unless Thad complies, Stark will truly fade out of existence, for his flesh has begun to rot, decay, stink and ooze fluids, although no outside force seems capable of destroying him. Thad is forced to comply, for Stark has taken his wife and children hostage. As the collaboration gets going, Stark begins to heal; Thad develops running sores.
title: HIS ALTER EGO IS A KILLER

text: On the whole, Mr. King is tactful in teasing out the implications of his parable - never mind an author's note that acknowledges a debt to ''the late Richard Bachman,'' Mr. King's own pseudonym, without whom ''this novel could not have been written.'' No character in the novel comes right out and says, for example, that writers exist (at least to readers) only in their writing, that each person (at least to himself) is his own fiction, that the writer's imagination can feel alien to him, a possessing and possessive demon, a Dracula arisen to prey on the whole man and his family. Nor does anyone in the novel say outright that reality inevitably leaks fiction, which then floods reality, that reality and fiction feed on and feed each other, that they are at war yet they are twins - so identical that attempts to say which is which only lead to more fictions. Such things are better left unsaid, anyhow. Stephen King is not a post-modernist.
title: HIS ALTER EGO IS A KILLER

text: He is, however, a very good storyteller. ''The Dark Half'' mostly succeeds, as both parable and chiller, in spite of occasional cliches of thought and expression and bits of sophomoric humor (the F.B.I. is ''the Effa Bee Eye,'' marijuana is ''wacky tobaccy''). At the end, the decent family man wins out, but at a cost - which is how it should be. Most readers, I believe, will want decency and reality to triumph, but only with some reluctance, only after their most monstrous imaginings, like George Stark, have been unearthed and indulged. And few writers around are better than Stephen King at giving readers what they want.
title: HIS ALTER EGO IS A KILLER

text: The only time Anna Pavlova wasn't acting, says Lydia Sokolova, was when she was asleep - and even then one could not be sure. This is from ''Dancing for Diaghilev: The Memoirs of Lydia Sokolova,'' edited by Richard Buckle (Mercury House).
title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE

text: Pavlova was immaculate on and off the stage, with never a hair out of place. At home she wore pastel colours to show off her sleek dark hair. Her hats often had ospreys drooping round the brim to soften her face. The way she used her hands or placed her feet with their great arched insteps all combined to produce an impression of art. She always wore flowers, which became her better than mink.
title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE

text: One day during that summer of 1912 she took two of us with her into her aviary of tropical birds. It was very high, with a rounded top. She walked straight into it through double doors and stood with her arms outstretched. The many-coloured birds showed no fear and behaved as if she was one of them. She then took us to the lake at the bottom of her garden where she knelt down and called to her pet swan. The bird came to her immediately, and she folded her arms round its neck and talked to it gently. The swan's mate, meanwhile, remained watching nearby in absolute stillness. Any Strong Emotion Will Do
title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE

text: Art moves people in mysterious ways, as this story shows. It's from ''Broadway Anecdotes'' by Peter Hay (Oxford University).
title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE

text: Ruth Gordon, in one of her books, tells the story of Diana Wynyard arriving at the stage door of the Globe by taxi. She saw a line around the block to the box office, and said to the people nearest her:
title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE

text: ''Oh you must be so cold.'' ''Oh we don't mind.'' ''But it's freezing.'' ''Oh, we don't mind.'' ''I suppose,'' the actress smiled charmingly, ''you love the theater.''
title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE

text: ''Oh, Miss Wynyard,'' said a woman with a troubled look, ''we dread it.'' Ice Cream Epiphany
title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE

text: Sometimes drugs help disclose emotions too deeply buried to allow ordinary access. Here is the truth about Allen Ginsberg, from ''Ginsberg: A Biography'' by Barry Miles (Simon & Schuster).
title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE

text: The first time Allen got really high on marijuana was with Walter Adams. They were in Adams's car and got lost on Allen's block. Eventually they parked the car, then went to a corner coffee shop. Allen ordered a huge black-and-white ice cream sundae. ''Then halfway through I realized the whole place was swaying back and forth, and the lights were dazzling. The sky was infinitely extensive and spacious, the plate glass windows of the restaurant showed people walking back and forth with their dogs, smiling and chattering or weeping. And it was a grand moment of synchronicity; everything was joyful and gay, and it was the first and only ice cream sundae I've enjoyed in my life; everything else has been anti-climax.'' A Plagiarized Life
title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
