text: Sometimes a reader wrests a book away from the author and rewrites it for himself. Jonathan Raban gives us an example in ''For Love and Money: A Writing Life 1969-1989'' (Edward Burlingame/Harper & Row).
title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE

text: Drawn to the book by its title (I'd never heard of its author), I read Joyce's Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man. I hadn't realized. I'd thought that novels were cleverly contrived escapes from the world, and that writing them must be something a bit like fretwork. Portrait of the Artist made the reader live in its language, and made him live more arduously, more unhappily, more intelligently in the book than he had ever lived in the world. It made some obscure but fundamental change to the essential grammar of things. I read it with excitement and shock . . . dazed to find myself simultaneously so deep in a book and so deep in the world. Every work of literature turns the successful collaborative reader of it into its co-author. In an important sense, we write what we read. My Portrait of the Artist defined my brimstone relations with my father and my family, with my boarding school and with my shamed sense of sexuality. Reading it, I stole it from Joyce and wrote it for myself; and as I went on reading I saw that if this was writing, it disenfranchised every book I'd read up to this moment. A Flash of Insight
title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE

text: Not all truths have to be eternal. The sense of a sudden clarity, a temporary understanding, can be enough for a poem. This is ''Just Once,'' from ''Love Poems'' by Anne Sexton (Houghton Mifflin). Just once I knew what life was for. In Boston, quite suddenly, I understood; walked there along the Charles River, watched the lights copying themselves, all neoned and strobe-hearted, opening their mouths as wide as opera singers; counted the stars, my little campaigners, my scar daisies, and knew that I walked my love on the night green side of it and cried my heart to the eastbound cars and cried my heart to the westbound cars and took my truth across a small humped bridge and hurried my truth, the charm of it, home and hoarded these constants into morning only to find them gone.
title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE

text: THE last two times out, Denis Dillon, the Nassau County District Attorney, ran for re-election unopposed. This time, he is being challenged more by his own record as a staunch antiabortionist than anything else.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: Mr. Dillon is seeking an unprecedented fifth term. It is an unorthodox race, not only because the focus is on abortion but because Mr. Dillon is a former Democrat now turned Republican, while his opponent, Robert J. Aliano, a Garden City lawyer, is a Republican running on the Democratic ticket.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: Although both men say they would prefer that public attention be directed to the more mundane responsibilities of the county's chief law-enforcement office, like homicides, drugs and family abuse cases, the abortion debate has become the crux of the campaign. Misuse of Office Charged
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: ''I would certainly prefer to talk about all the issues,'' said Mr. Aliano, ''but the larger issue,'' he contended, is that Mr. Dillon ''has misused his office for his own political and social agenda, instead of waging a war on crime.''
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: Each time he talks of matters other than abortion, Mr. Aliano said, he is ignored by the press. Indeed, at a recent poorly attended session with reporters, a session called by Mr. Aliano to discuss other issues, he stood virtually alone. ''It's like waiting on the sidelines to be asked to dance,'' he said. But when Mr. Aliano attends gatherings supporting the pro-choice position, he is among friends. A recent fund-raiser held in Great Neck by a group calling itself the Alliance to Defeat Denis Dillon raised $10,000.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: As its name implies, the organization is not so much for Mr. Aliano as it is against Mr. Dillon's views on abortion. Nonetheless, the money raised went into Mr. Aliano's campaign coffers.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: Mr. Aliano also has the backing of the Right-to-Choose Political Action Committee, which is raising money and has obtained the independent Pro-Choice ballot line for Mr. Aliano.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: Mr. Dillon said that, although he was not coasting through this campaign and did not believe in overconfidence, neither was he really concerned about losing.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: ''I have a fine 15-year record as Nassau District Attorney,'' said Mr. Dillon, whose office enjoys the highest conviction rate in the metropolitan area.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: ''The public votes for me because I run an extremely good D.A.'s office,'' he said. ''We have one of the safest counties in New York.''
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: Mr. Dillon readily admits to spending a good deal of time at what he calls ''finding my own way, an affirmation of human dignity.'' First Elected in 1974
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: The candidate, a 55-year-old Bronx-born Roman Catholic who keeps a large drawing of Robert F. Kennedy on his office wall, along with some small Irish flags, first became the Nassau County District Attorney in 1974 as a Democrat. He subsequently left the party after disagreeing with its abortion platform.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: Mr. Dillon has marched in antiabortion rallies numerous times, has stepped aside and had a special prosecutor handle the cases of those arrested at antiabortion protests and in 1986 ran for Governor of New York as the Right to Life candidate.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: In addition, he has been a strong supporter of independence for Northern Ireland. ''I'm involved in a number of human-rights issues,'' Mr. Dillon said. ''I spend the time on them that other district attorneys spend on the golf course.'' Notes Stands of Counterparts
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: He noted that district attorneys in other jurisdictions had taken similar human-rights stands.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: ''Liz Holtzman'' - the Brooklyn District Attorney - ''has played a major pro-choice role, Eugene Gold'' - the former Brooklyn District Attorney - ''was active on behalf of Soviet Jewry, and Carl Vergari'' -the former Westchester County District Attorney - ''once had himself chained to the gates of the Soviet Embassy,'' Mr. Dillon said.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: ''The D.A.'s office gives me a platform and an ability to reach more people than the ordinary citizen. I think it's good to use that platform for good causes.''
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: For his part, Mr. Aliano has said that, if elected, he will ''not merely be another Denis Dillon.''
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: ''I fully understand that the voters elect a district attorney to fight crime and nothing else,'' he said. ''I will not, under any circumstances, use my office to promote a pro-choice agenda.''
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: The candidate is particularly incensed that money raised through Mr. Dillon's fund-raising efforts could be used to pay the legal fees of people charged with crimes in Nassau County, like those who demonstrated outside the Bill Baird Abortion Clinic in Hempstead last year.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: Although his campaign has focused so strongly on pro-choice versus abortion, Mr. Aliano insists that his is not merely a symbolic race.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: ''There is some symbolism,'' he said, ''but I am a viable candidate, a viable alternative.''
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: The district attorney's office is not entirely new to the 38-year-old Mr. Aliano, a graduate of Hofstra University Law School. He worked for Mr. Dillon as an Assistant District Attorney from 1976 to 1979.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: The nearest Mr. Aliano came then to working on any high-profile cases was his involvement in the prosecution of Adam Berwid at a time when Mr. Berwid was accused of harassing his wife and before the much-publicized murder of Mrs. Berwid, which occurred some years later. 'If I Ever Come Back'
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: ''When I left the D.A.'s office,'' Mr. Aliano recalled, ''I said to myself, 'If I ever come back, it will be as district attorney.' '' He has since been in private law practice in Nassau County. Mr. Aliano said he had not given the matter of running for office much thought until last spring, when he discussed the district attorney post with a personal friend, Richard Korn, the Democratic candidate for Nassau County Executive.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: Although he remains a registered Republican, Mr. Aliano entered the race on the Democratic line. But when he appears at news conferences and fund-raisers, his usual nucleus of supporters is from pro-choice groups rather than the Democratic Party.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: Mr. Aliano's Democratic Party designation is a phenomenon that prompted Mr. Dillon to say: ''It's a concession of futility by the Democratic Party. They have to run a Republican; they have no one else.'' What Aliano Backers Hope
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: Mr. Aliano's backers hope that his appearance on both the Pro-Choice and Democratic lines will attract voters who might normally vote Republican, but who also support a woman's right to abortion.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: Mr. Dillon agrees that ''a small core'' of people may vote against him because of his abortion stance, but he believes that others will vote for him for the same reason.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: Beyond their differences on abortion, there are other debatable issues between the two men. But for the purposes of the current campaign, neither has been introducing many major agendas on how best to combat the county's drug menace or how to deal with the growing reports of incidents of sex abuse or domestic violence.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: Rather, Mr. Aliano has been attacking Mr. Dillon's actions in office, and Mr. Dillon has been saying that his opponent has his facts wrong.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: According to Mr. Aliano, Mr. Dillon discriminates against women in the prosecutor's office, he hires very few female lawyers, asks all job applicants their views on abortion and pays those women he does hire a lower wage scale. 40 Women on the Staff
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: When he first took office, Mr. Dillon said, there were two women among a staff of 75. Now there are 40 female assistant district attorneys on a staff of 140.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: ''I hired so many women at one time that it became the talk of the courthouse,'' said Mr. Dillon kiddingly.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: He also said that the women were paid commensurate with their responsibilities.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: Referring to the recent arrest and guilty plea of Martin Bracken, the former rackets chief in the Nassau County district attorney's office - he admittedly stole $120,000 from that office to support a gambling habit - Mr. Aliano said that Mr. Dillon knew of Mr. Bracken's gambling problems before the theft occurred and should have taken steps to ward off any difficulties.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: ''When you find someone has a problem, and Bracken's was not an isolated incident, you read them the riot act,'' he said. ''You make sure he seeks counseling or he's out. You have to show you have a grip on your office. Dillon didn't do that.'' Other Incidents Noted
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: Mr. Dillon disagrees with Mr. Aliano's version of events.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: ''As soon as I caught Marty Bracken stealing, we fired him,'' said Mr. Dillon, who said there had been other incidents, like finding some years back that some staff members were using marijuana.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: ''In that incident,'' he said, ''there were prosecutions, and all involved were asked to resign. A handful of drunk-driving incidents have also been prosecuted.''
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: There also has been a controversy over Mr. Dillon's appointments diary. Mr. Aliano contends it should be made public so that the amount of time Mr. Dillon spends on antiabortion causes can be documented.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: But Mr. Dillon counters that the diary is a personal one and has no role in the campaign.
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: ''Since 1974, Mr. Dillon has been the District Attorney,'' Mr. Aliano said. ''Since 1977, he's had no opponent. He's never been held accountable. Now I think it's time.''
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: ''My opponent has never tried a major case or supervised a large office,'' Mr. Dillon said. ''He's unqualified.''
title: Abortion Debate Dominates Prosecutor Race

text: A couple in the town of Washington will be allowed to keep their farm despite their admission that marijuana was grown there.
title: Family to Keep Farm in Vermont Drug Case

text: United States Attorney George Terwilliger said today that a settlement has been reached in the case, which involves Robert Machin and his wife, Joann Liddell.
title: Family to Keep Farm in Vermont Drug Case

text: The state police had found 200 marijuana plants growing on the farm last year, and the property was seized under Federal forefeiture laws when Mr. Machin admitted he had grown the plants. The forfeiture action was initiated under a Federal law that permits the United States to seize property that has been used to help commit a felony.
title: Family to Keep Farm in Vermont Drug Case

text: Lawmakers and family friends started a petition drive to protest that action, saying the amount of marijuana was too small to warrant a seizure.
title: Family to Keep Farm in Vermont Drug Case

text: Under the settlement, Mr. Machin admitted he grew the marijuana to help pay property taxes on the farm. He and his wife agreed to let Federal law-enforcement officers monitor their property regularly for drug activity, and said they would distribute a letter warning of the risks involved with growing and selling marijuana. In return, they get to keep the farm. ''We're glad that it's over and that the land is back,'' Ms. Liddell said. She said she disagreed with the Federal anti-drug policy that allowed the seizure, adding: ''I think it's been clear that many people are upset by the law. I hope it will change.'' Mr. Terwilliger defended the policy and his office's handling of this and other drug cases. He said he agreed to the settlement to protect Ms. Liddell and her children, who were unaware that marijuana was being grown in the garden by her husband.
title: Family to Keep Farm in Vermont Drug Case

text: Friends say the couple raised a small amount of marijuana for personal use and had supported themselves by growing organic vegetables.
title: Family to Keep Farm in Vermont Drug Case

text: Special to The New York Times
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: Even in the glow of Indian summer, Luella Wilson rarely goes outdoors anymore. She does not like to sit in the warm sunshine on her front porch because she fears that the neighbors will look at a tiny 91-year-old woman and see a criminal.
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: A Vermont jury has found Mrs. Wilson liable for a car accident in which alcohol was a factor that maimed a young man. But she is not seen, as she fears, as a symbol of the evils of drunken driving.
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: To the contrary, since word got out that Mrs. Wilson could lose her life savings and her house because of the ruling, she has been perceived as a kind of living martyr to the heavy hand of the law.
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: ''An elderly man called to ask if I wanted an apple pie,'' Mrs. Wilson said as she showed off dozens of cards of support, many of them stuffed with crumpled $1 bills. ''I told him I loved apples. He said he'd bring it down.'' A Dispute Over Responsibility
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: While there is some dispute over the seriousness of Mrs. Wilson's immediate plight, many Vermonters say she should not have been held responsible for an accident involving a car she neither owned nor drove. On the ground that she had lent the driver, her grandnephew, the money to buy the car, she was ordered to pay the victim $950,000, The plaintiff's lawyer, Rolf Sternberg, contends that Mrs. Wilson's claims of poverty are exaggerated and that her supporters are deliberately spreading false information to prejudice potential jurors shortly before a retrial is scheduled to begin.
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: ''She is not destitute,'' Mr. Sternberg said. ''The court order said that her assets are to be frozen except for what she needs to live adequately. Somebody is trying to make it difficult to pick a fair and impartial jury.''
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: And he said the judgment is consistent with established legal doctrines that hold people responsible for the consequences of knowingly giving dangerous tools to people who are likely to misuse them. Passenger Injured in Crash
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: ''You cannot give property to someone who, by reason of inexperience or incompetence, is likely to cause harm to someone else,'' Mr. Sternberg said.
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: Mrs. Wilson was asleep on the night of April 24, 1984, when her 18-year-old grandnephew, Billy Stuart, drove off a railroad bridge in a 1981 Chrysler that he had just purchased with money she had lent to him.
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: One of his passengers, Mark Vince, lost a leg in the accident. Mr. Vince sued both Mrs. Wilson and Ace Auto Sales, the Bennington car dealership where Mr. Stuart bought the car.
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: In a three-day trial held in Bennington Superior Court in February 1987, Mr. Stuart, who was not prosecuted on criminal charges, acknowledged that he and his companions had been drinking heavily and smoking marijuana on the night of the accident. And Mrs. Wilson acknowledged, in an interview, that she knew her grandnephew did not have a driver's license. Victim Awarded $950,000
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: She did not appear at the trial, both because of poor health and because her lawyer felt certain she could not lose.
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: Although the judge, Arthur O'Dea, ruled that the auto dealer could not be held liable for the accident, the jury held that Mrs. Wilson owed Mr. Vince $950,000 for his injuries.
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: ''I didn't give him the car and I didn't sell him the car,'' Mrs. Wilson said. ''I just loaned him the money to buy the car. They told me at the bank there could never be any trouble over that check.''
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: Mrs. Wilson's lawyer, Manfred Ehrich, called the judgment ''an outrageous precedent,'' and added: ''She didn't even own the car. It was never in her name.''
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: Earlier this year the Vermont Supreme Court ruled that Judge O'Dea had been wrong to exclude the auto dealer from the case before the trial began and ordered a retrial, tentatively scheduled to begin Nov. 6 in Bennington Superior Court. Insurance Company Sued
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: At the same time, Mrs. Wilson has sued her insurance company, Vermont Mutual, which refused to represent her at the 1987 trial.
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: The retrial has been a long time coming for Mrs. Wilson, who once had a bank account of more than $500,000 that she and her late husband, Harry Wilson, had accumulated over a lifetime. Over the years the Wilsons had raised horses and had owned a nightclub in Troy, N.Y., a motel in Miami and a grocery store in Bennington, four miles south of this village in southwestern Vermont.
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: She said she spent some of her savings on annual trips to Florida and Cuba, but much of it went to friends and relatives as loans and gifts.
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: Now, Mrs. Wilson said, she is destitute, eating a hot meal once a day provided by Meals on Wheels, for which she pays $1 a week. Taxes Due Next Month
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: ''She has no income except rent from me and $158 a month from Social Security,'' said Mike Madden, Mrs. Wilson's tenant and companion. ''She doesn't know how she'll pay her property taxes.''
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: The taxes, estimated at more than $2,400, are due early next month.
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: As it stands now, if Mrs. Wilson prevails in court she might, at best, hope to reduce the amount of the award and share the responsibility with the car dealer. If she loses, she will lose everything, including her house and antique silver.
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: ''If she loses this case, they'll auction everything off and put her in a nursing home for a crime she didn't commit,'' Mr. Madden said.
title: Loan Puts Widow, 91, In Jeopardy

text: Federal drug agents arrested 119 people today and raided retail stores in 46 states that sell specialized horticultural equipment that investigators say is used for growing marijuana indoors.
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: Officials of the Drug Enforcement Administration said that agents entered 22 businesses selling horticultural lighting and watering equipment and that 8 or 9 were closed.
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: Agents also seized business documents like shipping records and customer lists that could lead to indoor marijuana growers, the officials said. Charges Are Unclear
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: But most of those arrested today appeared to be people accused of growing marijuana indoors. It was not made clear where they were arrested, or on what charges.
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: Sixty-five sites where marijuana was being cultivated, in addition to the stores, were raided and shut down today by Federal drug agents in conjunction with state and local law-enforcement officials.
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: Terrence W. Burke, Acting Deputy Administrator of the drug agency, said the investigation was a broad attack ultimately aimed at reducing occasional marijuana use. Users Held to Account
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: ''Users are a major factor in the drug trafficking problem and they are going to be held accountable and subject to suitable penalties, both civil and criminal,'' he said.
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: More broadly, an Administration official said, the action was a signal to drug-producing countries, whose leaders have complained that American officials have asked them to curtail production while failing to take similar steps at home.
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: Representatives of groups that back liberalizing marijuana laws scoffed at the crackdown. Doug McVay, the projects coordinator of National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, said it was a ''publicity stunt.'' Fear for the Innocent
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: He said the inquiry was a waste of Federal resources because the effort to track down the purchasers of the growing equipment would lead drug agents to innocent people. ''A lot of gardening clubs around the country will be shocked,'' he said.
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: An agency spokesman said operators of stores that sell the equipment could be charged with cultivating marijuana or aiding in it by selling the equipment or providing advice to the growers. What It Is, What It Could Do
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: The equipment these stores sell is not in itself illegal. But one official said evidence obtained through wiretaps and undercover investigators showed that operators of some stores conspired with marijuana growers to cultivate the illegal plant.
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: The specialized equipment is well suited to promote the growth of marijuana indoors: track lighting, containerized irrigation tubs, ventilation gear, humidifying devices and carbon dioxide enrichment systems.
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: The manager of Worm's Way, a gardening supplies store in Tampa, Fla., said that early today two drug agents asked him to provide a mailing list of his customers. ''I told them I didn't have a mailing list,'' said the manager, Wallace L. Heydt. ''I don't know what to think, I'm selling fertilizer and hydroponics'' - enriched water for growth.
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: The raids were conducted in every state except Hawaii, Nebraska, North Dakota and West Virginia. Singled Out, Some Owners Say
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: Some store operators said the Government had singled them out because they advertised their products in publications that cater to the drug culture, like High Times. The magazine displays a photograph of an exotic drug in each issue, like ''Tennessee Tea,'' a potent form of marijuana, in the October issue.
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: ''The Government is trying to prove that somehow every single person who buys from these stores is a marijuana cultivator,'' said John E. Holmstrom, executive editor of High Times. ''They want nothing to do with illegal cultivation.''
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: Many marijuana growers have moved indoors in recent years as aerial surveillance and other drug enforcement actitivities against them has increased.
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: The drug agency said that in the past month, 112 people have been arrested in the investigation on charges of cultivating marijuana at 94 indoor growing sites that had 17,000 marijuana plants.
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: Domestic suppliers produce about 25 percent of the marijuana consumed in the United States, while Colombia produces about 40 percent, Mexico 25 percent and other countries 10 percent, according to Government estimates.
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: The drug agency said it selected marijuana growing because of estimates that domestic production increased from 2,100 tons in 1986 to 4,350 to 4,850 tons in 1988.
title: 119 Seized in Drive to Halt Indoor Marijuana Growing

text: Japan's stock market is strong and stable, churning out record levels of fresh capital for Japanese corporations, which could give them an advantage over their competitors abroad. Page A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: An East German Politburo member met with leaders of New Forum, a month-old opposition movement that the Government originally branded as hostile to the state. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: By Katherine Bishop, Special To the New York Times
title: Quake Forces Court Into Plebeian Quarters

text: An office building above a hamburger franchise is a far cry from the stately courtrooms of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. But this is the immediate reality for the court, improvising like dozens of other institutions since last week's earthquake.
title: Quake Forces Court Into Plebeian Quarters

text: As San Francisco began assessing the damage wrought by the quake, it found that two of the nation's busiest courthouses had to be closed. Among the many buildings to fall victim to the quake is the one housing the appellate court's offices, chambers and courtrooms at Seventh and Mission Streets, and the California Supreme Court a few blocks away.
title: Quake Forces Court Into Plebeian Quarters

text: While the Federal building itself is believed to be structurally sound, it has been declared uninhabitable as cracks continue to open in the marble-faced walls and as ornamental plaster falls in the many aftershocks that have occurred since the quake. Space for some court business has been leased in a commercial building that includes the fast-food franchise.
title: Quake Forces Court Into Plebeian Quarters

text: The Ninth Circuit Court's staff members struggled around the clock this week to restore the court to 90 percent of its functioning by the end of the week. The court, which reviews cases from nine Western states, Guam and the Northern Marianas Islands in the South Pacific, normally produces more than 200 opinions every month. #2-Year Relocation Planned The earthquake forced the State State Supreme Court to move earlier than anticipated from its building in the Civic Center. A planned $4 million project to make the building more earthquake-resistant had been scheduled to begin next year, and space had already been leased for the two-year relocation. In the interim, the court is being crammed into an adjacent state building; oral arguments will be heard in the court's quarters in Los Angeles and Sacramento.
title: Quake Forces Court Into Plebeian Quarters

text: The appellate court will temporarily hear oral arguments at the Federal District Court's headquarters half a dozen blocks away, and has moved its computers to that building.
title: Quake Forces Court Into Plebeian Quarters

text: Its other business is rapidly being relocated in available, although less than graceful, surroundings. Midway between the two court buildings, in the heart of San Francisco's down-at-the-heels Tenderloin district, the appellate court has established a ''command center'' above Carl's Jr., a fast-food franchise.
title: Quake Forces Court Into Plebeian Quarters

text: Chief Judge Alfred T. Goodwin said he had dubbed it the ''Karlsplatz'' office, after the elegant stop on the Vienna subway.
title: Quake Forces Court Into Plebeian Quarters

text: ''We finally have our own dining room,'' said Gregory Walters, the circuit executive.
title: Quake Forces Court Into Plebeian Quarters

text: Mr. Walters said he is one of the few court employees allowed to enter the damaged courthouse building to orchestrate the move, but added that he is ''standing close to the door,'' in anticipation of another temblor.
title: Quake Forces Court Into Plebeian Quarters

text: The Federal guidelines instituted to hit hard at illegal drug users by seizing their cars and boats have been altered, allowing some people to pay fines and go on their way, a Customs Service official said today.
title: Customs Eases Rule On Seizing Vessels That Contain Drugs

text: The new guidelines were signed Oct. 18 by Acting Commissioner of Customs Michael Lane, but they became effective Oct. 11.
title: Customs Eases Rule On Seizing Vessels That Contain Drugs

text: ''We think it will streamline the program, make it more effective, more equitable,'' said Ed Callahan, a senior special agent with Customs and one of two coordinators for the anti-drug program. ''Our goal and intent is still user accountability.''
title: Customs Eases Rule On Seizing Vessels That Contain Drugs

text: The new rules apply to an ounce or less of marijuana or hashish, a gram or less of cocaine, heroin or methamphetamine, one-tenth of a gram of PCP and 500 micrograms of LSD, Mr. Callahan said.
title: Customs Eases Rule On Seizing Vessels That Contain Drugs

text: When the guidelines were first issued in March 1988, Commissioner of Customs William von Raab said, ''There will be no mercy.'' But this is the third weakening in the zero-tolerance approach.
title: Customs Eases Rule On Seizing Vessels That Contain Drugs

text: In May 1988, two months after the program began, Customs or Coast Guard authorities who found small amounts of drugs on vessels beyond the 12-mile limit would seize the boats only if they appeared to be transporting drugs into the country.
title: Customs Eases Rule On Seizing Vessels That Contain Drugs

text: In February, the Government exempted fishing boats en route to or from fishing grounds from immediate physical seizure, instead issuing a summons ''so as not to interfere with their earning their livelihood,'' Mr. Callahan said.
title: Customs Eases Rule On Seizing Vessels That Contain Drugs

text: Under the new guidelines, the summons procedure has been extended to all vessels, provided that only small amounts of drugs are found.
title: Customs Eases Rule On Seizing Vessels That Contain Drugs

text: By Sally Johnson, Special To the New York Times
title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs

text: Federal efforts to seize the property of a Vermont man who was caught growing marijuana in his vegetable garden have aroused the ire of neighbors here.
title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs

text: More than 300 members of this central Vermont community have signed petitions protesting the forfeiture proceeding against the farm owned by Robert Machin, who last fall pleaded guilty in Vermont District Court to growing marijuana.
title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs

text: ''This type of case can either gain or lose public support for the war on drugs,'' complained Mark MacDonald, a Democratic State Representative from neighboring Williamstown. ''I'm absolutely convinced this is wrong. I can't imagine that Congress intended the law to be used in this fashion.''
title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs

text: Mr. Machin's troubles began a year ago after a hiker reported to the Vermont State Police that he had seen approximately 200 marijuana plants growing on the 49-acre farm where Mr. Machin, a 43-year-old Harvard graduate, and his wife, Joanne Liddell, press apple cider, make maple syrup and raise enough food to feed themselves and their five children.
title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs

text: Using that information to obtain a search warrant, the police raided the farm on Sept. 6, 1988, and confiscated a dozen plants, many of which were too dry to be of any value, according to Richard Rubin, Mr. Machin's lawyer. Two months later, Mr. Machin pleaded guilty to cultivation of marijuana, a felony, and was ordered to perform 50 hours of community service, which he served building bookshelves at the Chelsea Public Library. Mr. Rubin said there was no evidence that Mr. Machin had sold or intended to sell any of his crop.
title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs

text: ''The Machins thought the case was closed when they pled guilty,'' Mr. Rubin said. Mr. Machin declined to be interviewed.
title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs

text: But the case was not closed. The state police referred the case to the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, which, in turn, referred it to the office of the United States Attorney, George Terwilliger 3d.
title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs

text: On Sept. 29, Federal marshals seized the Machins' house and property and leased it back to them pending the outcome of the civil suit, which could result in the loss of the home. The seizure came under a section of the Controlled Substances Act that allows the seizure of any property that is either the proceeds of drug trafficking or is used for the commission of a felony under the Act.
title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs

text: While authorized by the law, the seizure outraged local citizens, including Dr. Daniel Wing, who was one of 25 state residents to write Senator Patrick Leahy, a Vermont Democrat.
title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs

text: ''The Machin family is a rare thing - an American nuclear family that is really working, that is full of love, that is producing good citizens,'' Mr. Wing wrote, noting that parents and children read aloud together every night, that all Christmas gifts traditionally are homemade. ''I don't think it should be casually destroyed by the overzealous application of a law designed to put drug racketeers out of business.'' Senator Leahy would not comment on the case.
title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs

text: Another half-dozen calls went to Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin, a Democrat, who instructed her legal counsel to investigate the matter.
title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs

text: Various local officials joined the chorus of outrage, including Stephen Webster, a Republican former prosecutor who now represents Orange County in the State Legislature. ''The imposition of this penalty is much too severe, and I'm hoping the U.S. Attorney will see it that way,'' said Mr. Webster, adding that as vice chairman of the Senate Government Operations Committee, he is troubled that ''the state police have had an active role in this.''
title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs

text: Mr. Webster said he was troubled by the role of the state police, who brought Mr. Machin's conviction to the attention of the Federal authorities, ''without the knowledge or approval of the Legislature.''
title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs

text: Others protested to Mr. Terwilliger, who said he will not decide how to proceed until fact-finding is completed. He did note that in a similar case the property was put permanently in the name of the wife, who had not been implicated.
title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs

text: He also disputed the popular notion that marijuana ''is a benign drug'' and argued that ''Vermont's needs are not being met by growing a drug that we know is not benign.''
title: Washington Journal; Vermont Ponders Spirit Of the Law on Drugs

text: Dr. Pearl (Perry) Izenzon, the co-founder and executive director of the Potsmokers Anonymous drug-rehabilitation program, died of cancer Friday night at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. She was 48 years old and lived on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.
title: Pearl Izenzon, Founder Of Support Group, 48

text: Dr. Izenzon founded the rehabilitation program in 1974 with her husband, David Izenzon, an artist and musician who died of a heart attack in 1977. Dr. Izenzon, who had a doctorate in education, was also an artist.
title: Pearl Izenzon, Founder Of Support Group, 48

text: The Izenzons modeled Potsmokers Anonymous after Alcoholics Anonymous. Thousands of marijuana smokers were helped by the program, said a longtime family friend, Richard Weiner. He added that Dr. Izenzon did not use drugs, and that she helped start the program because many of her musician and artist friends were battling drug problems.
title: Pearl Izenzon, Founder Of Support Group, 48

text: He also said she made many radio and television appearances warning about the dangers of drug abuse. ''She felt that pot was not something to be taken lightly,'' Mr. Weiner said.
title: Pearl Izenzon, Founder Of Support Group, 48

text: Dr. Izenzon received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Bard College in 1951 and her doctorate from Columbia University Teachers College in 1986.
title: Pearl Izenzon, Founder Of Support Group, 48

text: A native of Queens, she was active in many community rehabilitation and beautification projects on the Lower East Side.
title: Pearl Izenzon, Founder Of Support Group, 48

text: She is survived by two sons, Solomon and Seth, both of Manhattan, and a sister, Goldy Rosen, of Garden City, L.I. Her mother, Fannie Meresman, of Manhattan, died two weeks ago.
title: Pearl Izenzon, Founder Of Support Group, 48

text: THE fervor and intensity associated with the war on drugs is a tug on the emotional strings of America. The rhetoric smacks of a call to arms intended to placate the majority, who are worried that crack-cocaine, and the crowd associated with it, will soon be sitting on front lawns and calling to children in suburban classrooms.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: The problem with this battle cry to disarm dealers and toss them behind prison bars is that it ignores the root cause of drug abuse sitting quietly but conspicuously within our grasp. It ignores the root cause because of threats to mores and countless holiday traditions.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: The root cause is alcohol. Some might frown and say: ''Here we go again. Another lecture on the evils of spirits is more temperance and prohibition toned than reality based.'' But that is not the case. This is no ''Jim and Tammy Show.''
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: Alcohol should not be banned or unduly restricted. It is a pleasing part of our culture for the vast majority who are not addicted and who do not overuse this potent drug. It is perfectly O.K. to drink.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: Because this discussion is poised to pick on alcohol, some might discount the verbiage associated with warnings about its potential for addiction and destruction. The critics might do that because they cannot tolerate what they perceive to be a challenge to a ritualistic part of their lives. They might liken the message to the soapboxes of Wild West preachers who warned of doom, gloom and eternal damnation at the liquid sword of John Barleycorn.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: That is too bad. There is a great deal to talk about, because there is a great deal to worry about. The war on drugs should include alcohol.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: Alcohol is an addictive drug more damaging to this society than any other. The death rate from alcohol is far higher than from crack-cocaine, and its victims crisscross virtually all age, ethnic and social groups. In suburban settings, alchohol kills, while crack and cocaine threaten.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: Alchohol is the drug of choice for teen-agers, and it garners the distinction of being the No. 1 ''gateway drug.'' That means it serves as the bridge, along with tobacco and marijuana, to so-called harder drugs like cocaine and heroin.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: Alcohol accustoms young people to the feelings of mood alteration, so that they are often wide-eyed to try other drugs, a colorful assortment of pills, potions and powders.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: The popular message, reflective of our value system, encourages gateway use. It is important to drink to have fun, to be sophisticated, to be successful, to be attractive. Alcohol warms the heart and breaks the ice. It is the great liquid communicator. Young people believe this garbage. So do many adults who associate great times with repeatedly tipping the bottle. Don't leave home without it!
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: Alcoholism runs in families. That is a fact. Children of alcoholics are deeply scarred by the dysfunction and craziness of their upbringings. As adults, many turn to drugs other than alcohol, or in combination with what they perceive to be ''social drinking,'' to mask the feelings of hurt, abandonment and low self-esteem that are residuals of their past. They are self-medicating these feelings.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: Those who turn to other drugs will say they will never be like their alcoholic parents. They will never touch one drop of that liquid poison that turned their parents into Jekylls and Hydes. Instead they smoke marijuana, shoot dope or take Valium as if they were M&M's. One plus one equals two addicted generations.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: The complexities of the alcohol problem are mind boggling. And they can be directly and unequivocally tied to other drug abuse. They are perfectly synonymous and savage.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: But the war on drugs steers clear of liquor and, by doing so, sends the message to youths that it is O.K. to say no to drugs while guzzling cheap beer or fruity schnapps.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: The war on drugs has to be thoroughly preoccupied with the basics, alcohol in particular, but other gateway drugs, as well. Focusing on crack-cocaine sends this war into a blurry notion of junkies shooting dope and then one another.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: This mental image might help people feel less responsible for the drug epidemic, but it fuels their anger, fear and intolerance. It minimizes the possibility of paying for treating addicts, because the message that addicts, and alcoholics, are bad people who do not deserve our tax dollars is strengthened.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: Society's acceptance of alcohol without responsible warnings, coupled with the encouragement to use it inappropriately, causes us to impose minimal consequences for alcohol-related problems like drunken driving.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: The attitude causes people to turn the other cheek at alcohol's role as a gateway to other drugs, and it causes many to deny the severe consequences of alcohol addiction and to pretend that there is no problem.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: We can combat these destructive attitudes just as we have raised awareness about the hazards of nicotine smoke. We can do this without feeling threatened about our right to enjoy alcohol, provided it is not problematic to us, our loved ones or to society.
title: Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs

text: Donald T. Regan suggests America's drug problem can be cured simply by changing the color of money (Op-Ed, Sept. 18). But that idea was tried before and failed dismally.
title: Changing the Color of Money Won't Stop Corruption

text: Our last currency conversion took place during the spring of 1970. The reasons for changing the color of currency then were the same reasons Mr. Regan suggests for doing it now. However, changing the color of American Military Payment Certificates failed back in crime- , drug- and corruption-infested South Vietnam in 1970 because the American high command didn't appreciate that the major element in the ''evil triad'' paralyzing our war effort was neither crime nor drugs, but corruption.
title: Changing the Color of Money Won't Stop Corruption

text: Used as cash by the American military, the payment certificates replaced the greenback for two reasons: so as not to disrupt the South Vietnamese economy by flooding it with highly valuated American greenbacks, and to prevent the North Vietnamese and the last Vietcong remnants from obtaining an internationally accepted currency to purchase more advanced weapons, support and medical equipment.
title: Changing the Color of Money Won't Stop Corruption

text: But as senior military command and intelligence officers became aware that South Vietnamese drug lords, black marketeers, commodity brokers and enemy arms merchants possessed more payment certificates than American military personnel, a secret plan was hatched to change the color of the certificates abruptly and render impotent the entire ''evil triad'' pyramid: from the politicians and generals at the top who sold stores of spent brass bullet casings back to the U.S. Government, to the street urchins and barrack maids at the bottom who sold marijuana, cocaine, hashish and heroin on our military bases.
title: Changing the Color of Money Won't Stop Corruption

text: Planning for the conversion was kept from military personnel below the rank of division commander. Or so it was intended. As American G.I.'s awoke in the morning and received surprise orders to report to hastily built currency exchanges to replace their color-canceled M.P.C. bills, millions more of the new bills were already in the hands of South Vietnamese brothels than in American currency exchanges. Those of us who worked as liaison with the South Vietnamese Army discovered the night before that many of the lower-ranking Vietnamese soldiers, fronting for their generals or civilian merchants, possessed huge, hand-sized rolls of freshly printed M.P.C.
title: Changing the Color of Money Won't Stop Corruption

text: Was the conversion a failure? The true goal, it seemed, was not to eradicate the evil triad completely but to replace the uncooperative cartels that had become too wealthy and powerful for the American and South Vietnamese high command to negotiate with, with new cartels that promised to work more closely with our war effort. At that late stage in the war, corruption was an accepted basis for a growing, or at least surviving, South Vietnamese economy.
title: Changing the Color of Money Won't Stop Corruption

text: The new cartels, amply supplied with the brightly colored payment certificates, helped American officials buy back tons of black-market PX goods and military and medical equipment, thereby reducing the supplies that would otherwise have ended up in the hands of the enemy, who were caching tons of M.P.C.-purchased munitions along the Cambodian-Vietnamese border to prepare for invasion. Many of the supplies American officials failed to reclaim during the weeks following the M.P.C. conversion were recaptured during the Cambodian offensive.
title: Changing the Color of Money Won't Stop Corruption

text: Was the conversion a success? No. Drug use among G.I.'s continued to soar during the two remaining years of American military involvement. Munitions continued to flow into North Vietnamese caches across the border. And American law enforcement and intelligence morale sank to deeper depths.
title: Changing the Color of Money Won't Stop Corruption

text: Corruption among both South Vietnamese and American profiteers seemed a more potent enemy than the American high command had anticipated. Corruption here at home would spell failure in changing the color of American money. PHILL COLEMAN Redondo Beach, Calif., Oct. 2, 1989 The writer operates the Vietnam Data Resource and Electronic Library as a public service.
title: Changing the Color of Money Won't Stop Corruption

text: It seems to me that the spate of pro-legalization articles that have appeared recently in The Times are founded on a misconception, namely that drug use has not already been decriminalized. Drug use underwent a de facto decriminalization in America some 20 years ago. From the Hollywood celebrity publicly snorting coke at a party to the teen-ager smoking marijuana in front of his high school, Americans have ceased to worry about criminal penalties for drug use. It is the failure of decriminalization that we are living with now.
title: We Already Know the Folly of Decriminalized Drugs

text: Prohibitions against drug use are not founded in some abstract and hypocritical morality, as is often implied. Advocates of legalization seem curiously unable to distinguish gradations in human behavior. The argument that it is impermissible to outlaw drugs because people are legally ''addicted'' to coffee or aspirin is the ludicrous extension of a feeble train of thought. Teen-agers are not prostituting themselves in Times Square to buy another bottle of aspirin, nor are men and women destroying their families for the sake of another cup of coffee. It is not merely the sale and distribution of drugs that is destroying lives. It is the effects of the drugs themselves and the things that people do under their influence that are the real hazards to the lives and happiness of millions of our citizens.
title: We Already Know the Folly of Decriminalized Drugs

text: I suggest we try actually enforcing penalties for drug use and see if that has any effect before we give up and turn our society into a drug bazaar. Or possibly we should simply admit what A. M. Rosenthal perceptively argued in his column of Sept. 26, that the lives currently being destroyed by drugs are not lives most Americans consider important. Mr. Rosenthal's analogy of drug use to slavery was a particularly apt one. Slavery was defended by many citizens as being an economic necessity, while abolitionists were ridiculed as moralizing meddlers or naive idealists.
title: We Already Know the Folly of Decriminalized Drugs

text: However, even if charity and morality do not compel us to abolish this new form of slavery, prudence should, for we must remember that throughout history the well-off have never succeeded in finding a refuge remote enough to protect them from the results of the injustices they have inflicted upon the poor. Our society is creating a class of slaves who have been stripped by drugs of pity, hope, love, kindness and even fear, and I think that their retribution will eventually fall on all of us. ELIZABETH GESSNER New York, Sept. 28, 1989
title: We Already Know the Folly of Decriminalized Drugs

text: RECENT national surveys estimate that 2 million to 6 million children under the age of 13 regularly care for themselves without adult supervision after school or on weekends. For almost all parents of such latchkey children - ''children in self-care,'' as some researchers call them - the decision to leave them alone is unwanted but unavoidable.
title: Parent & child

text: High quality after-school programs in large cities, especially for older children, have not kept up with the demand and, if not publicly financed, can be prohibitively expensive. There are proportionally more programs in the suburbs, according to child-care researchers. Transportation to and from those programs, however, is a common problem.
title: Parent & child

text: A recent study found that eighth graders left at home alone more than 11 hours a week were twice as likely to use alcohol, tobacco and marijuana as children the same age who spent all their time after school supervised by adults. The study, which surveyed about 5,000 pupils in Southern California, was done by the University of Southern California and the University of Illinois at Chicago.
title: Parent & child

text: The survey found that of the eighth graders who spent 11 hours or more a week caring for themselves, 23 percent had consumed more than 11 drinks of alcohol in their lifetime, 13 percent had smoked more than one pack of cigarettes and 24 percent had tried marijuana.
title: Parent & child

text: Among those who always had an adult caring for them at home, 11 percent had consumed more than 11 drinks of alcohol, 6 percent had smoked more than a pack of cigarettes and 14 percent had tried marijuana.
title: Parent & child

text: ''This increased risk appeared no matter what the sex, race or socioeconomic status of the children,'' said Dr. Jean L. Richardson, an associate professor of preventive medicine at the University of Southern California who directed the study.
title: Parent & child

text: She said parents should be concerned but not panicked by the findings, since a majority of children who cared for themselves after school did not abuse alcohol, tobacco or marijuana.
title: Parent & child

text: The challenge for the parents of latchkey children is to make the most of an undesired situation by working out ways that the children can benefit from the time they spend alone.
title: Parent & child

text: For a small proportion of children, especially those in middle or junior high school, there is evidence that spending time alone after school can be better than participating in an inadequate or inappropriate adult-supervised after-school program.
title: Parent & child

text: ''Some kids, when they switched from a structured after-school program to self-care, felt less lonely because the after-school program didn't meet their needs,'' said Dr. Deborah Belle, an assistant professor of psychology at Boston University who is doing a study of latchkey children.
title: Parent & child

text: ''Being with peers is not the same as being with good friends,'' she said. ''Some kids felt isolated when they were with other children and adults they didn't feel close to.''
title: Parent & child

text: For many children who tell their parents that they enjoy the time they spend alone, caring for themselves gives them an opportunity to explore on their own areas that may have been de-emphasized in the school curriculum, like music and art. For others, it is a chance to relax and take control of their lives.
title: Parent & child

text: ''Some children thrive on being left alone,'' said Dr. Vivian Katzenstein Friedman, an associate professor of psychology and psychiatry at the University of Alabama at Birmingham. ''It gives them time to unwind and quietly start their homework. It allows them to make some choices about what to do.''
title: Parent & child

text: For others, caring for themselves after school and having a limited number of simple chores to help the family can improve their self-esteem.
title: Parent & child

text: ''Some kids, especially those of single parents, say 'I know I'm helping out my mom,' '' said Dr. James Garbarino, the president of the Erikson Institute for Advanced Study in Child Development in Chicago. ''It helps the child feel empowered.''
title: Parent & child

text: But child-development researchers emphasize that children who flourish when left alone after school are the exception rather than the norm, especially among those in elementary school. Even for young teen-agers, caring for oneself for several hours a day can be daunting.
title: Parent & child

text: ''My own children told me that there were times in middle school when they were frightened if they were alone in our house,'' said Michelle Seligson, the director of the School-Age Child Care Project at the Wellesley (Mass.) College Center for Research on Women. ''They would turn on the television and the radio and all of the lights in the house.''
title: Parent & child

text: Some child-care experts object to the relabeling of latchkey children as children in self-care.
title: Parent & child

text: ''This sometimes causes adults to be less concerned about the problem,'' said Dr. Judith A. Schaut, an associate professor of education at Bucknell University in Lewisburg, Pa., who specializes in issues related to child care.
title: Parent & child

text: ''We're being sold a bill of goods,'' she said. ''Parents still have to realize that there's a tremendous amount of stress for children that goes along with this.'' Making the Most of Time Alone
title: Parent & child

text: ALTHOUGH having your children spend time in a supervised setting is almost always preferable to having them spend that time alone at home after school, here are several things parents can do to help latchkey children handle the stresses of caring for themselves:
title: Parent & child

text: Arrange for your children to call you or some other responsible adult, like a grandparent or a neighbor, as soon as they get home. This ritual can make the transition to caring for themselves less stressful for children. The children who care for themselves most successfully appear to be those who sense they are still being supervised by adults.
title: Parent & child

text: ''In one study we found that the more frequently children called their parents, the happier they were,'' said Dr. Deborah Belle, an assistant professor of psychology at Boston University.
title: Parent & child

text: In addition to providing your telephone number at work, prominently post at least one other number that the child can call for reassurance during a scary moment or for non-emergency help.
title: Parent & child

text: Many communities have telephone help services specifically for latchkey children who need an adult's guidance. Although some of the calls they receive are from children who want to know such things as whether they can let someone in the door, many are simple questions like , ''How do I turn on the toaster?''
title: Parent & child

text: Work out a mutually agreeable schedule with your children that tells them what they can and should be doing.
title: Parent & child

text: ''It's not a good idea to have your child simply do homework until you come home,'' advised Dr. Judith A. Schaut, an associate professor of education at Bucknell University. ''That's not what other children would be doing. There should be some time to unwind, have a snack, and do something that's fun.'' Give your children permission to enjoy themselves. ''A lot of younger kids who are at home are told what they shouldn't do, such as opening the door,'' Dr. Schaut said. ''But they're not told what they should do. That only makes children more fearful.''
title: Parent & child

text: The wife and brother-in-law of Constabile (Gus) Farace, who is the prime suspect in the murder of a Federal drug agent, were freed on $250,000 bail each yesterday on charges of distributing marijuana.
title: Farace's Wife Free On $250,000 Bail

text: Henry Acierno, 34 years old, and his sister, Antoinette Farace, 31, were arrested over the weekend on charges they were part of a drug ring operated by Mr. Farace. The organization brought large amounts of marijuana from Texas to New York from 1987 until February 1989, court papers said.
title: Farace's Wife Free On $250,000 Bail

text: Federal investigators believe Mr. Farace, 31, shot Everett Hatcher, a Federal Drug Enforcement Administration agent, dead in a car on Staten Island on Feb. 28.
title: Farace's Wife Free On $250,000 Bail

text: Law-enforcement officers have put pressure on Mr. Farace's family and Mafia associates in an effort to flush him out, but he has thus far managed to elude the dragnet. He is on the F.B.I.'s list of 10 Most Wanted fugitives and the Government has posted a $250,000 reward for information leading to his arrest.
title: Farace's Wife Free On $250,000 Bail

text: Mr. Farace's mother, Mary, who appeared at the bail hearing in Federal District Court in Brooklyn and put up her Staten Island home as collateral, would not say if she had seen or heard from her son.(AP)
title: Farace's Wife Free On $250,000 Bail

text: The Central Intelligence Agency and other Federal groups have begun using satellites to spy on the maze of clandestine airstrips, roads and factories run by the illicit drug industry in South America.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: The agencies are also using the military and civilian satellites to locate remote areas under cultivation with drug crops, and they now plan to take on the more difficult job of actively tracking ships and planes that smuggle narcotics into the United States.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: Most of the new drug-reconnaissance work is secret because officials do not want to tip off the smugglers as to precisely what they know. But a glimpse of the developing activity was obtained through interviews with Bush Administration officials, Congressmen and industry experts.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: An official of a private concern that analyzes civilian spacecraft photos, Mark Labovitz, said special processing can now suppress the images of thick vegetation in forests of Colombia and Peru, for example, and highlight the obscured airstrips. Mapping the Coca Fields
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: ''Some of them stick out like a sore thumb,'' he said. ''You put the photo on a light table and pick them out, boom, boom, boom.''
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: A vivid example of the new drug reconnaissance is seen in the United States Drug Enforcement Administration's work in mapping the wilds of Peru's Upper Huallaga Valley - which produces nearly half the world's coca leaves and is dotted with cocaine laboratories, hideouts and some 60 jungle landing strips in the high end of the valley.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: The maps are made from the enlarged and enhanced satellite photos, with the aid of the Pentagon's Defense Mapping Agency and the United States Geological Survey. The new charts are seen as crucial to the future success of local law-enforcment and D.E.A raids because they can reveal escape routes for drug traffickers, and possibly for their pursuers as well.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: ''They need to know how to get in and out, so they don't get shot up,'' said a Federal official, who asked not to be identified. Drug-Crop Fields on the Move
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: The Upper Huallaga, a lush river valley largely controlled by the Shining Path guerrillas of Peru, has been called the D.E.A.'s most perilous assignment. Some 20 decapitated bodies, believed to be those of local informers, were recently found floating down the river past a new Peruvian police ranger and D.E.A. forward command post in Santa Lucia.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: Experts say that by concentrating on areas of drug production and traffic routes, space technology is arming law-enforcement agents with more precise information, helping them avoid false leads or fruitless searches and track the shifting patterns of drug production.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: ''You want the best reconnaissance you can get as these crops move to other locations,'' Peter B. Bensinger, former head of the Drug Enforcement Administration, said in an interview. In reaction to stepped-up anti-drug efforts, he said, the drug operators are constantly moving crop-field locations, the processing plants, and flying and shipping routes, which makes better intelligence crucial.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: Representative Nicholas Mavroules, a Massachusetts Democrat who chairs the House Armed Services subcommittee on investigations and is a member of the Intelligence Committee, said he was ''very impressed'' with the effort being made by the nation's spy agencies. Cartels' Use of Intimidation
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: ''They can make a significant dent in the armor of the drug cartels,'' he said.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: Representative Mavroules and others said, however, that technology alone will not end the problem. They pointed to the heavy demand for drugs in the United States and Europe, as well as political and economic factors in South America as complicating factors. They said that even when detected, drug smugglers often manage to corrupt or intimidate law-enforcement authorities all along the line - from the fields where the coca plant is grown to the factories where it is processed into cocaine to the streets where it is sold - to avoid arrest or conviction.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: ''It's one thing to know there are so many hectares under cultivation, and another to destroy them,'' said Adm. Stansfield Turner, former director of the C.I.A.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: Nonetheless, he said, space surveillance should be ''a big help.'' 'You Just Use More Analysts'
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: Mr. Bensinger, who ran the D.E.A. from 1976 to 1981 and is currently a Chicago-based drug consultant, told Congress in 1981 that the agency ''desperately'' needed satellite-reconnaissance help, that enforcement was ''immediately limited'' without it. ''Today,'' he said, ''reconnaissance is one area where we're ahead of the Medellin and Cali cartels.''
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: The military and C.I.A satellites are said to be powerful enough to produce photographs taken from orbit that can reveal the numbers on license plates on cars or trucks parked hundreds of miles below.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: Maj. Nelson B. Johnson, a retired Army intelligence expert at Comprehensive Technologies International, a management company in Chantilly, Va., said that converting the spy technology to drug detection was relatively simple. ''All it takes is more people'' to analyze photos, he said. ''You don't have to put up another satellite, you just use more analysts.''
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: The civilian photos being used are from satellites privately operated by Landsat and SPOT, which scientists have used for years for studying the earth's resources, monitoring worldwide crop production, water resources and the condition of world forests. Landsat and SPOT photos are available on the commercial market. Tracking Poppies in Thailand
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: Mr. Labovitz, manager of applications and analysis at ST Systems Corporation, based in Lanham, Md., said drug intelligence often entails comparing satellite images taken months apart in an effort to identify new structures and clearings. ''Why in the middle of nowhere would you cut down a forest?'' he said. ''Does it make sense in terms of local agriculture? Is there a house around?''
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: William A. Kennedy, an analyst at the Earth Observation Satellite Company in Lanham, Md., which sells Landsat photos, said a technique called spectral analysis can detect drug plants on the basis of their color ''signature'' but added that it was not always reliable. Coca plants, he said, are easier to detect in that way than marijuana.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: With $100,000 from the American Government, the United Nations Division of Narcotic Drugs is studying the feasibility of perfecting the ''signature'' method, convening a panel of a dozen experts at the end of October.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: The deputy director of the division, Bertrand J. De Fondaumiere, said in an interview that the SPOT satellite has already been used to track poppies in Thailand. ''So we're not starting from scratch,'' he said, adding that improved techniques gave the method ''a good chance of working.'' Spotting Ships and Airplanes
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: Congress last year greatly expanded the military's anti-drug role. A result is that the Defense Department is now spending $300 million to help control drug traffic. Early this year, the military made public some of its drug-reconnaissance plans. Lieut. Gen. Thomas W. Kelly of the Army, director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told a House hearing that the Defense Intelligence Agency was studying ways to concentrate the nation's assets on the drug war, and he alluded to the C.I.A.'s spy satellites and the communication listening skills of the National Security Agency.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: ''We think we can take national technical means and divert them to spotting those ships and airplanes that are coming in, and spotting where some of this stuff is produced,'' General Kelly told the House Armed Services subcommittee on investigations, chaired by Representative Mavroules.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: To aid the effort, William J. Webster, Director of Central Intelligence, in April created a Counter Narcotics Center, based at C.I.A. headquarters in Langley, Va. It includes agents from the D.E.A., the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the State Department, the Coast Guard, the Defense Department, and the National Security Agency.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: A C.I.A. spokesman, Mark Mansfield, said the center had ''full access to intelligence on international drug trafficking.''
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: A C.I.A. official, who asked not to be identified, said it was ''very safe to assume'' the center relied on the nation's full range of spy satellites. A D.E.A. spokesman in Washington, Joseph Keefe, said the agency could make no comment on the use of military satellites in the drug war.
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: ''Everybody knows they're up there, and knows they help things,'' Mr. Keefe said. ''But we don't like to talk about it. We really feel it's an important tool, but it's not ours to talk about.''
title: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

text: More than 100 pounds of marijuana estimated to be worth at least $25,000 was found today during a raid on a house here, Onondaga County Sheriff's deputies said. The two-story private house at 866 West Genesee Street. contained 71 fully grown plants in pots under time-controlled lights in the basement and 121 smaller 3-foot plants growing in an upstairs room, the police said. The tenant of the house was not found in the 10 A.M. raid.
title: 100 Lbs. of Marijuana Found

text: Stephen Gillers's Op-Ed article on the pitfalls of George Bush's strategy for getting tough on casual drug users (''Is Bush Repeating Rockefeller's Folly?'', Sept. 11) makes a number of telling points. But Professor Gillers was badly mistaken in stating that New York has overhauled the harsh Rockefeller drug law.
title: Rockefeller Drug Law Is Still Not Overhauled

text: In 1979, policy makers did enact a modest amendment to the law, mainly to reduce the penalties for marijuana-related offenses. But the punishments required by this law for the possession or sale of hard drugs like heroin and cocaine still rank among the most severe in the nation.
title: Rockefeller Drug Law Is Still Not Overhauled

text: Last year, Gov. Mario Cuomo and the Legislature approved a bill increasing the penalties for the sale of even small amounts of crack. Offenders now get sent to prison in New York for selling $10 to $20 worth of this drug.
title: Rockefeller Drug Law Is Still Not Overhauled

text: There are a number of problems with this get-tough approach. It causes the unnecessary imprisonment of people who could be handled more effectively through alternative punishments, involving community service, mandatory drug treatment and monitored curfews.
title: Rockefeller Drug Law Is Still Not Overhauled

text: It drives up the prison population -the number of state inmates locked up for drug offenses has gone from fewer than 2,000 to more than 14,000 since 1980 - leading to perilous overcrowding and bloated prison budgets. It diverts funds from potentially useful government programs like treatment efforts that have been shown to reduce the drug-abusing and criminal behavior of addicts.
title: Rockefeller Drug Law Is Still Not Overhauled

text: Most important, it does not work to control crime. The minor drug offenders we lock up in New York State are replaced in the streets before the police can turn around and arrest the new recruits to the trade. Despite the billions of dollars in expenditures on law enforcement and additional prisons, drug-related lawlessness continues to spread.
title: Rockefeller Drug Law Is Still Not Overhauled

text: Although New York has not done so, it should overhaul the Rockefeller drug law. Getting tough has failed. It is time to get smart. ROBERT GANGI, Executive Director Correctional Assn. of New York New York, Sept. 13, 1989
title: Rockefeller Drug Law Is Still Not Overhauled

text: Six months after the Department of Education began requiring college students receiving financial aid to sign oaths that the money would not be used to buy drugs, many university officials say they have no plans to enforce compliance with the oath.
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: Dallas Martin, president of the National Association of Student Financial Aid Officers, representing 3,300 post-secondary institutions, said financial aid officers were not willing to act as law-enforcement officials who turn in students to the Government. He said most of his colleagues felt that enforcing the pledge would take time from counseling students on how to manage their grant money.
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: Since March, students' eligibility for financial aid has depended on their pledging that they will not ''engage in the unlawful manufacture, distribution, dispensation, or use of any controlled substance'' while they receive benefits. #3 Million Signed, No Refusals Joseph A. Vignone, a Department of Education financial aid administrator, said almost three million students have signed the pledge and there have been no reported cases of anyone's refusing.
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: But students who violate the oath and are convicted of drug-related offenses can lose their grant money, Mr. Vignone said. They can also be prosecuted for fraud, which carries a potential $10,000 fine and a jail sentence, for making false statements to get Federal money.
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: Enforcement of the measure relies on college financial aid administrators' reporting students convicted of drug-related offenses to the Department of Education. While college officials have made sure that students sign the pledge, many administrators say they will not monitor students to determine whether they comply with the anti-drug statement.
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: ''Beyond being aware of students' signing the form, we must take their word for it,'' said Marilyn C. Jaeger, the University of California's director of student financial support. ''We are not going to do police investigations.'' No Tracking Apparatus
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: Dr. Martin and other university officials said financial aid administrators are rarely told when students are convicted of crimes. They said neither the Federal Government nor universities had sought to establish a system to provide financial aid offices with information about students' criminal records.
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: Mr. Vignone said he remained optimistic that campus officials would act as the Department of Education's ''eyes and ears.''
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: ''If college officials know about students dealing drugs and carrying Uzis in the back of the library, they're going to report it,'' Mr. Vignone said. He suggested that financial aid officers read the local newspaper and talk with the police to keep track of drug arrests.
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH
