text: Under the Drug-Free Workplace Act of 1988, anyone who receives a Federal grant must pledge that he will not be involved in drug-related activities. Throughout the Government, the law has set in motion anti-drug oaths by grant recipients and Federal employees. Only the Pell Grants
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: In the Department of Education, the law affects only one financial aid program, Pell Grants, which provide direct assistance of up to $2,300 to undergraduates. Applications for this fall's Pell Grant include the anti-drug oath along with questions about the applicant's immigration status, whether the applicant has defaulted on student loans and whether male students have registered with the Selective Service.
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: Representative Robert S. Walker, the Pennsylvania Republican who sponsored the measure, said the pledge sends an important message that is worth the added paperwork. ''I don't know whether it will stop students who abuse drugs, but it at least tells them that there are fairly big penalties,'' he said.
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: Proponents and opponents of the measure say they are unsure about the pledge's effect on students' behavior. And while some students deride the law as ridiculous, others say they fear the Government may enforce the law more strictly. Invaded Privacy Is Seen
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: Some students at the University of California at Berkeley, who recently held what may have been the first demonstration against the oath, and at other universities also object to the new law as an invasion of privacy. They say the new law singles out low-income aid recipients, those who receive most of the Pell grants.
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: Berkeley students called the measure a first step toward drug testing and increased surveillance.
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: Mr. Vignone said the Department of Education had no plans to require drug testing for students, although it had been discussed. American Civil Liberties Union officials said there was little basis for a constitutional challenge to the pledge unless harsher enforcement measures were taken.
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: About 1,500 people gathered in the main plaza at Berkeley in the protest. The aroma of marijuana drifted through the crowd; dozens of students and community residents smoked free marijuana cigarettes distributed by the demonstration's organizers.
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: No one was arrested. Photographs of the demonstrators were sent to the District Attorney's office, but no action was taken.
title: CAMPUSES COPING WITH A DRUGS OATH

text: When Mia Dillon, wearing a voluminous dress, makes her first entrance in ''The Aunts,'' it is immediately clear to everyone in the theater that her character is supposed to be pregnant - to everyone, that is, except the other characters on stage. For unexplained reasons, the young woman's two aunts are oblivious to her condition.
title: Review/Theater; Two Aunts, One Husband, a Niece and Complications

text: It is not simply that the aunts are self-involved. They are manipulated into their blindness by the playwright, Gary Bonasorte, who is trying to withhold information and delay a dramatic surprise. As it slowly evolves, the play at the 47th Street Theater is all delay - and the only surprise is that anyone would choose to produce it or act in it.
title: Review/Theater; Two Aunts, One Husband, a Niece and Complications

text: In this story of domestic strife, one aunt (Ann Wedgeworth) is facing the imminent death of her invalid husband and the other (Bethel Leslie) is struggling to extract herself from the misery of her marriage. Complicating their concerns is the behavior of their unmarried, orphaned niece. The three are gathered in Ms. Wedgeworth's house for what becomes a prolonged death watch.
title: Review/Theater; Two Aunts, One Husband, a Niece and Complications

text: To pass the time of the play, the women turn on the radio and phonograph, offering theatergoers an almost continuous ''Make Believe Ballroom'' of old ballads. They dance with each other, drink, bake marijuana brownies (to relieve the dying husband's pain) and manage to fill the emptiness of the dialogue with another kind of emptiness.
title: Review/Theater; Two Aunts, One Husband, a Niece and Complications

text: Acting can sometimes transcend dreary writing, but in this instance the actresses and the author descend to bathos together. The three accomplished performers are misled by their material and, presumably, by their director, Charles Maryan, into the land of self-parody.
title: Review/Theater; Two Aunts, One Husband, a Niece and Complications

text: Rushing around the small stage in a brightly colored dressing gown, Ms. Wedgeworth is in a perpetual dither, acting absentminded and frivolous as if she has already begun her merry widowhood. Ms. Dillon hides her talent behind the squeaks and squeals of arrested adolescence. Ms. Leslie, marginally more watchable than her co-stars, stresses her character's severity and is as sour as an unripe crab apple. Christopher Wynkoop adds bluster in a supporting role as Ms. Leslie's errant husband.
title: Review/Theater; Two Aunts, One Husband, a Niece and Complications

text: A modicum of interest - far short of tension - is supplied by the fact that the unseen invalid has a bell in his bedroom, which he has vowed to ring three times when agony calls and he wants help in ending his life. At one point, the doorbell rings loudly, three times, causing the women to leap to attention. Unfortunately, this is a false alarm. Dancing and Delay-THE AUNTS, by Gary Bonasorte; directed by Charles Maryan; set design, Atkin Pace, lighting design, John Gleason; costume design, Lana Fritz; production stage manager, Bill McComb; sound design by Brian Ronan; dances by Bertram Ross. Presented by Ervin Litkei, in association with Ethel Gabriel and Larry Lipp, at the 47th Street Theater, 304 West 47th Street. Meg . . . Bethel Leslie Nan . . . Ann Wedgeworth Pita . . . Mia Dillon Chuck . . . Christopher Wynkoop
title: Review/Theater; Two Aunts, One Husband, a Niece and Complications

text: Shari J. Perlstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Perlstein of Aberdeen, N.J., was married last evening to Roger M. Barzun, a son of the cultural critic and historian Jacques M. Barzun of New York and the late Mariana Lowell Barzun. Rabbi A. Allen Block officiated at Publican's on the Pier at the South Street Seaport in New York.
title: Shari Perlstein Wed to Roger Barzun

text: Mrs. Barzun is a graduate of Boston University. Her father, who is retired, taught English in the New York City school system.
title: Shari Perlstein Wed to Roger Barzun

text: Mr. Barzun is a vice president and the general counsel of the Miniscribe Corporation, a manufacturer of computer disk drives in Longmont, Colo. He graduated from Harvard University and the Columbia University School of Law. His previous marriage ended in divorce.
title: Shari Perlstein Wed to Roger Barzun

text: While cocaine has dominated public concern about drug use, alcohol remains the drug of choice among suburban teen-agers, like those in Westchester County.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: Drinking remains more prevalent among high-school seniors than among adults, national surveys show, and many experts believe alcohol has become a cornerstone of high-school life.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: Mention crack, and Kim Bulger, an animated 17-year-old from Rye Brook, N.Y., frowns disapproval. Mention beer, and she brightens. ''Everyone drinks,'' she said. ''We drink to get drunk. It's fun.'' Substance-abuse experts say that many teen-agers appear to have embraced alcohol as the one safe drug, and that their drinking comes almost as a relief to parents terrified of crack. 'Given Up the Battle'
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: ''It's unfortunate, but to some extent we have, as a society, given up the battle to get students not to drink,'' said Abby Hirsch, a guidance counselor at Hastings High School in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and adviser to the high school's chapter of Students Against Driving Drunk, known as SADD.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: ''In fact,'' she said, ''one of the problems with SADD is the implicit admission that students do drink.'' The group has chapters in 15,000 high schools and 4,000 junior high schools across the nation.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: The concern about alcohol has risen despite surveys showing that the percentage of students who drink has fallen, in line with a decline in the general population. This decline comes after years of school anti-drinking programs, and after the last state with a drinking age of 18 returned it to 21. New York did so in 1985.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: But those who work with young people now are concerned that alcohol is so rooted in the lives of teen-agers - as it is in the lives of many of their parents and society at large - that complacency about teen-agers' drinking will only grow as people become more intolerant of deadlier drugs.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: ''This has taken a backseat to hard drugs, but in our community and in the suburbs generally, teen-age drinking is by far our biggest problem,'' said William Shuluk, a police officer who monitors the activities of minors in Dobbs Ferry, on the Hudson River.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: The street drugs common across the border in sections of New York City do have a grip on the few urban pockets in Westchester, but educators, law-enforcement officials and young people say crack and most other narcotics are rarely seen in the suburbs, whether modest or wealthy.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: ''Beer is the way you get high,'' said Dr. Robert Mackin, the principal of Fox Lane High School in Bedford, an affluent town in northern Westchester. ''If you see any peer pressure among the kids as it relates to drugs and alcohol, it is against using hard drugs.''
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: Weekends for many teen-agers revolve around drinking beer - whether from kegs or bottles, in parks or kitchens, with or without parents present. And today, it is not uncommon for elementary-school students to begin experimenting with alcohol.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: Westchester is not unusual. Across the United States, alcohol eclipses all other drugs tried by high school students. According to a survey by the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan, 64 percent of 16,300 high school seniors surveyed in 1988 had drunk alcohol in the last month, compared with 18 percent who had smoked marijuana and 1.6 percent who had smoked crack.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: Westchester, a county of 890,000 people, has, like many large suburbs, long waged a campaign against underage drinking. 'To Rebel, to Defy - to Drink'
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: Yet there is a growing sense among the campaigners that, while they may be able to prevent drunk students from climbing behind the wheel of a car, they cannot prevent them from becoming drunk in the first place.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: ''What's part of the adolescent stage of development is the need to rebel, to defy authority - to drink,'' said Larry Posner, a supervisor of Student Assistance Services, a nonprofit Westchester organization fighting student substance abuse. ''So I don't think we can eliminate it. That would be a fantasy. But we can try to control it.'' The county's greatest effort in recent years has centered on reducing drunken driving by teen-agers. About half of the 35 school districts have ''Safe Rides'' programs in which sober students drive intoxicated ones home from parties on weekend nights. Two thirds of the high schools have SADD chapters, and a course emphasizing the dangers of drunken driving has reached 20,000 students.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: The efforts have not been restricted to Westchester's high schools. This year, a county-financed program on substance abuse for all sixth-graders was extended to the fifth grade. And in its third year is a mini-course for parents called ''Talking to Your Kids About Alcohol.'' Student Assistance Services furnishes 36 high schools and 17 middle schools with counselors specializing in drug and alcohol abuse. 'Current Drinkers' Decline'
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: In cities and towns across the country, anti-drinking campaigns may be producing positive results. Drug experts are buoyed by the steady decline in the last decade in students who say they are ''current drinkers'' - meaning they have had at least one drink in the last month. Surveys by the Institute for Social Research of high school students in their senior year show that alcohol consumption among them peaked in 1980, when 72 percent of students were ''current drinkers,'' compared with 64 percent last year.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: But those same experts caution that 64 percent is still a lot. Furthermore, high school seniors are out-drinking the general adult population. Of 4,214 adults ages 26 and over surveyed last year by the National Institute on Drug Abuse, 55 percent said they had had at least one drink in the last month.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: Surveys show that seniors have been out-drinking the population as a whole at least since 1972, the year the Institute began surveying them.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: Excessive ''binge'' drinking is an even greater concern: more than a third of the high school seniors said that in the last two weeks, they had had had five or more drinks in a row. 'Who Can Pass Out First?'
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: ''For some people, the idea is to see who can pass out first, or who is left standing,'' said Leonard Lombardi, a senior at Byram Hills High in Armonk, who said he goes to parties but rarely drinks. ''Everybody huddles around the keg and watches each other. It sounds stupid, but that's the half of it.''
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: ''You just have a better time in general if you're drunk,'' said Karen Pellicone, 16, a junior at Port Chester High School. ''But it's really not true,'' she added, laughing, ''because half the time, the next morning, you can't even remember all the fun you had.''
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: Why do students drink? Teen-agers and adults point to a number of reasons: peer pressure, alcohol's general availability but alluring illegality to them, and its glamorous portrayal in advertisements. Some students say it relieves boredom, helps them relax, makes them feel sexy and gives them confidence in social situations. 'One or Two a Total Mess'
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: Some students interviewed scoffed at the legal drinking age, noting that most European countries let teen-agers drink and contending that most students they knew were able to handle alcohol. ''The laws are absolutely ludicrous,'' said Jordan Copeland, 16, of Hastings-on-Hudson, who said he drank in moderation at parties.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: ''There's always one or two people at parties who are a total mess,'' he said. ''But the majority are in complete control. And they watch out for those one or two and drive them home at the end of the night.''
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: By and large, students do not drink during the school week, and with the legal drinking age at 21, bars are out of bounds. But come the weekend, practically every town has at least one underage party, indoors or out.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: ''Each town has its place - the park in Dobbs Ferry, the woods in Hastings, the beach in Rye,'' said Ellen R. Morehouse, the executive director of Student Assistance Services, adding that fake identification cards, older siblings, friends and even parents all help teen-agers obtain beer, wine coolers and, to a much lesser extent, hard liquor. 'From Rye to Yonkers'
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: Unlike crack, which is confined mainly to poor urban neighborhoods, alcohol seems to cut across Westchester's socio-economic lines. ''The problems of alcohol abuse exist across the board, whether it's rural North Salem, suburban Rye or inner-city Yonkers,'' said Larry Posner, a supervisor of Student Assistance Services.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: Drug experts and students say that in middle-class towns marijuana seldom circulates at parties now, and cocaine may be reserved for special occasions, like birthdays and graduation. LSD has made a minor comeback recently, but harder drugs, especially crack, are generally shunned.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: ''Drugs is nowhere near as popular as beer,'' said a 15-year-old Hastings High School junior and member of the SADD club and varsity soccer team, who requested anonymity. ''I don't think anybody in the school uses crack. Students joke around about it. But look at the effects of crack - you take it once and you're addicted. That's one good reason not to take it.''
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: Substance-abuse specialists say that the lack of compelling social choices for teen-agers is in some measure to blame for teen-agers' drinking. ''It's not as easy as saying, 'Okay, let's play Parcheesi,' '' Mr. Posner said. ''And it's partly the responsibility of adults to come up with alternatives, to acknowledge the fact that their children are bored and lonely and going through the hell of adolescence.'' Some Ground Children, Some Buy
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: Educators say parents play a vital role in shaping their child's attitude toward drinking. But in Westchester, parental response covers the spectrum. There are parents who ground their teen-agers caught with beer and object to Safe Rides because they feel it encourages drinking. Then there are parents who provide alcohol.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: ''I know parents who actually go out and buy a keg or beer-ball for their kids, set it up and just leave,'' said Mr. Lombardi, the high school senior.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: Laws in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and many other states hold parents liable if a minor has a car accident after drinking in their home. It is also against the law in those states for an adult to sell or give alcohol to minors who are not their children.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: But for many parents, drug experts say, there is sometimes a sense of relief that their children are dabbling in beer and nothing harder. ''When confronted, parents often say, 'Well, at least my child's not using crack,' '' said Ms. Morehouse.
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: ''The attitude seems to be, 'So what if my kids drink on weekends so long as they get A's in school?' '' she said. ''But what's really important in life is not whether they get an A in physics, but that they learn to flirt, handle boredom, be intimate and socialize without the crutch of alcohol.''
title: Drinking Keeps Its Grip on Suburban Teen-Agers

text: With the growth of crack addiction in the middle class, treatment specialists have discovered that affluent addicts are more likely to deny their problem at first, and more able to hide addiction's devastating costs.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Once in treatment, affluent addicts typically have more effective support from family and employers and an education level that makes them more receptive to health concerns.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Despite these advantages, there are no guarantees that even the best treatment will work. Expensive private treatment programs have increased markedly in recent years as the addiction in the middle class has grown. But treatment specialists say they still have much to learn about what particular strategies work for which patients, and why.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: The addicts themselves, some of whom have squandered not only money but marriage, family life and self-respect on crack, describe in detail a recovery process that is not just painful but never-ending. 'Collision With Reality'
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: The addict with social and economic support does not normally seek treatment until driven by some ''private collision with reality,'' in the words of Dr. Michael Sheehy of the Silver Hill Foundation in New Canaan, Conn., an institution with long experience treating addicts.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: ''For instance,'' the doctor said, ''nothing focuses the attention of your average middle-class person quite so quickly as a felony arrest.''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Many addicts arrive for initial treatment feeling that they are doing it for someone else - an attitude which, if continued, rarely presages success. ''Inner city addicts can hardly not face the reality of their addiction and situation,'' said Lee Chase, a Michigan drug counselor. ''But the middle class has the greatest denial instincts you can imagine.''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: William Hopkins, director of street research for New York State's Division of Substance Abuse, agrees: ''In the poor neighborhoods, everyone knows every user and every dealer, so there is no public image to protect. Middle class addicts have both a public and a self-image to protect with denial.'' A Slide Into Paranoia
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Typically, crack addicts who work become so paranoid about their addiction and the risk of discovery that they confine smoking to evenings or weekends, and usually do it alone. They smoke as much crack as they have and afterward may ease their depression by drinking and sleeping.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: ''They are incredible,'' agreed Joel Dannewitz, director of the crisis clinic for Aquarian Effort in Sacramento, Calif. ''They say, 'Well, yeah, I do some crack every day, but I'm not really an addict because I'm not poor. I don't go to crack houses. I don't use needles. And I don't hang around on street corners.' So we say: 'Well, then why is it your wife is leaving? And your boss is threatening to fire you?' They've got to see that bad is bad even when it's better than.'' THE ACCOUNTANT
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Mike L., a 30-year-old accountant, had learned an important lesson about the personal and social corruption wrought by drugs. On his way to buy cocaine, he was stopped for a traffic violation in a small New York town and then arrested when the officer discovered marijuana in the car.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Mike soon found himself in the local judge's basement. ''That's a lot of money,'' said the judge, eyeing the $500 in Mike's wallet. ''Now, you don't want a drug arrest on your record, do you?''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: The young man took the hint. He left $350 in the basement as a ''fine.'' Mike got no police record. Neither did he get any drug treatment.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: In recent years, he began smoking crack in his bedroom at night and on weekends, when his daughters and wife would flee this strange new person. ''I never used a crack house, though, so I knew I wasn't a crack addict.''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: He sold family property, consumed family bank accounts. ''Unless you go for help, I'm leaving,'' his wife said. And her lawyer's letter confirmed it. ''Find me someone to go to,'' said Mike. Days of Craving
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: She did. The day Mike was to begin a one-month residential treatment, he left his family at a coffee shop. Instead of taking the train to the hospital, he bought more crack and hid in his bedroom. His wife found him there later and put him in a taxi. He smoked more crack on the train.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: There followed days of craving. Hours of pacing. Drug dreams. Group therapy. There were private sessions with a psychiatrist and counselor. There were emotional highs and lows, and Mike was told to practice handling each.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: ''I just could not see myself as a drug low life. I was a nice guy. I manage lots of people at work. I'm in control. It was hard to admit that I wasn't in control of myself. Very hard.''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: After a month Mike returned to work (only a company counselor knows of his addiction and treatment) and began attending daily meetings of Narcotics Anonymous. ''Sober life has frightening moments. The drug becomes your best friend and closest enemy at the same time. Spare time is frightening. Watching TV is frightening. And coming home from work now, seeing all the dealers just around the corner is difficult, I gotta say.'' Counting His Clean Time
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Twenty-two weeks after his return home Mike slipped. He smoked marijuana - and the crack craving returned, as the doctor had predicted. Mike went out to buy some, but no dealers were around. After admitting his mistakes to his N.A. group, he started counting his clean time all over again. He walks home on different streets now. ''A slip is not always a fall,'' said Mike's doctor.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: ''It's frightening,'' said Mike, ''to think that right now I am determined never to smoke again, but three hours from now I could be out there. I got to be on guard forever.'' But his daughters no longer fear him. His wife remains understanding, if reserved. ''It's difficult to trust someone again after all those lies,'' Mike says. ''But there's definitely healing under way.''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: The other night his wife gave him a compliment. She had just returned from getting money from their bank's cash machine. She said how nice it was to check the balance and find that someone had not emptied it. All Addicts Are Not Alike ''We're just beginning to get a sense of what treatments work,'' says Dr. Arnold M. Washton, who operates a New York treatment center.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Experts are finding that, although the addiction's power and destruction cut across class lines, the effectiveness and psychology of differing treatment strategies do not. As Dr. Sheehy put it: ''An addict is an addict is an addict. But a patient is not a patient is not a patient. Every one of them is different, from the inner city to the suburbs.''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Treatment skill comes in mixing and matching the medicines and therapies to the individual's addictions and underlying emotional problems.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: ''There is no magic bullet,'' says Dr. Jeffrey S. Rosecan, director of cocaine abuse treatment at New York's Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Numerous private programs have emerged in the last three years to serve the thousands of working addicts with the insurance or private funds to cover residential treatments that normally last at least a month and may cost more than $1,000 a day. Addiction's Wide Swath
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Both the older private programs, which tend to rely on discreet doctor referrals, and the spread of new private addiction programs, a few of which advertise on radio and television, are now showing that most new patients are ''polyaddicts.'' They are addicted to more than one substance -crack and alcohol, for instance.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: According to the National Institute on Drug Abuse surveys, the number of treatment centers and patients has risen sharply in recent years, from 3,018 with 173,479 patients in 1982 to 5,360 centers with 260,151 patients in 1987. Self-help groups report similar increases. Narcotics Anonymous says it had 2,000 active groups of addicts in the 50 states in 1982. Today, it estimates 14,000 groups - at least one in every county in the nation - with 2,000 more groups in 50 other countries.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: There are no definitive figures on success rates, in part because there is no one standard treatment to judge. Some counselors say privately that some of the new treatment centers will only treat addicts as long as insurance lasts. These counselors are concerned about the quality of treatment at the new centers; they say the centers are not monitored or investigated. The Motivation Factor
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: And unlike purely medical problems, much of any addiction treatment's success depends on each patient's personality, especially motivation.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: ''Addiction treatment,'' Dr. Washton said, ''is the only health care field where effectiveness is judged by results among significant numbers of people who don't want our help. It's like saying, 'Why is penicillin so ineffective among those patients who refuse the drug?' ''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Some studies and anecdotal experiences suggest treatments are successful with only one or sometimes two of every three patients staying clean. ''Recovering from addiction is a lifelong day-to-day struggle every day,'' said Mr. Chase, himself a recovering addict. ''Down the line, most patients relapse. They have to road-test our teaching.''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Counselors also find potent denial even among relatives who may be addicted not to a drug, but to the dependence of the person on the drug. Any change can seem to threaten their lives and that stability, even if that stability is painful and costly at times.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Treatment strategies vary from long, military-style regimens to looser out-patient clinics. But three ingredients have emerged as crucial: effective detoxification; longterm counseling, both individual and in groups dealing with the addiction and underlying problems such as depression or low self-esteem; and followup support.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Many complain that private treatment is too expensive and public treatment underfinanced. But, at least for initial help, support groups such as Narcotics Anonymous, Cocaine Anonymous or Alcoholics Anonymous remain free and without waiting lists, and with virtually hourly meetings in every city are open to anyone any time. THE BUSINESSMAN
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: ''I stopped smoking crack a couple of times by myself,'' said Brian B., a Midwesterner who is 30 and was married to a nonaddict. ''It was terrifying.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: ''But then I'd start getting clear-headed again, and I'd have some opinions - and my wife would go out and buy me some more. And I'd light it up and sit in front of the TV.''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: The owner of a video-game leasing business in the Middle West, Brian is the son of an office supervisor. His first memory of getting high came at the age of 5. when a friend's father laughingly encouraged him to drink a beer. By 14, he had more than just tried vodka and marijuana. ''Sometimes I got angry or sad or quiet, and I was always being told I shouldn't feel that way. Drinking and pot let me feel the way I really felt.''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: One time, he saw a friend snort a gram of cocaine, jump up, run into a wall and collapse in convulsions, turning a deathly shade of white. So by some turn of internal logic, Brian switched to smoking crack, which eventually cost $800 a week.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Whenever he tried to stop, he found himself eating compulsively. His first rehabilitation, 90 days of out-patient care, failed. ''But then I wanted to not drink and do drugs, or I wanted to die and I didn't care which.'' After a 30-day in-patient stay, he felt so secure he was afraid to leave. But he did. He then began 12 weeks of out-patient sessions and now attends Narcotics Anonymous sessions. Often his 6-year-old daughter attends simultaneous Ala-Tot meetings of children of addicts.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: He said he was very afraid before his first Narcotics Anonymous meeting. Then he saw six of his old high-school snorting pals sitting there, too. The Language Of Treatment Among the new approaches in this new field of middle class crack treatment, Mr. Chase has found that even something as simple as the language spoken in group sessions can make a difference. Many middle class addicts are put off as much by torrents of street language as some inner city members are by recommended readings or academic citations. Other counselors find that descriptions of crack's impact on health arouse more concern among middle class addicts.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: But Dr. Forest Tennant, who operates 20 California clinics and is drug adviser to the National Football League, says real scare tactics or dire health warnings do not work with the 1,500 middle-class addicts his clinics treat annually.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: ''They may have done some dumb things,'' he said. ''And their sense of discipline may be dormant. But these are educated people. I give them a menu of 20 things - nutrition requirements, food supplements, physical and mental exercises, new hobbies, life style changes, and so forth. I say you need to do 12 of these. Pick them. With someone less motivated, I wouldn't give them the choice.'' Testing Is Constant
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Dr. Tennant takes ''the 'attaboy approach.'' The urine of all patients is tested every 48 hours, and those detailed results, showing declining amounts of harmful chemicals, are shown to abstaining patients as encouragement, like a successful dieter watching the scales each morning.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: ''But without the education, the family support and the motivation,'' Dr. Tennant adds, ''I could talk to some patients all day about getting their body chemistry back in balance by developing a breakfast habit of high-complex carbohydrates, and that would produce zero change.''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: ''In many inner city apartments there may be several addicts in the same family,'' said Dr. Tennant ''In the suburbs, an addict's family and co-workers may be shocked, but I have no trouble involving them in support, because crack is so devastating so quickly that the memory of the real Harry or Sally is still fresh.'' THE LONELY MAN
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Steve G. has lost track of all the treatment programs he has tried. ''The trouble with all these therapies,'' he said with a smile, ''is they ruin your high. You start feeling guilty.''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: He has gone through a series of encounter groups, residential and out-patient treatments and psychiatrist's visits, seeking to whip marijuana-cocaine-alcohol-crack addictions that consumed, among other things, a $50,000 trust fund. He did not feel he was addicted because he was not injecting drugs. ''I was big on denial,'' he says, a few days into another program.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Crack seemed the answer to loneliness and lingering depression over his mother's death. ''I was looking for something destructive to put me back in touch with the pain I'd become so comfortable with,'' he said.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: But this time his motivation is greatest. His days are filled with the usual meetings. His nights are often filled with long, bad dreams. ''There are a lot of ups and downs,'' he said. And he is debating his outright release versus a halfway house. Where he will go next week he has no idea.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: But he does know where he won't be going - to Manhattan's 167th Street or Times Square, where he could easily buy crack from the many street merchants. ''I was feeling pretty superior to them,'' he said. ''Then one day I realized something. They were smiling every time they saw me coming.'' Signs of Hope Despite Worry Dr. Rosecan and others are worried about the future because recent generations of teen-agers have insisted on experimenting with drugs, and crack allows no room for mere experimentation. Still, there are glimmers of hope. The total number of reported cocaine users declined, from 23 million in 1985 to 14.5 million last year, according to the National Institute on Drug Abuse.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: And while some insurance companies are increasingly reluctant to finance multiple treatments, counselors say many employers are quietly understanding about rehabilitation absences. The General Motors Corporation says post-treatment addicts are even better workers than before their addiction.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: ''But crack is not the real problem,'' said Bruce Hindenach, executive director of the Capital Area Abuse Commission in Lansing, Mich. ''Crack addicts have a way of getting help or getting dead. And there will always be another drug to abuse. The real problem is all of our national addictions.''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: And the general longterm ineffectiveness of many drug war strategies from the police car to the psychiatrist's couch are beginning to raise larger social questions.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: ''We are an increasingly addictive nation,'' said Dr. Washton. ''Crack, booze, cigarettes. Two years ago, Turkey was the bad guy for opium. Now it's Colombia. This month, the concern is crack. Next month it'll be crank. And then ice and whatever. See, that way it's 'them' not 'us.' That lets us avoid facing the more important, the more frightening question of ourselves and our own addictions.''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: ''The drug war,'' said Mr. Hopkins, ''is going to be won not by folks getting off drugs but by folks not getting on drugs. The police can't do that, only parents can, by teaching values again from Day One.''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: In his new book, ''Willpower's Not Enough'' (Harper & Row), Dr. Washton notes that the United States has 2 percent of the world's population but consumes 60 percent of its illicit drugs. And the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism reports that American alcoholics and problem drinkers total 17.5 million, or 3 million more than cocaine users.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: ''People worry about being mugged by crack addicts,'' said Mr. Hindenach. ''But drunk drivers have got nothing to do with Colombia, and they kill 25,000 Americans every year.''
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Robert Wadman is chief of police in Omaha, where crack is a daily problem now. ''We adults,'' he said, ''are staggering around with a vodka in one hand and a government-subsidized cigarette in the other, telling our kids they shouldn't use mind-altering substances that are bad for their health.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: ''Now what's the lesson you would draw from that?'' WHERE TO GO TO GET HELP
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Anyone desiring help for drug addiction can seek simple conversation or referral to treatment services by calling local offices of Narcotics Anonymous or Alcoholics Anonymous, which are listed in the white pages. In the New York area the 24-hour number for A.A. is 212-601-5817.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: National headquarters for Narcotics Anonymous is c/o Box 9999, Van Nuys, Calif. 91409. Phone 818-780-3951. Hours are 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. Pacific time.
title: Affluent Addicts' Road Back Begins in a Climb Past Denial

text: Eric Griffin, who lost a chance to make the 1988 United States Olympic team because of a positive test for marijuana, stood tonight as the world amateur boxing champion at 106 pounds.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: The 5-foot-3-inch Griffin, a 22-year-old from Houston, attacked Rogelio Marcelo of Cuba for three rounds and caught him often enough for a 17-13 decision victory.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: Griffin was the only one of the 12 members of the young, internationally inexperienced United States team to make the finals.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: The other two United States medals were bronze won by Tonga McClain, 19, of Racine, Wis., at 132 pounds, and by Raul Marquez, 18, of Houston.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: Marcelo was the one of two Cubans to lose in five attempts for golds tonight.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: Last year, Griffin finished second to Michael Carbajal in the Olympic Trials and was selected to meet Carbajal in the box-offs.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: He was barred from the box-offs, however, when a test taken during the trials proved positive for marijuana.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: Carbajal got a silver medal in the Olympics and now is fighting professionally.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: ''When I heard about the test results, it crushed me, my friends, my family,'' Griffin said. ''I thought my career was over because boxing is my life.''
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: Griffin said tonight, ''As I said, I wanted to make the U.S. team proud of me, and also the people back home. Now I'm world champion. I never felt this way before because now I have joy in my life.''
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: Griffin entered the ring to boos, but before the bout was over a few Soviet fans were chanting, ''USA, USA.''
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: The left-handed Griffin kept the pressure on Marcelo from the opening bell and scored points with right jabs and hooks.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: The first round was even, then the patient Griffin took charge.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: Enrique Carrion, 119; Julio Gonzalez, 132, and Felix Savon, 201, a world champion in 1986, were the Cuban winners tonight.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: Three more Cubans will box for gold medals Sunday.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: Carrion was greeted by cheers from a large contingent of Cubans in the crowd of about 10,000 at the Olympic Center.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: Carrion barely made it. Under the computerized scoring system, his bout with the 1988 Olympic champion, Andreas Zuelow of East Germany, was scored 15-15. Carrion was awarded the decision on the judges' discretion.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: The other Cuban loser was Angel Espinosa, a 1986 world champion, who was outpointed by 28-12 by Andrei Kurnyavka of the Soviet Union in the best action bout of the night.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: The only other non-Cuban champion was Fransic Vastag of East Germany, who upset the European champion, Siegfried Mehnert, in the 147-pound class.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: Six finals will be held Sunday night.
title: Griffin Outpoints Cuban for Only U.S. Gold Medal in Moscow

text: By Lindsey Gruson, Special To the New York Times
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: Farmers cultivating the lush volcanic mountains above this isolated city have in the last two years become one of the hemisphere's largest producers of opium poppies, from which heroin is made.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: Western diplomats say that local farmers, trained and financed by Mexican drug traffickers, have shifted thousands of acres of rich agricultural land from fruits and vegetables to opium production. The area can now supply about 60 percent of the annual consumption by the estimated 500,000 addicts in the United States, they say.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: The meteoric rise in poppy cultivation, which was rare in Guatemala until two years ago, has accompanied this sparsely populated country's emergence as a leading transshipment point for South American cocaine headed north to America and east to Europe, senior Guatemalan officials and foreign diplomats say.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: ''Guatemala is ideal for transshipment of cocaine, and it's perfect for growing poppies,'' a Western diplomat said. ''It's the only Central American country in the big leagues in both.'' As Crackdown Grows, So Does Trafficking
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: Drug trafficking has grown throughout Central America as United States anti-drug efforts have increased the risk of using Caribbean and Mexican smuggling routes.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: Traffickers now routinely use Honduras and Costa Rica for transshipment. Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's de facto ruler, was indicted two years ago in Florida on drug smuggling charges and is widely accused of making his country into a haven for money laundering and trafficking.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: Federal prosecutors in Miami say there is convincing evidence that several top commanders in the Honduran armed forces are also involved in drug smuggling. Officials of the Nicaraguan Government and aides to President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica have also been accused. Drug smuggling has also increased in El Salvador, but civil war appears to have prevented that country from becoming a major transshipment point.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: But Guatemala has emerged as the region's leading cocaine transshipment point and largest opium producer. In addition, it is becoming a major producer of marijuana. In an apparent response to a United States eradication program in Belize, marijuana producers have crossed the border and are clearing large patches of jungle in Peten province. Threat to Democracy From Drug Cartels
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: The growing military, financial and political muscle of the country's emerging drug cartels has sparked sharp concern for the survival of the country's nascent democracy. Increasingly, diplomats in the capital compare the country with Colombia in the 1970's, when rings of wealthy narcotics traffickers began accumulating power through intimidation and bribery.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: ''I call it proto-Colombia, in which case, God help Guatemala,'' a senior Western diplomat said. ''It's a lot more dangerous than the re-emergence of the far right, which is an accepted and traditional part of the country's politics. Traffickers are something this country is not capable of dealing with.''
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: Alfonso Cabrera, the leading candidate in next year's presidential election, has been repeatedly linked to traffickers. He denies the charges. But one brother was arrested five years ago with 22 pounds of cocaine; a second was linked to a 119-pound shipment. Officials close to the case say he engineered a cover-up of the investigation.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: ''It's not believable that he's just the piano player who didn't know what was happening upstairs,'' said a diplomat who knows Mr. Cabrera, President Vinicio Cerezo's closest friend and anointed successor. An Unwilling Army And Poppy Growers
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: Some Western diplomats charge that the country's guerrillas, who are newly active, protect growers. But the diplomats, who for years have asserted that the rebels cooperate with marijuana producers in northeastern Guatemala, acknowledge that they have little evidence to support their assertions, which are difficult to verify.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: The poorly armed Guatemalan Army appears unwilling or unable to confront the growers, whose growing firepower has forced a temporary halt in eradication programs funded by the United States. The Treasury Police, which keeps 16 officers in this city 200 miles northwest of Guatemala City, are outmanned and outgunned and rarely venture far from their barracks, a local army officer said.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: ''The growers have weapons and the police are afraid to go into the growing areas,'' said Alejandro Roblero Reyes, the Mayor of Cuilco, the region's agricultural center and long a prosperous city of 13,000. ''They are threatened when they go. The growers say, 'We have weapons, too, and, if you dare come here, we'll shoot.' ''
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: That is not an idle threat. Six treasury policemen and their peasant guide were killed in January 1988 as they destroyed a poppy field outside San Marcos, south of Cuilco. Heavily armed growers have on occasion stopped Guatemalan eradication teams. Aid to Guatemala Is Now Threatened
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: Guatemala's emergence as a major player in the international drug bazaar has sparked concern among United States diplomats that it will lead to a bitter Congressional debate over American aid to this country, which is just emerging from international isolation after years of military rule.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: United States law requires the President to certify that major drug producing countries receiving American aid are doing everything in their power to combat trafficking and that they are cooperating fully with eradication efforts. Guatemala is not yet on the list.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: The Government has given American enforcement agents a free hand to collect information about trafficking and to eradicate poppy and marijuana fields, diplomats said. But, they added, it has taken few steps to stop the trade by itself and permits more than 200 Colombians suspected of drug trafficking to stay in the country.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: Western diplomats and American officials seeking to prod Guatemala into taking more vigorous action against the traffickers say that the armed forces, the country's most powerful institution, have remained hestitant to get involved in the battle against drugs, fearing their corrupting influence. Mountains for Cover And Low-Flying Planes
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: In large part, Guatemala has become a drug transshipment center because of its location, almost exactly halfway between the Colombian cocaine processing laboratories and the American markets. That makes the country an ideal refueling stop, allowing pilots to use smaller planes, which are harder to detect by radar.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: But Guatemala also is attractive to the traffickers because it is unusually poorly equipped to prevent drug smuggling. Its mountains provide ideal cover for low-flying planes. The only radar in the entire country, at the capital's international airport, has a range of just 16 miles, when it is working at all. There are miles of unmonitored rural roads and dozens of unused landing strips, built by crop dusters to spray the once-plentiful cotton.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: The main tools for combating drugs and prosecuting leaders are impaired by lax export controls and a legal system that does not provide for conspiracy charges or the confiscation of ill-gotten profits. ''You have to nail them with the drugs in their possession,'' one American agent said.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: Despite handicaps, seizures of cocaine have more than tripled in the last year. In the last 11 months, the police have found more than 5,500 pounds, compared with 1,760 in the previous year. But they say that they have yet to dent the traffic, which by some estimates totals as much as 1,100 pounds a week.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: It is unclear if the increase in the amount seized is the result of improved police work or simply because traffickers are shipping larger quantities of drugs through the country. Mexican Poppy Seeds Arrived 5 Years Ago
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: Farmers around Cuilco said poppies were first introduced into the area about five years ago by Mexican drug traffickers, who provided the seed and advice. In the last two years, cultivation has expanded rapidly. An aerial reconnaissance survey of northwestern Guatemala in January by pilots for the Bureau of International Narcotics Matters, an arm of the State Department, found more than 3,600 acres under poppy cultivation, almost double the acreage mapped the previous year and more than twice as much as uncovered the year before that.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: Guatemala, which has a moderate climate, is often called the ''Land of Eternal Spring.'' It has three or four harvests a year and produces between 12 and 13 metric tons of opium gum a harvest, diplomats said. Most of the heroin base is shipped to Mexico to be refined into an estimated 5 tons of pure heroin a year, worth about $2 billion to $5 billion on the street. 15 Times More Money For Growing Poppies
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: Opium poppy production has jumped so quickly that the price of opium gum has plummeted in the last year from $9,000 an acre. But it remains about 15 times as lucrative as the best cash crop. Small landowners can earn $150 an acre farming tomatoes or $2,000 an acre growing opium poppies. The attraction is similar for their laborers.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: The profits have made eradication efforts futile. The United States began aerial spraying with herbicides last fall. But it was forced to suspend the program because flight crews were coming under concentrated ground fire. But poppy growers have learned to protect their crop by stretching plastic sheets over their plants.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: The United States budgeted $1 million this year to fight drug production and smuggling in Guatemala. It has bought and refurbished two rescue helicopters and plans to resume spraying next month, American Embassy officials said. But the diplomat acknowledged that the program may be counterproductive, leading poppy growers to plant additional acreage as insurance against losses.
title: Drug Trafficking and Poppy Growing Finding a Lush Home in Guatemala

text: Crack, which has been devastating entire inner-city neighborhoods, has begun to claim significant numbers of middle- and upper-class addicts, experts have found.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Bush Administration drug policy officials and many law-enforcement experts have maintained that crack is predominantly an inner-city problem, and research has indicated that occasional use of drugs, including cocaine, is declining among the more affluent.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: But now doctors, counselors and crack addicts themselves - in often moving personal accounts - report substantial increases of addiction among affluent and middle-income Americans with a variety of special problems.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: The director of a New York treatment center, Dr. Arnold M. Washton, among many others, said there were more crack addicts among white middle-class people than any other segment of the population, ''despite all the poor black crack addicts you see on TV and Page One.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Dr. Washton added: ''These new addicts are business executives and house painters and doctors and receptionists. And if you met them on the street or at the Little League game, you wouldn't have a clue they're smoking their brains out on crack back home in the basement.'' Crack Studies Just Beginning
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Poor urban neighborhoods clearly have the highest concentrations of crack users, experts agree. What is new, in their view, is the rapid growth of more affluent addicts.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: National research analyzing crack addiction by income and race is just beginning. But reviews of academic research and scores of interviews in recent weeks show a consensus on these points:
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: * Perhaps because they have more to lose in terms of income, property and reputation, middle- and upper-class crack addicts are unusually secretive about their addiction. ''They smoke it in tight little cliques,'' said William Hopkins, director of street research for the New York State Division of Substance Abuse. ''But there are oh-so-many of them. We see their suburban cars streaming through Harlem to make buys all the time.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: * Also mostly hidden are the larger social costs of middle-class addiction as families founder on the financial and emotional price of addiction and insurance companies raise premiums to cover treatment costs. The General Motors Corporation alone estimates that abuse of all drugs costs the auto maker more than $1 billion annually for treatment and worker absenteeism; in the year before seeking treatment the average G.M. employee addicted to drugs comes to work barely half the time.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: * The history that cocaine and crack addicts have most in common is repeated use of marijuana.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: * Cocaine use in all forms, snorted, injected or smoked, is greatest among white single men in metropolitan areas of the Northeast and West.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Dr. Washton said 70 percent of the more than 200 patients he treats at the Washton Institute in New York City each year are middle-class addicts with good jobs. ''There's an extraordinary amount of crack in the American workplace,'' he said. ''Crack is definitely an equal opportunity drug.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: About 70 percent of the 400 patients treated at the private Horizon Center in East Lansing, Mich., are crack addicts. ''They're just average Joes with jobs,'' said Mary Kaczperski, senior therapist at the center.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: At Sacramento's Aquarian Effort, a private, nonprofit center in California, Brian Weiss, a senior counselor, said, ''Crack cuts across all the social and class lines.'' THE BANKER
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Hal W. is a 40-year-old investment banker, the oldest son from a Southern Baptist farm family, who experienced his first drug high in high school when he took the keys to his grandfather's pharmacy and ''borrowed'' some amphetamines.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: ''I'd take the amphetamines to study, and smoke marijuana to come down,'' said the banker, who, like other addicts, spoke on condition that his full name not be used. ''I drank, like my parents. But I thought I wasn't addicted to anything because I knew I could quit anytime.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: In college, a friend introduced him to snorting cocaine. ''It made me feel fabulous, and then very sick,'' he said. ''But I would remember the fabulous and forget the sick, and I'd run out and buy more and more and more. And I'd use it pretty much every day.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Hal first tried crack about five years ago, but because he did not buy his own pipe and cooking paraphernalia, he knew he could not be addicted. When his dealer was arrested for shooting a drug supplier, Hal posted the $10,000 bond. ''I thought it was out of the goodness of my heart,'' he recalled.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: ''You need to understand how the dealer becomes the most important person in a user's life,'' Hal said. ''I gave him the key to my apartment. He had access to my bank account so I could phone from the airport and he'd send a car with a package of crack or he'd deliver it to my apartment at any hour, just like a pizza.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: He said the dealer was despicable. ''But I didn't care. Even when I found out he was skimming thousands extra out of my account, you can bet I found another dealer before I confronted him.'' The new dealer was the friend of a friend, a graduate in Chinese studies at Harvard and Columbia.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: In office meetings colleagues would wink and excuse themselves to go snort cocaine. Hal found himself spending days at a time by himself or with a prominent lawyer friend smoking crack, drinking and watching pornographic movies. ''I can't tell you how high crack made me feel,'' he said, ''or how frightened of the low I was. I'd smoke even when my left arm went numb and I got severe chest pains. I'd tell myself it was because I was sitting in a funny position.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: He lost his girlfriend, who did not use drugs. He was dismissed from his $300,000-a-year job. He borrowed from friends and banks. He bounced checks. ''I was miserable,'' he said, ''but I didn't know what to do about it. And I was so afraid of losing crack.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Last fall a friend who had quit crack steered him to a psychiatric hospital. But after two days Hal checked himself out. Within 48 hours of nonstop smoking he had consumed $5,000 in crack, barely one percent of the money Hal estimates he spent on drugs in recent years.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: He then threw away all his drugs and began serious treatment. ''Last Nov. 5 was the first day of the rest of my life,'' he said. His doctor says he has tested clean ever since.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Walking by an airport pay phone can still trigger a craving. ''But I'm determined that hell is over for me,'' he said.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: As a first step in reconciliation with his family, Hal confided his addiction to an uncle, a psychiatrist who treats many addicts. The uncle then shared a confidence of his own with Hal.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: He was, and still is, a crack addict. Crack Defies Class Lines
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Dr. Jeffrey S. Rosecan of New York City notes that a similar form of smokable cocaine, called freebase, which gives a quicker, more intense high than inhaling cocaine powder, has been popular among affluent addicts for more than a decade.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: The drug user made small amounts of freebase himself, but with materials that were expensive and dangerous. In contrast, crack is sold in vials for $5 to $30.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: ''Crack is just mass-produced freebase,'' said Dr. Rosecan, who heads the cocaine abuse center at New York's Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. ''And it's proving to be just as addictive among the middle class. Only it's more behind closed doors in nice homes.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Bill Coonce, who heads the Drug Enforcement Administration's Detroit office, said: ''It's not just a black or minority drug. We're seeing a rapid expansion of addiction now into suburban and small town America.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: In July the National Institute on Drug Abuse reported some decline in the number of Americans who admitted using any illicit drugs. But the institute's survey found that the number of people who said they used cocaine once a week soared to 862,000 in 1988 from 647,000 in 1985 and the number of daily or almost daily users rose to 292,000 from 246,000 in the same period.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Virtually all experts believe that crack accounts for much of the increase because it induces greater euphoria quicker and is more rapidly addictive than powdered cocaine.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Joseph C. Gfroerer, the institute's director of epidemiology and statistical analysis, said the computer study of the survey's answers by income and race would not be done until later this year. But he said preliminary work indicates that crack is not confined to any income group.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Lee Chase, a recovering heroin addict and counselor at the Care Unit Drug Program in Grand Rapids, Mich., said: ''There's more crack now than ever. You see it in the ghettos of Detroit and elsewhere because those addicts get into trouble with the law right quick. But these middle-class types have got jobs and savings and checking accounts. So it takes longer to burn through their lives.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: The typical middle-class patient sounds remarkably similar whether he is in Mr. Chase's group therapy sessions or Dr. Washton's private office: a man, white, in his 30's or 40's, one of several children of a father with a management or supervisory job, intelligent, employed, with a marriage in differing stages of disarray. He arrives for treatment under pressure from someone and is likely to be addicted to several substances like crack, alcohol and marijuana.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: ''Can you imagine,'' asked Mr. Hopkins, the New York State researcher, sitting in his office on Manhattan's 125th Street, ''a half-dozen shady-looking guys standing around a clean street corner in the suburbs with people on bicycles and in sports cars driving up to make buys? Too much attention, right? So the middle-class addicts send one or two into the city to buy. The exchange is made quietly in the back of the elevator on Wall Street while everyone else is watching the lights for their floor. Then they go smoke them in Bob's basement tonight and Lou's on Thursday. There's no holdups, just advances on the credit cards. They're invisible.'' THE HOMEMAKER
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: It was during one of the many arguments with her husband that Mary G. suddenly realized what she had done.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: He was loudly complaining about the messy apartment and lack of dinner again when their 4-year-old daughter rose to her mother's defense.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: ''Daddy, Daddy, Mommy's O.K. as long as she has her pipe.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Mary, now 37 years old, was first offered marijuana by her older brothers, both now alcoholics, when she was 12.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: She introduced her high school friends to marijuana and they would smoke and drive and drink some beer in the basement, depending on whose parents were not home that evening.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Mary first tried pills in San Francisco, where friends regularly snorted cocaine. She snorted now and then, too. Slowly it became more now than then. In the early 1980's a friend began smoking cocaine and Mary tried that just to be social. ''Immediately and unequivocably I was addicted,'' she recalled.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: When she became pregnant, she said she quit just as abruptly. And her husband, who manages a financial firm, stopped snorting, too. But as soon as Mary's daughter was weaned, Mary returned to crack. ''I said, 'Hey, I can handle this.' ''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: But once a week became twice a week and then three and four times. Mary would drop her daughter off at nursery school, go to a friend's apartment, smoke crack all day and pick her daughter up at 5:30. ''I told myself it was O.K. as long as I didn't take crack home,'' Mary said.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: ''I'd make dinner, give my daughter a bath, read her stories and put her to bed. Then when my husband fell asleep, I'd go to a cash machine, get some money and find a street dealer so I could smoke in my bathroom.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Mary became so eager to reach her friend's apartment and begin smoking crack that she would not bother to stop and leave her daughter at the school but would instead take her along. ''She saw me crawling around on that floor looking for little pieces of crack, as if it was gold,'' Mary said. ''I could have given up my husband, my daughter, my whole life and crawled into that pipe. I was so disgusting.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: She began treatment several times, often ending a day of counseling by heading straight for her friend's apartment to smoke crack.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: One day at a restaurant, after having several drinks at lunch, Mary blacked out. She awoke in a private hospital where no one said anything about drugs or alcohol. ''We in the middle class can get away with so much more,'' she said. ''We're not robbing stores. We just steal from ourselves and our families.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Her daughter's innocent remark about her pipe only eight months into crack addiction pushed her into treatment, which began with a two-week stay at a private hospital in another state. She slipped and smoked crack one day after her return home. But she says she has not smoked in 159 days and attends Alcoholics Anonymous meetings almost every day.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: ''It's a long road,'' she said. ''But I feel better about myself. I'm a good person who had a bad problem. Crack is on the street. But it's not just a street drug.'' Users Leading Double Lives
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: Many middle- and upper-class addicts talk of the pressures and sometimes the perverse joys of leading double lives. One identity is the husband and provider or the successful career woman, pretending to handle all the pressures, hiding the fears and insecurities and that silent inner voice that first whispers and then demands more crack.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: But after inhaling the cocaine fumes, which take effect in eight seconds, another self emerges, more confident, intelligent, in control, sexier.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: ''When I smoked,'' recalled one recovering addict, a 30-year-old daughter of a telephone company manager, ''I could talk at parties and laugh. I didn't have to be shy anymore.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: To finance her $200-to$300-a-day habit, just sitting and smoking for hours, she sold her jewelery, stole from her family and ran up $20,000 in cash advances on her credit cards. Every time she would approach her cards' borrowing limits, the banks would cheerfully announce in a letter that her limit had been increased. ''Hey,'' she said, ''for a drug addict credit cards are a dream come true.'' THE ASSEMBLY LINE WORKER
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: For 23 years Fred T. was the man of the family, the oldest of three children of a registered nurse. His father died in Vietnam. ''I think he was in the Marines,'' Fred said.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: His mother died of cancer at 46. But Fred had a good job on a Michigan automotive assembly line earning about $32,000 a year. He worked hard and saved his money, including a modest trust fund left by grandparents.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: He had seen many colleagues snort cocaine during and after work; one guy on the line was the dealer for office executives, too. His friends told him how good it felt. And one day Fred became curious. He remembers how it felt to be outside himself, free of responsibilities.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: ''I didn't know where I was,'' he said. ''But I was just watching me wander around. It was so easy.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: The next week Fred was curious again. And again. And soon he was smoking crack for the faster high and drinking a lot to ease the crash.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: With $1,500 a week going up in cocaine smoke, the trust fund did not last long. He was bringing home less money for his wife and daughter. He took out some loans against his house. And for a while other family members gave him money.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: ''But then I became an outcast,'' he said. ''They never knew who was at the door, the real Fred or the stranger who looked like him.''
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: His wife and daughter left. He lost the house. And at least two efforts at rehabilitation failed.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: ''There's a madness out there,'' said Fred. ''There are crack smokers sitting in offices making decisions and guys working on the line and running machines. And they don't believe they have a problem. It takes so long to learn. It's like blind men trying to lead blind men. They can't. So if you're blind, you better get yourself a dog.'' NEXT: New treatments emerge.
title: Crack, Bane of Inner City, Is Now Gripping Suburbs

text: MILE ZERO By Thomas Sanchez. 349 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.
title: A WINNING SORT OF LOSER

text: Thomas Sanchez first appeared on the literary landscape some 15 years ago with ''Rabbit Boss,'' a lavishly praised novel of epic dimensions about the tragic experience of the American Indian. That book, it is now clear, was only a warm-up for the dazzling achievement of ''Mile Zero.'' Mr. Sanchez' new novel is marked by the same commanding sense of place, the same mix of politics and poetry. But ''Mile Zero'' is more shapely, leaner and free of ''Rabbit Boss's'' diffuseness and longueurs. Its brilliantly contrived plot uncoils with the suspense of a thriller. Nothing is gratuitous: characters and actions are linked in a hidden web, sometimes with devastating irony. And it is funny, a comic masterpiece crackling with backhanded wit and laugh-out-loud humor.
title: A WINNING SORT OF LOSER

text: The novel is set in Key West, an island that has inspired writers ranging from Ernest Hemingway to Tennessee Williams. It focuses on a group of dropouts from mainstream America.
