At the center is St. Cloud, a burned-out 1960's radical 20 years down the line. His wife, Evelyn, a fellow activist from college days at Berkeley, has abandoned him for women. He has occasionally made a living as a courtroom interpreter, but mostly he is a habitue of a bar, the Wreck Room, where nightly he knocks back the local brew with a dedication not seen since Malcolm Lowry's ''Under the Volcano.''
title: A WINNING SORT OF LOSER

text: Three events combine to halt St. Cloud's downward spiral. He falls for Lila, a displaced Southern belle half his age, a woman ''born on the losing side of the American track'' who now works in a tropical bird shop owned by Evelyn. A boatload of Haitian fugitives arrives in the harbor; Justo Tamarindo, a black Cuban-American police officer, enlists St. Cloud's help in preventing the deportation, and certain death, of a teen-age boy, the boat's lone survivor. And St. Cloud gets drawn into the hunt for a mysterious, voodoo-inspired killer called Zobop who is terrorizing the island.
title: A WINNING SORT OF LOSER

text: ''Mile Zero'' is bursting with vital and engaging characters. Among them is Key West itself, its palette, fauna and Latin beat evoked with a superreal intensity. At times the background almost becomes foreground; in comic fashion, the locales virtually overshadow the people in them. In one scene, St. Cloud spies on Evelyn and her lover from the garden outside Evelyn's house. He is gripped by jealousy and self-pity. Yet the activities in the tropical garden - its crooning frogs, leaping lizards and ''a swirl of ants disassembling an upturned Cuban Death's Head palmetto bug'' - are conveyed as dramatically as St. Cloud's disarray.
title: A WINNING SORT OF LOSER

text: A shifting metaphor, Key West is the last place in America (''Mile Zero'' refers to the last sign marker before the Atlantic) - a place, Justo reflects, with ''the same scent of rancid inevitability as Saigon had in the final days before its fall,'' one that can be totaled by a hurricane the locals refer to as El Finito. Aswarm with drug smugglers, it is ''a marijuana republic, a mere cocaine principality,'' a land where anything goes. For the refugees from the Haiti of the Duvaliers, though, Key West is hope and the beginning of America.
title: A WINNING SORT OF LOSER

text: For St. Cloud, Key West is an accomplice in self-ruin and ultimately perhaps a seedbed of renewal. Having lost his youthful ideals without finding anything to replace them, he has survived, in effect, his own life. He is still atoning for the American sin of the Vietnam war, trying to ''wash away in a sea of alcohol . . . a war he couldn't forget, a war no one else remembered except those who fought in it or against it.'' In real life, a St. Cloud's self-flagellation might be wearying, but he is a winning sort of loser, always distilling humor from his own abjection. He has a perverse grandeur; conscience personified, he is the one man who rejects the prevailing ethos of greed and self-aggrandizement.
title: A WINNING SORT OF LOSER

text: But if beclouded, as his name suggests, by useless remorse, St. Cloud is hardly a saint. He still desires his wife, mounts a major campaign of conquest for Lila and lusts for the local ''Latin sizzle.'' St. Cloud belongs among those characters, common in fiction by male novelists, who oscillate between two women: one the intellectual equal, like Evelyn, who is onto his game and no longer wants to play; the other a not-so-innocent, nubile woman like Lila, who is unable to ''figure what his problem was.''
title: A WINNING SORT OF LOSER

text: The scammers and hustlers of the Wreck Room make up the background chorus, people who ''seemed to have left behind a shadow life.'' Among the more arresting are Brogan, reduced to obsession about his brother, known only as MK, a former Green Beret in Vietnam who now directs a drug operation from Latin America; Bonefish, the local gossip and Cassandra who is ever testing the breeze for signs of El Finito; and a trafficker in racing dogs named Handsomemost, a man who ''liked white powder and white women, bought and sold both, used and abused both, it was a man's right.''
title: A WINNING SORT OF LOSER

text: The lone pillar of probity on this ''Redneck Riviera'' is Justo the police officer, his only vice conch fritters. Justo is the closest that contemporary fiction gets to an old-fashioned hero. Devoted to his wife and daughters, he is ''an island of integrity on an island of shifting morality,'' with a pithy Cuban aphorism for every crisis. He's the novel's moral center and guide through the underworld, doomed, possibly, by his decency. THE crimes of nations cast a long shadow over these pages. (Especially powerful is the story of peasants fleeing Haiti on a craft made of rubber tires - better the sharks than slaughter by the Tontons, or Haitian goon squads.) Yet the novel's prevailing mode is comedy - dark and frequently X-rated. Mr. Sanchez mocks the derailed thinking of substance abusers (''twenty-four ideas jumped between his ears, he grabbed the last one'') and the pseudoprofundities of cokeheads (''animals jumped up on marching powder with nowhere to go''). Smoothly dovetailed into the main narrative are comic vignettes, such as the story of Lila's former marriage to a Southern marijuana grower; strictly a ''meatloaf-and-yams man,'' he takes Lila's mastery of French cooking - learned from afternoon television - as a personal affront. In another hilarious set piece, a woman named Marilyn loves the owner of a licentious parrot called Amigo. The trouble is that Amigo doesn't fancy Marilyn, so she is doomed to disappointment; her love object ''never went to bed with a woman Amigo didn't call out his craving for.'' Even the the novel's horror element, such as a ''Fantasy Fest'' carnival filled with masquerading revelers, including the killer, is laced with mischief.
title: A WINNING SORT OF LOSER

text: Mr. Sanchez shifts fluidly from macho tough talk (Key West's ''incautious end up on the wrong end of the food chain'') to sentences that, mimicking the movement of thought, sluice forward like waves. He avoids standard psychological analysis; he conveys St. Cloud's craving for Lila through dream images or phrases repeated like incantations (''it takes a fool to love like a fool''). St. Cloud's ''rum-soaked reverie'' becomes an instrument of artful distortion, yielding exotic visions - the scrambling of the senses prescribed by the poet Rimbaud. Mr. Sanchez avoids the predictable. He describes his own stylistic practice in St. Cloud's professed liking for ''sentences that slipped off one another with strikingly misguided purpose.'' The book's ending is itself a marvel of ambiguity - tragic, funny and hopeful all at once. ''Mile Zero'' is a novel of uncommon richness and resonance. KEY WEST WAS THE KEY
title: A WINNING SORT OF LOSER

text: Thomas Sanchez spent almost 10 years, a Guggenheim Fellowship and the proceeds from the sale of his house in search of voices to tell the story of America in the post-Vietnam era that fills ''Mile Zero.'' ''I had really been trying to put together a novel that would fuse the Vietnam generation with the post-Vietnam generation, but somehow the voices weren't coming,'' the 45-year-old author said in a telephone interview from Key West, Fla. When Mr. Sanchez stopped off in Key West in 1981 en route to the Caribbean, he carried with him hundreds of pages of notes and sketches for a novel set in California and Mexico. But narrative voices suddenly came to him in Key West, voices that warned of the cocaine tidal wave boiling in Latin America and threatening the United States.
title: A WINNING SORT OF LOSER

text: ''I think the reality of what is really happening in Latin America and Central America for most Americans is a shadow play,'' he said. ''It's the same way Vietnam was in the beginning, mostly a shadow play flickering in the window of television.''
title: A WINNING SORT OF LOSER

text: In the novel Mr. Sanchez uses images that evoke television news, and three of them - the first space shuttle, Haitian refugees fleeing political turmoil and seizures of cocaine along the Florida coast - gripped his imagination. ''These three things forged in my mind a new metaphor, and I realized that the themes of the novel I had been carrying around for all those years had finally coalesced in some hard voices speaking to me in soft, fresh language,'' he said. ''It was the language of the new American experience.'' STEPHANIE STROM
title: A WINNING SORT OF LOSER

text: AS BROADWAY CUTS UP through the Upper West Side of Manhattan and into Washington Heights, it gradually turns into a giant Caribbean bazaar. The avenue abounds with bodegas, farmacias, unisex beauty salons, bargain clothing outlets, restaurants serving pollo and platanos, and travel agencies offering bargains to the Dominican Republic. Women squeeze mangoes, children lick flavored ices, men play hard at dominoes, all to the accompaniment of a hundred different radios blaring salsa music. Long a magnet for immigrants, Washington Heights today is home to large colonies of Irish, Jews and, most numerous of all, Dominicans. As the ever-present crowds make their way up and down the street, the Heights seems a living embodiment of the American Dream - a vibrant, energetic urban melting pot.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Wander off Broadway, though, and the neighborhood quickly seems like an American nightmare. On side streets in the 150's and 160's, clusters of tough teen-agers wearing beepers, four-finger gold rings and $95 Nikes offer $3 vials of crack, the high-octane, smokable derivative of cocaine. On every block there are four or five different ''crews,'' or gangs, each touting its own brand of the drug, known to aficionados as ''Scotty'' (as in ''Beam me up''). Some blocks are ''hotter'' than others, depending on the availability of the crack. On the hottest blocks Scotty is available ''24/7'' - 24 hours a day, seven days a week. So much business is transacted on these streets that Washington Heights has gained a reputation as the crack capital of America.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: The experience of the Heights has been repeated in large cities throughout the country. And now, in smaller communities, too, crack is striking with swift fury, From rural woodlands to shady suburbs, prairie townships to Southern hamlets, no community seems immune. The roster of the infected reads like a roll-call of Middle America itself: Roanoke, Va.; Seaford, Del.; Sioux Falls, S.D.; Cheyenne, Wyo.; Sacramento, Calif.; Portland, Ore. Fort Wayne, Ind., once known as the City of Churches, is now home to an estimated 70 crack houses, causing law-enforcement personnel to christen it ''the crack capital of Indiana.''
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: How did it happen? How did a drug once confined to a handful of large-city neighborhoods make its way to Main Street in just a few short years? Much of the answer can be found in data generated by the Federal Government's unprecedented intelligence-gathering operation against crack. In 13 cities across the country, crack teams created over the last three years by the Justice Department are methodically tracking the importation, distribution and consumption of the drug. In New York, the United States Drug Enforcement Administration (D.E.A.) operates a special Unified Intelligence Division staffed by experts from a dozen agencies, including the F.B.I., the I.R.S., Customs, Immigration and the local police department. Twenty-four hours a day, the information pours in - from wiretaps and surveillance teams, witnesses and informants, police raids and drug busts. By combining this data with testimony from D.E.A. agents, police captains, sociologists, undercover agents, community leaders, criminologists, prosecutors, addicts and treatment experts, it is possible to trace crack's destructive sprint across America.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: WASHINGTON HEIGHTS HAS COME NATU-rally by its status as the nation's crack capital. It would be difficult to design a better location for marketing a new drug. First, the area is highly accessible. To the west, the George Washington Bridge brings in potential customers from New Jersey; to the north the Henry Hudson Parkway pulls them in from Westchester County. For residents of Passaic or Peekskill who want a quick high, the Heights offers easy-in, easy-out convenience. By all accounts, Washington Heights transacts more out-of-town drug deals than any other neighborhood in New York City.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: The neighborhood itself provides a substantial pool of users. For every newcomer who has made it as a shopkeeper on Broadway, there are others who have dropped out of school, had a child out of marriage, become permanently unemployed -likely candidates for drug use. Here, as throughout the country, crack does best where Americans -especially minorities - do worst.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Finally, Washington Heights is home to New York's most enterprising drug dealers. No, they are not Colombians. Although most people associate Colombians with cocaine and crack - especially now that open warfare has broken out between the drug lords and the Government in Bogota - Colombians are not generally involved in the retailing of crack in the United States. They just produce cocaine in South America and smuggle it into the United States. The Colombians living in New York are too few in number and too insular to have the array of contacts necessary to move drugs on the street.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: The Dominicans, New York's fastest-growing immigrant group, do have such contacts. They also have the marketing talent. Crack dealing, like more legitimate lines of work, requires the ability to exercise quality control, hire a dependable workforce and develop a steady clientele. At all of this, the Dominicans (only a small percentage of whom are involved in the drug trade) have had a lot of experience. In the Caribbean, they are known as merchants and tradesmen. In New York, they have applied their savvy to become highly successful shopkeepers - and the city's top crack traffickers.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: ALTHOUGH CRACK'S ORIGINS RE-main obscure - no one really knows who invented it - the Dominicans are generally credited with having first developed it for a mass market. The breakthrough seems to have come about by accident, an improvised response to shifting consumer tastes. Until 1983, cocaine was used almost exclusively in powder form (known as cocaine hydrochloride). Extremely expensive, the drug was often consumed at parties and discos, where it was sprinkled on mirrors and snorted - usually through a high-denomination bill.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Gradually, though, many snorters, seeking a more intense high, turned to freebasing. This involved treating cocaine powder with ether and reducing it to a crystalline base, which, when smoked, produced a sharp, pleasurable rush. Unfortunately, freebasing was complicated and messy, the subject of instruction booklets running on for many pages. It was dangerous, too, risking explosions like the one that hospitalized the comedian Richard Pryor. To avoid the hassle, customers began demanding that their dealers convert the powder to freebase in advance.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: This presented dealers with a dilemma. For, when cocaine is converted to freebase, it loses much of its weight. If they wanted to sell ready-made freebase at popular prices, dealers would have to absorb the loss - unless they could find an undetectable filler .
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: The search was on. One researcher who observed it was Terry Williams, a sociologist at the City University of New York who in 1982 began hanging out with a teen-age cocaine gang in Washington Heights. Williams, who recounts his experiences in a recently published book, ''The Cocaine Kids,'' recalls that the local Dominican gangs ''came up with something called 'comeback,' '' a chemical adulterant akin to lidocaine, a prescription anesthetic. ''When comeback is blended with cocaine powder and cooked, all of it remains in the mix,'' Williams explains. ''This became the first chemical that you could cut freebase with.'' The result was the prototype for crack.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Eventually dealers found other, less expensive substances that worked in conjunction with comeback. The cheapest and most effective was common baking soda. Formulas varied, but the typical instructions were as simple as a recipe out of ''The 60-Minute Gourmet'':
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Take two ounces cocaine hydrochloride. Mix with two ounces comeback and one ounce Arm & Hammer. Add water. Bring to a boil. Let cool into a solid mass. Break into small pieces. Smoke. Intense rush should follow instantly. Serves 2,000.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Before long, Dominican dealers were out on the streets of Washington Heights peddling the new substance in pellet form at a few dollars a pop. (The name came from the crackling sound the drug made when smoked.) The ''champagne'' of drugs, once limited to the elite, was now available - somewhat diluted - to drifters and dropouts, welfare mothers and unemployed youths. Dealers set up shop across the street from schools, enticing teen-agers with free samples. They also offered two-for-one deals and ''Mother's Day'' specials timed to coincide with the arrival of welfare checks. Soon, customers were seeking out dealers rather than the other way around, helping establish Washington Heights as America's first major crack market.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: The Dominicans then began fanning southward into Harlem and eastward into the South Bronx. They also began supplying cocaine to other ethnic groups. In Harlem, in South Jamaica, Queens, in the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Bushwick and Brownsville, poor young blacks - jobless, uneducated and desperate - hungered for a piece of the ''crazy money'' crack offered. To get started, it took as little as an ounce of cocaine, an investment of perhaps $1,000.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Obtaining it was not much of a problem. By the mid-1980's, cocaine was arriving in New York by the ton. Importation was controlled by the Cali Cartel, Colombia's second-largest syndicate, after the Medellin Cartel. Desperate to unload their supplies, the Colombians found dependable customers in the Dominicans of Washington Heights. The two groups got along well, joined not only by a common language but also by similar entrepreneurial values. The Dominicans became New York's chief middlemen. As sales boomed to aspiring young dealers outside Washington Heights, the city was eventually carved up along ethnic lines, with Dominican-supplied blacks controlling Harlem, Queens and Brooklyn, and the Dominicans dominant in upper Manhattan and the South Bronx.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: FROM THE START, CRACK'S DISTRI-bution system distinguished it from all other drugs. Heroin, for instance, was highly centralized. From poppy cultivation to street sales, the trade was dominated by a single organization - the Mafia, which, though ruthless, imposed a certain order on the trade. Gang wars were rare, and police officers were never fired upon. Because distribution was so tightly controlled, it was possible, with diligent police work, to put an entire network out of business, as occurred in the French Connection case.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: With crack, there could be no French Connection. In effect, it took the(Continued on Page 58) ''organized'' out of organized crime. ''The unique thing about crack is that for a relatively small investment you can buy some cocaine, convert it to crack in the kitchen, and begin distributing almost immediately,'' says John Featherly, staff coordinator of the D.E.A.'s cocaine section in Washington. ''This makes for a lot of entrepreneurs.''
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: If heroin was the Fortune 500, crack was Mom and Pop. A typical crack organization would have no more than seven or eight people - a street seller or two, a steerer to direct customers, a guard to protect the merchandise, a police lookout, a weigher (known as a ''scale boy''), a manager and a ''Mr. Big'' to count the profits. Competition was intense. In busy areas like Washington Heights, one block might host four or five crews, all contending for the same consumer dollar.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: With no overall hierarchy or command structure to impose order, turf wars broke out over the most lucrative spots. Dealers regularly ripped off customers and stole from one another, leading to frequent shootouts, stabbings and executions. Crack created a new breed of urban guerrilla, members of a fierce, proliferating army that left the police badly outnumbered and outgunned.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: By late 1985, when crack first came to the attention of the national press, it was deeply entrenched in New York's poor neighborhoods. In the rest of the country, only two cities - Los Angeles and Miami - had comparable crack problems. All three cities were major distribution points for cocaine, so it was natural that crack would engulf them first. Soon, however, the drug began to move out from these gateway cities and into the heartland. It would travel via a fearsome new set of traffickers - illegal immigrants from Jamaica - who would quickly and radically transform the way crack was distributed around the country.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: DELROY EDWARDS GREW up poor in the tough, stifling shantytowns of Kingston, Jamaica. In 1980, at the age of 20, he went to work as a street enforcer for the Jamaica Labor Party of Edward Seaga. Seaga was locked in a bitter election duel with the People's National Party, headed by Michael Manley, and each side was forming armed gangs to intimidate the other. The gangs did their job only too well, killing 800 people by election day. After his victory, Seaga launched a crackdown, and many gang members, feeling the heat, headed for the United States. Among them was Delroy Edwards. Slipping into Brooklyn on a tourist visa, he eventually made his way into the marijuana business, selling nickel bags out of a neighborhood storefront.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: At the beginning of 1985, Edwards learned to make crack. Soon he was selling little else. He worked out of two ''flagship'' spots in Brooklyn - one, a two-story house, the other, an abandoned brownstone near a housing project. Enough poor blacks coughed up enough $5 bills to enable Edwards to buy a $150,000 home on Long Island - and to pay for it in cash.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: That wasn't enough for Edwards, who began looking to expand his business. Unfortunately, New York was already crowded with crack dealers; outside the city, however, lay plenty of virgin territory. In Washington, Baltimore and Philadelphia, for instance, crack was just beginning to catch on. Enterprising local dealers would travel to New York, buy a few ounces of cocaine, return home, convert it into crack, and sell the product for three or four times the New York street price. In the fall of 1986, Edwards traveled to Washington and set up shop; by the following spring his lieutenants had established thriving businesses in Philadelphia and Baltimore as well. At its peak, Edwards's organization, known as the Rankers, employed 50 workers and made up to $100,000 a day.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: The glory days did not last. Edwards - nicknamed ''Uzi'' for his taste in weapons -was pathologically violent. People who crossed him were pistol-whipped, beaten with baseball bats, shot in the legs. One 16-year-old worker, suspected of cheating, was beaten unconscious with bats, scalded with boiling water, and suspended by a chain from the ceiling until he died. Eventually, the police caught up with Edwards, and in July a Brooklyn jury convicted him on 42 counts of murder, assault, kidnapping and drug dealing. Edwards is now awaiting sentencing. The Rankers have disintegrated.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: But there are 40 other groups just like the Rankers, running crack out of New York and Miami to points across the country. Posses, they're called, after their members' affection for American westerns (and the guns used in them). Most, like the Rankers, took shape as gangs during the 1980 Jamaican election, then fled to the United States and regrouped. Here, their 10,000 to 20,000 members, organized in posses with as few as 25 members and as many as several hundred, keep incessantly on the move, slipping in and out of the many Jamaican communities scattered across the country. To maintain loyalty, each posse generally restricts membership to the residents of a particular neighborhood in Kingston. Posse members travel with fake IDs, making it tough for policemen to identify them. Sometimes, as a cover, they attach themselves to reggae groups touring the country. Today, Jamaicans are believed to control 35 percent to 40 percent of the nation's crack network.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: ''They're very good businessmen,'' says John A. O'Brien, an agent with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms (B.A.T.F.), the Federal agency that most closely monitors the posses. ''They follow the law of supply and demand. When they see that a vial of crack selling for $5 in New York will get $15 in Kansas City, they'll move in.'' New York is their ''training school,'' O'Brien says, ''like going to Wharton. They'll take a guy doing a good job in Harlem and send him to open an office in the Midwest.'' On his arrival in the new area, the posse sales rep will rent a motel room and conduct a market survey of sorts to determine the most lucrative spot in town. Then he'll rent an apartment or, better yet, get a single female to lend him one in return for crack.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: When asked how the posses move the drug from city to city, Bill McMullan, the assistant special agent in charge of the D.E.A.'s Washington office, jokingly cites the title of a recent movie: ''Planes, Trains and Automobiles.'' Amtrak, Greyhound, commercial airlines, Federal Express, U.P.S. - the posses use them all, regularly.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: To carry cocaine on commercial flights, the Jamaicans tend to recruit overweight women able to conceal one- or two-pound packages on their person. Also popular are rental cars, preferably Volvos, sent over the nation's highways, preferably Interstates. ''When I see some of the places the posses are operating, I can't find any other explanation than the presence of a nearby Interstate,'' says Stephen Higgins, the B.A.T.F.'s director in Washington.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: In deciding where to strike, the Jamaicans generally follow the path of least resistance. Cities with well-organized criminal groups, such as Newark, St. Louis and Chicago, tend to get bypassed. At first glance, Chicago would seem to be an ideal posse target. It is a major transportation hub, has a vast inner-city population and offers block upon block of public housing projects, a favorite crack target. But Chicago also has plenty of established homegrown gangs doing a brisk business in cocaine and heroin. Intent on protecting their trade, they have worked determinedly to keep outside traffickers from entering. ''When crack first appeared, some groups did try to come here and stake out some territory, but they quickly left,' '' says Vincent Lang, chairman of the Chicago Housing Authority. ''They wanted to remain alive.'' Today Chicago is awash in powder cocaine, but crack is very hard to find. Perhaps wary of the anarchic market forces crack has unleashed elsewhere, local dealers have opted out of selling it themselves.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: In other cities, dealers tend to be too weak and disorganized to stand up to the posses and their tactics. The Jamaicans are fanatics for weapons. Taking advantage of lax gun laws in Texas, Florida and Virginia, they have stockpiled Uzis and AR-13 assault rifles. When breaking into a new area, the Jamaicans come in with all barrels blazing. ''One cause of the violence we're seeing in many cities is Jamaican traffickers pushing out American blacks,'' says Jonny Frank, a prosecutor in the Delroy Edwards case.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: According to the B.A.T.F., the posses have been responsible for approximately 1,000 murders since 1985. Washington, Philadelphia, Dallas, Houston, Kansas City, Denver - all have suffered Jamaican invasions. In New York, the posses have succeeded in taking over much of Brooklyn and Harlem, establishing themselves as the city's second largest traffickers, after the Dominicans.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Many smaller cities have been hit, too. New York-based posses have set up a thriving operation in Hartford, shipping their merchandise there via bus and train. In New York State, the Jamaicans are moving crack up Interstate 87, hitting such tiny Hudson Valley towns as Newburgh, Kingston and Saratoga Springs. In West Virginia, the posses have established crack houses in Martinsburg (population 13,000) and Charles Town (3,000). From there they have moved out along Interstate 81, shipping crack as far north as Chambersburg, Pa., and as far south as Roanoke, Va.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Roanoke! It would be hard to imagine a more unlikely setting for crack. A town of only 90,000, Roanoke is nestled in the heart of Virginia's dairy and orchard country, several hours' drive from the nearest city. Yet members of the Shower posse, the largest in the country, have managed to find their way there from New York.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: On closer examination, though, the presence of crack in Roanoke is really not so surprising. Even towns with Norman Rockwell-like reputations have pockets of alienation and despair, open sores in which crack can take hold and fester. Roanoke has its own modest ghetto, beset by the same social ills afflicting larger cities. ''We have a sizable minority community, and that's where the Jamaicans set up,'' observes Tom Bondurant, an assistant United States attorney in Roanoke. Demand was obviously high: crack was selling for $25 to $30 a vial - more than enough to catch the attention of big-city traffickers.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Roanoke's case is typical. Across the country, crack has displayed remarkable consistency, taking root in those sectors of society least able to resist it. In places like Charles Town, Newburgh, and even Fort Wayne, Ind., crack has found a foothold among poor blacks and - to a far lesser degree - Hispanics.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Will it stay that way? Or will crack break out like some threatening contagion into the middle-class population, white and black? In some places, it already has. In Washington - the city with the nation's highest rate of drug-related violence -crack has leaped across the city lines into the middle-class suburbs of Maryland and Virginia. Until June 1988, for instance, crack was virtually unknown in Howard County, a tranquil, middle-class area midway between Washington and Baltimore; today the drug is being distributed in 20 locations, including some attractive town houses.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Dr. Mark F. Gold, the director of research at Fair Oaks Hospital in New Jersey and the founder of the national ''800-COCAINE Helpline,'' detects a subtle shift in the profile of America's crack users. Until recently, he says, virtually all of those calling in to seek help with crack were young inner-city residents, poor and unemployed. Today, they remain the most common users, but, Gold says, ''crack appears to be making some inroads into suburban and rural America. I now get many calls from the Sunbelt, whereas before I didn't.'' Gold, a member of William Bennett's kitchen cabinet, says that the nation has reached a ''turning point. Whether crack expands and changes the typical crack user or not, only time will tell.''
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: TodAY'S REALITY, meanwhile, is most visible in Kansas City, Mo. A year ago, the city was declaring victory in the war on crack. A Federal organized-crime task force had succeeded in dismantling a thriving crack operation run by the Waterhouse posse. Working out of a fortresslike house in the heart of the inner city, the Jamaicans had employed an estimated 1,000 people at one point. Demand was so great that the posse had had to import Jamaicans from New York and Miami. This proved to be its undoing. The new workers felt little loyalty to the group, and, when arrested, tended to talk, providing the task force with invaluable information. In late 1986, the Feds struck, raiding ghetto crack houses and rounding up dealers. Eventually, 178 traffickers were prosecuted and 25 more deported. By the start of 1987, no more than 75 posse members remained in town. Across the nation, Kansas City was hailed as a stunning success story.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: The sense of triumph was short-lived, however. ''A year ago, we were really feeling good about the successes we had had,'' says the first assistant United States attorney Rob Larsen, who directed the task force from 1983 to 1987. ''Then the L.A. gangs began arriving.''
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Los Angeles's black street gangs are the fastest-growing set of crack traffickers in the country. Already they have established a national network second only to that of the posses. They are grouped into confederations known as the Bloods and the Crips, each with its own color (blue for Crips, red for Bloods), slang and hand signals. Fiercely territorial, the gangs have traditionally concentrated on fighting one another over impoverished patches of south-central Los Angeles.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Crack has changed that. Sensing the enormous profit potential in the drug, the Bloods and the Crips are now paying less attention to one another and more to transporting crack. Today, more than 10,000 gang members are at work in some 50 cities from Seattle to Baltimore. Generally, they emulate the tactics of the posses, infiltrating black communities by working through local contacts. So far, the gangs and the posses have avoided fighting one another. In fact, they seem to be dividing up the country between them -the gangs working eastward from California, the posses westward from New York. The two national networks are gradually crisscrossing - with devastating consequences for towns caught in the middle.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Thus, in Kansas City, when the crackdown on the posses created a vacuum, the Bloods and Crips quickly filled it. Today, crack is just as plentiful in the city as it had been before the Waterhouse roundup. Meanwhile, the Waterhouse posse, routed from Kansas City, is beginning to resurface in Des Moines and Omaha -even across the river in Kansas City, Kan. ''It was a startling experience'' says Larsen. ''Nobody feels like we're making any substantial progress at all.'' Crack, he adds ruefully, ''is a very difficult thing for law enforcement to deal with.''
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Indeed, even if the posses and L.A. gangs were somehow tamed - an extremely unlikely prospect - there are plenty of other groups ready to take their place. Both Cubans and Guyanese have established fledgling interstate operations, while Haitian traffickers based in Fort Pierce, Fla., are transporting crack along the East Coast, via migrant farm workers. In Miami, Detroit and countless smaller cities across the country, local black rings are at work, looking intently for opportunities to expand.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Not everyone has lost hope. Robert M. Stutman, special agent in charge of the D.E.A.'s field office in New York, points to a natural selection process taking place in the crack trade, with smaller organizations gradually being absorbed by larger ones. ''The crack business is becoming more highly organized, more like heroin,'' says Stutman. In New York, he observes, ''crack is now controlled by a finite number of groups. That was not true two years ago.'' The effect, he says, is to provide law-enforcement officials with a ''more discernible target.''
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Stutman cites a Dominican organization in Washington Heights that, in three short years, went from being street-corner peddlers to becoming a multitier conglomerate selling more than 10,000 vials of crack a day. The group was so well organized that it marketed its crack under a brand name (''Based Balls''). Such practices eventually attracted the attention of the D.E.A., which, after an intensive investigation, put the group out of business.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Unfortunately, the D.E.A.'s efforts had little effect on the supply of crack in New York - the usual outcome of law-enforcement action aimed at the drug. No matter how determined the effort to root it out, crack seems always to thrive. That has been the experience in Kansas City. In Brooklyn, crack continues to sell for $3 a vial despite the prosecution of Delroy Edwards. In Washington, the police recently seized Rayful Edmond 3d, allegedly the city's largest dealer, but crack remains available in 120 locations throughout town. ''Right after we locked up Edmond, the homicide rate slowed down for a while,'' says Collin Younger, commander of the narcotics branch of the D.C. police. ''Now it's beginning to pick up again as other dealers fight over his territory.'' Crack is getting so plentiful in the District of Columbia that Younger expects the price to drop any day now.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: As if crack weren't enough to contend with, a new drug has recently appeared on the horizon. Called ice, it is a smokable version of methamphetamine, or speed. It creates a high that lasts for up to 24 hours, compared with crack's 20-minute high, followed by a ''crash'' so severe that it can resemble paranoid schizophrenia.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: President Bush's anti-drug strategy, unveiled on Sept. 5, calls for a heavy reliance on police and prosecutors. Fully 70 percent of its projected $7.9 billion spending will go for law enforcement, including $1.6 billion for new prisons and $3.1 billion for state and local police. The remaining 30 percent will go toward treatment, prevention and education.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Judging from the record of the police to date, though, the Bush plan seems unlikely to make any real dent in the amount of crack on the streets. A sense of resignation is settling over America's drug agents. More and more of them are beginning to sound like Francis Hall. For four years, until his retirement in March, Hall served as commanding officer of the New York Police Department's narcotics division, making him, in effect, New York's top narc. Hall helped design the Tactical Narcotics Teams (T.N.T.) -the special police units that carry out sweeps through drug-infested neighborhoods - that today are the city's principal weapon in the fight against drugs.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: Looking back over his four years on the front lines, Hall compares the war on crack to another conflict. ''Drug enforcement,'' he says, ''is like the Vietnam War. In Vietnam, we underestimated the number of Vietcong and their will to fight. We appear to be doing the same thing with street-level drug traffickers.'' Noting that the staff of the narcotics division has increased from 525 in 1985 to 2,000 today, Hall observes, ''It's like Westmoreland asking Washington for two more divisions. We lost the Vietnam War with a half-million men. We're doing the same thing with drugs.''
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: The Vietnam analogy might be taken a step further. The Vietcong grew largely because of the social, political and economic breakdown engulfing Vietnam. No matter how much firepower the United States expended, the guerrillas always managed to regroup, nurtured by the poverty and injustice around them. Much the same is true of crack in America. No matter how many sweeps, raids and busts our police departments mount against crack traffickers, they always manage to resurface. Only when we address the conditions that have given rise to crack - the desperation of our inner cities - will we begin to see the light at the end of the tunnel.
title: CRACK'S DESTRUCTIVE SPRINT ACROSS AMERICA

text: By John H. Cushman Jr., Special To the New York Times
title: At Least 3 Are Killed in Amtrak Crash

text: An Amtrak passenger train bound from New York to New Orleans struck a fire truck and derailed tonight near Warrenton, Va., killing three firemen and injuring scores of people, the authorities said.
title: At Least 3 Are Killed in Amtrak Crash

text: Officials from the railroad and the National Transportation Safety Board said that Amtrak's Crescent, with two locomotives and 16 cars, was carrying 379 passengers and a crew of 20.
title: At Least 3 Are Killed in Amtrak Crash

text: Both locomotives and 11 of the cars derailed, according to preliminary information reaching the safety board, which dispatched a team of investigators from Washington. The train left Washington at about 6:30 P.M., and the crash occurred shortly before 8 P.M. between Catlett and Calverton, Va., about 40 miles southwest of Washington. #50 or More Injured Early estimates put the number injured at 50 and probably far more. Two firefighters died at the scene and a third died later at a hospital, The Associated Press quoted an official of the Fauquier County Sheriff's Department as saying.
title: At Least 3 Are Killed in Amtrak Crash

text: The injured were being evacuated, some by helicopter, to hospitals at Warrenton, Manassas, and Culpeper, Va.
title: At Least 3 Are Killed in Amtrak Crash

text: Hospital officials in Manassas and Warrenton said late tonight that most of the injuries were minor, although the A.P. said the two other firefighters on the truck and two train passengers were listed in critical condition in area hospitals. Crossing a Private Road
title: At Least 3 Are Killed in Amtrak Crash

text: The Warrenton hospital said 13 people had been admitted before 11 P.M. and that another busload with as many as 30 people was expected. Ambulances took 29 people to the Prince William County Hospital in Manassas.
title: At Least 3 Are Killed in Amtrak Crash

text: Sue Martin, a spokeswoman for Amtrak, said the fire truck was crossing the track on a private road where there was no signal or protective barrier to block a vehicle. Such crossings are usually marked with only a sign, and drivers are supposed to stop before crossing. Actual Speed Unknown
title: At Least 3 Are Killed in Amtrak Crash

text: The train's authorized speed at that point was 79 miles an hour, Ms. Martin said. She said she did not know its actual speed at the time of the accident. A passenger was quoted by the A.P. as saying the train was moving slowly when the crash occurred.
title: At Least 3 Are Killed in Amtrak Crash

text: Amtrak said it would provide lodging in the area to passengers, return them to their point of origin or provide alternative transportation to their destination.
title: At Least 3 Are Killed in Amtrak Crash

text: The train was carrying a number of Washington Redskins football fans to New Orleans, where the Redskins are scheduled to play the Saints this weekend. Many Washington fans travel out of town to see the team play because the home games are always sold out.
title: At Least 3 Are Killed in Amtrak Crash

text: The most serious Amtrak accident in history was the wreck near Chase, Md., in which 16 people died and 175 were injured when three linked Conrail engines drove through a closed switch and into the path of a high-speed Amtrak train. Crew members of the Conrail train were determined to have been smoking marijuana before the accident.
title: At Least 3 Are Killed in Amtrak Crash

text: There have been other serious train accidents this year, including two derailments in April 1989. One involved a truck driver who ignored a signal gate and caused a derailment that injured 58 people, and another involved the derailment in Virginia of an Amtrak train from Miami to New York in which about 20 were hurt.
title: At Least 3 Are Killed in Amtrak Crash

text: Chris Antley, acknowledging a recurrence of his drug-abuse problems, has voluntarily surrendered his jockey license to the State Racing and Wagering Board and has pledged to seek further professional treatment for his cocaine use.
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: The board could have revoked Antley's license. The 23-year-old jockey failed two drug tests last year, and returned to riding last January after undergoing a 30-day drug-rehabilitation program with the knowledge that a relapse might result in his being barred from the sport.
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: But the board, citing Antley's acknowledgment of his problem, instead decided to leave open the possibility that he might return to riding someday. Officials React Similarly
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: ''We believe this is a very difficult time for Chris Antley,'' Richard F. Corbisiero, the board chairman, said yesterday, ''and we believe he has acted in a responsible manner to address his problem.''
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: ''This seems to be a fair arrangement that should make everyone happy,'' said Dr. Manuel A. Gilman, one of the track stewards. ''He wants to straighten himself out, and now he has to.''
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: ''They're doing the right thing,'' said John Giovanni, president of the Jockeys' Guild, a national organization that works for the welfare of riders. ''He needs help, and everyone is trying to get it for him. Now, it's all up to him.''
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: Several officials said privately yesterday that they did not expect Antley to apply for reinstatement until next spring at the earliest. Absent Since Aug. 18
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: Antley, who has not ridden in a race since suffering a knee injury in a spill at Saratoga Race Track on Aug. 18, has declined to make any public comment since Saturday.
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: From the accounts of several racing officials and some of Antley's friends, who were interviewed about the situation in recent days on the condition that they not be identified, Antley's difficulties have had little to do with racing.
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: There has been no suggestion that Antley ever rode while under the influence of drugs, and this year had been his most successful. Apparently, Antley's greatest enemy had been free time away from the track.
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: Antley, who is from South Carolina, has admitted to having dabbled with drugs since at least 1985. He first tested positive, for marijuana use, in February 1988.
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: His serious use of cocaine apparently began after he suffered a severe concussion in a spill at Belmont on May 30, 1988. Antley was sidelined for several weeks, and two sources said friends began bringing him cocaine in the hospital while he was still being treated for head injuries. Aqueduct to Tokyo
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: Antley's cocaine use, they say, intensified last year, and he managed to escape detection until Nov. 24. He left to ride in the Japan Cup in Tokyo two days after taking a test at Aqueduct he was sure he had flunked, and when he returned he was told he had been suspended indefinitely.
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: Antley underwent a 28-day inpatient program at the Smithers Alcoholism and Drug Abuse Center in Manhattan under the care of Dr. Allan Lans, the psychiatrist whom the Mets employed this season as a counselor.
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: Antley emerged saying he was finished with drugs, and returned to riding with a new passion. He was the leading jockey at Aqueduct's winter and spring meetings, and rode at least one winner on 64 consecutive Aqueduct cards on which he had a mount.
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: Antley discussed his drug use and rehabilitation freely, but his initial ebullience seemed to fade. One day last spring, as an interviewer approached him to ask about his drug problems, Antley snapped, ''Is that all anyone wants to talk about?''
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: He delayed a suspension for rough riding last April to continue his Aqueduct streak, then took his suspension days in June. Friends said he spent most of that week in Atlantic City, where they say he may have been reintroduced to cocaine. Recovery Period Grew
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: After his spill at Saratoga, Antley underwent arthroscopic surgery on his knee, which did not heal as quickly as expected. As his time off grew to a month, friends said, he apparently drifted back into drugs.
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: Antley took and passed a drug test 10 days ago, and was scheduled to return to riding last Saturday. On Friday afternoon, his agent, Drew Mollica, said in a casual conversation with a reporter: ''Chris is coming back great and he'll be fine if he keeps his nose clean. No pun intended.''
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: But less than 24 hours later, after visiting Antley's home Friday night, Mollica called the Belmont stewards Saturday morning and told them Antley should be removed from his mounts because he was not fit to ride. Mollica, who had been Antley's business agent and best friend for five years, also announced that he was severing his relationship with the rider.
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: ''This has been excruciatingly hard for me to do,'' Mollica said three days later. ''You get to a point with someone where they're like family, but then you have to say, 'Enough.' There's only so much you can do for someone. Then it's up to him what he wants to do with his life. People in his situation may need to bottom out before they can really make some progress.'' Refused Another Test
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: The board demanded Saturday that Antley take another drug test, and the rider refused, but then met with board officials Monday. He acknowledged he had used drugs again, and agreed to enter a long-term rehabilitation program.
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: Antley also signed a sworn statement saying he would not attempt to ride anywhere else until the board ''acts on my application, if any, for relicensing or reinstatement in New York.'' Other riders with drug problems in the past have obtained temporary licenses from other state commissions.
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: Mollica is scouting for another rider, and none of Antley's friends are able to say confidently that he will return.
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: ''He had his chance and blew it,'' said one. ''At least he wants another one. I hope that's a good sign.''
title: Antley Surrenders His Jockey License

text: The President of Guatemala appealed to the United States today to use the aid it is giving the Nicaraguan rebels in Honduras to speed up their return and resettlement in Nicaragua.
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: In an interview, the Guatemalan leader, Vinicio Cerezo, said he spoke for all the Central American Presidents when he warned that if the United States fails to encourage their rapid return to Nicaragua, the rebels, known as contras, may remain indefinitely in Honduras and become ''a destabilizing element'' in Central America.
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: ''If we do not get them to go home soon they will become a very dangerous problem for the rest of Central America,'' he said. Agreement in Honduras Recalled
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: In an address to the General Assembly today, Mr. Cerezo recalled that the five Central American Presidents are committed to speeding the return of the contras under the terms of the agreement they reached in Tela, Honduras, last month.
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: ''We are committed to carrying out this plan and we call for international help and humanitarian assistance in doing so,'' he said.
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: Earlier this year Congress voted $49 million for aid for the contras, who have been fighting the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua. These funds must be spent by next February, when Nicaragua is scheduled to hold free elections under United Nations supervision. The aid includes items like food and uniforms, but no weapons or ammunition.
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: So far all this money has gone toward assisting the contras in their camps in Honduras. But under an agreement with the Congressional leadership, the Bush Administration has promised not to spend any more money on the contras after Nov. 30 without consulting Congress. Remaining U.S. Aid
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: United Nations and Congresional officials following the Central American peace process say this gives Congress a chance to insist that the $10 million to $15 million in aid that will be left unspent at the end of November is used to encourage the contras to return home as President Cerezo wants, rather than on maintaining them in Honduras.
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: The money could be spent providing housing for the returning rebels, they say, or used to finance agricultural development projects which would provide them with a livlihood after they go home.
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: President Cerezo warned that if the contras are not encouraged to return home now, they may remain in Honduras indefinitely.
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: He said that if President Daniel Ortega Saavedra wins a fair election in Nicaragua next year, he will have little incentive to encourage such opponents of his Government to return since the United States Congress is no longer willing to finance their attempts to overthrow his Government by force. A Refuge for Contras
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: Guatamala would be prepared to give permanent homes to a few of them, President Cerezo said. But he said that many would probably press the United States to accept them as refugees since it financed their rebellion against the Sandinista Government.
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: President Cerezo did not criticize the Bush Administration's current policy toward the contras. But some Congressional officials involved in the Central American peace process say the Administration appears in no hurry to see the contra forces disbanded.
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: Under the current Central American peace plan approved by the five regional Presidents, the United Nations is supposed to help disarm the contra rebels and assist their return to Nicaragua. In addition the United Nations is to send a separate peacekeeping force to the region to oversee the Central American peace plan. In another speech to the General Assembly today, the President of Paraguay, Gen. Andres Rodriguez, commended Colombia on its fight against drugs and said his country shared President Bush's commitment to combat drug trafficking and production. 'Infamous Trade' in Drugs
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: ''We stand unconditionally by Colombia and other nations to condemn, with all the strength at our command, the infamous trade in narcotics,'' General Rodriguez said. ''We share, with optimism and sympathy, President Bush's firm decision to lead the fight on drugs on a world scale.''
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: The issue of drugs is a particularly delicate one for General Rodriguez. In the 1970's, he was suspected of providing protection to Joseph August Ricord, a member of the so-called French Connection, which used Paraguay to transport heroin between Europe and the United States. General Rodriguez said today that his country had recently destroyed marijuana fields with the help of United States aircraft.
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: General Rodriguez, whose coup ended the dictatorship of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner last February, said his country was following ''a new framework for democracy,'' with free elections and freedom of the press.
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: Citing Paraguay's foreign debt and landlocked location, General Rodriguez called on industrial countries ''to strengthen the structures of production and finance in the developing economies.'' Foreign Investment Welcomed
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: ''Generalized poverty will not bring legitimate prosperity to anyone on earth,'' he said. ''Our nation opens its doors to productive investments by foreign enterprises.''
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: In other speeches, two neutral countries that traditionally send troops for United Nations peacekeeping operations complained that other United Nations members are not paying their fair share of the bill.
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: The Swedish Foreign Minister, Sten Andersson, and the Finnish Foreign Minister, Pertti Paasio, both said member countries should pay in full and on time.
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: Other speakers who addressed the Assembly today were Togo's Minister of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation, Yaovi Adodo; Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, Joe Clark, and Botswana's Minister for External Affairs, Gaositwe K. T. Chiepe. Statements were also delivered by Foreign Ministers Diego Cordovez of Ecuador and Gianni de Michelis of Italy.
title: Speed Contra Resettlement, Guatemalan Urges the U.S.

text: A 15-year-old boy has been sentenced to six years in the Rhode Island Training School after pleading guilty to killing four neighbors, three of them over the Labor Day weekend, the other in 1987, when he was 13.
title: BOY GETS 6 YEARS FOR SLAYINGS OF 4

text: The sentence was the maximum the law allows.
title: BOY GETS 6 YEARS FOR SLAYINGS OF 4

text: The victims were a mother and her two young daughters, slain over the Labor Day weekend, and a woman who lived two doors away and was killed two years ago.
title: BOY GETS 6 YEARS FOR SLAYINGS OF 4

text: Before he was removed from court Thursday after pleading guilty, the boy, Craig Price, told his friends outside the Kent County Courthouse: ''Later - when I get out I'm going to smoke a bomber,'' apparently a reference to marijuana.
title: BOY GETS 6 YEARS FOR SLAYINGS OF 4

text: He was arrested two weeks after the Sept. 1 slayings and pleaded guilty four days later. Some people here say they are not convinced that the punishment that will allow him to be freed when he is 21 is sufficient. 'Iron Man' Had a Record
title: BOY GETS 6 YEARS FOR SLAYINGS OF 4

text: ''Iron Man,'' as the 240-pound boy, a football player, was known at school, had a history of trouble with the law. He had been placed on probation for assaulting his sister two days before the killings and was put on probation last fall for burglary.
title: BOY GETS 6 YEARS FOR SLAYINGS OF 4

text: The Rhode Island Attorney General, James E. O'Neil, who unsuccessfully sought legislation to have juveniles under 16 tried on capital charges as if they were adults, expressed frustration that the sentence was the maximum allowed. ''It's a crying shame that it takes a tragedy to wake a community up,'' Mr. O'Neil said.
title: BOY GETS 6 YEARS FOR SLAYINGS OF 4

text: Police Capt. Ronald Carter said the defendant told investigators he broke into a home two blocks from his own on Sept. 1 to steal whatever he could and killed three people because he was afraid they would identify him. Violence Stirs Suspicion
title: BOY GETS 6 YEARS FOR SLAYINGS OF 4

text: The victims, Joan Heaton, 39, and her two daughters, Jennifer, 10, and Melissa, 8, had been beaten and stabbed. Several of Ms. Heaton's ribs were broken. Melissa's skull was fractured.
title: BOY GETS 6 YEARS FOR SLAYINGS OF 4

text: Captain Carter said the extreme violence led police to suspect youth in the killing of Rebecca A. Spencer, 27, who was stabbed 58 times the night before she was to move out of the neighborhood two years ago.
title: BOY GETS 6 YEARS FOR SLAYINGS OF 4

text: Investigators said the youth, who was repeating the ninth grade, has never showed remorse for what he did.
title: BOY GETS 6 YEARS FOR SLAYINGS OF 4

text: Drug-related criminal cases in the Federal courts have increased to the point where they are squeezing out many civil cases, according to the head of the office that runs the Federal court system.
title: Surging Criminal Cases Jam Federal Court System

text: That agency, the Administrative Office of the United States Courts, issued a report this week showing that the number of drug cases filed in Federal district courts jumped 270 percent in the nine years ended last June.
title: Surging Criminal Cases Jam Federal Court System

text: In 1988 and again this year, the number of drug cases increased more than 15 percent, while other criminal cases declined. For purposes of the report, a year was considered the 12 months ended each June 30. Echoed in the Appellate Courts
title: Surging Criminal Cases Jam Federal Court System

text: Similiar trends have developed in the Federal appeals courts. In 1989, there were 4,386 appeals in Federal drug cases, accounting for nearly 55 percent of all Federal criminal appeals. In 1987, there were 2,254 appeals related to drugs, and they accounted for 43 percent of all criminal appeals.
title: Surging Criminal Cases Jam Federal Court System

text: ''Additional drug use and additional prosecutors put a tremendous squeeze on the Federal court system,'' L. Ralph Mecham, director of the administrative office, said in an interview. ''Too often, the people who put together these drug programs and initiatives forget that the courts are affected by them.''
title: Surging Criminal Cases Jam Federal Court System

text: Because of the heavy load of criminal drug cases, Mr. Mecham said, ''Civil litigants are in effect discriminated against.'' Civil Cases Are Down Again
title: Surging Criminal Cases Jam Federal Court System

text: The researchers reported that the number of civil cases in the district courts fell in 1989 for the third time in the last four years. The report did not say why the heavy load of drug cases should necessarily have affected the number of civil suits, but Mr. Mecham speculated that many potential plaintiffs had become so discouraged by court backlogs that they turned to arbitration or some other nonjudicial resolution of civil disputes.
title: Surging Criminal Cases Jam Federal Court System

text: The drug problem has also burdened the Federal probation offices, which provide treatment for drug-dependent offenders, the report said. This year, 12,806 drug-dependent people were enrolled in probation treatment programs, as against 5,583 in 1984. Emphasis on Hard Narcotics
title: Surging Criminal Cases Jam Federal Court System

text: Over all, the report said, there were 45,995 criminal case filings in the Federal district courts this year, an increase of only 3 percent over 1988.
title: Surging Criminal Cases Jam Federal Court System

text: But filings involving only hard narcotics like heroin and cocaine rose by more than 18 percent, while marijuana-related cases increased about 9 percent.
title: Surging Criminal Cases Jam Federal Court System

text: The report was presented to the Judicial Conference of the United States, a policymaking body of the Federal courts.
title: Surging Criminal Cases Jam Federal Court System

text: The Queens District Attorney announced yesterday that evidence on last week's fatal crash of a USAir jetliner at La Guardia Airport would be presented soon to a grand jury, raising the possibility of criminal charges against the cockpit crew.
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: ''The fact that we're going to a grand jury is not to indicate we believe somebody is guilty of a crime,'' said the District Attorney, John J. Santucci, who called the panel ''investigatory'' and said his office's primary aim was to answer a host of questions about the crash and the conduct of the pilots and not necessarily indict them.
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: But other law-enforcement officials said the case could lead to charges of negligent homicide or reckless endangerment against the pilots, Capt. Michael W. Martin and First Officer Constantine Kleissas. Two passengers on the flight died when the captain aborted the takeoff and the jetliner plunged into the East River Wednesday night. No Evidence of Drug Use
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: In another development, the authorities said a laboratory analysis of urine samples provided by the pilot and co-pilot 48 hours after the crash showed no traces of 11 illicit drugs, including cocaine, opiates like heroin, marijuana, amphetamines, barbiturates and methaqualone. No alcohol test was performed, because the body dissipates alcohol too rapidly for such a test to have been meaningful 48 hours later.
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: There were no major developments yesterday in the Federal inquiry into the cause of the crash. Investigators continued to examine the wreckage of the plane, which had been removed from the river and placed in an American Airlines hangar at La Guardia, for clues to explain why the plane had veered to the left and apparently developed a vibration on the runway.
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: Federal investigators have criticized the relatively inexperienced cockpit crew for failing to follow certain procedures as the aircraft took off and for not making themselves available for 36 hours after the crash for interviews and drug and alcohol tests.
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: The pilots' union, the Air Line Pilots Association, noted that no Federal regulations required pilots to submit to drug tests or immediate interviews after an accident. It said the USAir pilots had been following the union's advice in obtaining counsel before appearing before investigators. Pilots' Actions Defended
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: Frederick P. Hafetz, a lawyer hired by the two pilots after the crash, said of Mr. Santucci's announcement:
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: ''Based on everything I know, there is absolutely no basis for any criminal charge against them. There was no wrongdoing by them. I believe they exercised appropriate care in a very difficult situation, and indeed their actions may well have averted the loss additional lives.''
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: The results of the drug tests, Mr. Hafetz said, ''come as no surprise - we had fully anticipated they would be negative, and indeed people's observations of the pilots on the night of the flight was totally consistent with their being in full control of themselves.''
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: John Mazor, a spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association, which has deplored a criminal inquiry against the pilots, declined to comment yesterday on prospective action by the grand jury, but he said, ''We're not aware of any commercial airline accident in this country where criminal charges were brought against a pilot.'' Prosecutors Are Pressured
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: Criminal investigations of the causes of transporation accidents are still rare, but in recent years local prosecutors have felt public pressure to answer more questions than are typically addressed by Federal safety investigators.
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: For example, major train wrecks -also under the jurisdiction of the National Transportation Safety Board -have produced indictments like that against Ricky L. Gates, the engineer of a Conrail locomotive that hit a passenger train and killed 16 people on Jan. 4, 1987. He was charged with 16 counts of manslaughter in Baltimore.
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: Mr. Santucci, in announcing the grand jury inquiry, declined to cite possible charges or even to say the pilots were targets of the investigation. He said evidence would be presented within two weeks on the aborted takeoff and what happened before and after the crash. An aide said the pilot and co-pilot would almost certainly be called to testify.
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: Earlier aides to Mr. Santucci and representatives of the National Transportation Safety Board met to discuss a number of issues that had arisen between local and Federal investigators looking into the crash.
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: Over the weekend there had been reports of bitter squabbling over who could have access to the wreckage and the crash scene, who had primary jurisdiction in the case and whether the local criminal inquiry and the Federal safety investigation were interfering with each other. Dispute Among Officials
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: Local officials - including investigators from Mr. Santucci's office, the New York City Police and the police of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the agency that operates La Guardia Airport - contended that Federal investigators cared only about the cause of the crash and were ignoring possible criminal conduct and relying on unsworn statements by pilots and others who might have something to hide.
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: Federal officials, on the other hand, argued that the local criminal investigation might force the pilots to retreat into silence, making it harder to determine what happened. They also complained that local investigators had threatened to limit their access to the crash site and wreckage.
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: On Sunday, Federal officials said the District Attorney's office had declared the crash site a ''crime scene'' and had said the pilots' association, as representatives of a cockpit crew that had come under suspicion, would be denied access to the wreckage. Since union members are a part of the safety board inquiry, the jurisdiction of the board itself appeared to be threatened.
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: But yesterday, after a meeting in Mr. Santucci's office, Richard Piperno, a spokesman for the District Attorney, said that the crash site had not been declared a crime scene and that no legitimate representative of the safety board would be denied access to evidence.
title: Grand Jury Inquiry Due in USAir Crash

text: Motorists who are stopped for erratic driving have long faced tests to detect alcohol. Now, more and more, they are being tested for drugs as well.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: In a half-dozen states, police officers are being trained to identify drug-impaired drivers.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: The technique, which combines physical and toxicological tests, was largely developed by Sgt. Richard C. Studdard of the Los Angeles police and is now being used in parts of New York, Texas, Virginia, Indiana, Arizona, Illinois, Colorado and Utah.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: Police officers in New York City are among those being trained to administer the tests. Since July, about 26 of them have been schooled in Sergeant Studdard's method and some are expected to undergo added training as instructors, starting Oct. 2.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: The new tests are being introduced as concern grows that America's drug problem, be it from illicit substances or ill-used legal substances, is affecting the roadways. ''When you have 160 million drivers out there and drug use is rampant, a lot of drivers are going to be using drugs,'' said Jeffery Miller, assistant administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in Washington.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: Officials are enthusiastic about the new tests, which are given at a station house by officers who check the offender's vital signs, how eyes react to light and other behavior.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: The technique appears generally reliable. In a 1985 study financed by the highway safety administration, Los Angeles police officers were able to tell that a driver had used a specific drug about 78 percent of the time.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: The authorities in Los Angeles said the method was so so successful that it is being taught to narcotics detectives and others not in traffic work.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: But the issue of testing drivers for drugs is fraught with complications. Unlike alcohol, scientists say, little is known about the levels at which various drugs affect driving. While many states bar driving under the influence of illegal or controlled substances, other states' laws include over-the-counter medications and herbal medicines. There is no agreement among states on whether drivers have to submit to testing.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: The specter of police officers acting as medical experts poses scientific and legal problems. One test has previously come under attack in the courts. Law-enforcement officials say they are moving slowly on adopting the overall procedure to demonstrate to judges that it should be accepted.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: ''Right now we don't have any case law on the technique,'' said Deputy Inspector James F. Garside of the Nassau County, L.I., police. Last year, Nassau pioneered in training officers in drug recognition. In 1988, about 150 drug-impaired drivers were arrested, a threefold increase over 1987.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: Nationwide, experts say they can only guess at the number of drug-impaired drivers. From limited research, the Federal highway safety authorities estimate that 10 to 20 percent of drivers in accidents may have used drugs, often in combination with alcohol. By comparison, it is estimated that alcohol is involved in about half of all highway fatalites.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: One survey, however, suggests a much higher rate of drug use. That study, conducted on car accident victims last year at the University of Tennessee Medical Center in Knoxville, found that 4 out of 10 injured drivers had traces of marijuana, barbiturates, cocaine or some other drug in their bodies. Many had also used alcohol. Impairment by Prescriptions
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: ''We were rather shocked,'' said Dr. Kimball I. Maull, chairman of the university's department of surgery. ''This data is not coming from the inner city. This is Middle America.'' Although the precise role of drugs in accidents is still undetermined, a growing body of research indicates that a number of prescription drugs and illegal drugs impair driving skills. A recent report by the highway safety administration said the most serious hazards are marijuana, sedatives, barbiturates and tranquilizers known as benzodiazepines that include the popular drug Valium. A number of over-the-counter drugs like antihistamines can also affect driving.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: After a suspected drunken driver is pulled off the road, the characteristics of drunkenness are often clear: slurred speech and scented breath. But the vast array of available drugs produce various and subtle symptoms. Without any handy tests available to detect drug impairment, police officers have typically been loath to make drugged-driving arrests and prosecuters reluctant to pursue them, several experts said. When Los Angeles Took the Step
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: That is the situation Sergeant Studdard said he found in 1971 when he was appointed head of his police department's ''driving under the influence'' team. ''No one could even tell me how drugs affected driving,'' he recalled.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: As a result, he developed a number of tests to detect both drug-impaired and alcohol-impaired drivers that were adopted by the department. The driver is typically taken to a station house, where a trained officer does the testing.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: The procedure works like this: After a driver is asked if he or she uses alcohol, or drugs, vital signs like blood pressure and pulse are measured. The suspect is tested for physical balance and visual perception.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: The eyes are examined for pupil size, reaction to light and an involuntary jerking of the eyeball, or nystagmus, as it follows an object moving in front of the suspect.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: Sergeant Studdard said different classes of drugs produced their own ''fingerprint,'' or battery of symptoms: Depressants will slow eyeball jerking, but do not dramatically change pupil reaction. On the other hand, narcotics like heroin constrict the pupil and slow down vital signs but do not cause nystagmus. Blood or Urine Sampling
