title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: Those tests may form the basis for a police officer to assume that he has probable cause to demand a urine or blood sample from a driver. That sample, if positive in laboratory tests, can then be used as legal evidence, much in the same way as results from alcohol testing devices.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: Impressed by the accuracy of the tests in the 1985 study, the Federal Highway Safety Administration provided money to start training other police departments in the method.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: New York City is one such area. Inspector James Mills, who heads the New York Police Department's Traffic Division, said city officials decided to get involved after studies showed that drug use was prevalent among those killed in traffic accidents.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: Inspector Mills said the city hoped to have 150 officers trained in two years. He said some would be used at roadway checkpoints.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: In New York State, the penalties for drug- and alcohol-impaired driving are the same. The first conviction is a misdemeanor bringing a mandatory fine of $350 to $500 and revocation of a license for at least six months. A jail sentence of up to one year may also be imposed. Penalty for Those Who Balk
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: In states like New York, drivers who refuse to provide blood and urine samples to the police for drug tests face the loss of the license for six months.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: Inspector Mills and other law-enforcement officials interviewed for this article said they were seeking to incorporate drug-screening techniques into police procedures gradually because of likely legal challenge. ''You don't flood the courts with a hundred cases,'' the inspector said, ''because if you lose two or three of them you might find the whole concept challenged.''
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: Indeed, one test in the Studdard method, for the jerking of the eyeballs, has faced criticism from defense lawyers in drunken-driving cases. In several states, the lawyers have questioned either the validity of the test as a measure of intoxication or the expertise of the police officers adminstering it. Arizona, Ohio, Colorado and New Hampshire have accepted nystagmus as valid in drunken driving cases. Most states have not ruled on it. The Perceived Danger Area
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: Some defense lawyers say the potential weak point is the police officer acting as medical expert. ''The big problem will getting a judge to accept a medical opinion from a cop,'' said Peter Gerstenzang, a lawyer based in Albany who specializes in driving-while-intoxicated cases and is consulting with New York City prosecutors on the drugged-driving issue.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: Cliff Vanell, an Assistant City Prosecutor in Phoenix, said that he had brought only a few drugged-driving cases to court and had not encountered problems. He also said he expected that Sergeant Studdard's technique would face a legal challenge eventually. ''We're surprised that it hasn't happened already, and we'd be happy if it did,'' Mr. Vanell said.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: Some states are still sorting out which drugs to include in impaired-driving laws. California includes any impairing drug, legal, prescription, over-the-counter or illegal. The laws in New York and some other states apply only to controlled substances or specifically named illicit compounds.
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: A report last June by the New York State Legislative Commission on Critical Transportation Choices recommended that the state law include any substance that could affect the ability of a motorist to drive safely. ''When you run over the boy in the crosswalk,'' said Mr. Vanell,''no one is going to care whether you were high on antihistamines or crack.''
title: New Test for a Highway Peril, the Drugged Driver

text: LAST THINGS. By Madison Jones. (Louisiana State University, $17.95.) Finishing Madison Jones's eighth novel is like waking up from someone else's nightmare - or maybe being released from someone else's paranoid fantasy. That's because, although the fears that materialize in ''Last Things'' may not be anything like the reader's own, they still have a scary, spiky grip. As ''Last Things'' begins, Wendell Corbin has returned, against his better judgment, to his birthplace in the Deep South, the ironically named Bliss County. Here he intends to take up graduate studies with Leonard T. Rathbone, who, like Wendell, is a zonked-out fan of both William Blake and marijuana. But as quick as you can say cannabis, Wendell, who had done some dealing in his undergraduate days, is set up in a drug sale and given the chance, as a condition of his release by the corrupt arresting officers, to become a soldier in the illegal drug-running operation of a local businessman, Jason Farrow. Wendell's assignments include getting rid of a busybody who happens to have guessed what Farrow is up to and is also, conveniently enough, the hateful mother-in-law of Tricia Harker, a Nietzsche-obsessed woman that Wendell has taken up with. Wendell's uneasiness over his illicit activities eventually prevails, and he blows the whistle on the chicanery - but without producing quite the results he had intended. Although ''Last Things'' ends as an exploration of what can happen when middle-class morality is flouted, it begins as if it's going to be another satire of academia. But although there's a shift of gears midway, going from first to second certainly gives ''Last Things'' a surge of giddy power.
title: FICTION

text: Your Economic Watch article on the high hidden costs of the war on marijuana (Sept. 5) is informative, but like much reporting on the topic, lacks historical perspective. This is most prominent in the discussion of legalization.
title: It's Time to Repeal Marijuana Prohibition

text: ''Legal marijuana,'' it is stated, ''could be a major source of tax revenue rather than a $14 billion business for criminals and a billion-dollar cost to the Treasury. But there is little support for such a radical experiment; it is generally agreed that more people would smoke marijuana if it were legal, just as more people began drinking alcohol with the end of Prohibition in 1933.''
title: It's Time to Repeal Marijuana Prohibition

text: This paragraph perpetuates the popular misconception that marijuana has been illegal since the beginning of time. Of course, it has not, nor has any drug; indeed, it is the prohibition of marijuana that is, as the prohibition of alcohol was before repeal, an experiment - and to judge from ''Marijuana: Costs of Abuse, Costs of Control,'' the Michael Kleiman report that occasioned your article, and from the collective experience of those charged with enforcing this prohibition, a failed experiment. The same can be said for the criminalization of all recreational drugs.
title: It's Time to Repeal Marijuana Prohibition

text: Also, this paragraph ignores that in recent years, with the public recognition of the health hazards inherent in the consumption of alcohol, and resulting from better public education about these hazards, per capita consumption of all alcohol has declined significantly, with a steeper decline in the category of distilled spirits, which have the highest concentration of alcohol and carry the highest risk. This, despite the constant advertising of these spirits on billboards, in public transportation and in every edition of The New York Times Magazine, among other places.
title: It's Time to Repeal Marijuana Prohibition

text: In other words, an educated market, in the best American tradition, is choosing the safer drug over the more dangerous drug, just as it would were marijuana (and preferably the other recreational drugs as well) legalized, as they were before this failed prohibition began.
title: It's Time to Repeal Marijuana Prohibition

text: The public is beginning to recognize, despite the news media's (and legislators') easy dismissal of the facts, that drug-related crime is really drug-law-related crime, and that our experience with alcohol in the 1920's speaks to our experience with other recreational drugs in the 1980's and 90's. The only way to eliminate drug-law-related crimes is to eliminate the profit of the illicit trade that engenders those crimes.
title: It's Time to Repeal Marijuana Prohibition

text: The police state we are approaching now is no solution (witness the recent bill passed by the Senate that authorizes the Drug Enforcement Agency to shoot down suspected drug smugglers in aircraft, endangering every private pilot who operates near our borders); it is just a greater problem. We need to recognize that economical and sensible solutions exist, and we should concentrate on the best way to implement them, and stop wasting our time on our current futile wars. THOMAS BETZ Yonkers, Sept. 5, 1989
title: It's Time to Repeal Marijuana Prohibition

text: IN THE >CRACKDOWN on >crack and other drugs, there may be no >magic bullet, but >drug kingpins, narco-terrorists and even >casual users - not to mention >carpers on the sidelines - can expect >zero tolerance.
title: On Language; Drug-War Lingo

text: This is the lingo of drug warfare. The nation is hooked on it (we are all linguistic junkies), and because there is no getting this particular monkey off our backs, let's at least dig up the derivations of the phrases being pushed in the discourse of drug dudgeon.
title: On Language; Drug-War Lingo

text: In the early days, about three generations back, we had >hopheads (''hop'' for >opium) and >dope fiends (''dope'' from the Dutch doop for ''sauce'' or ''dip,'' referring to the sticky opiate). The standard English covering these slang terms is >user, in contrast to >pusher.
title: On Language; Drug-War Lingo

text: ''To the so-called >'casual user' '' was the beginning of a warning by President Bush in March of 1989 to >recreational users, a phrase chosen by some drug users to differentiate themselves from addictive users. >Casual user is not rooted exclusively in the drug culture; the phrase can be found in a 1976 Business Week story about a computer system ''not geared for the casual user''; other early citations also point to popularization by computer whizzes derogating those of us in the nonserious software crowd. Crossover use was natural: Mary Jane Hatcher, the widow of a murdered law officer, said, ''We middle-class suburban Americans, we casual users . . . must accept blame . . . .'' (Curiously, >casual - rooted in the Latin for ''chance'' -has a military sense, first as a clipped form of >casualty, later as a soldier in temporary status on the way to another station. The use of >casual in the 1593 term >casual poor, for those who drift in and out of poverty, has been carried over into >casual labor, used for transient or migratory workers since 1852.) ''American cocaine users need to understand that our nation has >zero tolerance for casual drug use,'' said the President in his Sept. 5 speech outlining what he labeled his ''drug strategy.'' >Zero is from the Arabic >sifr; the first citation for >zero tolerance in the Barnhart Books files is from a 1958 Science Newsletter: ''A good example of the care taken to protect against pesticide poisoning is the minimum tolerance set for milk: zero . . . . Recently, zero tolerance was set for methoxychlor and malathion.'' In the Nixon White House, H. R. (Bob) Haldeman was known for demanding >zero mistakes, and the >zero tolerance phrase was popularized in the drug world by William von Raab, then United States Customs chief, when he sought last year to impound yachts that had even a single marijuana cigarette aboard. Lately, >zero has become an emphatic way to say ''no'': margarine makers promise ''zero cholesterol,'' and economists warn of ''zero growth.'' The word has been booming ever since the atomic age's ''ground zero,'' and one of these days I will zero in on it.
title: On Language; Drug-War Lingo

text: A >narc was long the slang name for a narcotics law enforcement officer, rooted in the Greek >narke, ''numbness, stiffness, stupor,'' but now the first two syllables of ''narcotics'' are frequently found in longer terms. Like >klepto- and >crypto-, >pseudo- and >porno-, >narco- is a combining form, which can now be applied to anything in the illicit drug trade. Nestor K. Ikeda, reporting from Lima for The Associated Press in 1982, attributed the coinage of >narco-terrorism to Fernando Belaunde Terry, at that time Peru's President, who was describing a union of drug dealers and political terrorists. In his Democratic response to President Bush's message, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. lashed out at >narco-terrorism, which had been used on the cover of Newsweek that week. >Kingpin seems to be the only acceptable term for drug bigshots, just as >vice overlord was once the only title journalists permitted for a leader of the prostitution racket. Disagreement rages among etymologists about the metaphoric origin.
title: On Language; Drug-War Lingo

text: One school holds that >kingpin comes from the sport of bowling. In the game of kayles, played with a set of ninepins, the tallest pin was called the >kingpin. In modern bowling, the >kingpin is the pin numbered five and is surrounded by the other pins.
title: On Language; Drug-War Lingo

text: Some dictionaries, even some bowling aficionados, have been using >headpin as a synonym, but this is confusing; the headpin is the pin numbered one, placed at the head of the triangle of pins.
title: On Language; Drug-War Lingo

text: If you are right-handed and hook your ball (thereby causing it to curve slightly to the left), the best place to aim is between the headpin (the No. 1 pin) and the pin to its right facing you (the No. 3 pin); this will allow the bowling ball to crash into the kingpin, directly behind the headpin, perhaps leading to a strike and waking the pin boy if the alley is not automated. (There will be mail on this paragraph from irate expert bowlers, who should be reminded that >bowler was the name for an opium smoker, taken from the bowl of the smoker's pipe. I am not without defenses.) Other lexicographers argue that >kingpin is akin to >kingbolt, which was in use as early as 1825 for the main bolt in a machine. The Oxford English Dictionary holds that this is the sense that led to meanings of ''that which holds together any complex system or arrangement'' and ''the most important or outstanding person in a party, organization, etc.,'' as first used in Harper's Weekly in 1867: ''His best position was as a batter. He was a 'King-pin' there.'' >Crack (originally, the word referred to a noise) is recent. The term for pellet-sized pieces of cocaine prepared for smoking was just becoming popular when the 1986 Slang and Jargon of Drugs and Drink was being printed, and was not included. The author, Richard A. Spears, professor of linguistics at Northwestern University, suggests a clue to the etymology in the entry for >crystal.
title: On Language; Drug-War Lingo

text: ''What is now called >crack was known as >crystallized cocaine in the early medical days, and that hard form is still known as >rock. There's no definitive evidence,'' says Professor Spears, ''but it makes sense that >crack comes from the physical cracking of those rocks and crystals - literally, the crackling sound of those rocks as they are broken up.'' >Crackdown, the sudden introduction of severe discipline, is not all that old, either. The noun made its first appearance in a May 18, 1935, Washington Post story about punishment planned for liberals who wanted to abolish public-utility holding companies.
title: On Language; Drug-War Lingo

text: When pledging a crackdown on crack kingpins and narco-terrorists, zero-tolerant drug strategists are careful to refrain from promising a cure-all. ''There is no >magic bullet,'' said William J. Bennett, director of national drug-control policy. (He is called a >czar, and claims he calls his wife the >czarina and his children >czardines.) This was a reference to the German bacteriologist Paul Ehrlich, who was seeking a treatment for the scourge of syphilis and discovered the drug >arsphenamine, better known by its trademark name Salvarsan, or by the number 606, which was its numerical order in a series of experiments.
title: On Language; Drug-War Lingo

text: Dr. Ehrlich, who shared the Nobel Prize in 1908 for his work in immunology, is credited with having first used the term >magic bullet (in German, >Zauberkugel) to mean that ideal therapeutic agent that destroys unhealthy cells while sparing healthy tissues. The phrase was popularized in the United States in the title of the 1940 movie about his life, starring Edward G. Robinson. (A related phrase, >silver bullet, was a talisman thought to ward off werewolves and vampires, and was modified as a kind of trademark by the radio cowboy ''The Lone Ranger.'') Today, a >magic bullet is a cure without side effects, and can be applied to any headaches, from air pollution to the economy. However, the phrase is almost always used in the negative, in cautioning against over-optimism, as in ''This is no magic bullet, but . . . .''
title: On Language; Drug-War Lingo

text: President Bush characterized critics of his program as partisan >carpers who are intent on hiking taxes. That is an old noun now heard infrequently. Robert Browning used it in his 1868 ''The Ring and the Book'': ''>Carpers abound in this misjudging world.''
title: On Language; Drug-War Lingo

text: We are more familiar with the verb >carp, which means ''find fault, complain without reason''; this is from the Old Norse >karpa, ''to boast, brag,'' influenced by the Latin >carpere, ''to pluck, gather,'' which led to the sense of ''to slander'' as one snatches the reputation of another. The have-tux, will-cavil verb is not connected with the freshwater fish of the same name, first reported in the West by the sixth-century Roman statesman Cassiodorus as swimming in the Danube, and best known today for its use in the making of gefilte fish.
title: On Language; Drug-War Lingo

text: Administration officials concede that the goal President Bush set forth in his drug-policy address to the nation three weeks ago - ''victory over drugs'' -cannot be achieved in this generation.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: For now, the officials said, the real objectives are to bring the hard-core drug-addiction problem in the nation's inner cities under some degree of control and to speed the current national decline in use among people who take drugs only occasionally but are in danger of becoming addicted.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: In a number of interviews, these officials conceded that an all-out effort to get large numbers of addicted people off drugs, whether they are in inner cities or outside them, is not being planned: that aim, they said, is too complicated and the problems in reaching it are too intractable to be achieved anytime soon.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: One drug policy aide who helped draft the plan said its true goals were set so as simply to move the nation ''a little bit'' beyond where current trends would put it anyway.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, said the anti-drug effort would not ''undo all of the social problems of the inner cities.'' But he said he would consider it progress if the plan helped reduce the casual use of illegal drugs and made some headway in reducing habitual use that would ''bring some tranquility in terms of the criminal problems that people face in the cities.''
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Another senior White House official, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, bluntly said there was little hope for weaning from drugs large numbers of young people who are at the heart of much of the current crisis. Of more concern, he said, is ''doing better by the next generation of kids,'' adding, ''But it would be a considerable accomplishment if this Administration can show that this free society can cope with the problem, make some gradual headway.''
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: When pressed about what constitutes some headway, White House officials emphasized the specific numerical goals listed in the policy report, ''The National Drug Control Strategy.''
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Critics contend that the report itself is flawed in that respect, however, in that it has large gaps in the specific targets to be attacked. Some, like New York's Mayor Edward I. Koch, say the proposed policy represents an abrogation of Federal responsibility for dealing with a devastating national condition.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Broadly speaking, the Bush plan calls for spending $7.9 billion in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, and larger sums in subsequent years, on a variety of measures, including substantially increased money for law enforcement and some increase, though much less, for education. prevention and treatment. The Numbers Game Tying Goals To Current Trends
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: The strategy, drafted by William J. Bennett, Director of National Drug Control Policy, sets nine goals with both 2-year and 10-year objectives, and most are tied directly to trends already in progress.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: One objective of the plan is a 10 percent reduction in the next two years in the number of people reporting any use of illegal drugs in the previous month, and a 50 percent reduction over 10 years. The study sets the same goals for all people who use cocaine occasionally and for adolescents who use drugs occasionally.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: But the Federal Household Survey on Drug Abuse by the National Institute on Drug Abuse, released weeks before the plan was announced, showed that the number of people reporting the casual use of an illegal drug in the previous month fell 37 percent from 1985 to 1988. The household survey was based on personal interviews and questionnaires filled out by 8,814 people 12 years old and older and living in households. Prison inmates and the homeless, two groups known to have high levels of drug abuse, were not surveyed. Decline Reported in '79
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: A decline in the casual use of illegal drugs was actually reported for the first time by the national institute as beginning in 1979 and accelerating from 1985 to 1988.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: While drug policy analysts have questioned the reliability of the household survey, noting the absence of groups in which drug use is prevalent, they say it is the best measure available for those it does survey.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Administration officials said the baseline by which the 2- and 10-year goals will be compared will be, in most cases, this year's household survey by the national institute.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: The strategy sets far less optimistic goals for what virtually all experts agree is now the worse aspect of the current problem, frequent use of cocaine, or, more particularly, crack, its smokable derivative. The household survey showed the number of people who reported using cocaine once a week soared to 862,000 in 1988, from 647,000 in 1985, and the number of daily or almost daily users rose to 292,000 from 246,000.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Over two years, the drug program calls for no reduction at all in the number of people reporting weekly or more frequent cocaine use, but rather only cutting its rate of increase by half. Over 10 years, the objective is to reduce by 50 percent the number of these people who are using cocaine at least once a week.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Asked how that goal would be reached, Dr. Herbert D. Kleber, Mr. Bennett's deputy for demand reduction, said simply, ''It's assuming that we will not only work harder but work smarter.''
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: The report did not set specific goals for a decline in the use of other illegal drugs, but the planners said they hoped the following indicators would be reduced by 10 percent over two years and 50 percent over 10 years: The frequency with which drug use is mentioned by patients admitted to hospital emergency rooms; estimates of drug availability in this country; estimated domestic marijuana production, and the number of high school students who report in surveys that they do not disapprove of illegal drug use. The Battlefronts Inner-City Abusers And Casual Users
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Critics argue that the Administration is essentially taking a politically expedient course, and giving up on the drug war before it has even started.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: The Bennett report's very name, ''The National Drug Control Strategy,'' the development of which was mandated by Congress, suggests that the drug problem is more to be controlled than defeated.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: The plan, the critics contend, seems to be based largely on a general perception that the middle class is turning away from drugs, though the statistics may indicate that this is true only among those not already addicted, and that the crux of the remaining problem exists among the underclass, a group that does not make up an important political constituency.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Although the policy report itself asserts that ''our most intense and immediate problem is inner-city crack use,'' it also states that the most significant progress will be among occasional users.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: In the introduction, Mr. Bennett wrote that ''we are now fighting two drug wars'' that pose very different challenges. ''The first and easiest is against 'casual' use of drugs by many Americans, and we are winning it,'' he wrote. ''The other, much more difficult war, is against addiction to cocaine. And on this second front, increasingly located in our cities, we are losing, badly.''
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: He makes no assertions about how or when he would win or lose the second drug war but other officials who helped devise the strategy suggested in the interviews that the war in the inner cities was not only daunting but perhaps impossible to win in the forseeable future.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: ''It would be a mistake for people to believe that this strategy is going to bring about overnight success,'' said Reggie B. Walton, associate director of drug control policy. ''It took us a long time to get to this point; it's probably going to take an equally long time to get out of it. But we feel we have to start somewhere.'' Treatment on Demand Rejected
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: But, again, exactly where this start would be on the serious addiction problem itself, beyond controlling the inner-city crisis and resulting crime with added law enforcement, remained unclear from the interviews. Seventy percent of the proposed new drug budget would go for law enforcement with the rest going for prevention, education and treatment.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Several Administration officials said they rejected the concept of treatment on demand, which many experts say is critical to reducing drug use in the inner city. The officials contend that the current treatment structure cannot be easily expanded to accommodate large numbers of new patients, and that instead the emphasis should be on improving the quality of treatment programs.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: While providing some additional treatment money, the plan places heavy stress on a more punitive approach to treament, like forcing addicts into programs as part of a sentence. The Enforcement Who Bears The Burden?
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Many local officials say the Bush-Bennett plan would place an unrealistic burden on state and local governments.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Addressing a United States Conference of Mayors meeting here last week, Mayor Koch attacked the Administration for proposing to spend $7.9 billion to fight an illegal industry that generates at least $150 billion a year in profits.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Referring to ''the morsels that they give us from Washington,'' Mr. Koch added: ''How can we allow the Federal Government to reject its responsibilities? Let's not let them get away with it.''
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Indeed, if the goals are not met, a senior White House official said, the Administration will blame state and local governments and private citizens for not doing their best to carry out the strategy. ''We have an out,'' he said, ''that this was not under the control of the national Government.''
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Administration officials insisted that they are not indifferent to inner cities or local governments. They noted that the plan provides substantial sums of new money for local law enforcement, and some new financing for treatment, prevention and education programs. Moreover, the officials say one way of attacking drug addiction among the poor is to curb occasional use in the middle class through programs outlined in the drug package, such as tougher penalties for drug offenders convicted for the first time.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Mr. Sununu, for one, said profits that drive the inner city drug trafficking network come in part from casual drug users. ''They provide a lot of the money that goes into the system,'' he said.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Some experts question the premise of attacking the inner city epidemic by curbing occasional users.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: ''I don't believe anyone yet knows what the structure of this business looks like,'' said James Q. Wilson, a professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, a leading criminologist who has advised Mr. Bennett on drug matters. ''Is the real market the ghetto or is the real market middle-class joggers?''
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Delaware who is chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said the emphasis on casual users was misguided and that more money should be spent both for the police in inner cities and for education, prevention and treatment. The Origin of Goals Best Guesses On Possibilities
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Dr. Kleber, who was a professor of psychiatry at Yale University, and other Administration officials said it was unfair for people to make too much of the stated goals in the strategy because they are only best guesses of what the nation can accomplish.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: The law that created the Office of National Drug Control Policy last year mandated that the goals be listed, but Adminstration officials say that requirement was a frustrating exercise because of the uncertainty over what indicators to use and because it is quite difficult to make predictions.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: In setting out the goals, Mr. Bennett's aides said they looked at various studies and decided that the household survey was the best guidepost.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: It is clear that the Bennett report set lower goals than President Bush articulated on Sept. 5 in his first prime-time address to the nation when he concluded: ''Victory over drugs is our cause, a just cause, and with your help we are going to win.''
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Yet several critics, pointing to the latest trends, complain that goals in the strategy are too modest.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, said the strategy's goals were ''like being half pregnant - winning 50 percent of the war,'' adding, ''In World War II did we say we were goning to beat the Japanese and not the Germans?''
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: But some defend the Administration for doing the best it can. And the debate goes on over whether winning the drug war is beyond the realm of social engineering. History has shown that drug epidemics often do peak, as one drug simply replaces another.
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: Prior epidemics have declined within a decade, said Mr. Wilson, the professor. ''History is on their side,'' he said of those setting drug goals. ''But there's only one problem: Now we have crack.''
title: DRUG STRATEGY: The Real Goals - A special report.; President's 'Victory Over Drugs' Is Decades Away, Officials Say

text: By John H. Cushman Jr., Special To the New York Timeswashington, Sept. 22 -
title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December

text: The pilot and co-pilot of USAir Flight 5050, as well as other crew members, were not obliged by law or regulation to submit to drug or alcohol tests after the accident on Wednesday at La Guardia Airport in which two passengers died.
title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December

text: The rules are to change in December, when employees in the aviation industry join railroad employees and air-traffic controllers employed by the Government in being subject to drug tests after accidents.
title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December

text: Under plans filed last month by airlines, their employees will be subject to tests for the use of illegal drugs after accidents, before employment, as well as randomly and at other times. The airlines are the first group of employers to file drug-testing plans under a Transportation Department rule announced a year ago that will eventually affect four million transportation workers.
title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December

text: Even then, however, there will not be any rule requiring the testing after accidents of airline crews or other transportation workers to see whether they have used alcohol. Suspension of Licenses
title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December

text: There is no known evidence that either the pilot or co-pilot on Flight 5050 was under the influence of alcohol or drugs. But Federal investigators clearly want the question addressed, after the crew's unexplained decision to abort the takeoff of Flight 5050, which crashed into the East River at the end of the runway at La Guardia.
title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December

text: The fact that the two crew members did not meet investigators until a day and a half after the accident led the Federal Aviation Administration to suspend their licenses and led Federal Aviation Administrator James B. Busey to accuse the two of hampering the investigation.
title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December

text: ''These actions also have negated the opportunity for any meaningful toxicological testing, thereby denying us factual information as to whether drugs were or were not a factor,'' he said. ''The importance of air-carrier programs for postaccident drug testing, such as will be required later this year under F.A.A. regulations, are again emphasized by this accident.''
title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December

text: The Associated Press quoted a spokesman for the National Transportation Safety Board, Ted Lopatkiewicz, as saying crash investigators had requested the pilot and the first officer to provide blood and urine samples voluntarily. He did not say whether they had agreed to do so. The Air Line Pilots Association said in Washington, ''The crew has been asked by the N.T.S.B. to take a drug test and will do so.'' Crash in Colorado
title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December

text: There has been one crash of an American commercial airliner in which the safety board found drug use was a contributing factor. It involved a commuter line that crashed in January 1988 in Colorado. An autopsy determined that the pilot, who died, had used cocaine. The co-pilot was flying the plane when it crashed. But the board found that the decision to use a tricky approach to the Durango airport was taken by the pilot, who may have been hampered in making decisions because of repeated and recent cocaine use.
title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December

text: Six court cases brought by employee groups opposing the Federal drug-testing rules, which are one element of the Transportation Department testing program, have been consolidated in a case that is nearing a decision in a Federal court. The Air Line Pilots Association is among the groups that has opposed drug tests for aviation workers. Varying Periods of Time
title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December

text: Urine tests can show the presence of illegal drugs. The use of alcohol is detected in Breathalyzer tests and in blood samples. Traces of various drugs last for different periods of time in the blood and urine, depending on the amount consumed and other factors.
title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December

text: The periods can range from a few hours to several weeks. Evidence of marijuana can remain in the system and be detected for as long as 30 days after use. Cocaine can be detected up to two to five days after use.
title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December

text: The longer the delay in testing, the less meaningful the results. That is especially true of alcohol tests, because signs last a short time and would be rendered meaningless if alcohol were consumed between the accident and the test. The fact that alcohol is legal and that testing for it may mean drawing blood, among other issues, has prevented the Transportation Department from issuing a rule calling for alcohol testing. The department is studying the issue.
title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December

text: The question of drug and alcohol testing has been under discussion in the transportation industry for years, receiving wide attention after an Amtrak accident in which crew members were found to have smoked marijuana. Alcohol use by the captain of the Exxon Valdez oil tanker is also thought to have played a role in the Alaska oil spill this year.
title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December

text: The trend is toward widening the use of tests in the transportation business. Both houses of Congress are considering legislation that would codify drug testing in the transportation business, as well as to include alcohol testing. A Senate would cover aviation workers, including pilots, in the alcohol program. The House bill applies just to railroads.
title: U.S. to Tighten Drug Tests for Pilots in December

text: LEAD: The patriotic indignation against the use of illegal drugs and in favor of President Bush's resorting to extreme methods to combat drug traffic leaves the armchair detective puzzled.
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: The patriotic indignation against the use of illegal drugs and in favor of President Bush's resorting to extreme methods to combat drug traffic leaves the armchair detective puzzled.
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: The sales figures for legal drugs tell us that Americans are in love with drugs - that they need them desperately and spend their hard earned money to buy them.
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: Take, for example, legal drugs. Most adults begin their day with caffeine-laden coffee or tea. The amount of prescription ''speed'' - drugs that give millions energy to suffer through the day at work - totals hundreds of millions of dollars. In addition, Americans use downers - tranquilizers -which doctors (the legal drug pushers) prescribe.
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: Then, too, Americans drink caffeine-laden Coca-Cola or diet Pepsi throughout the day. They smoke billions of dollars of cigarettes a year, and, of course, cigar and pipe smoking have not disappeared.
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: The average adult also drinks beer or wine. In addition, many take one, two, three or more drinks of hard liquor. At night, millions use sleeping pills, Valium or some variety of legal drug in order to get their eight hours' sleep.
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: Some of these people obviously also use cocaine, marijuana and some exotic designer drugs. Ice, a super-''speed,'' is spreading through California. ''Ecstasy'' remains high on the list of middle class excitement experiences. And few scientists doubt that a synthetic variety of crack will appear even if the Medellin cartel doesn't survive President Bush's war.
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: If, as the Drug Enforcement Administration says, up to $150 billion worth of illegal drugs is consumed in the United States each year, who exactly is using them?
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: Clearly, cocaine consumption extends far beyond the ghettos. Indeed, middle- and upper-class use of illegal drugs is considerable.
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: Are those who tell pollsters that drugs must be stopped hypocrites or self-haters who cannot stop?
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: Why do the opinion polls reflect such anger, such desperation, on the part of a public, that, according to Government statistics, uses drugs, legal and illegal, regularly?
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: The users apparently do not offer the pollsters any positive feedback on the drugs that they take to make them happy or enable them to function. Clearly, one reason for the mad rush to do something about illegal drugs is the crime wave that has resulted from trafficking. Drug-related murders and robberies grab headlines, and those who must bear the pain and anxiety of living under such conditions - or who fear that they may one day be affected by them -must rightly feel desperate.
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: Oddly, the market logic of legalizing drugs now deemed illegal - and thus diminishing the violence -seems to be something the majority does not want.
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: Since no politician would declare that we work at unhealthy levels of pressure and anxiety and thus need relief, drugs may continue to be necessary to maintain the American way of life. For people in the ghetto, this way of life means crime, poor housing, bad health care and rotten education - all reasons why the use of crack is so widespread.
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: In light of the failure of President Bush and the Congress to deal with the public's need for drugs, the President's response is seen by users as both militant enough to maintain the facade of real action and sufficiently irrational to make possible the displacement of emotion and action.
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: If the angry messages from the White House and Capitol Hill reflect public thinking, then users do not blame themselves for drug use.
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: Instead, they displace that blame onto foreigners - Colombians, Bolivians and Peruvians - who grow coca and manufacture the evil powder, and Mexicans, Panamanians and Cubans who allow it to be transported into the U.S. Somehow these wily Latins lure and tempt us innocent gringos into cocaine addiction.
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: For all the attention and money going into stopping the illegal traffic and maybe even usage, there is precious little being spent on answering this central question: Why so many Americans continue to use the stuff? Unless this question is answered, the prevention measures will amount to little.
title: Almost All of America Is on Drugs

text: By James C. McKinley Jr.
title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say

text: A 28-year-old East Village man charged with killing and dismembering his girlfriend is a marijuana dealer who created his own bizarre religion, practiced animal sacrifice and sometimes said he was God, acquaintances and the police said yesterday.
title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say

text: The man, Daniel Rakowitz, of 700 East Ninth Street, was arrested Monday and charged with murder after he led detectives to a parcel check area in the Port Authority Bus Terminal, the police said. There officers found a five-gallon bucket containing a skull and bones believed to be those of his 26-year-old girlfriend, Monika Beerle, said Deputy Chief Ronald Fenrich, commander of detectives in Manhattan.
title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say

text: The discovery ended a two-week search and confirmed rumors that had been circulating in the Lower East Side among squatters, homeless people, nightclub workers and musicians for more than a month. A Martha Graham Student
title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say

text: The victim was from St. Gallen, Switzerland, and had been studying at the Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance on 63d Street about a year, Chief Fenrich said. Neighbors said she moved into apartment No. 7 at 700 East Ninth Street about two months ago.
title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say

text: Mr. Rakowitz, who acquaintances say lived in Tompkins Square Park and in squatters' buildings, moved in with her shortly after Miss Beerle moved in, the police said. Chief Fenrich said Mr. Rakowitz killed Miss Beerle on Aug. 19 after she told him she wanted him to move out.
title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say

text: An investigaton began on Sept. 8 after the police heard a rumor about a body being dismembered and boiled in the apartment.
title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say

text: Two searches of the building and nearby lots turned up nothing. On Sept. 13, the police found a woman who said she had seen the body, and Mr. Rakowitz was arrested at a Brooklyn restaurant where he had worked for two days. He led the police to the bucket with the remains. Punched Her in Throat
title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say

text: The criminal complaint filed yesterday said Mr. Rakowitz killed Miss Beerle ''by punching her in the throat as hard as he could.''
title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say

text: Acquaintances said Mr. Rakowitz arrived in the East Village in 1985. A lanky man with scraggly hair, sharp blue eyes and a Texas drawl, he sold marijuana and amphetamines openly in the park, acquaintances said.
title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say

text: He also carried a live rooster with him, insisted at times that he was Jesus and made long, disjointed speeches about crucifixion, reincarnation and the power of Satan.
title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say

text: ''He liked to think he was God,'' said Chris Karma, a busboy and musician.
title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say

text: Mr. Karma said Mr. Rakowitz had created his own religion, the Church of the 966. The premise of it was that Satan, represented in the Bible by the number 666, had metamorphosed and was now represented by the number 966.
title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say

text: ''He talked a lot about animal sacrifice,'' Mr. Karma said. ''And in various squats he lived in they found 966 written in blood and chicken feathers.''
title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say

text: Mr. Rakowitz grew up in Rockport, Tex., a small coastal town of about 6,000, and is the son of a former jailer, Tony Rakowitz, said David Vickford, a deputy sheriff in Rockport. He is not wanted for any crime in Rockport, the deputy said.
title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say

text: The elder Mr. Rakowitz became a deputy sheriff in Edna, Tex., five years ago and worked there until he retired last year, the sheriff's office there said. He did not respond to a series of messages left on an answering machine.
title: Accused Slayer of Girlfriend Began a Religion, Police Say

text: Something made Detective Pat DeGregorio do a double-take on the ride home that afternoon a year ago, an instinct, perhaps, after years of making undercover drug buys on the streets of Brooklyn and Queens.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: There was a crowd of young people clustered around a van on a rural lane in Kings Park, L.I. He swung his car back for a look and the teen-agers scattered, all but one of them, a tall blond girl with bow lips. At her feet was a paper bag that turned out to contain marijuana, cocaine and LSD.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: Detective DeGregorio had an awful sense of what he was about to see, but still it shattered him to recognize his 16-year-old daughter, Mary Anne. From Disbelief to Rage
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: In the year since the stunned officer stood there anguishing over whether he was now expected to arrest his own daughter for dealing drugs, Detective DeGregorio and his wife, Barbara Adametz - also a veteran New York City undercover narcotics detective - suffered the torments common to millions of American parents whose children fall victim to drugs, a cycle of disbelief, denial, rage, resignation, understanding and, perhaps, painful recovery.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: The story of Pat, Barbara and Mary Anne DeGregorio, extreme in some ways, illustrates all the more strongly, they say, how the most seemingly attentive and devoted parents and children can deceive each other and themselves over drugs and how even the most well-meaning efforts at parental education can go awry.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: But, they say, it also points a way out: how honesty, forceful action and good therapy can help salvage shattered lives.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: The story came to light in comments by Detective DeGregorio to a reporter several weeks ago, and the family subsequently agreed to discuss the ordeal as a way of dramatizing the need for more drug treatment programs.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: At first glance, the DeGregorios might have seemed as immune to the drug pandemic as any family in the nation.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: For nearly five years, from 1981 to 1985, Pat DeGregorio, a stocky police veteran with silvery hair and the profile of a friendly shark, worked in undercover narcotics, making hundreds of street buys that set up drug peddlers for later arrest and prosecution. For two terrifying years, as ''Pasquale Greco,'' a supposed Neapolitan mobster, he worked undercover inside a Sicilian Mafia ring in Queens that was smuggling heroin into the country.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: Barbara Adametz, a slim woman with red hair who uses her maiden name, was also a narcotics detective in Queens and met the divorced Pasquale, known as Pat, when they worked together in the 83d Precinct in Brooklyn. Twin Beepers
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: At home in Kings Park in Suffolk County, Pat and Barbara's twin beepers rested on top of the refrigerator. When a beep sounded, they would ask each other, ''Yours or mine?'' Sometimes the beepers went off together.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: With Pat DeGregorio's young daughter, Mary Anne, often looking on in wide-eyed fascination, they would call the drug dealers back, carefully tape-recording the voices as evidence.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: ''She'd hear our beepers go off, she'd hear us making deals, how we'd set up,'' said Barbara Adametz, 36. ''When we taped the calls, she was taught to be quiet. We wanted her to see all that.''
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: Her husband went even further. ''My daughter went to trials with me,'' Detective DeGregorio, 41, said. ''I would show her the pictures of the people I arrested. No one was better educated than my daughter.''
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: But somehow it backfired. Mary Anne DeGregorio starting secretly drinking at 12, beer at first, then whisky. She hung out with older youths and tried drugs. By 15 she was a psychologically addicted abuser of marijuana, amphetamines, cocaine and LSD as well as a drug dealer - and used the knowledge acquired at home to evade detection. Selling Drugs at School
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: She too worked with a beeper. ''I had a dealer and he had a beeper,'' she said last week. When she took an order, she would beep him for delivery. ''I used to be the drug dealer at school,'' she said. Her best sellers, she said, were marijuana, LSD and mescaline.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: The parents do not pretend they were caught entirely by surprise, although Pat DeGregorio admitted that as Mary Anne's natural father, he was more inclined to stick his head in the sand.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: ''Like any other parents, we saw things were not right,'' he said. ''She was disobeying us, coming home at 6 A.M. instead of midnight. She wasn't looking good. She seemed tired all the time. My first reaction was the ostrich syndrome. I said: 'It'll go away. She'll grow out of it.' ''
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: ''He saw it,'' Mary Anne said. ''But I'm his daughter. He said, 'Not my kid.' He didn't want to believe I got high.'' Detective Adametz said it was more obvious to her. ''She would get the munchies; all the signs, she had.'' But as the girl's stepmother, she felt reluctant to be too forceful. ''The ground was shaky between us,'' as she put it. 'All He Had Left'
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: There were other factors. Detective DeGregorio's son, Tommy, Mary Anne's younger brother, died of a heart defect in 1981 at the age of 6, plunging the family into despair and contributing to the breakup of Detective DeGregorio's first marriage.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: ''Mary Anne was all he had left,'' Detective Adametz said. ''He didn't want to face her possible loss.''
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: Even when the evidence became impossible to ignore, the parents hesitated. Once, they found an apparent order for drugs in a note in Mary Anne's room: ''I really need something bad today.'' She insisted she was just passing the note from one friend to another.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: Another time they found some marijuana in the room. The girl said it belonged to her friend Crissie.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: ''We didn't know what to do,'' Detective Adametz said. ''We were paralyzed.''
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: But their hands were forced after Detective DeGregorio found Mary Anne with the drugs at the van off Route 25A in Kings Park in early September 1988. He actually thought for a moment about summoning the Suffolk County police to have her arrested. Instead, he said, he yanked her into the car. Later at home, he flushed the drugs down the toilet. 'Something's Wrong'
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: They drove the half-mile home in silence. His first words when they got inside, he said, were: ''This is over! You know something's wrong. I know something's wrong.''
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: ''I don't have a problem,'' Mary Anne insisted.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: When Barbara Adametz came home later, the parents decided the girl would either have to agree to treatment or get out of the house. Their resolve was strengthened by a talk with Tough Love, a family support group that advocates such shock tactics.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: ''Get out until you get help,'' Detective DeGregorio raged. ''I'm leaving,'' said Mary Anne. Her father demanded she give up her house keys, and she walked out. Bagged All Her Clothes
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: Enraged, Detective DeGregorio went up to her room and threw all her clothes out of the window. Later, he gathered them from the yard, bagged them and stored them in the garage.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: ''I loved my daughter,'' he said. ''But I didn't like her.''
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: Two days later, Mary Anne called, but all she wanted was her clothes.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: ''They're in the garage,'' said her father. ''Get them out by the end of the week.''
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: Crying, he called a woman from Tough Love.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: ''Did you tell your child she's welcome to come back when she gets help?'' the woman asked. The detective assured her he had. ''Then you have no choice,'' she said. Looking for Apartment
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: Three weeks passed. Mary Anne never came back for her clothes. Detective DeGregorio heard his daughter had dropped out of high school and was looking for an apartment. ''I'm dying,'' he recalled. ''I figured I lost this kid.''
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: One morning, Detective DeGregorio was leaving for work when he noticed a light on in the basement. Investigating, he found Mary Anne passed out under the bar, ''crumpled up, soaking wet, like a rat, like a bum.'' Drunk, she had sneaked in the window the night before.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: The father left her there and tiptoed out. Later he called home from work and she answered.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: ''Oh, you're there,'' he said, trying to sound surprised. Then his anger erupted. ''You're killing me!'' he screamed. ''You're killing my marriage. It's not enough your brother died?'' ''I want help,'' said Mary Anne. The detective rushed home and found Mary Anne at the kitchen table. ''So you want help?'' he asked. ''Yes,'' she said, ''but I'm not going to need it for long, maybe 30 days.'' ''That's the wrong attitude,'' he said. Destructive Patterns He had heard about a substance-abuse treatment center called Apple, a nonprofit therapeutic community in Hauppauge, L.I., where ex-addicts trained as counselors treated addicts and sought to break down destructive behavior patterns under a professional staff's supervision. He took Mary Anne there for an appointment.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: The staff member who interviewed her recited his own history casually: ''I was locked up 18 times. I was shot carrying cocaine in the Everglades.''
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: Detective DeGregorio met Apple's management: Logan Lewis, the president; Robert Alberti, the vice president for drug-free services, and Mark Howard, the director of communications, all of whom introduced themselves as former drug addicts and criminals.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: ''The only time I ever met people like you was putting them in handcuffs,'' Detective DeGregorio said. As it happened, Apple, usually oversubscribed, would have one of its 100 beds available in three days. Detective DeGregorio, terrified of letting Mary Anne out of his sight until then, kept her with him day and night. When he went to work, she waited in his car outside the station house.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: Once, he drove her to Manhattan for a tour of drug locations he knew from his years working narcotics cases. They drove through the ruined streets of Alphabet City on the Lower East Side, where drugs and money were passed through holes in brick walls, and addicts nodded out on stoops. Mary Anne looked but said nothing, her father recalled. ''She was still resistant,'' he said. Not a Vacation
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: The next day, she reported to Apple. As instructed, she carried her clothes and toiletries not in a suitcase but in plastic bags, intended to symbolize the harsh life there. This was not a vacation.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: Her parents left her with the staff. All three were crying. They would not be allowed to have contact with her for at least a month. She would have to earn the privilege of receiving and writing letters and getting phone calls.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: The parents attended orientation sessions and meetings with other parents. They did not see Mary Anne. On one visit, Detective DeGregorio asked a staff member how she was doing.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: ''O.K.,'' he said. ''She's scared. She's having a tough time.''
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: Two months into her stay, Mary Anne told her parents: ''I still crave it. I know I have to be here now.'' Based on his ability to pay, Detective DeGregorio contributes $100 each week toward the $300 a week it costs to keep Mary Anne at Apple. The state makes up the rest. Family Encounter Groups
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: Every two weeks, he and his wife gather with Mary Anne and other residents and parents in family encounter groups. In one such session last week that the participants agreed to open to a reporter and a photographer, one parent, Joan Heusel of Shirley, L.I., confronted her son, Troy, 18, over his visits to a neighborhood crack house that eventually landed him at Apple.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: ''He robbed everything in the house,'' she announced. ''He robbed off his sister. Even the TV.'' ''Not the TV,'' Troy protested. ''The little one,'' Mrs. Heusel reminded him.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: ''Oh, yeah,'' Troy remembered. ''I did steal the TV.''
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: On Friday it will be a year since Mary Anne entered Apple. She figures on staying six months more. She is getting her high school diploma and wants to study fashion design. Or perhaps, she said, she would go to work for Apple. ''I grew up a lot,'' she said. ''I still get an urge,'' she added. ''I think I always will. I can't say I'll never get high again.'' But she said she was determined not to forget why she had come there.
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: ''You can't forget all the bad things,'' she said. ''I can't forget where I came from.''
title: For Child of Detectives, Torment Over Drugs

text: One month after the murder of a presidential candidate here unleashed Colombia's attack on cocaine cartels, President Virgilio Barco Vargas appears to be preparing for a long war against the major drug traffickers.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Breaking the pattern of previous, short-lived crackdowns, Colombia's Government has arrayed its weapons for a prolonged fight: seizing ranches and planes, freezing bank accounts, extraditing drug suspects to the United States and placing the headquarters of drug rings under military control.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: ''Barco has told me, one on one, that he is going to keep this up until he pushes them out of the country,'' a high Government official said of Colombia's President, who is starting his final year in office.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Clara Lopez Obregon, a congressional candidate from the left wing of the ruling Liberal Party, said, ''My sense is that the anti-drug effort is honest and is not going to blow away.''
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: But many narcotics experts fear that without major successes, public support will begin to drift. Already political figures are sniping at the drug war.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: ''The measures adopted in the United States do not satisfy us: educational videos in the United States, bombers for Colombia, persuasive chats in the consuming centers and helicopters for Colombia,'' Senator Ernesto Samper Pizano, a presidential candidate for the Liberal Party, said at a press conference on Thursday. On Drug Dealers' Side Is Their Vast Wealth The outcome is far from certain in a contest that pits a democratically elected Government of a developing nation against drug merchants who are often described as the richest criminals in the world.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: The traffickers, the source of 80 percent of the world's cocaine, have on their side vast wealth, private armies and a predilection for terror and bribery that has intimidated or corrupted courts, congress and much of the press.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Against this, President Barco has overwhelming public support and two new allies - the army and the United States. Narcotics experts say they are surprised by the tenacity of this crackdown, the fifth against the cartels here in five years.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: ''The drug traffickers have been really hurt this time,'' said Guy Gugliotta, who co-authored with Jeff Leen a new history of the Medellin cartel, ''Kings of Cocaine.''
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: ''The cartels have been hurt in the pocket book,'' Mr. Gugliotta continued in a telephone interview. ''The Government has taken away their toys, their land, their ability to be rich and have fun.'' Supplies of Narcotics Are 'Seriously Disrupted'
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Indeed, in the four weeks since the murder on Aug. 18 of the popular politician, Luis Carlos Galan, the police and army have seized an impressive inventory: 367 aircraft, 72 boats, 710 vehicles and motorcyles, 4.7 tons of cocaine, 1,279 guns, 25,000 rounds of ammunition, 989 buildings and ranches, and 32,773 farm animals.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: In addition, 535 people have been arrested and charged and more than 10,000 others have been detained and later released. For the first time in two years, a drug suspect has been extradited to the United States and two more are awaiting extradition.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: ''It's put the traffickers off balance,'' an American diplomat said here. ''The supplies of marijuana and cocaine have been seriously disrupted.''
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: For the first time in five years, the wholesale price for cocaine in Miami is rising. Since the crackdown started, the price has risen to $18,000 a kilogram, from $11,000.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: While Colombia grows about 15 percent of the world's coca leaf production, its major role is processing cocaine base made from higher grade leaves grown in Bolivia and Peru.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Police efforts have largely focused on hindering production by seizing chemicals used for refining coca base into cocaine powder. By mid-August, the Colombian police had seized twice as much ether, three times as much acetone and eight times as much ammonia as in all of last year.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: The director general of Colombia's police, Miguel Antonio Gomez Padilla, said in an interview published Saturday in El Espectador, ''In the last laboratory destroyed we found a chemical recycling unit, which means two things: one, that they are having problems bringing the chemicals into the country, and, two, that they realized it is cheaper to recycle.''
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Government officials have not explained why the security forces have not heavily hit laboratories and plantations in the first month of the current crackdown, although they have burned some coca plantations in the Amazon area and raided some laboratories.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: The police have concentrated on seizing real estate, radio and aircraft suspected of being used for smuggling.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Corruption in the police and army may explain why the so-called 12 most wanted traffickers have slipped away and why major laboratories have not been destroyed, American narcotics experts here suggest.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Mr. Gomez, the police director, said in the El Espectador interview:
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: ''Why haven't we captured the principal ringleaders? There are two groundless charges that are not true: the first is that they are not captured because we don't want to capture them. And the other is because the security forces are very infiltrated. In reality, these people are not being caught because they are not walking around openly in the streets. They are fugitivies and move around a lot.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Under attack, the Medellin cartel has fought back with its trademark violence. In the last four weeks, the toll from the cartel's terror action has been 13 dead, 140 injured and millions of dollars in damage. In all, more than 50 bombs have been exploded.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Tonight a homemade rocket was fired at the United States Embassy, The Associated Press reported. The news agency quoted an embassy spokesman as saying that the device struck a corner of the building but caused minimal damage and no injuries.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Three bombs exploded today in Cali, killing a security guard, and three bombings were reported tonight in northern Bogota. On Saturday, Guillermo Gomez Murillo, a reporter for El Espectador, was shot to death by three men who entered his house in Buenaventura.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: The targets of the attacks have been carefully chosen.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Colombia's 200,000-man army, which has joined the fray for the first time, has been virtually untouched. The bombers have largely hit banks, restaurants, ranches and shops owned by wealthy and politically influential Colombians.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: ''The narcos are going after the ruling class - and they are already starting to squeal,'' a European diplomat said, citing calls for discussions from some leaders in Medellin.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Mr. Galan's murder came three weeks before President Bush unveiled his Adminstration's drug policy. Anger over the assassination is partly credited with prompting the American aid that is suddenly pouring into this Andean country.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: As recently as 15 years ago, American anti-narcotics aid amounted to $45,000 - some jeeps and some handcuffs. Days after the August 18 assassination, President Bush ordered $65 million in emergency aid to Colombia.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: The Bush Administration's anti-drug plan contains an ''Andean strategy'' that calls for increased economic and military aid for Colombia, Peru and Bolivia in addition to the $65 million.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Pete Williams, a Pentagon spokesman, said last week that for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 the Bush plan specifically calls for $90 million in military and economic aid for Colombia, $97.5 million for Bolivia and $73.4 million for Peru. In those three countries, officials said, there now were 50 to 100 American military officers, but that number is expected to grow.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Responding to Colombian and American officials who have complained that the United States has sent military equipment that was not appropriate for fighting drug traffickers, Mr. Williams said: ''We have to best match their needs with what we are limited by law to offer from existing stocks. We believe that the aid that we have offered is appropriate to the circumstances.'' Public's Attitude Shifts To Favor Extradition Some narcotics experts believe that the traffickers have lost some credibility by not following through on threats to wage war on the Government or to kill 10 judges for every Colombian extradited to the United States.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: ''One good symptom was that the reaction to the first extradition was not as strong as we expected,'' a presidential aide said cautiously.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: The traffickers have won few friends with their policy of terrorism. A recent opinion poll indicated that attitudes towards extradition have reversed since March. Six months ago, 63 percent of Colombians polled opposed sending their countrymen to face trial in American courts. In late August, 77 percent of those polled by the newspaper El Tiempo backed extradition.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: The traffickers have singled out congress and the courts for bribes or intimidation. Last week, the House of Representatives gave a cold shoulder to President Barco's Cabinet when they arrived at the chamber to brief legislators on the drug war.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: In coming weeks, the Supreme Court will be the scene of next battle. By October, the court must rule on the constitutionality of Mr. Barco's decrees. If they are found to be unconstitutional, all property seized from drug dealers since Aug. 18 must be returned.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: ''If the court strikes down the decrees as unconstitutional, it will be a victory for the mafia and a terrible embarassment for Colombia,'' said Luis Ricardo Paredes, a Harvard-trained Colombian lawyer. ''On the other hand, if they don't strike them down, they are dead people.'' In recent years, the traffickers have killed about a dozen Supreme Court judges. Top 12 Traffickers Remain at Large Four weeks after the crackdown began, the top 12 traffickers wanted for trial in the United States are still at large. ''I think they had hideouts prepared for a long time and are in Colombia,'' Mr. Gugliotta said.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: During past crackdowns, the traffickers have turned to Colombia's guerrilla groups to rent extra firepower. In 1985, the traffickers are believed to have hired the M-19 group.
