Eleven Supreme Court justices died during M-19's seizure of the court that year. But the M-19, which is about to conclude a peace agreement with the Government, is no longer for hire.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Colombia's largest group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, is feuding with the traffickers. In the last four years, paramilitary squads organized by the traffickers are believed to have murdered 750 members of this guerrilla group's political wing.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Of five left-wing guerrilla armies in Colombia, only one, the National Liberation Army, is not conducting peace talks with the Government. ''The word is out that the narcs have said to the E.L.N.: 'Name your price,' '' the European diplomat said, using the Spanish initials of the National Liberation Army.
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: Last Thursday, the army reported the arrest in Medellin of 28 members of the National Liberation Army ''who worked in the service of drug traffickers.''
title: War Report From Colombia: Fight Will Be Long

text: An angry Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist says a new book about Robert H. Bork's ill-fated Supreme Court nomination incorrectly states that the Chief Justice broke a promise to keep Justice Lewis F. Powell's impending retirement a secret.
title: Rehnquist Denies Breaking Word to Powell

text: In the book, ''Battle for Justice,'' published by W. W. Norton & Company, the author, Ethan Bronner, says Justice Powell told Chief Justice Rehnquist on June 25, 1987, that he would announce his retirement the next day and asked for ''a solemn promise'' to keep it a secret overnight.
title: Rehnquist Denies Breaking Word to Powell

text: ''The Chief Justice expressed his sincere regret, agreed to keep it to himself'' and then called the White House chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., with the news, the book says. According to the book, Mr. Baker immediately told President Reagan.
title: Rehnquist Denies Breaking Word to Powell

text: ''That statement is in error,'' Chief Justice Rehnquist said Thursday in a statement. ''I notified Howard Baker of the retirement shortly before we went on the bench on the morning of Friday, June 26, 1987.'' Announcement Stunned Court
title: Rehnquist Denies Breaking Word to Powell

text: Chief Justice Rehnquist objected to being portrayed as a man who could not be trusted to keep his word. After the passage was called to his attention by a friend, he told some journalists and Court employees on Wednesday that he was offended by the account.
title: Rehnquist Denies Breaking Word to Powell

text: Justice Powell's announcement of his retirement, on the last day of the Court's 1986-87 term, stunned those in the courtroom and touched off an epic battle to fill the Court vacancy.
title: Rehnquist Denies Breaking Word to Powell

text: The nomination of Mr. Bork, who was then a Federal appeals court judge, was defeated by the Senate after a bitter fight in which the nominee was attacked as an extreme conservative outside the mainstream of American judicial thought.
title: Rehnquist Denies Breaking Word to Powell

text: Mr. Reagan's second choice, Douglas H. Ginsburg, another Federal appeals court judge, withdrew as a nominee after admitting that he smoked marijuana while a Harvard law professor. The President then nominated Anthony M. Kennedy, also a Federal appeals court judge, who was confirmed by the Senate and joined the Court in February 1988. Baker Backs Justice's Version
title: Rehnquist Denies Breaking Word to Powell

text: Chief Justice Rehnquist's version of when the White House was told of Justice Powell's retirement was supported by Mr. Baker in an interview Wednesday.
title: Rehnquist Denies Breaking Word to Powell

text: Mr. Baker, now a Washington lawyer, said his office received a telephone call from Chief Justice Rehnquist's office the evening of June 25 alerting the White House that something was up. The message, from an aide to the Chief Justice, was that the Chief Justice intended to call Mr. Baker the next morning.
title: Rehnquist Denies Breaking Word to Powell

text: Mr. Baker said he was ready for a call from Chief Justice Rehnquist on June 26 but had no idea what the Chief Justice wanted to tell him.
title: Rehnquist Denies Breaking Word to Powell

text: Mr. Baker said he promptly told Mr. Reagan the news at their regular morning meeting. That took place shortly before Justice Powell announced his retirement, Mr. Baker said.
title: Rehnquist Denies Breaking Word to Powell

text: Mr. Bronner said that he had interviewed Mr. Baker for the book and that Mr. Baker had said he knew of Justice Powell's decision to retire a day before the public announcement. Mr. Bronner said he had taped the interview.
title: Rehnquist Denies Breaking Word to Powell

text: Mr. Baker said that if he told Mr. Bronner he had advance knowledge, ''I misspoke myself; I did not know.'' Mr. Powell, asked for his recollection, said he believed Chief Justice Rehnquist had lived up to his promise, adding that ''there's no question in my mind'' the White House was not informed until shortly before the courtroom announcement.
title: Rehnquist Denies Breaking Word to Powell

text: The first follow-up studies of babies born to mothers using crack show that in early childhood they have serious difficulty relating to their world, making friends, playing like normal children and feeling love for their mothers or primary caretakers.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: Prenatal exposure to illegal drugs, particularly powdered cocaine and its smokable derivative, crack, seems to be ''interfering with the central core of what it is to be human,'' said Coryl Jones, a research psychologist at the National Institute of Drug Abuse in Bethesda, Md.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: The new research does indicate that most babies exposed to the illegal drugs appear able to develop normal, if low-range, intelligence despite their subnormal emotional development. Relationships Are Affected
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: But the studies suggest that without help, the children of addicted mothers may be unable to develop into adults with basic employment skills and unable to form close human relationships, the researchers said. The studies indicate that exposure to crack and cocaine has a particularly devastating effect on the emotional lives of the children.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: Researchers report that the babies themselves are free of drugs not long after birth but that what then happens to them results from the exposure to drugs while in the womb, when substances in the mother's blood enter the baby's. Many women believe that the placenta acts as a shield against harmful substances. But the researchers say the opposite is true: it acts as a sponge.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: A hopeful note concerning these children comes from a pilot program in Florida that appears to be helping 25 babies exposed to cocaine to develop better play skills and interpersonal relationships. The program is being run by the only federally financed center caring for the infants of cocaine-addicted mothers. Striking Abnormalities
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: Two research groups have thus far observed striking abnormalities in how these babies organize their play and react to adults, Dr. Jones said. One is led by Dr. Ira Chasnoff, director of the Perinatal Center for Chemical Dependence at Northwestern University School of Medicine in Chicago. He will present his findings today at the annual meeting of the National Association for Perinatal Addiction Research and Education in Miami.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: The other group is headed by Dr. Judith Howard, director of the Suspected Child Abuse and Neglect Team at the University of California at Los Angeles.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: Dr. Chasnoff and Dr. Howard are among the nation's leading experts on babies exposed to crack and cocaine, Dr. Jones said. Using new analytical methods, they are picking up behavioral problems in babies born to addicted mothers that other researchers have missed. The babies in their studies were born to mothers who had been using a variety of drugs, primarily crack and cocaine. #300,000 Infants Affected Each year, more than 300,000 infants are born with traces of some illegal drugs, Dr. Jones said. No one knows how many are being exposed specifically to crack. But few doubt that the needs of these babies will present an overwhelming challenge to schools, future employers and society. More women than men are now reported using crack in several major American cities, and drug experts say a large number of these new users are young pregnant women.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: The Northwestern group is studying the progress of nearly 400 babies born to mothers in the Chicago area who used cocaine in pregnancy, Dr. Chasnoff said in an interview. Of these, the staff has followed 263 babies for two years, testing them along the way on a variety of intellectual and developmental scales.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: At first glance, he said, the children seemed to function normally in structured tests. For example, when an adult asked a child to put a small round object into a bigger square box, the child could do it. His intelligence seemed all right.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: ''But when we looked at the quality of their performance,'' Dr. Chasnoff said, ''we saw problems.'' An average toddler not exposed to drugs can place two, three or more objects in the box. ''When we gave more than one object to the cocaine babies, they got frustrated,'' he said. ''They had difficulty concentrating and were distracted by the second objects.''
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: Dr. Chasnoff said the poor quality of their performance suggested that these children had great difficulty organizing their responses to their surroundings. While they score on the low end of normal on intelligence tests, they score much lower on tests that measure abilities to concentrate, interact with other children in a group and play by themselves in unstructured environments.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: The U.C.L.A. group under Dr. Howard, the first to report abnormal play patterns, began seeing babies born of addicted mothers from the Los Angeles area 11 years ago. Cocaine and Lethargic Babies
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: Unlike jittery babies previously studied after exposure to heroine and P.C.P., the babies born to mothers who favor crack and cocaine are lethargic. Dr. Howard said. These women use alcohol, marijuana and other ''downers,'' or sedative drugs, to ease the emotional crash after their cocaine highs, and this might account for the babies' lethargy, Dr. Howard said.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: After four or five weeks, many of these babies become physically rigid, a phenomenon that lasts several days, Dr. Howard said. The tests of many of these babies appear to show that they are blind at birth, yet by the time they are 9 months old, their vision is normal, the doctor said.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: As one group of babies studied at U.C.L.A. approached 1 year of age, Dr. Howard said of them: ''We were getting optimistic. They seemed to be calmer. Their motor skills were better. Their moms were doing better.'' Only one thing seemed odd. When the babies were placed on the floor by themselves, they appeared apathetic to the toys around them, Dr. Howard said. Without an adult to show them how to pick up and handle toys, she said, they did not know what to do. Two Groups Compared
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: To explore ''what our eyes were telling us,'' Dr. Howard said, the researchers compared two groups of toddlers from similar backgrounds. One group of 18 toddlers had been exposed to cocaine and other drugs in pregnancy. Another 18, used as a control group, had been born very prematurely but had not been exposed to drugs. In both groups, the babies experienced medical difficulties after birth and were at increased risk for learning disabilties. Their mothers were poor, uneducated and had had virtually no prenatal care.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: All the children in both groups and all their caretakers, mothers, grandmothers, relatives or foster parents, were part of an intervention program at U.C.L.A. The toddlers in the program received excellent health care and were not abused or neglected. Thus the relative effects of the drugs as opposed to home environment would be the differentiating factor. Testing Revealed Differences
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: At first, Dr. Howard said, the toddlers exposed to drugs did not seem to develop differently from the babies born prematurely. As researchers played with them in testing sessions, seeing, for example, if they could build a tower of blocks, the babies exposed to drugs scored consistently lower than those born prematurely but were still within the low average range.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: When the toddlers were left to play by themselves and their actions videotaped, researchers observed marked differences in the two groups. The researchers counted how many times the children made novel combinations of toys around them. The researchers found the best score among the babies born prematurely was 38 combinations. The best score among babies of addicted mothers was 10.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: The premature babies played as most children do. They would comb a doll's hair, pretend to stir a pot and make sounds like a motor when they played with trucks.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: The babies exposed to drugs scattered and batted the toys. They picked toys up and put them down, without purpose. If they did play with an object, they would walk away from it long before most children would, their faces dispassionate, joyless. Less Attached to Caretakers
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: Finally, the majority of toddlers exposed to drugs seemed less attached to their caretakers. ''You drop off most 18-month-old kids with strangers and they show appropriate fear,'' Dr. Howard said. But most of the drug babies did not show any strong feelings -pleasure, anger or distress.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: Up to now, Dr. Howard said, research on babies exposed predominantly to heroin or PCP has indicated that the infants, given supportive environments, were able to catch up with normal children. Their intellectual and developmental tests scores have been in the normal ranges, and it has been thought that young human brains, pliable and still rapidly developing, should be able to overcome most neurological damage from the exposure.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: But these new studies paint a far less optimistic picture for babies exposed to crack and cocaine. Many of these babies today show symptoms similar to those in children with mild autism or those with personality disorders, conditions characterized by withdrawal and lack of emotion. ''Something is interfering with their ability to engage in simple creative play,'' Dr. Howard said. Free play requires self-organization, self-initiation and follow through without adult guidance.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: Cocaine may produce the effects by altering fundamental neurological pathways in the baby's brain, researchers say. The drug crosses the placenta during the first trimester of pregnancy when the brain is forming. The pleasure and reward pathway, based on the brain chemical dopamine, is especially vulnerable to cocaine. This might explain the flat moods and emotional poverty seen in crack babies, both Dr. Howard and Dr. Chasnoff agree.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: Whatever the cause of the problem, thousands of babies exposed to crack, cocaine and other drugs will be reaching school age in the next few years, Dr. Howard said. Good school and home environments are crucial for these children, she said. They will need lots of structure and individual attention. Intervention That Works
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: The day care center in Florida especially designed for babies exposed to cocaine is showing that such intervention works. Each morning, 25 children from 2 months to 5 years of age are picked up in a van and taken to bright, cheerful classrooms with three teachers and three aides. The center in St. Peterburg is run for the Federal Government by Operation Par, the largest nonprofit provider of drug abuse services in Florida.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: When the children first arrived a year ago, their attention spans were three to five seconds, said Kelly Twiss, the teacher in charge of 10 children, ''We give them lots of hugs, a lot of love, and a lot of structure,'' she said.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: At first, she said: ''They did not know how to play. They would not pick up a toy, a crayon or a doll. But now I see them experimenting with everything. A casual observer would not notice that many differences.''
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: It is too soon to say whether the improvements will be long lasting. Ms. Twiss said that when structure is removed, the children tend to withdraw again.
title: Crack's Toll Among Babies: A Joyless View, Even of Toys

text: By Katherine Bishop, Special To the New York Times
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: The use of smokable methamphetamine, which produces a much longer period of euphoria than crack and is followed by a more disturbing psychological reaction, has reached major proportions here and has begun to appear in several cities on the mainland as well.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Experts on substance abuse fear that use of the drug, called ice, could grow to devastating proportions among many of the nation's addicts, especially if efforts are successful to halt the smuggling of cocaine from abroad. The drug can be made cheaply and easily in this country in the same clandestine laboratories that are now used to make speed, the powdered form of methamphetamine, a synthetic stimulant of the nervous system that is a form of amphetamine.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: ''There is an urgent need to stop the flow of cocaine from overseas, but there are plenty of dangerous drugs that are made in the U.S.A.,'' said Donald Hamilton, a spokesman for William J. Bennett, the Federal drug policy director. ''Experts are warning us that smokable methamphetamine will be the drug plague of the 1990's.''
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: And James N. Hall, the executive director of Up Front Drug Information Center in Miami, a nonprofit research foundation, agreed, saying: ''Drugs from clandestine labs will demand attention because the United States is becoming a big producer of drugs. In the 1990's, most drugs used in America will be made in America.''
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: At present, most of the smokable crystals of methamphetamine are made in Hong Kong, Korea and the Philippines and smuggled here by Asian drug gangs.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Law-enforcement officials say that ice, which was virtually nonexistent in Hawaii only 18 months ago, has already become its most serious drug-related problem. Arrests in Honolulu for the possession or sale of ice have reached 400 this year, more than double the arrests in connection with cocaine and crack, its smokable derivative.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: In addition, the arrests of sellers and users of ice are now being reported by the police in the areas of San Francisco Bay, Los Angeles, San Diego and Phoenix and in parts of central Florida, though the numbers are not high. Law-enforcement authorities and those working in drug treatment centers say there have been no reports of the use of ice in New York City.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: In Honolulu, as in cities on the mainland where crack is epidemic, medical and mental health centers are beginning to show the strain of treating ice users. 'They Go Absolutely Crazy'
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Alma Y. Takata, the chief of the mental health division of the Hawaii State Department of Health, said Honolulu is averaging six hospital emergency room admissions a night for people being treated for symptoms caused by smoking crystal methamphetamine.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: ''They go absolutely crazy,'' Mrs. Takata said. ''They are bouncing off the walls. You've never seen anything like it. They're much more belligerent than those on crack.''
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: She said a survey of the 700 people who appeared for emergency treatment in the last six months showed that 50 percent had been using the drug by itself or in conjunction with another drug like alcohol.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Although ice creates feelings of euphoria followed by severe depression just as crack does, its effects differ significantly.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Instead of the 15-minute high with crack, the high from ice may last as long as 24 hours, and the psychological crash is much worse. In addition to euphoria, crack, which is a stimulant, may produce highly excitable and agitated behavior and severe but short-lived depression. With ice, along with depression, are symptoms of acute psychosis not normally associated with crack that last up to 48 hours. Severe paranoia, hallucinations, delusions and an impaired ability to speak coherently make its addicts temporarily indistinguishable from paranoid schizophrenics. Weight Loss and Insomnia
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Like those abusing crack, ice users initially suffer weight loss and insomnia because of the stimulation from the drug. On a physical level, the drug can produce irregular heartbeat, convulsions and cause body temperature to rise as high as 108 degrees, which can bring kidney failure.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Of special concern to those trying to treat users are studies demonstrating that addiction to amphetamines is as severe as addiction to cocaine. Research surveyed by Dr. Louis Harris of the Medical College of Virginia showed that monkeys taught to press a lever to receive an injection of either amphetamines, cocaine or nicotine would press the lever until they died rather than stop to eat or sleep. Heroin and alcohol were found to be less addictive.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Mrs. Takata said her office is planning to ask the State Legislature for money to devise a plan for comprehensive short- and long-term treatment of ice addicts. The obstacle is not in devising a new method of treatment, but in providing an adequate number of treatment spaces in programs already dealing with addictions to other drugs. Thus far, only a small number of treatment programs exist for ice addicts and those are through private groups that contract with the state.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Karl D. Muller is the director of a crisis response team working for the state that responds to calls of people acting bizarrely on the streets of Honolulu. More and more, those people turn out to have been smoking ice, he said. 'An Instant Psychosis'
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: ''Every person on ice I have seen has to be in restraints,'' Mr. Muller said. ''We look upon ice as an instant psychosis.''
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Most cases are taken to the emergency room at Queen's Medical Center in downtown Honolulu. Dr. Donald C. Fancher, the director of the emergency department, said that users displayed violent or aggressive behavior toward anyone, necessitating more security guards to restrain them. ''They pound on the walls, threaten - they're out of control,'' Dr. Fancher said.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: While the acute toxic affects of the drugs normally dissipate in 48 hours, there is evidence to suggest that patients have ''permanent psychological problems if they abused it a lot,'' Dr. Fancher said.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Synthetic stimulants of the central nervous system from the amphetamine group were first synthesized in Japan in 1919 and have since had prescribed medical uses in the treatment for falling asleep at inappropriate moments, or narcolepsy; for hyperactivity in children, and for obesity. The illegally sold methamphetamine form can be made from a wide variety of heated chemical compounds, some of which are easy to obtain.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Dr. Marvin Snyder of the National Institute on Drug Abuse said that smokable methamphetamine ''produces a higher level of the drug in the brain in a shorter period of time'' than speed, which in powdered form is snorted or can be heated into liquid and injected.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: The basic apparatus for making ice already exists in small chemical laboratories, many of them on the West Coast, where speed is now illegally made. The highly volatile cooking procedure is simple to set up in abandoned factories, for example, or in buildings in remote rural areas.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Illegal marijuana cultivation and clandestine production of powder methamphetamine make up the bulk of domestic drug production with the manufacture of LSD and PCP playing a much smaller role. But experts say that ice presents a much more frightening alternative. Enormous Profits for Dealers
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Speed has long been called the poor man's cocaine because of its price. But the ice dealers have held the price above that of cocaine, thereby creating enormous profits. They have been able to maintain this high price because of the long-lasting effects of the drug and because of the appeal of its newness, officers here say.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Ice is being sold in one-gram sealed plastic bags for about $400. It is also sold in $50 bags of one-tenth of a gram, the amount normally used for a high. Experts say that it only cost a few hundred dollars for the chemicals to produce a pound of nearly pure methamphetamine that can be dissolved in water or acid and cooked to produce large crystals.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: The police report that cocaine, from which crack is derived, sells for about $110 a gram here.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Maj. Mike Carvalho of the Honolulu Police Department's narcotics unit said that the arrest this week of a street dealer is typical. The suspect was found to be in possession of 10 grams of ice, $55,000 in cash and a pistol.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: The authorities say that abuse of ice at this stage of its evolution cuts across all social, economic racial and ethnic lines, but tends to be concentrated among people in their late teens and early 20's. The experts say that most ice users have not yet fully realized the extent of the suffering that takes place once the euphoria subsides and the experts believe that once the side-effects are known, the drug will lose its cachet. 'Nice for the Middle Class'
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: One Honolulu doctor who has treated many users of the drug said his patients often look like the girl next door.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: ''It seems clean because you don't have to use a needle or go to a crack house and it's available,'' said the doctor, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. ''It has the panache of cocaine when it first came out - something nice for the middle class.''
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: A special group of state, local and Federal authorities has resulted in the prosecution of 21 dealers involved in larger smuggling activities. In one such case, 13 pounds of ice sent from Hong Kong were seized.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: Although the drug is normally shipped here from Asia, one recent seizure netted ice that had first been shipped to Portland, Ore., and then brought into Honolulu, in an attempt to avoid customs inspection.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: In San Francisco, spokesmen for the Haight-Ashbury Free Medical Clinic and the Larkin Street Center report that speed is the drug most used by young people living on the streets in these areas. Both clinics are concerned that ice will take its place.
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: ''We've been hearing about it from kids with a real sense of excitement,'' said Michael Shriver, a substance abuse counsellor at Larkin Street. Young people report that the drug is showing up on the streets and it's believed to come from Los Angeles and is known as L.A. crystal. ''They think it's a drug from heaven because of the long duration of the high. We're really scared about what will happen.''
title: Fear Grows Over Effects of a New Smokable Drug

text: In a chic neighborhood in Bogota, young executives gather in private clubs, set in mansions and fashionable apartments to smoke a powerful and extremely addictive form of cocaine.
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: Tens of thousands of other middle- and upper-class Colombians regularly smoke and sniff cocaine in their homes while thousands of the wretchedly poor take drugs in back alleys, cardboard hovels and in broken-down buildings reminiscent of the shooting galleries of American inner cities.
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: ''We always thought the drug problem was a United States problem,'' said Andres Pastrana, Mayor of Bogota. ''But we now have a big problem.''
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: Dr. Augusto Perez Gomez, one of Colombia's leading experts on drug consumption, estimates that the country of 30 million has more than 500,000 regular users of cocaine, while another 800,000 regularly use marijuana. Highest Drug Use in Medellin
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: ''The figures are a little astonishing,'' Dr. Perez said. ''They're more or less the same, in proportion, as those for consumption in the U.S.''
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: According to 1988 figures from the National Institute of Drug Abuse, the number of cocaine users per capita in the United States and Colombia is comparable, but marijuana use is almost twice as prevalent in the United States.
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: Government officials say cocaine use is particularly acute in Colombia's cities but is also increasing rapidly in rural areas. Drug use is highest in Medellin, the center of Colombia's cocaine trafficking, followed by Cali, the second important trafficking city, and Bogota.
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: Consumption of cocaine is also acknowledged as a serious problem by officials in Peru and Bolivia, the two main sources of the coca leaves that yield the essence of cocaine. Colombia grows little coca but refines 80 percent of the cocaine that reaches the United States.
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: Not long ago, Colombian officials maintained that if the country had any problem with consumption at all it was among the poorest of the poor. But Mayor Pastrana said a study completed a few months ago showed that most of Colombia's regular users were members of the middle and upper classes. Easy Access for the Elite
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: Some of the most graceful parks in Bogota have been taken over by cocaine sellers and users. Dealers saunter around university campuses and the most treacherous alleys and streets in the slums.
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: But for the elite, making a purchase requires only a phone call.
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: ''You tell them your name and a messenger on a motorcycle brings you your package in 10 minutes,'' said Angela F., a 42-year-old architect. ''You can call 24 hours a day and you pay with a check or credit card.''
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: By far the most popular form of cocaine here is a lethal semi-refined substance laced with traces of gasoline, hydrochloric acid and lime. The substance is smoked, usually mixed with tobacco, and gives an exhilarating, almost instantaneous high. It is highly addictive, and doctors say heavy use can cause brain damage.
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: The effects of the drug, known here as ''basuco,'' or base of coca, are similar to those of crack. Like crack, basuco is cheaper than refined cocaine, but its use becomes so incessant that the poor turn to crime and the wealthy plunge into bankruptcy.
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: ''The first hit is wonderful,'' said Angela F., who is recovering from addiction. ''Your mood changes immediately. But it lasts only a few minutes. Then you start a process of anguish. Your heart pumps like crazy. ''At the beginning, you're having fun,'' she said. ''But then it becomes a nightmare. You cannot deal with life without it.''
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: Experts say many Colombians who use cocaine do so in combination with marijuana and whisky use - or, among poorer people, sniffing glue or gasoline.
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: The penalty for possession of as little as a gram of cocaine can be up to 12 years in jail. But doctors, researchers and users say that few people are arrested and that the police happily accept bribes of as little as $10 to let users go. On a radio talk show here this week, several people complained of police officers selling cocaine.
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: For the elite, a kind of sexless brothel has sprung up on the quiet, tree-shaded streets of Chico, a stylish neighborhood on the north side of Bogota, where a patron might spend as much as $1,000 for a night of drinking whisky and smoking cocaine, with women rolling drug-spiked cigarettes as fast as they can be smoked.
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: There are about 50 such houses, Dr. Perez said. They are marked only with their addresses. Visitors are scrutinized through a peephole and admitted only on referral. Inside, the lights are low, the furnishings often exquisite.
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: ''They are like very elegant bars,'' Dr. Perez said. ''When you enter, they take your credit card and ask you to sign a blank charge slip. You get a bottle of Scotch for $100 and two women to roll cigarettes with cocaine. The women are prostitutes but there is no sex because the men are impotent when they smoke.'' Dozens of Cigarettes a Night
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: Customers smoke dozens of cigarettes in a night, Dr. Perez said. ''The women smoke, too,'' he said. ''The man has no way of knowing how much he has smoked. He just pays whatever they say.''
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: Experts on consumption say cocaine use in Colombia nearly parallels the beginning of cocaine exports to the United States in the late 1970's and early 80's. Peasants working in cocaine refining and shipping were paid partially in basuco. The peasants began using it and also selling it to workers in nearby coffee fields. Eventually it spread to the cities. Some wealthy urbanites had been dabbling in the use of pure cocaine. But basuco cut across all classes like a brush fire.
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: Colombia's two drug cartels say they do not sell cocaine domestically and are only interested in the more lucrative export market. Researchers say they are not certain of that, but they believe most domestic supplies come from relatively small, independent producers and distributors.
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: Probably nowhere in the world is cocaine cheaper and more easily available than in Colombia. Researchers and users say a gram of basuco, which can be used to make up to eight cigarettes, sells for as little as $2.50. A gram of pure cocaine goes for just under $4.
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: ''You can be any place in Bogota,'' Dr. Perez said, ''and be sure that within a radius of 100 yards you will find basuco.''
title: In Colombia, Cocaine Is the Elixir for Rich and Poor

text: Lest any hasty or careless reader of your excellent Economic Watch account of my work on Federal marijuana enforcement (Sept. 5) might have received a misimpression about my views on legalization, allow me to state them briefly.
title: Give the Poor Better Choices Than Drug Dealing and Addiction; Dangers of Abuse

text: If marijuana were legally available, as alcohol and tobacco are legally available, it might be nearly as widely used and abused, particularly by adolescents, as alcohol and tobacco now are. In my view, that would be a bad result, so bad as to overwhelm whatever cost savings and revenue gains legalization would bring. Cutting back on Federal marijuana enforcement seems to me an obviously wise step with very limited risk. Legalization, by contrast, would be a high-risk gamble against unknown odds. MARK KLEIMAN Cambridge, Mass., Sept. 8, 1989 The writer is lecturer in public policy, Kennedy School, Harvard University.
title: Give the Poor Better Choices Than Drug Dealing and Addiction; Dangers of Abuse

text: By Bernard Weinraub, Special To the New York Times
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: President Bush pleaded with young people around the nation today to stop using drugs and ''not to look the other way'' when others do.
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: In a 15-minute nationally televised plea from the White House library, the President presented the latest round of an anti-drug campaign that began a week ago with another nationally broadcast message announcing a $7.9 billion package.
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: But less than a mile from the White House, a 7-year-old boy who heard the President shook his head and suggested that the President's argument was too simple.
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: Selton Shaw, who watched the President's speech with his classmates at Stevens Elementary School, said many youngsters in his own neighborhood, many as young as 7, were drug users.
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: ''They're so addicted they never listen to me,'' said the boy, who said he had declined offers of drugs.''If my mother did drugs, I'd tell her to get help. If she didn't, I'd call the police because I'd already given her the one chance.'' Death Close to Home
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: A teacher asked how many of the youngsters knew someone who had died or been killed as a result of drug use. More than half of the pupils raised their hands.
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: In schools around the nation, students voiced doubt, indifference, cynicism and some interest after the speech.
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: The President's drug package calls for more prosecutors, more prisons, stiffer sentences for drug sellers and users and aid to nations fighting drug rings. In speaking directly to the young, Mr. Bush adopted a different approach, reaching out to the potential victims of the drug epidemic.
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: At least 15,000 superintendents and 55,000 principals were notified by the Education Department of the speech today, and many schools held assemblies or brought television sets into classrooms so students could watch Mr. Bush. 'Won't Make You a Nerd'
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: In the speech, Mr. Bush said that saying no to drugs ''won't make you a nerd.''
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: ''Presidents don't often get the chance to talk directly to students,'' Mr. Bush said. ''So today, for each of you sitting in a classroom or assembly hall, this message goes straight to you.
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: ''Most of you are doing the right thing. But for those of you who let drugs make their decisions for them, you can almost hear the doors slamming shut.''
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: Equating drugs with death and displaying the badge of a slain 22-year-old rookie policeman, Mr. Bush said, ''I keep this badge in a drawer in my desk to remind me of that.''
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: The badge belonged to a New York City police officer, Edward Byrne, who was killed in 1988 while protecting a witness in a drug case. Mr. Byrne's father presented the badge to Mr. Bush last year in a Presidential campaign appearance in New York.
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: ''In the early hours of a cold February morning, sitting in a police cruiser, Eddie was blown away at point-blank range, killed on the order of a drug kingpin. Cold and calculated,'' Mr. Bush said. ''To me this badge is a constant reminder that Eddie Byrne's life was not given in vain.'' A Plea to Help Friends
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: Mr. Bush coupled his warnings against drug use with a plea that students help troubled friends. ''I'm asking you not to look the other way,'' he said.
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: But around the nation, in Teaneck, N.J.; Boston; West Hartford, Conn., and Atlanta, in predominantly middle-class schools as well as those in poorer urban areas, the speech stirred a mixture of interest and applause for Mr. Bush's commitment to fighting drugs along with a measure of skepticism about what the President's words would ultimately achieve.
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: At Teaneck High School, six students in Stanley Zak's advanced television-production class taped the President's speech for future use by other Teaneck schools. All said they wholeheartedly supported the President's speech, but they seemed uneasy and uncertain about carrying out his appeal to help those on drugs.
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: ''It's hard to get help for your friends if they don't want help,'' said Jamala Gaither, a junior. ''A friend of mine who was into drugs - he wouldn't listen to me. He just lied and denied it.''
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: Most of the 22 fifth- and sixth-graders in Andrea Lazaroski's class at the Whiting Lane School in West Hartford, Conn., found the story of Officer Byrne's murder particularly touching.
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: The unanimity stopped, however, when the students were asked whether the speech would make a difference. Hands shot up. ''Some people do it just because people say, 'don't do it,' '' said Pleasance Lowengard, a sixth grader.
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: Some children in the group, all 10 to 12 years old, thought the President should have included alcohol in his message. Indeed, based on the 45-minute discussion that followed the President's speech, most of the students had seen far more evidence of alcohol abuse, in their own families or in those of their friends, than they had from cocaine, marijuana or heroin. Where Can They Go? In James P. Timilty Middle School in the predominantly black Roxbury section of Boston, Edward M. Considine, the eighth-grade social studies teacher, said, ''It was a big step foward for the President to just be there and bring the problem out in the open, for a leader in our country to say, I know we have a problem.''
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: But he added: ''What I didn't hear is what are these youngsters going to do if they don't do drugs. These kids are still living in the projects where the dealers, drugs and guns are. Where can they go if they decide to say no?''
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: In Atlanta, seventh- and eighth-graders at Christ the King School, a Catholic parochial school, generally thought the President was taking the right approach to the drug problem, but some wondered if his efforts would be successful. The students were mostly white, from middle-class and upper middle-class families.
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: ''People kids look up to are actors, movie stars, sports stars,'' said Leslie Bumgarner, a seventh-grader. ''They are better role models than the President, so kids would pay more attention to them. If they do drugs, kids will think it's cool. If they don't, that's a good example.''
title: Bush Urges Youngsters to Help Friends on Drugs

text: The police officers who subdued a mugging suspect before he died at their feet in the Bronx Saturday told investigators yesterday that they struggled eight or nine minutes against fierce resistance to handcuff the man and that he fought on even after being manacled.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: Investigators said the officers acknowleged using force - including night sticks, their feet and Chemical Mace - to subdue the thrashing, kicking 25-year-old man, Henry Hughes, on a sidewalk at Southern Boulevard near East 163d Street in the Hunts Point section at about 5:45 A.M. Saturday.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: But in their fullest account of the incident, the police said eight city and transit police officers had apparently not used excessive force and rejected accounts by some witnesses that the officers had beaten the black suspect to death in a half-hour of violence punctuated by racial slurs.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: ''Somebody may have seen an officer hit his legs with a night stick to stop him from bucking and thought he was beating him,'' said Alice T. McGillion, the Deputy Police Commissioner for Public Information. ''There may have been force, but it was not excessive.''
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: After linking Mr. Hughes's wrists behind him with two lengths of handcuffs, investigators said, the officers held down his neck and legs with their feet and summoned a sergeant, who brought Velcro strips that they intended to use to bind the man's legs.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: But by the time the sergeant arrived, Mr. Hughes was not moving, and within minutes he was pronounced dead. The police said he had tried to break into a police car and an ambulance before the mugging that led to his arrest, and they said a small quantity of cocaine and $126, including a $100 bill, were found in his pockets.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: The precise cause of the man's death was still a mystery yesterday. The New York City Medical Examiner's office had said Sunday that preliminary autopsy results found cuts and bruises, but no broken bones or internal injuries that would have indicated a severe beating.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: The Medical Examiner, Dr. Charles S. Hirsch, declined yesterday to amplify on that assessment, but he said further details would be made public later in the week as toxicological and histological studies were completed. Toxicological tests seek the presence of drugs or alcohol, while histological studies examine skin tissue for clues to illness.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: Witnesses, meantime, continued to give the police and reporters sharply conflicting versions of what had happened, with some contending that Mr. Hughes had been brutally beaten to death and others contending that the police had behaved with moderation under the circumstances.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: Besides questions about the extent of force, there were conflicting accounts by witnesses over what the officers said and did at the scene. And the police and the Emergency Medical Service disagreed about the exact time Mr. Hughes was pronounced dead, though the differences were probably the result of confusion over reports from two ambulances.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: The police said its investigators had found 12 witnesses from among residents and workers in the area. Some described a prolonged scene of struggle that they regarded as brutal and needlessly violent, while others told of a struggle in which Mr. Hughes thrashed about and the police used a reasonable amount of force to subdue him.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: The case is under investigation by the Bronx District Attorney's office as well as the Police Department's Internal Affairs Division.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: Reconstructing the episode from statements by the four city police officers who helped subdue Mr. Hughes, investigators said it began with a purse-snatching at 5:13 A.M. in the IRT subway station at Hunts Point Avenue, Bruckner Boulevard and 163d Street. Ambulance Called
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: Four transit police officers - a white man, a black man, a Hispanic man and a black woman - responded, along with two city officers, a white man and a Hispanic woman. They found that the victim had been struck on the back and slightly injured, so they called an ambulance.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: Later, as they accompanied the victim to the street, the officers saw a man who proved to be Mr. Hughes trying to break into the city police car. They chased him away, but when the ambulance arrived, he reappeared and banged with his fists on the door.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: While the officers waited on a traffic island at the center of the big intersection, they heard a woman scream on the southwest corner of Bruckner Boulevard and 163d Street, and they saw Mr. Hughes running away from the woman, heading west on the south side of 163d Street.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: The white male transit officer gave chase on foot, while the other three transit officers jumped in their van, and the city officers into their patrol car, to pursue the mugging suspect. The city officers reported the development by radio at 5:43 A.M.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: Mr. Hughes ran west one block to Southern Boulevard, crossed the boulevard and inexplicably bashed into -and shattered - a plexiglass door at 936 Southern Boulevard, about 80 feet south of 163d Street. Joined in Pursuit
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: As he got up, the city officers emerged from their car and joined the transit officer in pursuit on foot. Mr. Hughes ran 60 feet north along the sidewalk but was caught and brought down 20 feet from the 163d Street intersection.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: This chase lasted only a minute or two, and the police estimated that the struggle with Mr. Hughes began at 5:44 or 5:45. The officers said Mr. Hughes kicked, thrashed and tried to strike them while they grappled with his flailing arms and legs and, in an attempt to subdue him, struck him with their night sticks.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: Several residents of the six-story brick building at 1018 East 163d Street, whose windows directly overlook the scene of the struggle, heard noises below and went to their windows to watch. Marilyn Merced, 22, a Manhattan secretary, said she watched the whole episode from her fourth-floor window and saw no excessive violence.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: ''They were trying to handcuff him and he was trying to get away,'' she recalled. ''I don't know if he fell or they pushed him down.'' She said he was face down on the sidewalk and his body was bouncing as if in the throes of a seizure. She heard him emit a ''gargling noise,'' but did not hear him shout for help, and said she heard the officers curse him, but not with racial remarks.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: ''I didn't hear any racial things,'' she said.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: Another resident of the building, who gave her name only as Mae, said she had watched from a sixth-floor window and heard no racial slurs either. She described moderate use of force by the police, not a beating. One officer, she said, just pressed his foot down on the man's back but did not stomp him.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: But other residents who saw the struggle described more excessive force. ''He was lying on the ground and they kept hitting him,'' said Maria Jiminez, a fifth-floor resident. ''It lasted at least 20 to 25 minutes. He kept saying, 'Help me, help me,' but the police, forget it, they kept hitting him.''
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: From her third-floor window, Nellie Gaetan saw it, too. ''They were definitely beating him up,'' she said. She said the female officer had her foot on the man's head and was grinding down on it ''like a person putting out a cigarette,'' while a male officer was kicking the man in the back. Heard the Commotion
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: Several other witnesses - men waiting for buses at the intersection or patronizing a pizza parlor across 163d Street - heard the commotion and went out to see what was happening. They all said the police were beating Mr. Hughes.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: Miguel Flores and Victor Vega, who deliver carpets, said they saw the incident from 25 feet away. They said the police were beating the man with night sticks in the groin, on the head and on other parts of the body. They said that when bystanders approached and pleaded with the officers to stop, they were chased away by a male officer who drew his gun.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: ''They were kicking him, hitting him with night sticks, beating him to death,'' said Steven Perez, who saw it from the street. And Renaldo Oquendo said the police had beaten the man for more than a half-hour. ''They were treating him like an animal.''
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: The police, denying these assertions of excessive force, said six officers attempting to subdue Mr. Hughes had called for assistance during the struggle. Two officers from the 41st Precinct - a black man and an Asian-American man - arrived and joined the effort. Continued to Thrash
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: Investigators said the officers finally got the handcuffs on Mr. Hughes at about 5:53. But because he continued to thrash, they decided to call for a supervising sergeant, who would have Velcro ties to bind the suspect's legs.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: The sergeant arrived shortly after 6 A.M., but by then the man was not moving. They called for an ambulance at 6:02, but two minutes later, the ambulance that had been summoned for the initial mugging was passing and they flagged it down.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: The ambulance crew pronounced Mr. Hughes dead at 6:04 A.M. The ambulance did not take his body away, and another ambulance, arriving in response to the officers' call, arrived at 6:18 and that crew also pronounced the victim dead, causing some temporary confusion about the time.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: Mr. Hughes, who lived at 120-34 Elgar Place in Co-op City, was paroled last June 15 after serving nearly four years in prison for convictions for selling drugs and possessing marijuana. He previously had served six months in 1986 for possessing narcotics in Manhattan and had a criminal record including grand larceny and reckless endangerment dating to 1982.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: The eight officers in the incident have been reassigned to desk jobs and relieved of their weapons and police shields, pending the outcome of the investigtion. Edward McCarthy, a spokesman for the Bronx District Attorney, Robert T. Johnson, said his office's inquiry was continuing.
title: Police Say Force Used on Suspect Who Died Was Not Excessive

text: Seven out of 10 Americans approve of President Bush's strategy to fight drugs, and 6 out of 10 say they think that the plan, if enacted, will significantly reduce the nation's drug problem, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: Even so, there was division on whether Mr. Bush would succeed in curbing illegal drug sales and use and whether his spending priorities were the right ones.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: But despite those differences there was striking public agreement about the priority that drugs should command on the national agenda.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: The proportion of Americans who cited drugs as the nation's most important problem has nearly tripled since the end of July, to 64 percent from 22 percent. The rise came after weeks of sustained news coverage of the worsening crack epidemic and the turmoil caused by cocaine barons in Colombia and after Mr. Bush's address to the nation Tuesday when he outlined his anti-drug policy.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: The percentage was the highest recorded for any single issue since the Times/CBS News poll began in 1976 and is one of the highest registered by any major national survey. A National Consensus
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: Americans in every region and every income level reported that in some way illegal drugs had intruded upon their lives. Forty-eight percent of the adults questioned said they knew someone who had been ''seriously affected'' by illegal drugs, either through that person's drug use or another's. Twenty-eight percent said they knew of a specific drug seller or a place in their community where drugs were sold.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: The nationwide telephone poll of 824 adults began Sept. 6, the night after Mr. Bush's speech, and concluded Sept. 8. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: Over all, 69 percent said they approved of Mr. Bush's drug package, and 56 percent said that if it was enacted the plan would lead to a ''significant reduction'' in the drug problem. Seventy-three percent said they believed it was possible to significantly reduce the drug problem, while 19 percent said it was beyond control.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: But there was division over whether Mr. Bush would actually reach his goal. Thirty-eight percent said he would be able to reduce the drug problem, but 44 percent said he would not.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: Forty-seven percent of those surveyed said they had heard or seen Mr. Bush's speech, and of that group, 81 percent said they approved of his plan.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: The program calls for higher spending in areas like building new prisons and increasing military and economic aid to Bolivia, Colombia and Peru, the primary sources of cocaine shipped into the United States. Roughly 70 percent of the money is earmarked for law enforcement and 30 percent for treatment and education. Forty-three percent of those surveyed said there was too much emphasis on law enforcement rather than on root causes of drug use like poverty and unemployment; 42 percent said the emphasis was appropriate.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: The public was sharply divided on whether Mr. Bush's proposed $7.9 billion was an appropriate sum to fight drugs. The largest fraction, 38 percent, said it was the ''right amount.'' But 22 percent said it was ''too little'' and 16 percent said it was ''too much.''
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: There was general agreement that the Federal Government should spend more than in the past to combat drugs. Fifty-six percent said that in general they favored such higher spending, and 39 percent even said they would be willing to pay $100 a year more in taxes to increase the budget for drug programs, although Mr. Bush has pledged not to raise taxes.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: While there was widespread familiarity with illegal narcotics among most age levels, most striking was the high percentage of young adults who reported being touched by drugs.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: Among the 18- to 29-year-olds, 45 percent said they knew of a place in their community where illegal drugs were sold, or of a person who sold them. The figure dropped to 27 percent among 30- to 44-year-olds and to 26 percent among 45- to 64-year-olds.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: Twenty-eight percent of the 18- to 29-year-olds said they had seen drugs sold in their neighborhood, as did 12 percent of those who are 30 to 64 years old.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: There were clear generational patterns among those who said they had tried illegal drugs. Over all, 28 percent of those surveyed said they had tried an illegal drug, but the figure rose to 38 percent among 30- to 44-year-olds and 50 percent among 18- to 29-year-olds.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: Mr. Bush's program puts new emphasis on punishing not only drug sellers but also drug users. Still, 47 percent of those surveyed said the sellers were more responsible than users for the nation's drug problem. Thirty-one percent said the users were more responsible, and 20 percent said the groups were equally to blame.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: Sixty-one percent of those surveyed endorsed requiring ''workers in general'' to be tested for illegal drug use, a point stressed in Mr. Bush's plan. In a Times/CBS News poll in August 1986 only 44 percent favored such a policy. In the recent poll 24 percent said testing of workers would be an unfair invasion of privacy, a sharp decline from the 44 percent of three years ago.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: Sixty-two percent said they would favor mandatory drug testing for high school students, while 27 percent said it would be an unfair invasion of privacy.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: Mr. Bush's plan calls for a major increase in expanding Federal prisons for drug offenders, as well as stiffer penalties for drug users convicted for the first time. Eighty-four percent of those questioned said first offenders should be sent to treatment programs, while 8 percent said they should be imprisoned. Seventy percent said jail should be mandatory for repeat offenders, while 16 percent favored treatment. Replies From Drug Users
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: Those who say they have tried illegal drugs are as likely as all adults to approve of Mr. Bush's plan. Sixty-four percent said of that group supported it, as against 69 percent of all adults surveyed.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: But those who report having ever used drugs were more likely to say that law enforcement gets too much emphasis, as against treatment and education.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: In addition, 75 percent of those who have tried drugs at some time said that someone who smoked marijuana occasionally should not be prosecuted, while 50 percent of the general public gave that response.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: Mr. Bush has said he would not send troops to Colombia in a combat role, although White House officials said they would consider such a request if Colombia's President made it.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: If there was such a request, 42 percent of those surveyed said the United States should send the troops, while 47 percent said it should not. Support for dispatching soldiers fell to 34 percent if the troops could be in Colombia for a year or more.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: The poll showed that Mr. Bennett, a former Secretary of Education, is still not well known among the public. Seventy-three of those surveyed said they ''didn't know enough'' about him to have an opinion, 11 percent said they had a favorable opinion and 3 percent unfavorable.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: For Mr. Bush, however, the approval rating was 70 percent, up from 61 percent in June, but statistically indistinguishable from the 67 percent registered in July.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: Until the latest poll, the highest percentage of Americans listing a single issue in the Times/CBS Poll was in October 1979, when 52 percent cited the economy. In the Gallup Poll, which asks people to list more than one problem issue facing the country, 81 percent cited inflation in October 1974.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: No current issue approaches drugs for capturing the public's interest as a major problem. The economy was a distant second in the Times/CBS News poll, cited by only 5 percent, followed by the poor, with 3 percent. In the Times survey six weeks ago, 22 percent cited drugs as the most important problem, followed by 9 percent for the deficit and 8 percent for unemployment and jobs.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: When asked in a separate question for the most important problem facing the community they live in, the public mentioned drugs more than any other topic, with 35 percent saying it was the most important local problem.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: George C. Edward 3d, a professor of political science at Texas A & M University who has studied public opinion and the presidency, said: ''The President is exploiting the moment, if you will, and I use that in a positive sense Normally, a President is not able to set the agenda quite so easily.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: ''But there has not been a lot of news in domestic policy recently and, rather remarkably, the media has given a tremendous amount of attention not only to the President's speech but to specials on drugs.'' How the Poll on Drugs Was Taken
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 6-8 with 824 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened to limit calls to residences.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: The percentages reported are the particular results most likely to match what would be obtained by seeking out all adult Americans. Other possible percentages are progressively less likely the more they differ from the reported results.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for people who are 18 to 29 years old it is plus or minus seven percentage points.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.
title: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Back Bush Strategy on Drugs

text: The New York City Medical Examiner's office said yesterday that based on preliminary findings, a man who died in police custody on Saturday received no injuries that could have caused his death, but only minor cuts and bruises.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: But the Medical Examiner's office declined to give a detailed account of what the minor injuries were and would not comment on the cause of death, pending the completion of toxicological and histological reports.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: The preliminary findings, if borne out, would seem to contradict several witnesses who said at least two police officers in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx severely beat Henry Hughes, a 25-year-old black man, kicking him in the head and pounding him with nightsticks while shouting racial slurs.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: Some witnesses said two officers, a white man and a Hispanic woman, first captured Mr. Hughes and beat him. The police said eight officers - four city police officers and four transit officers - were eventually at the scene. The four city officers were a black man, a white man, an Asian man and a Hispanic woman, and the transit officers were a white man, a black man, a Hispanic man and a black woman, the police said.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: In another development yesterday in the confusing case, one witness said she had seen Mr. Hughes's encounter with the police but had seen no beating. And she and another witness said they had heard no racial slurs.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: In addition, the Police Department and the Emergency Medical Services, which runs the city's ambulances, say Mr. Hughes was pronounced dead at the scene, but the times of death the two agencies give are 21 minutes apart.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: The incident on the streets of the South Bronx began just after 5 A.M., the police say, when officers responded to a purse-snatching at the Hunts Point Avenue subway station at Bruckner Boulevard and 163d Street.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: At 5:43 A.M., a second woman screamed just outside the subway station, awakening residents in their apartments and alerting the eight police officers who were helping the first woman. The police spotted Mr. Hughes running across the intersection of Southern Boulevard and 163d Street, and all eight began to chase him, by foot and car.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: What happened next is uncertain. It is not clear when all eight officers caught up with Mr. Hughes or how long the initial officers were alone with him.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: Capt. Stephen Davis, a police spokesman, said two city officers - described by most witnesses as a Hispanic woman and a white man - first caught Mr. Hughes a short distance away, just after he crashed into a Plexiglas door at 935 Southern Boulevard, shattering it, and ran another 60 feet. Witnesses and Police Disagree
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: Within two minutes, Captain Davis said, the six other officers arrived. But several witnesses said the two officers were alone with Mr. Hughes, beating him, for as long as half an hour. Other witnesses said a beating occurred before and after the six other officers arrived.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: Captain Davis said that force was necessary and that at least one officer used a nightstick to subdue the suspect, who was violently resisting them.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: Sgt. Maurice Howard, a police spokesman, last night said the four city officers were Brendan Sullivan, Triffton W. Rose, Carmen O. Koota and Trenton K. Persaud. He said he did not know which officers were of which ethnicity.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: The transit police would not release the names of its four officers.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: According to police records, Mr. Hughes, of 120-34 Elgar Place in Co-op City in the Bronx, was arrested four times since 1982 on charges including grand larceny and reckless endangerment. At the time of his death, he was on parole from a two-to-four-year sentence for criminal sale of narcotics and unlawful possession of marijuana. #21-Minute Difference The police said their radio transmissions showed that at 5:52 A.M., with all eight officers present, one called for a supervisor. At 6:02 A.M., a sergeant from the 41st Precinct arrived, saw that Mr. Hughes was not moving and requested an ambulance. Moments later, however, the officers flagged down the ambulance leaving the scene of the subway mugging. The ambulance technicians pronounced Mr. Hughes dead at 6:04 A.M., Mr. Davis said.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: But the Emergency Medical Service could not explain yesterday why their records showed that death was pronounced at 6:25 A.M. when the police said 6:04. An E.M.S. spokeswoman, Lynn Schulman, said their account was the same, except for the time of death, with the police at the scene hailing the ambulance.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: ''We're sticking with the 6:25,'' she said, adding that the ambulance stopped to check on Mr. Hughes a few minutes before he was pronounced dead. ''I'm sure we'll work out the discrepancies during the investigation,'' she said. ''Maybe the police went by what their watches said, and that can be confusing. We have it on computer,'' Ambulance Crew Questioned
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: Ms. Schulman said the ambulance crew was questioned by the Bronx District Attorney's office and the Police Department.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: The Bronx District Attorney's office and the Police Department's Internal Affairs division are investigating Mr. Hughes's death. The eight police officers involved were removed from regular duty and given desk jobs for the length of the investigation.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: Ellen S. Borakove, the director of public affairs for the New York City Medical Examiner's office, said the autopsy showed that Mr. Hughes's physical injuries, consisting of minor cuts and bruises, neither contributed to nor caused his death.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: ''There were no injuries that caused damage to his internal organs,'' she said. ''There were no bone fractures. He had some cuts from the glass door that he went into and some superficial bruises. At this point we don't know how he died. This is a preliminary report. The final cause of death will be given later this week,'' when the toxicological and histological findings should be complete.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: Toxicological tests look for the presence of drugs and alcohol; histological studies look for illness or other physiological problems by examining skin tissue under a microscope.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody
