text: Ms. Borakove would not say how many bruises Mr. Hughes had or where they were located. Time Difference Is Stressed
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: The lawyer for two of the witnesses, C. Vernon Mason, challenged the Medical Examiner's report. ''The Medical Examiner's office has been the vehicle that the Police Department has employed to exonerate officers from this kind of conduct, from killing civilians,'' Mr. Mason said. ''When you have a case where a man was thrown through glass, kicked in the groin and beaten in the head repeatedly for a period of 30 minutes, then you have a cover-up,'' he said.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: Mr. Mason also seized upon the time discrepancy, charging the police with trying to minimize the time the officers were alone with Mr. Hughes. Witnesses' Accounts Differ
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: Witnesses who viewed the scene from the street and apartment windows gave differing accounts of the encounter between the police and Mr. Hughes.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: Several said on Saturday that there was a prolonged attack in which the police threw Mr. Hughes through the Plexiglas door, used racial epithets and beat the man as he lay handcuffed on the ground. But one woman said yesterday that she saw no attack.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: Marilyn Merced, of 1018 163d Street, who said she watched the entire encounter from her fourth-floor window, said she saw no excessive force and heard no racial remarks. What she did describe, however, was an apparent convulsive fit by Mr. Hughes.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: ''Once he was on the ground, a cop was poking him in the side with a nightstick,'' said Ms. Merced, a secretary who works in Manhattan. ''Then he started making a gurgling noise, like when someone has an epileptic attack. He was shaking so much, that's what bothered me. One officer put his foot on his back, and two others tried to keep him down.''
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: A woman who watched from her window in the building and gave her name only as Mae said she heard no racial slurs during the course of the struggle. Although she did not describe a beating, she recounted a forceful restraint by police as well as apparent convulsive movements by Mr. Hughes. ''They held him down while he was gasping and coughing,'' she said, adding that the police officers ''stomped'' on his back while ''his body kept bouncing up and down.''
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: Another witness, Renaldo Oquendo, of the same building, said two police officers were ''stepping on his head, kicking him and treating him like an animal'' while they beat him handcuffed for more than a half hour. Tried to Intervene
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: Two witnesses, Victor Vega and Miguel Flores, co-workers who were waiting for a bus when, they said, they saw the incident, said Saturday they and several others tried to intervene but one of the two police officers waved them away, holding his gun in the air and cursing.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: Mr. Vega and Mr. Flores, while delivering a carpet to an apartment building at 4 Park Avenue in Manhattan later that morning, recounted the episode to a man they met in the elevator, Frank Weston. Mr. Weston put the workers in touch with a friend, Mr. Mason, a civil rights lawyer.
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: The two leading Democratic mayoral candidates said yesterday that more facts needed to be learned about the incident. Mayor Edward I. Koch said: ''There seems to be a difference of opinion, not only on the part of the cops, but on the part of the witnesses. I have no opinion. It will all go before a grand jury.'' Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan said: ''Any death is tragic. We don't yet know the facts and circumstances. What we need is a swift and thorough investigation.''
title: Report Finds Only Minor Injuries To Suspect Who Died in Custody

text: WHAT AM I DOING HERE By Bruce Chatwin. 367 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.
title: HOME WAS WHERE THE ROAD WAS

text: Obsessed with the life of nomads, about which he wrote with insight and tenderness, Bruce Chatwin was himself the essential wanderer, who roamed the world for decades. Although he was forever pitching his tent somewhere new, he was not exactly a ''travel writer''; the phrase irritated him because it suggested too insular an attitude toward the planet. Home was everywhere. All countries, in his mind, shared a common frontier. And the people he ran into on his travels were usually eccentric, improbable and exotic, whether they lived in the groomed drawing rooms of France or slept under an arbor of stars in so-called primitive lands. Before he died in January, from what he described as ''a very rare Chinese fungus of the bone marrow,'' he put together ''What Am I Doing Here,'' a miscellaneous collection of his travel essays, reminiscences and fiction that contains some of his finest writing.
title: HOME WAS WHERE THE ROAD WAS

text: In ''The Coup,'' Chatwin tells of a visit to the dilapidated former slaving towns on the coast of Benin, where he was arrested as a suspected mercenary, strip-searched and forced to stand against a wall in the raging sun, under a circling of vultures, while an angry crowd chanted ''Death to Mercenaries!'' Such events prompted him to write a novel, ''The Viceroy of Ouidah'' (1980), which is set in that sort of cinematic locale.
title: HOME WAS WHERE THE ROAD WAS

text: When Werner Herzog decided to film the book, he invited Chatwin to visit the set in Africa. But by now the writer's illness had left him too frail to walk and climb stairs. He needed a wheelchair, but there was no way to haul one through the jungle. Instead, as Chatwin reports in ''Werner Herzog in Ghana,'' the director offered to provide him with ''four hammockeers and a sunshade bearer,'' and the ceremonial suavity of the gesture was impossible to refuse. Chatwin went, and took notes, sketching a wonderfully zany portrait of Mr. Herzog, a contradictory man with a ''laughing-skull tattoo on his shoulder,'' a mystical belief in ''the sacramental aspect of walking'' and an apparent penchant for organized disorder. ''The Viceroy of Ouidah,'' which concerns one of the most successful entrepreneurs in the Brazilian-African slave trade, calls for a re-created 19th-century African court, but Mr. Herzog decided to use an actual contemporary African court instead, hiring the king and his subjects as actors and treating them with ''old-fashioned Germanic courtliness.''
title: HOME WAS WHERE THE ROAD WAS

text: ''Without a hint of condescension,'' Chatwin tells us with combined amusement and esteem, ''he takes a woman by the arm, as if he were escorting her to a ball, and shows her how to walk through the Great Gate. The others follow. For the next shot he says, 'Ladies, you now have the privilege of giving us the best screams.' Or to the king: 'Nana, would you please lean back so we can see your very royal face.' ''
title: HOME WAS WHERE THE ROAD WAS

text: The set required many walls of human skulls, and the villagers made hundreds of them out of plaster, which, because it chips, had to be constantly patched and repainted. Bystanders turned the area into a carnival, selling their candies and hot fritters. One surreptitious young man was peddling something illicit-looking in plastic bags that Chatwin took to be marijuana, only to discover that the packets were full of false teeth. A man walking 40 dogs on a leash was busily buying up even more dogs, which, Chatwin learned, he later sold as food in the north of the country. There was a local watering hole called AYATOLLAH DRINKS BAR.
title: HOME WAS WHERE THE ROAD WAS

text: The movie's star, Klaus Kinski, revealed himself as ''a sexagenarian adolescent all in white with a mane of yellow hair,'' who, managing to irritate everyone, ''leaves a trail of smouldering resentment wherever he goes.'' And then there were the hundreds of rowdy, down-and-dirty, costumed ''Amazons'' from Accra, who slept at the army barracks and made relentless demands on the film crew's pocketbooks and patience. The whole wacky scene would make a wonderful movie itself, with Chatwin held aloft by hammockeers in the midst of the tumult.
title: HOME WAS WHERE THE ROAD WAS

text: Such vignettes are not uncommon in the unfolding pageant of Chatwin's travels. In China, he accompanies a geomancer, who wears ''a blue silk Nina Ricci tie, a gold wristwatch with a crocodile strap, and an immaculate worsted grey suit'' to the new Hongkong and Shanghai Bank, whose builders want him to check it for ''malign or demonic presences.''
title: HOME WAS WHERE THE ROAD WAS

text: Chatwin seemed especially to prefer vibrant, earthy, outspoken, slightly farouche older women. In Russia, for example, he visits the elderly writer Nadezhda Mandelstam, widow of the poet Osip Mandelstam, whose ''hair was coarse, like lichen, and the light from the bedside lamp shone through it. White metal fastenings glittered among the brown stumps of her teeth. A cigarette stuck to her lower lip. Her nose was a weapon. You knew for certain she was one of the most powerful women in the world, and knew she knew it. . . . She waved me to a chair and, as she waved, one of her breasts tumbled out of her nightie. 'Tell me,' she shoved it back, 'are there any grand poets left in your country?' ''
title: HOME WAS WHERE THE ROAD WAS

text: In France, he finds Madeleine Vionnet, the famous dress designer who ''around 1900, rescued other women from the tyranny of the corset,'' invented the bias cut and from 1901 on designed ''seductive peignoirs or tea-gowns: clothes to collapse in before the ordeal of dressing for dinner.'' At 96, Miss Vionnet is spunky and blunt as she reminisces about her salon days and how she fitted her designs to clients from Argentina, women ''with undulating buttocks like carnivores.'' In the Peruvian desert, Chatwin meets Maria Reiche, ''the mad woman with the lines,'' as the locals call her, a German mathematician who has spent almost half her 72 years perched on an aluminum ladder, studying the so-called ''Nazca lines,'' ancient Indian drawings of huge animals sprawled across the flat, dry pampas.
title: HOME WAS WHERE THE ROAD WAS

text: In India, Chatwin travels with Indira Gandhi and then visits a recently captured wolf-boy. In the Himalayas, he searches for signs of the yeti, accompanied by a young Sherpa named Thunder-Lion, who ''had the habit of prefacing his statements with 'I have something to say,' and of closing with 'That is all I have to say.' '' The Sherpas remind him that ''Man's real home is not a house, but the Road,'' a theme that reverberates through all of Chatwin's writings. There are also meditations on restlessness itself, and why we are so driven to wander. And, in a more prosaic vein, Chatwin writes about his brief stint as a young man working at Sotheby's (''Smootherboys as a friend likes to call it'').
title: HOME WAS WHERE THE ROAD WAS

text: Some of Chatwin's other books, such as ''In Patagonia'' and ''The Songlines,'' though full of captivating people and facts, lack structure, are written in a flat style and somehow overlook the ravishing natural environment in which they are set. Chatwin often liked to blur just a little the line between fact and fiction, not entirely choosing one or the other, and not writing historical fiction or so-called faction either. So, for example, we are to understand that ''The Songlines,'' though generally true, has some fictional elements in it - only we don't know where exactly or how many. As a happy reader of both nature's truths and fiction's truths, I prefer knowing which general response is being asked for. When I'm reading about the aborigines, say, am I to be astonished by their inventiveness or by the author's?
title: HOME WAS WHERE THE ROAD WAS

text: In ''What Am I Doing Here,'' Chatwin comes right out and tells us that five of the pieces are short stories, labeling each of them ''A Story'' lest there be any confusion. They're the weakest part of this collection, and they read more like outtakes from his other books than self-contained works of fiction. But many of the essays in ''What Am I Doing Here'' are examples of Chatwin at his best - part observer, part interviewer, part scholar. What brings them alive is his special talent for noticing life's strange, riveting details. He was a born Autolycus, a snapper-up of unconsidered trifles. What comes through in his last book is a life miscellaneous and on the move, traveled on foot, but never pedestrian.
title: HOME WAS WHERE THE ROAD WAS

text: The war on drugs was still being lost on the battlefield of the South Bronx streets yesterday.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: Rebecca Guzman, a 22-year-old prostitute addicted to crack and heroin, hardly paused to ponder when asked whether the anti-drug program President Bush announced in a televised address Tuesday night would have any effect.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: ''Nope,'' she said. ''He can't take it away. It's all over the place.''
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: Miss Guzman, dressed in a lacy black camisole, clutched her crack pipe in her right hand as she leaned against the wall of a ramshackle house on Casanova Street, where statues of Jesus and the Virgin Mary made a small shrine. ''There's so much money in it,'' she said. ''It's worth even more than pornography. Crack 'All Day Long'
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: ''Crack? Yeah, I smoke every day, all day long,'' Miss Guzman said. She and about 14 other addicted prostitutes use the abandoned house, in a part of Hunts Point crowded with long-distance trucks, as a resting place between their labors.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: ''And I do dope twice a day,'' she added, referring to heroin. ''It's maybe $200 a day. I make enough to support my habit and buy some food.''
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: The house on Casanova Street, where the residents say that even the ugly brown dog named Castro smokes, is only one part of a nightmarish world of drugs - mainly crack and heroin - that has taken over the streets of Hunts Point. But the hardened police officers and the handful of embattled residents trying to fight the drug dealers took little real comfort from the President's speech, and the dealers and the junkies showed only scorn. A 'Drop' on Faile Street
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: As dusk fell Wednesday, a young man on a bicycle, his brown trousers rolled halfway up his shins, stopped at an abandoned house on Faile Street, a row of boarded-up buildings that is a center of heavy drug commerce. He approached the abandoned house, near 165th Street, and passed a bundle through a hole in the concrete stoop.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: ''He's dropping,'' said one of two police officers from the 41st Precinct watching from a nearby rooftop. ''That's a new supply of heroin. They usually drop it in packets of 50. They call the brand they sell there 'Tuna.' It's marked on the package. They've all got brand names now. There's Esso, and Stripe. You know. Some people like McDonald's, some people like Burger King.''
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: Almost a dozen men had been waiting in a lot across the street. As the young man on the bicycle hurried off, the men rushed toward the building.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: One after another, they thrust a hand clutching money into the hole in the stoop. When they pulled their hands out, the officer said, they were holding heroin. Stream of Customers
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: Early afternoon, yesterday, the intersection of Seneca and Irvine Streets, another heavy drug location, was crowded. On each corner a knot of young men - steerers, who direct customers to the sales points, and lookouts - waited. A prostitute made up her face from cosmetics and a mirror laid out on the hood of a car. A steady stream of people moved in and out of an abandoned building, buying drugs. Farther down the block, other young men loitered, sometimes bouncing jerkily. A warning whistle from the young men - signaling the approach of a car thought to carry police - would scatter the whole group.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: Asked about the President's announced policy of focusing on dealers and users, one steerer, a tall, husky man with an Afro pick in his hair and a length of 2 by 4 in his hand, said: ''Hey, there's no work. You go looking for a job, they want to pay you $3.50 an hour. New York's expensive, man. You can't live on the breeze. That's why we're selling drugs.''
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: A few steps from the corner, across a garbage-strewn vacant lot, an alcove of an abandoned building housed a shooting gallery, where there was a mattress and the dregs of a bottle of Colt 45 malt liquor, and where addicts could rush to get their fix after buying drugs.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: A scraggily looking man lurched out of the building. ''It's this methadone,'' he complained. ''Got me all messed up on methadone. In jail, that's all you get. You ask for the detox and they give you methadone.'' 'From Here You Die'
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: Frank Salazar, who is 39 and who grew up in the neighborhood, looked at the scene. ''This area is drug infestated, I mean seriously infestated,'' he said. His father and brother still own restaurants there, the San Juan Bar and Hungry Joe's, where addicts sometimes break into the cigarette machines and the jukebox to get quarters to buy crack.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: ''From here you die,'' Mr. Salazar said. ''There's no rehabilitation here.''
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: And the President's program, he was asked.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: ''It's not reality,'' he said. ''Reality is right here.''
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: Gladys Perez, the superintendent of a nearby building on Hunts Point Avenue, said: ''This neighborhood is terrible. You can see they're smoking crack everywhere. Look outside. The prostitutes are dressing right on the street. They're washing. Right here, we've got a lot of little children living. I don't think it's right.''
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: ''People are afraid to be killed if they stand up,'' she said. ''This goes on all day and all night.''
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: Did the President's program give her any hope? ''When I see it, I believe it,'' she said. Shots From a Roof A Police Department special Tactical Narcotics Team swept the area last February, making ''buy and bust'' arrests, in which an undercover officer would buy drugs and a backup team would swoop down on the dealers. Day after day, the narcotics officers gathered up dealers until the back of their van was full, then carted them off for booking. Because the jails are overflowing, the dealers were usually back on the street within 72 hours. On Sunday night, four shots were fired at police officers checking a report of crack sales at 850 Bryant Avenue. The shots came from the nearby rooftop of 1314 Seneca Avenue.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: Residents say the situation has improved, and several crack houses have been shut by the T.N.T. sweep. But many of the same street corners still have the groups of jittery young men that indicate the presence of a crack house.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: ''It's never really going to change,'' said an embittered Bronx narcotics detective. ''The whole system collapsed years ago, and nobody's willing to own up to it.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: ''There's so much money in drugs,'' said the detective, who asked not to be named to avoid trouble with his superiors. ''Power is money and money is power. That's the vicious cycle. When I make retirement in 12 years, the drugs will still be here.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: ''Look at that woman out in Brooklyn that was shot. You think a citizen will want to help us now? And a cop is watching a witness, he gets blown away,'' the detective said, referring to the drug-related killings of Maria Hernandez and Officer Edward Byrne. ''We arrest people, it's a joke. They know we don't have the jail space. I lock you up, you know you're going to be out two days later.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: ''Look what's happening in Colombia. That's what will happen here,'' he said. ''It's already starting to happen. In L.A., these gangs are doing drive-by shootings like it was nothing. The system is fighting a losing battle.'' 'Hundred Grand a Day'
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: A man pumping gas in the trucking district of Hunts Point said: ''There's too much money in it. They'll never stop it. They're making a hundred grand a day, some of these big ones. They got all these corners and got all these kids out. There's high dollars, bro, believe it.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: ''Me? Well, I smoke my herb, it's true,'' he said, although his demeanor suggested this limitation to marijuana may have been an understatement.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: Maria Medina, a 39-year-old Dominican immigrant, comes to Hunts Point each day from the Washington Heights section of Manhattan and sets up a stand by her truck, where she sells sugar cane, avocados and a Caribbean drink, called Mavi, that is fermented from bark. ''It's a good idea to stop the drugs, because it's destroying our world,'' she said.
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: ''I always live in fear here,'' said Mrs. Medina, whose purse has been stolen by addicts. ''Anyone who comes close, you don't know what they're doing. What I fear most is the junkies.''
title: In South Bronx, Drugs Already Claim Victory

text: All New York City police officers, from those on patrol to Commissioner Benjamin Ward, will be subject to periodic random testing for drug use beginning later this month, Police Department officials announced yesterday.
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: Detroit, Miami and Honolulu already have random drug testing for police officers, but New York City, with more than 26,000 officers, is by far the largest department in the nation to adopt such a policy.
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: Police Department officials said that they were not acting out of concern about widespread drug use, but to insure that drugs do not become a problem. 'To Keep It Clean'
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: ''We believe the department's clean,'' said Alice T. McGillion, Deputy Commissioner for Public Information. ''It's just to keep it clean.''
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: Currently, the department tests all new recruits, Police Academy cadets and officers who apply for promotion to detective or to join the Organized Crime Control Bureau, which includes an elite corp of undercover police officers. All officers in the Narcotics Division, which is part of the bureau, have been subject to random testing since last October.
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: Ms. McGillion said the department has been trying to phase in drug testing for certain divisions in the department since 1986 but has been hindered by lawsuits from the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, a union representing police officers.
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: The decision to institute broader testing came after department officials became convinced this summer that recent court decisions had established its legality. ''Now we feel it makes sense,'' to go ahead, said Ms. McGillion.
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: The proposal is expected to draw a strong reaction from the patrolmen's association, which last year sued unsucessfully to stop the random testing of narcotics officers. ''We are examining the order and discussing possible courses of action with the P.B.A.'s attorneys,'' Dennis Sheehan, a spokesman for the P.B.A., said yesterday. ''Until this review is completed, the P.B.A. will have no further comment.''
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: The officers to be tested will be chosen at random by computer and given 24 hours notice before the test, Ms. McGillion said. About 2,600 officers, or 10 percent of the force, will be tested every year for heroin, cocaine and marijuana. If they test positive, they will be tested a second time, using a more accurate technique. If the second test is positive, they will be dismissed, Ms. McGillion said. Any officer who refused to take a test could be dismissed for failing to follow orders.
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: Recruits or cadets who test positive twice are dropped from the training program.
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: Random testing will begin Sept. 18. #37 Officers Test Positive Under a longstanding departmental policy, a police commander can order any officer to be tested if there is a strong reason to believe that the officer is using narcotics. Last year, 3,946 police officers were tested and 37, about 1 percent, had positive results. The deparment also tested 8,818 recruits and police cadets; 161, or about 2 percent, tested positive.
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: None of the 37 officers who tested positive last year had risen above the rank of patrol officer, the police said. Only one was an undercover narcotics officer.
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: The right to conduct random testing of narcotics officers was upheld in a 5-2 decision by the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, in October 1988.
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: The Court of Appeals ruled that narcotics officers have less of a right to privacy than average citizens because they have agreed to work under heightened scrutiny from their employers. The court also ruled that the government had an overriding interest to protect the public's safety because police officers carry guns. Railroad Workers
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: Deputy Inspector Thomas J. Flanagan, commanding officer of the department's Legal Bureau said police officials believe the court's decision can be interpreted to allow the proposed drug testing program.
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: The decision to test police officers also gained impetus from a 7-to-2 United States Supreme Court ruling on March 21 that upheld drug testing programs begun by the Reagan Administration for the railroad industry, Inspector Flanagan said. That case, Skinner v. Railway Labor Executives, concerned an 1985 regulation of the Federal Department of Transportation subjecting all crew members of trains involved in serious accidents to mandatory blood and urine testing.
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: In essence, the court ruled that the ''surpassing safety interests'' of the public outweighed the worker's right to privacy. The decision was widely seen as opening the way for drug testing in the areas of law enforcement, public safety and national security.
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: In a third case cited by Ms. McGillion, the U.S. Court of Appeals in the Third District ruled earlier this year that the Washington Township, N.J., police department had the right to require its officers to submit random drug testing.
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: Darrell Stephens, director of the Police Executive Research Forum, a Washington think tank, said that of the nation's six largest police departments, only Detroit now has random testing.
title: Police Face Drug Testing In New York

text: Cocaine is not the only losing front in the Government's war on drugs. In what experts regard as the most authoritative study of the illegal market for marijuana, a Harvard economist has concluded that the billion-dollar Federal effort to disrupt the trade is a failure.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: Tighter controls at the borders in the Reagan years did indeed reduce imports of marijuana, says the economist, Mark A. R. Kleiman of Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. But he argues that this merely stimulated domestic cultivation and encouraged producers and sellers to put far more potent forms of the drug on the market.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: By cutting back on enforcement, Mr. Kleiman argues, the Government could reverse these two unintended effects and thereby advance the goals of anti-drug policy. Total consumption of delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol or THC, the active ingredient in marijuana, would probably fall, he says. So would the profits of drug traffickers. 'Costs of Control'
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: It is not clear how these conclusions, in Mr. Kleiman's new book, ''Marijuana: Costs of Abuse, Costs of Control'' (Greenwood Press), will be received in Washington.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: There seems to be little sentiment, either in Washington or among the general public, for treating marijuana differently from illegal drugs like cocaine and heroin. On the other hand, Mr. Kleiman's call for a relaxation of the effort to stop marijuana imports may mesh with the Bush Administration's general inclination to spend more of its anti-drug budget on prosecution of drug offenders and treatment of users. President Bush is scheduled to present the Administration's anti-drug strategy in a broadcast speech tonight.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: The Federal war on marijuana, Mr. Kleiman says, has been anchored by the simple idea that one ton confiscated by the Customs Service or the Drug Enforcement Administration is one ton less consumed. In this case, he believes, simplicity is misleading.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: Confiscated marijuana has been replaced at low cost, he says, so the enforcement effort has had little effect on consumption. Moreover, as a closer look at the marijuana market suggests, the border crackdown has given rise to a much more potent form of the drug.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: In the Carter years, Washington's limited effort to disrupt drug imports focused on cocaine and heroin. The Reagan Administration radically altered course, sharply increasing total expenditures on border controls and ending the unofficial policy of ignoring small shipments of marijuana.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: The intensified search for marijuana, Mr. Kleiman reports, reduced imports from about 4,200 tons in 1982 to 3,900 in 1986. The price of the drug went up, compensating shippers and dealers for the added risk of property confiscation and arrest. Adjusted for inflation, the average retail price rose 35 percent, to about $84 an ounce. Still Widely Available
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: Marijuana remains widely available, however, and a dollar still buys enough to get high. And the success in reducing imports has masked the ominous ways in which the market has adjusted.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: The increased cost of importing marijuana stimulated domestic production, which rose 10 percent from 1982 to 1986, by Government estimates. And this infant industry of the 1970's has grown into a healthy giant: one-quarter of the marijuana sold in the United States is now home-grown. As Peter Reuter, an economist at the Rand Corporation, wryly pointed out, ''This is the rare instance in which trade protectionism really worked.''
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: Small-scale domestic producers, lacking farmland they can easily conceal, have had an incentive to cultivate sinsemilla, the sticky, seedless marijuana with a much higher content of the active ingredient, THC, than ordinary marijuana. And with the help of cloning technology, says John P. Sutton of the Drug Enforcement Administration, Americans now grow ''the most potent marijuana in the world.'' As a result, Mr. Kleiman estimates, the total amount of THC consumed by Americans actually rose 22 percent from 1982 to 1986.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: The social cost, many experts believe, has similarly climbed. In the 1970's, marijuana sold in the United States had a THC content of 1 to 2 percent. Last year the D.E.A. confiscated marijuana whose THC content was as high as 18 percent. Smokers looking for the the equivalent of a beer may thus unwittingly end up with a triple martini, with unfortunate consequences for job productivity. Higher Profits Than Ever
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: Another unwelcome effect of the Reagan policy, Mr. Kleiman argues, is on the way the marijuana market is organized. Tougher border controls, he believes, increased risks to all importers and drove poorly capitalized ones out of business. But the added costs to large, well-organized shippers, who could afford to lose an occasional boatload, were more than offset by the higher prices they could charge. The profits to those still in the trade, he concludes, are higher than ever.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: One way to undo the unintended effects of the crackdown on marijuana, Mr. Kleiman says, would be to legalize it and regulate its purity and potency. Legal marijuana could be a major source of tax revenue rather than a $14 billion business for criminals and a billion-dollar cost to the Treasury. But there is little support for such a radical experiment; it is generally agreed that more people would smoke marijuana if it were legal, just as many more people began drinking alcohol with the end of Prohibition in 1933. The Middle Ground
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: Still, Mr. Kleiman argues, there may be a politically acceptable middle ground.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: Cutting the Federal enforcement budget in half might increase consumption of marijuana by a few percent, he says, but it would probably reverse the changes in the market that have made marijuana much more potent and profitable in the 1980's. And lowering its potency would reduce the threat it poses to health, safety and productivity.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: Some economic analysts take issue with some of Mr. Kleiman's findings. Mark Moore, also at the Kennedy School, says loosening border controls on marijuana would not save much money, since the same personnel would still be involved in the effort to block cocaine and heroin. But there is little disagreement among economists that the consequences of marijuana interdiction have been largely perverse.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: Yet it may be hard to persuade policymakers and the public to treat marijuana differently from other drugs. Mathea Falco, an Assistant Secretary of State for narcotics matters in the Carter Administration who wrote a study on drugs for the Twentieth Century Fund, a research group in New York, points to a paradox in the evolution of drug policies. Public Makes Few Distinctions
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: In the past decade, she says, the public has become much less willing to consider each drug as a separate problem, requiring a separate containment strategy, even though the social and medical consequences of the various drugs have been diverging widely. Cocaine, for example, used to be mainly a pleasure drug for the well-off; now crack, its cheap and smokable form, has run rampant through the inner cities, destroying families and neighborhoods. Heroin's destructiveness, too, has taken on a new dimension; addicts who share needles have become a major conduit for the spread of AIDS.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: The Reagan Administration catered to the attitude that all drugs are unacceptable with its policy of ''zero tolerance,'' the absolute prohibition of all illegal drugs. And the strategy paper released by William J. Bennett, the Bush Administration's director of drug control policy, makes few distinctions among illegal drugs or strategies for combating them.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: But there is still one reason to believe that the Administration may quietly choose to de-emphasize border control for drugs in general and marijuana in particular: money.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: Attacking drug supply and demand at every level, as Mr. Bennett seems to be advocating, will be very expensive. And in the search for Federal cash to augment both law enforcement and drug treatment, it will be very tempting to tap the billion dollars a year that serve to protect domestic marijuana producers from foreign competition.
title: Economic Watch; The High Hidden Costs Of the War on Marijuana

text: Tonight, President George Bush will unveil his new drug strategy. Draft versions have already circulated widely, and the drug czar, William Bennett, has been actively promoting the plan. Written with an easy candor unusual in Government documents, the report promises to spark a long-needed national debate on the goals of our drug policy.
title: The Bush Drug Plan: Nothing New

text: The report vividly depicts the devastating impact of drug abuse, recognizing that inner-city crack cocaine is our biggest and most immediate problem. It acknowledges that a variety of approaches are needed and that overreliance on any single element will fail - witness the enormous concentration on drug law enforcement of the past eight years. It also makes a convincing case for a halt to the rapid expansion of border interdiction, which this year received more support than prevention, education and treatment combined.
title: The Bush Drug Plan: Nothing New

text: Yet the report is curiously two-headed. An insightful and compelling analysis of the drug problem is accompanied by proposals that continue many of the failed policies of the past eight years. Consider the following.
title: The Bush Drug Plan: Nothing New

text: Mr. Bush's new strategy would continue to concentrate primarily on law enforcement, despite overwhelming evidence accumulated during the past eight years of the minimal impact of law enforcement on drug abuse and drug trafficking. Enforcement will receive about 70 percent of the total Federal drug budget, compared with 30 percent for prevention, education and treatment. This represents an increase of less than 5 percent in spending to reduce the demand for drugs.
title: The Bush Drug Plan: Nothing New

text: The report recommends doing more of everything, with the notable exception of interdiction, and avoids the tough choices among programs that budgetary constraints inevitably will impose. Although systematic evaluation of programs to reduce supply and demand is still limited, we know that some approaches have relatively little effect and should be modified or abandoned, no matter how appealing they are in principle, For example, the strategy provides greater increases in efforts to reduce cocaine production in the source countries than for treatment of drug abusers in the U.S. But there is strong evidence that reducing coca production will have little effect on cocaine prices in this country. Even if coca cultivation and cocaine refining were reduced by half, the street price of cocaine in the U.S. would increase by less than 5 percent.
title: The Bush Drug Plan: Nothing New

text: It may be good foreign policy for the U.S. to provide, say, $65 million to the democratically elected Government of Colombia to strengthen its war against the Medellin cartel, but we should have no illusions that this aid will do much to cut cocaine availability here. Treatment, on the other hand, although not a panacea, does reduce drug abuse and criminality by some addicts, as is acknowledged in the Bennett report.
title: The Bush Drug Plan: Nothing New

text: The report also attacks all drugs and drug use equally, continuing the ''zero tolerance'' approach of the past eight years. Although recognizing the greater destructiveness of crack cocaine, for example, it proposes increased resources for eradication of illegal domestic marijuana cultivation, even though marijuana use has dropped significantly.
title: The Bush Drug Plan: Nothing New

text: Moreover, the new strategy would strengthen criminal penalties against drug users at a time when the criminal justice system cannot even impose swift and sure punishment on drug traffickers. Given the likelihood of strict funding limits, targeting resources becomes imperative.
title: The Bush Drug Plan: Nothing New

text: Another curious aspect of the Bennett report is the modesty of its goals. So modest are its aspirations, in fact, that if Mr. Bennett were just to continue with the existing Federal antidrug effort, he would in all likelihood exceed his goals for reducing consumption of illicit drugs.
title: The Bush Drug Plan: Nothing New

text: Mr. Bennett, for example, wants to achieve an annual drop of 5 percent in the nation's illicit drug use, when that use has declined about 12 percent a year since 1985. He wants to reduce annual cocaine use by 5 percent, although it has dropped at an annual rate of more than 10 percent a year over the past three years.
title: The Bush Drug Plan: Nothing New

text: The strategy's impact should be measured not by use, which is falling anyway, but by quantifiable reductions in the destructive effects of drug abuse and drug dealing: the numbers of drug-addicted babies, the rate of transmission of the AIDS virus by intravenous drug users, the numbers of drug-related crimes and children arrested for dealing. These are graphic, painful reminders of our continuing failure to respond effectively to the nation's drug crisis.
title: The Bush Drug Plan: Nothing New

title: News Summary

text: Even as President Bush prepares to declare war on drugs Tuesday evening, bureaucratic infighting threatens to undermine the plan of attack.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: The strategy that Mr. Bush will present at 9 P.M. Eastern time in his first nationally televised address is intended to bring unity to an effort that for years has been plagued by feuding, duplication and sometimes conflicting philosophies among the more than three dozen Federal offices claiming some jurisdiction.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: William J. Bennett, the Federal drug policy director, acknowledged in an interview last week that ''there's going to be a certain degree of enmity and rivalry.'' But he insisted, ''There's nothing major that's going to clog the wheels.'' $2 Billion a Year Yet Administration officials, lawmakers and analysts said they were not convinced that Mr. Bennett has the influence to carry out the blueprint he drafted for Mr. Bush's approval, a blueprint that calls for spending $2 billion a year more for enforcement, treatment and prevention and for military and economic aid to South American countries battling cocaine producers.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: Although he is responsible for assuring that agencies cooperate in carrying out the plan, Mr. Bennett has no official power to tell them how to spend their money or deploy their people.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: In some ways, the infighting among agencies seems beyond any President's control, since it results from differences in institutional cultures.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: The State Department, for instance, has long been more interested in improving relations with foreign powers than penalizing them for not fighting drugs. The Justice Department is geared more toward arresting drug traffickers than using military force to stop them. Pentagon's Reluctance
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: The Pentagon has for years been reluctant to pour money into a battle in which victory seems distant. And while their philosophies may be similiar, the Customs Service and Coast Guard have had celebrated feuds over issues like who gets credit for seizing a boatload of marijuana.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: William von Raab, who left office a month ago as United States Customs Service commissioner, ending an eight-year tenure in which he was often involved in intramural disputes over drug policy, asserted in an interview today:
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: ''My major concern about the plan is not what the plan says but whether the departments and the agencies will implement it with enthusiasm. I'm not saying they won't pay lip service. But will they really support it? I have heard even now some of the proposals are being pooh-poohed by the State Department and the Justice Department.''
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: Indeed, there were struggles between Mr. Bennett's office and some Federal agencies in drafting the strategy itself. Justice Department officials, for example, blocked an effort to establish an intelligence center for Federal agencies to share information on traffickers, which the officials saw as intruding on their domain. The Justice Department tried but failed to block other efforts that could diminish its authority by giving more money to state and local law enforcement and increasing the military's presence in South America. 'There's No Pouting'
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: Outwardly, Mr. Bennett and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh have insisted that relations are fine.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: ''There's no pouting,'' Mr. Bennett said. ''Thornburgh and I have worked well together. We've had some differences, and we've worked them out in a direct way.''
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: As Attorney General in the Reagan Administration, Mr. Thornburgh opposed the effort in Congress last year to create the post Mr. Bennett now holds. Since Mr. Bennett took office, the Attorney General has taken pains to insist that he and Mr. Bennett get along, while at the same time describing himself, and not Mr. Bennett, as the chief drug enforcement official.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: The drug package would cost $7.8 billion in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, about $2 billion more than in the current fiscal year. It calls for building more prisons for Federal drug offenders and for aid to local governments to step up enforcement against narcotics peddlers. It also calls for greater economic and military aid to Colombia, Bolivia and Peru and for greater efforts to arrest middle-level operators in major rings. Casual Users Are Targets
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: The plan emphasizes stiffer penalties for casual users and more spending for treatment and prevention.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: For budgeting purposes, Administration officials said, they have decided to wait until February to declare certain areas of the country in need of special Federal aid. The areas that would get top priority are New York, Los Angeles, Houston, Miami and the Southwest border.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: Along with the strategy, Administration officials said they would submit to Congress a proposal from budget officials this week for specific cuts in other domestic and military programs to pay for the fight against drugs. Mr. Bush has pledged not to raise taxes.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: But already, some Congressional officials have complained that the White House will take credit for the drug program and leave Congress to decide how to pay for it. Jurisdictional disputes are inevitable on Capitol Hill, where Representative Matthew J. Rinaldo, Republican of New Jersey, said he fears that at least 80 committees and subcommittees will try to question Mr. Bennett about the plan. How to Resolve Disputes
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: The plan would establish two groups, one dealing with supply, the other with demand, to mediate disputes among agencies. It also proposes that agencies revise their personnel evaluations so that individuals who cooperate with other departments are rewarded.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: But the real test of a new collegiality is whether Mr. Bush will put the force of his office behind the strategy and Mr. Bennett.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: ''There will be a challenge for this White House to break from the usual pattern of handling 30 issues incrementally and really hammer away at one or two themes,'' a senior White House official said.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: When Mr. Bennett was sworn in last March, the President delivered a stern lecture to the Cabinet: ''I will not tolerate, and the country cannot afford, bureaucratic infighting that forces us to fight this battle with one arm tied behind our back.'' Bennett Reportedly Was Annoyed
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: Mr. Bennett said he expects full backing from the President. Even so, aides to Mr. Bennett said he was annoyed over Mr. Bush's decision not to place his position in the Cabinet. Mr. Bush has defended the decision, saying that Mr. Bennett would be invited to Cabinet sessions in which drugs were discussed.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: Recalling how an earlier President would referee disputes, Mr. von Raab said: ''Lyndon Johnson would just call four of the agency heads in and tell them in unattractive and vulgar langauge that if they didn't pull themselves together, they'd be fired. The President could basically tell Bennett that he had the last word on this issue. But that doesn't seem to be happening.'' Mr. von Raab had wanted Mr. Bush to name him the drug chief.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: Yet some say that skirmishes between the agencies may not be so bad.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: ''It would give the appearance that we were trying to do something,'' said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York and chairman of the Select Committe on Narcotics Abuse and Control.
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: Mark A.R. Kleiman, a lecturer in public policy at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government, agreed: ''Competition among prosecutors and investigative offices can lead to bad outcomes and bad feelings, but it keeps people on their toes.''
title: DISUNITY IS FEARED AS BUSH MAPS WAR ON DRUG USE IN U.S.

text: Herbert B. Loper, a retired Army major general and former chairman of the Military Liaison Committee of the Atomic Energy Commission, died of cardiac arrest on Friday at the Palm Bay Care Center in Florida. He was 92 years old and had lived in Bozman, Md., before entering the nursing home last year.
title: Herbert Loper, 92, Retired Army General

text: General Loper, a 1918 graduate of the United States Military Academy, at West Point, was commissioned in the Corps of Engineers. In World War II he was in an engineering intelligence unit and later helped plan operations for the Marianas and Okinawa campaigns. He retired from active duty in 1953 after serving with the Joint Chiefs of Staff. From 1954 to 1961 he was chairman of the Military Liaison Committee.
title: Herbert Loper, 92, Retired Army General

text: He is survived by two sons, Herbert and Thomas, both of Satellite Beach, Fla.; six grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren.
title: Herbert Loper, 92, Retired Army General

text: The Jet careers of two young players, Bobby Riley, a receiver, and Vince Amoia, a running back, came to an end today when they were suspended for testing positive for steroid use.
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: They were part of a leaguewide total of 13 players who tested positive and who will be suspended for 30 days, meaning they will miss the first three regular-season games. No Giants were involved.
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: But for Riley and Amoia, it appears their careers with the Jets are over.
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: Riley had been a starter through three exhibition games in the absence of the Pro Bowl star, Al Toon, who agreed to terms on Monday. With Toon's arrival, Riley became a backup but appeared to have a chance to make the squad. The Jets protected him in the free-agent draft last winter. Sidelined by Surgery
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: Amoia was returning to the Jets, who drafted him in 1986. He spent last year sidelined after knee surgery. He contended today through his agent that the steroids he took to help him recover were the ones that showed up in the recent test.
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: In any event, Coach Joe Walton said after the results were made public that neither player would be brought back to the Jets after their suspension period is up.
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: Walton also said that, regardless of the tests, neither had a chance to make the club. But several players said Riley would have made the team if it were not for the test results.
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: ''These are two young guys who can help the team and had a good chance to make the club,'' said Marty Lyons, the veteran defensive lineman. ''You'd think with all the education and literature on steroids that the league put out, players would know not to use it.''
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: This is the first year that steroid use is a punishable offense in the league. A second positive test for any of the 13 players will result in an automatic suspension for the remainder of the season. Walton's Irony
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: Walton spoke in glowing terms a few weeks ago about Amoia's aggressiveness and size and commented, ''He's bulked up.''
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: Generally, steroid use has been confined to the so-called strength positions, the offensive and defensive lines and linebackers. Amoia is 5 feet 11 inches tall and weighs 214 pounds. Riley is 5-9 and weighs 168. Amoia's agent, Bruce Allen of Phoenix, described the player as devastated by the suspension. ''I'm sure that when the commissioner made the rule, he didn't have Vinny Amoia in mind,'' Allen said.
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: According to Allen, the steroids were ''prescribed to Vinny by a doctor to break up scar tissue.''
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: But the Jets' team physician, Dr. Elliot Pellman, dismissed that possibility.
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: Pellman said he was unaware of any steroids used by Amoia for rehabilitation.
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: According to the league directive on steroid use to the players, anyone who used them under a physician's advice was to notify the testing agency.
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: And the league's directive on steroids reads in part, ''The N.F.L. Physicians Society is on record declaring that there are no legitimate medical purposes to prescribe anabolic steroids for N.F.L. players.'' Severity Criticized
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: Jim Sweeney, the center, said he had never used steroids but still believed the punishment was too severe for Riley and Amoia.
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: ''It's unfair,'' he contended. ''If you're caught with cocaine or marijuana they don't suspend you, they give you another chance.''
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: Ken O'Brien, the quarterback who had thrown to Riley, described the receiver as ''quick, and he had the ability to get off the bump-and-run.''
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: Riley played in two strike games in 1987, when he caught 4 passes for 42 yards. He was out for the season last year after suffering an elbow injury.
title: Two Suspended Jets Are Out of a Job

text: Special to The New York Times
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: In a red brick house on the grounds of a community health center here, Massachusetts is experimenting with a way to break a cycle of crime and drug use before it is passed on to a new generation.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: The Neil J. Houston House in the Roxbury section of Boston is a home for women, some of them pregnant, some of them with newborn babies, all of them addicted to drugs or alcohol and all of them convicted of crimes for which they could have been sent to state prison.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: How to deal with the children of parents who are in prison is a problem that has long plagued corrections officials and social service workers.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: Some prisons have programs that permit inmates to visit with their older children, and the Bedford Hills Correctional Center in New York has a nursery and allows the women whose babies are born in prison to keep them for up to one year.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: What's different about Houston House is that the mothers and children are never separated from each other and do not live behind bars.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: The women in the program volunteer for it, pledging to go through drug and alcohol detoxification programs, to carry the baby through delivery and, after leaving Houston House, to continue to visit it for a year for follow-up care.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: Most of the women have been convicted of prostitution or nonviolent drug-related crimes, for which they would have served about five months in state prison.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: Eleven women now live in Houston House. So far they have given birth to eight babies who show no sign of addiction. Four more residents are expected soon.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: Women usually come to Houston House six months before delivery so they can detoxify before giving birth and receive counseling for their addiction. They also stay there at least two months after giving birth.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: They attend classes in parenting and AIDS prevention, go to counseling sessions and get help finding work. They also plan their meals and daily schedules together and baby-sit for each other.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: Eventually, they venture out to look for housing, to apply for social service programs and to attend meetings of Alcoholics Anonymous or Narcotics Anonymous.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: Houston House is named for Neil J. Houston, who was a 43-year-old lawyer for the Gardner Howland Shaw Foundation in Boston, a private, nonprofit group that gives grants to programs for women who are imprisoned and to shelters for battered women. Mr. Houston, an advocate of alternatives to prison for women who are criminals, was killed by a drunken driver in 1987.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: The house was opened last February after three years of planning by state officials, legislators and a private group called Social Justice for Women that works with prisoners.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: The group runs the house in cooperation with Beth Israel Hospital, which is connected with Harvard Medical School, and the Dimock Community Health Center, on whose grounds the house is situated. Money for the project, whose budget is $834,000 a year, comes from the state corrections department, the City of Boston and private foundations.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: ''Developing a relationship between mother and baby as a service to them and society'' is what Houston House is all about, said George A. Vose, the state corrections commissioner.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: Because the program is only six months old, it is too early to assess how it is succeeding in meeting one of its goals: making sure that the women do not return to prison.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: One of the women at Houston House is a 29-year-old mother of a three-month-old boy. The woman, who asked that her name not be used out of concern for her son's future, said she had been a medical secretary and had been addicted to cocaine, marijuana and alcohol for 12 years.
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: The woman said she found that she was pregnant after she had gone to prison on charges growing out of a knife fight. ''I imagined being handcuffed to the delivery room bed and then having my son taken away,'' she said. ''By the time I got out he wouldn't have known me.''
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: Expressing fear about ''dealing with the real world'' after she goes home, she said, ''I think I'll call these women every night.''
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: But she said she would overcome her fear, and would succeed because of her son. ''Everytime I look at him I feel proud,'' the woman said. ''I'll tell him the truth, within reason, about drugs like my mother never told me.''
title: Boston Journal; Experimental Program For Mothers in Prison

text: With a Government crackdown continuing, leaders of two of Colombia's largest cocaine rings have offered to get out of the drug trade in return for an amnesty and truce in Colombia's war on drugs.
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: The offers became public today as bombs shook Colombia's two largest cities, Bogota and Medellin, increasing tension that has remained high since traffickers touched off the war by assassinating the nation's leading presidential candidate, Luis Carlos Galan, 11 days ago. There were no reports of injuries in the bombings today, which occurred early in the morning.
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: ''No more drug trafficking, no more war, no more assassinations, no more bombs, no more arson,'' Fabio Ochoa Restrepo, the patriarch of a Medellin cocaine clan, proposed in a letter to President Virgilio Barco Vargas. ''Let's sit down and talk.'' Government's Response Last week, a second leading cocaine figure, Jose Rodriguez Gacha, called a Colombian reporter from his hiding place to make a peace offer. A reporter who listened to a tape of the telephone call said Mr. Gacha offered to give the Government all his farms and airplanes in return for his ''integration'' into society. Army troops occupy about 10 of Mr. Gacha's ranches and houses.
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: It is impossible to judge the sincerity of the offers, which are reminiscent of others made in the past, or to determine whether such views were widespread among the cocaine traffickers.
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: In response to the overtures from the traffickers, Communications Minister Carlos Lemos Simmonds said today: ''The Government has not considered negotiating with people who have committed drug-trafficking crimes. The drastic nature of the measures taken does not justify this kind of dialogue.'' 'Let There Be Dialogue'
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: Mr. Ochoa, the father of three men wanted in the United States on drug charges, warned in his letter, made public today, that Colombia's cocaine traffickers ''prefer a grave in Colombia over a jail cell in the U.S.''
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: ''Doctor Barco, let there be dialogue, let there be peace, let there be amnesty,'' the elder Mr. Ochoa wrote in the letter, dated last Saturday. ''Let us not be proud. Let us not be stubborn.'' Mr. Ochoa lives on a horse farm near Medellin. He is not being sought by the Colombian authorities at this time.
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: In Washington, Colombia's Justice Minister, Monica de Greiff, asked the State Department for $14 million more in aid to protect judges and court officials from assassination by drug traffickers. She also denied reports that she would resign. [ Page A10. ] In Medellin, a few hours after this morning's bombings, the city's Mayor backed Mr. Ochoa's call for peace talks. ''It is not only the position of Fabio Ochoa, it is the position of many people who believe that you have to talk to obtain peace,'' said the Mayor, Juan Gomez Martinez. Six judges resigned in Medellin today under death threats.
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: A drug-financed terror group that works for the Extraditables, as the Colombian traffickers sought by the United States are known, is believed to be behind the bombings that have shaken Medellin daily since Thursday.
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: But President Barco has refused to back away from his declaration of ''war,'' made against drug dealers last week. ''We cannot rest until we destroy the organizations dedicated to narcotics trafficking,'' Mr. Barco said in a message recorded on Monday for American television. In a direct appeal to American cocaine users, Mr. Barco said in English, ''Those of you who depend on cocaine have created the largest, most vicious criminal enterprise the world has known.'' History of Offers
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: Colombia's cocaine dealers have a history of trying to negotiate peace with the Government. In mid-1984, after the assassination of Justice Minister Rodrigo Lara Bonilla, a police crackdown forced several traffickers to flee to Panama. At that time, an envoy of Colombia's President, Belisario Betancur, held secret talks with leaders of the Medellin cartel.
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: The fugitives offered to stop dealing drugs and to bring home enough money to offset Colombia's foreign debt, about $15 billion at the time. But when the talks became public, they caused a furor and were abandoned.
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: ''How much blood could have been avoided after the Panama talks,'' read a statement from a major Medellin trafficker, Pablo Escobar Gaviria, which was printed in the newspaper La Prensa on Saturday. ''We want peace. We have demanded it shouting, but we cannot beg for it.''
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: In contrast to the two other cocaine figures, Mr. Escobar did not offer to give up dealing drugs. ''No more the path of legal action,'' his statement concluded. ''Now it is with blood.''
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: President Barco also appears to believe that it will be a fight to the finish.
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: ''The survival of Colombia, which is one of the oldest and most stable democracies of Latin America, is now at risk,'' he said in the videotape broadcast, which was recorded for American television.
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: Government raids are continuing. But Col. Eduardo Arvelo Castaneda, the Defense Ministry spokesman, said today that the police had released 60 percent of the 11,000 people arrested in the last 10 days in sweeps against suspected traffickers. Details of an Arrest
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: Today the army gave details of the arrest last Friday of Abraham Majuat Hernandez at a ranch near Medellin.
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: In one of the biggest seizures of the year, the raid netted a small airplane and 4.5 tons of cocaine - roughly the equivalent of 1 percent of Colombia's annual production. According to the Bogota newspaper El Espectador, Mr. Majuat offered soldiers $25,000 and information on other traffickers if they would let him go.
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: Two other raids, in the port of Barranquilla, netted 8.2 tons of marijuana.
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: Mr. Majuat was identified by the army as a major financial figure in the Medellin cartel. He and two others arrested in the last 10 days, Eduardo Martinez Romero and Bernardo Londono Quintero, are believed to be candidates for extradition to the United States.
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: Gen. Miguel Maza Marquez, director of Colombia's national security agency, asserted today that Mr. Majuat was also ''very involved'' in the killing of Mr. Galan.
title: 2 COCAINE FIGURES IN COLOMBIA SEEK A DEAL ON AMNESTY

text: With its long nose and bulbous cockpit, the Turbo-Thrush looks like an airplane designed by a committee. But the plane's ungainly features make it a high-performance crop duster, with promising potential in the drug fields of Colombia.
title: The Editorial Notebook; The Air War on Drugs

text: It is Colombia's role as a major cocaine supplier that currently focuses the attention of the Bush Administration. But Colombia had become a significant exporter of marijuana by the early 1980's, and local authorities began a program to eradicate the weed. The idea did not stir much attention at first; U.S. efforts to promote drug crop eradication in Mexico have long been frustrated by corruption. And the forbidding Andean terrain caused doubt that eradication could ever be practical.
title: The Editorial Notebook; The Air War on Drugs

text: At first troops attacked the crop on foot, tearing out the marijuana plants one by one. That was slow, costly and exhausting. Then in 1984, Colombian officials decided to permit spraying of a mild herbicide from helicopters that could reach fields in the steep, narrow mountain valleys. But helicopters are slow and burn much fuel. Besides, Colombia's anti-narcotics police possessed only a handful of them, and they were essential to operations against cocaine processing.
title: The Editorial Notebook; The Air War on Drugs

text: Then American advisers introduced Colombian police to the Turbo-Thrush. The plane could carry much more fuel and spray than could a copter, and go higher and faster. The Colombians could spray 128 acres a day with a plane - versus only 48 acres for their largest helicopter.
title: The Editorial Notebook; The Air War on Drugs

text: Somewhat to everyone's surprise, the highly maneuverable airplanes had no trouble working the extremely close quarters of the Colombian marijuana valleys. Spraying has now declined, but only because the police are having trouble finding more marijuana to spray.
title: The Editorial Notebook; The Air War on Drugs

text: United States drug enforcement agents believe Colombia still exports much marijuana; vast fields may thrive in the remote southeast, still beyond the reach of the new planes. And some big producers may have been planning in any case to get out of marijuana and into cocaine. Still, D.E.A. officials acknowledge that the spraying has had some effect.
title: The Editorial Notebook; The Air War on Drugs

text: Ultimately, the Colombian marijuana spraying experience may be most important for what it contributes to the growing debate over spraying coca fields. That's a more complicated subject because the woody coca bushes require a stronger herbicide, more threatening to the environment, than do fragile marijuana plants. Furthermore, the bulk of the coca crop is grown in Peru and Bolivia, where spraying would raise powerful economic and political issues that are not a concern in Colombia.
title: The Editorial Notebook; The Air War on Drugs

text: But Colombia's marijuana campaign at least ends doubt that spraying can be done efficiently in the mountains, and strongly suggests that farmers, when frustrated by spraying, will plant something else.
title: The Editorial Notebook; The Air War on Drugs

text: Recent sizable drug seizures as reported by state law enforcement officials. 1. June 13: Louisiana State Police seized 34 grams of Mexican brown heroin on I-20 in Bossier Parish from two men in a 1970 Cadillac with Louisiana license plates. Passenger threw bag containing balloons of heroin out of window. 2. June 16: Texas Department of Public Safety seized 136 kilograms of marijuana on U.S. 59 in Nacogdoches County from an Illinois resident. Marijuana discovered inside trunk of 1978 Chevrolet Monte Carlo with Illinois Plates. 3. June 21: New Jersey State Police seized 85 grams of heroin, four ounces of cocaine and $31,516 on New Jersey Turnpike in Bergen County from three in a 1985 Chrysler with New York plates. 4. July 3: Georgia State Patrol seized 6 kilograms of cocaine on I-75 in Crisp County from a couple in a 1978 Chevrolet with Illinois plates. 5. July 4: New Jersey State Police seized 49 grams of heroin on New Jersey Turnpike in Hudson County from two New Jersey men. Heroin concealed inside glove box of 1988 Chevrolet Blazer with New Jersey plates. 6. July 9: Louisiana State Police seized 227 kilograms of marijuana on I-12 in St. Tammany Parish from two men. Marijuana concealed in 1986 Chevrolet motor home with Mexican plates. 7. July 14: Delaware State Police seized 6 kilograms of cocaine on I-95 in New Castle County from two Florida men. Cocaine discovered inside rear quarter panel compartments of 1984 Oldsmobile Cutlass with Pennsylvania plates. 8. July 14: Georgia State Patrol seized 9 kilograms of hashish and $800 on I-95 in Effingham County from two men in a 1979 Ford van with Ontario, Canada, plates. 9. July 17: Georgia State Patrol seized 20 kilograms of cocaine and $1,711 on I-75 in Dooly County from a Georgia man. Source: State Police records.
title: 5 Weeks, 5 States, 9 Major Drug Arrests

text: A Federal narcotics intelligence center here sent out a confidential cable last month to state police officials across the country with this alert:
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: ''Maryland State Police reported one pound cocaine seizure concealed in stuffed teddy bear. Two teddy bears discovered in vehicle, one heavier than the other. Velcro closure on heavier bear opened and cocaine discovered.''
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: It was one more sign of the resourcefulness with which drug distributors are spreading their merchandise beyond the borders to the American heartland in what has become a vast, intricate and growing interstate commerce in illegal drugs. Whether stuffed in teddy bears or buried in truckloads of refrigerated but potentially very smelly fish, whether mailed in Federal Express packages or merely tossed into the trunks of cars, cocaine, crack, marijuana and heroin are making their way to retail markets on airplanes, automobiles, trucks, boats, buses and trains all across the nation. Drugs are found on anything that moves.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: The barons of the Medellin drug cartel, who have masterminded the flow of cocaine into the United States, are believed to be gaining more and more control over its traffic within this country. American intelligence data show that they have set up regional distribution centers in places like Houston and Miami, Denver and Oklahoma City.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Law-enforcement officials, frustrated by what they acknowledge is a losing battle to stop illegal drugs at the borders, are placing new emphasis on their next line of defense: highways and other domestic drug conduits. Boats and Mobile Homes
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: From a squat brick building under tight security at the El Paso Intelligence Center, or EPIC, composed of officials from the Drug Enforcement Adminstration and nine other Federal agencies, workers at computer consoles take reports from police agencies across the country about drug movement on highways. This is an added responsibility for EPIC, a clearinghouse for tactical information on global trafficking that has now been enlisted in the effort to break down the new interstate commerce in drugs.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Working with Operation Pipeline, a Federal highway surveillance effort, officials here communicate around the clock with their counterparts in dozens of state police forces about narcotics on major highways. They transmit wire reports, often based on tips from informers, on how and where drugs are moving.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Using such intelligence, for example, EPIC recently cabled details on a pickup truck traveling from one state to another on a clockwork schedule, towing a boat with 12 kilograms of cocaine hidden inside.
