The interstate travels of a mobile home and a smuggler using several limousines to transport cocaine and marijuana were also reported in the cable. These drug couriers, the authorities said, have yet to be caught.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Despite such intensified efforts, law-enforcement officials are not optimistic. As hard as it is to catch drug traffickers at the border, it is even tougher when they reach the interior, blending in with families on vacation and truckers hauling all sorts of legitimate loads.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: ''The last line of defense we have is the highway,'' said Warren Henderson, the state and local training coordinator at EPIC. ''Once it gets past that line, the odds are probably one in a million of getting an entire load of dope off the street.'' The Highway Elusive Smugglers And New Routes
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: A map of the major drug routes could just as easily be a map of the Interstate highway system. Within the United States, most illegal drugs travel by car and truck.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Sometimes vehicles carry drugs from Mexico into Texas, New Mexico, Arizona or California and drive them directly to dealers. Even if they enter the country by air or sea, more often than not they are loaded on cars or trucks, usually near the border. Often, regardless of where they enter, they are transported to a hub like New York or Los Angeles, repackaged and driven by car or truck to their final destinations.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Americans spend billions on drugs each year. The state police, who patrol the Interstate highways, seize only a small fraction of that. In 1988, the 41 state police agencies that gave statistics to Operation Pipeline reported seizures of 35,947 kilograms of marijuana, 4,055 kilograms of cocaine and 10.6 kilograms of heroin. The cocaine would have a wholesale price of $45 million to $138 million, depending on purity and market conditions.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: The authorities are particularly concerned about cocaine because of its devastating effect on society, particularly in the cheaper, highly addictive form of crack. And they are not claiming great success. 'We're Not Touching the Traffic'
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: ''We're not bragging for a minute,'' said Sgt. Roy Herren, who supervises the intelligence section of the Missouri Highway Patrol. ''We know we're not touching the traffic.''
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Once it was thought that crack, the crystalline and smokable form of cocaine, was so easy to manufacture locally that it was not being moved long distances. But apparently some drug operators are beginning to keep tighter control over the profits. As recently as 1986, there were no reported seizures of crack on highways; in the first four months of 1989, the 41 states reported seizing 12.8 kilograms on the highways.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Troopers in several states have spotted trailer trucks hauling large loads of drugs, but the couriers' main strategy is to be unpredictable: to carry drugs in refrigerated fish trucks, for instance, or in empty trailer trucks with drug compartments in their fuel tanks or mufflers.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Just as modes of smuggling are unpredictable, so are the routes. Interstate 75, which goes from southern Florida through Atlanta and Cincinnati and northern Michigan to Canada, has seen far more narcotics seizures in the first half of 1989 than in the same period in 1988. This could reflect more drug traffic or stepped-up law enforcement or both. Most of the seizures occurred in Georgia. Some traffickers seem to be avoiding the I-95 corridor, long a favorite East Coast route, perhaps because of intensified police surveillance.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: A similar decline in highway smuggling has occurred on Interstate 40, from Southern California to North Carolina. To elude the police, smugglers are using diversionary tactics, like driving north from Arizona and east on Interstate 70 through Utah, Colorado and Kansas before dropping back to I-40 through Oklahoma to points east.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: ''Does Utah look like it's a major route to anyplace?'' Mr. Henderson asked. But at least 306 kilograms of cocaine were seized on highways in Utah last year, one of the largest totals among the states reporting. The Telephone Talking in Code: Cocaine Is 'Flour'
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: The organizations that transport and distribute drugs in this country are as varied as the ways drugs move. But at the heart of the drug business are two products of technology: the telephone and the beeper. The life of a drug trafficker is a life of phone calls to set the times and places for meetings. Dealers drive from pay phone to pay phone to avoid detection.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: The multimillion-dollar cocaine smuggling ring headed by Miguel Pacheco-Valdez, arrested on drug trafficking charges in Phoenix last year, seemed to be run largely by telephone, through calls made from Arizona, New Mexico, California, Oregon, Utah, Washington and British Columbia. Undercover agents watched traffickers make their contacts from pay phones outside a Circle K convenience store and later from a Bob's Big Boy restaurant. Between phone calls, the traffickers would try to keep from being followed. They would travel at high speeds for a while, then slow down and turn into quiet neighborhoods. 'Half a Million Fast'
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Testifying before the Senate Judiciary Committee this month, Max Mermelstein, a convicted drug dealer, said the new cocaine network ''is predicated on communication and getting in contact with the people the cocaine is going to be given to and who the money is going to be received from.''
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: The dealer, who is now a protected Government witness and uses a different name, added: ''None of this communication is handled through somebody's home phone - they're afraid of using a home phone because of interception of the line. They use pay phones, and they're constantly changing pay phones. Everybody walks around with a beeper; they're called from a pay phone, and they return the call from the pay phone.''
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Nevertheless, investigators have managed to listen in on many calls from public phones.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: They tapped one conversation in which Jose S. Valdez, identified as key figure in the Pacheco-Valdez ring, was trying to find a pilot. Calling from Apache Junction, Ariz., Mr. Valdez told a man called Octavio that he needed five planeloads of drugs from Mexico and would pay him $100,000 per load. The drugs were said to be stashed 100 miles or so inside Mexico, and the pilot was told he could fly two loads a day and ''make a half a million fast,'' according to an affidavit from a Federal narcotics agent. Octavio told Mr. Valdez that he was going to Virginia for three months and would be unavailable, but that his partner might be interested.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Another trafficker in the organization, in a phone call from Portland, Ore., said it was important that the ring sell legitimate items once in a while; this would disguise its activities and provide cover for its members if they were arrested. ''Like I told you,'' he said, ''if ever we have the misfortune, at least we can say I used to sell salmon, shrimp and everything like that.''
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: The traffickers routinely spoke in code. Cocaine was ''white dresses,'' ''white trees,'' ''little white cars,'' ''flour,'' ''oranges'' or ''ice cream.'' Marijuana was ''green carpet,'' or just ''carpet.'' Heroin was ''blacks,'' ''tires'' or ''black grapes.'' The Connections From Colombia To Oklahoma
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Informers have told law-enforcement officials that the Medellin smugglers of Colombia have placed one overlord in the United States to supervise cocaine traffic. Under him are said to be regional chiefs in Miami, Houston, New York and Los Angeles. Federal agents or local police detectives will not say if they have learned who these chiefs are.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: In one recent case, a lower-level lieutenant, Rodrigo Chegwin-Vergana, was convicted of working with the cartel in bringing cocaine into Oklahoma. Mr. Chegwin-Vergana is said to have guided the movements of more than 50 boat and airplane loads of several hundred kilograms each. He arranged the planes and boats, the unloading crews and the landing or docking sites. A pilot flew cocaine from Colombia directly to the False River area of Louisiana, and from there it was distributed to Oklahoma, Texas, Florida and elsewhere.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: In another case involving Colombia's Oklahoma connection, a group of Colombians brought cocaine from Colombia to southern Florida. Middlemen hired by the organization either drove it or carried it on commercial airlines to Oklahoma City, where it was redistributed in quantities of an ounce or more. 'Small-Town Associations'
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Why Oklahoma? There is demand there, but just as important, the connection is in place. This is as important to the local operators as it is to the cartels.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: ''Small-town associations'' are the basis for cocaine distribution in South Dakota, said Phillip N. Hogen, the United States Attorney there. ''To supply more than one-ounce quantities of cocaine, a distributor in South Dakota must have a contact in a metropolitan area,'' he said in a report to the Justice Department.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: A dealer in Aberdeen, S.D., for example, was caught receiving a supply of cocaine from his regional center in Denver - which sent it by United Parcel Service. Gordon R. Edgecomb, a convicted smuggler, used the mail until a package containing $25,000 in cash was lost. From then on, he picked up the money by commercial airlines.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: America's interstate cocaine runners are occasionally caught through their own miscalculations as they drive long distances, often nonstop, from one region to another. They may be caught speeding or fall asleep at the wheel and lose control.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: When one state trooper in the South stopped a car for speeding, a passenger got out and recited what seemed to be the only English he knew: ''I don't have the cocaine. I don't have the cocaine.''
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: The trooper found 20 to 30 kilograms of cocaine hidden behind the back seat. Searches and Seizures
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Under the Fourth Amendment to the Constitution, police officers may not search vehicles unless they have a good reason to believe they will find illegal drugs or weapons. If they do so without consent, anything they seize cannot be used as evidence. Surprisingly, however, many smugglers consent to being searched.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: ''I don't know why they do it,'' said Major O. L. Sanderson, field operations officer of the Wyoming Highway Patrol. ''A lot of them don't understand the legal procedures.''
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: But the searches do pay off. In Missouri recently, a drug trafficker was driving a van 68 miles an hour in a 55 m.p.h. zone. A trooper pulled him over and, on a hunch, asked if he could search the back of the van. The result was one of the largest cocaine seizures on a highway: 500 kilograms stuffed in cardboard boxes. The Outlook Little Optimism On the Battle Lines
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Drug policy experts see the new interstate commerce in drugs as a measure of how deeply narcotics have permeated American society.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Yet even with stepped-up law enforcement, they say, little can be done to solve the problem quickly. Even trying to close off the borders or amending the Constitution to allow routine searches of cars and truck would pose huge practical problems, to say nothing of costs.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Larry L. Orton, the special agent in charge of the El Paso Intelligence Center, acknowledges that concentrating on the circuitous pathways of drug traffickers is not the ultimate solution.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: ''We don't think interdiction is the answer,'' he said. ''There are more ways to bring the drugs into the country than we have the ability or where-withal to stop. You can't just go willy-nilly stopping people in the country. The answer is not interdiction, but combining law enforcement and reducing demand.''
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Asked what can be done about the interstate travel of drugs, M. Douglas Anglin, director of the Drug Abuse Research Group at the University of California at Los Angeles, replied:
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: ''We need a urine test for coars. That's what we need.''
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Nets: a heartland city battles crack.
title: New Form of Interstate Commerce: How Drugs Spread Through U.S.

text: Corruption is a major factor in the drug trade, north and south of the border. It involves United States agents, the Mexican police and private citizens in many different ways.
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: Gary P. Callahan, a 19-year veteran of the Federal Border Patrol, an agent long regarded as enthusiastic and dedicated, was recently arrested on charges of conspiring to possess and distribute cocaine. Mr. Callahan is one of several law-enforcement officers who have come under investigation along the Southwest border.
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: Mr. Callahan, who has been suspended without pay, has pleaded not guilty. He is in custody pending trial. Trouble From Cocaine Left Behind
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: Federal prosecutors contend that this is what happened in the Callahan case: It was just after midnight June 29, 1988, and Mr. Callahan was alone in his official car, patrolling hills and border scrubland, when he encountered 8 to 10 backpackers starting to cross the border. He chased them on foot, but was able to capture only one of the men, although most of them dropped their backpacks. Mr. Callahan said he recovered eight backpacks, each stuffed with more than 40 pounds of cocaine.
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: But the prosecutors contend that Mr. Callahan hid an additional 80 pounds of cocaine and delivered it to one of the state's best-known dentists, who lived in Paradise Valley near Phoenix. Mr. Callahan was romantically involved with the sister of the dentist. The dentist has admitted in court documents that he was also a cocaine and marijuana smuggler. He is now cooperating with the authorities.
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: A second Border Patrol officer has been charged with tampering with evidence in the case and two others are under investigation for possible complicity. A Dozen Bribe Offers Rejected
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: Mr. Callahan's supervisor, Ronald J. Dowdy, chief Border Patrol agent in Tucson, said in an interview that since January 1988, more than a dozen of his employees had reported turning down bribes. ''It's my sense that a lot of people are approaching our officers with bribes,'' he said. ''I understand the temptations are there. I don't understand giving in to them.''
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: In another case, Joe Bonzelet, former Mohave County sheriff, is awaiting trial on charges of setting fire to the sheriff's office to destroy evidence against an accused drug dealer.
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: William Ruzzamenti, supervisor of the Drug Enforcement Administration's anti-narcotics group in Phoenix, said: ''There's no question there is corruption on our side of the border as well as the Mexican. The narco-dollars are so devastating, it's hard at times to keep everybody straight.''
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: While the new President of Mexico, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, has pledged improved cooperation with United States in curbing traffickers, the American authorities say corruption is rampant on the other side of the border.
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: In one case earlier this year, the Customs Service spotted a twin-engine plane from Colombia that landed at a ranch three miles south of the border, and smugglers were seen loading two pickup trucks with cocaine taken from the plane.
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: Clarence W. Dupnik, the sheriff of Pima County here, whose deputies were involved in the operation, said United States officials contacted the commandant in San Luis, Mexico, who agreed to help arrange an immediate joint raid on the ranch with helicopters.
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: But Sheriff Dupnik said the commandant was promptly told by his superiors in Mexico City not to cooperate, and that he told his counterparts in Arizona, ''I'm sorry - Mexico City has told me that we have to end this.''
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: The American authorities were helpless as the trucks drove away.
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: ''That's a common occurrence, unfortunately,'' Sheriff Dupnik said.
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: As far north as Phoenix, a three-hour drive from the border, the police find case after case in which residents are corrupted by cocaine and marijuana money. In one recent example, Ron Gomez, an investigator for the Arizona Attorney General's office, went undercover as a drug trafficker. Wearing diamond rings and expensive lizard skin boots, he sauntered into a used-car dealership, the Fiesta Car Company. There he struck up a conversation with the operator, Toby Lee Barton, who the authorities suspected had been selling cars to drug dealers.
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: ''I said, 'I want to buy a car regularly from you,' '' Mr. Gomez recalled. ''He said, 'I know what you mean. I've done business with Mexican boys like you.' We became like business associates. I told him I needed vehicles to transport drugs.'' Buying Into Business With Drugs
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: Within a few months, Mr. Barton had sold a 50 percent interest of his business to Mr. Gomez for 3 pounds of cocaine and 150 pounds of marijuana.
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: Last month, Mr. Barton pleaded guilty to charges of money laundering and theft in return for the dismissal of other charges, including conducting an illegal enterprise and conspiring to possess cocaine and marijuana for sale. He is awaiting sentence.
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: ''More and more people are allowing themselves to be corrupted,'' said Mr. Gomez, a 20-year veteran of the Phoenix Police Department. ''A typical attitude is, 'If I don't sell a house to a dope dealer, somebody else will.' ''
title: Official Corruption Grows as Drug Smuggling Flourishes

text: South American cocaine cartels have transformed this desert town and other seemingly bucolic points along the cactus-dotted Mexican border into international drug passageways that now rival those of south Florida.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: The flow of illegal narcotics across the 2,013-mile border into Arizona, California, New Mexico and Texas marks a dramatic shift in strategy by the drug barons that is seriously hindering the nation's efforts to stop cocaine from entering the United States. New Drug Avenues Opened
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: While the cartels are still funneling more drugs through south Florida, intensified law enforcement there has driven much of the business to the Southwest. And once the new surge of cocaine makes it past this seemingly endless and often unguarded barrier, the traffickers are finding it extremely easy to push it to the remotest corners of America. There are these related developments:
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: * The flow of drugs into the Southwest has turned Los Angeles, Tucson and Phoenix into leading drug distribution markets and consumption is rising particularly fast in those cities as well. For example, the Phoenix authorities report that members of the Crips drug gang are flying from Phoenix on commercial airlines to Kansas City, Mo., Tulsa, Chicago, Denver, Dallas and Wichita, Kan., to deliver cocaine.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: * More and more allegations are surfacing of law-enforcement officers, both Federal and local, being corrupted. In a recent case, a veteran Border Patrol officer was arrested on drug trafficking charges and the authorities are investigating the possible involvement of other agents in the case.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: * Dedicated drug-enforcement officials in the field are complaining bitterly that Federal Government decisions in the early 1980's have left them seriously unprepared to meet the present crisis.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: * When Border Patrol officials in Arizona have an average of one agent to patrol every 12 miles of border, the Bush Administration's proposed budget for the fiscal year 1990 would result in even fewer agents along the border.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: * Sharp increases in violence along desert trails and highways are a byproduct of the rise in smuggling.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: On a recent afternoon, a Border Patrol agent at San Ysidro, Calif., came upon dozens of teen-age smugglers from Mexico climbing through rocky canyons into the United States. Rather than hide or run, they brazenly picked up their pace, knowing there was nothing a single officer could do to stop them. Indeed, worried that the smugglers would begin hurling rocks at him, the officer jumped into his all-terrain vehicle and hurried back to the station. Some Smugglers Are Caught
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: Not all smugglers get away. The other day, the view from a two-story Nogales rooftop featured an almost daily occurrence: four people on a nearby hillside climbing over a chain- link fence, in full sight of the port of entry into the United States from Mexico. They were seized with their contraband by Border Patrol agents.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: But this was clearly the exception. Most smugglers, whether by foot, in a vehicle or in an airplane, elude capture. Customs Service officials estimate that they search no more than 5 percent of the vehicles and people that pass through ports of entry. Typically, they discover fresh gaps in the international fence that separates the two countries within an hour after they mend it. Heroin From Grandparents
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: Rudy M. Camacho, the Customs Service's director of inspection control division in Nogales, said, ''The drug craze has so permeated every part of society that we no longer have a typical profile for a smuggler.'' Explaining that they are of all ages and walks of life, he said, ''We've pulled pounds of heroin off grandparents with kids in tow.''
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: Because so much gets through undetected, no one knows the full volume of cocaine, marijuana and other drugs that are moved illegally across the border, but statistics point to dramatic escalations: in the first nine months of the fiscal year 1989, Federal agencies seized 26,000 pounds of cocaine along the Southwest border, nearly 15 times as much as they seized in the same period in 1986. Federal criminal cases in Arizona for drug-related violations increased 85 percent from 1987 to 1988. The Federal Reserve Bank's current cash surplus in Los Angeles soared to $3.8 billion from $165 million in 1985, which law-enforcement authorities attribute largely to drug money being laundered in Los Angeles.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: Federal narcotics experts now estimate that at least one-third of the cocaine that enters North America is routed from Mexico across the Southwest border, with most of the remainder entering by two routes: a Pacific Ocean route from Colombia to California and to Vancouver, Canada, and a Caribbean route from Colombia to Florida and New York. Pathways Drug Rings Reopen Ancient Lanes
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: The current Southwest smuggling routes were opened more than a century ago when Mexican workers, Chinese immigrants, cigars and mescal were illegally slipped into the United States through Mexico. Alcohol was the most common contraband smuggled across the border during Prohibition, and in the late 1960's and early 1970's, marijuana flooded across. From the mid-1970's until about 1980, the marijuana flow was sharply diminished by Federal efforts, largely through the wide-scale spraying of marijuana crops with paraquat, a herbicide.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: As recently as 1982, cocaine smuggling across the border was barely discernible. But vigorous law enforcement in Florida and nearby states led smugglers to make contact with traditional Mexican marijuana organizations. While marijuana smuggling has picked up again and still outranks cocaine in the amount smuggled, the authorities say, the trafficking of cocaine has exploded. Demand Fuels Supply
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: The soaring demand for drugs in the United States along with the great abundance of unemployed Mexicans willing to smuggle them are enabling traffickers to run larger, more sophisticated and more lucrative operations than in the 1970's.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: From South America, Colombian drug cartels fly cocaine to northern Mexico, where they hire Mexican smuggling groups, most with extensive family ties on both sides of the border. Indeed, a new specialized industry is developing as groups with no share in the ownership of smuggled drugs have gone into the highly paid business of trucking them across the border.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: Many of the Southwest smugglers, called ''mules'' by their pursuers -some of them actually do transport drugs on the backs of mules or horses - normally cross the border on foot. They stuff 50 pounds or more of cocaine or marijuana in a backpack and, usually in groups, traverse the rugged canyons or desert, which they know far better than do most of the police or Government agents who pursue them. Days may pass before they reach their contact, often waiting near a highway as far as 50 miles inland. The smugglers receive $250 to $1,000 a load. Intuition Brings Seizure
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: One day this summer, Damiana Aguilar-Aispuro walked from Mexico across the pedestrian lane to the port of entry at San Luis, Ariz. Perhaps sensing some nervousness, a Customs inspector referred her for a secondary, ''pat down'' inspection. Ms. Aguilar-Aispuro tried to flee back to Mexico, running from the Customs building through turnstiles and two sets of double doors before she was caught.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: She was arrested and accused of hiding 1.7 pounds of heroin ''inside a sewn compartment in her undergarment.''
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: Other ''mules'' drive across the border in cars or trucks carrying elaborately concealed drugs. One dump truck was recently discovered full of gravel covering a secret plywood compartment filled with drugs. A motor home driven through downtown Nogales, the family inside, had an entire floor raised to make room for drugs.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: A front-wheel-drive Cadillac had a false drug-packed rear-wheel transmission hump running through its luxurious interior. The authorities in El Paso recently seized a semitrailer stuffed with cocaine, and it turned out that the truck had crossed the border at least six times in the past year. $200,000 for a Delivery Often the smugglers stay clear of the ports of entry entirely and drive their cars through gaps in the international fence, or make their own holes.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: While most ''mules'' travel by land, the best-paid ones are pilots, who can command up to $200,000 a flight on a small twin-engine plane. Ground crew members can make $1,000 to $10,000 a person for a load. There are hundreds of dirt airstrips near the border, and it is common for a specific smuggling flight to have a dozen possible landing sites and several ground crews standing by.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: Amateur pilots tell of seeing planes land at remote strips in the middle of the night, the runways lighted only by the headlights of a waiting station wagon. The pilot taxis to the end of the runway, throws out a package and takes off while the station wagon picks up the package and pulls away into the night.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: But some drug flights are conducted more openly. One organization, headed by Jaime Bermudez-Botero, retained commercial airline pilots and owned at least two private planes, said Stephen M. McNamee, the United States Attorney in Arizona. Initially, the organization moved 1,000-pound lots of cocaine from Colombia to Florida, but responding to the crackdown in Florida, changed routes and flew the loads to Arizona.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: Mr. Bermudez-Botero was arrested after undercover investigators seized 1,264 pounds of cocaine, with an estimated wholesale value of $18.9 million, on a plane that had flown from Colombia through Mexico to the Sky Harbor International Airport in Phoenix. He is currently serving a 14-year prison sentence. Confrontation Federal Response Is Found Slow
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: A key element of the problem has been the slowness of the Government's response to the rerouting of drug trafficking from Florida. The law-enforcement officers are simply unable to watch over all the land and air routes being used. It is a classic military problem: how do you defend a long open frontier against continual probing attacks?
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: ''By the time we get there, they are gone,'' said William Ruzzamenti, supervisor of a Drug Enforcement Administration anti-narcotics group in Phoenix. At the Southwest border, ''the Arizona division is the smallest division within the D.E.A,'' he said. ''By the time we respond and get our manpower up, who knows where they're going to be?''
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: It was not until August 1986 that the Government announced the formation of Operation Alliance, a multi-agency effort to coordinate drug enforcement at the Southwest border. But the operation depends on the financial support of individual agencies, which has been slow in coming.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: ''The problem on the Southwest border was recognized individually by all the agencies involved,'' said Jim Bowen, deputy tactical coordinator of Operation Alliance. ''But collectively, they were two years late.'' More Than Money Is Needed
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: William J. Bennett, the director of national drug policy, recently proposed that the Southwest border be designated as one of five ''high intensity'' trafficking zones that needed a significant infusion of Federal aid, along with Miami, New York, Los Angeles and Houston.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: But David S. Wood, the special agent in charge of the anti-drug agency's Phoenix field division, with 63 agents statewide, suggested that the needs went far beyond what the Government could ever provide. ''We could very easily double the staff of D.E.A. in this division,'' he said, ''and perhaps not have sufficient personnel.''
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: A former cocaine trafficker, Max Mermelstein, who is now a protected government witness who had close ties with the Medellin drug cartel in Colombia, told the Senate Judiciary Committee this month that traffickers have become adept at finding holes in the Government's drug nets. ''Basically, the way the cartel has been able to exist and flourish,'' he said, ''is that they can change faster than the United States Government can. It's basically what keeps them alive.'' 'Mules' Are Generally Ignorant
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: The agents, relatively few in number, say that when they direct their flashlights at a group of backpackers with drugs, the smugglers scatter quickly. At best, they might leave the drugs behind. Or, if the police or border patrol spot a suspicious car or truck and pursue it, the driver may simply wheel around and speed back into Mexico.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: Even when caught, these ''mules'' are generally of little real value in solving the broad problem: they usually say they know nothing about the band that hired them, and often that is the case.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: ''The drug distribution organizations have broken themselves up into completely independent cells which don't know about the other cells they're doing business with,'' said Jack A. Blum, a former special counsel on narcotics to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ''What happens is that when you arrest one group of people, there's no capacity whatsoever to get out there and arrest anybody else.''
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: The drug rings are extending their corruption into the law-enforcement agencies. Federal agents are being accused, in more than a dozen investigations, of selling cocaine themselves. The corruption of agents is believed to be even wider spread south of the border. Repercussions Merchants Hone Their Sales Skills
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: Most cocaine shipped into Arizona is for wholesale distribution. The supplies are often stockpiled at what the smugglers call ''stash houses'' in Tucson or Phoenix until the distributors package it for shipment to Los Angeles.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: But the Federal authorities say that with increasing frequency, Mexican smugglers are selling the drugs directly on the Arizona market.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: There are increasing signs that the Southwest flow of drugs is being felt north of the border, in drug availability, addiction and violence. In a Federal survey last year, 51 percent of high school seniors nationally reported that they could buy cocaine if they had the money. But in a separate survey in Arizona, 65 percent of the seniors said they could buy the drug, a difference the authorities in the state say is significant. Bodies Tell of Ruthlessness
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: And the authorities say there are more and more cases of drug-related violence. In late March, they said, the bodies of five men were found bound, tortured and shot to death in a shed in Tucson. A few days later, they said, 12 bullet-ridden, mutilated bodies were found in a well and cesspool on a ranch near the Mexican town of Agua Prieta across from Douglas, Ariz.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: ''We thought it was bad in the 70's,'' said Lieut. W. G. Rogers of the Arizona Department of Public Safety, who headed the department's narcotics section for four years. ''I don't think it's ever been this bad. When I started in law enforcement 20 years ago, drug dealers would give themselves up. Now, you can count on them being armed.'' Gunfire Becomes Common
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: So severe is the violence that more than a half dozen agents in the Tucson Border Patrol sector reported being fired upon this year, sometimes with automatic weapons, and the agents report that it is not uncommon to stumble on unidentifiable bodies in the desert. Rivalries among drug traffickers are believed to be responsible.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: The police in Phoenix report that in the first half of this year there were 46 gang-related incidents, resulting in nine deaths.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: When the cocaine reaches Los Angeles, it often causes still more violence. But much of the cocaine does not stay in Los Angeles. After it is repackaged, couriers take the cocaine east, north and even, in significant quantities, back to Arizona.
title: Drug Rings Turn Border Into a Vast Route to U.S.

text: After resisting such a role for years, the Defense Department is preparing to play a major part in combating the flow of drugs into the United States. The change has been brought about in part by legislation last year giving the military a role in controlling drug traffic and in part by a change in attitude in the leadership at the Pentagon.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: As a result, the military services are planning to train and provide technical support to American and foreign drug enforcement agencies more than ever before. The military will play the major role in setting up a command, control and communications network in the United States and in drug-producing regions to help drug enforcement authorities locate and take timely action against drug traffic.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: The legislation adopted by Congress in September 1988 appropriated $300 million to the military to fight drug trafficking and broadened the mission of the armed forces to include surveillance of suspected drug-carrying ships and aircraft, as well as stepped-up communications and intelligence. This year $470 million for the drug effort is expected to be earmarked for the military.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: But the change also stems from a conviction among senior military officers and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney that drugs are tearing at the fabric of American society and pose such a threat to national security that greater military involvement is warranted. Resistance to Drug Role
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: In the past, Defense Secretaries Caspar W. Weinberger and Frank C. Carlucci, as well as many senior military officers, resisted using the military to combat drugs because they believed that it would interfere with the services' traditional military mission.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: There was also widespread concern among the senior military leaders that servicemen combating narcotics might be corrupted by drug dealers willing to pay large sums to have a blind eye turned to their trafficking.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: Administration officials say no American servicemen will be directly responsible for drug arrests and seizures, either at home or abroad. That job will be left to authorized drug enforcement agents and police.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: The military's role will be to support those directly involved in fighting drugs, but that is regarded as significant because United States military equipment, training and technical intelligence support of domestic and foreign authorities is considered critical if there is to be any hope of stemming the flow of drugs into this country. Memories of Vietnam
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: Although American servicemen are only to advise American and foreign anti-drug teams, some Pentagon officers with memories of Vietnam say it will be difficult to avoid direct involvement.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: ''What if the druggies fire at an Army helicopter carrying Colombian soldiers into a drug site?'' an officer asked. ''The next thing you know we'll be putting door gunners on the Hueys and providing the locals with forward observers to call in artillery.''
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: But even those in the Pentagon who counsel caution concede that the military should be doing more to combat drugs.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: President Bush announced on Friday that he was sending $65 million in aid to the Colombian government. The aid package includes helicopters, airplanes, weapons, ammunition and other equipment, along with technical advisers. Helping Other Latin Nations
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: The American military is already helping other Latin American nations. In an operation called Blast Furnace in 1986, Army helicopters transported Bolivian forces on raids against drug manfacturing sites in the jungle. Army Special Forces soldiers are now in Bolivia giving tactical advice to American agents of the Drug Enforcement Administration. Under another program called Snowcap, Rangers at Fort Benning, Ga., are training D.E.A. agents in military skills before they go to major drug regions in Colombia and Peru.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: The increased activity comes against a background in which the military's usefulness in combating drugs is in dispute. Last year a General Accounting Office report charged that the past Pentagon drug interdiction efforts were not cost-effective. The report found that in 1987 the Air Force spent $2.6 million flying drug detection missions, which resulted in only 10 arrests. The Navy spent $40 million on one of its programs, the report said, which resulted in only 20 seizures by the Customs Service and other law enforcement agencies. Legislation Makes Changes
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: Before last year's legislation specifically assigning an anti-drug role to the military, the armed forces assisted drug enforcement authorities only if doing so did not interfere with purely military missions. For example, Navy ships could carry Coast Guard officers, with the authority to make arrests at sea if a warship happened upon a drug runner incidental to its assigned activity, but the ship's captain could not deliberately search for drug boats.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: That changed last year in the new legislation. Now American warships may actively seek drug-runners on the high seas, although the power of arrest still resides with the law enforcement officers aboard each ship.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: Pentagon studies on the drug problem define it in terms of geographic zones, each requiring different countermeasures. Source of the Drugs
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: One zone encompasses the source of the drugs. The studies place particular emphasis on Latin America, believed to be the source of most of the marijuana and all the cocaine that reaches the United States, but they also include the Far East, where much of the world's heroin is produced.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: A second zone covers the routes used by drug dealers to bring their goods into the United States. These are primarily the air and sea routes into the Southern and Southwestern states and the land route through Mexico and to a lesser extent through Canada.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: The third zone, called the demand zone, is within the United States itself.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: By law the Pentagon has the lead in detecting and monitoring illegal drugs coming into the country by sea and air, and that is where the military is placing its initial emphasis. Two Command Centers
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: Two command centers have been set up to process and evaluate surveillance reports on possible drug runners and to alert police authorities in the United States. One center, known as Joint Task Force 4, is in Key West, Fla. It receives reports from surveillance satellites, ships, aircraft and radar balloons monitoring the East and Gulf Coasts.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: Joint Task Force 5 is in Alameda, Calif., covering the approaches to the West Coast. The United States military commanders of the Pacific and Atlantic in Hawaii and Norfolk, Va., are in overall charge of these surveillance missions.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: The North American Air Defense Command, with its powerful long- range radar designed to pick up missile attacks against the United States, has also been ordered to search for drug planes as they take off from remote jungle sites in South America and feed its information to the command centers. The Pentagon has also drawn up a master communications plan designed to tie the various agencies together to better coordinate the overall anti-drug effort.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: With dozens of separate Federal, state and local departments and agencies combating drugs, command, control and communications procedures have been chaotic. Many experts studying the problem of drug interdiction believe that the Pentagon's ablity to organize a coherent command, communications and intelligence network is the greatest contribution the military can make in the drug war.
title: Military Assumes Wider Role in Anti-Drug Effort

text: LEAD: THE COCAINE KIDS The Inside Story of a Teenage Drug Ring. By Terry Williams. 140 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $16.95. ADDICTED Kids Talking About Drugs in Their Own Words. By Joel Engel. 174 pp. New York: A Tom Doherty Associates Book/Tor. $15.95.
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: THE COCAINE KIDS The Inside Story of a Teenage Drug Ring. By Terry Williams. 140 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $16.95. ADDICTED Kids Talking About Drugs in Their Own Words. By Joel Engel. 174 pp. New York: A Tom Doherty Associates Book/Tor. $15.95.
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: As illicit drugs devastate not only the inner cities of the nation but the inner lives of millions of American families, ''The Cocaine Kids: The Inside Story of a Teenage Drug Ring'' and ''Addicted: Kids Talking About Drugs in Their Own Words'' offer sorely needed information from the front lines. They shed light on two distinct phenomena: adolescents as the backbone of the retail drug trade, and adolescents as addicts.
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: For nearly five years Terry Williams, a sociologist, spent much of his time with a group of teen-age drug dealers at after-hours clubs, discos, crack houses, street corners and their homes and places of ''business.'' The fruit of that work, ''The Cocaine Kids,'' provides a remarkable close-up view of the drug trade in New York's Spanish Harlem. Mr. Williams, a senior scholar at the Center for Social Research at the City University of New York, and a recipient of a MacArthur Foundation grant to study the culture of housing projects, is clearly a warm and engaging man who earned the trust of the crew of seven young men and one woman. They allowed him to observe them as they cut, mixed and sold their illicit wares. They knew he was taking notes on their lives and they let him know their secrets. In return, he ''was kind of a big brother, able to help with homework and even babysitting, but most of all a willing and sympathetic listener.''
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: Perhaps the most startling conclusion that emerges from Mr. Williams's ethnography is how much these young drug traders conform to mainstream values, including the work ethic, and how deep is their belief in the American dream, even as the communities in which they live are being shattered by the effects of drugs. The ''cocaine kids,'' aged 14 to 19 when we meet them, seven Dominicans and one black, are willing to work hard (sometimes 24 hours a day and 7 days a week), maintain self-discipline and risk their lives in the search for power, respect, prestige and wealth.
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: Unable to extract from family, school and community the skills, credentials, connections and opportunities to compete successfully in the regular economy, these youngsters have found a way to use their entrepreneurial talents. Through the drug trade they have been able to make a living, and to obtain status, prestige and proof that they can succeed at something.
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: Mr. Williams's detailed observations yield a fascinating picture of an underground economy that is remarkably similar to the world of respectable commerce. Moving up requires hard work, skill, intelligence and luck. Successful dealers and distributors generate repeat business, limit their own consumption, keep accurate records and avoid arrest. ''A kid who can routinely handle money, control personal use of cocaine, deal with buyers, and control a weapon, may make it out of the street and into the elite world of the super dealer.''
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: Max, the leader of the gang, worked his way up slowly. ''I had to convince people I could do it. I didn't have my hand out for no charity. I worked hard to get established.''
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: ''Selling coke is just like any other business,'' says Masterrap, second in command of the crew. ''You gotta work hard, stay on your toes, protect what's yours,'' he says, and not mess up ''with silly matters.'' Anyone who gives away or uses too much cocaine or parties too much doesn't last in the business. Self-indulgent behavior and freebasing - smoking base cocaine - are grounds for dealers to reject potential recruits.
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: We learn how the attraction of the drug business extends beyond its ''flash and dazzle'' and the chance to make big money. It also serves as ''a 'safety net' of sorts, a place where it is always possible to make a few dollars.''
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: What makes ''The Cocaine Kids'' particularly valuable is that Mr. Williams combines his talents as a keen observer with thoughtful, sophisticated analysis. He shows how the drug trade has become for many adolescents a thoroughly institutionalized social and economic system, shaped by powerful outside forces. The current prevalence of crack - base cocaine - is a result of a 1983 cocaine supply glut in foreign countries that led to price cuts and the search for new consumers; the centrality of teen-agers in today's drug economy is a result of vastly harsher penalties for drug traders over the age of 18.
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: Most important, Mr. Williams makes clear that the drug trade flourishes in direct response to the absence of legitimate opportunity. That is why its ranks are filled with minority children from poor families and from neighborhoods where the future looks forever bleak. These youngsters cannot see a future in lawful pursuits, or if they do, they cannot imagine a legitimate entry point. If you want to get into a legal business, says Masterrap, dealing is the way to get start-up money. Charlie, the only black in the crew, also sees the drug world as a stepping stone. He says his parents wanted him ''to at least finish college. . . . I don't plan to be in this business forever; I've got potential to do better, and I will. But right now, the thing is to make some money. After I do that, then I can think about college and all that.''
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: Mr. Williams's eye-opening account should be widely read, for it provides some of the understanding that could help this nation to formulate the complex policies and programs to assure that the inner-city youngsters coming of age in the 1990's will not be doomed to repeat the sad struggle of the cocaine kids.
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: The lives chronicled in ''Addicted'' are in striking contrast to those of the cocaine kids. In their own words, 10 youngsters describe how they spun out of control, starting with early experimentation with alcohol and marijuana (most were younger than 13 when they began), to a point where, in the words of one youth, they ''just couldn't relate to anything except drugs.''
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: Joel Engel, a freelance writer, recorded interviews with these young people in several southern California drug and alcohol treatment and rehabilitation centers where they landed after hitting bottom. Their backgrounds include both strict and permissive families, parents who issued warnings to stay away from ''bad kids'' and parents who did not keep track of their children's whereabouts. Mr. Engel says he is reluctant to generalize for fear of oversimplifying, but I suspect most readers would have welcomed some guidance in thinking about how an individual's constitution and early experience may be linked to later outcomes. One is struck by how often these youngsters talk of divorce and physical abuse, of foster care and adoption, of shyness and a sense of not fitting in, and of the enormous pleasure they experienced from their first tastes of alcohol and drugs. How does the frequency of these factors compare to a random population of otherwise similar, predominantly middle-class, teen-agers?
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: I would also have welcomed some discussion of whether the desperate circumstances (drug-related seizures, overdoses, destitution, prison sentences and suicide attempts) of these youngsters prior to successful treatment seem to be a necessary precursor, or whether better prevention, treatment and rehabilitation options might have averted some of the misery they both endured and caused. Nevertheless, the inside look we are offered is illuminating and gripping.
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: Joel Engel's interviews and Terry Williams's extensive observations and analysis will both contribute to our understanding. Americans urgently need to know more about every aspect of the destruction wrought by illicit drugs. In the absence of greater understanding and wiser action, including substantial investment in powerful social alternatives to drug using and trading, drug-related casualties - ranging from random shootings and even murder to addicted and abandoned babies and children - will continue to mount. ETHNOGRAPHY INWASHINGTON HEIGHTS
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: Terry Williams arrived in New York City by bus in 1966. He came from McComb, Miss., scene of much violence during the civil rights movement. Emerging from the Port Authority Bus Terminal he saw 42d Street, with its combination of glitter, grime and crime, and felt a spark of curiosity, the awakening of what he now calls ''a sociological imagination.''
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: Today, Mr. Williams is a senior scholar at the Center for Social Research at the City University of New York, with offices on - 42d Street. Looking down at a different stretch of the same bustling street in a recent interview, he remembered wondering ''Who are all those people and what are they doing?''
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: Over the years he studied after-hours clubs and wrote ''about prisoners, and then the Black Panther Party folk,'' he said. Still calling himself a ''country boy,'' Mr. Williams devoted four years to research in the Washington Heights neighborhood where he lives for ''The Cocaine Kids,'' his third book, just as the cocaine business turned into the crack epidemic.
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: He describes his research technique as an ''applied sociological method that is more a cousin to cultural anthropology,'' adding ''I've only been frightened once or twice.'' With William Kornblum, he is working on a new book about the lives of black and Hispanic youth in Manhattan public housing projects. ''We are finding that housing projects are stable and it is the community around them that is falling apart,'' Mr. Williams said. MICHEL MARRIOTT
title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVE AND DIE

text: The State of Texas is wagering that there is something drug dealers fear more than prison: the tax collector.
title: Tax on Drugs Aims to Snare Dealers

text: Next month the state will start taxing the sale of illegal drugs. The tax rate for marijuana will be $3.50 a gram, or $3,500 for each kilogram. For drugs like cocaine, the rate will be $200 a gram, or $200,000 for each kilogram.
title: Tax on Drugs Aims to Snare Dealers

text: ''If you deal untaxed drugs in Texas,'' said the State Comptroller, Bob Bullock, ''Bullock's raiders are coming after your property, your bank account, your car or anything else that can be seized to collect the tax.''
title: Tax on Drugs Aims to Snare Dealers

text: State officials say they do not really expect drug dealers to start lining up at the tax office door, checkbook in hand. ''We probably won't hear from a lot of drug dealers,'' said Mary Jane Wardlow, a spokesman for the tax collector's office. ''That isn't the real purpose.''
title: Tax on Drugs Aims to Snare Dealers

text: Rather, the tax is an added enforcement device, or another route of prosecution. Officials can immediately confiscate assets against the taxes that are owed - real estate, bank accounts, cars, boats and other possessions of suspected drug dealers. And if drug-dealing charges do not stick for any reason, prosecutors can pursue the tax evasion charges. The 'Al Capone Law'
title: Tax on Drugs Aims to Snare Dealers

text: The tax has been called the ''Al Capone law.'' Its sponsor, State Representative Billy Clemons, recalled that it was tax evasion charges that brought down the gangster in 1931, not ''bootlegging or any of the other stuff he was doing.''
title: Tax on Drugs Aims to Snare Dealers

text: Similar laws have been adopted by 12 other states in the past four years. Of those 12, only Minnesota, Arizona and Florida actively enforce their statutes. Minnesota, which enacted the tax nearly four years ago, has collected $730,000 in taxes and penalties. In addition, $26 million in delinquent assessments are on the books.
title: Tax on Drugs Aims to Snare Dealers

text: Florida has collected $300,000 and Arizona has collected $200,000 as of June of this year. Of the remaining states - California, Illinois, Kansas, Maine, Maryland, Montana, Nevada, West Virginia and Wyoming - most have not collected any revenue.
title: Tax on Drugs Aims to Snare Dealers

text: Under the Texas law, those who plan to sell illegal drugs are required to pay the tax before the sale and are issued a stamp for the amount paid. To sell a kilogram of marijuana, for instance, a dealer is required to pay $3,500 for a two-inch-square black and silver stamp with a picture of the Grim Reaper and the word ''drugs'' linked by arrows to the words ''death'' and ''taxes.''
title: Tax on Drugs Aims to Snare Dealers

text: To sell half a kilogram of cocaine, a dealer must buy a $100,000 stamp that is similar except that it has a picture of a skull and crossbones.
title: Tax on Drugs Aims to Snare Dealers

text: The law requires that stamps be attached to the drug container when a sale is made. Having a stamp does not make the sale legal, but it does spare the seller from prosecution for failing to pay the tax.
title: Tax on Drugs Aims to Snare Dealers

text: The new law requires that the names of purchasers be kept confidential. It bars the authorities from using the names to initiate criminal proceedings.
title: Tax on Drugs Aims to Snare Dealers

text: The law does not take effect until Sept. 1, and so far the only requests for the stamps have been from philatelists who want to add them to their collection.
title: Tax on Drugs Aims to Snare Dealers

text: Officials predict that nearly all the revenue from the new law will be raised not by selling the stamps but by collecting the tax and the penalties after dealers are arrested.
title: Tax on Drugs Aims to Snare Dealers

text: ''I hope they don't pay it,'' Mr. Clemons said of the fees for the stamps. ''I'd rather be able to charge them on tax evasion.''
title: Tax on Drugs Aims to Snare Dealers

text: LEAD: As the citizens of the Republic tremble with anticipation, a governmental body, created last year by an act of Congress, is wrestling with one of the most momentous decisions of our time. Within a few days, the 13 members of the National Film Preservation Board will announce their long-delayed selection of 25 films as official, bureaucratically sanctioned ''National Treasures.
title: Nix Critics' Flix Picks

text: As the citizens of the Republic tremble with anticipation, a governmental body, created last year by an act of Congress, is wrestling with one of the most momentous decisions of our time. Within a few days, the 13 members of the National Film Preservation Board will announce their long-delayed selection of 25 films as official, bureaucratically sanctioned ''National Treasures.''
title: Nix Critics' Flix Picks

text: Like so many Federal fiascoes before it, this dubious initiative arose from the best of intentions. When the Hollywood community lifted its voice to protest the colorization of classic films, Congress heard the anguished cry - or at least discovered the publicity value of hearings featuring some of the biggest names in show business. The result was the National Film Preservation Act of 1988, a grandly titled piece of legislation that does nothing to block the cutting or colorizing of motion pictures.
title: Nix Critics' Flix Picks

text: Under the act, those few films designated ''National Treasures'' must carry a ''conspicuous and legible'' warning label if any altered version is released on video or for television broadcast. The Librarian of Congress, advised by the newly constituted Film Preservation Board, will anoint up to 25 movies each year. For all other titles, the colorizers and choppers may proceed as merrily as before - without labels or hindrances of any kind.
title: Nix Critics' Flix Picks

text: Our experience with cigarette warnings suggests that even for the few films included in the Congressional canon, labels will constitute something less than a potent deterrent, especially since the message on a video box can hardly proclaim ''the Surgeon General has determined that colorization may be hazardous to your health.''
title: Nix Critics' Flix Picks

text: Moreover, one can easily imagine a different sort of notation once the board has made its recommendations: bold-faced announcements alerting video renters that ''This Film Has Been Certified as a Classic by the U.S. Government!'' Surely some enterprising marketeer will come up with a new ''National Treasure'' logo - perhaps a pirate chest filled with glowing gold coins.
title: Nix Critics' Flix Picks

text: It is also certain that some of our political leaders will feel compelled to second-guess the official selections every year. Imagine the logical designation of D.W. Griffith's ''The Birth of a Nation.'' Will members of Congress sit still when the Government places its seal of approval on a film that glorifies the Ku Klux Klan?
title: Nix Critics' Flix Picks

text: Or consider the potential inclusion on the Federal honors list of ''Easy Rider'' (with its glorification of marijuana) or ''Fort Apache'' (with its negative images of Native Americans) or ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' (with a host a problems too obvious to mention).
title: Nix Critics' Flix Picks

text: The eagerness with which our representatives in Washington recently assumed their new role of art critics inspires scant confidence that they will show restraint when it comes to the deep-seated and seemingly universal urge to review movies.
title: Nix Critics' Flix Picks

text: If Congress were serious about addressing the atrocity of unauthorized cutting or colorization of motion pictures, then some form of protection would be extended to all films, not just 25 a year. I would never suggest that the recently released sequel ''The Return of the Killer Tomatoes'' is a national treasure, but it seems reasonable to insist that if this or any other film appears at some future date in a significantly altered state, then prospective viewers should be notified with an appropriate label.
title: Nix Critics' Flix Picks

text: The temptation to appeal to government to solve every problem and to judge every issue is so powerful and pervasive that there is a horrifying logic in a Congressionally mandated list of best films. But why stop there? Let our legislators do something constructive about the appalling quality of today's new releases and make it a capital crime to initiate a project with a Roman numeral in the title. And mandatory life imprisonment would surely be appropriate for the perpetrators of new scripts about unconventional cops battling the system, or underdog sports heroes winning some unlikely triumph in an orgy of uplift.
title: Nix Critics' Flix Picks

text: If such new legislation is deemed unconstitutional or ill-advised, then Washington should abandon the movie review business altogether. We rely on government inspectors to approve prescription drugs or cuts of meat. But their efforts at evaluating feature films offer one public service we can easily forgo.
title: Nix Critics' Flix Picks

text: A virtual doubling of Federal drug law-enforcement money has failed to stem marijuana use in the United States, according to a study by a Harvard University researcher.
title: Policy on Marijuana Has Failed, Study Says

text: From 1982 to 1988, the annual Federal budget to enforce marijuana laws grew from $526 million to $968 million, but neither the availability nor the abuse of the drug has been curtailed, said the researcher, Mark A. R. Kleiman of the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.
title: Policy on Marijuana Has Failed, Study Says

text: Mr. Kleiman, whose study was made public Monday, said Federal efforts to halt the drug traffic on the international level had paradoxically encouraged a wider domestic marijuana industry that produces an even more potent form of the drug.
title: Policy on Marijuana Has Failed, Study Says

text: ''Some consumers are literally growing it at home,'' Mr. Kleiman said, ''and domestic production has gone from possibly 10 percent of the U.S. marijuana market to probably a third today by weight.''
title: Policy on Marijuana Has Failed, Study Says

text: Mr. Kleiman said he based his domestic production figure on Federal drug enforcement reports. The National Narcotics Intelligence Consumer's Committee said that in 1988 about 25 percent of the American market for marijuana was supplied by domestic growers.
title: Policy on Marijuana Has Failed, Study Says

text: Instead of pouring money into enforcement programs, Mr. Kleiman said, the money should be directed toward educational programs that would make marijuana use less acceptable.
title: Policy on Marijuana Has Failed, Study Says

text: Larry Cirignano, a spokesman for William J. Bennett, the national drug policy coordinator, declined to comment on Mr. Kleiman's study.
title: Policy on Marijuana Has Failed, Study Says

text: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that he had given Colombian authorities a list of 12 people described as ''drug-trafficking kingpins'' wanted for trial in this country, as the United States began talks with Colombia to arrange new extradition procedures.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: The move underlined the Bush Administration's desire to take advantage of Colombia's new, tough offensive against Colombian drug figures who make huge profits from the production and export of cocaine and marijuana.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: ''Facing trial in the United States is what these drug lords fear the most,'' Mr. Thornburgh said in a statement today announcing the move.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: There is no indication that Colombia has arrested any of the men on Mr. Thornburgh's ''dozen most wanted list.'' An American law-enforcement official said tonight that the United States still had doubts about the sincerity and depth of Colombia's commitment to destroy its drug cartels. Summary Extraditions Planned
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: In response to a wave of popular outrage after the assassinations in Colombia of a judge, a province police chief and a presidential candidate, President Virgilio Barco Vargas announced Friday that drug traffickers wanted abroad would be summarily extradited. Such extraditions had been halted as a result of a ruling by the Colombian Supreme Court in 1987, and about 80 Colombians are now thought to be under indictment in the United States on drug-related charges.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: In extradition, the Colombians will apparently have to use procedures other than those struck down by the court, but American officials said that the details were unclear.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: American officials said they were seeking the extradition of at least one of the more than 10,000 suspects arrested by Colombian authorities in the last four days, Eduardo Martinez Romero. In an indictment returned by a Federal grand jury in Atlanta in March, he was accused of laundering vast sums of money for the drug cartel based in Medellin, Colombia. He is not on Mr. Thornburgh's most-wanted list.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: The list includes five men identified as leaders of the Medellin cartel: Pablo Emilio Escobar Gaviria, 39 years old; Jose Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, 42; Jorge Luis Ochoa Vasquez, 40, and his brothers, Fabio Ochoa Vasquez, 32, and Juan David Ochoa Vasquez, 41. Mr. Thornburgh said they were among the most important of the Colombians under indictment in the United States. Slow and Laborious Process
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: The 12 Colombians have been charged with a variety of crimes. The charges include conspiracy to import or distribute illicit drugs, the distribution or import of such drugs, and the conduct of ''a continuing criminal enterprise,'' according to Justice Department officials.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: Though President Barco has vowed to extradite drug suspects to the United States, American officials said the process would be slow and laborious because it required large amounts of paperwork and delicate negotiations between Washington and Bogota.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: ''The bureaucracy does not work very fast,'' said an official of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration, which is part of the Justice Department.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: Justice Department officials said they were waiting for guidance from the State Department, and State Department officials said they were waiting for Justice Department lawyers to work out details of extradition arrangements with Colombia. No Need for U.S. Troops
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: In a telephone conversation Monday night, President Barco told President Bush that ''U.S. troops would not be necessary'' in Colombia's campaign against drug traffickers, the White House reported today.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: Pentagon officials said they were relieved that Colombia saw no need for American troops. The Joint Chiefs of Staff are reluctant to see American forces become directly involved in Colombia's drug war and do not have full confidence in the integrity of Colombia's armed forces.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: In a report in February, the State Department said there was little evidence that the Colombian armed forces had tried to purge their ranks of people responsible for human-rights abuses.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: Mr. Thornburgh said he was issuing the list of suspected drug traffickers to help Colombia identify and capture the fugitives of greatest concern to the United States. Talks on Documentation
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: As he left his office this afternoon, Mr. Thornburgh said the Justice Department did not know the whereabouts of the 12 men.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: ''We have begun discussions with the proper Colombian officials to determine the exact needs they have with regard to documentation'' of the American requests for extradition, he said.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: The Attorney General acknowledged that some of the Colombian suspects might try to flee to other countries. He said he had asked Interpol, the International Criminal Police Organization, to disseminate the 12 names to law-enforcement agencies around the world, so they would know that the United States was ''seeking these individuals for trial in our courts.'' Indictments in Atlanta
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: The most-wanted list was prepared by Justice Department officials in consultation with United States attorneys around the country.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: Four men on the list were recently indicted in Atlanta as part of Operation Polar Cap, the large money-laundering investigation of the arrangements prosecutors say was used by the Medellin cartel to move $1.2 billion in cocaine proceeds out of the United States. The four were Mr. Escobar, Jorge Luis Ochoa, Gustavo de Jesus Gaviria Rivero, 42; and and Gerardo Moncada, 42.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: Mr. Ochoa was arrested in November 1987 by Colombian authorities and at that time, his extradition was sought by a team of American officials sent to Bogota. He was released a month later at the order of a Medellin judge, who said she found no merit to the charges against him.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: The other people on the list are Gilberto Jose Rodriguez Orjuela, 50; Miguel Angel Rodriguez Orjuela, 45; Jaime Raul Orjuela Caballero, 46; Jose Santa Cruz Londono, 45, and Jose Ivan Duarte Acero, 37.
title: Thornburgh Gives Colombia a List of 12 Drug Figures the U.S. Wants Most

text: While the Colombian Government has clashed with its drug barons before, Bush Administration officials say that the latest crackdown indicates deeply felt outrage in Bogota and, perhaps, a turning point.
title: Are Colombians Fed Up?; U.S. Officials Hope for Break in Drug War, But There's a History of Blood and Failure

text: ''There have been cycles in the past where assassinations happened and the Colombian Government stepped up its efforts,'' said a State Department official who monitors the worldwide battles to control narcotics. ''The stakes get higher and higher every time. The latest crackdown shows that there is a great deal of sincerity and anger in Colombia, and we are encouraged by that.''
title: Are Colombians Fed Up?; U.S. Officials Hope for Break in Drug War, But There's a History of Blood and Failure

text: The Colombian police and military authorities have arrested more than 10,000 people in the last three days after the assassinations of a judge, a province police chief and a presidential candidate. The candidate, Luis Carlos Galan, had campaigned against drug lords and antagonized them by supporting the extradition of drug traffickers to the United States.
title: Are Colombians Fed Up?; U.S. Officials Hope for Break in Drug War, But There's a History of Blood and Failure

text: American officials said it was too early to know whether the arrests in Colombia would disrupt the flow of cocaine and marijuana to the United States.
