They said the Colombian Government and the big drug producers there had for years been engaged in attacks and counterattacks, continually raising the stakes in their war.
title: Are Colombians Fed Up?; U.S. Officials Hope for Break in Drug War, But There's a History of Blood and Failure

text: In 1984, Rodrigo Lara Bonilla, Colombia's Justice Minister, was killed. Belisario Betancur, then the nation's President, declared war on drug deal-ers and announced emergency measures. He approved the extradition of a suspected drug smuggler to the United States.
title: Are Colombians Fed Up?; U.S. Officials Hope for Break in Drug War, But There's a History of Blood and Failure

text: The head of the Bogota office of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration said in 1984, ''If the campaign continues at this pace, it is going to have a major impact on trafficking in Colombia and to the United States and Europe.''
title: Are Colombians Fed Up?; U.S. Officials Hope for Break in Drug War, But There's a History of Blood and Failure

text: Despite efforts by the Colombian Government over the last five years, Colombia retains its role as a major grower of both coca and marijuana, and illegal laboratories in Colombia produce most of the world's cocaine.
title: Are Colombians Fed Up?; U.S. Officials Hope for Break in Drug War, But There's a History of Blood and Failure

text: Melvyn Levitsky, the Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters, said tonight, ''It's obvious that public opinion in Colombia is outraged, and the executive branch there is intent on doing something'' about the big drug dealers.
title: Are Colombians Fed Up?; U.S. Officials Hope for Break in Drug War, But There's a History of Blood and Failure

text: In a report issued on Aug. 1, the State Department praised the Colombian national police and other security forces. ''In the first six months of 1989, cocaine seizures almost equaled those for all of 1988,'' it said. In the first half of this year, the Colombian authorities seized 21 metric tons of cocaine, as against 23 metric tons in all of 1988.
title: Are Colombians Fed Up?; U.S. Officials Hope for Break in Drug War, But There's a History of Blood and Failure

text: But Mr. Levitsky said Colombia ''does not have a functioning judiciary.'' Judges have been terrorized and assassinated by drug lords and compromised by bribes. As a result, he said, there is no guarantee drug traffickers will go to jail if arrested.
title: Are Colombians Fed Up?; U.S. Officials Hope for Break in Drug War, But There's a History of Blood and Failure

text: Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, chairman of the House Committee on Narcotics, praised Colombia for its tough actions against drug traffickers.
title: Are Colombians Fed Up?; U.S. Officials Hope for Break in Drug War, But There's a History of Blood and Failure

text: Colombian drug dealers have operated with impunity since 1987, when the nation's Supreme Court ruled that measures to put a 1979 extradition treaty with the United States into effect were unconstitutional.
title: Are Colombians Fed Up?; U.S. Officials Hope for Break in Drug War, But There's a History of Blood and Failure

text: Before the ruling, Colombia had extradited 16 people, including Carlos Lehder Rivas, a leader of the Medellin drug cartel, who was found guilty last year of smuggling tons of cocaine to the United States. He is in Federal prison in Marion, Ill., serving a life sentence without parole.
title: Are Colombians Fed Up?; U.S. Officials Hope for Break in Drug War, But There's a History of Blood and Failure

text: The United States has been prodding Colombia to resume extraditions. On Friday, President Virgilio Barco Vargas of Colombia announced that drug traffickers wanted abroad would be summarily extradited, in a procedure that bypasses the courts.
title: Are Colombians Fed Up?; U.S. Officials Hope for Break in Drug War, But There's a History of Blood and Failure

text: When a deranged man brandished a knife on Fifth Avenue at 45th Street one recent Monday, a man in blue quickly responded. Over the next 48 hours he helped subdue two more disorderly people, one of them half naked, quelled a robbery, witnessed a drug deal, chased a street peddler and called in two fires.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: Yet the peacekeeper, Kent Frezell, is no policeman.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: He is one of 29 uniformed but unarmed security guards who have been patrolling a 50-block section of midtown Manhattan in a privately financed venture to augment the New York City Police Department.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: In their first seven months, the guards, who have no law-enforcement powers beyond those of ordinary citizens, have intervened in more than 1,100 incidents, from robberies and assaults to auto accidents, and have participated in 176 arrests. There have been no shootings or other casualties among the force, and no disciplinary or corruption problems have arisen to date, organizers said.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: The effort is directed by a former Bronx and Queens police borough commander and financed by a surtax that commercial property owners in the Grand Central and Bryant Park areas voted to impose on themselves. It comes as a growing number of neighborhoods around the city, and many cities around the country, are turning to the private sector for help in coping with a tide of violent crime that has inundated conventional law-enforcement institutions. Beyond the Traditional
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: The trend, troubling to some experts, has taken private security services beyond the traditional interior confines of boutiques, malls, factories and office buildings to public streets.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: The efforts range from the so-called ''rent a cop'' services of moonlighting policemen - encouraged by some municipalities but restricted in New York City - to hired security companies and private security forces, like the one now patrolling in midtown Manhattan.''People have asked city cops to do too much,'' said Richard Dillon, who was on the New York City police force for 32 years and who retired last year as an assistant chief to recruit and run the security force for two private-public coalitions, the Grand Central Partnership and the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation. ''Cops can't do it alone.'' Now, Mr. Dillon said, it is time for citizens to pitch in. His force's patrolling has freed the police to concentrate on more important calls, he added.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: ''This was not created because we are aware of any trend,'' said Peter L. Malkin, chairman of the Grand Central Partnership and senior partner of Wien, Malkin & Bettex, a national real-estate company. ''This was created to cope with a problem.'' Wide-Open Crime Apparent
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: The problem, property owners have long complained, is harassment of travelers and passers-by by taxi hustlers and bag-snatchers, as well as open drug selling, particularly around the New York Public Library on 42d Street.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: The Partnership, a coalition of property owners, tenants and city officials, was organized in 1985. Later, under a state law empowering property owners to form special districts to collect a property surtax for local improvements, it helped form the nation's largest Business Improvement District.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: Commercial property owners in the district - which is bounded roughly by 38th and 48th Streets and Second and Fifth Avenues - voted to assess themselves 9.2 cents a square foot, thereby raising about $4.7 million a year for various projects. In addition, $1.4 million was raised by grants. Of the total, $800,000 went toward the $1 million security budget, with the Bryant Park counterpart contributing the remaining $200,000.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: In addition to the security force, the Grand Central Partnership underwrites extra cleanup crews, tourist information booths and a taxi dispatcher at Grand Central, and it will soon help sponsor a drop-in center for the homeless. Preliminary Training Given
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: The security guards start at about $10 an hour, or about $21,000 a year. They take a one-week, 35-hour course at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, a unit of the City University of New York, and spend two more weeks in training on the street.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: Two eight-member squads patrol the streets daily, one from 8 A.M. to 4 P.M. and the other from 3 P.M. to midnight. A six-member squad patrols from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: In addition to the 29 uniformed guards, including three women, there are three plainclothes investigators. Each squad is headed by a supervisor, equivalent to a sergeant in the Police Department. The supervisors are former police detectives, licensed to carry weapons.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: Squad members are trained to summon the police by radio through a command post in the Graybar Building, on Lexington Avenue at 44th Street, rather than try to seize malefactors themselves, except in dire emergencies. The patrolling area is trisected by three police precincts.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: ''I tell them, 'Hey, you're not cops,' '' Mr. Dillon said. A large part of their value is deterrence, he said. They are also stopped a lot by tourists with questions. Marijuana dealers - there is little crack in the area, Mr. Dillon said -often flee as the security guards approach, and illegal peddlers also tend to fold up their wares and melt away, at least until the patrol passes. Ample Action on Patrols
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: But at other times there is ample action, as Mr. Frezell's busy log showed for July 24 and 25, when he subdued the knife wielder and dealt with other incidents.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: On a typical afternoon last week, colleagues of Mr. Frezell summoned the police to arrest marijuana sellers on Vanderbilt Avenue at 45th Street. ''They just took three dealers and a buyer,'' Nick Maskew, a supervisor with a small radio receiver in one ear, reported to Mr. Dillon as he toured some of the posts.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: Outside Grand Central Terminal, another guard, Darren Kittrell, gave directions to a tourist couple. Across the street, in front of the Philip Morris Building, yet another guard, Kenneth Lind, called an ambulance for an intoxicated, disabled derelict who had fallen out of his wheelchair and was lying on the sidewalk.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: The logbook for July recorded 76 incidents of drug sales, of which the police responded to 44 and the security guards two, leading to 23 arrests; four assaults, all handled by the police and resulting in three arrests; 10 grand larcenies, of which the police responded to eight and security guards two, leading to two arrests; and three robberies, all handled by the police and leading to two arrests.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: Lesser offenses, like illegal peddling, bag-hustling and three-card-monte schemes, were largely handled by the security guards. Koch Supports Program
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: The patrolling program is supported by Mayor Edward I. Koch and other city officials, as well as business leaders, who say it has augmented, not replaced or interfered with, regular police patrols.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: ''They sold drugs right outside my door,'' said Carol Konop, owner of The Shirt Store, on Vanderbilt Avenue at 44th Street, and head of the Grand Central Merchants Association. ''The majority of the merchants were at their wits' end.''
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: The patrols have chased the drug sellers away, she said.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: The Police Department says it has no objection to private patrolling if it is closely supervised and coordinated with the police. But it has refused requests to confer ''special officer'' status on the private force, which would grant members broader arrest powers and other law-enforcement authority, like the right to issue summonses and take prisoners for booking.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: Special officer designation is intended mainly for governmental units patrolling housing complexes, hospitals, schools and other well-defined properties, said Capt. Alan Shulman of the Police Department's licensing division. ''There's no precedent for a private security company patrolling city streets having special officer status.''
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: Probably the longest-established private security force in the city is one at Rockefeller Center, a 285-member unit with some armed plainclothes officers. The force, headed by a former assistant police chief and Manhattan South Precinct commander, Michael McNulty, patrols the interior concourses and streets. Concept Is Spreading
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: The South Street Seaport has a 49-member unarmed private force that has been patrolling the enclave for five years. Roosevelt Island has an unarmed 35-member force commanded by a former police official and instructor, Neil N. Hetherington.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: Property owners and merchants in other districts are adopting or weighing similar strategies. The 14th Street-Union Square Business Improvement District, started in 1984 as the city's first, has contracted with a nonprofit security agency to patrol the area with three unarmed guards on a trial basis in November and December.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: In the Bronx, merchants in a business district around the Hub, along Third Avenue from 148th to 153d Street, have extended patrols by three unarmed security guards since last Christmas. The unit coordinates closely with the 40th Precinct, said Richard Propper, president of the merchants' management association.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: And in Washington Heights, merchants of the business district along 181st Street, Broadway and St. Nicholas Avenue will be meeting next month with a security company to plan coverage by two or three unarmed guards to curb purse-snatchings, drug trafficking and illegal peddling. Using Hired Guns
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: Other cities have adopted different approaches. Miami and St. Petersburg, Fla., allow off-duty police officers to work privately, armed and in uniform, and even arrange for the jobs. New York City police officers may moonlight on private security jobs, but only out of uniform and outside their precinct.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: Some criminal-justice experts see inherent dangers in the privatization of police work and say that poorly run private programs could pose a public threat.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: ''In general,'' said Thomas A. Repetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission of New York, a watchdog group, ''we believe the job of policing belongs to the municipal government, but in certain circumstances it may be incumbent on locals to organize patrols.''
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: While the group respects Mr. Dillon, he said, ''we would want any patrolling to be closely supervised and done together with the N.Y.P.D.''
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: Mr. Malkin of the Grand Central Partnership said: ''This is an antidote to vigilantism. This is not a lot of crazy people running around.'' Better Services Envisioned
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: Privatization could point the way to better public services, said Andrew Heiskell, chairman of the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation. ''Like a lot of things that happen in a civilization, somebody does it privately at first,'' he said.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: Daniel A. Biederman, president of the Partnership, said calls had come in from business leaders in other cities who said incredulously: ''You have your own police force? You got to be kidding.'' Experts see other issues at stake. ''When people contract out for police services, are they paying more for the extra overhead than if they just added money to the public police budget?'' asked Sheldon Greenberg, associate director of the Police Executive Research Forum, a nonprofit organization of chief executives of state and local enforcement agencies.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: Other questions, he said, are: Are citizens paying extra to fill a gap in policing or to obtain what they are entitled to anyway? Is there effective coordination between the private security unit and the police? And is the private patrolling being done safely?
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: As for whether tough private patrols merely push criminals into the next neighborhood, perhaps one too poor to afford such extra protection, Mr. Dillon is untroubled.
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: ''All I care about is that they're not here,'' he said. ''If I could chase them to Jersey, I would.''
title: And Now a Private Midtown 'Police Force'

text: When he was playing tennis, Bjorn Borg was known for never showing emotion on the court and rarely revealing any off it. Yet even now, seven years after he stopped playing the professional circuit, the man from Sweden who was the world's No. 1 player from 1978 to 1980 and a five-time Wimbledon champion continues to intrigue tennis fans: they follow every report of his behavior, from a mysterious alleged suicide attempt to assorted romantic difficulties to the recent financial troubles of his designer clothing line.
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: ''I'm amazed that years after I stopped playing tennis, people still recognize me in restaurants and ask for my autograph,'' the 33-year-old Borg said recently as he sat on a sofa in the New York office of his design-group company. ''I feel very proud of that.'' Relaxed Demeanor
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: Borg seemed relaxed and confident as he spoke and sipped coffee, quite a departure from the portrait painted of him after he was rushed to a hospital in Milan, Italy, last February for either a suicide attempt, a drug overdose or food poisoning, depending upon the source. And while he was given the chance, in an interview, to expound on a variety of subjects, it was clear Borg really wanted to discuss only one. ''You mean, the night I was supposed to kill myself?'' he asked, laughing.
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: ''We were home, Loredana and me,'' he said, speaking of his fiancee, Loredana Berte. ''I got sick, very sick from eating. I was feeling very bad, food poisoning probably. I took two sleeping pills because I wanted to sleep. Finally, I went to the hospital and they pumped my stomach. I was out of the hospital in two hours, feeling very good.
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: ''But when I came home, there were a lot of journalists asking, 'What did you do?' My mistake was that I didn't come out with a quote right away. I never dreamed that they would write I'm a suicide or taking drugs or whatever.''
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: There have been rumors around tennis circles about Borg and drugs for years, but when Borg was told of this, he just laughed and said, ''No, No.'' 'Never Taken Drugs'
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: ''Listen, it was not drugs,'' he added. ''I'm telling you the truth. It's never been drugs. I have never taken drugs.''
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: Part of the reason for the suicide speculation was the bevy of personal problems Borg has faced since he left the sport abruptly in 1982, not long after losing the 1981 United States Open final -his fourth Open final without a victory -to John McEnroe. His four-year marriage to Mariana Simionescu, a Rumanian tennis player, broke up in 1984 and for the next three years, Borg was romantically linked to Jannicke Bjorling, a Swedish model with whom he had a child, Robin, who will be 4 years old Sept. 18.
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: He and Bjorling, who split up two years ago, are currently involved in a custody battle over Robin as Borg prepares to marry Berte, an Italian rock-and-roll star whose outspokenness has often ruffled the Swedish establishment. Said Borg of his fiancee: ''She's a great woman. She's just like me. I love her very much and sooner or later people will find out that she's a great person.''
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: On top of all that, the Bjorn Borg Design Group - manufacturers of sportswear, shoes and accessories - is undergoing major financial difficulties and Borg has had a parting of the ways with his European partner, Lars Skarke, after Borg refused an offer of cash designed to keep the company solvent because he did not want to lose control. No Tournament Visits
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: But even with all the problems, Borg seems to relish his new life, and to have no inclination to pine for tennis stardom.
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: Borg hasn't been to a tennis tournament since 1983. Though he was in London this past year, he said, the thought never occurred to him to visit the All England Club, where Wimbledon is held. Nor is he likely to show up at Flushing Meadows for the United States Open, which starts next week.
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: ''I don't really miss it,'' he said. ''When I retired from tennis I wanted to do other things with my life. It had to come at one stage that I would retire, whether it was 35 or whenever. I had so many possibilities to learn, to see and to find out.''
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: ''I felt like I was sitting in a room and I could never go out that door,'' Borg continued, pointing to the glass wall in the office. ''I could never open that door. I mean, I loved tennis but there were things outside that door and I knew about it but I couldn't touch it.
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: ''I can't even think back now because mentally I'm so far from tennis. It's very strange that I did these things that I did.'' Gray in the Blond
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: Borg has matured tremendously since the days when comic books were his main source of reading and getting dressed meant changing from one contract-induced outfit to another. His blond hair still touches his shoulders, but it is now streaked with gray.
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: Borg is well aware of his legacy to tennis in his homeland, but he doesn't know why so many Swedes - like Joakim Nystrom, Henrik Sundstrom and even Mats Wilander - rise to a certain level and then burn out.
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: ''Sundstrom and Nystrom have been a little bit unlucky,'' he said. ''They've both had injuries and Nystrom's had some private problems. With Mats, it's a different story. He's not been injured and he doesn't have any problems, at least I don't think so. His big goal was to be ranked No. 1 last year. And I think for Mats to continue to achieve or to come back to be the No. 1 player, I don't think he's going to do that. Mentally, he's been there once but he's not ready to stay there.
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: ''I was a little more determined to win all the time. I just hated to lose. The Grand Slams were great, but any match or any tournament was important, even an exhibition. I wanted to win, even in practice. For Mats to continue thinking this way is very difficult, and if you've been No. 1 once, to stay on the top thinking this way is almost impossible.'' Nagging Memory of 1976
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: If Borg, who also won six French Open singles titles, has one regret in his own career, it is that he never won the United States Open. His greatest chance, he said, came in 1976 against Jimmy Connors at Forest Hills, a match he felt he really should have won.
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: ''It's not like a nightmare,'' he said, ''but if I had to pick one match, that would be it. I still miss today not winning the U.S. Open, mostly because I would be sitting here telling you how great it is that I won the U.S. Open.''
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: And if he were allowed a rematch of that 1976 Open final against Connors, would that be his dream match?
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: ''Since I stopped playing tennis,'' Borg said, ''I haven't had one dream about tennis. I do dream. I dream about everything except tennis.''
title: BORG STILL BOASTS THAT CALM EXTERIOR

text: By John H. Cushman Jr., Special To the New York Times
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: Drug testing of transportation workers is an increasingly popular idea, but programs to begin the testing are moving at a crawl.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: Eventually, four million transportation workers could be subjected to random drug tests, which are scheduled to begin in December unless litigation by unions blocks them.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: Last week, airlines met the Federal Aviation Administration's deadline for submitting new plans for testing employees for drug abuse. Industries like trucking and railroad transportation will file plans in the months ahead.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: The only tests of such workers that are routinely conducted now are those that follow accidents. The process of putting testing into effect in transportation illustrates how complex it will be to broaden drug testing to private business and industry. Dozens of Court Challenges
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: The new Federal rules on the testing face dozens of court challenges by unions and small transportation companies.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: Under these rules, imposed by the Transportation Department last year, employees in safety-related transportation jobs will be tested for the use of illegal drugs before employment, on a periodic schedule, after all accidents, whenever employers believe there is cause to suspect drug abuse and at random.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: When the Bush Administration presents its strategy for fighting drug abuse next month, this testing could be proposed beyond the transportation industry, where it is viewed as a precaution.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: The adoption of drug testing in other areas of society would be part of an effort to emphasize preventing drug abuse over the intercepting drug suppliers. A draft of the Administration plan calls for ''drug-free workplace policies in the private sector and in state and local government that include clear penalties for use and drug testing where appropriate.''
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: The airlines have not objected to the requirement for drug tests, even though they represent a substantial new expense and there has been only one documented case of a commercial air crash caused by drug abuse. Testing for the Airlines
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: Fisher & Hurst, a San Francisco law firm that has helped clients in the aviation industry develop testing programs, says 500,000 airline employees may be covered, adding that the tests could cost $25 for an initial screening and $35 for a confirming test. Any employee of an airline who performs duties as a flight crew member, flight attendant, instructor, aircraft dispatcher, mechanic, security guard or air traffic controller is subject to the new tests.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: The tests cover using marijuana, cocaine, opiates, PCP (phencyclidine, a hallucinogenic tranquilizer) or amphetamines. ''Whether the forms of employee drug testing required by the F.A.A. are constitutionally valid is likely to be answered later this year by the U.S. Supreme Court,'' said Ken Markowitz, who specializes in aviation and employment law at Fisher & Hurst.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: One indication of the Supreme Court's attitude was provided in March, when the Court rejected a labor union challenge to rules calling for drug tests of railroad employees after accidents.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: The Court found that the Fourth Amendment's prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures applied to drug and alcohol testing required by the Federal Railroad Administration's regulations. But the Court ruled that the regulations were reasonable when balanced against the Government's interest in regulating the behavior of railroad employees entrusted with the public safety. #22 Different Challenges The legal briefs will pile up as thickly as autumn leaves as at least 22 different legal challenges to Transportation Department rules move through lower courts. Furthest along are the challenges to the Federal Aviation Administration's drug testing programs. Six cases have been consolidated and oral arguments will be held on Sept. 15.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: Other cases have been brought against the Urban Mass Transportation Administration, the Federal Highway Administration, the Coast Guard, the Federal Railroad Administration and other agencies in the Transportation Department.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: The picture is no less murky on the legislative front. Congressional committees remain at loggerheads for the second straight year as proponents of testing argue over how to expand the concept to cover the most widely abused drug of all, alcohol.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: The Administration, too, is approaching the issue of alcohol testing cautiously. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, who has said that he believes it is a good idea, has not come up with a detailed plan to impose the tests on workers in aviation, trucking, or sea and rail transport.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: Despite pressures to initiate alcohol testing after the tanker Exxon Valdez oil spill, after which the captain's drinking was identified as a contributing cause of a transportation disaster, the department has decided on a time-consuming examination of options for possible new regulations. Skinner Sees Need for Caution
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: ''A lot more thought needs to go into the ideas of extending random drug testing to alcohol,'' Mr. Skinner told one of the committees grappling with the issue.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: The House of Representatives approved legislation this month that would dramatically broaden testing of rail workers for both drugs and alcohol. The bill would include random and periodic tests.The Senate Commerce Committee is insisting that any bill include workers in other transportation industries as well.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: Even though the Senate committee has approved a broad transportation testing bill, the chances of a compromise appear as slim this year as they were last year. Aside from who would be covered, there are other differences. The House bill sets detailed standards for how tests should be administered; the Senate bill leaves the details to the discretion of the Administration. The House bill emphasizes rehabilitation of offenders, while the Senate bill envisions harsher penalties, including dismissal of workers who test positive.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: It has been easier to draft comprehensive legislation in the Senate, where the Commerce Committee has jurisdiction over all transportation, than in the House. The testing bill's author, Representative Thomas A. Luken, chairman of the committee responsible for rail transportation, has no jurisdiction over aviation and road transportation.
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: ''When we attempted to find a middle ground in the area of testing railroad workers,'' said Mr. Luken, an Ohio Democrat, ''we found the Senate was adamant in insisting upon an all-or-nothing approach. Because the House had not passed legislation covering other modes of transportation, our bill was left out in the cold.''
title: Opposition Delays New Programs To Test Transport Workers for Drugs

text: In an auditorium in the Bronx one recent evening, the air was sour, the acoustics were abominable and the crowd was small and sleepy.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: None of that seemed to bother City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, who waited patiently for two other Democratic mayoral candidates to complete their pitches. Then, along with his wife and two of his sons, he plunged into the audience to pump hands and extend greetings. Next, he bounded onto the stage to speak - no, to orate - about his qualifications and ideas for the city.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: Many of the 50 or so listeners scattered through the hall appeared to be impressed. A few even seemed to be converted. ''Goldin finally came across as a guy who really knows what he's talking about,'' said Al Rivera, vice president of the Riverdale Hispanic Society, the group that sponsored the forum. ''If the election were tomorrow, I think I'd vote for him.''
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: The problem, as Mr. Goldin recognizes, is that with less than a month to go before the primary, nowhere near a majority of New York's voters share Mr. Rivera's view. Waiting for a Stumble
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: Most people, Mr. Goldin conceded, still see the race as a two-man contest between Mayor Edward I. Koch and Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan. That means that for Mr. Goldin to capture the lead, both Mr. Koch and Mr. Dinkins must stumble.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: ''I'm convinced that's happening,'' Mr. Goldin said in an interview between campaign events. ''People are getting very tired of Koch. They don't want to look at him for four more years. They're also realizing that while Dinkins is a very nice man, he just doesn't have the experience or competence to be an alternative to Koch.''
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: ''I have to show them that I'm the one they should turn to, the one who can actually be an innovator, a problem solver,'' he said. The other Democrat in the mayoral primary is Richard Ravitch, a former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. 'I Also Sell Retail'
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: Like other candidates, Mr. Goldin, who is 53 years old, is trying to communicate his persona and his proposals through television commercials, mailings and public appearances, including many where the turnout of registered voters has been low. Mr. Goldin says he does not let that discourage him.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: ''You know those signs on stores along Seventh Avenue: 'Wholesale, we also sell retail,' '' he said. ''That's me. I also sell retail.''
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: Many New Yorkers, Mr. Goldin said, still think of him only as the keeper of the city's ledgers. He would like for them to think of him instead as the dynamic leader New York has pined for, one who, in the words of a campaign aide, is ''a liberal on social issues, a conservative on fiscal issues and Attila the Hun on drugs and crime.''
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: In a couple of recent days of campaigning, those ideas were conveyed with mixed success.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: Stylistically, Mr. Goldin, may be the most polished of this year's mayoral candidates. On the stump and in interviews, he speaks in complete sentences and even in organized paragraphs. But partly because he is so thoroughly prepared, he often seems overly rehearsed and unspontaneous.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: As New York's chief financial officer for the last 16 years, Mr. Goldin can convincingly call himself the most knowledgeable candidate on the city's economic problems and prospects. But he is reluctant to play that suit too strongly because, he said, he does not want to feed the perception that ''I'm too boring, too dull, too uninspiring.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: ''I don't want people to say, 'He only deals with numbers - he can't get elected,' '' Mr. Goldin said.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: In one attempt to counter that image, a campaign brochure describes Mr. Goldin's ''passion for life: the fiery intensity that marks a great leader.'' 'Most Compelling Issue'
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: Instead of economics, Mr. Goldin has chosen to concentrate on drugs and crime, which he calls ''the most compelling issue in this election.''
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: But his ideas on this theme sometimes come across differently than intended. Mr. Goldin portrays himself as the ''only candidate who wants to make drug use a crime'' and who ''wants criminals who use drugs'' to be sent to work camps in upstate New York.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: To some listeners, that sounds like a declaration of war against casual and ''recreational'' drug users. Others discern racial insensitivity in the plan.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: ''I don't see why you should concentrate on putting a lot of black and Hispanic petty criminals into camps while the rich, white-collar criminals who bring the stuff into the country and who launder their drug money through the banks just sit back and laugh,'' said Coral Caporale, a lawyer and health administrator who attended the candidates' forum in Riverdale.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: ''I consider Goldin a bright man,'' she said. ''I think he could come up with better solutions than concentration camps for poor little punks.''
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: Such criticisms, Mr. Goldin said, misinterpret his proposal. The criminalization of drug use, he said, would not be enforced by having the police break into living rooms where marijuana is being smoked, nor would heroin addicts be arrested while nodding off on park benches. Instead, the law would be used as a weapon against the muggers, rapists and other criminals who make the streets of New York hazardous.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: If the police were permitted to run blood tests on criminal suspects as they do on drivers suspected of operating vehicles while intoxicated, Mr. Goldin said, prosecutors would have a simple and more certain way to obtain convictions.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: But that fuller explanation, Mr. Goldin acknowledged, is not easy to squeeze into a few inspiring sentences that are also intended to convey what he called his ''boldness, originality and willingness to do what needs to be done.'' Similarly, he lamented, many of his best ideas - for example, for reorganizing the Police Department, improving basic municipal services and revising the tax structure - are virtually impossible to package in ways that do not render listeners hypnagogic. Family Values
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: With his wife and teen-age sons in tow - they wear Frisbee-sized buttons saying ''Hi'' and giving their relation to him - Mr. Goldin is more successful in showing himself to audiences as a devoted, caring family man.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: At a recent $50-a-plate fund-raiser in Chinatown, Diana Goldin filled in for her husband with a few words about family values, while the candidate gave a radio interview by telephone, standing by the Chinese restaurant's men's room, one finger plugging an ear to block out the din of the diners as he fielded question after question.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: Mr. Goldin was still on the telephone when Mrs. Goldin finished, so their two sons - both dressed in the preppy uniform of blue blazers, baggy khaki trousers and loafers, with shirts and ties -improvised testimonials to their father's good character and devotion to civic duty.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: When at last Mr. Goldin returned to the room, he changed tack abruptly, telling the audience not to believe those naysayers who say there is too little time for him to overtake his rivals.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: ''Four weeks is an eternity,'' Mr. Goldin said. ''It's long enough for our campaign to catch fire.''
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: Once again, the hundred or so people in attendance responded well. ''I've admired Jay Goldin for many years,'' said James Chien, a Brooklyn physician. ''He's been doing his job well. There has been no loss of money from his office.''
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: ''We Orientals,'' he said, ''admire excellence.'' 'Honest' and 'Sincere'
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: Gerald Wen, a retired United Nations employee, called Mr. Goldin ''straightforward and honest.''
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: ''I think he's sincere and that there is still time for him to catch up,'' he said.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: Still, as Mr. Goldin has noted, his candidacy cannot ''catch fire'' until and unless the flames die out for Mr. Koch and Mr. Dinkins.
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: ''I like Goldin - he has the best handle on the economics of the city,'' said Odell Richardson, a Manhattan architect who listened to several candidates at the Riverdale forum. But at this juncture, he added, 'I can't say Goldin would be my first choice.''
title: ENERGETIC GOLDIN HURRIES TO CATCH UP

text: The doorbell to Francis Bacon's ramshackle mews house in South Kensington, London, has not worked for some time. Visitors knock loudly and then cling to a rope bannister while climbing the steep, narrow stairs that lead to the kitchen, bedroom and studio.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Bacon cannot paint anything so large it won't fit down the steps and out the door. On those infrequent occasions when the artist permits someone to see him at home, he must usher guests past the kitchen that includes a bathtub to the cramped bedroom that doubles as a living room.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: He has lived in this place for more than a quarter of a century. Widely regarded as perhaps the greatest living figure painter, a man whose works have lately sold for millions of dollars at auction, Bacon presumably could live anywhere in London. A few years ago he set himself up in a handsome and spacious home on the Thames, but he says the speckled light that reflected off the river and into his studio's windows proved too distracting, so he moved back here.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Even more than most people, Bacon is full of contradictions. He will turn 80 in late October, yet his wide eyes, chubby cheeks, pouting mouth and hair falling casually over his brow give him an astonishingly boyish look. Although he moves gingerly nowadays, his step retains traces of the jaunty side-to-side spring that was a characteristic of his youth.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: He can be intensely private yet disarmingly frank. With almost no prompting he details his fondness for alcohol and for men, his kinship with gangsters and drunks, his antipathy toward certain politicians, fashion designers and fellow painters. If coaxed just a bit, Bacon tells wonderful stories about being in Morocco with the novelist and composer Paul Bowles or wandering through galleries with Giacometti (''He liked all the wrong pictures,'' Bacon recalls with a laugh). Friends know he can be ornery and unpredictable, especially after a few drinks, but they also know him as a man of tremendous generosity, wit and vulnerability. Although he has created some of the most alarming and outrageous images ever painted, Bacon is in fact immensely likeable and kind, a true gentleman.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: He is especially eager to express opinions about art and literature. A few days earlier, over a leisurely lunch of wine, oysters and deviled crab at Bentley's in London, Bacon talked about Velazquez and Degas, Boulez and Freud (''Does anyone go to analysis anymore?'' he asked with apparent sincerity), Proust and Yeats (whose productivity in old age particularly intrigues Bacon) with the passion of the self-educated. A recent exhibition of early works by Cezanne prompted waves of enthusiastic commentary, although when the conversation eventually turned to American painters, he became coy. ''He does those women, nice man, what was his name?'' is the extent of Bacon's remarks about Willem de Kooning, and about Jackson Pollock he said: ''I can't see the point of those drips, and I think he couldn't do anything else particularly well.''
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Subtly, Bacon manipulates a conversation so that it never strays from subjects he is prepared to discuss, and it is almost impossible to get him to talk about anything else. He particularly dislikes analyzing his own work -''If you can talk about it, why paint it?'' is one of his favorite ripostes - and he tends to fall back on canned remarks as a way of sidestepping queries.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Bacon hates pretense, and he can be modest to the point of self-deprecation. When London's National Gallery asked him four years ago to do the first of the ''Artist's Eye'' shows, in which prominent British painters juxtaposed their works with favorites from the museum's collection, Bacon refused to include his own canvases.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: He eschews almost all the trappings of success. When necessary, he reaches into his pocket for a wad of cash to cover expenses, which may include an elegant suit, gambling debts, medical costs for an ailing friend, lunch at a swank restaurant or champagne for everyone at the Colony Room, the rundown drinking club in Soho he has been going to for more than 40 years. In an art scene that has become dominated by commercial excess and ironic posturing, Bacon seems like a character from an altogether different time, a genuinely serious painter, a survivor from the generation of post-war intellectuals for whom culture was not largely a matter of money.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Now he is the subject of a retrospective, on the occasion of his upcoming birthday, that opens Oct. 12 at the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington. The first Bacon exhibition in the United States since a modest show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1975, it travels to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art in February 1990 and to the Museum of Modern Art in New York in May 1990.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Bacon settles himself behind a table next to the single window in his bedroom, where four bare bulbs hanging on wires from the ceiling provide most of the illumination on a gray day. A cot is tucked at the far end of the room behind two old couches and a couple of dressers. There is a space heater in one corner. Years ago, Bacon owned paintings by the English artists W.R. Sickert and Frank Auerbach, but he gave those away. Several tattered photographs of his own works are now taped above the kitchen sink and around his studio. Otherwise the walls are bare. ''I can't live with pictures,'' he explains.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Only after a little while does the artist suggest taking a look at the studio, and even so, he clearly feels some hesitation about it, as if fearful of revealing one of his more intimate secrets. Bacon can appear very open and jovial to strangers, but he can be extremely reticent when it comes to certain aspects of his work, and this room is one of them.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: The studio, on the other side of the kitchen, is shaped like the bedroom but has a skylight that Bacon installed some years ago. It is a mess. Aged paint tubes, discarded rags, brushes, papers and dust (he has incorporated the dust in certain paintings to suggest sand dunes) have accumulated over the course of two decades and been swept into waist-high piles around the floor. Bare bulbs dangle from the ceiling. ''I once bought a beautiful studio round the corner in Roland Gardens with the most perfect light, and I did it up so well, with carpets and curtains and everything, that I absolutely couldn't work in it,'' he once told an interviewer. ''I was absolutely castrated in the place. That was because I had done it up so well, and I hadn't got the chaos.''
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Bacon has noted, only half in jest, that the closest he comes to abstract painting is on the walls of his studio: he uses them as a palette, and they are covered with multicolored dabs of pigment. On one (Continued on Page 74) easel rests a small portrait of Bacon's friend and, for the last several years, favorite subject, John Edwards, but all the other canvases have been turned to the wall, and the artist declines to show them. ''There's nothing on them,'' he says. Bacon remains in the doorway throughout, anxious to leave.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: He suggests a walk to the Victoria and Albert Museum before lunch. ''If you'd like, we can see the Constables,'' he offers, and a minute or two later slips a leather jacket over his turtleneck sweater and eases himself down the front steps and toward the street.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: I N APRIL 1945, BACON exhibited at the Lefevre Gallery in London a triptych entitled ''Three Studies for Figures at the Base of a Crucifixion,'' now at the Tate Gallery. Bacon's trio of half-human, half-animal creatures, mutilated and eyeless, their necks elongated and teeth bared, were perched on tables or pedestals in rooms with disorienting, fun-house proportions. They were roughly, angrily drawn, suggesting both Picasso's and Francis Picabia's works from the 1920's and something of German Expressionism. But nothing precisely like the ''Three Studies'' had been seen before. Bacon's tortured and menacing figures seemed to capture perfectly the anguished, claustrophobic spirit of war-ravaged England. At a time when painting in Britain, like so much else, had become enervated, these potent images were a sign of renewed vitality. Those who went to the Lefevre Gallery may not have liked Bacon's work, but they surely wouldn't forget it. Bacon had made his mark.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: During the next decades the artist developed his now-famous repertory of blurred figures, screaming popes, butchered carcasses and twisted portraits - images that continue to occupy his attention today. They have inspired some critics to classify him as a Surrealist or an Expressionist, and skeptics to describe him as a sensationalist or a lunatic. Bacon insists he is a realist, that he does not paint merely to shock. ''What is called Surrealism has gone through art at all times,'' he says. ''What is more surreal than Aeschylus?''
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Bacon maintains he is simply aiming to reproduce, as immediately and directly as possible, what his friend, the French anthropologist and poet Michel Leiris, calls ''the sheer fact of existence.'' This can encompass, Bacon points out, both violence and beauty, absurdity and romance. ''You can't be more horrific than life itself,'' he is fond of saying. Still, his paintings have lost none of their power to unnerve.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: In part for this reason, private collectors have not stood in line to buy, and although the work has always been very popular in France, Italy and Germany, it has engendered more respect than enthusiasm in the United States and even in Britain. The poet Stephen Spender, one of Bacon's oldest friends, says, ''I wanted to get a painting, but no one in my house really wanted one.'' Margaret Thatcher once described the artist as ''that man who paints those dreadful pictures.'' And in the recent film ''Batman,'' the only painting in Gotham City's Flugelheim Museum that the Joker prevents his henchmen from destroying is a Bacon.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: ''I think Americans have tended to measure him against de Kooning and find him less good,'' says David Sylvester, an English art historian, author of a book of penetrating interviews with Bacon, and one of the painter's most devoted friends. Spender insists that ''American artists provide for Americans a foreground of activity that they can't see beyond.''
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Yet a third view is held by Lawrence Gowing, the English art historian and painter who has been an admirer of Bacon for many years. ''Abstract Expressionist taste was buoyed up by a solid optimism and a feeling that painting was getting better, that a way was opening to something fruitful,'' he states. ''But Bacon's painting is rather tragic, and his whole work is an overt criticism of abstract art.''
title: UNNERVING ART

text: There are, however, few important museums of 20th-century art that do not own, or at least covet, one of Bacon's paintings, and his canvases are prominently displayed in London's Tate Gallery and the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art in Edinburgh. Bacon's work has increasingly been so ambitious in scale and polished in execution that it looks specifically designed for public exhibition, as if the artist were demanding his place in the museum beside Manet, Picasso and the other modern masters. Gowing describes these latest canvases, even the most violent, as ''classically serene.''
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Consider, for example, one of his most recent works - a second, much larger and arguably more affecting rendition of the ''Three Figures,'' in which Bacon has added an element of ambiguity to the gruff original by refining its forms. The new version is like a memory of the earlier one, still vivid but less tactile. After an initial reaction of horror or wariness, the viewer's attention almost invariably focuses on the strange lyricism and meticulousness of the paintings. Bacon has a quirky and rather wonderful sense of color, and there have been very few artists who have ever managed to depict flesh in such a voluptuous way. The word ''shocking'' is still constantly used to describe Bacon's works, but in fact they can be exceptionally beautiful and very moving.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: The artist insists that his paintings be hung in gold frames and protected by a sheet of glass, which he thinks imparts evenness and sheen to his unvarnished surfaces. This style of presentation recalls the Old Master pictures that Bacon so admires; it also heightens the tension that comes from representing bizarre or subversive scenes in a highly formal, elegant way. He may depict two Michelangelesque nudes thrashing on a bed, but he shrouds the details behind seductive, titillating veils of paint. There is decorum to Bacon's impropriety -a paradox that describes the artist himself: He talks about sex and alcohol the way most people discuss the weather, but he also exudes a natural courtliness and grace, as if he were a good boy trying to be bad.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: T HE SON OF A RACE-horse trainer (and a collateral descendant of the great Elizabethan statesman and philosopher), Bacon moved with his family between Dublin and London during the first years of his life. He was the second of five children. He never got along with his parents, who, in turn, never supported the idea of his becoming a painter.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Asthma made school a problem, so he was tutored by clergymen at home, where in general he was left to his own devices. These involved what his heavy-gambling but strict father considered behavior so unacceptable -Bacon had sex with some of the grooms at the stables and was once caught trying on his mother's underwear - that he banished the youngster. At the age of 16, Bacon set out for London, and then Berlin.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: There, in a city devoted to extravagance and excess, Bacon could indulge in sexual escapades and gambling sprees; he spent long nights in transvestite bars and endless hours with the sort of rough-and-tumble characters who would always form a part of his social circle.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: ''Berlin was a very violent place - emotionally violent, not physically - and that certainly had its effect on me,'' Bacon says. But I wasn't the slightest bit interested in art until about 1930. I lived a very indolent life. I was absolutely free. I drifted for years.'' He smiles. ''You know, when you're young, there are always people who want to help.''
title: UNNERVING ART

text: He also spent time in Paris, and although he says he was not interested in art, Bacon remembers attending an exhibition of Picasso's surreal, biomorphic bathers painted in the 20's. Over the years, he has given different accounts of how significant this event was to his own development, but he certainly left Paris with a particular notion of the artistic life properly spent. Bacon has always cultivated an image of himself as an instinctive painter, a loner, someone who is unconcerned with success - qualities that make him resemble more the French artist of the 20's than the celebrity artist of today.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: He returned to London in 1929 and for a brief period designed modernist furniture, producing works that earned him a reputation as innovative and highly talented but that he now dismisses as ''absolutely horrid'' and ''ghastly stuff.'' A Cubist-inspired pattern for a rug suggests Bacon's interest in Picasso was not entirely casual. Unfortunately, Bacon came to consider the paintings from these years ''so awful'' that he painted over most of the canvases and bought back others in order to destroy them; virtually none exist.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Bacon participated in a group show in 1933, the same year that the critic and historian Herbert Read reproduced the artist's ghostly ''Crucifixion'' in his book ''Art Now.'' The next year, Bacon organized a solo show, and in 1937 his work was included in an exhibition at Agnew's in London.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: But that was the last time Bacon put his paintings on public view until 1945. More than lackadaisical about his career, he was totally indifferent. Bacon had never had any formal art training, and even when he began to teach himself to paint during the 30's it seems to have been little more than a distraction from drinking, gambling and wandering around the edges of London society. ''Bacon before 1939,'' writes John Russell in his monograph on the artist, was ''Marginal Man personified.'' When the Second World War began, he tried to enlist but was turned down because of his asthma. He took a variety of odd jobs, working for a time as a house servant and a secretary.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: It was not until 1944, when he began to work on ''Three Studies for Figures at the Base of a Crucifixion,'' that Bacon says his career as a painter began in earnest. Yet the years spent in Dublin, Berlin and Paris, and in London during some of its grimmest days, clearly left their mark. The emotional turbulence of Bacon's life, the restlessness, the sexual indiscretions, the sense of frustration and claustrophobia he felt as a boy, the offhand disregard for social mores and, importantly, the complete lack of concern for what others might think - all these became distinguishing features of his art. Only toward the end of the war, when he was already 35 years old and just beginning to take himself seriously, did Bacon finally realize that painting was the best way for him to bring order to the chaos of his life, to translate what he calls his ''obsessions'' into concrete images.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: U PON ARRIVING AT the Victoria and Albert, Bacon immediately marches down one of the museum's cavernous halls looking for an elevator to the floor where Constable's paintings are displayed. He quickly becomes lost, asks directions from a guard, takes another wrong turn and again loses his way. The circuitous route leads him past some pottery, a display of raincoats, medieval wood carvings and jewelry, and in every case the artist becomes momentarily absorbed by what he sees. Just as he feels socially at ease with both petty thieves and wealthy patrons, he can become deeply intrigued by a Turner hanging in the National Gallery and also by a chair he glimpses in the window of Conran's on his way to lunch. Not surprisingly, Bacon's paintings are full of references to Ingres and the daily press, to Picasso -who, with Duchamp, remains just about the only 20th-century artist he admires - and the latest fashion shows.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Finally, Bacon stumbles upon the elevator and finds the Constables. ''These are pictures I could live with,'' he says enthusiastically, bounding toward the great sketches for ''The Hay Wain'' and ''The Leaping Horse.'' Although Bacon spent a good portion of his youth in the Irish countryside, he has painted very few landscapes. Yet he feels a particular affinity with these scenes and with many of the small sketches displayed in cases nearby because, he explains, they exemplify Constable's ''free style, his tremendous spontaneity.''
title: UNNERVING ART

text: ''I know that in my own work,'' he continues, ''the best things are the things that just happened - images that were suddenly caught and that I hadn't anticipated. We don't know what the unconscious is, but every so often something wells up in us. It sounds pompous nowadays to talk about the unconscious, so maybe it's better to say 'chance.' I believe in a deeply ordered chaos and in the rules of chance.''
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Bacon never makes preliminary drawings but works directly on unprimed canvas, where a wayward brush stroke cannot easily be disguised. Sometimes he will toss a bucket of paint across the canvas in order to promote spontaneity. ''I have to hope that my instincts will do the right thing,'' Bacon says, ''because I can't erase what I have done. And if I drew something first, then my paintings would be illustrations of drawings.'' Arriving at another of his favorite phrases, he adds, ''I want to create images that are a shorthand of sensation.'' Photographs have always been a source of inspiration for Bacon. Many of his ideas and quirky compositional devices have originated in the newspaper and magazine snapshots that he collects, and especially in the famous sequential photographs of prancing animals and walking, running and wrestling men that Eadweard Muybridge took during the last quarter of the 19th century.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: In the twisted, awkward, even bizarre movements of Muybridge's figures, Bacon sees a potential repertory of images that are at once startling and commonplace, and it is this impression of something sudden and unposed, yet absolutely true to life, that the painter wants to convey in his own work. In painting portraits, he dispenses with a sitter and relies solely on photographs and memory. Bacon uses only intimate friends as subjects, and he fears they might be offended to see him maneuvering and rearranging their faces - despite the unmistakable likeness that emerges.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Bacon has also based works on paintings by Van Gogh, films by Luis Bunuel and poems by T.S. Eliot. During the 50's, he combined references to Velazquez's ''Portrait of Pope Innocent X'' and a still photograph of a screaming nurse from Sergei Eisenstein's film ''The Battleship Potemkin'' to create his series of screaming popes, which have achieved a degree of fame he now finds tedious. ''Those references were just mental starting points, armatures on which to hang the pictures,'' Bacon says. ''Actually, I hate those popes. I think the Velazquez is such a superb image that it was silly of me to use it.''
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Bacon insists his paintings are not about anything in particular, that nothing should be read into his borrowings from certain images, and that even his triptychs, which might seem to be recounting a tale in three scenes, are in no way narrative. He compares them to police mug shots of a suspect's face and profiles. Nonetheless, his paintings often contain arrows, circles, mirrors and boxes that seem to single out one or two elements as having special significance. Bacon disagrees. ''I've no story to tell,'' he says. IT IS EARLY AFTERNOON, and so far Bacon has had nothing to drink. Once, when asked to sum up his life, he said it consisted of ''going from bar to bar and drinking and that kind of thing.'' The walk is short from the museum to Bibendum, the elegant restaurant in a former Michelin tire factory where Bacon has made a lunch reservation and where he is greeted warmly as a regular. He orders oysters and the first of what will be many glasses of champagne. By the end of the meal he has also drunk the better part of two bottles of wine. When the idea of a trip to the Colony Room comes up, Bacon agrees, saying that he hasn't been to the bar in months.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: It is a small, oddly shaped and rather claustrophobic place - not unlike many of the rooms in Bacon's paintings - and it is almost impossible to find the entrance from the street. Photographs and caricatures of the owners and regular patrons hang haphazardly on the dark green walls. The dozen or so people who are there getting drunk in the late afternoon seem very happy to see the artist, and he seems utterly at home joking and laughing with them. They are not part of the London art scene but clearly know he is a famous painter and don't seem to care. This especially pleases Bacon. He offers drinks all around, then orders a bottle of champagne, then another. Most people couldn't stand up at this point, but Bacon is just getting started.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Nikos Stangos, an editor at the British publishing house Thames & Hudson, who has edited books about Bacon and known the artist for many years, notes that ''Francis never expresses moral indignation about anything.'' And in fact, chatting easily over drinks, Bacon recalls without the least sense of outrage or distress episodes like his arrest in 1970 for drug possession.''It was obvious at the trial that the police had planted marijuana on me, because I'm asthmatic and can't smoke,'' he says drily. ''I wasn't really worried anyway, since I recognized some criminals on the jury.''
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Still, a vein of deep compassion and sorrow runs just beneath the surface of Bacon's images. These feelings occasionally emerge in conversation, as when the subject of George Dyer comes up. A heavy drinker, Dyer was the artist's closest friend throughout the last half of the 60's; he died in a hotel room in Paris in 1971 at the age of 37, just two days before a Bacon retrospective opened at the Grand Palais.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Between 1972 and 1974, Bacon did a series of three triptychs that, despite the artist's repeated statements about never painting narratives, are transparent meditations on Dyer's death. Dyer, naked or almost naked, is shown slumped on the toilet, vomiting into a sink or slouching in a chair, either half-asleep or in a drunken stupor. Parts of his limbs and chest are invariably missing, as if they had evaporated. In all the scenes Dyer is alone and in the sort of bare, windowless room that is a trademark of Bacon's work but in this case specifically evokes the hotel in Paris. The flesh is both roseate and ashen -voluptuous and deathly -and in several of the scenes Dyer casts a pink shadow that does not conform precisely to the shape of his body but resembles a thick pool of liquid or a spectral presence, like a shadowy version of the beastly Furies Bacon later painted in a triptych based on the ''Oresteia.''
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Perhaps the most memorable of the scenes, the centerpiece of ''Triptych - August 1972,'' represents Dyer as hardly more than a lumpy, oozing form, his face obliterated, his body prone across a blackened doorway. There is something of Muybridge and of Michelangelo in this twisted, fleshy figure, something, as well, of the Manet who painted ''The Execution of Maximilian,'' which was among the works Bacon chose to include in his ''Artist's Eye'' exhibition at the National Gallery.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: To see figures that look at once corporeal and ghostly, sensual and morbid, beautiful and horrific, is to understand why Bacon has come to be regarded as one of the most distinctive and difficult figure painters of the century. The triptychs of Dyer's last hours demonstrate what the artist means when he describes himself as a realist, as a painter devoted not to Expressionism or Surrealism but to what he has called ''the brutality of fact.'' During lunch at Bentley's, Bacon had described old age as ''a desert because all of one's friends die,'' and the paintings of Dyer exude this despair. The only faith they can be said to express is in the power of paint.
title: UNNERVING ART

text: ''I am an optimist, but about nothing,'' Bacon says, repeating another of his favorite phrases. ''It's just my nature to be optimistic.'' He stops to polish off the last drops from a glass of champagne. ''We live, we die and that's it, don't you think?''
title: UNNERVING ART

text: Lawrenceville School, the prominent, private boarding academy near Princeton, N.J., was accused in a lawsuit yesterday of being responsible for the alcohol and drug abuse of a former student.
title: Lawsuit Faults Lawrenceville For Addictions

text: In the suit, filed in Federal District Court in Trenton, the former student's father accused the school of ''condoning and permitting the presence, use, and retention of illegal drugs and alcohol by minors'' in dormitories, and of failing to conduct effective anti-drug and alcohol counseling programs.
title: Lawsuit Faults Lawrenceville For Addictions

text: In response, Lawrenceville's headmaster, Josiah Bunting 3d, asserted that responsibility for the teen-ager's problems rested with his father. 'Culture Soaked With Alcohol'
title: Lawsuit Faults Lawrenceville For Addictions

text: ''I'm not denying the boy did not develop an addiction,'' Mr. Bunting said in a telephone interview. ''But it taxes credulity to find the school responsible. Short of putting someone behind a locked door, an American teen-ager is going to be exposed to drugs and alcohol. Kids live in a culture soaked with alcohol, especially beer.''
title: Lawsuit Faults Lawrenceville For Addictions

text: Mr. Bunting said Lawrenceville had a ''very imaginative and very deliberate'' program to discourage drug and alcohol use by its 750 students.
title: Lawsuit Faults Lawrenceville For Addictions

text: First offenders, which include those possessing a bottle or can of beer, are placed on a year's probation and confined for a time to their dormitories for all but classes and meals, Mr. Bunting said. A second violation, he said, means automatic dismissal.
title: Lawsuit Faults Lawrenceville For Addictions

text: Since he became headmaster in September 1987, Mr. Bunting said, 10 students had been expelled for violating the policy.
title: Lawsuit Faults Lawrenceville For Addictions

text: The former pupil's father, Dr. Manuel C. Palao, a physician in Bethlehem, Pa., seeks recovery of $32,304 that he said he spent on rehabilitation programs for his son Michael, 16 years old. Dr. Palao is also seeking $33,739 in tuition and other expenses for his son's three-year stay at Lawrenceville between Sept. 1985 and June 1988.
title: Lawsuit Faults Lawrenceville For Addictions

text: The suit says that school authorities first became aware of Michael Palao's drug use when he admitted to it in April 1988, near the end of his sophomore year. Dr. Palao said he was not aware of his son's ''depth of involvement with drugs and alcohol use'' until he had a hospital conduct urine tests that revealed marijuana use.
title: Lawsuit Faults Lawrenceville For Addictions

text: He said school officials knew of the presence of alcohol and drugs in the dormitories because of a program through which students at the end of each year can anonymously surrender alcohol and drugs in boxes and garbage cans.
title: Lawsuit Faults Lawrenceville For Addictions

text: The brother-in-law of Luis Escheverria Alvarez, who was President of Mexico from 1970 to 1976, was held without bail today as a witness in the 1985 torture-murder of a Federal drug agent.
title: In-Law of Ex-Mexican Leader Held in Drug Agent's Slaying

text: The former President's brother-in-law, Ruben Zuno-Arce, was flown from Texas to Los Angeles on Monday and ordered held pending a hearing next Monday. Investigators say he has information about the slaying of Enrique Camarena, an agent of the Drug Enforcement Administration, according to papers filed by the agency.
title: In-Law of Ex-Mexican Leader Held in Drug Agent's Slaying

text: Mr. Camarena and his pilot were kidnapped and slain after the agent led a series of raids on marijuana plantations allegedly run by a reputed Mexican drug kingpin, Rafael Caro-Quintero. Eight more men are charged with murder and conspiracy in the case, including Mr. Caro-Quintero, who is awaiting trial in Mexico City.
title: In-Law of Ex-Mexican Leader Held in Drug Agent's Slaying

text: SOME young Alaskan Eskimos are illegally shooting hundreds of walrus, using chainsaws to cut off their heads and trading the great beasts' ivory tusks for cash and drugs.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: While these ''headhunters'' have not yet reduced the walrus population to the danger point, conservationists fear they could do so, especially when an impending international ban on trade on elephant ivory takes effect.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: ''The walrus could end up in the same situation as the elephant in the next few years unless something is done to prevent it,'' said Dave Cline, regional vice president of the Audobon Society in Anchorage.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: No one knows exactly how many walrus inhabit the ice floes in the Bering Sea. The last walrus census, done by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service in 1985, put their number at 234,000. Another census is scheduled for next year. 'A Few Rotten Apples'
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: The Marine Mammal Protection Act prohibits the hunting of walrus, seals, whales, polar bears and other mammals except by Alaskan Eskimos hunting in a ''non-wasteful manner,'' using the animal for food.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: Eskimos who hunt walrus legally say the walrus herd has never been healthier, and that hunting is so limited by weather that the illegal hunters are not a threat to the herd. They say it is being exaggerated by whites who resent Eskimo hunting privileges and by conservationists who hope that alarm over the walrus will attract donations. Most hunters who kill walrus do so legally, Eskimo leaders said.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: ''A few rotten apples are making the whole bushel look bad,'' said Benjiman P. Nageak, chairman of the Eskimo Walrus Commission.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: But even a small number of headhunters do significant damage, Mr. Cline said. Headhunters hunt more often than other Eskimos, he said.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: ''When they only take the heads, they can kill several walrus on one trip, he said. ''When they hunt for meat, one walrus is usually plenty.''
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: ''The bad guys use chainsaws to cut off the heads in a hurry,'' said Dave Fisher, manager of the Togiak National Wildlife Refuge where some illegal hunting has recently taken place. ''It's quicker than using a knife.'' #12,000 Killed Each Year The Fish and Wildlife Service estimates that about 10 percent of the walrus taken by Alaskan Eskimos, about 400, are killed by headhunters, generally young men in the mid-20's to mid-30's.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: About 12,000 walrus are killed each year, said Francis H. Fay, a professor of marine science at the University of Alaska in Fairbanks. About 4,000 are taken by Alaskan Eskimos. Another 4,000 are taken by Siberian Eskimos and Soviet hunting ships that supply walrus meat for animals raised for their fur. About 4,000 more are killed by hunters but not retrieved. One percent of the herd die each year of natural causes.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: ''Twelve thousand a year is too much,'' Mr. Fay said. ''That level of killing in the past has reduced the population drastically. That's the basis for concern that the current harvest may be excessive.'' A Source of Food
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: Walrus and seals are still a main source of food for many Eskimo villages. Eskimo walrus hunters travel to out to ice floes by motorboat and shoot the walrus with high-powered riles, butchering them on the ice.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: For food they take walrus's heart, liver, flippers and some of its skin. They use its ivory tusks to make tools, buttons, jewelry and other items.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: ''Just cutting off their heads is considered a wasteful manner'' and a clear violation of the law, said James Sheridan, a special agent for the Fish and Wildlife Service in Anchorage.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: But the Marine Mammal Protection Act is nearly unenforceable unless headhunters are caught in the act, Federal agents say.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists
