text: ''You can't tell by just looking at a walrus head whether it was taken properly or not,'' said Wally Soroka, a special agent for the Fish and Wildlife Service. ''If you ask someone, they'll always say they killed the walrus for food.''
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: While Federal officials have handled several cases of illegal possession or trading of walrus ivory, only one Eskimo has ever been tried for a ''wasteful taking'' of walrus. He was found guilty last month in Federal court, said the acting United States Attorney in Anchorage, Mark R. Davis.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: Federal authorities said they saw the man, Richard Clark, 38 years old, of Clark's Point, Alaska, cut the heads off nine walrus. He was hunting at the Togiak National Wildlife Refuge along Alaska's Bristol Bay, near where the Aleutian Islands begin to stretch away from the mainland into the Pacific. He faces up to a year in prison and a $100,000 fine.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: His father, Joseph Clark, 68, and brother, Samuel, 26, pleaded guilty to the same charges and received sentences of six months probation and had to pay $500 fines. The elder Clark agreed to tape public service announcements warning hunters not to kill walrus solely for ivory. A Motive: Drugs
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: Although no drug charges were filed against the Clarks in connection with the ivory poaching, Fish and Wildlife Service agents say nearly every walrus case they handle involves drugs.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: Joeseph W. Bottini, an assistant United States attorney in Anchorage, said the amounts of drugs involved are often ''amazingly small.'' In one instance, he said, 10 walrus heads were traded for one ounce of marijuana. An average walrus head, with two tusks, typically sells for $500 to $700 depending on the size and quality of the tusks, Mr. Bottini said. An ounce of marijuana sells for $250, at most, in remote regions of Alaska, he said.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: State wildlife officals are more numerous and more widespread than their Federal counterparts. But they have no jusristiction over the illegal hunting of walrus because the Marine Mammal Protection Act, passed by Congress in 1972, placed authority solely with the Federal Government to keep the state from restricting the Eskimos' hunting rights. The Fish and Wildlife Service has only 10 agents to police thousands of miles of Alaskan coastline, officials said. Leaders Fear Restrictions
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: Tribal leaders and officials of Eskimo organizations say they fear the illegal hunting could result in laws to restrict Eskimo hunting rights.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: ''Headhunters are a small minority but unfortunately they are the most visible,'' said Charles Johnson, a walrus hunter and a delegate to the Inuit Circumpolar Conference, a group that represents Arctic natives from Siberia to Greenland.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: He and other Eskimo leaders said that headhunting is best battled by stricter enforcement of existing laws and educating the many Eskimos in remote villages who are unaware that it is illegal to hunt the walrus only for its ivory.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: But many, including many Eskimos, say that the task will be difficult because the authority Eskimo elders once had has been eroded by increasing contact with modern culture.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: Eskimos have much to lose if the walrus population is threatened. Not only will many villages be deprived of one of their sources of food, but the vast network of native ivory carvers and sellers will also be threatened.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: Competition from drug dealers and black-market traders has already driven up the price of wholesale ivory, making it expensive for legitimate carvers to obtain raw ivory for their work.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: Representatives from the 101 nations that are members of an international treaty to protect the world's wildlife, the Convention on International Trade of Endangered Species, are scheduled to meet in October and will probably vote to ban the trade of African elephant ivory. 'Poachers Rarely Just Go Away'
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: Unless the worldwide demand for ivory is somehow reduced, poachers and black market traders will probably look to Alaska and the walrus to relace the lost supply of ivory now coming from Africa, said Ginette Hemley who monitors the trade of wildlife products for the World Wildlife Fund.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: ''Poachers rarely just go away after they extinguish a species or after a ban takes effect,'' Ms. Hemley said. ''They look for a new supply.''
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: The conservationists fear that the economic rewards of headhunting will become too great for some Eskimos to resist and that they will abuse their privilege to supply the hungry ivory traders who will come bearing cash.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: One answer, they say, would be to restict the number of walrus each village is allowed to take, based on its food needs. Such a system is already in effect for whales.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: Everyone agrees that any solution will have to take into account the poverty of the Eskimos' coastal villages.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: Whatever the solution, the Eskimos are adamant about retaining their right to hunt the walrus.
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: ''We have hunted these animals for hundreds and thousands of years,'' said Mr. Nageak of the Eskimo Walrus Commission. ''We as a race have never done the population of these animals any harm.''
title: Hunt for Walrus Ivory Worries Conservationists

text: One of the most puzzling aspects of the labyrinthine Wedtech affair has been the friendship of former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and his old law school buddy E. Robert Wallach, who once tried to run for the Senate on a platform advocating gay-rights legislation and the decriminalization of marijuana. From the beginning, Mr. Wallach told prosecutors that his letters to Mr. Meese on behalf of Wedtech, a small minority-owned company seeking Government contracts, were part of his lifelong fight against racism. Last week, Mr. Wallach and two co-defendants were convicted of receiving more than $1.5 million in illegal payments from the company.
title: Labor of Love

text: Mr. Wallach insisted that his only crime was ''being in the wrong place at the wrong time with the wrong people.'' He made it clear that by ''wrong people'' he did not mean Mr. Meese, who has not been charged in the case.
title: Labor of Love

text: I HAD just turned 22 that eventful summer of 1969. My husband, 20-month-old son and I were living with my parents in their summer home on Kauneonga Lake, in Bethel, N.Y.
title: Woodstock Came To Our Little Town

text: We had been following the saga of the Woodstock Music and Arts Festival's search for a home after the nearby town of Woodstock backed out, and were thrilled to learn that it would take place just two miles from us, up the hill on Max Yasgur's farm. That's where we got our milk.
title: Woodstock Came To Our Little Town

text: The advertising for the event was very heavy and there were many advance sales, but we planned to buy our tickets ''at the gate.''
title: Woodstock Came To Our Little Town

text: On Friday, Aug. 15, we packed our car - picnic basket, blanket and baby - and took off for the short ride to the festival. But the narrow country road was jammed, and we had to abandon our car about a mile from the site and join the masses hiking up the hill. As it turned out, there was no ''gate'' - no collection or selling of tickets. What a break for us! It had been declared a ''free concert.'' (Tickets were strewn everywhere; I still have a few.) We found a great spot in the middle of the crowd. It was amazing to see the transformation that Yasgur's farm had undergone. Instead of the horses and cows that usually grazed the meadow, there were thousands of people streaming in, filling every spot. The day was hazy and gray, but no matter. The concert began.
title: Woodstock Came To Our Little Town

text: Richie Havens opened, and you couldn't help but imagine what he might be feeling, all alone, with just an acoustic guitar, in front of all those people. He was electrifying. Ravi Shankar followed, but for us it was time to return home. We had to retrieve our car, get the baby fed and put to bed. That's when we realized the extent of what was to come. All roads were closed to general traffic. Only food, water and medical-supply vehicles were allowed access. Helicopters flew overhead carrying reporters and performers. There was a constant buzz everywhere. Our little town was on the map, and we weren't getting our milk delivered.
title: Woodstock Came To Our Little Town

text: Saturday morning we grabbed what we could spare from our pantry - cookies, crackers and snacks - and headed for the road. Our neighbors were also there handing out food and water to the exhausted travelers who had camped along the way and those who were still coming. Standing there, I felt detached and yet somehow a part of it.
title: Woodstock Came To Our Little Town

text: Later that day we hiked back up to the concert, blanket in hand, baby at home. It was dark when we reached the festival site, which had turned into a sea of mud. (About the rain: We'd had a lot of it that summer, 21 straight days, I believe. Some said an old Indian folk tale told that the rain was caused by disturbances on the moon. Man had landed on the moon just weeks before.) The smell of mud was overwhelming. The bucolic scene from the day before had dissolved into something Salvador Dali might have painted.
title: Woodstock Came To Our Little Town

text: We sat just to the right of the stage and saw not only Sly and the Family Stone on stage, but also the many dramas that were unfolding on all sides: the lines for the phones, overflooded portable toilets, the medical emergencies and the ''bad trips.'' But, there was also the sharing of food, marijuana and stories of rain-soaked days and nights.
title: Woodstock Came To Our Little Town

text: We left that night feeling a new sense of awareness. In the darkness, as we quietly made our way back to our house, the music followed us.
title: Woodstock Came To Our Little Town

text: By Sunday, the Sheriff of Sullivan County (who lived across the road) had deputized everyone - even my father was sporting a badge. The Sheriff's office needed people to help coordinate the traffic and handle other emergencies. For that short period, in that tiny town of Bethel, the ''hippies,'' the ''town folk'' and the ''pigs'' seemed to declare a silent cease-fire. The buzz from the meadow had drifted down and everyone was working together.We didn't return to the festival on Sunday. It was too wet, and many people had already abandoned the concert. But early that morning, in the blackness and silence that we usually experienced, I could very clearly hear the sounds of the Jefferson Airplane soaring over the hills.
title: Woodstock Came To Our Little Town

text: My parents still have their house there, and my father proudly displays his Woodstock Music and Arts Festival full-color program. We visit my parents every summer, and each time we make a pilgrimage to the site of the festival. Mr. Yasgur is gone, as is the farm. The meadow is green again, and very peaceful. Someone has built a small monument, replacing the plaque that had been placed there some years before. It sits on top of the hill, just off the road, commemorating the event, listing performers and dates.
title: Woodstock Came To Our Little Town

text: Last August, as my son, now 21, and I sat there in the dusk, another car joined ours - someone else, with his own memories. We smiled at each other in acknowledgment - kindred spirits.
title: Woodstock Came To Our Little Town

text: There are lots of us out there - aren't there?
title: Woodstock Came To Our Little Town

text: THE Bush Administration reacted with suspicion when Fidel Castro offered last month to join the United States in the fight against narcotics traffickers.
title: The U.S. and Cuba Do An Anti-Drug Tango

text: Little has come of the offer, and last week Mr. Castro declared in Havana that it apparently had been rejected.
title: The U.S. and Cuba Do An Anti-Drug Tango

text: As often happens with matters between the United States and Cuba, Washington had a different view. ''Heavens, no,'' a State Department official said. ''We haven't rejected anything. What is he talking about?''
title: The U.S. and Cuba Do An Anti-Drug Tango

text: In fact, Mr. Castro's offer has put Washington in a somewhat uncomfortable position. For years American officials have been accusing him of condoning or directing drug smugglers. They don't want to be seen as rejecting any offer to fight narcotics. But they are skeptical about Mr. Castro's intentions, and suspect he merely wants to turn the issue to his advantage in other ways. So American officials are saying there are ways Mr. Castro can help without a formal agreement, a position that rests on the assumption that Cuba is not crucial to winning the drug war.
title: The U.S. and Cuba Do An Anti-Drug Tango

text: Until now, Mr. Castro's reaction to the American accusations has been simply to accuse the United States of slandering him. Now, experts on Cuba say, he is trying to certify his anti-drug credentials. If his offer is accepted, he will make progress toward a far more basic goal: a less antagonistic United States that might end its trade embargo, which today denies him a bonanza in American business transactions and tourism that could help his stagnating economy.
title: The U.S. and Cuba Do An Anti-Drug Tango

text: But a warming of relations with Cuba is just what the Administration is not seeking. President Bush says he has no plans to ease political and economic pressure on Cuba until it stops trying to undermine United States interests in Central America and ends human rights abuses.
title: The U.S. and Cuba Do An Anti-Drug Tango

text: Mr. Castro's proposal was made after a spectacular show trial and executions of army officers in Havana last month on charges that they ran a cocaine and marijuana smuggling ring out of Cuba's secret police and intelligence organization. Bush Administration officials say they do not believe Mr. Castro's contention that the existence of a smuggling ring was a surprise to him. Some Western diplomats in Havana say they believe that an operation in Mr. Castro's security apparatus could have been conducted without his knowledge. There is little evidence, the Administration says, to support speculation that the trial was a response to a political threat.
title: The U.S. and Cuba Do An Anti-Drug Tango

text: Mr. Castro has not said how he is willing to help the United States stop drug trafficking. American officials say Cuba could help pursue smugglers who hide along its long coast and could also advise when drug planes head north across the island. But an American official said, ''Cuba is not absolutely critical to what we're trying to do.''
title: The U.S. and Cuba Do An Anti-Drug Tango

text: Although Cuba stretches across the most direct drug smuggling routes from South America to the Southeastern United States, United States officials operating in the Caribbean say other avenues are available, and most of the narcotics transfers from planes to speedboats take place off the Bahamas and other waters north of Cuba. Avenues of Communication
title: The U.S. and Cuba Do An Anti-Drug Tango

text: Melvyn Levitsky, the Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters, said, ''Ways of communicating drug-related information'' already exist. These channels have not worked in the past, he acknowledged. But he said all that is needed is for Cuba to begin responding when the United States provides information that, for example, a plane is dropping bags of cocaine at a certain spot along the coast.
title: The U.S. and Cuba Do An Anti-Drug Tango

text: The Cubans want to talk. Said Manuel Davis, the acting chief of the small Cuban diplomatic mission in Washington, ''We need to establish a real basis for cooperation to know what each party needs and what are the means for the cooperation.''
title: The U.S. and Cuba Do An Anti-Drug Tango

text: Instead of agreeing to formal discussions, which some United States officials believe might in themselves lend legitimacy to Mr. Castro, the Administration is demanding evidence that Cuba is serious. Washington has suggested that Mr. Castro hand over Adm. Aldo Santamaria, a Defense Ministry official, and Fernando Ravelo-Renedo, Cuba's Ambassador to Nicaragua. Both were indicted in Miami in 1982 on drug-smuggling charges when Admiral Santamaria was chief of the Cuban Navy and Mr. Ravelo-Renedo was Ambassador to Colombia.
title: The U.S. and Cuba Do An Anti-Drug Tango

text: ''Anyone who proposes this can't be serious about a drug agreement,'' said Jorge Dominguez, a political science professor at Harvard who specializes in Cuba.
title: The U.S. and Cuba Do An Anti-Drug Tango

text: The depth of Washington's distrust of Mr. Castro was illustrated in late July, during Congressional hearings on Cuba and narcotics. William von Raab, who was in his last days as Customs Commissioner, called Mr. Castro a ''piece of narco-trash.''
title: The U.S. and Cuba Do An Anti-Drug Tango

text: ''He has turned to the United States for a life preserver,'' Mr. von Raab told Congress. ''I feel we should throw him an anchor.''
title: The U.S. and Cuba Do An Anti-Drug Tango

text: AFTER eight years, millions of dollars and thousands of casualties, it has come to this: Nicaragua's contra rebels, the ''freedom fighters'' who have been an essential element of American policy toward the Sandinista Government throughout the 1980's, are to be forced to disband. In a ringing declaration of independence from the United States last week, the leaders of five Central American countries ignored Washington's objections and came up with a plan that promises to eliminate the rebels as a military force before the year is out.
title: Central America Goes Its Own Way

text: For the Bush Administration, the accord announced at Tela, Honduras, is only one of several recent reverses in the region that the President likes to call ''the front yard'' of the United States. In Panama, where American and
title: Central America Goes Its Own Way

text: Panamanian soldiers took turns arresting each other last week, Gen.
title: Central America Goes Its Own Way

text: Manuel Antonio Noriega remains in power in spite of American jawboning aimed at forcing him to step down. In El Salvador, a right-wing party with a dubious record on human rights and land reform won the presidential election this spring after a decade of American support for the centrist Christian Democrats.
title: Central America Goes Its Own Way

text: In the Caribbean, the promise of a military leader, Gen. Prosper Avril, that he will bring ''irreversible democracy'' to Haiti continues to be elusive. Colombia, Peru and Bolivia seem unable to gain ground against domestic cocaine and marijuana traffickers despite the high priority the Bush Administration says it is giving to the international war against drugs. And the weight of $400 billion in foreign debt continues to thwart the efforts of virtually every Latin American nation to put an end to a decadelong cycle of recession and inflation - even after American promises that help is on the way.
title: Central America Goes Its Own Way

text: But if the American colossus appears hamstrung in its dealings with the rest of the hemisphere, there is, strangely, less of a sense of threat than there might have been five years ago. Then such a combination of problems would have been a source of deep concern, if not panic, in Washington, which was portraying fighting in El Salvador and the Sandinista presence in Nicaragua as posing real threats of Soviet-supplied bases and insurrection spreading through the region.
title: Central America Goes Its Own Way

text: In fact, the frustrations for American policy today are occurring against a backdrop of at least temporary success in addressing these basic security concerns - at least in part because American rivals in the region are occupied with serious difficulties of their own.
title: Central America Goes Its Own Way

text: Fidel Castro, for instance, must now worry about a drop in the subsidies from the Soviet Union that keep the Cuban economy afloat, and is also confronting the biggest corruption and security scandal in his 30 years in power. In Nicaragua, economic problems are so severe that both the appeal and power of the Sandinistas are reduced even though they have managed to remain in power.
title: Central America Goes Its Own Way

text: For its part, the Soviet Union under Mikhail S. Gorbachev seems much less interested in confrontation, as evidenced by the fact that Bernard W. Aronson, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, flew to London last week to discuss events in Latin America with Soviet officials. ''Little by little, the element of East-West confrontation that had crept into the Central American question during the Reagan years is beginning to diminish,'' said a Latin American diplomat here.
title: Central America Goes Its Own Way

text: But at the same time, allies in Central America and former allies like General Noriega seem more determined than ever to go their own way. American efforts to persuade the Organization of American States to take a strong collective stand on the Panamanian question have largely stalled, to the despair of a political opposition that by now can only conclude that General Noriega has successfully stolen the May 7 presidential election. Changing Tactics
title: Central America Goes Its Own Way

text: General Noriega is so confident of his position that he has stepped up his tweaking of the United States, recently taking a stroll across an American military installation in the Panama Canal area with delighted followers in tow. But the United States has another decade to go before it must hand over the canal to Panama - time enough to weigh options as drastic as military intervention or even abrogating the canal treaties.
title: Central America Goes Its Own Way

text: Unlike the Central American guerrilla problem, challenges like General Noriega, drug production in the Andean countries and the foreign debt have little if anything to do with ideology. For that reason, they require a readjustment of American strategy and tactics, perhaps giving greater emphasis to stability in Mexico, the security of the Panama Canal and the economic well-being of the Latin countries. Mr. Bush appears to recognize the need for such a redefinition, but it is not likely to be achieved overnight.
title: Central America Goes Its Own Way

text: Mr. Bush has won some praise in the region by jettisoning Ronald Reagan's obsession with Nicaragua and increasing the attention the United States gives to large countries like Mexico, Brazil, Argentina and Venezuela, which together hold the bulk of Latin America's foreign debt.
title: Central America Goes Its Own Way

text: But the initial optimism generated by the announcement in March of the Brady Plan for debt relief has given way to skepticism as finance ministers and bankers study the fine print in the package offered Mexico last month. They have discovered that interest payments will be cut by no more than $2 billion a year.
title: Central America Goes Its Own Way

text: Visiting here last week, Secretary of the Treasury Nicholas F. Brady urged Argentina, Brazil and other debtors ''to do what Mexico did: bite the bullet, make the tough choices, put on economic programs that open up markets, reduce tariffs and barriers.'' But many doubt whether these sacrifices are worth the limited relief Washington has thus far offered.
title: Central America Goes Its Own Way

text: ''If this is the best deal that the prize pupil can get,'' a Latin American diplomat here said, ''then there is not an awful lot of hope for the rest of us.''
title: Central America Goes Its Own Way

text: Long reviled by American music critics, Soviet ideologists and parents everywhere, the thundering hordes of Western heavy-metal rock found respect today in Lenin Stadium - as ambassadors of peace and temperance.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: On a stage the size of the battleship Potemkin, flanked by batteries of speakers reminiscent of the Krasnoyarsk radar, under a sky that had undergone 75,000 rubles worth of cloud seeding, the rockers of Bon Jovi, Motley Crue, Ozzy Osbourne and other black-leather ensembles pumped earsplitting megawatts in the name of moderation.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: Genrikh A. Borovik, whose official Soviet Committee for the Defense of Peace promises to make charitable use of an expected million rubles in ticket profits, expanded the agenda in his introductory speech to include not only drug prevention but nuclear disarmament and the end of ''nationalism, racism and chauvinism.''
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: If the lure today was high-decibel rock, the logic was pure Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: Thanks to the world's fascination with the Soviet leader, Moscow, which has little else to sell, now markets itself as the world's hippest backdrop for Western causes, whether commercial, philanthropic, or - as in the case of the Moscow Music Peace Festival - a combination of the two. Red Carpet for Hard Rockers
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: ''I call Moscow the Klondike,'' said Doc McGhee, the mastermind of today's benefit and the manager of four of the performing bands.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: True enough. Last week alone, the publicity seekers prospecting in Moscow included, besides Mr. McGhee's clients, marathon runners (for hunger relief), disabled kayakers (for unity), two American Congressional delegations, the octogenarian industrialist Armand Hammer, the pop performers Leon Russell and La Toya Jackson, and the North American team of the World Arm Wrestling Federation.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: On Tuesday the American comedian Billy Crystal taped a show at the Pushkin Theater before a predominantly American audience. Judging by a show of hands, the Soviet citizens in the hall were outnumbered by the visiting Little League team from West Chester, Pa.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: But no matter. Mr. Crystal's real intended audience, American viewers of Home Box Office, will know the comic was in Moscow from the painted socialist-realist stage backdrop of tool-clenching workers, and from his shtick about food lines and Chernobyl.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: Few events demonstrate the strange alchemy of Mr. Gorbachev's political force field better than today's extravaganza on what the promoters described as ''the sacred soil of Lenin Stadium.''
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: Why would a concert organizer plan a show in a country where everything from the electricity to the drinking water - not to mention 25,000 pounds of prime beef, salmon, breast of duck and other catered victuals that made some of the Soviet hired help weep -must be delivered by the largest truck convoy since lend-lease? And where the tickets are sold for rubles that buy nothing much of value here and nothing at all abroad? Where in short, ''it's like doing a thing in Mongolia - it's just the desert,'' as Mr. McGhee put it? Head Bangers as Role Models
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: And why would Moscow give red carpet treatment to an entertainment genre that, while long beloved of the Soviet young, has been officially regarded as the vilest strain of Western heathenism - ''ideological AIDS,'' in the formulation of one critic? ''Impact,'' answered Mr. McGhee. ''In L.A. or New York, every weekend they have save the whales, stop the injustice, what have you,'' he said. ''Benefits are happening there every day. It just doesn't have the impact.''
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: Sebastian Bash, lead singer of the New Jersey-based band Skid Row, finally got a chance to screech into a microphone after several sedate days of being lionized as a role model for temptation-prone teen-agers. ''I think the whole point of this show today,'' he said, ''is for the East to meet the West,'' loudly.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: The financing of the show, as explained by the chief accountant, Bruce Kolbrenner, is a complex carom shot aimed at scattering millions of dollars and rubles into various charitable and commercial side pockets, while generating priceless good will for the Soviets and the musicians.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: The big money, an anticipated gross of $6 million to $10 million, was advanced by American companies, which will market a record album, an MTV documentary and pay-cable broadcasts in the West. Whatever is left after production costs - over $3 million and growing - is to go to the Make a Difference Foundation, started last year by Mr. McGhee's lawyer, Joseph B. Cheshire, to promote anti-drug messages. Image of 'Savages With Cash'
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: Mr. McGhee said his sponsorship of anti-drug concerts is a personal commitment and a condition of his 1987 probation for what his lawyer called ''a very peripheral role'' in a marijuana-importing scheme.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: ''Whether the recognition from doing something good means more people buy the groups' albums and go to their shows, we can't project that,'' Mr. Cheshire said of the concert's promotional value.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: Mr. McGhee said he hoped the event would help dispel the reputation of his clients as ''savages with cash.''
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: ''Tipper Gore and everybody else said Motley Crue and Ozzy Osbourne were these satanic cult bands,'' Mr. McGhee said. ''We want to show the world how concerned they are.'' Computers and Pinball Machines
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: Mrs. Gore is a prominent crusader against rock lyrics that she asserts are offensive. Mr. Osbourne, a 20-year veteran of heavy metal, is perhaps less remembered for his lyrics than for biting the head off a live bat during one of his concerts.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: On the Soviet side, the ruble profits from sales of tickets and T-shirts are to be turned over to the peace committee, which holds the state franchise for promotion of officially sanctioned good works. It promises to channel the money into temperance programs.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: Other beneficiaries include Soviet television, which gets free broadcast rights; the state recording monopoly, Melodiya, which plans to peddle a concert record here, and an array of middlemen.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: The American promoters insured a warm welcome by donating to Soviet authorities 20,000 desperately scarce disposable syringes, at least eight computers, and such road-crew flotsam as food freezers and pinball machines. Soviet Metal-Style Bands
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: Heavy metal is not new to the Soviet Union. Bon Jovi and Motley Crue have a large following from bootleg cassettes. Metal rock videos are sometimes featured on late-night television, and many Soviet bands imitate the genre. Three Soviet bands shared the bill today.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: But the Soviet authorities have never tolerated an invasion on the scale of this two-day event.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: Whisked through the airport V.I.P. entrance without customs inspection, the bands were dragged through several days of press conferences and given the kind of reverent press treatment they rarely get at home.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: The Soviet authorities may have had some second thoughts late Friday night, when 200 Moscow motorcyclists gathered in a parking lot near the stadium demanding a promised audience with Motley Crue. Heavily Policed Decorum
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: After the bikers had set two cars on fire, the band's drummer materialized and quelled the mini-rampage.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: But Lenin Stadium today was a display of heavily policed decorum. Clean-cut young people who looked like Communist Youth League members predominated in the crowd of 80,000, and except for the elite who bought pricier tickets to dance down on the soccer field, the fans never reached the frenzy of a comparable American concert. The show is to be repeated Sunday. Meanwhile, Mr. McGhee, trying to stay ahead of the impact curve, is already contemplating his next venue: Beijing in 1991.
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: ''We already know you can fit a million people in Tiananmen Square,'' he said. ''Probably more if you take the tanks out.''
title: Leather Rockers Take Moscow, A New Market for West's Fringes

text: Crack is rapidly accelerating the destruction of families in poor urban neighborhoods where mothers are becoming increasingly addicted and children are selling the drug in greater numbers than ever before.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Though drugs have always brought misery to families affected by their use, crack has greatly intensified that misery in recent months in inner cities throughout the nation. Isolation and a Sad Acceptance
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: But perhaps nowhere can this be seen more readily than in the doorways and abandoned buildings of New York City's poor neighborhoods. These are some of the elements of family breakdown that social scientists and others have observed:
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: * Children are taking over as heads of their families, largely because of their incomes from selling crack.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: * Young pregnant mothers are endangering their lives to get the drug, and in many cases, people describe mothers or brothers procuring sex for the young women in their families to raise money to buy it.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: * Teen-age girls are abandoning their families and forming what social scientists say are new and violent gangs to sell or buy crack.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: * And in some neighborhoods female users outnumber male users for the first time. For years, it had been the women, more often than not, who held poor families together. Yet almost worse than the breakdown of the family are the isolation and sad acceptance expressed by so many people in the affected communities - as if crack has become a final plague they cannot overcome.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: The overall picture of the unraveling family emerges in scores of conversations and interviews with members of families hit by crack and with treatment experts and social scientists studying the matter.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: What emerges as well is the perception that very little community structure is in place to cope with or to stop what is happening. For the most part, there are not enough treatment centers, social workers or law-enforcement officers to give the extensive help that is needed.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: On streets where drugs have long been sold, most sellers are much younger than their predecessors. ''The kids are taking over,'' said Dr. Ansley Hamid, an anthropologist at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan. Crack to Go - From Young Pushers
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: On a quiet summer day recently, a 12-year-old boy sat on an upturned milk crate at the corner of Regent Place and East 21st Street in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, selling crack. His mother stood beside him, drinking from a bottle of beer and patting his head.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Other boys waited for customers in nearby doorways. Outside, children as young as 7, 8 and 9 waited almost nonchalantly. They were the ''layaways,'' who were holding most of the drugs to be sold. They would help protect the sellers from being caught with drugs in their possession. A teen-age boy called the layaways ''dumb and young,'' and said they were paid only $25 to $50 a week. Still, he said, ''That's a lot of money for a kid.''
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: In West Harlem, at 132d Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard, a boy was on a public telephone with a customer. He signaled to two other youths who were double-parked nearby in a 1989 white Chrysler New Yorker. The boys in the car were to make the delivery. Crack to go.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: At 140th Street between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and Frederick Douglass Boulevards, the once-grand brownstones are crumbling backdrops for crack selling. But they are far from vacant. As night draws near, the ''vampires come out,'' as one resident puts it. In nearly every doorway, clusters of teen-age lookouts scrutinize customers. The lookouts - boys as young as 14 or 15 - are very polite as they keep the crowds moving to avoid attracting the police. ''Move on, please,'' one says as three people congregate. Mothers escaping their hot apartments watch from stoops nearby, holding babies sucking on pacifiers.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Inside virtually every building on the block are young guards with guns. Their age and their inexperience with the weapons are two reasons for the sharp increase in the shootings and in other violence in those neighborhoods, Larry Brown, a former addict now in a treatment program, said. Gold Teeth Set With Diamonds
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: A buyer passed the guards and slipped money through a slot in a door. A dealer waited on the other side. The crack, a smokable derivative of cocaine, was passed back through. Again, many dealers were teen-agers. ''This has not been true before,'' said Dr. Phillipe Bourgois, an anthropologist at San Francisco State University, who is doing research in East Harlem.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Some teen-agers who work these streets, some with grins that reveal gold teeth with diamonds set along the edges, said they could earn as much as several thousand dollars a week, depending on how high they climbed in the drug network. The most successful are careful not to become addicted themselves.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Dr. Hamid said the higher-level distributors like to employ adolescents because often they are more willing than adults to take risks and because their youthful sense of invulnerability makes them less wary of the violence that stalks a crack seller. The Parents Big Rewards For Blind Eyes The intensive crack activity of those young people - selling it or using it, or both - dominates what home life they have.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Michael H., a skinny 17-year-old who is now in a drug-treatment program, said he paid his mother for the use of her apartment to sell heroin, which is becoming popular among crack addicts because it brings them down from the high of crack. Heroin acts biochemically as a sedative; crack a stimulant.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: ''I gave her $200 a day,'' Michael said. ''I used to open at 7:30. Went to school at 8. I'd get the workers, get the lookout, and tell my sister to take care of the place until I got home from school.'' He said he earned $500 a day. ''By 10:30 at night, the shop was closed.''
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Parents of boys like Michael often turn a blind eye to drug dealing by their teen-agers because they want drug money for themselves. Balance of Power Shifts
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: ''The parents definitely know what's going on,'' Dr. Richard Curtis, an anthropologist at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, said. Dr. Terry Williams, an anthropologist at City University of New York who lives and works in East Harlem, agreed, adding: ''The kids start bringing in money, buying gifts for Mom and clothes for little brother. The child in essence becomes the parent. Then you can't tell them what to do. The balance of power has been shifted. Suddenly, as a parent, you turn the other way. You are reaping the benefits of the drug trade. This is altering the whole structure of the family.''
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Dr. Peter Pinto, a clinical psychologist who specializes in drug treatment at Samaritan Village in Queens, said even actions that a teen-ager might think are benign can leave psychological scars. When a boy like Michael supports his family throught drug selling, family members get ''very, very confused,'' Dr. Pinto said.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: ''Every boy wants to please his mother,'' he said. ''Every kid wants Mom's approval. The dad can never make that much money so in a sense it's emotional incest. The kid becomes the husband.'' Stealing From Mother
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: The damage becomes especially acute in relationships between mothers and pregnant daughters. Sonya H., lean, lanky and pregnant with her second child, showed up at the door of her mother's Flatbush apartment recently, her lips swollen and a front tooth knocked out. She said she had been beaten by a dealer who thought she had stolen some of his crack. Sonya, who is 22, admitted that she paid for the crack through prostitution and stealing and that she stole from her mother.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: At first glance the mother's apartment looked sparse. The living room had two battered sofas, a low scratched table and a television set, turned on. Sonya's 3-year-old daughter and her younger sister's 2-year-old son watched a game show.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: But the back bedroom, where Sonya's mother slept, was crammed with the family's belongings. Clothes, furniture, books and mementos were stacked halfway to the ceiling. On a table next to the bed was a Bible, and fronds collected on Palm Sunday hung on the wall. The mother said she locked everything of value in that back bedroom, to prevent Sonya or her associates from stealing it.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Sonya's mother and sister were afraid that Sonya would not live to 30. She has suffered seizures, the most recent on a subway. And if the crack does not kill her, there is another threat -the recurring beatings she suffers from men from whom she tries to steal. She has scars on her neck, which she says were gotten when a crazed dealer tried to cut off her head. Recurrent Nightmares
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Sonya has entered many treatment programs but usually leaves after a short time and returns to crack. Dr. Pinto said that among teen-agers who sought help at Samaritan Village, the drug-related experiences were so devastating that 44 percent suffered from post-traumatic stress syndrome similar to that of Vietnam veterans. He said 70 percent had recurrent nightmares.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: In any event, Sonya's mother felt powerless to control her. She has locked her daughter out of the apartment many times but always weakens and takes her back. So now instead of locking Sonya out, she locks herself in, behind her bedroom door.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Parents in similar situations give up any hope, and particularly in cases like that of Michael H., also give up dignity and authority. If the parents are using drugs themselves, a kind of child-as-parent syndrome develops. ''The child is taking on more of the role of an adult,'' Dr. Pinto said. ''On the surface, the child has an exhilarating feeling of power. But inside, the little adult is an angry deprived, lonely child who is hungry for parental nurturance.'' Prostituting Children
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Family members addicted to crack go to extremes to get it, in many reported cases prostituting their own children or siblings. Dr. Pinto said he counseled a 17-year-old girl from Jamaica, Queens, who said her two older brothers kept her a prisoner in a crack house and forced her to prostitute herself so they could get crack.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Sonya H. said she and a 17-year-old friend were out one night recently. The friend's mother had told her daughter that ''she better bring her back something,'' Sonya said. Later, the mother called down from her window for the girl to come up. She had a man lined up for her daughter. Sonya said her friend went upstairs and performed sex in exchange for crack for her mother.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Keith S., a tall shy, gentle-looking 17-year-old, said he and his mother used crack. Keith also sold the drug, as did most teen-agers he grew up with. He said his mother's increasingly severe addiction concerned him so much that he tried to cut off her supply. ''I had a couple of conferences with my friends, you know, and that's when I had a certain type of beef with them.''
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: But despite his pleas, the friends continued to sell to his mother. Still, Keith did not cut off his friends or their crack network. Bit by bit, his mother's apartment became a hangout, where crack was bought and sold and used. She lost the apartment, Keith S. said. He said that he did not know where she was living and that he drifted among the homes of friends and relatives. Trading Crack for Grades
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Family members may be alerted to a child's drug use when his schoolwork begins to suffer and his grades drop dramatically.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: But in one instance involving crack, a change in grade performance indicated yet another aspect of an adult-child relationship turned upside down. Jon W., who is undergoing treatment at Samaritan Village, said he raised his grades in one class at a Long Island high school by selling crack to his teacher. ''My parents kept wondering why I kept getting A's in this class,'' he said. ''They wanted to know because I was bringing home C's and D's in my other classes.''
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: ''Most of the adults,'' he said, sneering, ''they know you've got something they want, they'll do anything for you.'' The Women Their Strength Crumbles The loss of women to crack is clearly a powerful element in the breakup of poor families.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: And there are indications that in New York City and several other urban areas in the United States more women than men now use crack. The Justice Department reported recently, for example, that for the first time crack-related arrests of women were exceeding those of men in New York, Washington, Kansas City, Mo., and Portland, Ore.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Larry Brown, the former addict who lives in West Harlem, said he saw more women than men using crack in his neighborhood.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: A young woman sat on her bed in a small, unbearably hot city-owned apartment in Harlem watching television. She wore her hair in braids, like a child, though she was 22. She was pregnant for the third time. And she knew that the city would make her give up her baby at birth, because this baby, like the other two, was going to test positive for cocaine.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: But she was unwilling or unable to stop using crack.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Another young Harlem mother, of a 1-year-old girl, was flying high. She bounced as she talked nonstop on a sidewalk. Her eyes darted and she spoke in bursts. Presently, she grabbed the wrist of an old man on West 140th Street and led him off. Others who watched said he would give her more crack in return for sex. High Is Too Intense
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: One woman, a mother in her late 20's, strode nervously up and down another treeless street lined with abandoned buildings. She was leery of speaking to a reporter because she was selling crack.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Still, she could not resist stopping to bemoan the fact that crack was now being used by children as young as 9, who sprinkle it on marijuana cigarettes to dilute its high, which, she said, is too intense for their young brains.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: While she talked about the children, she ceased selling. And when two men and two women, in their 30's and 40's, approached to try to buy crack, she shooed them away.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: But before long she was back at it again.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Still another woman, now in a treatment program, told of how completely the crack habit had shattered her life and kept her from functioning at any level. Her head was shaved, and her once-beautiful face badly scarred. When she smoked crack she was beset with visions of insects crawling on her. She would tear at her face, trying to get rid of the bugs, and she shaved her head because of the illusion that she had lice. The Girls New Gangs Hit the Streets Although the sale of crack is still essentially controlled by men, some teen-age girls are forming gangs to sell it, or to buy it. ''This is a new phenomenon in American history,'' said Dr. William Kornblum, director of the Center for Social Research at the City University of New York Graduate School. Many more women and girls are selling drugs, and they are more organized, he said.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Dr. Bourgois, the San Francisco anthropologist who is doing research in East Harlem, says the new gangs, or posses as they call themselves, have come about as more girls move out of their homes and into the streets. Just as girls are hanging out on basketball courts, practicing their shots, so are they hanging out on the streets, selling drugs, Dr. Bourgois says. Girls ''used to not be allowed to participate in street culture,'' he explained. But now they say, ''I'm going to get mine.''
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Many girls leave home permanently and live on the streets or in crack houses. Some carry razor blades for protection. Less Likely to Be Searched
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Lyvia H., an innocent-looking 16-year-old from Jamaica, Queens, who is in a treatment program at Samaritan Village, said there were five girls in her posse. Aided by two lookouts and two helpers, she was the seller, dressed up ''in my church clothes'' so the police would not suspect her.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: A male dealer gave her $500 worth of crack at a time, which she said she could sell in a half-hour on a weekend night. She would work twice a week, for 12 hours at a stretch. For every $500 worth of crack she sold, she could keep $25, she said. Lyvia said she sold about $12,000 worth of crack each night, earning a weekly income of about $1,200, most of which she spent on drugs for herself.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Dr. Williams said higher-level drug dealers were willing to use girls as sellers because they were less likely than men to be searched by undercover police officers. Only policewomen search girls, and most undercover officers are men.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: In the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn recently, two teen-age girls were on a ''mission,'' as they called it, looking for money to buy crack. The terminology was from the popular television series ''Star Trek.'' The girls called crack ''Scotty,'' and getting high was ''beaming up.'' On the mission, the girls said, they would hunt for a wallet to steal or would have quick sex for as little as 50 cents. Searching for Family Ties
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: In his research on life in crack houses, Dr. Williams sees young girls, known on the street as ''TQ's'' for teen queens, who have run away from home and who stay in crack houses. The girls, about 14 or 15, ''are highly desirable to the older men,'' Dr. Williams said. ''They are fresh, new,'' he said. At the crack houses, which are usually decrepit rooms in abandoned buildings, they go on binges that typically last for two or three days, he said. The girls often perform oral sex in exchange for a smoke. Between binges they sleep in alleyways or abandoned buildings.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Adults at the crack houses become the only family the girls have. They often call the older women Ma and the older men Poppy.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Rays of hope do exist amid the suffering and misery. Some treatment centers have clearly helped addicts to survive.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: But Larry Brown said that the despair felt by Sonya H.'s mother and sister, for example, was evident throughout New York's poor neighborhoods, where after a few years most addicts are struck down by shooting or other violence, by the AIDS virus that spreads through crack houses, or by illnesses caused by malnutrition.
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: Mr. Brown told of a saying repeated often by residents of those neighborhoods: ''There are no old crackheads.''
title: On Streets Ruled By Crack, Families Die

text: George Gervin, the former scoring star of the Spurs who led the National Basketball Association in scoring four times, was arrested early yesterday in San Antonio on charges of driving while intoxicated and possession of marijuana. The five-time All-N.B.A. first team selection, who retired at the end of the 1985-86 season, was released on a personal recognizance bond. (AP)
title: Gervin Arrested

text: AN INVISIBLE SPECTATOR A Biography of Paul Bowles. By Christopher Sawyer-Laucanno. Illustrated. 501 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $24.95.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: Most Americans travel to find the things we have eliminated from our own culture: tradition, history, religion, picturesqueness, coziness, classicism and romanticism. Paul Bowles, for whom travel was like a neurosis, seemed to pursue none of these. As far as one can tell, he traveled simply to get away. Compared with writers like Lawrence Durrell, Norman Lewis, Robert Byron or Patrick Leigh Fermor, he is an incurious traveler. He loves awfulness, or offalness. One is never very far from the smell of excrement in his travel writing and his fiction.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: Some of us travel because we are bored, but Mr. Bowles and the characters in his fiction, who are mostly travelers too, set out toward boredom, as if boredom were the ultimate destination. The only reason one can imagine for going to some of the places they choose is that they need to know the worst. Travel becomes an infinite regression, an undoing of everything from toilet training to high culture. Sometimes the characters are killed by the impact of so much otherness, so that travel becomes an indirect form of suicide.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: Mr. Bowles, who is in his late 70's now, is a wonderful subject for a biography. He was the patron saint of the Beats, a writer who, like an American Beckett, discovered alienation for us. Years ago Franklin P. Adams said of Jack Kerouac that no one could describe a man eating a plate of beans better than he could. One might say of Paul Bowles that no one could describe better than he does the peculiar odor, mood or ambiguous menace of a North African town. While other writers have done a more convincing job of depicting Americans floundering in a foreign place, Mr. Bowles's people have an almost camp quality that moves us in a primitive or unreasonable way, as dreams do. Certainly he is the grand panjandrum of paranoid expatriation, an almost perfect example in his life and work of a familiar American syndrome. Also, he is something of a bore, which raises interesting questions about the relation between boredom and modern art.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: In ''An Invisible Spectator'' by Christopher Sawyer-Laucanno, Mr. Bowles may have got the biographer he deserves. The theme of alienation seems to attract the admiration of the earnest and the awkward. All we know of Mr. Sawyer-Laucanno is that he teaches in the foreign languages and literatures section at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, that he has done translations and has written books as a staff writer for Time-Life Books in Japan. It is at least partly true that the quality of a writer's biographer is, in some convoluted ironic sense, the sincerest criticism of him and his work. Still, though Mr. Sawyer-Laucanno can't write a decent colloquial sentence, he has done quite a decent job of presenting Mr. Bowles. A more sophisticated writer would not have had his patience and innocence, his willingness to abide with his subject.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: Paul Bowles was born in Queens in 1910, the son of a dentist. According to a family legend that Mr. Bowles says he believes, his father, who did not want a child, took him from his crib during a snowstorm, stripped him and put him on the sill of an open window. The young Paul was forbidden to play with other children, the perfect prescription for raising a modern writer. At the family table he was forced to Fletcherize his food, a contemporary health fad that required him to chew each mouthful at least 40 times before swallowing. It is not surprising that when he became a writer, Mr. Bowles was one of our first minimalists. At the age of 9 he wrote an ''opera'' about wife swapping, divorce, drugs, desertion, lawsuits and plague. For the next 10 years he appears to have been merely a pretentious, not very talented young man who ran away to Paris when he was 18, fully expecting, he said, never to see his parents again.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: Some of the material in ''An Invisible Spectator'' has been published before in Mr. Bowles's autobiography, ''Without Stopping,'' which came out in 1972. The book, however, was so noncommittal that William Burroughs, who knew Mr. Bowles, called it ''Without Telling.'' Virgil Thomson, another friend, said it read like a travelogue rather than a life. The book left almost everything about Mr. Bowles ambiguous. Though he was married, it was impossible to tell which sex, if any, he preferred. There was no hint of what sort of reasons he gave himself for his incessant travels. The reader could form no idea of his dimensions, either as a man or as an artist.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: It is impressive that Mr. Bowles managed to make so much out of what he has. With very little formal training, he became a highly regarded, if not profound, composer, and while only half-educated, he produced a first novel, called ''The Sheltering Sky,'' that was a literary best seller. His books have been praised at one time or another by almost everybody, and one is tempted to say he somehow usurped the roles of writer and composer. Though he was reported to be charming by people like Gertrude Stein, Tennessee Williams and Gore Vidal, only his intelligence comes across in print.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: In 1938 he married Jane Auer, who had previously said of him, ''He's my enemy,'' and was later to say, ''I had never met anyone so inimical to me.'' If there are marriages made in heaven, this one was apparently made in hell. She was entirely lesbian and he was, according to his friends, uninterested - or ''disinterested,'' as Mr. Sawyer-Laucanno would say - in sex. They may have married because they found the incongruity irresistible. Once they were husband and wife, Jane was promiscuous and Paul was abstemious. He admits to only two sexual consummations, both in Paris - one hetero- and one homosexual - and says he was disgusted by both. Most of his close friends were homosexual, but he appears to have been merely a nonparticipating fellow traveler. You might say that he traveled in everything. It is possible too that this lack of sexual definition undermined the characters in his books, that it deprived them of a certain kind of recognizability.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: Jane Bowles was in most accounts an interesting woman, but it is hard to tell whether she was genuinely talented or merely a faux naif, an idiot savant juggling the kind of word salads schizophrenics have an aptitude for. Her novel, ''Two Serious Ladies,'' which was published in 1943, and her play, ''In the Summer House,'' which was first performed in 1953, both have cult reputations. In relation to modern literature, they are like a mixed drink made up of everything in the liquor cabinet: a dash of Gertrude Stein, a jigger of surrealism (though she professed to hate it), a shot of absurdity, a drop of bitters and so on.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: Her life, according to Mr. Sawyer-Laucanno, consisted of one destructive infatuation after another. Besides drinking too much, she enslaved herself to a rapacious and illiterate North African woman who appropriated most of her property and some of her sanity. While all this was going on year after year, in one country after another, Mr. Bowles behaved with an inscrutable patience and forbearance. Their marriage was so open that it yawned. While Jane hoped to be ''a source of mild pleasure at meal times,'' Paul never said what he hoped to be for her. Sometimes with Jane and sometimes without her, he lived in a remote town in the Sahara, a tiny island off Ceylon, in Morocco and in Mexico. Much of their traveling was a voyage a trois, in which either he or Jane brought along a companion.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: In 1947 Partisan Review published what is perhaps Mr. Bowles's best short story, ''A Distant Episode.'' It is about a French professor of linguistics who goes to North Africa to study a particular dialect and is kidnapped by nomads who cut out his tongue, tie tin cans to him and turn him into a dancing clown. The story realized the worst fears of the contemporary imagination: to be disarticulated, to be an object of ridicule, to be used and to be homeless. In Mr. Sawyer-Laucanno's all-too-imitable summing up, ''A Distant Episode'' is ''as precise, cold, and delicate as cut crystal.''
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: Commenting on the violence and relentlessness of his fiction, Mr. Bowles said that ''it takes an exceedingly insensitive person today to be able to continue being an artist.'' ''Unhappiness,'' he said, ''should be studied very carefully; this is certainly no time for anyone to pretend to be happy.'' Yet in ''An Invisible Spectator'' he does not come across as particularly unhappy. Rather, he seems impervious to circumstance, like some new human model or mutant for whom happiness and unhappiness are irrelevant. As far as one can see, he lives in what might be described as a squalor of equability.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: In 1949, after being rejected by several American publishers and taken up by an English house, ''The Sheltering Sky'' became a talked-about book in both countries. Described by Mr. Bowles as ''a triangle laid in the Sahara,'' the novel is the story of an American couple who go there with a male friend. The couple are at an impasse in their sexual relations, and she sleeps with the friend while the husband chooses an Arab prostitute. The friend leaves, the husband dies of syphilis and the wife is enslaved in a harem, where she goes mad. The satisfaction afforded to the American public by such a plot is one of the luxuries of life in a democratic country.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: His second novel and his collections of short stories are more or less the same sort of thing: Americans coming to grief in strange places where they appear to have an appointment with disaster. Mr. Sawyer-Laucanno rather scants ''Their Heads Are Green and Their Hands Are Blue,'' a very good travel book about North Africa that was published in 1963. ''Up Above the World,'' a novel set in Latin America, came out to mixed reviews in 1966. It was described in The New Yorker as ''a dull story . . . about an unamiable couple who are incessant nap-takers.'' His next novel, ''The Time of Friendship'' in 1967, was widely praised but did not sell well. Once again the public was ahead of the reviewers in seeing through a book.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: As an English critic put it, Mr. Bowles seemed ''old-fashioned.'' While no one was more fashionably affectless than he was, the taste in affectlessness was changing and his books were perhaps too exotic and too demonstrative in their bleakness. Yesterday's desperations are today's sentimentalities. Even boredom and displacement are exhaustible subjects. In the ultimate disparagement, Mr. Bowles began to be regarded, as Mr. Sawyer-Laucanno says, as a ''foreign'' writer.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: In 1973, after a long and varied series of illnesses, Jane Bowles died. By now Mr. Bowles was doing mostly translations of North African novels and cutting back on his intake of kif, a form of cannabis that he had claimed as a source of inspiration. In a photograph in ''An Invisible Spectator'' we see the modern apartment house in Tangier where he still lives: it looks like a corner in Queens.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: For all his sturdy thoroughness, Mr. Sawyer-Laucanno has much to answer for as a writer. In his pages all actions are performed quickly, quietly, readily, immediately or in short order. More than once he writes ''convinced'' for ''persuaded,'' and he seems to have no sense whatever of vernacular language. In a jargon entirely of his own devising, he says that Jane and Paul felt a ''vast uncertainty as to their actual mutuality.'' Paul is ''delighted'' to have his mother ''once again in his proximity.''
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: Yet ''An Invisible Spectator'' is fascinating, even important reading. In an age of improbabilities, Jane and Paul Bowles's marriage was one of the imaginative prodigies of that institution, a tragedy so perfectly of its time that it achieves an almost classical status. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald are nothing next to them. Paul Bowles himself so exquisitely anticipated our time that we now find him dated. In his impenetrable way, he is probably a hero or saint of some peculiarly modern kind. Against all odds he wrote some good books, and against much greater odds Mr. Sawyer-Laucanno has written a good one about him.
title: THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED ALIENATION

text: WILLIAM HOPKINS has been fighting drugs for more than 40 years, first as a Bronx narcotics officer and for the past 11 years as the supervisor of the street studies unit of the New York State Division of Substance Abuse Services. He is retiring this year, as soon as a replacement can be named and trained.
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: Based in a state office building on West 125th Street in Harlem, Mr. Hopkins employs a 16-member staff to comb the streets to learn of the latest trends in the distribution, marketing and use of illicit drugs. He and his staff members - many of them former drug addicts - were instrumental in the discovery of crack, a highly addictive form of cocaine, in New York City.
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: In a recent interview with Michel Marriott, a reporter for The New York Times, Mr. Hopkins discussed the city's drug scene. Here are excerpts from the interview.
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: Question. Over the years we've seen marijuana, heroin and cocaine go in and out of fashion. Now there's crack and evidence that heroin is making a comeback by being smoked with crack. What are the dynamics of creating a drug of choice?
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: Answer. We find that the people on the streets are constantly, but constantly, mixing substances together to try to get a better high. They are experimenting with everything. They put together unbelievable things, such as two things that will kill you; one is battery acid and the other is Ajax. We see them drinking bleach. We see them mixing developing fluid, at least 20 or so substances I know of. Plus all kinds of pills.
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: What happens is that in the morning you will find street addicts comparing notes with each other: ''What did you use last night?'' ''I used Sudden Impact.'' ''I used Mr. T.'' What they are doing is comparing brands of the drug.
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: Q. Don't they realize that they are experimenting with their lives?
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: A. If people die from something, overdose from it, automatically others run out and try to get that drug because that, they think, must be some good stuff. But they think they will be a little more careful. They think, ''I'm not going to die.''
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: Right now the craving on the street for heroin is China White; that's a street brand name and the impression is that it is the best heroin out there. The Discovery of Crack
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: A. When crack started getting out there, everybody was talking about how great a high you get. When we first found it, I didn't break the story to the media right away because mainly I thought the media would cause a problem by spreading the word.
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: The first time we heard the word crack was in December 1983. It happened at one of our meetings. When one of my staff mentioned crack I didn't know what the hell it was. A few months later one of my staff said they saw up in the Bronx on Tremont Avenue some guys smoking something called crack. I said no big deal, it's freebase. ''No,'' he said, ''it's not freebase; this is in a ball.''
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: Q. Since then, has there been anything new in the processing of crack?
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: A. It's being made in microwave ovens. They can make it in 10 seconds. They call it Instant Gratification.
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: Q. Is there anything new about the use of crack itself?
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: A. I know that it is smoked in regular cigarettes, and many people don't know that. Remember that cocaine is also a sexual stimulant. And there are guys who would give a gal a cigarette to turn her on and she would not know she is smoking crack.
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: Q. So where is New York City's drug market heading?
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: A. What crack did that no other substance did, what heroin didn't do, was to create a lot of individual entrepreneurs. Everybody and their brother got into the crack-making and selling business because it was a quick, instant buck. It was a considerable time before that market was controlled. That is beginning to happen today. Organized groups are trying to control the streets and they are doing it.
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: One of the problems crack sellers had was that, for example, if I was going to give you crack to sell you are going to steal from me. If I give you 100 vials of crack, what you are going to do is to take a few rocks out of each one and create a couple of extra vials for yourself and make money.
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: The sellers are now heat-sealing the crack into packages, making it harder for people to tamper with it. They call this a gun clip. They are making it in huge pancake forms or bricks and selling it that way.
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: Q. What has crack done to the consumption of other drugs, such as marijuana?
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: A. We hear very little about marijuana. It's still plentiful; it's still available. It is still the drug of choice second only to alcohol. But what we found is that in many cases you can go out on the street and buy crack. You have to look sometimes for the person who is selling the pot.
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: Q. How do dealers of other street drugs view the crack dealer and user?
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: A. The dealers of other drugs take an attitude toward the crack dealer that is, ''Hey, I've been running numbers, I've been running con games, three-card monte and the rest, and I've been selling heroin here for years; I've haven't had no static. You, the crack user, are responsible for all the cops coming in this area. So get the hell out of our area.''
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: That is one of the groups that is chasing them. Other groups chasing the crack dealers are religious groups, regular people.
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: Q. Are we seeing this more and more, citizen groups reclaiming their neighborhoods from drugs?
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: A. Citizens groups mostly are laughed at. It depends on who they are and how they are doing it. Some of them are doing damn good jobs. Some of them are having a one-day march through the street led by some politician who never shows up again. And the addicts' attitude is that this will be over in two hours. ''We'll be right back.''
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: Now when the Tactical Nacotics Teams come in, the attitude is going to be that the pressure will be there for a while. But what they do is send steerers into the area to let the customers who come into the block know that they are not dealing here anymore.
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: Q. After 40 years of combating street drugs, are you discouraged by what you see?
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: A. I'm a believer. I honestly believe that someday things are going to turn around. It is not going to happen overnight. But I honestly believe it is going to change.
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: Q. Is it getting better or worse?
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: A. It is getting much worse. But the pendulum has to swing back sooner or later.
title: Intelligence-Gathering Among the Addicts Of New York City

text: NEVER will I forget the pathetic sight of a tiny, stiff-legged cocaine-addicted baby, trembling nervously and crying for help.
title: From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help

text: Just how many American infants are being exposed to cocaine, marijuana, heroin, methadone and other illegal drugs in the womb, no one knows for sure. What we do know, however, is that drug abuse in women of childbearing age is commonplace. A nationwide study showed that about 11 percent of pregnant women were taking illegal drugs.
title: From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help

text: This survey by the National Association for Perinatal Addiction Research and Education estimated that as many as 375,000 infants may be exposed to illicit drugs each year. That means that more than 1,000 babies born a day are affected by their mothers' substance abuse in pregnancy. Since most physicians never question their patients about substance abuse, the number of infants born to drug-abusing mothers is grossly underestimated. Many infants born to these women are born prematurely with very low birthweight and are addicted, often with physical and neurological problems.
title: From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help

text: The high rate of drug abuse in pregnancy is not just an inner-city problem; it afflicts all socioeconomic and racial groups, especially since cocaine-crack usage has become so popular.
title: From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help

text: One pregnant woman who admitted smoking crack 10 times a day said, ''I know my baby might be born with birth defects, but I'm not going to stop.'' What does this do to the unborn child? We know that crack constricts the mother's blood vessels, which deprives the fetus of oxygen and can damage the infant's nervous system. Moreover, when a pregnant woman takes a drug and gets a rush, the fetus gets the drug through the placenta. Because he cannot recirculate the drug back to the mother, it gets caught in his system and he may get 10 or more rushes each time.
