The drug is carried in the blood, raising the blood pressure and cutting down the circulation to the brain and other areas, thus increasing the possibility of birth abnormalities.
title: From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help

text: One wonders how a mother can be so cruel and uncaring toward her innocent child. As an addict, she does not care what happens to her or to her child. Her main concern is how to get the next rush. What is the outlook for such a baby's developing normally? Extremely slim.
title: From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help

text: Consequences of prenatal exposure to cocaine include strokes before birth, retarded fetal growth, breathing problems, malformed kidneys and abnormalities in genital and urinary organs, brain abnormalities, heart attack, behavioral problems and a high risk of early death.
title: From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help

text: Women who smoke marijuana during pregnancy have smaller babies than nonsmokers, and their babies are at greater risk of having neurological difficulties like abnormal startle reflexes, tremors and behavioral problems. Abuse of heroin and methadone during pregnancy can cause low birthweight, withdrawal sickness, convulsions and other problems in the newborn.
title: From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help

text: The grim reality is that untold numbers of infants are born to women who cannot or will not give up drugs, and their babies are born addicted, with physical and mental handicaps. How can we prevent and reduce the suffering of innocent children? Women should be informed that even occasional use of drugs in pregnancy can cause lasting damage for the unborn child. Health-care professionals should question pregnant patients in order to recognize substance-abusing women and to identify early infants at high risk.
title: From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help

text: In addition, we must provide access to prenatal care for every pregnant woman. It has been reported that prenatal care that can prevent a baby's being born too small can cost as little as $400, but that the lifetime medical costs often associated with low birthweight can run as high as $400,000. In light of the fact that most drug babies have additional problems, the lifetime medical costs will be even greater.
title: From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help

text: Since most drug-abusing mothers are unable or unlikely to provide a healthy environment for their infants, we should seriously consider placing children of addicted mothers temporarily or perhaps permanently into the care of social agencies and discharging them not to their parents, but to a foster home to prevent further suffering and abuse.
title: From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help

text: We must help these innocent drug babies who are born to substance- abusing mothers. If we do not take care of them now, the social, economic and human costs to our nation will be staggering.
title: From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help

text: Sadly, funds available for poor children have declined drastically in the last decade. Despite our resources and medical technology, the infant mortality rate in the United States has gone up. We rank last among the 19 industrialized nations in infant mortality. This rise in the mortality rate seems to coincide with the widespread abuse of drugs among women of childbearing age and with less financing available to needy families.
title: From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help

text: Every year we spend billions of tax dollars to save ailing corporate giants like Chrysler, Lockheed and savings and loan institutions. Saving the lives of children should be first among our priorities. President Bush has a chance to keep his promise to help needy children and families.
title: From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help

text: Yes, this project will be expensive. The Federal Government, state and local authorities must insure that enough funds are available for Medicaid insurance and other coverage for needy children and their families, so that every American child has a fair chance to grow up healthy and to become a productive and self-sufficient member of society.
title: From Drug Babies, a Cry for Help

text: MONKEY BAY By Elaine Ford. 244 pp. New York: Viking.
title: FAR FROM KENNEBUNKPORT

text: Monkey Bay, the remote Down East setting of Elaine Ford's fine new novel, is about as bleak a hamlet as can be imagined. Far up the Maine coast from the fabled seaside resorts of Kennebunkport and Bar Harbor, it's a place where most folks just barely scrape by on seasonal work. Even their kitchen gardens are unyielding, full of stones ''as though something is sending them up from deep inside the earth, or that they have to come to the surface to breathe, like seals or cormorants.'' Named for a fisherman and smuggler called Monkey, who was murdered at a nearby bay, the town is an isolated backwater of rusting house trailers, boarded-up bait shops and rundown laundromats, not to mention the dreary bottle-redemption and video-rental center where tall, once pretty Marilla Pratt is employed.
title: FAR FROM KENNEBUNKPORT

text: Ten years ago, Marilla walked out on her whiny husband, Lyle, and their 12-year-old daughter, Hannah, to take up with an old flame from her teens, footloose Tucker Burchard. It's a decision she's beginning to regret. About all that can be said for Tucker, who spends most of his time holed up in the cellar germinating marijuana seeds and contemplating the end of the world, is that he has a quirky, feline independence. Marilla can be terrifically stubborn in her own way - she more than half suspects she married Lyle mainly to disprove her mother's prediction that she'd never land a husband - and she doesn't waste much time repining over her circumstances. But when her ''set-adrift daughter'' returns home after a three-year sojourn out West, confused and full of resentment for both her parents, all hell threatens to break loose.
title: FAR FROM KENNEBUNKPORT

text: For Hannah, however, like the residents of Monkey Bay, nothing ever seems to turn out right, even the impulse toward revenge. She manages to seduce Tucker, presumably to avenge herself on Marilla for abandoning her, but just as they make a halfhearted attempt to run off together, Hannah totals her car, smashing into a tree within sight of Tucker and Marilla's house.
title: FAR FROM KENNEBUNKPORT

text: In a brief introductory note to ''Monkey Bay,'' Elaine Ford writes that the novel ''is about the experience of living, rather than the experience of living in Maine.'' It's a point that's well taken. For while Ms. Ford's fourth novel is accurate about a thousand details of life on the northern coast of New England, there's absolutely nothing regional, in a limiting sense, about her story.
title: FAR FROM KENNEBUNKPORT

text: ''My mother used to say, what's done is done,'' Marilla tells a friend in a poignant and revealing conversation that happens to take place in a kitchen in Maine, but could easily take place in almost any kitchen in America. ''She said that the day I married Lyle. But it isn't true, really. I feel like I'm still marrying Lyle, still leaving Lyle, still longing for Tucker, still. . . . Nothing's ever done.''
title: FAR FROM KENNEBUNKPORT

text: The first few chapters of ''Monkey Bay'' are a bit choppy, relying on abrupt and frequent flashbacks that might have been more effectively linked in two or three sustained sections of narrative. But this is a minor drawback in a realistic, often unexpectedly funny and invariably well-written novel. In its unsparing but sympathetic treatment of its characters and locale, Elaine Ford's book reminds me of Andrew Wyeth's stark paintings, which use the terrain of northern New England to explore a much larger emotional landscape.
title: FAR FROM KENNEBUNKPORT

text: WILLIAM J. BENNETT never professed any vast knowledge about illegal drugs before President Bush named him the nation's first director of narcotics policy. But last week, after nearly six months of reading books and summoning hundreds of experts to ruminate on the subject, the former Education Secretary came forward with his first assignment: a strategy to halve in a decade the number of Americans who use drugs.
title: After Studying for War on Drugs, Bennett Wants More Troops

text: While the document calls for more funds for treatment, the emphasis is squarely on law enforcement and criminal justice. The plan does not pour greater resources into the pursuit of drug kingpins, but would increase the number of Federal prison cells by as much as 85 percent and would double grants to cities and states for police officers and prosecutors, even while using Federal funds as a lever to force the local authorities to commit more money to enforcement.
title: After Studying for War on Drugs, Bennett Wants More Troops

text: Mr. Bennett's basic philosophy is that treatment and prevention are most effective when coupled with the deterrent of highly visible police work. ''Success comes from focused and sustained campaigns waged at particular neighborhoods or streets, certain drugs or clearly identified gangs,'' the report asserted. 'Heresy for a Cop'
title: After Studying for War on Drugs, Bennett Wants More Troops

text: Yet some law-enforcement professionals grouse that Mr. Bennett is too reliant on law-and-order prescriptions for a problem with deep social and economic roots.
title: After Studying for War on Drugs, Bennett Wants More Troops

text: ''I know it would be heresy for a cop to say this, but we need to quadruple our effort on the demand side,'' said Sheriff Clarence W. Dupnik of Pima County, Ariz., which is seeing a proliferation of illegal drugs from Mexico. But such programs will get short shrift, he added, because ''people are in a 'lock 'em up and throw the key away' mood, and it is that emotion that is fueling our national policy.''
title: After Studying for War on Drugs, Bennett Wants More Troops

text: Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York and chairman of the Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, said: ''Not even a conservative like Bennett can possibly say that law enforcement is a solution to the problem. This talking about police and jails, we don't need it. J. Edgar Hoover can do that.'' Mr. Rangel said he favored ''a dramatic program'' of rehabilitation and literacy and job training. Others were cautiously optimistic about the Bennett approach. Mark A. R. Kleiman, a lecturer in public policy at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government, said that while he was ''quite nervous'' about how details of the plan would be carried out, he shared Mr. Bennett's reasoning about tougher law enforcement.
title: After Studying for War on Drugs, Bennett Wants More Troops

text: ''To say you're concentrating on prevention when the number of neighborhoods where you can sell crack openly on the street continues to grow,'' he said, ''seems to me to misunderstand what prevention is about. Prevention can't mean only persuasion.'' Beyond the debate about priorities are two more practical questions. Will President Bush support Mr. Bennett's pronouncements? More important, will he press for the money to back up the plan?
title: After Studying for War on Drugs, Bennett Wants More Troops

text: The proposal, which by law must be delivered to Congress by Sept. 5, calls for spending as much as $1 billion more than the $5.96 billion that Mr. Bush initially recommended for anti-drug efforts in his fiscal 1990 budget.
title: After Studying for War on Drugs, Bennett Wants More Troops

text: The President has met regularly with Mr. Bennett, so details of the strategy should come as no surprise. But the plan marks a departure from some of Mr. Bush's past comments. In January, the President said in an interview that his campaign to fight drugs would stress education over law enforcement because of the ''overriding problem of the deficit.'' And Mr. Bennett's threat to cut off Federal money to state and local governments that do not cooperate seems out of character for a Republican administration.
title: After Studying for War on Drugs, Bennett Wants More Troops

text: In the meantime, the same governments have weathered Federal cutbacks. ''It's ironic for them to call for additional state and local programs,'' Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, said of Mr. Bennett and his advisers. ''For eight years, they decimated those programs while in the Reagan Administration.''
title: After Studying for War on Drugs, Bennett Wants More Troops

text: The unpredictable nature of the narcotics problem has also complicated Mr. Bennett's efforts.
title: After Studying for War on Drugs, Bennett Wants More Troops

text: On the eve of its distribution to Cabinet members last week, Mr. Bennett had to revise the preamble of his strategy because a Federal report had concluded that the drug problem among casual users was not as severe as he had thought, despite a rise in those heavily addicted to cocaine, especially crack. The National Institute on Drug Abuse reported that its survey found a 37 percent decrease from 1985 to 1988 in the number of people who said they had used cocaine, marijuana or other illicit drugs in the previous month; the number who said they had used an illegal drug in the previous year fell 25 percent. Trying Everything
title: After Studying for War on Drugs, Bennett Wants More Troops

text: Mr. Bennett's dozens of recommendations, some timeworn, some innovative, include using courts to force more drug addicts to get treatment; increasing economic and military aid to cocaine-producing and transit countries to help them disrupt drug trafficking; providing grants for alternative schools for youths with drug problems, and consolidating the Federal bureaucracy so, for example, a single office would be responsible for gathering intelligence on drug cartels.
title: After Studying for War on Drugs, Bennett Wants More Troops

text: Several days before he finished the report, Mr. Bennett said in an interview that he hoped that ''when history is written, it will become a watershed'' in fighting drugs. But then he quickly sought to dampen expectations.
title: After Studying for War on Drugs, Bennett Wants More Troops

text: ''Even a first-rate Government report is still a Government report,'' Mr. Bennett said. ''We should not go revering or idolizing a Government report. The best thing you could say is it makes sense, looks good.''
title: After Studying for War on Drugs, Bennett Wants More Troops

text: By Esther B. Fein, Special To the New York Times
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: Word had reached the special anti-drug force here in the capital of Soviet Turkmenia that poppy was being grown and harvested for opium on the Kalinin collective farm.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: So early one recent morning, before the sun rose high and hot over this arid republic bordering Iran, a helicopter from the Turkmen Interior Ministry hovered over the farm until the agents inside spotted a patch of blossoming red poppies.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: When the craft landed, the agents found nearly 3,000 poppy plants on the personal plot of Ana Khodzhamamedov, an 80-year-old retired farmer. By afternoon, his flowers had been cut, doused in gasoline and set afire.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: More than 270,000 poppy and hemp plants have been destroyed this year in Turkmenia, the Central Asian republic with the highest rates of drug addiction and production in the Soviet Union. The number of plants wiped out is probably just a fraction of all that is grown here. 'Very Dangerous Evil'
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: The crackdown in Turkmenia began in 1986, when the local Interior Ministry discovered that the number of fields in the republic where drugs were growing had jumped dramatically, as had drug-related crimes and the number of known addicts.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: That fall and winter, agents of the ministry organized Operation Poppy, the country's most intense and widespread anti-narcotics effort.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: ''This is a very dangerous evil and one that remained behind closed doors for too long because of our pride,'''' said Kiyas Tashmamedov, the earnest First Deputy of Turkmenia's Interior Ministry and chief coordinator of its anti-drug campaign.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: It has been about five years since the Soviet Union began a more realistic appraisal of its own life and history, encouraged by the leadership of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. But it took several years before the press's new focus on such long-denied problems as drug abuse translated into new programs, and only now are undertakings like Operation Poppy beginning to show significant results, officials say.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: ''A serious fight against narcotics simply didn't exist before,'' said Ansar Tebuyev, the deputy head of the Turkmen Interior Ministry's criminal investigations department. ''Before we had an ideological problem. Now we have a drug problem.'' 'Worst of the Lot'
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: A Soviet Interior Ministry spokesman, Aleksandr V. Timokhin, said the Soviet drug problem is most acute in Central Asia, and Turkmenia ''is without a doubt the worst of the lot.''
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: Most of the locally grown poppy and hemp (hemp is used to make marijuana and hashish as well as rope) is used in the republic itself, or sold in other Soviet cities; officials said there is virtually little export of the drugs.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: Mr. Tashmamedov's office in this dusty city is the base for the anti-drug operation, which runs its seek-and-destroy missions primarily in the spring and summer. He said he has a permanent staff of about 1,500, with part-time help and volunteers swelling the force to over 40,000 around harvest time.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: His walls are covered with maps tracking drug farms throughout the republic's 188,417 square miles: red flags for poppy plantations and green for hemp growers.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: ''This stuff is dearer than gold and more dangerous than guns,'' said Mr. Tashmamedov, holding up a packet with a few ounces of processed opium, which he said fetches about 1,500 to 2,000 rubles an ounce, $2,400 to $3,200 at the official exchange rate.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: Local officials said a monetary estimate would be difficult, but that the lucrative, illegal business was ''obviously a major portion of the local economy,'' as one put it.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: Finding out about growers and dealers is a ''very primitive business'' in Turkmenia, Mr. Tashmamedov said.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: ''This is not done out in the open,'' he said. ''We don't have the problem of street sales like you do in America. We also don't have any sophisticated equipment to detect drugs, and the law doesn't allow us to raid homes, even if we know they are dealing with drugs, unless we have the approval of a procurator. It's a lot of legwork, real legwork.'' Number of Addicts Said to Drop
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: The anti-drug team gets most of its leads and information by going door-to-door in the republic of about 3.5 million people. Local officials lend them cars and personnel to comb the nearly 700-mile stretch along the Karakum Canal, which meanders across nearly the entire republic and where most of the republic's population lives, and to search areas on the borders with the republics of Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: There have been some successes, the authorities say. They said that in the early 1980's, agents knew of 30 to 40 drug-growing fields; in 1986, before they began their campaign, they knew of about 100. In the first year of Operation Poppy, they hit a peak of 207 fields, and since have declined to 182 last year and 111 so far this year.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: The Turkmen Interior Ministry says that the number of registered addicts has dropped to 5,124 from 6,583 three years ago, although the republic still has the highest number per capita among the Soviet republics. Drug-related crimes - including possession, theft and murder and other crimes but not growing and selling - numbered 1,282 in 1986 but fell to 357 last year.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: To encourage addicts to seek treatment, Mr. Tashmamedov said, the republic in 1987 decriminalized possession of small amounts of drugs for first-time offenders. Drugs in Prison
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: One of the people caught in the web of the ministry's new anti-drug network is Ata Atayev, who prison officials presented for an interview at the Interior Ministry here. In July 1987 he was 23 years old, home from the army and unemployed, supporting a 50-ruble-a-day opium habit by breaking into apartments here. He was arrested and sentenced to seven years in prison.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: ''I first began smoking opium when I was in the 10th grade,'' said Mr. Atayev. ''I stopped for about four years, but then I started shooting up and I fell pretty low. You used to be able to get away with that here.''
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: Agamurad Muradov said that when he was convicted for possession and assault in 1984, he kept up his habit in prison by buying and stealing drugs from the infirmary. In the days of Operation Poppy, he said, finding such contraband in prison has become nearly impossible. ''Sources are drying up in general,'' he said.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: Since the special unit began its annual sweeps, the poppy growers have become more resourceful. Some have moved their fields away from population centers and into the heart of the vast Karakum Desert that covers most of the republic, laying miles of irrigation pipe to coax their lucrative crops out of the parched land.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: ''These crops don't just happen to pop up somewhere on their own, even when the soil is rich,'' said Mr. Tashmamedov. Many Pensioners Are Growers
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: Nearly all the poppy fields in Turkmenia belong to pensioners like Mr. Khodzhamamedov on the Kalinin farm. For centuries, opium has been consumed in Central Asia for medicinal purposes; many of the republic's elders have taken small daily doses since childhood and are addicted.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: Others are unwitting frontmen for greedy relatives, who are almost never sentenced to jail terms. Mr. Khodzhamamedov, as is typical, was fined and lost his plot.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: And some are themselves criminal distributors of opium, who realize that jail is an unlikely risk for the handsome payoff. Interior Ministry officials cite evidence that organized crime networks are trying to make inroads into the local drug trade, increasing the incentive of the operation's work.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: The officials said there was a range of penalties for offenders, depending on their age, the amount confiscated and previous criminal records.
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: ''With the elderly, it's not worthwhile to put them in prison,'' Mr. Tashmamedov said, adding, ''So we fine them, we transfer the land back to the state, and we try to determine further connections. Most important, though, we shut down an active source of opium.''
title: Soviets Confront Drug Growers in the Central Asian Heartland

text: By Julie Johnson, Special To the New York Times
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: Enticed by the huge profits reaped by selling cocaine and crack, drug trafficking organizations have expanded beyond the nation's cities into rural states like Iowa and Wyoming, the Justice Department reported today.
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: In the first major analysis of the business aspects of illicit drug use, the department drew a new portrait of organized crime in which California-based gangs, Colombian ''cartels,'' Asian ''triads and tongs'' and Jamaican ''posses'' are spreading drugs and violence across the country. An 'Impressive Document'
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said at a news conference: ''These crime conglomerates operate with various degrees of structure and sophistication. They include highly publicized international operations such as the Colombian cartel, as well as other groups operating on a regional basis, such as the Dixie mafia based in Georgia and the Miami Boys gang in Florida.''
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: William J. Bennett, the director of national drug control policy, who was with Mr. Thornburgh, called the report an ''impressive document'' but did not comment directly on how he intended to use the findings or how it would change Federal anti-drug efforts.
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: Mr. Thornburgh acknowledged that the report's findings underscored information that was suspected or had been exchanged anecdotally among law-enforcement officials. For more than a year, urban-based groups have been establishing distribution networks in the Midwest and rural South to sell not only cocaine but heroin, marijuana and synthetic drugs like LSD and methamphetamines, law-enforcement officials have said.
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: ''We knew that the country was awash in narcotics and dangerous drugs, but we did not expect to find significant cocaine operations, for example, in Wyoming, or heroin trafficking in Iowa,'' Mr. Thornburgh said. He also cited the growing consumption of LSD in rural Georgia and the widening use of methamphetamine in South Carolina.
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: He said the study, which was sent today to President Bush for review, reflected the first comprehensive outline of the ''size and breadth of these illegal and insidious drug operations'' and was the latest move by the Administration in the drug war.
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: In what the Attorney General characterized as a ''Dun & Bradstreet-type'' assessment, the report compares the roles of the chief organizers, the middlemen and distributors and looks at how they run their operations, hide the criminal origins of their money and interact with informers.
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: For example, the report, based on information gathered since last October and provided by the 93 United States Attorneys, states with large, well-established drug trafficking operations ''may have a board of directors, a C.E.O., a bureaucracy that are disciplined and whose functions and benefits mirror those of executives and middle-level management in a modern corporation, complete with expense accounts, bonuses and even 'company' cars.''
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: Mr. Thornburgh said that the report named 43 drug organizations around the country. Hired Killers in Iowa
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: Charles W. Larson, the United States Attorney for the northern district of Iowa, said at the news conference that cocaine is available in every town and ''affects all aspects of society.''
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: Asserting that ''violence follows drug trafficking'' to America's heartland, Mr. Larson said Federal prosecutors in Iowa had handled three or four cases involving hired killers.
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: ''One drug dealer was going to have an informant killed and hired two people to come from Minnesota,'' Mr. Larson said. ''Unfortunately they were going to kill the wrong informant but fortunately we stemmed that, stopped it, literally in the parking lot. To give you an idea of how violent they can become, they had taken steps to rent a wood chipper to dispose of the body.''
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: Law-enforcement officials in Fort Wayne, Ind., which calls itself the ''City of Churches,'' have renamed it the ''crack capital of Indiana.'' It is a city of 182,000 where 60 to 70 crack houses and crack distribution centers are operating, the report said. New Area for Initiatives
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: In drawing attention to the drug problem in rural areas, the Justice Department report would seem to raise a new area for policy initiatives in the Federal drug strategy being developed by Mr. Bennett. His plan, not yet made public, calls for a huge increase in Federal prison capacity and, among other things, designates five urban areas for new anti-drug spending.
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: While the report was not sent to members of Congress, Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, who is the chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, said of the findings, ''This is not a surprise.''
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: Mr. Rangel and drug policy experts in the Senate asserted that the spread of drugs to rural areas reinforced arguments in Congress that the Bush Administration had to be willing to spend more money to fighting drugs.
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: Mr. Rangel, ''You can't say you're going to declare war and give no money for the bullets.''
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: Mr. Bush has proposed $5.96 billion in anti-drug spending for the fiscal year 1990. The Senate has passed an amendment to the military budget bill calling for an additional $1.7 billion in Federal spending to fight drugs.
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: And Mr. Bennett, in a strategy document presented to budget officials this week, urged the Administration to spend at least $1 billion more than Mr. Bush proposed.
title: Drug Gangs and Drug Wars Move Into the Rural States, U.S. Warns

text: A new survey of drug users shows that the number of casual users has sharply dropped but that addiction to cocaine and crack is growing, Federal officials said today.
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: The 1988 National Household Survey on Drug Abuse found a 37 percent decrease from a 1985 survey in the number of people who said they had used marijuana, cocaine or other illicit drugs in the previous month.
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: The survey also showed that the number of people who said they had used an illegal drug in the previous year fell by 25 percent over the three years. 'Triumph of Changed Attitudes'
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: ''We are making some real progress in this war,'' said William J. Bennett, director of Federal drug control policy. ''People who have been saying, 'All is lost, we can't win, let's legalize' have never been more wrong.
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: ''Drugs are cheap and they are available almost everywhere, yet millions of Americans who once used them regularly appear now to have given them up altogether,'' Mr. Bennett said. ''This is primarily a triumph of changed attitudes.''
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: But the survey also found that the number of heavy cocaine users, including those using crack, a highly addictive form of the drug, rose sharply from 1985 to 1988, by 33 percent for those using it once a week or more and by 19 percent for daily and almost-daily users.
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: Although casual use of cocaine dropped sharply overall - by 50 percent - the survey found that among black and Hispanic people the numbers did not change significantly. Shift in Attitude Seen
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: The survey found that 72 million Americans, 37 percent of the population, had tried at least one illicit drug in their lifetimes.
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: ''Illicit drug use by Americans remains much too high,'' said Louis W. Sullivan, secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services. But, he added, ''attitudes are changing.''
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: Mr. Sullivan acknowledged that some underreporting was likely, but he said the data was reliable in showing trends in drug use.
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: The survey found that marijuana remained the most commonly used illicit drug among Americans.
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: The survey covered members of the population age 12 and older living in households in the 48 contiguous states. The results are based on personal interviews and written questions answered by 8,814 people. Half of them were white, while the other half was evenly split between black and Hispanic people.
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: The survey does not include homeless people, people living in military installations, dormitories and institutions like hospitals and prisons and does not cover heroin use.
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: The survey, conducted last fall, is the ninth in a series that began in 1971. It is sponsored by the National Institute on Drug Abuse, an agency of the Department of Health and Human Services.
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: A separate study, by the Justice Department, has found that more than half the men arrested in 14 major cities who volunteered for drug testing were found to have taken at least one drug.
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: The highest percentage of drug use, 82 percent, was discovered in Philadelphia, followed by San Diego, with 80 percent, according to the study, by the National Institute of Justice. The testing period ran from October through December 1988.
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: The tests were maded to detect the presence of cocaine, marijuana, opiates including heroin, PCP, amphetamines, Darvon, Valium, methaqualone, methadone and barbiturates.
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: After Philadelphia and San Diego, the cities with the highest percentages of men arrested who tested positive for drug use were New York and Chicago, at 78 percent; New Orleans, 75 percent; and Portland, Ore., and Birmingham, Ala., 70 percent. Then came Detroit, 69 percent; Cleveland, 68 percent; Dallas and Phoenix, 57 percent; St. Louis, 56 percent and Kansas City, Mo., 54 percent.
title: CASUAL DRUG USE IS SHARPLY DOWN

text: To the casual observer, a container of pumpkins transported by sea and resting on the docks here not long ago appeared harmless enough. But to the United States Customs inspectors poking bagfuls of the vegetable in search of cocaine, there was the very real possibility that the produce was just another hiding place for smuggled drugs.
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: The pumpkins turned out to be just pumpkins. But scenes like this one are more frequent as officials grapple with a sharp rise in the amount of narcotics brought into the United States in marine containers.
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: Last year, 30 percent of the cocaine and marijuana brought into the United States came by sea, say Customs officials, who add that the figure will probably reach 50 percent next year. Customs agents - recently joined at some ports by National Guardsmen - have found drugs stuffed in containers of L'eggs pantyhose, planted in pots of fresh flowers and secreted in the cages of snakes. Coast Guard scuba divers have even found drugs tied to ship propellers.
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: ''In 1985 and 1986, we didn't dream smugglers would make use of commercial sea carriers because too many people handle the goods,'' said Louis Razzino, a Customs coordinator for the agency's narcotics interdiction unit. He and others say the smugglers' increased use of sea carriers is a response to effective surveillance of Customs and the Drug Enforcement Agency against airborne drug trafficking.
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: Whatever the reason, the rise in such seaborne smuggling is further roiling relations between Customs and the highly competitive international shipping business, which is just beginning to emerge from a 15-year slump.
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: The shippers are already required, by the 1986 Anti-Drug Act and by a voluntary pact between the industry and Customs, to police their vessels for contraband. And carriers that are found to have transported drugs are subject to heavy fines - $1,000 an ounce for seizures of cocaine and $500 an ounce for marijuana - if Customs decides they have failed to exercise ''the highest degree of diligence'' in their self-policing.
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: Shippers like the $2 billion Sea-Land Corporation and the $30 million Kirk Lines already face fines totaling millions of dollars, although Customs' long appeals process has postponed actual payment. Now, worried about those fines, higher legal fees and the cost of beefing up security, the industry is refusing to sign a new version of its pact with Customs, the so-called Super Carrier Initiative Agreement proposed by the agency in May.
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: Recently, John R. Arwood, chairman of Kirk Lines, formed the Maritime Security Council to help shipping executives negotiate the terms of the new agreement, which Customs describes as a tougher document than the original pact of three years ago. ''With the first one we were in a 'feel-good' mode; we said it would be 'nice' if they did certain things,'' said John B. McGowan, director of inspection enforcement at Customs. ''Now we're saying that they must do certain things to get diminished penalties.''
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: Mr. McGowan says that under the new pact, a first-time seizure will be less serious than a second. And ''prior violations won't count as much if they stay clean for two years,'' he said. But Mr. Arwood sees the new pact as a betrayal of indications by William von Raab, the departing Customs Commissioner, that conscientious companies could avoid penalties. 'It doesn't reflect Commissioner von Raab's earlier promise to do away with fines if companies show they've been taking necessary security precautions,'' he said. ''We haven't gained anything.''
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: Mr. Arwood says the procedures prescribed by the new agreement - including background checks and fingerprinting of employees and installation of extra lighting in ports - may add $250,000 in annual costs for each trade route (a port-to-port roundtrip). In all, they say, the pact could raise the industry's costs 2.5 percent.
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: Kirk Lines, which moves cargo from the high-risk port of Kingston, Jamaica, already reports extra expenditures of $250,000 in 1988 for that port alone. Sea-Land says its overall surveillance now costs about $15,000 a voyage - two to three times more than three years ago.
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: These expenses come on top of some huge fines faced by the companies. Sea-Land is appealing penalties of $84 million. Kirk Lines also faces millions in fines imposed last year after dogs sniffed out about 13,000 pounds of marijuana nestled among cartons of biscuits inside a sealed container. Appeals have reduced that figure, but Mr. Arwood still describes it as a ''ransom.'' He says no one on board could have known about the drugs. ''When they mitigate a $101 million fine to $1 million, they wonder what we're complaining about,'' he said. ''I'm complaining about the six zeros, especially when we did nothing to deserve this.''
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: There are other costs, too, shippers say. Customs agents are authorized to destroy cargo - and vessels - if a search requires it, and to hold ships in port for days, even weeks, to examine cargo. Last year, a Kirk Lines carrier was removed from service for two weeks, a delay that the company says cost $250,000 in operational expenses and lost business. The ship was a relatively small one, costing $6,000 to $8,000 a day to operate, industry executives say, but operational expenses for large vessels, some the size of two or three football fields, sometimes amount to $14,000 an hour.
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: There are revenue losses, too, as companies shy away from high-risk routes. Evergreen Marine, a Taiwanese company and the world's biggest shipper, no longer calls at Kingston, a trade route that once accounted for 60 percent of its revenues.
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: Perhaps to demonstrate that the new agreement could be workable for companies that cooperate, Customs seems to have recently eased its policy on fines in some cases.
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: Six weeks ago, Evergreen Marine was fully absolved of a $29 million fine (already reduced from $65 million) when it persuaded the agency that it was not culpable in the tampering with containers from which 8,000 pounds of marijuana were seized. Two months earlier, Customs decided not to levy a fine after it found 2,900 pounds of cocaine secreted aboard a Sea-Land conveyance.
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: Still, the agency says it ''fully expects to continue'' its enforcement of the anti-drug act and that it backs the tough stance taken by Commissioner von Raab before he announced his resignation. ''If carriers are cooperating and have tight controls in place, they can expect fair treatment,'' he said then. ''Those who are lax will see a continuation of heavy penalties and more intensive scrutiny.''
title: A Skirmish Over Seaborne Drugs

text: Stars of the New Curfew By Ben Okri 194 pages. Viking. $17.95.
title: Books of The Times; Brave New Africa Born of Nightmare

text: ''Some of the people of the village had their feet facing backwards,'' observes the narrator of one of these stories by the Nigerian writer Ben Okri. ''I was amazed that they could walk. Some people came out of tree-trunks. Some had wings, but they couldn't fly. After a while I got used to the strangeness of the people. I ceased to really notice their three legs and elongated necks. What I couldn't get used to were the huts and houses that were walled round with mirrors on the outside. I didn't see myself reflected in them as I went past. Some people walked into the mirrors and disappeared.''
title: Books of The Times; Brave New Africa Born of Nightmare

text: A fantastical world in which fairy-tale creatures mingle with ordinary human beings, in which the mundane continually fades into the surreal, Mr. Okri's Africa seems like a continent dreamed up, in tandem, by Hieronymus Bosch and Jorge Luis Borges -a land where history has quite literally become a nightmare. Here, the old and the new, the ancient and the modern exist uneasily side by side. Men pour libations and pray to their ancestors before heading off to work, wearing the latest American fashions, attache cases in hand. Bigshot politicians travel to fancy-dress balls in bulletproof limousines, while the poor look to Nostradamus and fortune tellers for prophecies and hope.
title: Books of The Times; Brave New Africa Born of Nightmare

text: Though the statues built in commemoration of a vanished empire have ''disintegrated beneath the sun and under the onslaught of the sand and wind,'' the brave new world promised by independence has yet to emerge from the chrysallis of time. Corrupt officials award themselves citations from universities they have set up themselves, and they use state money to protect their private marijuana farms. Almost daily blackouts keep the people in thrall to the state-run electrical companies, and soldiers regularly stop women on the street, comandeering their sexual favors as casually as they might ask for directions in a more civilized time. The newspapers are filled with stories of ''accidents on the roads, armed robberies, contract killings, ritual murders, military executions at the beach.''
title: Books of The Times; Brave New Africa Born of Nightmare

text: In fact, it is hard to distinguish between this brutal everyday reality and the worst imaginings of a fevered brain. Often nature itself seems out of joint: it has become a dark mirror of the political corruption and moral disorder overtaking the countryside. In ''Worlds That Flourish,'' rain pours down unceasingly for days, houses crumble in the force of the wind and the birds disappear from the sky. In ''In the City of Red Dust,'' the capital of a country - which has been celebrating the military governor's 50th birthday - is slowly and inexorably buried in red dust. And in the title story, a host of bizarre ailments and skin diseases proliferate in a town, driving the population to seek the aid of sorcerers and herbalists, disreputable doctors and enterprising con men.
title: Books of The Times; Brave New Africa Born of Nightmare

text: The narrator of this story is a salesman of dubious medicines. His latest concoction - something called ''Power Drug'' - is supposed to be ''more effective than anything the white man had invented.''
title: Books of The Times; Brave New Africa Born of Nightmare

text: ''I said this was the product of African powers, the collaboration of Africa and India,'' the narrator says. ''I made extraordinary claims for it; I said it could cure anything from headaches to elephantiasis, that they could either drink it, bathe with it, rub it on their skin, or sniff its essences in boiling water.''
title: Books of The Times; Brave New Africa Born of Nightmare

text: In Mr. Okri's telling, Power Drug becomes something of a metaphor for the impossible expectations raised by African independence. Predictably enough, the elixir fails to live up to its inflated claims. Though people purchase it with huge sums of money -often acquired at the expense of their children's lives - they are rewarded not with improved health, but with further afflictions, including frightening hallucinations, uncontrollable bouts of anger and grief.
title: Books of The Times; Brave New Africa Born of Nightmare

text: ''We needed modern miracles,'' Mr. Okri writes. ''We were, all of us, hungry. We had abandoned our private lives, our business lives, our leisure, our pain, because we wanted to witness miracles. And the miracle we had come to witness, which seemed to comprise the other side of ritual drums and dread, was that of the multiplying currency. We had come to be fed by the great magicians of money, masters of our age.''
title: Books of The Times; Brave New Africa Born of Nightmare

text: Cut off from the sustenance of old traditions and committed now to the new gods of expediency, Mr. Okri's people live in a state of suspended animation, their private lives overshadowed by political atrocities, whatever ideals they might have had eroded by the demands of day-to-day survival.
title: Books of The Times; Brave New Africa Born of Nightmare

text: A man who has recently lost his job is robbed of all his possessions and tries to flee his war-town home by driving to the countryside beyond, only to fall prey to strange - and possibly imagined - creatures who live beyond the laws of civilization. A man who supports himself by selling his blood to a hospital suffers a series of emotional and financial setbacks and descends further and further into madness. An aspiring musician - a would-be Orpheus - decides to make up with his estranged girlfriend, but discovers that she has slipped into a paranoid fantasy world from which he cannot retrieve her.
title: Books of The Times; Brave New Africa Born of Nightmare

text: There is a certain sameness to these stories that indicates a somewhat limited reservoir of images and preoccupations. In tale after tale, the characters' nightmares become inseparable from their real-life dilemmas. In tale after tale, madness and hallucinations reflect a world that's grown impervious to reason. Still, it's clear from these stories that Mr. Okri possesses both a gift for fiercely lyrical language, and a well-developed aptitude for showing how the social realities in contemporary Africa resemble our worst dreams. This, his first book to be published in this country, points to the emergence of a distinctive new literary voice - a voice that needs only to expand its narrative territory to fulfill its bright promise.
title: Books of The Times; Brave New Africa Born of Nightmare

text: State legislators considering laws that restrict a woman's right to terminate pregnancy, in response to the Supreme Court decision upholding state limits on abortions (front page, July 4), should consider a new turn of events. Many pro-choice advocates fear a return to the days of the coat-hanger abortion. But in this technological age, the struggle seems more likely to take another form.
title: Abortion Ruling Evokes Drug Nightmare

text: The drug RU486, developed in France, allows women to end a pregnancy shortly after conception with very little disturbance of any physiological system. These pills will of course be prohibited, like marijuana and other controlled substances, and an illicit market of the same kind will be created. The sellers (will they be called pushers?) will at first import the drug from abroad. If that becomes too expensive and risky, they will switch to manufacturing it here in clandestine laboratories.
title: Abortion Ruling Evokes Drug Nightmare

text: Users will have no assurance that the product is pure and the dose correct, but that will not stop them, and occasional disasters will occur. Federal money will be poured into efforts to interdict imports and identify and destroy illicit laboratories. Further police incursions on privacy are inevitable. So is law-enforcement corruption. Some large-scale dealers will be apprehended and convicted, but 10 will be waiting to take the place of each one who goes to prison.
title: Abortion Ruling Evokes Drug Nightmare

text: Since it will be impossible to punish all the users, the White House may endorse a ''Just say no'' campaign. We can even imagine politically influential fanatics demanding urine tests to detect the drug in all women of childbearing age who are not pregnant. That may be only a nightmare, but the battle against abortion has the potential to become a new act in the tragic farce of the war on drugs. LESTER GRINSPOON, M.D., JAMES B. BAKALAR Boston, July 7, 1989 The writers, co-authors of ''Psychedelic Drugs Reconsidered,'' teach in the Harvard Medical School psychiatry department as, respectively, associate professor and lecturer in law.
title: Abortion Ruling Evokes Drug Nightmare

text: A 30-year-old man who was accused of being the leader of one of the largest and most violent drug rings in Brooklyn was convicted yesterday of Federal racketeering charges, including six murders.
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: The man, Delroy Edwards, a Jamaican national who lived in Brooklyn, glowered as the jury foreman said ''guilty'' to 42 counts that included 17 assaults, a kidnapping and a maiming. But before delivering the verdict, the foreman notified the judge that members of the jury were concerned for their safety.
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: In a note to Judge Raymond J. Dearie, the foreman asked, ''After rendering our verdict, will any precautionary measures be taken on our behalf?''
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: Judge Dearie later assured the jurors that they had no reason to be concerned. He told them that they would be escorted by marshals from the courthouse after the verdict, as they had been during the trial, and that no personal information about them would be made public. Fifth Day of Deliberations
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: The verdict came on the fifth day of deliberations after a six-week trial in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. Mr. Edwards was accused of operating a drug ring from 1984 until last year.
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: Prosecutors said Mr. Edwards was the first dealer to sell crack, the smokable cocaine derivative, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn in 1985. A spokesman for the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, Robert Strang, said that a number of Jamaican groups were active in crack distribution in Brooklyn but that Mr. Edwards's operation was among the largest and best organized.
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: Mr. Edwards - who the authorities said had been nicknamed Uzi because he sometimes concealed an Uzi submachine gun under a trench coat - faces possible life imprisonment when he is sentenced. No date was set for sentencing. He is also facing trial on a murder charge in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: The court-appointed defense lawyer, David Gordon, said he assumed Mr. Edwards would appeal the verdict.
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: During the trial, the Federal prosecutors, John Gleeson and Jonny J. Frank, depicted the defendant as a ''coldhearted, brutal, vicious killer'' who dealt harshly with rival drug dealers, employees he suspected of stealing from him, and, sometimes, innocent people ''who happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time.'' Beaten and Shot to Death
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: One man who was first beaten and then shot to death had been mistaken for his twin who worked for the Edwards ring, or ''posse,'' as it was called, and was suspected of withholding money from drug sales.
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: Mr. Edwards's second-in-command, Kenneth Manning, and 13 other members of the ring, who are now in Government custody, testified for the prosecution. The ring, which was said to have about 50 members, sold crack, cocaine and marijuana in the Bedford-Stuyvesant, Crown Heights and Flatbush sections of Brooklyn. It was also active in the Washington, Baltimore and Philadelphia areas.
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: Prosecutors said that the ring, composed chiefly of Jamaican nationals, took in from $40,000 to $100,000 a day and that Mr. Edwards, as the leader, made ''mountains of money.'' They said Mr. Edwards once paid $150,000 in $10 and $20 bills to buy a house in Amityville, L.I., and owned several luxury cars.
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: Much of the testimony detailed the ring's ruthlessness. Mr. Edwards, wearing a business suit, sat impassively as his former associates told of the murders and brutal beatings he had participated in or ordered. Body Wrapped in Plastic
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: One of the victims, Norman Allwood, a 17-year-old who was suspected of stealing money and drugs from the ring, was beaten with baseball bats, scalded with boiling water and hung by chains from a basement ceiling, according to testimony. His body, wrapped in plastic, was later found on a Brooklyn street.
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: In September 1987, witnesses said, Mr. Edwards was shot and he suspected that the shooting was the work of a rival Jamaican gang. The jury was told that he ordered an associate to go to the corner of Schenectady Avenue and Sterling Place in Bedford-Stuyvesant and ''to shoot anyone who looks Jamaican.''
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: The reprisal shooting left an innocent man, a musician, paralyzed from gunshot wounds.
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: The defense lawyer, Mr. Gordon, described the former ring members who testified for the Government as ''vicious, ruthless, horrible people'' who could be expected to lie on the stand to be given less jail time for their crimes.
title: Jury Convicts Man as Chief of Drug Ring

text: By Jeffrey Schmalz, Special To the New York Times
title: Officers Along I-95 Stop 11,000 Drivers In Anti-Speed Effort

text: Hundreds of police officers in 15 East Coast states stopped more than 11,000 motorists along Interstate 95 today and Thursday as part of a crackdown on speeders and drug traffickers.
title: Officers Along I-95 Stop 11,000 Drivers In Anti-Speed Effort

text: In the operation, 297 people were arrested for felonies, mostly for drug violations. Officers seized 340 grams of crack, about 13 pounds of cocaine and about 147 pounds of marijuana.
title: Officers Along I-95 Stop 11,000 Drivers In Anti-Speed Effort

text: Most of the drug arrests were made in cars that were originally stopped for traffic violations. Speeding tickets were issued to 5,462 drivers, 5,000 others received other traffic citations, and 100 were arrested for driving while intoxicated.
title: Officers Along I-95 Stop 11,000 Drivers In Anti-Speed Effort

text: ''We're concentrating on highway safety violations, but any time you're out there in such a mass effort - we're hoping the criminals using the highways are aware we're out there,'' said Lieut. Randy Brown of the Florida Highway Patrol in Jacksonville.
title: Officers Along I-95 Stop 11,000 Drivers In Anti-Speed Effort

text: The operation, called Co-Flame, for Cooperation from Florida to Maine, was organized by the International Association of Chiefs of Police. It lasted from 8 A.M. Thursday until 8 A.M. today and involved 2,200 officers, mostly state troopers. It was intended to remind the public of the presence of the police in an effort to make travel safer on Interstate 95, the East Coast's main north-south highway, which is a favorite road of speeders and a major route for drug traffickers.
title: Officers Along I-95 Stop 11,000 Drivers In Anti-Speed Effort

text: Ronald Sostkowski, director of the Division of State and Provincial Police for the police chiefs' association, said the operation marked the first time that every state crossed by an interstate had joined for one large highway law-enforcement operation. He predicted the opeartion would be repeated on other interstate highways.
title: Officers Along I-95 Stop 11,000 Drivers In Anti-Speed Effort

text: Jim and Helen Kilroy have emblazoned the name of their murdered son across the windows of a storefront wedged between a pizza parlor and a printing shop in a suburban shopping center. Inside, at old metal desks, they stuff envelopes and make phone calls all day long. They are turning their grief into a crusade.
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: Like many other middle-class parents, the Kilroys learned about the damage done by drugs by becoming victims. They also became celebrities; after burying their son with television news cameras whirring, they decided it was their mission to remain in the limelight.
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: The son, Mark Kilroy, was a smart, clean-cut, 21-year-old college student who disappeared off the streets of Matamoros, Mexico, March 14 during a spring-break revel in that border town. A month later his mutilated body was one of 13 corpses found on a nearby ranch. All the victims had been killed by a drug-smuggling ring.
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: Young Mr. Kilroy had been picked at random for kidnapping and murder by marijuana traffickers who believed human sacrifice and voodoo rituals would protect them from the police.
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: The big letters spell out ''M.A.R.K.'' on the windows of the Kilroys' headquarters here in Santa Fe., a tiny town 32 miles from Houston. The letters stand for ''Make A Responsible Kommitment.''
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: Speaking on the steps of the State Capitol in Austin, appearing on talk shows, in churches and at business conventions, the Kilroys are campaigning to get five million signatures on a petition demanding a Federal crackdown on drugs. They say they will present their case Wednesday to the Federal drug policy director, William J. Bennett, when he visits Houston.
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: The Kilroys have developed suggestions including measures like rehabilitation camps run by the military for drug sellers, but they are not promoting any specific policy or proposal; they say they just want action.
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: ''This is a critical situation, and we want the Government to do something about it before drugs destroy us,'' Mr. Kilroy said. ''The biggest lie is that this is a victimless crime. Everyone except the pushers and the addicts is an innocent victim. So, we want everyone to demand a policy that works because that is only way we are going to get one.''
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: The M.A.R.K. petitions read: ''Yes! We have had enough! We support a great change in the national drug policy!''
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: A woman walked into the store recently. ''You the Kilroys?'' she asked. Receiving a nod, she added her name to the petition. ''You're right,'' she said. ''Anyone who smokes just one joint is helping wreck the country.''
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: Until they launched their campaign at the end of May, Mr. Kilroy, a chemical engineer, and Mrs. Kilroy, a paramedic, say they had never thought of influencing the Government on any subject. In a photograph that has appeared repeatedly in Texas newspapers, their son's yearbook smile seems an emblem of their previously happy, uneventful lives.
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: Mr. Kilroy, who is 45 years old, has not returned to work since his son disappeared. He is on a three-month unpaid leave so he can work full time on the M.A.R.K. campaign. A native of Chicago who has kept a Midwestern twang through 20 years in Texas, Mr. Kilroy does not disguise his amazement when he recites statistics that link drugs to everything from homelessness to suicides of teen-agers.
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: ''Every day we learn more and more and every day it looks worse and worse,'' he said, shaking his head.
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: Almost apologetically, his wife interjected: ''Honestly, we were not aware of what was going on with drugs. Most people like us aren't aware because what we see on TV and in the paper seems so far away.''
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: ''Who do we blame for our son's death?'' Mr. Kilroy said. ''We blame people like ourselves who let this go on.''
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: So far, the Kilroys have not counted the names they have collected on their petition.
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: ''We've stopped and wondered what we were doing several times,'' Mrs. Kilroy said, ''but I think we were meant to do this because at every bad moment we hear from somebody, an addict, a parent that has lost a child, somebody who says they want us to keep going.''
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: The Kilroys find solace in what they are doing and in the people who come to to volunteer work and money. Rubbing her thumbs and forefingers together, Mrs. Kilroy glanced around the room that has taken on the apperance of a precinct office in a political race. ''If we couldn't put our energies into this,'' she said, ''it would be a much more difficult time for us.''
title: Santa Fe Journal; Parents of Slain Texan Keep Up War on Drugs

text: Public television's ''American Masters,'' now in its fourth season, seems to be ghettoizing its schedule in clusters of thematically related documentaries. The past three weeks have been devoted to documentaries on the Group Theater, the critic and director Harold Clurman and the actress and teacher Stella Adler. The overall scene was almost exclusively white and markedly Jewish. Now, beginning this evening at 9 and continuing for the next two Mondays, the series is offering profiles of three giants in American music, each of them coming out of this country's often troubled and troubling black experience.
title: Review/Television; 3 Black Musicians and Their Roots

text: Tonight's ''Celebrating Bird: The Triumph of Charlie Parker'' traces the story of the saxophonist who was barely in his 20's when he started pointing jazz in new directions. In 1955 he died at the age of 34, ravaged by alcohol and drugs. Next Monday, the series is repeating ''Aretha Franklin: The Queen of Soul,'' a glossy and curiously underestimating British Broadcasting essay that was given more of an upbeat spin for American audiences. And on July 31, ''Satchmo'' focuses on the life and times of the extraordinary Louis Armstrong.
title: Review/Television; 3 Black Musicians and Their Roots

text: ''Celebrating Bird'' and ''Satchmo'' are based on books by Gary Giddins, writer of a jazz column for The Village Voice since 1973. Produced by Toby Byron, the documentaries were directed by Mr. Giddins, collaborating on ''Celebrating Bird'' with Kendrick Simmons, who also did the editing. Not surprisingly, the formats are similar. The biographies unfold, more or less chronologically, through a straightforward narrative that is supplemented with photographs, archival film footage, movie and performance clips and interviews with friends, experts and former colleagues. The result is a kind of helpful and valuable primer, tending to suggest rather than explore, and then to move on briskly.
title: Review/Television; 3 Black Musicians and Their Roots

text: Parker is an elusive figure. There are only two film clips extant of the saxophone legend in performance, and one of them is silent. Born in 1920 in Kansas City, Kans., and raised across the river in Kansas City, Mo., he began playing the alto saxophone at the age of 12. Rebecca Parker Davis, his first wife, recalls the day in July 1937 when she first saw her husband shooting heroin.
title: Review/Television; 3 Black Musicians and Their Roots

text: Parker quickly became known in the jazz world once he arrived in New York. The early 1940's was a time of revolution in jazz, and Parker would be joined by such other trailblazers as Dizzy Gillespie, Thelonious Monk, Max Roach, Bud Powell and Miles Davis.
title: Review/Television; 3 Black Musicians and Their Roots

text: In a familiar story, Parker and be-bop were appreciated more in Europe than in their native land. On two very successful tours abroad, Parker was lionized. Back home, he faced either neglect or condescension. Captured forever is the racial patronizing of a 1951 television broadcast in which a white Broadway columnist presented Parker and Mr. Gillespie with Downbeat Magazine awards. The look of seething contempt on Parker's face is memorable. There is one consolation: the two musicians then perform a brillian rendition of ''Hot House.''
title: Review/Television; 3 Black Musicians and Their Roots

text: Mr. Giddins has included some surprising details. One of Parker's favorite sax players, for instance, was Jimmy Dorsey, Tommy's brother and very much in the popular mainstream. The Parker story is now fairly familiar, having served as the basis for major movies, including Clint Eastwood's ''Bird.'' But the legend is obviously here to stay. A profoundly serious artist, Parker described his dedication this way: ''Music is your whole experience, your thoughts, your wisdom. If you don't live it, it won't come out of your horn.''
title: Review/Television; 3 Black Musicians and Their Roots

text: ''Satchmo,'' of course, focuses on a considerably more accessible figure. Louis Armstrong, born in New Orleans on July 4, 1901, wasted little time in becoming a public figure. Before his death in 1971, he was internationally recognized through a steady succession of recordings, films and television appearances. Although he insisted on living in a relatively modest home in Corona, Queens, he had accumulated considerable wealth over the decades. As one fellow musician says in this documentary, ''His influence is undeniable; it's unmistakable, and it's eternal.''
title: Review/Television; 3 Black Musicians and Their Roots

text: Most Americans today might remember him for his more popular hits, ''Mack the Knife'' or ''Hello, Dolly,'' which gave his career a major boost in the mid-60's, but ''Satchmo'' goes back to his early work when Armstrong initiated the instrumental solo in jazz performances. His trumpet work on ''West End Blues,'' recorded in the late 1920's, is positively stunning. A born showman, he pushed on to Hollywood in the 1930's, appearing in everything from silly jungle romps to a string of Bing Crosby movies. No matter how racially offensive the production numbers, it's noted, Armstrong's talent and personality always emerged unscathed. A Crosby quotation is mentioned: ''He was the beginning and end of music in America.''
title: Review/Television; 3 Black Musicians and Their Roots

text: Here again, the details can be surprising. Recalling that Armstrong was arrested in Hollywood in 1930 on a marijuana charge, the documentary notes that Armstrong would continue to smoke it - 6 to 10 joints a day - all his life. We are also reminded that Armstrong's final years were marked by unfortunate tensions. For one thing, with the advent of modern jazz typified by Parker and the others, Armstrong was sometimes dismissed as old-fashioned. For another, during the volatile civil-rights eruptions of the 1960's he was condemned by some activists as an ''Uncle Tom'' even as, incredibly enough, the Federal Bureau of Investigation was investigating him for possible Communist leanings. At this remove, the detractors and zealous sleuths seem decidedly puny when stacked up against the enduring genius of Armstrong.
title: Review/Television; 3 Black Musicians and Their Roots

text: Although sketchy at times, these two television essays are bound to leave most viewers wanting to go back to the recordings of Charlie Parker and Louis Armstrong. In that sense, they work splendidly.
title: Review/Television; 3 Black Musicians and Their Roots

text: Only one emotion comes to my mind upon hearing the Supreme Court's decision to uphold Missouri's restrictions on abortions - anger. It is directed against antiabortion activists who believe lives will be saved if abortion is outlawed. Nothing could be further from the truth.
title: Now We Must Reason Together About Abortion; No Lives Saved

text: Although the decision does not actually change legislation much, it gets the ball rolling in the wrong direction. Clearly, the majority of Supreme Court justices opposes a woman's right to terminate her pregnancy safely. If this decision results in changes that make safe abortions more difficult to obtain, abortion opponents will have succeeded only in ruining and perhaps killing innocent women and children.
title: Now We Must Reason Together About Abortion; No Lives Saved

text: Most women seeking abortions are poor and cannot afford to support a child, perhaps their fourth or fifth. These women would not be able to travel to another state to receive a safe abortion, but would be forced to jeopardize their lives by finding other means to terminate pregnancy. Or worse, they would give birth to a child who will be sentenced to a life of abject poverty and resentment. How can this be considered saving lives?
title: Now We Must Reason Together About Abortion; No Lives Saved

text: I've heard abortion opponents talk about helping pregnant women receive prenatal care but I have yet to hear one offer to help support the family for the next 18 years, nor have I heard them offer to babysit while the mother goes back to work or school. (If they really believe adoption is a choice, they should try carrying a fetus for nine months and then giving the baby away. They would also see how little demand there is for adopting minority babies.) In the coming months, the Supreme Court will decide whether a teenager can receive an abortion without her parents' consent. Isn't it obvious that if a teen-ager has a close and open relationship with her parents, she would look to them for support at such a time? It is precisely those girls who will be beaten or kicked out of the house after informing their parents of their pregnancies who may be forced to do so.
title: Now We Must Reason Together About Abortion; No Lives Saved

text: No one will argue that there are already too many children born to parents who cannot lovingly support them. Let's save a child from a lifetime of misery. Let's keep abortion safe and available to all those who need it. MARIANA NACHT Philadelphia, July 4, 1989
title: Now We Must Reason Together About Abortion; No Lives Saved

text: Some of the top officials of Cuba's police and state security apparatus have resigned in the latest twist to the country's drug smuggling scandal, the Government has announced.
title: Cuba Police Officials Quit in Drug Scandal

text: The sweeping changes at the Ministry of Interior, involving six top officials, were disclosed Friday on the front page of the official newspaper Granma a day after four former military officers, including revolutionary hero Arnaldo Ochoa Sanchez, were executed after being convicted of conspiring to ship tons of cocaine and marijuana to the United States.
title: Cuba Police Officials Quit in Drug Scandal

text: Four top Interior Ministry officials, including the chief of intelligence, Gen. German Barreiro, resigned along with two departmental deputies, Granma said. Gen. Roberto Gonzalez was dismissed as chief of the Department of Immigration, it said.
title: Cuba Police Officials Quit in Drug Scandal

text: A Cuban official called the shakeup ''part of a general house-cleaning at the Ministry.''
title: Cuba Police Officials Quit in Drug Scandal

text: Two of the four who were executed, former Col. Antonio de la Guardia and former Maj. Amado Padron, were Ministry of Interior officials. Ten other officers of the same ministry were given long prison terms.
title: Cuba Police Officials Quit in Drug Scandal

text: By Jeffrey Schmalz, Special To the New York Times
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: The pilot who was apparently unconscious while his small plane flew a thousand miles and crashed told Federal investigators today that he had no idea how he was shot and that the last thing he remembered was having difficulty breathing.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: It was the first meeting of the pilot, Thomas L. Root, with Federal investigators since he sank into the Atlantic Ocean on Thursday.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: After 40 minutes of questioning Mr. Root in his hospital room, the chief investigator, Andrew A. Alston of the National Transportation Safety Board, was both supportive and skeptical of the pilot's account.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: Mr. Alston said Mr. Root, a 36-year-old Washington lawyer, had described symptoms consistent with oxygen deprivation: headache, shortness of breath and tunnel vision. He also told investigators that he did not shoot himself, Mr. Alston said.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: The investigator said no evidence had been turned up so far to make Mr. Root a criminal suspect. ''We have no reasons to disbelieve him,'' he said at a news conference. Cooperative and Forthcoming
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: Asked if a lie-detector test would be administered, Mr. Alston replied, ''There's no reason at this time to enter into that area.''
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: ''He was very cooperative, very open, very forthcoming,'' Mr. Alston said of Mr. Root. ''I think he wants to find out what happened also. That was the attitude he exuded to me.''
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: But at another point, Mr. Alston said there were ''inconsistencies.'' He declined to elaborate, other than to cite the obvious one. ''He doesn't remember a gunshot wound, and we see one. That's a large inconsistency.'' Mr. Alston said things might become clearer by the middle of the week, when the results are known of blood tests for such drugs as cocaine and marijuana, as well as for carbon monoxide, which could have leaked into the cabin and caused Mr. Root to pass out.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: On April 24 the police, responding to an anonymous tip, found 28 guns and a five-gallon drum of ether in the Virginia hangar housing Mr. Root's plane, a Cessna 210 Centurion. Mr. Root at the time explained the guns by saying he was a collector and the ether, which is used in the processing of cocaine, by saying he used it to clean the plane.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: Asked about the credibility of that statement, Mr. Alston said, ''I've never cleaned my airplane with ether.''
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: Federal official said they had been keeping a watch on Mr. Root as a possible drug trafficker because of ''suspicious'' trips to the Caribbean.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: As Mr. Root lay in a hospital bed in Hollywood, Fla., in stable condition, investigators said privately that the inquiry was still in its initial stages and that all possibilities were being considered. Among them, they said, are these:
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: * That Mr. Root is telling the truth. He passed out in the cabin, perhaps from carbon monoxide, and a gun in the plane's glove compartment fired accidentally.
