title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: * That Mr. Root, under investigation by various agencies and organizations for possible security fraud and misrepresenting his clients' interests in applications for FM radio licenses, might have been planning suicide and trying to make it look like an accident. Investigators said they are trying to find out what insurance policies he held.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: * That Mr. Root intended all along to ditch the plane off the Bahamas, making it look like an accident, then swimming off to begin a life anew under an alias. Under this theory, investigators said, Mr. Root did not expect military jets to be scrambled to help him, panicked when he saw them and then wounded himself in some unclear effort to explain his feigned unconsciousness and flight route.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: * That Mr. Root planned an accident in which he would survive but the plane would be destroyed. Under this theory, Mr. Root would collect the insurance money for the plane, which investigators have confirmed was worth about $130,000 when new and was insured. The plane was repossessed last month when the Roots fell behind in their payments, and they recovered it less than a week ago. It was leased by Mr. Root from the Aircraft Leasing Corporation, a company formed by Mr. Root and his wife, Kathy.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: The investigators acknowledge that each of these theories has internal inconsistencies they cannot explain. If Mr. Root was attempting suicide, for instance, why would he shoot himself in the abdomen, not the chest or head? If he shot merely to wound himself to justify his unconsciousness and route, why would he then speculate that the gun did not go off until the impact of the crash?
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: ''I have not worked on a case like this before,'' Mr. Alston said, referring to the inconsistencies and questions.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: At a news conference this afternoon, members of Mr. Root's family said that news organizations were stringing together isolated bits of information that paint an inaccurate portrait of Mr. Root. They described him as a hard-working lawyer who was not involved in anything illegal.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: ''He is just a regular Washington lawyer,'' said Mr. Root's wife. She was accompanied by her brother-in-law, Todd Root, and her father-in-law, Thomas Root.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: They said that any reports linking Mr. Root to drug trafficking were ridiculous. Few Items of Baggage
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: Mr. Root, the Federal investigator said, told him that he was alone and that he took only a briefcase, some papers and a tape recorder with him on the plane Thursday morning. Witnesses at the airport, Washington National, confirm that was all he was carrying. He filed a flight plan for Rocky Mount, N.C.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: The plane sank within minutes of crashing 14 miles east of the island of Eleuthera in the Bahamas. Mr. Alston said none of the personal effects that floated to the surface contradict Mr. Root's statement.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: The investigator said that when Mr. Root became short of breath, he turned on the automatic pilot but was unable to get his breathing apparatus to work. He reported to air controllers that he was having difficulty breathing.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: Mr. Root told the investigator that he did not say he was having chest pains, as the Federal Aviation Administration reported, and investigators said a review of tapes showed Mr. Root to be correct.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: Mr. Root told investigators that in the plane's glove compartment, on the passenger side, he routinely carried a .32 caliber Smith & Wesson revolver, with all its chambers loaded but with the hammer not cocked. Mr. Root said he carried the gun in case the plane crashed in a remote area and also because his business frequently took him to airports in isolated areas.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: Mr. Alston said that after failing to get the oxygen system to work, the next thing Mr. Root recalled was coming to in a plane filling with water. He escaped by climbing out the left window and clinging briefly to the left wing before swimming toward rescuers. He took off his shirt and tried to trap air in it, making it into a flotation device, but failed.
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: ''He said he has no idea how he was shot,'' Mr. Alston said, ''and said he did not even realize he had been shot until doctors told him at the hospital.''
title: Pilot Says He Doesn't Have Answers

text: LEAD: WHEN Democrats on the Board of Legislators called for an office within county government to coordinate the fight against illegal drugs, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke initially criticized the idea as an unneeded new layer of bureaucracy. But in a reversal, Mr. O'Rourke, running for re-election, last month appointed Robert M.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: WHEN Democrats on the Board of Legislators called for an office within county government to coordinate the fight against illegal drugs, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke initially criticized the idea as an unneeded new layer of bureaucracy. But in a reversal, Mr. O'Rourke, running for re-election, last month appointed Robert M. Maccarone to be the director of the ''War on Drugs'' program.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Mr. Maccarone, 36 years old, had been the county's Director of Criminal-Justice Planning since 1982. In his new post, which carries a salary of $67,130, he will coordinate the activities of 11 county departments. It is estimated they spend more than $40 million on drug-related matters.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: The largest chunk is spent by the Department of Correction. Seventy-five percent of the prisoners at the country's jail complex are said to be chemically dependent; 40 percent of the pretrial prisoners were arrested on drug charges and another 35 percent for drug-related reasons. Funds are also channeled through the Departments of Social Services and Mental Health, among others.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Mr. Maccarone, a lawyer who has degrees in psychology and sociology.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Q. What is the purpose of this new office?
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: A. It identifies one person who oversees the county's ''War on Drugs'' and insures that it is waged in a concerted way. We already have many fine programs. For example, the Department of Community Mental Health is doing curriculum training with fifth- and sixth-grade schoolteachers. They've already educated 25,000 youths in Westchester through this program. We have the Treatment Alternatives to Street Crime Program, operated under the Department of Community Mental Health, to divert from the criminal-justice system substance abusers and alcoholics into treatment programs. And we've most recently developed the first intensive drug-treatment program within the Department of Correction.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: We're doing many fine things, but we're not doing anything in a concerted way. No one is overseeing the coordination of our efforts in education, prevention, treatment and law enforcement.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Q. How bad is the drug-abuse problem in Westchester?
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: A. I met recently with Robert Stuttman, the special agent for the area for the Federal Drug Enforcement Agency. He said the problem in Westchester was far worse than he or anyone else ever recognized. His barometer is the amount of drug trafficking that is going on, primarily of crack.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Q. Are we talking about a problem of poor people or yuppies on cocaine?
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: A. What Mr. Stuttman said, and I subscribe to, is that the crack problem in this country knows no socio-economic barriers. It goes across every race, color, creed and every level of affluence or poverty. Our effort will be directed at targeting it all, not just the element that comes to the attention of the criminal-justice system.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: That is why he suggested - and we since have had - a conference with chief executive officers to discuss its impact on business, dollars and cents wise. We want to help them develop a policy on drugs in the workplace. We already have a county government policy.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Q. What is the county government policy toward its employees?
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: A. The basic tenets of the policy are that if you have a drug problem the county wants to join in a partnership with you to see that you are treated; you are encouraged to come forward and you will be held harmless and, indeed, assisted to involve yourself in treatment. However, if you don't seek treatment and you are discovered to have a problem, then you will be terminated.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Q. Will your office be concerned with alcohol abuse as well?
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: A. Not alcohol. We decided that at this point we wanted to make a concerted effort on illegal drugs alone.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Q. Beyond the estimated $40 million now spent by the county fighting drugs, you have asked for $250,000. What will you do with this new money?
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: A. In my tentative budget, I've included $100,000 for education and prevention, because I want that to be the signal that this is our long-term answer. I have put in $75,000 for treatment and $75,000 for law enforcement.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: On education and prevention, I've included money for expanding the education program into kindergarten through fifth grade. We hope to be in all the schools with our program to teach the teachers. I also put in money for some education through public information, developing pieces of literature directed at different audiences. I'd also like to develop volunteers to help get the message across.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: With our treatment programs, we want to try to get off the ground a program within the Mental Health Department aimed at pregnant women who are drug-dependent, to see that their children are not born drug-dependent. Also, we need to expand our treatment programs, specifically for cocaine abusers.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: We need short-term intensive residential treatment followed by outpatient treatment. We have a long wait now for these kinds of services. At the same time, we have nothing equivalent to what methadone was for heroin - a chemical treatment. These people are being treated very successfully. They are not large contributors to criminal activity. Although they are dependent on methadone, their lives are under control; many of them are leading quasi-successful lives.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Q. So why not legalize cocaine? Wouldn't this get rid of the criminal activity?
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: A. My opinion, as well as that of the County Executive, is that this would not be a good thing. First, it would automatically increase the population that becomes involved with the drug. That is destructive right there. It is not a drug that can be used casually. The drug by its nature is an aggressive drug. It results in people becoming very aggressive, violent and unpredictable.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Its negative effects on the body are extremely dangerous, including heart problems and extreme loss of weight. What you see are young persons, 20 and 30, dying of heart attacks. Although I'm not a big proponent of alcohol use, because I think over the long term it can be very destructive to the body, it can be ingested casually in moderation.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Q. How will you spend the $75,000 for law-enforcement activities?
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: A. This would be to train police officers in interdiction techniques. It's already been done with state and county police, but not with the local police officers who are responsible for some major thoroughfares in the county. I also put in some money for mandatory random urine testing for certain probationers, in addition to what is already in the county's 1989 budget.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Q. How do you view the Federal Government's efforts to combat drugs?
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: A. The intent has been there on the part of the Federal Government. The financing has not. Yet at the same time, I recognize that the Federal Government is limited by its revenues, as well. I'm not going to be overly critical, because I think our ability to deal with the drug problem is on a local basis. The Federal Government is involved with interdiction, but the answer is not interdiction. It's always the easiest answer to say that if we only just do away with these drugs and make them not available, we wouldn't have a drug problem. That's just not true.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Six of the 10 drugs that are the problem are manufactured here in the United States. If we were able to do away with importation of cocaine, we would certainly develop a new one synthetically. Right now, the U.S. is the largest grower of marijuana in the world.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: If you want my opinion, the answer is to change attitudes toward drug abuse, the way attitudes have changed about drinking and driving. How do you make drug use socially unacceptable? We need to point out to the public, through education and prevention, more of the cost. Look at industry. Roger Smith, the chairman of General Motors, told his stockholders recently that $400 is added to the cost of each vehicle as a result of chemical dependency. Look at the costs of neonatal units across the country, where many of the babies were born with a drug dependency. And the costs of drug use are not just financial; they are personal, they are social and they are national.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Q. With so much money to be made dealing drugs, how do you get young people to care about these things?
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: A. We have to convince them that there's more to life than just financial rewards, and that's a difficult thing to accomplish. Many of the values of this country are predicated on dollars and finances, and now to turn around and say that that is not desirable is a very difficult message to send. But what we have to reinforce is the idea that the way to success and affluence is hard work and education and the rewards that they bring. Making money running drugs in the long term is not going to give you the happiness that each of us seeks in life.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Q. Are tougher laws needed?
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: A. I think the laws on the books are pretty strong, especially in New York. But we need to reinforce on the streets the message that illegal drug activity will be prosecuted and that those who are caught will have swift and certain punishment. But at the same time we need to do more treatment in our correction facilities.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Q. How will you measure your success at this job?
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: A. I hope to be able to say that we have found a less expensive and more available treatment program. Halfway houses are badly needed for treatment; one possibility is to put one on the Grasslands Reservation, in Valhalla, for former prisoners. I hope to be able to say that through education and prevention I have helped change public attitudes and helped to get the message out at schools.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: Since my appointment to the job, several people have come to me - and I try not to take myself too seriously - and said, ''you are the new drug czar, now we will know where to get drugs.'' I see that they're trying to be funny but, on the other hand, I don't think drugs is a funny topic. I see this as the country's most serious problem; many of us will joke because we don't really understand how damaging it is to our lives.
title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT M. MACCARONE;
Pulling the Strands Together on Drugs

text: The police were not at fault in the death of a man who fell from a Harlem rooftop while being chased by officers on a drug raid, said a grand jury that dismissed the case yesterday.
title: A Grand Jury Clears Officers in Fatal Fall

text: Trevor Francis, 30 years old, of 231 Edgecombe Avenue, died when he fell six stories from the roof of 157 Edgecombe Avenue as he fled from the police on May 31.
title: A Grand Jury Clears Officers in Fatal Fall

text: ''The dismissal indicates that the grand jury concluded that there was insufficient evidence to hold any officers criminally responsible for Francis's death,'' District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said in a statement.
title: A Grand Jury Clears Officers in Fatal Fall

text: The officers who chased Mr. Francis were part of a team from the Manhattan North Narcotics Unit that was executing a search warrant at 342 West 145th Street. They made several arrests and confiscated a quantity of marijuana and cocaine, the police said at the time.
title: A Grand Jury Clears Officers in Fatal Fall

text: Several people who claimed to have witnessed the rooftop chase said the police pushed Mr. Francis or failed to hold onto him as he tumbled over the edge of the building. (AP)
title: A Grand Jury Clears Officers in Fatal Fall

text: Cuba announced today that a firing squad had executed four Cuban Army officers convicted by court-martial of conspiring to ship tons of cocaine and marijuana to the United States.
title: Cuban General and Three Others Executed for Sending Drugs to U.S.

text: The four included Gen. Arnaldo T. Ochoa Sanchez, a highly decorated war hero who commanded Cuban combat troops in Ethiopia and Angola.
title: Cuban General and Three Others Executed for Sending Drugs to U.S.

text: The death sentences were imposed by a special military tribunal in Cuba's biggest scandal since Fidel Castro took power 30 years ago.
title: Cuban General and Three Others Executed for Sending Drugs to U.S.

text: Despite the executions, the United States said it was not certain if President Castro was serious about combating drug traffic. Richard A. Boucher, the deputy spokesman at the State Department, said the Bush Administration was not ready to accept Mr. Castro's proposal for a dialogue leading to cooperation in the war against drugs.
title: Cuban General and Three Others Executed for Sending Drugs to U.S.

text: ''You don't automatically start negotiating cooperation until you have an indication the other side is really serious, and that's what we're looking for,'' Mr. Boucher said. Representative Charles B. Rangel, the chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, said the Administration should accept Mr. Castro's offer and demand that he provide information on ships and planes carrying drugs through Cuba to Florida.
title: Cuban General and Three Others Executed for Sending Drugs to U.S.

text: ''It's time for the State Department to stop playing anti-Communist politics,'' said Mr. Rangel, a Manhattan Democrat. ''It's drugs, not Communists, that are killing our kids.'' American Charges Supported
title: Cuban General and Three Others Executed for Sending Drugs to U.S.

text: Testimony at the trial of General Ochoa and 13 co-defendants provided abundant new evidence to support longstanding American charges that Cuban officials were involved in drug smuggling. Mr. Castro had long denied such charges.
title: Cuban General and Three Others Executed for Sending Drugs to U.S.

text: Although many experts on Cuba say they believe the court-martial was a show trial staged for political reasons, the testimony supports American assertions that the Cuban authorities allowed the island to be used as a transit point for cocaine shipped to the United States from Colombia.
title: Cuban General and Three Others Executed for Sending Drugs to U.S.

text: The evidence dovetails with charges made over the last seven years in United States grand jury indictments. The indictments charge that a Cuban admiral was involved in drug trafficking, that smugglers' vessels were escorted out of Cuban waters by the Cuban Coast Guard and that Mr. Castro mediated a dispute between Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama and the Medellin drug cartel in Colombia.
title: Cuban General and Three Others Executed for Sending Drugs to U.S.

text: Ten of the 14 Cubans convicted by the military tribunal were sentenced to prison for terms ranging from 10 to 30 years. Those executed at dawn today, besides General Ochoa, were Col. Antonio de la Guardia Font, Maj. Amado Padron Trujillo and Capt. Jorge Martinez Valdes, the Cuban radio reported. 'To Protect Castro's Image'
title: Cuban General and Three Others Executed for Sending Drugs to U.S.

text: Ernesto Betancourt, director of Radio Marti, the United States Government station that broadcasts to Cuba, said a major purpose of the trial was ''to protect Castro's image from forthcoming revelations in U.S. courts about Castro-Medellin cartel links.''
title: Cuban General and Three Others Executed for Sending Drugs to U.S.

text: Mr. Castro insisted that the defendants were renegades acting without authorization from his Government. But evidence presented at the trial suggests that his brother, Defense Minister Raul Castro, may have been aware of the drug trafficking.
title: Cuban General and Three Others Executed for Sending Drugs to U.S.

text: It is difficult for the Government to dissociate itself from the scandal because General Ochoa and his colleagues said their activities had generated hard currency for the Cuban treasury and had been authorized by the Castro brothers.
title: Cuban General and Three Others Executed for Sending Drugs to U.S.

text: Cuban military officers testified that they sold diamonds, fish, sugar, rum and electronic equipment on the black market in Angola to obtain hard currency for Cuba. One witness, Lieut. Col. Arnaldo Morejon Plat, testified that General Ochoa had told him that such sales ''had been authorized'' by the Castro brothers.
title: Cuban General and Three Others Executed for Sending Drugs to U.S.

text: Jaime Suchlicki, director of the Institute of Inter-American Studies at the University of Miami, in Florida, said there were apparently two drug-smuggling operations - ''an official operation sanctioned by Fidel and Raul Castro and a second operation by Ochoa and small independent mafiosi.''
title: Cuban General and Three Others Executed for Sending Drugs to U.S.

text: Secret Service agents seized $1 million in counterfeit $100 bills on Tuesday and arrested a man they said had produced the bills using a photocopier. Richard Perez, 39 years old, could face up to 15 years in prison if convicted of counterfeiting, Agent Don Tucker said. Mr. Perez was arrested after trying to negotiate with an undercover agent to buy 500 pounds of marijuana with the counterfeit money, Mr. Tucker said.
title: Counterfeit Cache Is Seized

text: Detective William Pinho Sr., a 23-year veteran of the 320-member Elizabeth police force, says he hates to see his son and namesake leave the department, but he thinks that maybe it is not altogether a bad thing.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: ''We got a war going on in Elizabeth, a drug war,'' said Detective Pinho. ''We've had a shooting every night, one of our drug kingpins murdered on Tuesday, another one on Monday. It's got tough the last five years.'' But for William Pinho Jr., the prospect of the mean streets and the drug wars in Elizabeth was not the main reason - ''a little bit maybe'' - that he took the oath of office yesterday to join the 111-member force in green, suburban Parsippany-Troy Hills, where the last big drug bust was made by the mayor on his way to get a haircut on his lunch hour five years ago.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: ''I didn't have a job,'' said Officer Pinho, whose first duty after he tucked his brand new Parsippany badge in his pocket was filling out his new employment forms. ''I like what I see so far,'' he said. Officer Pinho was one of 67 members of the Elizabeth force laid off last April when city employees were caught in a budget crisis. The officers were told the layoffs would be temporary, and that they would be back on the job by August. But some were not so sure, and on Wednesday morning, Officer Pinho and four others raised their right hands in the Parsippany-Troy Hills Council chambers to become the newest members of the force.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: Most will continue to live in Elizabeth, at least for the time being - Parsippany-Troy Hills waived its residency requirements for the five new men - and several conceded they leave the Elizabeth force with some regret, albeit tinged with bitterness.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: ''All I ever wanted to do was be a police officer in Elizabeth,'' said Kevin Duffy, a boyish 26-year-old who said he had already seen as much of the seamy side in four years in Elizabeth as most suburban cops do in their entire careers.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: ''Then they turn around and slap us in the face,'' he said of Elizabeth. ''That's what motivated me to pursue this job.''
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: ''I don't want to go through that again,'' said Anthony Bonavitacola, 31, a former Elizabeth officer who made ends meet for his wife and four children during the layoff by returning to his former trade as an X-ray technician.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: ''They couldn't guarantee my job after six months in Elizabeth,'' he said. Parsippany-Troy Hills is ''financially stable, and I want to make a career here,'' he said.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: ''A cop's job is your life, it's not 9 to 5 and then forget it,'' Officer Bonavitacola said. ''It was very depressing, taking my badge away. Part of me was gone.'' According to Detective Pinho, whose job is secure and who would not think of leaving Elizabeth, about 25 of the 67 officers who were laid off have taken other jobs. Others are beginning to return to the Elizabeth force as the budget crisis is resolved.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: Meanwhile, Elizabeth's fiscal problems have proved a boon to departments in communities like Parsippany-Troy Hill, which, through no fault of their own, have been having recruiting prolems.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: ''We benefit from the misfortune of Elizabeth,'' said the Mayor of Parsippany-Troy Hills, Frank B. Priore.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: Last November, the Federal Justice Department challenged New Jersey's standard police screening test, maintaining that the physical test discriminated against women and the written test against minority applicants. Exceptionally high numbers in each category failed the tests.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: Since then, no state tests have been given, and many departments had exhausted their lists of tested recruits.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: Revised physical and written tests have been adopted, and the first new written test is scheduled for July 27. But Mayor Priore said at the swearing-in ceremony for the new officers yesterday that his community's new roster of tested recruits will not be ready until February.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: Meanwhile, the Mayor welcomed the new officers to a town that, he said, had a reassuringly low crime rate.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: The last major drug arrest, in fact, occurred Sept. 7, 1983. Mayor Priore himself, on his way to get a haircut, noticed a car making an illegal U-turn on Route 46.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: The Mayor, who is prone to stopping errant motorists, waved the car down. Dressing down the driver, he noticed some seeds on the floor of the car, and a search unearthed 50 pounds of marijuana. The driver and a companion went to prison.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: ''I had to show the police how to do it,'' the Mayor said.
title: Our Towns; Suburbs Beckon Officers Spurned By a City's Crisis

text: INTERNATIONAL A2-7 A temporary U.S. loan to Mexico of between $1 billion and $2 billion will be granted, the Bush Administration said. The loan is contingent on an agreement between Mexico and its foreign banks on reducing debt. Page A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: World leaders gathered in Paris for their 15th annual economic summit meeting, and fell at once to arguing over how far they should go in condemning China for crushing student-led protests. A6
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: In Paris, a week of ceremony opened, with Francois Mitterrand presiding, to mark the bicentennial of the French Revolution. The tight security measures appeared to have dampened the mood in the city. A7
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Gen. Jaruzelski appealed for aid by asking the major non-Communist industrial powers for a two-year, multibillion-dollar rescue program, warning that Poland's economic crisis poses a major threat. A6
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The changes in Eastern Europe are ''absolutely amazing,'' President Bush said, reflecting on his five-day trip to Poland and Hungary. He credited the Soviet Union with making those reforms possible. 6
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: As Roman Catholic divisions deepen, dissident theologians across Western Europe have begun openly challenging the conservative teachings and leadership of Pope John Paul II. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Four Cuban officers were executed by a firing squad. They were convicted by court martial of conspiring to ship tons of cocaine and marijuana to the United States. A3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: News analysis: President Botha's gesture toward Nelson Mandela seems to be rooted in the rivalry between President Botha and F. W. de Klerk, his successor as National Party leader. A3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The new Sudanese military leader has sent conflicting signals about whether and how he intends to resolve the civil war that has brought famine to the southern Sudan. A2
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Honda Motor Company will purchase a 20 percent stake in the Rover Group P.L.C., the British car making subsidiary of British Aerospace P.L.C., and build a plant in England. D1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: NATIONAL A10, B5-8 The ban on importing assault rifles has created a bonanza for some small and medium-sized gun manufacturers in the United States that is driven by fear. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Electronics experts were arrested on charges of links to Irish Republican Army terrorists whom they were said to have supplied with devices for detonating bombs and anti-helicopter rockets, the F.B.I. said. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A group of senior housing officials, who obtained more than $130 million in renovation contracts as developers after leaving the Government, has emerged as a case study of grants during the Reagan years. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A small plane on automatic controls raced down the East Coast for a thousand miles as military jets and rescue craft scrambled in pursuit. The plane ran out of fuel and crashed off the Bahamas. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: An overhaul of U.S. immigration was approved by the Senate that would guarantee more visas for skilled workers with no family ties in America and that aims to increase immigration from Western Europe. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The N.A.A.C.P. hailed Jesse Jackson, who has long struggled to gain acceptance among mainline civil rights groups. The group decided to give Mr. Jackson its highest honor, the Spingarn award. A10
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The surtax that older Americans pay to insure against prolonged illness costs should be reduced, the Democratic majority on the House Ways and Means Committee agreed. B5
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A highly addictive mixture of crack and smokable heroin is emerging as the new drug of choice among some of New York City's nearly one million chronic drug abusers, city and state drug-treatment officials say. The combination threatens to addict a new generation on heroin, which was recently believed to be waning in popularity.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: The mixture is considered particularly dangerous, experts said, because it combines the physical addiction of heroin with the intense high of crack.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: ''This could easily be the worst news to the drug-abuse-control community since the emergence of crack in the early 1980's,'' said Mark A. R. Kleiman, a lecturer in public policy at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government. A Longer High
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: A recent survey by a New York City treatment program found that 37 percent of nearly 100 drug abusers said they had tried the mixture. It is called a variety of names, including ''crank'' and ''speedball,'' though it bears little resemblance to street drugs that have similar names but are used differently.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: Speedball usually refers to the intravenous injection of cocaine and heroin. The new mixture of crack and heroin is smoked in a pipe.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: The smokable heroin lengthens the crack high and reduces the intensity of the depression that follows it, said Joyce Hartwell, executive director of the Recovery Hot Line and Addiction Anonymous Education Project in New York City.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: ''It is not at all surprising that heroin is making a comeback,'' said Dr. Mitchell S. Rosenthal, president of Phoenix House, which operates 10 drug-treatment centers in New York and California. ''We've been expecting something like this for the past three years.'' $10 a Dose ''Crack users need some way to come down from that racing high,'' he said, ''and it was inevitable for a large number to eventually turn to heroin. But we didn't expect to see so much so quickly.''
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: The drug combination is sometimes sold premixed, users said, and generally costs about $10 a dose, roughly twice as much as a dose of crack. While it has not been found outside New York City, drug-enforcement officials say, it is likely to appear in other large cities where crack and heroin are already widely available.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: Ms. Hartwell and other experts said they fear that smoking heroin in any combination will appeal to young drug abusers who have historically been reluctant to use hypodermic needles and other paraphernalia associated with heroin. That aversion has been heightened in recent years, said Mr. Hartwell, as the link between intravenous drug use and AIDS has become better known among drug abusers.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: Some treatment specialists said crack users who think heroin enables them to control their high might be less willing to seek treatment. Less Than a Year
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: In a survey completed Tuesday, Phoenix House officials asked the last 97 drug abusers entering a long-term treatment program whether they had used the crack-heroin mixture.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: Thirty-seven percent said they had, said Chris Policano, a Phoenix House spokesman. In all cases, the drug abusers had been mixing the drugs for less than a year, Mr. Policano said.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: ''They are telling us things like, 'Heroin saved my life. It slowed me down from crack.' '' he said. ''But the truth is that they are dysfunctional, a whole population chronically intoxicated.''
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: And unlike intravenous heroin, which is mostly used by men, smokable heroin, like crack, is being used by as many women as men, the Phoenix House survey suggests.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: Since the early 1970's, the number of heroin addicts in New York State has remained at about 250,000, state figures show; most of them are in New York City. The average addict is male and in his 30's. In contrast, crack users are usually in their teens and early 20's, treatment experts said. Quest for Best Highs
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: A primary fear is that crack users who smoke the crack-heroin combination will become addicted. Eventually, the addict would probably turn from smoking heroin to injecting it, said Dr. Stanley Yancovitz, chief of the chemical dependency division of the Beth Israel Medical Center.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: William Hopkins, who studies drug trends for the New York State Division of Substance Abuse Services, said mixing heroin and crack is a natural consequence of addicts' near-constant experimentation to get the best highs.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: ''Now they are taking the worst of both,'' Mr. Hopkins said.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: Drug experts said a reason for the mixture's popularity is the nature of the high from crack, which is a stimulant. The high is brief, from 8 to 10 minutes, and extremely intense. Some crack users refer to the high as all the pleasurable feelings they have ever had crammed into a few minutes. But once the high abates, users say, they become jittery and depressed. Escape the 'Crash'
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: Heroin, a sedative, produces a high that may last as long as four hours.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: To escape the depression or ''crash,'' crack addicts are turning to a range of sedatives including marijuana, alcohol and heroin, said Mr. Hopkins.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: Smoking heroin, which is how it is ingested in much of the world outside of the United States and Europe, has only recently became economically practical in New York as heroin has become more abundant and pure, he said.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: Bob Strang, a spokesman of the New York City office of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, said the quality of heroin in the city went from 12 percent pure to 45 percent in the last three years.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: ''And the price has remained stable as the supply has remained up,'' he said.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: Lisa, a 28-year-old former crack addict enrolled in a Harlem drug-treatment center, said it was not usual to see people ''chasing the dragon,'' an old term newly applied to smoking heroin with crack.
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: ''Crack hypes you up,'' she said. ''The heroin gives you a calm, drowsy high.''
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: ''A lot of people,'' Lisa said, ''are chasing the dragon now.''
title: Potent Crack Blend on the Streets Lures a New Generation to Heroin

text: LEAD: Vanderbilt Avenue, a five-block strip flanked by gilded office buildings, the Yale Club, two banks and a large hotel, has become a thriving enclave for drug dealers selling marijuana to workers in the midtown Manhattan neighborhood.
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: Vanderbilt Avenue, a five-block strip flanked by gilded office buildings, the Yale Club, two banks and a large hotel, has become a thriving enclave for drug dealers selling marijuana to workers in the midtown Manhattan neighborhood.
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: On weekdays during the lunch and evening rush hours, the police, security guards and merchants say, at least a dozen marijuana dealers occupy the avenue, which borders Grand Central Terminal on the west and stretches from 42d to 47th Streets.
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: ''We're talking about an area where most of the buyers are white-collar office people wearing suits and carrying briefcases,'' said Capt. William Allee, an executive officer for the Midtown South Precinct and a veteran narcotics officer.
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: As law-enforcement officials focus their efforts on stronger drugs like crack and heroin, marijuana has become a low priority, carving a safe niche for itself on Vanderbilt Avenue and other streets in New York City, the police, prosecutors and judges say.Back in Two Hours
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: ''We used to call 911 15 times a day, but the police never did a thing,'' said Marc Angel, the vice president of Times Circle East, a stationery store at Vanderbilt and 45th Street. Four to five people sell marijuana in front of his store almost every day, he said.
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: ''And whenever they make arrests, the dealers are back on the street two hours later,'' he added. ''The fact is marijuana has become decriminalized - it's a thing of the past.''
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: Under New York law, the sale of marijuana is a misdemeanor that carries a maximum sentence of a year in jail upon conviction, which is usually suspended for first offenders, a spokesman for the Manhattan District Attorney's office, Gerald McKelvey, said.
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: An undercover narcotics sergeant in the Midtown South Precinct said complaints about drug dealing on Vanderbilt have doubled this year. In 1988, the unit received 16 complaints and made 24 arrests. So far this year, it has received 29 complaints and made 28 arrests, he said.Private Security Force
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: Merchants on Vanderbilt say they have been forced to attack the problem virtually by themselves. Grand Central Partnership, an association of businesses and landowners near the terminal, hired a 20-member security squad in December.
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: The squad has used plainclothes guards to videotape drug deals, sent photos to the police and even followed dealers to find out where they lived. At least one uniformed guard patrols the avenue every weekday from 8 A.M. to midnight, carrying a radio to report drug deals to the police via the partnership's security office.
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: Marijuana dealing became a problem on the avenue about three years ago and worsened significantly as crack became common on New York City streets, Captain Allee said.
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: Although the police do not post an officer on the avenue, they average two or three arrests there a week, he said. Buyers are rarely arrested, he added, because it is difficult to apprehend them at the same time as the dealers.
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: The police and guards on the street say the dealers are semiorganized and friendly with one another.
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: ''There's a day crew and a night crew and they're usually the same faces every day,'' said Demetri Kazik, a security guard for the partnership. He said the first group usually works from 11:30 A.M. to 1:30 P.M and the next from 3:30 P.M. to 6 P.M. Fridays are usually the busiest, he said.
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: The police do not think that the dealers, who are mainly in their 20's and 30's, are armed. They usually work the avenue in pairs, openly displaying small plastic pouches of marijuana, which they sell for $10 to $20 each.
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: The police and merchants say it has become routine for many commuters to buy drugs on their way to and from Grand Central.
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: ''I don't see why they can't just go home and suck down a martini instead of lighting up a joint on their way home,'' said a security guard working outside the Pan Am building at 45th Street and Vanderbilt. ''It's a disgrace and it's only getting worse.''
title: Big Business In Marijuana On Vanderbilt

text: Seventy police in riot gear and more than 200 protesters skirmished over a line of symbolic tents in Tompkins Square Park last night, as demonstrators repeatedly pitched sheets of plastic over branches and wires and the police moved in to tear them down.
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: As of 11:30 P.M., four protesters had been arrested. One was charged with assaulting and robbing a police officer, one with playing a radio without a license and two others with disorderly conduct. Two other people were arrested in the park on charges of possessing fireworks and brass knuckles, but it was unclear whether they were involved in the protest.
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: The tents were meant to recall a shantytown the police and parks department workers tore down on Wednesday night. City officials said the shanties, prohibited under park rules, had taken over what should be public space. The protesters maintain that the approximately 200 homeless people living in the park have no where else to sleep, and that the raid on the shantytown was a thinly veiled attempt to drive homeless people away from a neighborhood that is becoming more affluent.
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: The pitching and destruction of the tents was repeated several times through the evening. Police officers repeatedly pushed through the mass of chanting protesters, cut support wires, removed the tents and put out bonfires. As soon as police retreated, the protestors promptly restarted a bonfire and pitched more tents. Rally Begins Protest
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: The protest began at 1:30 P.M. with a rally, which consisted principally of several homeless residents speaking against Mayor Edward I. Koch and the Parks Commissioner, Henry J. Stern, whom they want to remove regulations prohibiting shelters and tents.
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: The police said that the shantytown had grown from six lean-tos three weeks ago to more than 35 and that the population had grown to more than 200.
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: The demonstrators erected the first two tents at 5 P.M. yesterday in the northwest corner, which were removed an hour later by parks enforcement patrol officers as about 70 police in riot gear looked on. One woman, Eva Unhold, 29 years old, of 539 East 13 Street, was arrested for disorderly conduct.
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: Within an hour, another tent had appeared nearby. At 8:45 P.M., the police swept through the crowd of protesters and cut down six tents.
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: A second protester, George P. Rossovich, 35 years old, of 506 East 5th Street, was arrested at 10:30 after he allegedly hit a plainclothes police officer taking pictures of the protest over the head and robbed him of his baseball cap, the police said. A Visible Police Presence
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: Earlier in the day, several community advocates and religious leaders were at the protest. Ronald L. Kuby, a lawyer with the Center for Constitutional Rights, said, ''They are stopping the homeless from living.''
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: Police patrol cars and vans lined 10th Street between Avenues B and C. Sanitation trucks also parked nearby in case the homeless tried to rebuild the tent city.
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: After the rally yesterday, the demonstrators also marched behind a tie-dyed banner to the Ninth Precinct station house on Fifth Street. They yelled, ''Housing - not condos'' as they passed the Christadora House apartment building next to the park.
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: The building has come to symbolize the long-running tensions in the neighborhood between newer, affluent residents and a loose coalition of the homeless, artists, squatters and others opposed to gentrification of the area. Strollers and Sunbathers
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: Last year, the tension helped spark a 12-hour melee when police officers tried to enforce a 1 A.M. park curfew. That incident led to 121 complaints of police brutality, most of which were dropped because of a lack of evidence and the unwillingness of officers to testify against colleagues.
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: The heightened police presence yesterday follows the arrest of 31 people on Wednesday after the police and park officials tore down the shanties. The police were pelted with eggs and bottles as they hauled away the possessions of the homeless, and fireworks were set off under several cars.
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: Throughout the day yesterday, though, the park was peaceful. People played basketball, mothers pushed children in strollers and teenagers smoked marijuana and sunned themselves on the grass. Several of the homeless dozed on benches, and others wandered about.
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: At the rally, the homeless gathered around an old amplifier and loudspeaker carried by one demonstrator. One by one, they hopped on a park bench and derided the presence of the police. ''They haven't even said why they want to kick us out,'' said Ziggy Boden, 25, who said he had lived in the park for six months.
title: 4 Held in Tompkins Sq. Skirmish at Symbolic Tents

text: DESPITE promises this year from Governor Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor Edward I. Koch to provide significantly more treatment slots to addicts who need them, New York state's drug treatment system remains overloaded and under financed, its officials say.
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: Announcements by politicians notwithstanding, the number of openings available to treat addicts has not changed significantly in 10 years, even with the explosion in crack and new concerns about the role of drug addiction and the spread of AIDS.
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: Caught in a web of mounting needs fueled mostly by crack's pandemic, the state's drug treatment apparatus is dogged by persistent neighborhood resistance to new drug programs. And with dwindling dollars in the state budget and a weakening Federal commitment to drug treatment, the system - and the addicts it seeks to serve - find themselves in crisis.
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: The state last year estimated that 879,800 New Yorkers are heavy users of illicit drugs, not including a sizable group that uses only marijuana.
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: In contrast, the state offers fewer than 50,000 treatment slots to those seeking help in breaking their addictions. Most of those, like the drug abusers themselves, are in New York City and have chronically operated at just over 100 percent of their capacity. The result has been ever-lengthening waiting lists and estimates of tens of thousands of addicts who no longer seek help because they realize help is largely unavailable.
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: ''There hasn't been a new methadone treatment center built in New York City in 10 years,'' Charles LaPorte, a deputy director of the State Division of Substance Abuse Services, said recently. ''Community pressure is tremendous.''
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: In the face of great opposition from area residents, however, a new drug treatment center for paroled criminals is preparing to open in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn next month. Another, the first on Staten Island, is scheduled to open by early next year. Yet they will not significantly dent the problem.
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: ''We have a system that is completely filled,'' said Gerard M. Armstrong, a deputy director of the state's substance abuse services. ''We have waiting lists of people who want treatment and need treatment, but can't get treatment because the system is overwhelmed.''
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: Dr. Robert G. Newman, president of New York City's Beth Israel Medical Center, which operates the largest methadone maintenance treatment program in the United States, said some 20,000 to 50,000 addicts would almost immediately seek treatment if they were convinced that it was available.
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: Indeed, more than 2,300 addicts are awaiting treatment in the state's residential drug-free programs; another 660 are waiting to enroll into a methadone program, according to statistics compiled by the state in May. Addicts Turned Away
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: Hector Maldonado, a counselor for Beth Israel's interim methadone clinic in Harlem, said he watched a chronic heroin addict walk into his clinic out of a pouring rain recently and beg for treatment.
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: ''I unfortunately had to tell him that there were no treatment slots available,'' said Mr. Maldonado, a 21-year veteran of drug treatment programs. ''It was painful to have to see an individual, sick as a dog and soaking wet, sent back into the streets.''
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: In May, the Koch administration announced that it was going to abandon its policy of not directly paying for city drug treatment programs. Since the city's fiscal crisis of the 1970's, the state had the sole responsibility to provide drug treatment.
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: Mayor Koch's five-year plan proposes to create 21,000 new treatment slots at a cost to the city of $448 million. But the plan is predicated on contributions of $633 million from the state and $125 million from the Federal Government, far exceeding past spending limits for drug treatment programs.
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: So far Federal officials have been mum about the Mayor's new plan. Some drug treatment specialists said privately that they view Mr. Koch's plan with the same skepticism as they view the Governor's recent call to add some 5,000 treatment slots to the state's 48,542 slots, many of those in state prisons.
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: ''I think what is missing is commitment,'' said Beth Israel's Dr. Newman. ''That has to come from the Federal Government.''
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: But for the last decade, the Federal contribution to drug treatment has lagged far behind the state.
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: For example, in 1979-80 the state allocated $56.5 million to drug treatment while Federal dollars totaled $19.2. In the current fiscal year the state has earmarked $146.8 million plus an $18.3 million capital fund. The Federal Government, whose fiscal year begins in October, is likely to allocate $44.7 million.
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: ''The Federal Government has to do much more,'' said Dr. Newman. ''I think the problem is too big to be handled by any one community.''
title: Treatment For Addicts Is as Elusive As Ever

text: DEJA VU is common among skiers who go scuba diving in the Caribbean: Despite the warmth, there is something oddly familiar about that first plunge into the blue-green water. Most will tell you that few things compare with the exhilaration of an early morning run through fresh-fallen powder; but one of them is the thrill of soaring, weightless and silent, over a coral reef alive with fish.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: There are other similarities. Scuba diving tends to attract people of widely differing skills and tastes. Often, those just learning the sport settle for lesser experiences - uninteresting reefs and marginal water visibility, for instance - in return for comfort and a sense of security.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: Determined veterans, on the other hand, will put up with just about anything - long boat rides, hard bunk beds and terrible food, to name a few possibilities - for the opportunity of diving a seldom-visited coral wall, or of swimming goggle-eyed past a school of pelagic sharks. It all depends on your enthusiasms, your daring and your inclination to rough it, not to mention your wanderlust - there are almost as many resorts that offer competent scuba diving and instruction as there are islands in the Caribbean.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: At one pole is Grand Cayman Island, which has emerged in recent years as the scuba divers' answer to Aspen. Part of a British colony 500 miles south of Miami, Grand Cayman has scores of spectacular dive sites that begin in shallows accessible to any novice, along with first-class hotels, a variety of restaurants, and pulsating night life. It is nirvana for casual beginners and snorkelers alike, and very pleasant for those looking for a simple beach vacation.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: Bonaire, 35 miles off the coast of Venezuela, is something else again. A tiny coral atoll in the Netherlands Antilles, it has long been a magnet for people who want to do little but dive - even at night, when the reefs take on a whole new identity under hand-held lights. There are, to be sure, places to go and things to do on Bonaire - but its chief draws remain its year-round perfect weather, crystalline water and coral walls, which are among the most unspoiled in the Caribbean.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: For novices, the quality of instruction should be a paramount consideration in deciding where to go. Scuba diving is a safe sport, but it is not for the absent-minded. Carelessness can kill you, a theme instructors like to drum into their first-time students. It usually catches their attention.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: Most of the major dive resorts around the Caribbean offer classes in scuba diving, and most are accredited by the major American teaching organizations, either the Professional Association of Diving Instructors (commonly called Padi), or N.A.U.I., the National Association of Underwater Instructors. While the better resorts generally offer strict, no-nonsense instruction, some diving teachers, through sheer dint of personality, inspire more confidence in novices than others. Finding the right one is often a matter of chance, helped along by intuition.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: Instruction ranges from so-called resort courses, which teach basics, to full-scale ''open water'' regimens, which lead to full certification. Open-water instruction combines classroom and underwater lessons in such matters as diving physiology, equipment handling, life saving, navigation and marine biology.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: One can dive without being certified, but certification documents -more familiarly known as C cards - bestow a certain measure of freedom. Once bearers convince the presiding dive master of their skills - a gantlet that must be run at every dive resort - they're usually allowed to dive without the close supervision automatically given those without certification. They can also purchase breathing equipment and refills for air tanks, a privilege ordinarily denied noncertified customers.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: The resort course usually involves an afternoon, much of it commonly in a swimming pool; the open-water course takes closer to a full week to complete. (Many people save time by taking the classroom end of the open-water course at home, at a more leisurely pace, then complete the underwater segment on vacation.) One increasingly popular option among intermediate and advanced divers is to find a live-aboard, a dive boat that visits out-of-the-way spots on voyages that last a week or more.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: Other elements to consider are water clarity and temperature. Since these are usually a function of the season and the weather, it's best to check carefully before you make reservations. Ordinarily, summer and fall are the best seasons everywhere in the Caribbean, barring hurricanes.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: Another consideration is the condition of the reefs. Coral, the limestone formations produced by colonies of tiny marine organisms, is easily damaged, and the cumulative effects of being touched and accidentally brushed by passing divers can be devastating. Some resorts and Caribbean governments have instituted strict controls on anchoring practices and the number of divers that may visit reefs at a time. At some of the more popular spots, such as in parts of the Florida Keys and around Grand Cayman Island, the reefs are bruised and dying from too many visitors.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: Often the best way to gather information is to contact one of the many travel agencies that specialize in dive vacations and tell them exactly what you are looking for. Another is to look through the monthly Skin Diver magazine, or Undercurrent, a monthly newsletter out of Sausalito, Calif., that carries unvarnished resort reviews and no advertising.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: Here are thumbnail sketches of some representative diving regions of the Caribbean and Atlantic, in alphabetical order. Bahamas
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: The proximity of the Bahamas make them an easy spot to visit for divers traveling on short notice and low budgets. The islands also offer a vast choice of sites, from small resorts that offer personalized attention to larger hotels that cater to crowds. The quality of the reefs varies as well, although they are widely regarded among experienced dive travelers as good, but not among the best. Water conditions are ideal during the summer months, when it is ordinarily warm enough to dive without a wet suit.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: In Freeport, for example, the Underwater Explorers Society (Post Office Box 5608, Fort Lauderdale, Fla. 33310; 800-992-3483) offers an eight-day, seven-night package for $690 a person with two to a room ($1,082 a person), which includes 13 dives plus accommodations at the Lucaya Beach Resort and Casino. For those not using the package, on three-dive boat trips, each dive costs $29. On Bimini, Bill and Nowdla Keefe's Bimini Undersea Adventures (Post Office Box 21766, Fort Lauderdale, Fla. 33335; 800-327-8150) offers eight-day, seven-night packages beginning at $644 a person, $883 including meals. The prices include hotel, round-trip airfare to Bimini from Miami or Fort Lauderdale, 18 dives, weight and tank rental and all taxes, transfers and tips. Belize
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: For years, this independent Commonwealth nation, formerly British Honduras, was one of the Caribbean's most exotic destinations. It is still exotic, but its growing popularity - and that of sport diving generally - has made it increasingly less out-of-the-way. Besides Mayan ruins, jaguars, tapirs, reggae bands and what authorities concede is a thriving marijuana-growing industry, Belize also has the largest barrier reef in the hemisphere, second in size only to Australia's. It is home to a vast population of huge marine creatures - eagle rays, deep-water sharks, barracuda - rarely seen with the same frequency elsewhere in the Caribbean. They tend to mind their own business unless harassed, but the thrill of spotting them is a major reason many people dive. Most of Belize's dive resorts are on small islands (or cays, as they are called) accessible by boat or small plane from Belize City's tiny international airport. They run from Ambergris Cay, whose hotels cater to large numbers of novices and nondiving tourists, to smaller operations in outlying cayes that tend to cater exclusively to divers.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: These include such places as St. George's Lodge (Post Office Box 625, Belize City, Belize; 800-678-6871), on St. George's Cay, where nightly rates start at $145 a diver in the lodge, double occupancy; $160 in the cottages.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: The price includes two dives and three meals a day, ground transportation from the airport and the rental cost of tanks and weights. At the Turneffe Island Lodge (Post Office Box 480, Belize City, Belize; 800-338-8149), on Cay Bokel, an atoll 30 miles to the southeast of Belize City, six-day, seven-nightpackages cost $850 a person in double occupancy. The price includes two dives a day, lodging, meals, taxes, transfers and transportation between the island and the Belize City airport. Bonaire
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: Apart from its exceptionally clear water - because there is very little topsoil left for rains to wash into the sea - this 112-square-mile desert island, not far from Curacao and Aruba, is loved among divers for its informality and for residents' dedication to preserving the reef. That dedication is not surprising, considering the fact that diving is the backbone of the island economy.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: Beginners and intermediate divers brushing up on half-forgotten skills can get personalized attention at many of the resorts. But those who want to strike out on their own can arrange to forgo organized boat trips and drive around, unescorted, to the scores of reef sites that are accessible from the beach.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: Divi Flamingo Beach Resort and Casino (central reservations: 54 Gunderman Road, Ithaca, N.Y. 14850; 800-333-3484), for example, offers a eight-day, seven-night package for $664 a person in double occupancy that includes two boat dives a day, unlimited air for shore dives and accommodations, transfer from airport, tax and service charge. Sand Dollar Dive and Photo (Travel Barn, 52 Georgetown Road, Bordentown, N.J. 08505; 800-345-0805) offers a six-day diving-only package for $250 a person, plus a 10 percent service charge, that includes unlimited shore and boat dives. Accommodations are available at its condominium complex, where studio apartments are $125 a night and one-bedroom apartments are $155 a night. There is a $10 a day charge for maid service in these units. Cayman Islands
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: Aside from Grand Cayman, there are two other islands in this archipelago first discovered by Columbus in 1503 - Cayman Brac and Little Cayman, 74 and 89 miles from Grand Cayman, respectively. All offer spectacular sights for divers. The outer islands are popular with live-aboard visitors, although there are resorts on both. Grand Cayman, probably the most heavily visited dive spot in the hemisphere, is a good choice for beginners because many of the most popular sites are in relatively shallow water, 50 feet or less. Fish life abounds - one reef is home to so many tame queen angelfish, groupers and yellowtail snappers that it is officially known as the Aquarium. There are also several shipwrecks worth exploring, one of them in a harbor where divers can wave to tourists passing above in glass-bottomed boats. For more experienced divers, Grand Cayman's so-called north wall offers stunning vistas just past the 100-foot level.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: Don Foster's Divi Grand Cayman, for example (Scuba Tours, Post Office Box 366, Little Falls, N.J. 07424; 800-526-1394), offers eight-day, seven-night packages for $664 a person in double occupancy that include roundtrip airfare (midweek travel) from Miami or Tampa, accommodations at the Grand Pavilion hotel, two dives a day for six days and unlimited air for shore dives. On Cayman Brac, Peter Hughes's Divi Tiara (54 Gunderman Road, Ithaca. N.Y. 14850; 800-333-3484) offers eight-day, seven-night packages - six days of two dives a day, hotel, weights and tanks - for prices that start at $632 a person, plus a 10 percent service charge. Airfare to the island is not included. Florida
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: There are more than 50 dive-boat operations in the Florida Keys, a 150-mile stretch of coastal waters sweeping south to Key West. The most popular destination by far is Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park, an underwater wildlife sanctuary off Key Largo. The park, little more than an hour's drive from Miami, is home to one of the last unsullied reef habitats in South Florida. There are many varieties of coral, most of it healthy, and plenty of friendly, inquisitive fish. The waters are shallow, mostly 25 to 30 feet (40 feet is a deep dive in the Keys) - and water visibility is generally good in the summer, except immediately after storms.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: Outside the park, the reefs have not fared as well; there are areas of broken and dying coral, and spearfishing has taken a toll on the larger fish. But there are still some relatively pristine areas to see. For beginners and out-of-practice divers, the larger dive boats - many of which carry more than 30 people - are popular; the more experienced may prefer one of the smaller craft, which carry a maximum of six divers.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: There is no shortage of motels in the region, as well as spots that accommodate campers. In Key Largo, Capt. Slate's Atlantis Dive Center (51 Garden Cove Drive, Key Largo, Fla. 33037; 800-331-3483 or 305-451-3020), one of the bigger operations offering trips to Pennekamp Park, charges $30 a dive for two-dive trips; packages that include two dives a day plus accommodations at the Howard Johnson Motor Lodge in Key Largo cost $71 a person per day, with a three-day minimum. Those who check in on a Sunday and stay four days get a fifth night free. Farther south, in Islamorada, the Reef Shop (84771 Overseas Highway, Islamorada, Fla. 33036; 305-664-4385), one of the smaller-boat operators, offers two-dive boat trips for $35; accommodations, at the Ocean 80 Resort, begin at $60 a day, with efficiency apartments available, at the Seven Seas Condominiums, for $350 a week. U.S. Virgin Islands
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: The waters around St. Thomas and St. Croix lack the dazzling variety of reef life and the year-round clarity of the premier dive locations of the Caribbean, but the less jaded will still find plenty to see. Off St. Thomas, for example, there are a number of easily accessible shipwrecks, including the much photographed Cartanser Sr., a 190-foot vessel in 50 feet of water. Another spot, a favorite for shallow night dives, boasts a colony of stingrays and spotted eels that have become so accustomed to humans that they can be petted. Night dives at the same locale, Coki Beach, are often marked by the arrival of a school of huge tarpons drawn by the divers' lights. St. Croix has its own assortment of sunken ships, known collectively as the Butler Bay wrecks, and there are also some excellent wall dives.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: On St. Thomas, the Bolongo Bay Beach and Tennis Club (Post Office Box 7337, St. Thomas, United States Virgin Islands 00801; 800-524-4746), near Charlotte Amalie, offers a 10-dive summer package -eight days, seven nights - starting at $740 a person, in double occupancy including accommodations and the rental of weights and tank. Single dives are $45 each. On St. Croix, V.I. Divers Ltd. in Christiansted (Pan Am Pavilion, Christiansted, St. Croix, United States Virgin Islands 00820; 800-544-5911) offers 10 dives in an eight-day, seven-night package for $469 a person, double occupancy at the Hotel Caravelle. The price includes unlimited air for beach dives, weights and tank rental. Single-tank dives from a boat are $40 each, or $55 for a two-tank trip.
title: A Guide to Exploring the World Under

text: By James Feron, Special To the New York Times
title: Student Charged in Strangling of a Schoolgirl

text: A 19-year-old student at the Hawthorne Cedar Knolls School in central Westchester, a residential treatment center for emotionally disturbed boys and girls, was charged with second-degree murder today in the strangulation of a 15-year-old student.
title: Student Charged in Strangling of a Schoolgirl

text: Chief Paul Oliva of the Mount Pleasant Police Department said the body of the girl, Ann Marie Sullivan, was found Tuesday in the gymnasium. ''Apparently they had both entered the weight room, socialized by sharing some marijuana and engaged in sex, and then argued over her wanting more marijuana and his refusing to give it to her,'' he said.
title: Student Charged in Strangling of a Schoolgirl

text: The suspect, Ronald Appling, ''made a voluntary admission,'' Chief Oliva reported, and ''said he used a pair of trousers in the room to wrap around her neck and squeeze until she was limp.''
title: Student Charged in Strangling of a Schoolgirl

text: Both students came from Staten Island but did not know each other there, Chief Oliva said. 'A Terrible State of Shock'
title: Student Charged in Strangling of a Schoolgirl

text: Jane Linker, a spokeswoman for the school, which has been operated by the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services for 80 years, said ''the kids are very disturbed, and everyone is in a terrible state of shock because nothing like this has ever happened here.''
title: Student Charged in Strangling of a Schoolgirl

text: The school has 165 students, about 40 of them girls, she said, and provides ''an open setting for children between the ages of 8 and 22 who cannot remain at home or in regular schools.''
title: Student Charged in Strangling of a Schoolgirl

text: Chief Oliva said the slain girl had been at the school for five months and the suspect for about one year.
title: Student Charged in Strangling of a Schoolgirl

text: Ms. Linker said the average student stayed 10 years. ''We have an open setting - the kids live in cottages and are not locked in - with some coming from private referrals, some from social service agencies and some from the courts,'' she said. ''They attend classes together, like at a boarding school.''
title: Student Charged in Strangling of a Schoolgirl

text: Chief Oliva, who has been with the Mount Pleasant police force for 38 years, said, ''I don't recall any homicides at Cedar Knolls, although there have been occasional runaways and some burglaries and assaults and cases of arson, but we have had a good relationship with the staff in dealing with any problems.''
title: Student Charged in Strangling of a Schoolgirl

text: LEAD: AT sunset on a warm Saturday not long ago the streets of Wyckoff were abuzz with activity as more than 2,000 residents - young and old -gathered for the last day of the Lions Club's annual spring carnival. They played games of skill, lined up for the merry-go-round and other amusements and whiled away a few hours with friends.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: AT sunset on a warm Saturday not long ago the streets of Wyckoff were abuzz with activity as more than 2,000 residents - young and old -gathered for the last day of the Lions Club's annual spring carnival. They played games of skill, lined up for the merry-go-round and other amusements and whiled away a few hours with friends.
