title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: The carnival is but one demonstration of the strong sense of community in this Bergen County suburb nestled within the foothills of the Ramapo Mountains. Neighbors know one another well because many are longtime residents. And newcomers can form ties easily through more than 40 social and civic organizations and 13 churches and a synagogue.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: Winding roads, tall, leafy trees and broad lawns make a distinct semi-rural impression on first-time visitors to the residential neighborhoods that make up most of Wyckoff's 6.7 square miles.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: There are a half dozen ponds and lakes, and the rural image is buttressed by Alba's Farm and Russell Orchard, both of which have stores selling their seasonal produce.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: ''Neighbors watch out for one another,'' said Aimee McLean, a four-year resident whose husband, Stephen, is managing director at Merrill Lynch Capital Partners in Manhattan. ''I don't have to worry when my children are playing out in front of the house.''
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: ''Living here,'' she added, ''is like having a summer home that you can commute to all year round.''
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: The community has the best of two worlds: It resembles a country hamlet, but it is linked by mass-transit lines and major highways to Manhattan and to other parts of New Jersey. This is a boon for residents, most of whom commute to jobs.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: Beyond going to work, they say, there is little reason for them to leave, for the township has its own weekly newspaper, The Wyckoff News, two supermarkets and light industries as well as retail centers with boutiques and service shops.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: To enhance its commercial base the Township Committee passed an ordinace a few years ago allowing large old dwellings in ''the triangle,'' its main shopping district, to be converted to retail space on the ground floor with apartments on the upper stories.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: Over time, the sidewalks in the 10-block area - borderd by Franklin, Wyckoff and Godwin Avenues - will be paved with brick to give it a colonial look, said Gordon Stanley, a committeeman.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: The price for serenity and convenience has been relatively high property taxes, which rose last year from $1.73 per $100 of assessed valuation to $1.94 to defray an increase in garbage-dumping costs - although schools are the major contributor to the tax rate.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: Most residents say they get value for their money, but some still voice concern over the cost of the proposed school reorganization.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: THAT plan, currently under review, is to expand the township's middle school to include grade 6 and possibly build a new structure on 19 acres owned by the Board of Education. The district serves some 1,625 children in four k-6 elementary schools and one 7-8 middle school.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: School Superintendent Robert Clarke said alternatives are being explored and a decision will not be made until January.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: The district offers computer classes beginning in kindergarten as well as a prekindergarten readiness program. And for academically talented students in grades 4-7 there is the Wyckoff Extended Learning Program, which Dr. Clarke said is meant to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills. Each school has a library media center.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: Also in the township are St. Elizabeth's, its only Roman Catholic elementary school, and Eastern Christian Children's Retreat for handicapped students.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: Most secondary school age students go to Ramapo High School in nearby Franklin Lakes. It has a comprehensive program with instruction in academic, business and vocational subjects, as well as many clubs and sports. Among special course offerings are anthropology and a seminar entitled, ''Global Conflict in the Nuclear Age.''
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: Ninety percent of last year's graduating seniors went on to higher education. This year the school's jazz ensemble placed first in a statewide music competition.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: The Lenni Lenape Indians were the first to make their home amid the hills and pastures of what is now Wyckoff Township, calling it ''wickoff,'' or high ground. By the early 1700's they were joined by Dutch and English farmers. The Indian past endures in streets with names like Sicomac - a Lenni Lenape word meaning happy hunting ground -and the Colonial past in stone houses dating to the 18th century, including one on the corner of Wyckoff and Franklin Avenues that is now the Brownstone Inn.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: In 1870, the New Jersey and Midland Railroad laid tracks for its Port Jervis line and speculators carved homesites from the apple orchards that dominated the area. Fifty years later vacationers built summer homes around the lakes in Wyckoff, which became an independent township in 1926.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: Through the first half of this century the community's population hovered around 6,000 and growth was slow. But it accelerated over the next three decades, despite the loss of rail service in the 1960's, and much of the open space gave way to rambling ranches and stately colonials scattered around and clinging to the hillsides.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: ''The community has become more suburban and houses prices are getting out of reach,'' said Douglas Anderson, a resident who owns a commercial printing business in Hawthorne, but it ''still has a down-to-earth charm.''
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: Because of its affluence, Wyckoff is vulnerable to burglaries; there were 63 in 1988, up from 39 the previous year, said Police Chief Donald Stapleton. And like other New Jersey suburbs, it has had its share of drug problems. In the last two years, Chief Stapleton said, seven arrests were made on charges of selling cocaine and marijuana from Wyckoff homes.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: Coni Carnegie of Schlott Realtors said prices of homes range from $200,000 to more than $1 million, depending on their age, location and lot size, typically from one-half to one acre. In the exclusive Hartung and Carriage Lane areas, houses fetch between $500,000 and $700,000, said Ms. Carnegie, noting that new homes often command more than that. Going up on Charnwood Drive, for instance, is the 10-acre Willow Pond Estates with 15 residences each priced at $750,000 to $1 million.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: HOMES in the more moderately priced sections such as East Wyckoff sell from $200,000 to the low $300,000's. Condominiums, either under construction or completed, are in short supply, Ms. Carnegie said. The newest one, the 30-unit, 8.6-acre Windham North at Wyckoff, is now taking shape on Windham North Drive; three-bedroom town houses start at about $300,000 range.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: There are a handful of one- and two-bedroom rental apartments, above the stores or in the few two-family homes in town, renting from $700 to $895, Ms. Carnegie said.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: The township must also come to terms with the New Jersey Supreme Court's Mount Laurel decision, which requires communities to provide housing for families with low and moderate incomes. Wyckoff's obligation is for 286 units.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: Robert J. Shannon, the Township Administrator, said that with little land left on which to build such housing, the township may consider petitioning the state to reduce its obligation. Meanwhile, the community is at risk of being sued by developers seeking to build multifamily housing.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: Free time in Wyckoff can be spent exploring the 81-acre Bergen County Wildlife Center on Crescent Avenue, with its nature trail and horticultural gardens; or playing tennis at any of eight courts. The Wyckoff Family Y.M.C.A. on Wyckoff Avenue has activities for all residents for a nominal fee and in the summer offers swimming at Spring Lake and a children's camp.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: There are town-run sports leagues, too, and the 70,000-volume library sponsors children's story times. Families can listen to summer concerts at the Memorial Field bandshell.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: There are many fine restaurants, among them the Wyckoff Inn on Godwin Avenue.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: But the most unusual is the Barn Original on Sicomac Avenue, a barn more than a century old converted into a tavern serving hamburgers and steaks. Its appeal is tied to its atmosphere: Cow stalls serve as drinking nooks and the bar is part of an old milk wagon. GAZETTEER Population: 15,593 (1986 estimate). Median house price: $379,000. Property tax on median house: $4,500. Public-school expenditure per pupil: $6,006 elementary, $7,767 high school. Distance from midtown Manhattan: 27 miles. Rush-hour commutation: Up to 75 minutes to Port Authority Bus Terminal via N.J. Transit, $3.55 one way, $110 monthly; Leisure Line, $6.20 one way, $143 for 40 trips, or Short Line, $6.85 one way Government: Five-member township committee elected to 3-year terms. Mayor, now Douglas A. Dial, a Republican, is elected by committee members. Committee appoints township manager, now Robert J. Shannon Jr. Museum in a Mansion: Wyckoff's oldest building is the Van Voorhees-Quackenbush-Zabriskie House, a stone structure dating to 1730 on Franklin Avenue, just north of its intersection with Wyckoff Avenue. Its last resident, Grace Zabriskie, willed it and its antique furnishings to the township in 1973. Now the house, a national historic landmark, is a museum open Fridays from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. when school is in session and for special events and holiday tours. Admission is $1 for adults, 50 cents for children.
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Wyckoff

text: Many city halls have been taken over and held for months by the opposition, and the Governor was stoned by angry citizens. On the campaign trail, supporters of rival candidates have fought with clubs and fists and sought to disrupt each other's rallies.
title: Election Fervor Reignites in a Mexican State

text: Across most of Mexico, the fervor ignited by last year's presidential election, in which the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party won an officially recorded 50.7 percent of the vote amid charges of widespread fraud, has largely died down. But here in Michoacan, home state of Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, leader of the country's left-wing opposition, the rough-and-tumble approach to politics still prevails.
title: Election Fervor Reignites in a Mexican State

text: ''In Michoacan, the rational elements that make up the political process have lost their validity and standing,'' warns a document analyzing local conditions that was prepared for the PRI, as the governing party is known. ''What is happening here is an uncommon overflowing of passions, emotions and subjective facts.''
title: Election Fervor Reignites in a Mexican State

text: Indeed, all political forces here say they are worried that another round of ''political effervescence,'' to use the most popular euphemism for what has been going on here for the last year, could erupt again on Sunday.
title: Election Fervor Reignites in a Mexican State

text: In this state of 3.5 million people west of Mexico City, a major exporter of both marijuana and migrant labor to the United States, state elections on Sunday loom as a major test for President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and his pledge of ''modern politics'' in Mexico.
title: Election Fervor Reignites in a Mexican State

text: Last July, as presidential candidate of the National Democratic Front, Mr. Cardenas won 394,534 votes to 142,700 for Mr. Salinas in this state, and his long coattails allowed his supporters to win 12 of 13 congressional races and both Senate seats. But PRI officials, saying they have ''absorbed the lessons of 1988,'' now predict that they will win a majority of the 18 seats in the state legislature that are at stake.
title: Election Fervor Reignites in a Mexican State

text: For Mr. Cardenas, who was Governor of Michoacan from 1980 to 1986 and also served four years as Senator before breaking with the PRI, that outcome would be disastrous.
title: Election Fervor Reignites in a Mexican State

text: If his new Democratic Revolutionary Party, formed after his leftist coalition splintered, fails to win a majority here, it will be interpreted as a sign his movement has lost the appeal it showed just a year ago.
title: Election Fervor Reignites in a Mexican State

text: Mr. Cardenas has warned his supporters to prepare for what he believes is an official effort to steal this election from him. Over the last year, Mr. Cardenas's followers here have on several occasions successfully shown political muscle when they felt the Government was acting arbitrarily. Their biggest trophy has been former Gov. Luis Martinez Villicana, who was driven from office last year after Cardenas supporters took over government buildings across Michoacan and vowed to remain until he resigned. 'People's Governments'
title: Election Fervor Reignites in a Mexican State

text: At the peak of the protest movement, the Cardenas forces had occupied or blocked access to 59 of the 113 town halls in the state. That number is now down to 14, party leaders say, but the tactic could be used again if party members conclude that the PRI has deprived them of the victory they are certain will be theirs.
title: Election Fervor Reignites in a Mexican State

text: In at least four municipalities the Cardenas forces have set up a parallel government in defiance of the authorities recognized by the state capital. These ''people's governments'' operate from city hall on donations from local residents, while the official mayors, all PRI members, govern from their homes with funds supplied to them by the new interim Governor, Genovevo Figueroa Zamudio.
title: Election Fervor Reignites in a Mexican State

text: ''The people in these four muncipalities told the army that if you want us out, you're going to have to come in and get us,'' said Isidoro Aguilera, the Congressman for the affected area.
title: Election Fervor Reignites in a Mexican State

text: Jorge Mendoza, who as the state's Secretary of Government handles security matters and also presides over the State Electoral Commission, attributes the lack of action to the state government's prudence and desire not to worsen the tensions.
title: Election Fervor Reignites in a Mexican State

text: Nevertheless, Mr. Mendoza added, army units and state and federal police have been called out ''for the sole purpose of maintaining order and calm.''
title: Election Fervor Reignites in a Mexican State

text: Because of a production error, an article on the Health page on Thursday about nursing mothers' use of medications appeared in some copies with a passage misplaced. The affected passage should have read:
title: Corrections

text: ''Normal amounts of caffeine, described as one or two cups of a caffeinated beverage a day, pose no hazards for infants, the report said. The medications considered harmful have a number of effects, from suppressing lactation in the mother to suppression of the infant's immune system. Some medications are suspected of impairing growth or development of the infant. Besides the risky medications, the report says, six drugs that are often abused are hazardous to nursing infants, as well as to their mothers. They are amphetamines, cocaine (both when it is prescribed as an anesthetic and when used as a recreational drug), heroin, marijuana, nicotine and phencyclidine, or PCP.''
title: Corrections

text: Because of a production error, an article on the Health page on Thursday about nursing mothers' use of medications appeared in some copies with a passage misplaced. The affected passage should have read:
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: ''Normal amounts of caffeine, described as one or two cups of a caffeinated beverage a day, pose no hazards for infants, the report said. The medications considered harmful have a number of effects, from suppressing lactation in the mother to suppression of the infant's immune system. Some medications are suspected of impairing growth or development of the infant. Besides the risky medications, the report says, six drugs that are often abused are hazardous to nursing infants, as well as to their mothers. They are amphetamines, cocaine (both when it is prescribed as an anesthetic and when used as a recreational drug), heroin, marijuana, nicotine and phencyclidine, or PCP.''
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: >While prudent mothers should avoid unnecessary medications when they are nursing babies, most medicines are not dangerous to breast-feeding infants, a new report says.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: The report, prepared for the American Academy of Pediatricians, lists medications and other substances that nursing mothers should avoid, and other medications for which there is no indication of danger.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: The report is intended to eliminate persistent confusion among doctors and patients about medications for nursing mothers, said Dr. Cheston M. Berlin, who prepared the report. It should also ease many mothers' fears that medications might pass into the milk and harm their babies, he said.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: ''We are trying to encourage breast-feeding,'' said Dr. Berlin, a professor of pediatrics and pharmacology at Pennsylvania State University. ''There are a lot of people out there, including some pediatricians, who think that if a mother goes on any medication she should stop nursing. There is no evidence for that.'' Use of Other Substances
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: Nonetheless, nursing mothers, and everyone else for that matter, should refrain from taking medications unless they are absolutely necessary, Dr. Berlin said.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: The report also addresses the use of legal substances, like alcohol, nicotine and caffeine, and illegal drugs like marijuana and cocaine. Generally, the use of the legal substances is not believed to harm nursing infants if used in moderation, but the report does not encourage their use.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: While no studies have found marijuana to be harmful to infants, the report recommends against its use. The use of cocaine by nursing mothers can cause cocaine intoxication in their babies.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: The report, scheduled to be published this fall in the journal Pediatrics, updates a report published in 1983. Doctors took into account research that has been conducted since the earlier report.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: The recommendations remain essentially the same, but a few changes were made. For example, gold salts, an anti-inflammatory agent used to treat arthritis, were once considered harmful but are now said to have no ill effects on nursing children. Increasing Concerns Cited
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: Doctors said the updating is also important because of increasing concerns of new mothers about the effects of medications and other substances on their nursing children. About 60 percent of new mothers breast-feed their infants.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: ''Many mothers think they have to stop nursing if they go on a medication,'' Dr. Berlin said. ''There is really no reason that mothers can't continue nursing while taking most medications.''
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: Dr. Sumner J. Yaffe of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development said that while most drugs are permissible during nursing, caution should still be taken.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: ''Breast-feeding should give a mother pause to consider whether she really needs the drugs she has been taking,'' Dr. Yaffe said. ''In many instances, women need not be taking certain drugs in the first place. We're an overmedicated society in general and tend to take pills for this and that at the drop of a hat to treat symptoms, when medication should really only be used to treat disease.'' When to Take Medications
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: It is recommended that mothers who must take medications do so just before nursing, so that the child feeds before the chemical has time be absorbed into the breast milk.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: That advice is particularly true for alcohol, Dr. Yaffe said. Some doctors suggest that mothers who have difficulty producing milk have a drink before nursing to relax them and encourage milk flow.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: ''An occasional drink can be helpful,'' he said. ''But we don't know what the long-term effects might be.'' Alcohol passes easily into mothers' milk; heavy alcohol consumption, meaning more than a drink or two a day, can impair brain development in nursing infants, he said.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: Similarly, heavy smoking by mothers can cause a host of problems for nursing infants, including diarrhea and increased heart rate. Heavy smoking also tends to make it difficult for new mothers to produce milk.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: Normal amounts of caffeine, described as one or two cups of a caffinated beverage a day, pose no hazards for infants, the report said. A Number of Harmful Effects
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: The medications considered harmful have a number of effects, from suppressing lactation in the mother to suppression of the infant's immune system. Some medications are suspected of impairing growth or development of the infant.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: Besides the risky medications, the report says six drugs that are often abused are hazardous to nursing infants, as well as to their mothers. They are amphetamines, cocaine (both when it is prescribed as an anesthetic or used as a recreational drug), heroin, marijuana, nicotine and phencyclidine, or PCP.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: Several drugs, including many antidepressant and anti-psychotic drugs, have not been shown to cause harm in nursing infants but still warrant concern, the report said.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: Drugs that are generally compatible with breast-feeding are antibiotics, mild pain killers, cardiovascular compounds and hypertension drugs. MEDICATION, FROM MOTHER TO CHILD BEFORE USING ANY DRUG A breast-feeding woman and her doctors should:
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: * Decide if the drug therapy is really necessary.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: * Use the safest drug; for example, acetaminophen, not aspirin.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: * If there is a possibility that a drug may present a risk to a nursing infant, consider measuring blood concentrations in the baby.
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: * Consider minimizing drug exposure by taking it when it is least likely to be passed to the child. DRUGS THAT SHOULD NOT BE USED These drugs are thought to affect infants, or to affect milk production in the mother. Some may impair an infant's immune system, while others are suspected of causing different complications. Drug: Bromocriptine Key uses: Parkinson's treatment, milk suppression. Drug: Cocaine Key uses: Anesthetic; abused as a narcotic. Drug: Cyclophosphamide. Key uses: Cancer treatment Drug: Cyclosporine Key uses: Immunity suppression for transplants. Drug: Doxorubicin Key uses: Cancer treatment. Drug: Ergotamine Key uses: Migraine treatment. Drug: Lithium Key uses: Antidepressant, antimanic. Drug: Methotrexate Key uses: Psoriasis and cancer treatment. Drug: Phencyclidine Key uses: Abused as potent hallucinogen. DRUGS TO BE GIVEN WITH CAUTION Significant effects on some nursing infants have been reported. Infant blood concentrations should be measured where possible. Drug: Aspirin (Salicylates) Key uses: Pain relief. Drug: Clemastine Key uses: Allergy treatment. Drug: Phenobarbital Key uses: Sedative, anticonvulsant. Drug: Primidone Key uses: Anticonvulsant, Drug: Salicylazosulfapyridine (Sulfasalazine) Key uses: Inflammatory bowel disease treatment. DRUGS THAT MAY BE OF CONCERN The effects on nursing infants are unknown. Psychotrophic drugs, including antianxiety, antidepressant and antipsychotic drugs, are of special concern when given to nursing mothers for long periods of time. Others: Chloramphenicol (treatment for resistant infections), Metoclopramide (gastrointestinal stimulant, anti-vomiting agent), Metronidazole (treatment for yeast and bacteria infections), Tinidazole (see Metronidazole.) (Source: American Academy of Pediatrics)
title: HEALTH: Pediatrics

text: THE Sheraton Stamford Hotel and Towers, on a Monday afternoon, breathed the quiet of a slowly filling hotel. A few people clustered at the front desk, a car or two slithered up outside. The gift shop was deserted, and only a couple of stragglers were dining in the lobby restaurants.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: David Richey had scarcely walked into his room, but he was already muttering to himself. The front desk agent hadn't been wearing his jacket and failed to address Mr. Richey by name (though he did say ''sir'' a lot). Nobody told him where the elevators were. The bellman was of the ''drop and go'' stripe, dumping the bags in the room and offering no information about the hotel. All these lapses were recorded on a Dictaphone that Mr. Richey kept in his shirt pocket. The manager would definitely hear about them.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Personally, Mr. Richey is no fussbudget. Give him a comfortable bed and dinner at McDonald's, and he's positively happy. When he's working, however, a single hair on the shower curtain, a bellman who doesn't hang up his flight bag or a crumpled Milk Duds box lying in the stairway sets off blaring alarms in his head.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: His job is to be persnickety. He is a quality-control inspector. Hired by owners and managers of hotels, he poses as a guest and goes snooping about to see if staff members are smiling from ear-to-ear, giving stupendous service and not stealing money.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: As the president of the D. Richey Management Corporation, Mr. Richey operates in an odd little industry. The notion of paying people to do quality control has become increasingly commonplace in all service industries and is especially key in the hotel business.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: For one thing, employee theft is so pervasive at hotels. Approximately 8 out of 10 Richey checkups catch a crook. Bartenders are notorious for not ringing up some rounds or serving strong drinks to cadge bigger tips. And waiters like to do such things as pocket the money and check from a cash-paying customer - sometimes even using pens with disappearing ink to erase the check so it can be reused. Richey people once nabbed a bellhop who handed out free marijuana as a way to pick up drug business.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Hotels and restaurants used to simply hire retired police officers or lumpy private investigators. Some chains also dispatched managers from one property to review another. But over the years, a number of companies have sprouted up in an attempt to introduce more professionalism to the inspection process. These include firms like Cunningham Associates and Hospitality Consultants Inc., which specialize in hotel inspections, and Restaurant Consultants Inc., which caters to restaurants and bars. The Biggest Snoop
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Founded in 1979 by Mr. Richey, a former hotel chef, D. Richey Management is considered the biggest hotel evaluator, with revenues of $2 million last year. Based in Wilton, Conn., it performs everything from quick one-day reports to full-fledged, four-day operations like the Sheraton job. Complete inspections typically cost $2,500 to $5,000, depending on how large the place is, plus expenses. D. Richey employs 35 inspectors, although Mr. Richey and Todd Lapidus, the co-owner, still regularly conduct surveys themselves. (The inspectors are so familiar at some hotels that they need to don disguises and use phony names.) Clients include most of the country's well-known hotels - the Pierre and the Plaza in New York, all the Four Seasons and Hilton hotels, the Stanford Court in San Francisco and the Century Plaza in Los Angeles. The company also tackles the Cineplex Odeon movie theaters, checking that seats aren't gooey from half-eaten candy, that the image on the screen is clear and that ticket takers are on the up-and-up (agents once collared a taker who had been printing phony tickets on his computer).
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: The Sheraton Stamford Hotel is a cheerful, 500-room, 10-story tower a stone's throw from Route I-95. Light (and an occasional spattering of rain) pours through copious skylights. The four-year-old hotel caters chiefly to executives visiting the myriad corporate offices in Stamford. Though its occupancy has been rising recently, the hotel has been struggling because of fierce competition and the difficulty of finding good help.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: ''O.K., O.K.,'' Dave Richey announced. ''Time to do the room condition.'' A lithe, alert curly-haired man with a mellifluous voice, Mr. Richey had registered as Richard Adams and was assigned to room 1012.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: He gave the room a solid going-over: checked for dust on the window sills, saw how many hangers were in the closet (12 wooden, two padded), made sure there was a Bible in the night table drawer, tried the clock radio and TV, tested the blow drier, inspected the bathtub for grime, saw that the toilet tissue was neatly arranged and the top sheet folded into a point to make it easy to grab.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: ''Pretty good,'' was his summation. He did find some dust on the television cabinet and by checking a rotation label on the mattress (hotel mattresses are to be rotated every three months so they don't get lumpy), he discovered that the mattress was still in its third-quarter position. ''Unfortunate,'' he said.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: His findings were spoken into his Dictaphone. They would be subsequently transcribed and presented to the hotel's manager. Mr. Richey also uses a camera to snap pictures of annoying things that might interest management, like lipstick on the rug or holes in the wall.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: It was getting on toward evening. Mr. Richey was starved. Before leaving for dinner, he marked up the bathroom mirror with soap, like a naughty child, to see if the turndown maid would clean it. He also left $13 poking out of a book on the desk to see if it would be stolen.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Seated in Magnificent J's restaurant in the lobby, Mr. Richey ran his hand over the table. No crumbs. He ordered his entree first to see if the waiter would ask about an appetizer and salad. He did. (Hotel managers like the help to push people to eat and drink until they explode.) Asked by Mr. Richey to suggest a wine, the waiter responded with a moderately priced one. ''He should have offered a choice,'' Mr. Richey said, ''both a moderate one and a high-priced one.''
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: The food passed muster, though the service got progressively slower. ''It doesn't seem as if the help is that well trained,'' Mr. Richey said.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: After dinner, he strolled over to Celia's, the hotel's discotheque, but it was dead so he repaired to his room.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: It was about 10 P.M. Earlier, Mr. Richey had left a message for himself to test the operators. It was delivered, but incorrectly. It was supposedly from James Irving, but was given as being from Mr. James.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Turndown service was satisfactory, except the garbage wasn't emptied and the mirror remained smudged. The cash in the book was still there. An After-Dinner Snack
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: ''O.K., time to try room service,'' Mr. Richey said, even though his dinner had barely settled in his stomach. Seven meals (and about three cases of acid indigestion) are the norm for a D. Richey agent. He went for the ribs, clam chowder, apple pie a la mode and a Diet Coke. When the food arrived, he paid in cash, mentally noting the check number so he could later ask the accounting department if the money was turned in.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: After the waiter left, Mr. Richey snapped several pictures of the tray. These would allow the manager to be sure that the presentation was as he wished it. He dictated his report, noting that the waiter hadn't used his surname, hadn't slid a chair over to the tray, and had brought a Coca-Cola Classic instead of a Diet Coke. Mr. Richey got down on his knees and studied the wheels of the cart. He dictated: ''The cart was only slightly dusty and stained.''
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: The problem now was the food. Leaving it would look pretty fishy. So he followed standard D. Richey procedure: he flushed a bunch down the toilet. ''One thing I learned is to never order cake,'' he remarked as some prime ribs vanished. ''Cake doesn't flush. It floats.''
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: He tossed in some pie. ''It's a lot harder getting rid of food when you're in a restaurant,'' he said. ''Our female agents usually line their purses with a Pampers or plastic so they can stuff food in there. One of them once deposited a veal chop in her purse, forgetting there was a bone there. The waiter looked all over, even under the table, trying to find the bone. I guess he assumed she just ate it.''
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: At 11, Mr. Richey dropped in at the Magnificent J's bar and had three rounds of Miller Lites. He didn't like the fact that the bartender could open the cash register with a key and not have to ring up a sale.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Before turning in, Mr. Richey made a tiny pencil mark on the corner of each sheet and inside the pillow cases. That would enable him to tell if the maid changed the sheets the next morning. ''You'd be surprised how often we find they're not changed, even in first-class hotels,'' he said. ''I mean, you deserve clean sheets.'' Morning Sickness
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Tuesday morning brought the revelation that the toilet that had received much of yesterday's room service had some indigestion. Upon being used, it overflowed. The mess afforded a perfect opportunity to test the maintenance department. A sullen-looking engineer with a plumber's snake responded in about 46 minutes. ''Not bad at all,'' Mr. Richey said.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Waiting for breakfast in Raspberry's, Mr. Richey was rather displeased by the dirty tables. The music was relatively loud marching music. ''Boy, give me a break on this music,'' he grumbled.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Later, the pencil mark trick revealed that one bedsheet had been unchanged. After dictating that, Mr. Richey assembled some clothes for the valet service. ''I'm going to put a dollar in a shirt pocket and one into a pair of pants,'' he said. ''We'll see if we ever see them again.''
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: About 15 minutes after eating breakfast, he called room service to order breakfast. ''Let's go with a cheese omelette and tea,'' he said.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Mr. Richey likes to see how aggressive the room service people are in promoting extras. ''She was O.K.,'' he said of the woman who took the order. ''She asked if I wanted juice, but she could have pushed some toast.''
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: A little later, after lunch at Raspberry's, Mr. Richey stopped at the Magnificent J's bar for a Kaluha and soda. He got shortchanged by 13 cents by the bartender.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Mr. Richey had a ton of notes already, but he said that the flaws so far were fairly typical for hotels below the ranks of the truly elite. Lots of things inevitably go wrong. He has witnessed far worse. ''Once I was walking out of a hotel with the manager and I mentioned one particularly surly employee,'' he said. '' 'Oh, that's nothing,' the manager shot back. 'She slapped the last guest.' ''
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: A little after 5, Mr. Richey returned to the lobby, where a portable bar is set up from 5:30 to 8. It was a cash bar, and Mr. Richey was suspicious that there was no cash register to assure that the solitary bartender didn't pocket some money. He stuck around to count the drinks so he could compare his tally with the money turned in.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: After watching 41 drinks being guzzled, Mr. Richey grabbed some dinner in Raspberry's. He went to his room and found his laundry had been returned. The cleaning was well done, with ''no chemical odor present,'' Mr. Richey said. But both dollars were gone. ''Figures,'' he shrugged.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Around 11:30, it was time to visit Celia's discotheque. There were about a half-dozen customers. All of them had enough drinks to make them friendlier than your own family. Mr. Richey ordered a Scotch and soda. The bartender didn't use a shot glass, which Mr. Richey feels is proper to prevent waste. ''Boy, look at her free-pouring that Scotch,'' he said.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Mr. Richey is not a devoted drinker, so when the bartender was preoccupied, he spilled the drink. He ordered a second round, which also wound up as a puddle. ''In this work, you leave a lot of liquor on bar floors and in potted palms,'' Mr. Richey said. ''Otherwise, you pass out a lot.''
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: At 12:15, he left Celia's and said, ''Do you think anyone could get my car out now? Let's see.''
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: No one was at the bell station, so he asked the attendant at the front desk. He said, sure, he'd get it, and left the front desk unattended. ''Bad news if a guest shows up to check in,'' Mr. Richey said. When the car came, Mr. Richey drove it a couple of blocks and parked it back in the garage. Friendly, But Ill-trained
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: On Wednesday, it was a weary breakfast at 6:25 A.M. He returned to his room and ordered coffee and tea to test room service at the high-demand hours. The beverages came in 15 minutes but the waiter didn't address Mr. Richey by name or set up seating.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: ''The thing about this place is the employees are unbelievably friendly, which is something so hard to accomplish,'' Mr. Richey said. ''Everyone seems as if they would do anything for a guest, if they only knew how.''
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: As the day wore on, Mr. Richey tried the valet again, tried out the swimming pool and health club (the pool area was a little messy), sent a fax at the hotel's Business Center, and tested the catering department by pretending to want to book an anniversary party for 55 people (the sales manager did a solid job).
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: He capped off the day with a club sandwich from room service at 2:30 A.M. and was pleased by the service. ''Often in the middle of the night you get some strange things, like a security guard delivering the food,'' Mr. Richey said.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Thursday morning, Mr. Richey checked out the tidiness of the fire stairs (''wonderful'') and phoned security to report he had left a notebook last night in Raspberry's. He got ''a classic runaround.''
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Then it was reckoning time. Loaded down with his notes, Mr. Richey headed for the office of Fred Corso, the diminutive general manager of the hotel.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Mr. Richey quickly summed up his general impressions, and said his full printed report would arrive within a week. He told Mr. Corso how friendly everyone was, but pointed out how ill-trained much of the staff seemed.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: ''I know,'' Mr. Corso said. ''I'm working on that. The thing about this area is, you can hire for attitude, but the skills aren't there.''
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Mr. Richey asked that the cash checks of his meals be brought in to certify that they had been properly handled. One room service check for $8.65 was missing, and there were no signs the cash had been turned in.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Mr. Corso nodded. ''Looks like we've got a problem,'' he said. (Subsequently, Mr. Corso determined who the thief was and dismissed him.) The cash from the 41 lobby bar drinks was about $15 short of Mr. Richey's calculation. Mr. Corso chose not to take any action but said he planned to set up a better system for tracking sales. Mr. Corso also said he was going to give the valet manager a stiff warning about the stolen money.
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Once Mr. Richey was done, Mr. Corso said, ''Well, that was good. Some of the things you hit, we're aware of and it's a constant battle. I'm going to meet with my people now while all this is fresh in my mind.''
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Mr. Richey returned to his room and got his bags together. He had a hotel to tackle in New York next week - seven more meals a day, a slew of bedsheets to mark up. ''I'm bushed,'' he said. ''What I could use are a few days in a hotel as a plain old guest. Now, that might be fun.''
title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes

text: Cuba has gone to great lengths in the last few days to acknowledge that some of President Fidel Castro's closest aides were involved in smuggling drugs to the United States.
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: For years, Cuba has denied involvement in drug smuggling. The reversal has astonished American officials and other specialists on Cuba. They are speculating that the stream of allegations, disclosures and admissions may reflect a political power struggle in Cuba or an effort by Mr. Castro to explore areas of potential cooperation with the United States.
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: Some experts on Cuba say Mr. Castro is trying to dissociate himself from the drug smuggling by condemning it. The United States says he has known of such traffic for years. Unveiling Medellin Connection
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, said Mr. Castro had admitted Cuba's role as a transit point for cocaine smugglers after being ''confronted by overwhelming evidence.''
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: Cuban officials charged on Thursday that senior military officers had helped the Medellin drug cartel of Colombia smuggle six tons of cocaine and some marijuana into the United States over the last two and a half years.
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: The American officials said they could not immediately provide information about possible connections between Cuban traffickers and people in the United States.
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: Official Cuban newspaper reports and radio broadcasts give extraordinary detail about the drug-smuggling activities, including the time, place and content of conversations among Cubans, Colombians and Panamanians. The information is generally compatible with data collected by United States law-enforcement and intelligence agencies, Administration officials said. From Denial to Disclosure? Such allegations are startling because Cuban officials in the past repeatedly denied any official or unofficial Cuban involvement in narcotics trafficking. In a 1985 interview, Mr. Castro said that ''Cuba has an unimpeachable record'' on drugs. He said then that he did not know of any case in which a Cuban official had been involved in the drug business.
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: On June 14, Cuba announced the arrest of one of its most highly respected generals, Arnaldo T. Ochoa Sanchez, who had commanded Cuban troops in Ethiopia, Angola and Nicaragua. Two days later Cuba announced the arrest of six more miliatry officers including Brig. Gen. Patricio de la Guardia Font and his twin brother, Col. Antonio de la Guardia Font.
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: The Cuban suspects asserted that their narcotics activities were authorized by the Cuban Government and that they intended to turn over the proceeds to the Government, the official Cuban newspaper Granma reported on Thursday.
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: But the newspaper said ''the cynicism of these pretexts was quickly discovered'' when the Cuban authorities discovered hundreds of thousands of dollars hidden in the suspects' briefcases and at the homes of their friends and relatives. Questions About Castro's Role
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: Ernesto Betancourt, director of Radio Marti, the United States Government station that broadcasts to Cuba, said Mr. Castro was trying to deflect suspicion away from himself. ''How can Castro claim he knew nothing about drugs when he himself has been involved?'' Mr. Betancourt asked. ''Nobody in Cuba is involved in this type of thing on his own.''
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: Mr. Castro was mentioned in the indictment of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader, returned by a Federal grand jury in Miami in February 1988. The indictment said that Mr. Castro met with General Noriega in Havana ''on or about June 29, 1984,'' in an effort to mediate a dispute between the Panamanian leader and members of the Medellin cartel. The dispute involved the cartel's cocaine operations in Panama.
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: In 1982, the chief of the Cuban Navy and three other high-ranking Cuban officials were indicted in Miami on Federal drug-smuggling charges. Last year in a separate case, a Federal grand jury charged that cocaine was flown from Colombia to Cuba, where it was unloaded and transferred onto boats for shipment to the United States. Two men recently pleaded guilty to a 27-count indictment in that case. Skeptical Americans
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: Jacqueline Tillman, who followed Cuba for the National Security Council from 1984 to 1988, said today, ''The evidence of Cuban involvement in narcotics trafficking was becoming so abundant that the regime moved to protect Fidel Castro by dissociating him from those activities.''
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: Frank Calzon, a Cuban-born political scientist who serves as the Washington representative of Freedom House, a human rights organization, said that Fidel Castro or his brother, Raul Castro, the Defense Minister, ''had to approve of this activity, or at least looked the other way.''
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: American officials said they wanted to see a change in Cuban behavior before they gave Mr. Castro credit for taking a tough stance against drug trafficking. An aide to William J. Bennett, the director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, said officials at that agency were taking ''a wait-and-see attitude.''
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: Granma said on Thursday that an aide to General Ochoa, Capt. Jorge Martinez Valdez, met ''the all-powerful chief'' of the Medellin cartel, Pablo Escobar Gaviria, in Colombia in May 1988. ''An understanding was rapidly reached between Martinez and Escobar for trafficking cocaine through Cuba,'' Granma said. ''This cooperation was to be paid at the rate of $1,200 per kilogram.''
title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials

text: A 44-year-old gym teacher who has worked the last 21 years in the New York City public school system was arrested yesterday in the parking lot of a Manhattan high school while apparently snorting cocaine, the police said.
title: Teacher Seized on Drug Charges

text: The teacher, Michael Vogel, was arrested in his car at 11:45 A.M. in the teachers' parking area behind George Washington High School, at 549 Audubon Avenue in Washington Heights.
title: Teacher Seized on Drug Charges

text: Michael P. Sofarelli, the Inspector General for the city's Board of Education, said that at the time of his arrest Mr. Vogel was carrying 10 grams of the cocaine derivative crack, one gram of cocaine powder, one ounce of marijuana, tranquilizers, sedatives, a crack smoking pipe and a switch-blade knife.
title: Teacher Seized on Drug Charges

text: Mr. Vogel, who lives at 5400 Fieldston Road in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, was charged with criminal possession of narcotics with intent to sell, the police said.
title: Teacher Seized on Drug Charges

text: An investigation of Mr. Vogel began on Tuesday after an unidentified employee at the school called the Inspector General's office and asserted that Mr. Vogel used drugs between classes or during breaks. ''We got a tip with enough information and specificity that we could actually go out and set up a surveillance,'' Mr. Sofarelli said.
title: Teacher Seized on Drug Charges

text: Mr. Sofarelli sent two of his investigators to observe Mr. Vogel in the parking lot. They saw him consuming what they believed was an illegal substance and informed the Manhattan North narcotics unit.
title: Teacher Seized on Drug Charges

text: Yesterday morning, two narcotics detectives, accompanied by the two Board of Education investigators, again observed Mr. Vogel in the school parking lot from an unmarked Inspector General's van, Mr. Sofarelli said.
title: Teacher Seized on Drug Charges

text: After the detectives saw Mr. Vogel sniffing what they believed to be cocaine, they arrested him, the police said.
title: Teacher Seized on Drug Charges

text: Mr. Vogel joined the school system as a substitute physical education teacher in 1968. He taught at the High School of Art and Design in Manhattan from 1968 to 1985 before moving to George Washington High School, school officials said.
title: Teacher Seized on Drug Charges

text: The Federal district judge in the trial of Oliver L. North announced today that he was postponing the sentencing of Mr. North until next month to hear defense arguments about whether a juror used cocaine during the trial.
title: Questions About a Juror Stall North Sentencing

text: The judge, Gerhard A. Gesell, delayed the sentencing from Friday to July 5. He scheduled a hearing on June 28 to consider the defense charges concerning Tara L. King, a 34-year-old photocopier operator, including an assertion that she lied about her relatives' criminal records when the jury was being selected.
title: Questions About a Juror Stall North Sentencing

text: Mr. North, a retired Marine Corps lieutenant colonel and a former National Security Council adviser, was convicted on May 4 of destroying official documents, accepting an illegal gift of a $13,800 home security system and obstructing Congress in 1986 by helping to prepare a false chronology about arms sales to Iran.
title: Questions About a Juror Stall North Sentencing

text: A reporter's telephone call to Ms. King's home today was unanswered, and a representative of the company that employs her said she was on vacation and could not be reached until her return on Monday. Trial Fairness Is Questioned
title: Questions About a Juror Stall North Sentencing

text: In one motion unsealed today by Judge Gesell, Brendan V. Sullivan Jr., the chief defense lawyer, said Mr. North deserved a new trial because ''the possibility that a juror might have been under the influence of narcotics during trial calls into question the fairness of the proceeding and warrants further inquiry.''
title: Questions About a Juror Stall North Sentencing

text: The defense motion attached a transcript of Ms. King's statements in a television interview on the day after the verdict in which she said she had used marijuana and cocaine until four months before the trial began. Ms. King insisted she had stopped using drugs before she was selected as a juror and did not use drugs in the trial.
title: Questions About a Juror Stall North Sentencing

text: The prosecution, in a motion opposing the post-trial hearing that was also unsealed today, noted Ms. King's denial of drug use in the trial and said a hearing on the issue would amount to an ''abusive fishing expedition.'' Juror Questionnaire Is Cited
title: Questions About a Juror Stall North Sentencing

text: In another motion unsealed today, Mr. North's lawyers said Ms. King failed to disclose the arrest record of family members although she was asked about it on a questionnaire that was used in the jury selection process.
title: Questions About a Juror Stall North Sentencing

text: But the defense motion contained records from the District of Columbia Superior Court showing that one of Ms. King's brothers, Samuel A. King Jr., had an arrest record, including a conviction for armed robbery. The records also show that two other brothers were arrested on other charges, but their cases were dismissed.
title: Questions About a Juror Stall North Sentencing

text: The prosecutor's written response said that any court inquiry into Ms. King's jury service should be narrowly limited to whether the drug charges were true, and regardless of that, whether she was capable of reaching an impartial verdict.
title: Questions About a Juror Stall North Sentencing

text: LEAD: CASEY ON THE LOOSE. By Frank Deford. (Viking, $15.95.) Frank Deford, a former senior staff writer for Sports Illustrated and a television sports analyst, is also a novelist, mystery writer, biographer and the author of several nonfiction books. Now he has written the essential what-if book of baseball, ''Casey on the Loose.
title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION

text: CASEY ON THE LOOSE. By Frank Deford. (Viking, $15.95.) Frank Deford, a former senior staff writer for Sports Illustrated and a television sports analyst, is also a novelist, mystery writer, biographer and the author of several nonfiction books. Now he has written the essential what-if book of baseball, ''Casey on the Loose.'' In Ernest L. Thayer's oft-recited 100-year-old poem, ''Casey at the Bat,'' the mighty Casey did not come through for the beloved Mudville team. In the bottom of the ninth inning with two out, two men on, the score at 4-2 and two called strikes against him, Casey whiffed. Now, Mr. Deford asks, what if the catcher let the third strike get by him? Intrigued? Of course. So read the book - a novella, actually - and find out about what happened to Casey after he got extraordinarily lucky, and about the story of Casey's complicated life before the notorious game. And learn about the origin of the seventh-inning stretch, how the spitball came into play and what team was beaten by Mudville. ''Casey on the Loose'' also features photographs of the characters to whom Mr. Deford has given new life, as well as those of his own invention: Casey himself, his girlfriend, his mentors and fellow ''ballists,'' in addition to an assortment of cranks, wheeler-dealers and scribes. Any time a writer has this much fun producing a book, you can bet the reader will reap the rewards. Go reap.
title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION

text: The Mets lost their chance to be the dominant team of the 80's when they eliminated Kevin Mitchell and Ray Knight from their roster. The '89 Mets have all of the talent in the world but none of the spirit and inner strength characterized by these two players. That kind of drive is what enables a half-crippled outfielder to hit a home run at the 11th hour of a World Series game or a 17-year-old tennis player, seeded 15th, to win a Grand Slam tournament. The absence of such intangibles is what thrusts high-priced talent into a quagmire of mediocrity. MARIANA BERNUNZO Elmhurst, Queens
title: Question Of the Week; What's Wrong With The Mets?

text: ''I am a rich man,'' Earl Manigault said. ''Just look at my arms. All of my money is in my veins.''
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: Manigault does not hesitate to show the track marks that race around his lean arms, the result of shooting heroin into his system for the better part of 13 years. He points to small circles around the tracks. ''If you didn't hit the vein correctly, you'd get the swelling,'' he said. ''We'd call them 'misses.' ''
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: Last weekend, Manigault, the most gifted New York playground athlete never to make it to the National Basketball Association, came home. Manigault, who now lives on the brink of poverty in Charleston, S.C., returned to the park on 98th Street and Amsterdam Avenue where he was once so popular that in 1977 the local residents played a tournament named after him while he was in the Bronx House of Detention on weapons and drug charges.
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: What Manigault found was that nearly 25 years after he ruled the city's playgrounds, his legend remains intact. 'Somebody Has to Fail'
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: Part of the Manigault mystique is that he never made it, that he succumbed to the street life that consumed many of his friends in the 1960's. The man Kareem Abdul-Jabbar once called ''the best basketball player his size in the history of New York City'' became a drug addict and a thief, not an N.B.A. star.
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: ''For every Michael Jordan, there's an Earl Manigault,'' Manigault said. ''We all can't make it. Somebody has to fail. I was the one.''
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: As the 44-year-old Manigault walks through the small park, only a few blocks from where he grew up, he is instantly recognized. Everyone he passes approaches Manigault (pronounced MAN-eh-galt) to offer greetings. Most of his friends and admirers call him the Goat, the nickname he picked up when a junior high school teacher kept pronouncing his name ''Mani-Goat.'' Some just call him Legend.
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: Manigault hardly looks like a hero. At 6 feet 1 inch and 175 pounds, he is not a particularly big man. He moves through the park with a cigarette hanging from his mouth, carrying a can of beer in a brown paper bag and sipping through a straw. He is dressed in a faded T-shirt and blue shorts. He hunches slightly when he walks.
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: But while the neighborhood residents now see a shell of the athlete they once idolized, they also remember the pride he brought to them. Playing 'Like 6-9'
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: They remember his soaring dunks over much taller opponents that thrilled the audiences at the Rucker Tournament in Harlem. They remember his duels against the playground stars who made it, Connie Hawkins and Abdul-Jabbar (then Lew Alcindor), and those who did not, Joe Hammond and the late Herman (the Helicopter) Knowings, for example. They remember the time he dunked a ball backwards 36 times in a row to win a $60 bet.
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: ''His ability to play like a man who was 6-9 was incredible,'' said Gene Williams, an organizer of the Rucker Tournament who played against Manigault in high school. ''He was a phenomenal player. And he's still a legend to the kids today.''
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: Manigault established a reputation as a remarkable leaper as a teen-ager, outplaying older, taller competitors. He starred at Benjamin Franklin High School until he was dismissed from school in his senior year for smoking marijuana in the locker room, a charge he denies. He then went to Laurinburg Institute, a North Carolina prep school, where he played for one year, finishing second-to-last in his class but taking home a high school degree.
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: The major college recruiters went after Manigault with zeal, as stories of his dunks and emphatic shot-blocking in the Harlem playgrounds at 129th Street and Seventh Avenue and at 155th Street and Eighth Avenue spread throughout the city. But Manigault feared that he couldn't handle the academic work at a prominent college, and he chose to attend Johnson C. Smith University, a predominantly black school in Charlotte, N.C. He struggled in the classroom, didn't get along with the coach and lasted less than a year. 'Right to the Bottom'
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: With no thought of returning to college, Manigault realized basketball would take him no farther than the playgrounds. ''That's when I went right to the bottom,'' he recalled. ''I started messing with the 'white lady.' ''
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: It wasn't long before Manigault had a heroin habit that cost more than $100 a day. He went to Manhattan's garment district to steal mink coats to support his addiction. Drug dealers would give him heroin for free, ''because I was the Goat,'' he said, ''and they didn't want to see me stealing for it.''
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: The one thing that Manigault felt was untouchable, his basketball ability, soon deteriorated. He remembered a game in the 1965 Rucker Tournament when he lost his balance and fell twice, a shameful experience that steered him away from the game and toward the street corners, where he nodded pathetically, strung out in full view of the neighborhood.
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: Manigault was arrested for possession of drugs in 1969, the same year Abdul-Jabbar was made a rookie millionaire by the Milwaukee Bucks. He spent 18 days in the Tombs, where he fought urges to commit suicide and kicked his habit. He was then transferred to Green Haven prison in Stormville, N.Y., where he served 16 months of a five-year sentence.
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: In 1970, Manigault, at the age of 25, got his only shot at professional basketball. Bill Daniels, the owner of the Utah Stars of the American Basketball Association, read about Manigault in ''The City Game'' (Harper's Magazine Press, 1970), a book written by Pete Axthelm. Daniels gave Manigault a tryout, but the Legend had abused his body for too long.
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: ''I drove Earl to the airport when he flew out to Utah,'' said Willie Mangham, one of Manigault's former teammates at Benjamin Franklin. ''But it was too late for him. His body had been through too much. He couldn't take the pace.'' Giving Something Back
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: Manigault said he stayed clean for several years. Ironically, he went to the drug kingpins for money to start his Goat Tournament, which was played at 98th and Amsterdam, then known as Goat Park. ''I told them they had to give something back to the community,'' Manigault said. ''They couldn't say no to the Goat.''
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: But the Goat couldn't say no to drugs. He started dabbling in heroin again. On a rainy summer day in 1977, the first day of the Goat Tournament was canceled and Manigault got into a car with some friends and headed to the Bronx. ''We had a plan to steal $6 million,'' said Manigault, who refuses to reveal the plan. ''But we got busted. They figured I was the ringleader. I got two years.''
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: After two years in the Bronx House of Detention and the state prison in Ossining, Manigault took two of his sons, the youngest of his seven children (he never married), and moved to Charleston to get out of the city and away from the lure of drugs. ''I didn't want my sons to be greater junkies than I was,'' he said.
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: Manigault says he hasn't touched drugs since he left the city. He lives with his two sons in a small home in Charleston, and has survived by painting houses, mowing lawns and working for the local recreation department. He has never held a full-time job for any length of time.
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: The playground at 98th and Amsterdam is still called Goat Park by the neighborhood, although a sign on the chain fence now declares it ''The Happy Warrior Playground.'' When Manigault is in town, word spreads and people head for the park. They come to wish him well, to buy him a beer or a pack of cigarettes. 'No Meanness'
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: Manigault's hold on the people is not restricted to the poor or to blacks. Stephen F. Cohen, the director of the Russian studies program at Princeton University and the author of numerous books on Soviet history and politics, is proof.
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: Cohen, a self-proclaimed ''basketball junkie'' and a former neighborhood resident, met Manigault in the late 1960's and they have been close friends since. Cohen said he was touched by the genuine sweetness of Manigault, and by the way he'd smile to the children or tell a joke to an admirer.
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: ''Earl has absolutely no meanness in him,'' Cohen said. ''If Earl ever did anything to anybody, he did it to himself. That's the tragedy.'' Manigault's personality is one of the reasons the neighborhood people still treat him with reverence. Despite all his failures, he is still regarded as a king of sorts, a ruler of the two blocks that connect Goat Park to Frederick Douglass Playground on 100th Street.
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: ''Earl lived like exiled royalty on these mean streets,'' Cohen said. ''He lived on the kindness of admirers. He had job opportunities, but he'd always walk away from them because he never had to worry about anything.''
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: Today, Manigault worries about his health. Two heart operations, including corrective surgery on two valves last February, left him with huge scars and took away any stamina he had left. He still shows flashes of his brilliance in pickup games, but he cannot sustain a consistent pace for more than five minutes. When asked if he could still dunk a basketball, Manigault smiled but didn't answer. Precious Legs
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: After shooting baskets for 15 minutes, Manigault rests on a bench in his park and rubs his muscular legs. He is proud of his legs, the springs that once carried him over the other playground stars. The most striking aspect of his legs is that there are no tracks or ''misses'' to be found on them.
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: ''When the veins in my arms were full, it was tempting to go to my legs,'' Manigault said. ''But I've always loved my legs. No matter how bad it got, I always went to another spot on my arms.''
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: When everyone in the park has had the chance to see Manigault, it is time for the Goat to head uptown. As he leaves the park, a man on the corner stops him and offers a beer. The exiled king in the faded T-shirt, the ex-junkie and convict, has received another gift.
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: ''I let thousands of people down,'' Manigault said. ''But I'm nothing phony. And there was a time when I gave the people what they wanted.''
title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm

text: Without so much as a POW! BAM! or a ZOOM!, Federal law-enforcement authorities yesterday announced the arrest of a former New York City police officer who gained fame as the Batman half of a celebrated anticrime team known as Batman and Robin.
title: Ex-Officer Known as 'Batman' Is Charged in Fraud

text: The ex-detective, David Greenberg, 45 years old, who was later elected to the New York State Assembly on a law-and-order platform, was charged with mail fraud and insurance fraud.
title: Ex-Officer Known as 'Batman' Is Charged in Fraud

text: He was taken into custody by postal inspectors in Belleair, Fla., where he lives. His brother, Bruce, 37, of Staten Island, and their lawyer, Samuel Konigsberg, 34, whose office is in Manhattan, were also charged. They were arrested in New York City.
title: Ex-Officer Known as 'Batman' Is Charged in Fraud

text: The men were accused of trying to defraud the Chubb Insurance Corporation of $350,000 after a December 1986 burglary of Tri-State Video of Brooklyn, a wholesale purchaser and distributor of used movie videotapes. David Greenberg was described as a partner in the company. They are accused of inflating the losses in the burglary.
title: Ex-Officer Known as 'Batman' Is Charged in Fraud

text: As undercover officers in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn from 1968 to 1972, Mr. Greenberg and his partner, Officer Robert Hantz, were dubbed Batman and Robin after the comic strip characters because of the officers' achievements. The two made more than 600 arrests and were the subject of a book and then a movie, ''The Super Cops.''
title: Ex-Officer Known as 'Batman' Is Charged in Fraud

text: In 1978, three years after he left the police force, David Greenberg, then a Brooklyn Assemblyman, was convicted in Federal District Court in Brooklyn of mail fraud and obstruction of justice in connection with a Small Business Administration loan. He served nine months.
title: Ex-Officer Known as 'Batman' Is Charged in Fraud

text: Mr. Hantz was demoted from detective in 1975 after he was arrested, while vacationing in the Bahamas, on charges of possessing four marijuana cigarettes. He resigned from the force.
title: Ex-Officer Known as 'Batman' Is Charged in Fraud

text: The charges of mail and insurance fraud carry up to 10 years in prison and a fine of $500,000 on conviction, said Dave S. Hattem, an assistant United States attorney in Brooklyn.
title: Ex-Officer Known as 'Batman' Is Charged in Fraud

text: Mexico's most politically charged murder case, the 1984 shooting of the country's best-known journalist, appears to have been cracked with the arrest of a former security official who headed the initial investigation.
title: Mexico Arrests Investigator In Political Journalist's Murder

text: The official, Jose Antonio Zorrilla Perez, former head of the Federal Security Directorate, surrendered to law enforcement agents Tuesday night after a seven-hour siege in which more than 200 policemen surrounded his hideout in Mexico City.
title: Mexico Arrests Investigator In Political Journalist's Murder

text: The Attorney General's office said Sunday that it had obtained evidence implicating Mr. Zorrilla as ''the intellectual author'' of the death of the journalist, Manuel Buendia, and announced a nationwide search for him. A Sullen Impasse
title: Mexico Arrests Investigator In Political Journalist's Murder

text: Mr. Buendia's killing, and the inability of the police to apprehend his assailant, had long soured relations between the Mexican Government and the press. Irritation grew so great that journalists last year boycotted official National Journalists' Day ceremonies attended by then-President Miguel de la Madrid as a way of protesting the deaths of Mr. Buendia and 28 other reporters they said had been killed in the line of duty during Mr. de la Madrid's presidency.
title: Mexico Arrests Investigator In Political Journalist's Murder

text: But at this year's ceremonies, held last week, Mr. de la Madrid's successor, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, promised to ''redouble'' efforts to find Mr. Buendia's killer. ''The demands for respect for the integrity and security of journalists are just and will be attended to,'' he promised.
title: Mexico Arrests Investigator In Political Journalist's Murder

text: ''This case is the most notorious in Mexico in recent years,'' a Government official who has been following the investigation said Tuesday. ''When repeatedly in the course of these years, there have been petitions, demands and complaints of journalists, intellectuals and journalists' groups, obviously that influenced things in a decisive manner, at least insofar as corresponds to this government.''
title: Mexico Arrests Investigator In Political Journalist's Murder

text: The official attributed the sudden break in the case to a combination of Mr. Salinas's ''political will to do it'' and a new efficiency on the part of Mexican law enforcement agencies. Since taking office on Dec. 1, Mr. Salinas has initiated shake-ups of police, intelligence, customs and immigration agencies, often regarded in the past as hopelessly corrupt and incompetent. He has replaced top officials and recruited new personnel.
title: Mexico Arrests Investigator In Political Journalist's Murder

text: In another demonstration of increased aggressiveness, the police last weekend announced that they had recovered 133 of 140 pre-Columbian pieces stolen from the National Anthropology Museum here on Christmas Day 1985. Seven people, most of them linked to a ring of cocaine smugglers and users, have been arrested in connection with the theft of the items, which included priceless gold and jade masks and jewels fashioned by the Aztec, Maya and Zapotec civilizations. Identification Not Helpful
title: Mexico Arrests Investigator In Political Journalist's Murder

text: Law enforcement officials also said they have determined the identity of the man they say actually killed Mr. Buendia at Mr. Zorrilla's behest. They have declined, however, to make his name public, arguing that to do so would encourage him to flee the country.
title: Mexico Arrests Investigator In Political Journalist's Murder

text: Mr. Buendia, whose muckraking daily column ''Private Network'' was syndicated in more than 200 newspapers, was shot four times in the back at point-blank range shortly after leaving his office on May 30, 1984. He frequently wrote about such sensitive topics as involvement of government officials in drug trafficking, American intelligence activities in Mexico, paramilitary organizations run by top police and security officials, and corruption in the state oil company and union.
title: Mexico Arrests Investigator In Political Journalist's Murder

text: Mr. Zorrilla, who once served as private secretary to Interior Minister Fernando Gutierrez Barrios, was one of the first people to arrive at the murder scene, and for several months headed the Government investigation into the killing.
title: Mexico Arrests Investigator In Political Journalist's Murder

text: ''Within 20 minutes, Zorrilla's agents had gone up to Buendia's office and removed files Buendia had in his archives, files which never were seen again and presumably were burned or are in the possession of Zorrilla or his people,'' the Government official said. The content of the missing archives is not known, but there have been press reports here that they included information on Mr. Zorrilla. Link to Drug Suspect
title: Mexico Arrests Investigator In Political Journalist's Murder

text: In 1985, Mr. Zorrilla resigned as head of the Federal Security Directorate and was chosen by Mexico's governing party to run for a congressional seat. The nomination was withdrawn after it became known that he had supplied police credentials to Rafael Caro Quintero, now being held in a Mexican prison on charges of murdering a United States Drug Enforcement Administration agent in Guadalajara.
title: Mexico Arrests Investigator In Political Journalist's Murder

text: Mexican and American officials say the Federal Security Directorate was actively involved in cocaine and marijuana trafficking between 1981 and 1985, the period during which Mr. Zorrilla headed the agency. The directorate was later abolished, with Mr. Zorrilla and many other agents then disappearing from view.
title: Mexico Arrests Investigator In Political Journalist's Murder

text: The federal security chief, said to be a friend and informant of Mr. Buendia, had been mentioned as a suspect in the case since the beginning, and was in fact questioned about allegations against him. Several Mexican newspapers and magazines published investigations that appeared to link Mr. Zorrilla to the murder, but Government officials had always maintained that there was insufficient evidence to bring a case against him.
title: Mexico Arrests Investigator In Political Journalist's Murder

text: Federal agents arrested eight people yesterday after seizing up to 8,000 pounds of marijuana that was being smuggled into the country inside cans labeled as pickled jalapena peppers. ''I guess you could say that we picked pot packed in pickled peppers,'' said Joan Baran, a spokeswoman for the United States Customs Service. The drugs were shipped to Newark from Costa Rica aboard a Panamanian freighter and had a wholesale value of up to $6.4 million, the authorities said. There were no peppers in the six-pound cans.
title: 8 Arrested in Drug Smuggling

text: A comprehensive community program that encourages teen-agers to avoid cigarettes, alcohol and marijuana is far more successful than programs that rely only on the schools, a new study has found.
title: Community Program Succeeds in Drug Fight

text: The study, which involved 22,500 sixth and seventh graders in 42 schools in the Kansas City area, used parents and family members, community organizations, and newspapers and television as well as the schools to drive home an anti-drug message.
title: Community Program Succeeds in Drug Fight

text: The study, conducted by Dr. Mary Ann Pentz of the University of Southern California and her colleagues, is reported in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association. It concentrated on tobacco, alcohol and marijuana because their use in early adolescence is highly correlated with later use of drugs, including cocaine, the researchers said.
title: Community Program Succeeds in Drug Fight

text: Dr. Charles R. Schuster, director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse, said the study ''is one of the most important primary prevention studies that we've seen.'' He added that he hoped other communities would use similar methods to prevent drug abuse.
title: Community Program Succeeds in Drug Fight

text: In the study, the 42 schools in Kansas City, Mo., and Kansas City, Kan., were randomly assigned to carry out the experimental program or, for purposes of comparison, to continue their normal programs. The students in the schools with the experimental program were taught why they should not use drugs and how to resist using them.
