The program included sessions at school, homework assignments that involved role playing with family members and interviewing of family members about family rules on drug use, and newspaper articles and television and radio spots on resisting drugs.
title: Community Program Succeeds in Drug Fight

text: A year after the study began, students were asked whether they had used drugs in the last month. Among those in the group who had the experimental program, 3.4 percent said they had smoked cigarettes, 4.2 percent said they had drunk alcohol and 3.4 percent reported using marijuana. In contrast, 13.1 percent of the students who did not have the experimental program reported smoking cigarettes, 9.4 percent reported drinking alcohol and 7.1 percent reported using marijuana. Five-Year Study
title: Community Program Succeeds in Drug Fight

text: The study will continue for five years to assess the long-term effects of the comprehensive education program. Dr. Pentz said the data from the first three years, which have not yet been published, show that ''the program effects are being maintained and in some cases have even increased.''
title: Community Program Succeeds in Drug Fight

text: Dr. Pentz said she and her colleagues designed the study after a meeting in 1983 sponsored by the National Institute on Drug Abuse and the National Institute on Alcohol and Alcoholism that looked at what was known about preventing drug abuse. The participants concluded that programs relying on the schools alone to teach students not to use drugs had little impact.
title: Community Program Succeeds in Drug Fight

text: ''Too often, schools present activities for 30 minutes a week or a month and expect that to help,'' Dr. Schuster said. ''Clearly, when the students leave school, they are getting other messages.'' Delay in Using Drugs
title: Community Program Succeeds in Drug Fight

text: Dr. Schuster said a goal in drug abuse prevention programs was to delay the use of drugs until adolescents reach their early 20's. ''The older they get, the less likely they are to initiate drug use,'' he said. ''Very few people who are over age 21 will start using drugs if they haven't used them before.''
title: Community Program Succeeds in Drug Fight

text: Drug abuse tends to start in the teen-age years because that is when people are more likely to take risks and rebel, and there is less at stake, social scientists have found. They add that when people reach their early 20's and start working, marrying and having children, they are much less prone to experiment with drugs.
title: Community Program Succeeds in Drug Fight

text: The Kansas City program would be very expensive to carry out nationally, Dr. Schuster said, and there is a chance it would be less effective as its novelty wore off. But he said he thought that an intensive effort was needed to get the epidemic of drug abuse under control.
title: Community Program Succeeds in Drug Fight

text: ALONG with the half-million cars that were unloaded last year at Port Newark and Port Elizabeth to help make them the largest shipping center in the nation were some unwanted goods. Most of the cocaine and marijuana confiscated entering the New York metropolitan region came through the ports, according to United States Customs Service officials.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: The vulnerability of the ports to the flow of narcotics has sparked growing concern among law-enforcement agencies, particularly the Customs Service, which has entered a number of agreements in recent months to staunch illegal imports. This week, the National Guard began searching containers at the ports as an inexpensive way to boost patrols. Shipping companies have been firmly asked by the agency to adopt rigorous security procedures, and the International Longshoreman's Association will be reporting suspicious cargo to officials.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: At a time when national concern with drug abuse spawns calls to prevent sales before the drugs hit city streets, questions are being raised on whether the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the 2,000-acre port complex, is doing all it can to bolster security at the docks.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: Fighting the importation of drugs at the ports ''is like trying to swim upstream in the Niagara rapids,'' said Peter J. Baish, the Customs Service's Newark area director. ''There are so many containers that it is very hard to make a dent.''
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: One million containers were shipped in and out of the ports last year. In them were found more than 6,000 pounds of cocaine and more than 51,000 pounds of marijuana. The drugs came packed in cans of roofing tar or food, in furniture and in false bottoms and sides of trucks and boats. The cocaine and marijuana confiscated at the ports account for 90 percent of all drugs seized by the Customs Service in the New York City region, including the New York ports and airports, according to the agency's statistics.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: ''The bad guys are always going to find a new way,'' said Rick Mercier, the special Customs agent in charge at Newark. ''Once we find a method that is used, they turn around and find a new method.''
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: One-third of all the cocaine entering the country comes in containers, said Samuel H. Banks, the Assistant Commissioner who is director of inspection and control for Customs in Washington. ''It's the sheer numbers of containers that make it so difficult to select which containers to check,'' he said.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: Joseph Rivera, supervisor of the Customs contraband enforcement team, said. ''We think if we can look at 5 to 10 percent, we are doing O.K.'' He estimated that Customs agents at Newark and Elizabeth were checking 6 to 7 percent of containers.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: To sharpen its vision and stretch its reach, the Customs Service has established a number of unorthodox alliances. Beginning this spring, shipping carriers were asked to sign contracts certifying that security was adequate and that they were making significant independent searches for drugs and other contraband on their vessels.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: In a more unusual step, an informal agreement was reached with the International Longshoreman's Association to encourage the dockworkers to report peculiar conditions. Mr. Banks said longshoremen had provided important tips leading to seizures in the past. ''They are out on the waterfront, and who knows better than longshoremen what is out of the ordinary?'' he said.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: But the biggest improvement to Customs operations in the ports will come from the assignment of a contingent of 15 National Guardsmen, which will enable the Customs Service to search more containers at the ports. The 15 members of the National Guard military police will be deputized as Federal agents and assigned to the ports. Once under Customs jurisdiction, they will be permitted to conduct searches without warrants.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: The alliance of unions, shippers and guardsmen patrolling the ports has touched off complaints by the Port Authority Police Benevolent Association that its members are being ignored and that they could be playing a more substantial role in combating drug traffic.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: ''We are dealing with one of the most drug-infested areas of the country and we don't even have a narcotics unit,'' said the union's first vice president, Tom Moore. He contends that the Port Authority management has abdicated its responsibilities in order to save money, a contention that is denied by authority officials.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: On a recent morning, a tour of the port complex found three patrol cars, each occupied by a single officer, guarding the entire 2,000 acres per eight-hour shift. Danger to Officers Seen
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: Mr. Moore said it was dangerous for officers to enter the dark, cavernous warehouses alone to break up fights involving port workers or to look for someone hiding.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: He said it was not unusual for Port Authority officers to stumble upon drug raids and find unidentified people shooting at each other. He said the officers often had no way of knowing which were the Federal agents and which were the drug smugglers because the Customs Service and the Federal Drug Enforcement Agency did not notify the Port Authority police of their raids.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: Drugs are not the only problem. On a recent daytime tour of the ports, a visitor was easily able to drive into unprotected private yards containing thousands of new automobiles, each with keys in the ignition.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: In recent years, hundreds of vehicles have been reported stolen from the ports, leading the Port Authority to place $1.5 million worth of guard rails behind the chain-link fences surrounding the large yards. This deters thieves from driving cars through the fences. But with only one or no private guard watching the sprawling lots, entry is still possible. Cannot Search Without Warrants
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: Henry I. DeGeneste, the Superintendent of the Port Authority Police, maintains, however, that the level of crime at the ports does not justify an expansion of patrols. He explained that unlike Customs agents, Port Authority officers do not have authority to search containers without warrants, which limits the role they can play in drug interdiction.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: Mr. Rivera of Customs said, however, that there have been times when Customs has deputized New York City police officers to help search containers.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: In addition to the problems of drugs and theft, there is the issue of hazardous waste. An average of 14,000 trucks pull in and out of the ports each working day, and only this spring did the state police begin inspecting them on a periodic basis for hazardous waste. Mr. Moore argues that the Port Authority police should be doing that job on a regular basis.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: W. Cary Edwards, the former State Attorney General, also argues that the Port Authority could do more to combat drug smuggling. ''There is a big cry to do drug interdiction,'' he said. ''If you are going to do that, why leave a hole in the police operation?''
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: Mr. Edwards, who has met with officials of the Port Authority police union, said the authority's police must be trained to become ''key players'' in an ''integrated law-enforcement effort.''
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: ''They are an integral link between Federal, New York and New Jersey law enforcement, but they are not treated in that way,'' he said. ''They were disengaged as a matter of Port Authority policy.'' Mr. Edwards did not discuss the issue with Port Authority officials before resigning as Attorney General to open his drive, which proved unsuccessful, to become the state Republican gubernatorial candidate. Lack of Financial Commitment
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: Customs and Drug Enforcement Agency officials agree that additional patrols are needed, but no agency is ready to make the financial commitment. ''If we could afford to pay overtime to detectives to help out, we would, but we are not in a position to do that,'' said Richard Carley of the Statewide Narcotics Task Force.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: Superintendent DeGeneste agreed. ''If we could get a whole platoon of National Guardsmen, maybe you could check a lot more than 6 percent'' of the containers, Mr. DeGeneste said. But he warned that such extensive searching could ''grind the economy of the port to a halt,'' and that shippers might decide to use other ports.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: Mr. DeGeneste argued that the issue was simply a ploy by the Port Authority police union to increase its membership. The Port Authority police, with 1,500 officers, are already the 26th largest police force in the nation. For the union, it is a matter of the Port Authority's being tightfisted to do its job. Meanwhile, no one disagrees that the drugs are getting in through the ports.
title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security

text: Track and field has a problem. The problem is drugs, not the so-called recreational type like cocaine and marijuana, but the body-building drugs like anabolic steroids.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: Last year, at a time when track and field seemed to be gaining more attention, more public acceptance, more newspaper space and more television time, the Ben Johnson incident came crashing down. When Johnson tested positive for anabolic steroids in the Seoul Olympics and was stripped of his 100-meter gold medal, it left an unfortunate public perception that the sport was not clean. This perception is being reinforced daily by testimony in an inquiry into the use of performance-enhancing drugs in Toronto, where Johnson is scheduled to testify starting tomorrow.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: For many of us who are willing to compete without drugs, this image hurts. We are willing to put ourselves on the line without using drugs, but it becomes more and more frustrating to compete that way and do well.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: I think several people, including Charlie Francis, Ben Johnson's coach, have said what is in the minds of many athletes: others in their events are using drugs, so they have to start using them, too, to be competitive.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: That's a bad attitude. I think it's a poor excuse. It's unsportsmanlike. It's unethical. Still, I've heard it so many times. I don't think everyone feels that way, but some people do give up the fight and start with steroids. Some just quit the sport.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: Last December, I talked with a world-class hammer thrower, an American, about the drug problem. He said he wanted to compete, but he didn't want to take drugs. He said the only thing he could do was retire because he couldn't be competitive without drugs. He said he thought about it, he researched it and he retired. He said he hoped our imminent out-of-season testing program plus our competition testing program would become effective quickly so he could come out of retirement.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: Another weight-thrower, citing poor distances, said to me, ''No one wants to see me put the shot 65 feet or throw the discus 200 feet, and the only way I can make a big throw is to use steroids.'' He said the competition would still be legitimate because he said 80 percent to 90 percent of the athletes he would face were using steroids.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: While he may have had a point, using steroids is still the wrong thing to do. They are illegal. They are dangerous. They manipulate the hormones in the body and can destroy the body. Research shows that athletes who use steroids have more cardiovascular disease, strokes, heart attacks and liver damage. And steroids can be addictive.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: We have to get rid of steroids in sports. We have our rules and we are going to enforce them. That's the bottom line.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: We have had drug testing for years, but it has not been that effective because of the speed-trap effect. When you know where the speed trap is, you drive slower and get through it. When athletes on drugs know they are going to be tested in competition, they adjust their doses accordingly and very few get caught. I think Ben Johnson got caught because he miscalculated how long it would take for steroids to clear his system.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: The answer is to make the speed trap only part of the control system. The only way we can get rid of drugs is to test year round. We've been talking about it for years, and finally we're about to do it.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: For track and field in the United States, the national governing body is The Athletics Congress, known as T.A.C. I am the chairman of the United States Olympic Committee's subcommittee on substance abuse, research and education, and I am involved with a similar program with T.A.C. The T.A.C. board of directors and the convention have passed legislation for out-of-season testing to supplement the in-competition testing.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: We have another meeting on the subject during the USA/Mobil championships that begin Thursday in Houston. That's when we hope T.A.C. will appropriate the money so the out-of-competition testing can start July 1. We feel we need more than $1 million to start. Because we have to get the athletes to a testing location or get a testing crew to the athletes, the tests may cost an average of $500. That's a lot of money, but if you're going to have an honest sport you have to spend the money.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: We still must decide how many athletes will be in the pool for possible tests. Do we want the top 25 in each event? Do we want fewer? Once we resolve that, a separate committee will decide who and where to test.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: We can win the drug battle. With new research and with better detection devices and out-of-season testing, we will have a better chance to catch people who use steroids, and that could deter them and others from using steroids.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: It won't be easy because the drug problem in sports is just as difficult to stop as the drug problem in society. We need broader drug education for young people. We're finding seventh and eighth graders using steroids, and their drug-education programs in school cover cocaine, marijuana and other recreational drugs, but not steroids.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: How many elite American track and field athletes use steroids? I think 40 percent to 50 percent. People rarely say to me, ''Look, I'm using them,'' because they may regard me as sort of a cop. I hear second-hand from a lot of athletes that so-and-so is on steroids, but sometimes someone can have a great performance and opponents try to explain it away by pointing falsely to drugs.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: Most athletes want to stop the steroid problem. They want track and field to be regarded as respectable, and it can be. I remember when attendance in the National Basketball Association went down after drug problems, but the N.B.A. cleaned up the problem and is going like gangbusters now.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: I know there will always be individuals who will try to win at any cost. But the only way we can get the confidence of the athletes and the public is to convince them that drug users will be found and removed. Only then will we have a clean sport, and only then will we be sure that the winner will be the best athlete and not the athlete with the best druggist.
title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids

text: Lois Bennett stood in front of an anxious crowd with nothing but her comedy. She had better be funny - one of her final grades partly depended on it.
title: CAMPUS LIFE: Ohio; A Funny Thing Happened to Me On My Final Exam

text: Humor is taken seriously at Ohio University, where hundreds of people paid $3 each for the hottest ticket in town and then waited hours for a seat to see what, if anything, was so funny about Ms. Bennett and other class comics.
title: CAMPUS LIFE: Ohio; A Funny Thing Happened to Me On My Final Exam

text: Ms. Bennett, a ''nontraditional'' major from Akron, Ohio, who says she weighs ''230-plus,'' sipped a Diet Coke, aware of the apparent contradiction. ''I know what you're thinking, but it's not true,'' she said. ''I'm really not this big. My problem is I retain water. Lake Erie, to be exact.''
title: CAMPUS LIFE: Ohio; A Funny Thing Happened to Me On My Final Exam

text: Her required five-minute monologue continued with a discussion of truth in advertising: ''Did you ever look at the label of a pint of Haagen-Dazs? Serves four. Get real.''
title: CAMPUS LIFE: Ohio; A Funny Thing Happened to Me On My Final Exam

text: Her performance was punctuated by clapping and followed by sustained applause. When you're taking your final exam in Humor Writing 488, as about 20 students did this month, it's crucial to leave them laughing.
title: CAMPUS LIFE: Ohio; A Funny Thing Happened to Me On My Final Exam

text: The grading scale for the final, as Mel Helitzer, the professor in the course, explains, is simple: ''If you get a standing ovation, that's an A; enthusiastic applause is a B, and polite applause is a C. If the audience throws fruit, you get an F. But if the fruit's edible, your grade is bumped up to a D.''
title: CAMPUS LIFE: Ohio; A Funny Thing Happened to Me On My Final Exam

text: The crowd's decision isn't necessarily final, however, Mr. Helitzer said. Five faculty members also judge the students.
title: CAMPUS LIFE: Ohio; A Funny Thing Happened to Me On My Final Exam

text: Ms. Bennett, who received a standing ovation, pleased the other judges as well and earned an A. So did Sara Nay, a senior from Cheshire, Ohio, majoring in advertising, who told the crowd that she suspected her neighbor was growing marijuana:
title: CAMPUS LIFE: Ohio; A Funny Thing Happened to Me On My Final Exam

text: ''They're on welfare, they live in a tarpaper shack, they've got an outhouse and they've got a Cadillac and a Corvette. Also, how many people do you know that go and do their gardening carrying a machine gun?''
title: CAMPUS LIFE: Ohio; A Funny Thing Happened to Me On My Final Exam

text: When Mr. Helitzer, a former Madison Avenue advertising executive, began the humor course in 1982, it was the first time the subject had been taught for credit on a college campus, he said.
title: CAMPUS LIFE: Ohio; A Funny Thing Happened to Me On My Final Exam

text: ''Comedy Writing Secrets,'' the textbook Mr. Helitzer wrote for the course, is now used to teach humor at about 20 colleges and universities, he said. The list includes the University of California at Los Angeles, Arizona State University and Emory University. One of his former students, Matt Wickline, writes for ''Late Night With David Letterman.'' Two others, Steve Spiegel and Mark Drop, write for Arsenio Hall.
title: CAMPUS LIFE: Ohio; A Funny Thing Happened to Me On My Final Exam

text: The humor final was not in the syllabus in 1982. Several weeks into that class, some of the students told Mr. Helitzer they thought they were pretty funny. When he asked them how they knew, they told him that their friends thought so.
title: CAMPUS LIFE: Ohio; A Funny Thing Happened to Me On My Final Exam

text: ''Friends don't count,'' Mr. Helitzer answered. ''You need to make a strange audience laugh.'' The comedy final was established, and an Ohio University tradition was born.
title: CAMPUS LIFE: Ohio; A Funny Thing Happened to Me On My Final Exam

text: The final is one-third of the grade for the course, which meets three and a half hours one weekday night for eight weeks. In addition to weekly class exercises, students write a term paper on some aspect of humor. The final, Mr. Helitzer said, gives students the opportunity to put what they learn into practice.
title: CAMPUS LIFE: Ohio; A Funny Thing Happened to Me On My Final Exam

text: FABULOUS NOBODIES By Lee Tulloch. 272 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.
title: SHE SAID NO TO JACKIE O.

text: Reality Nirvana Tuttle, born in 1968 in Phoenicia, N.Y. (where not a single shop sells Jean-Paul Gaultier), is supremely powerful. She is the doorperson of Less Is More, the hippest nightclub in the East Village, the only neighborhood that counts. She trains her flashlight only on those who are fabulous enough to come inside. If you're wearing a Burberry or leg warmers, go home. Reality (''Really'' to her friends) won't let you in. She wouldn't let in Mother Teresa unless she did something about her hair.
title: SHE SAID NO TO JACKIE O.

text: ''Fabulous Nobodies'' is a night life novel. However, nobody speaks in the second person singular, no 12-year-old girls are tied up and raped, nobody is a slave. Nothing is dark, dank or seamy. For Lee Tulloch's East Village is a magical kingdom - summery, clean, friendly - where even the two old bums making love in the gutter manage to be endearing.
title: SHE SAID NO TO JACKIE O.

text: In this East Village everybody's speech is inexplicably English (the author, a fashion writer, is Australian; presumably her editor didn't care that a girl born in Phoenicia wouldn't use the word ''frock'' incessantly, nor would she find ''jumble sales'' in Manhattan).
title: SHE SAID NO TO JACKIE O.

text: In this East Village all the clubs have wonderful names - Cafe Orlon, Ultrasuede, Eton Crop - and are so incredibly cool that we'd all like to go there every night.
title: SHE SAID NO TO JACKIE O.

text: In this East Village nobody has the time for hideous drug bouts or depressing orgies; they're all much too concerned about their outfits.
title: SHE SAID NO TO JACKIE O.

text: Really, her best friend, Phoebe (who looks and dresses exactly like Audrey Hepburn, circa 1961-67), and her neighbor Freddie are totally in love with, obsessed with, clothes. In fact, Really communes daily with her dresses, all of which have names and personalities. There's Gina, who has a great sense of humor and a wonderful Italian outlook on life; Dolores, who has been known to froth at the hem. There's Anita, Petula, Tallulah, Clara. . . .
title: SHE SAID NO TO JACKIE O.

text: Instead of saying ''hello,'' characters say ''fab frock'' or ''I love your dress.'' Their knottiest problem is keeping up-to-date. ''We're recycling so fast we're gobbling up a decade every few months,'' says Really. ''Before the year is out, it will be last year again.''
title: SHE SAID NO TO JACKIE O.

text: The plot is clever froth. Really loses everything but eventually finds true love after many career and romance mishaps. She loses her job by accidentally turning Jackie O. away from the club - she was wearing a boring cardigan. A boy mistreats Really and then asks her for hair gel. ''Sorry,'' she says. ''I'm over gel.'' She is misunderstood by her hippie mother, Constance. (''Let a silly old hippie loose in your closet, and the first thing you know, she's shredded all your vintage Puccis and crocheted them into dolls to scare the crows off the marijuana plants.'') If your idea of entertainment is reading about Nazi conspiracies to take over the universe, forget this book. But if you have a taste for frivolity, humor and Manolo Blahnik sling-backs, you will be enthralled. Ms. Tulloch's voice is sharp, affectionate and hilarious. She reminds me of the master, P. G. Wodehouse, because although her world is totally unrealistic, it is much more true to life than any of its sordid predecessors.
title: SHE SAID NO TO JACKIE O.

text: Intensified Federal efforts to curb the smuggling of cocaine and marijuana into the United States on private planes have been largely ineffective, says a General Accounting Office report to be made public Friday.
title: Study Finds Flaws in U.S. Effort To Stop Airborne Drug Smuggling

text: Federal spending on radar attached to balloons, tracking aircraft and other measures to detect airborne smugglers has increased dramatically, to nearly $205 million in the 1989 fiscal year from about $18 million in the 1982 fiscal year.
title: Study Finds Flaws in U.S. Effort To Stop Airborne Drug Smuggling

text: But the accounting office, the investigative arm of Congress, found in an 18-month study that the latest drug detection technology often did not work and that even when successful it did not make much of a dent in the huge volumes of illegal narcotics entering the country on small planes, usually from Latin America and the Caribbean. Shift in Priorities Urged
title: Study Finds Flaws in U.S. Effort To Stop Airborne Drug Smuggling

text: Entering the debate over priorities in the nation's drug war, the accounting office also suggested that the Government spend more on treatment, prevention, research and education.
title: Study Finds Flaws in U.S. Effort To Stop Airborne Drug Smuggling

text: In the 1988 fiscal year. which ended last Sept. 30, efforts to stop the flow of drugs into the United States accounted for $1 billion of the $3.8 billion in anti-drug money spent by the Government. The report said that the 55,346 pounds of cocaine seized from private aircraft in 1987 represented more than a third of all seizures from smuggling but only a small fraction of the volume of illegal drugs thought to have entered the country.
title: Study Finds Flaws in U.S. Effort To Stop Airborne Drug Smuggling

text: ''If we measure the success of the current Federal drug abuse control strategy by looking at the number of drug users and amounts of drugs entering the country,'' the report said, ''we must conclude that our present strategy, which emphasizes supply reduction, is not very effective.'' #10 Percent Success Rate The G.A.O. found that about 10 percent of airborne anti-smuggling missions result in seizures of drugs. Often, it said, smugglers cannot be detected because the costly radar used works poorly in bad weather and needs frequent maintenance.
title: Study Finds Flaws in U.S. Effort To Stop Airborne Drug Smuggling

text: The report also noted that as efforts to block airborne drug smuggling have intensified, smugglers have responded by switching airports or finding other ways to get into the country.
title: Study Finds Flaws in U.S. Effort To Stop Airborne Drug Smuggling

text: Congress asked for the 60-page report as part of its effort to decide how to channel Federal resources to curb illegal drugs. It will be officially released Friday at a hearing of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, which is examining the military's role in blocking the entry of illegal drugs.
title: Study Finds Flaws in U.S. Effort To Stop Airborne Drug Smuggling

text: Until last year, Federal efforts to pursue airborne drug smugglers were coordinated by the Customs Service and Coast Guard, with the Defense Department using radar to help detect smuggling routes. In September, Congress designated the Defense Department as the lead agency in the effort.
title: Study Finds Flaws in U.S. Effort To Stop Airborne Drug Smuggling

text: Maj. David Super, a Pentagon spokesman, said the department would not comment on the accounting office's report today since it had not been officially released. Bennett Is Criticized
title: Study Finds Flaws in U.S. Effort To Stop Airborne Drug Smuggling

text: Also today, Senator John Glenn, chairman of the Governmental Affairs Committee, sharply criticized William J. Bennett, director of the Government's anti-drug policies, for declining to testify at his committee's hearing on the drug problem in the city of Washington. Mr. Glenn, an Ohio Democrat, suggested that he would subpoena Mr. Bennett to testify about the Federal drug plan for Washington.
title: Study Finds Flaws in U.S. Effort To Stop Airborne Drug Smuggling

text: ''Mr. Bennett has found plenty of time to hold press conferences, give interviews and make numerous television appearances, yet he does not have time for this committee,'' Mr. Glenn said. ''That is intolerable.''
title: Study Finds Flaws in U.S. Effort To Stop Airborne Drug Smuggling

text: Mr. Bennett, who returned from a trip to California today, had turned down Mr. Glenn's request to testify, saying he needs to complete his national anti-drug strategy, which Congress has demanded by Sept. 5. In a statement, Mr. Bennett's office said that ''74 different Congressional committees and subcommittees claim responsibility for anti-drug efforts'' and that ''the director cannot satisfy every request.''
title: Study Finds Flaws in U.S. Effort To Stop Airborne Drug Smuggling

text: ''CAN you imagine what it's like to have a newspaper that gives you nothing but the local news?'' a woman who lives at what she considers the end of the earth asked me recently. Yes, I can imagine it, because whenever I visit my family I have the pleasure of reading one that does just that.
title: Close to Home; By Mary Cantwell

text: This is the paper that announced my birth, my presence on the high-school honor roll and my marriage, and that will probably announce my death. It is 152 years old, and has been reporting much the same news, twice a week, since its beginning. The Town Council held a meeting. There is a problem with the sewage system. Plans are under way for this year's Fourth of July parade, which will be bigger and better than ever.
title: Close to Home; By Mary Cantwell

text: The paper still reports what the bride wore, information missing from the paper I read daily and that I sorely miss. One of the three brides celebrated in last week's issue wore a dress whose sleeves had ''the mermaid look,'' and two carried silk bridal bouquets. One couple will honeymoon in the Poconos, another on St. Maarten and the third at Cocoa Beach, Fla.
title: Close to Home; By Mary Cantwell

text: I like having that kind of information: it provides my imagination with a playroom. None of the newlyweds have experienced higher education, but all are employed. Where I come from, a college degree is not a prerequisite to making a decent living. This, as I see it, is how it should be.
title: Close to Home; By Mary Cantwell

text: There is a possibility that the town will get a hitch-up with another reservoir, thus depriving the distributors of Perrier and Evian a strong market. ''Wish we had this water at home,'' my relatives say on drinking the fabulous freshet that pours from a New York faucet. That is all of New York, however, that they wish they had at home. The Town Council has decided that no new building permits will be issued until roads and sewers are in. This strikes me as logical, but I suspect a subtext to the decision. There is doubtless a lot more than meets the eye in the Planning Board elections, too. Small-town politics are as tangled as big-city politics, and often just as ethnically oriented. I've heard the sentence ''They're trying to take over'' in my hometown as frequently as I've heard it in New York, and it is as accurate in the one as it is in the other.
title: Close to Home; By Mary Cantwell

text: I have always enjoyed my hometown paper's letters column, not least because it once ran a letter from a man who said the town should amend its practice of passing the gold-headed cane, awarded to the oldest citizen, only to men. After all, he pointed out, the town's oldest citizen is a woman. So it was - my grandmother, in fact - and she received the cane with a wry ''It's about time.''
title: Close to Home; By Mary Cantwell

text: Last week's longest letter was about ''affordable housing,'' a clear sign that my town, like many pretty New England towns, is perhaps too pretty for its own good. Or, to be more precise, for its natives' own good. Once money moves in, it takes up a lot of room.
title: Close to Home; By Mary Cantwell

text: The Personals column is not what it used to be. Last week there were only two items, where once it was full of townspeople's comings and goings, and of one family's in particular. This family boasted four daughters, none of whom could travel to the next town (or to the bathroom, constant readers claimed) without their parents calling Personals.
title: Close to Home; By Mary Cantwell

text: I didn't see any birthday party announcements, either. My fifth birthday party was reported in this paper, along with a list of the guests and a description of the presentation to the hostess (me) of a charming Colonial bouquet by a little boy whose father happened to be the town florist. A charming Colonial bouquet from the same florist was in my hand the night I graduated from high school. School news, though, is a constant. The high-school baseball team has won its second Eastern Division championship, and the girls' volleyball team ''has clinched at least its share'' of the Class B-East championship. There will be an all-night party after the senior prom so the graduates won't get into trouble on the road, and a fifth grader has placed in the National Geographic Society's Geography Bee. Forty-four teachers have signed a letter protesting a day of early dismissal. ''Your taxes pay for your child's education,'' they thundered. ''They cannot receive an education if they are not at school.'' Too true.
title: Close to Home; By Mary Cantwell

text: The police report, once devoted to chronicling which town drunk had one too many on Saturday night, has taken on a darker tone. Two young girls, both living in a shelter, were arrested for assaulting their counselors. A man was caught driving with a handgun in the front seat of his car. A drug raid netted 3,690 tabs of ''paper acid,'' a pound of marijuana, $1,000 worth of cocaine and two packets of heroin. My family consoles itself with the knowledge that the dealers, like all malefactors are presumed to be, are from out of town.
title: Close to Home; By Mary Cantwell

text: ''The town has changed,'' they tell me. ''There's a regular crime wave, all the time.'' Dear hearts, you don't know what a crime wave is, and I hope you never do.
title: Close to Home; By Mary Cantwell

text: In years past I beat my grandparents to the door on the day the paper was delivered, so eager was I to read about my world of high-school sports and honor rolls and weddings. Last week I outpaced my mother. She was eager to read about the facts of her life. I was eager to escape the facts of mine.
title: Close to Home; By Mary Cantwell

text: J. DAVID HAWKINS remembers seeing a miniature milk bottle in a restaurant when he was 8 years old. He wanted it so much that he simply stole it from the table. He has been involved with crime and consorting with thieves ever since.
title: Parent & Child

text: Dr. Hawkins, a criminologist and the director of social development research at the University of Washington in Seattle, has been studying which children progress from shoplifting and other petty crimes to more serious trouble with the law when they reach adolescence and adulthood. He and other researchers have discovered patterns of behavior within those families where the children are at greatest risk.
title: Parent & Child

text: Shoplifting and other forms of petty thievery are among the most common crimes committed by children. Whether it is a cause for concern, criminologists and child development researchers say, has to do with the child's age, the object stolen, the child's other behaviors and the parents' response to the incident.
title: Parent & Child

text: ''Young kids in preschool or first grade lack moral development,'' said Dr. Philip C. Kendall, head of clinical psychology at Temple University. ''Seeing some gum that you want and just taking it makes sense to them.''
title: Parent & Child

text: Children this age often don't understand the concepts that something can belong to someone else and that specific amounts of money are needed to buy things. They don't yet realize that they're doing something bad.
title: Parent & Child

text: Older children, especially adolescents, understand that such thievery is wrong. Often, however, they'll try to justify their thefts with rationalizations similar to those used by adults: the store can afford it; they charge too much anyway; I don't take from poor people.
title: Parent & Child

text: The probability that a child who engages in petty crime will progress to more serious crimes is quite low. ''Only about 1 in 7 adolescents who commit minor crimes will engage in more serious felony crimes over the next 12 months,'' said Dr. Delbert Elliott, a sociologist at the Institute of Behavioral Science at the University of Colorado in Boulder.
title: Parent & Child

text: That does not mean, he emphasized, that parents should take their teen-ager's shoplifting lightly. His studies of a national sample of adolescents also showed that almost all teen-agers who committed serious crimes and had other significant problems with antisocial behavior had a history of petty theft and other minor infractions.
title: Parent & Child

text: ''Children who have engaged in minor delinquencies as adolescents are 26 times as likely to commit serious crimes as children who have not,'' Dr. Elliott continued. They are twice as likely to have some mental-health problems, he said, and three times as likely to use marijuana.
title: Parent & Child

text: Not all children are equally likely to engage in such petty thievery. ''The kids who are shoplifting are often the ones who are not supervised after school,'' said Dr. John B. Reid, a psychologist at the Oregon Social Learning Center, a nonprofit research corporation, who has been studying children who steal. ''Also, children may shoplift when their family is under a lot of stress, such as during a divorce.''
title: Parent & Child

text: Many times, shoplifting is a disguised cry for help for painful or confusing issues bothering a child. One sign of this is how secretive the child is about the stolen goods. ''Many kids don't really try to hide it. Some of them even flaunt the items they've shoplifted,'' Dr. Reid said.
title: Parent & Child

text: Although child development experts strongly recommend that even an isolated incident of shoplifting should be treated seriously by parents, they also state that, by itself, it is usually little cause for concern. Most children recognize the social and financial risks of thievery.
title: Parent & Child

text: ''The kids who are chronically doing this don't care how their parents or teachers feel about what they've done,'' Dr. Hawkins said. ''They think, 'So what if they're mad at me? They're mad at me anyway.' These children aren't risking anything when they shoplift or commit petty crimes.'' 3 Ways to Deter Serious Crimes
title: Parent & Child

text: RESEARCHERS have found three things parents can do to help prevent their children from progressing from shoplifting to more serious crimes.
title: Parent & Child

text: ''First, give your children clear expectations for their behavior,'' said Dr. J. David Hawkins, the director of social development research at the University of Washington in Seattle. Those expectations include letting the child know that you won't tolerate stealing, even of small items.
title: Parent & Child

text: ''The way to perpetuate the problem is not to say anything about it,'' said Dr. John B. Reid, a psychologist with the Oregon Social Learning Center. ''You may have to make some rules such as, 'For a while, you can't borrow things. If you buy something, you'll have to show me a receipt.' ''
title: Parent & Child

text: ''Second, monitor your children's behavior,'' Dr. Hawkins said. ''Know who they're with and what they're up to. Third, provide clear and appropriate consequences for both their good behavior and their bad behavior.''
title: Parent & Child

text: ''The child should always make restitution,'' said Dr. Ron J. Prinz, a professor of clinical psychology at the University of South Carolina in Columbia. ''There should be some additional penalty, such as having a privilege taken away or having to do an unpleasant chore.''
title: Parent & Child

text: Some preadolescents who shoplift may not fully understand the concept of saving to make purchases and may need to learn how to delay gratifying their desires. Often parents assume that 10- and 11-year-olds have much greater financial sophistication and impulse control than they actually possess. It is useful to get children this age more involved in family financial decision-making, like comparing prices for similar items or working on a food budget.
title: Parent & Child

text: ''Let children hear the thinking behind your financial decisions,'' said Dr. Philip C. Kendall, the head of the division of clinical psychology at Temple University. ''Don't just say, 'You can't have those.' Instead, say something like 'You can't have all of those right away. You can get one now. The rest will have to wait.' ''
title: Parent & Child

text: If you do suspect that your child has shoplifted, confront your child with your suspicions, your feelings and the evidence. Make your feelings about stealing clear. ''Don't turn it into a courtroom scene,'' Dr. Reid said. ''If you do, your child will just deny everything.''
title: Parent & Child

text: A sailor who went absent without leave during the Vietnam War 20 years ago comes from ''a different era'' and should not be court-martialed, his lawyer said Friday at a hearing.
title: AWOL Discharge Is Sought

text: Charles Smith, who walked away from the Treasure Island naval base with his wife and child in 1969, was tracked down by the Navy last month.
title: AWOL Discharge Is Sought

text: Mr. Smith, 40 years old , was charged with desertion and using marijuana. A test for marijuana use was positive when he surrendered May 4, Navy officials said.
title: AWOL Discharge Is Sought

text: If court-martialed and convicted, Mr. Smith faces up to seven years in prison.
title: AWOL Discharge Is Sought

text: At a hearing Friday to determine whether Mr. Smith should be court-martialed or simply discharged, his lawyer, Howard De Nike, described Mr. Smith as ''a dinosaur, someone from a different era.''
title: AWOL Discharge Is Sought

text: When Smith became absent without leave from the base near here, he was 19, naive and angry that his wife had been unfaithful, Mr. De Nike said.
title: AWOL Discharge Is Sought

text: Mr. Smith remarried, fathered five children and became a respected foreman at a paint company, the lawyer said.
title: AWOL Discharge Is Sought

text: The Navy's prosecutor, Coast Guard Lieut. Dennis Hoffman, argued that Mr. Smith's long absence without leave warranted strict punishment.
title: AWOL Discharge Is Sought

text: The commander of the 30th Precinct, Capt. Richard Martin, strolled Edgecombe Avenue on the Upper West Side of Manhattan yesterday, patting children on the head and waving to elderly neighbors fanning themselves on the stoops. He wore a white shirt and a tight smile.
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: On Wednesday night, the street had been filled with hostility and tension. Curses and trash flew through the air as word flashed around that the police had pushed a man off a roof at 157 Edgecombe Avenue.
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: The 30-year-old man, who the police believed was a drug dealer, was fleeing over several rooftops when he fell six stories to his death about 6 P.M., the police said, adding late yesterday that they had found no evidence that the man had been pushed.
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: ''I just wanted to make sure everything was calm,'' Captain Martin said yesterday as he paused in front of an abandoned building, across the street from a group of men who said they were friends of the dead man.
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: Then the captain began walking again. ''I don't want to stand around too much,'' he explained. ''I don't want to be a target.''
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: Yesterday, the mood on the street appeared to be ambivalent and divided over what had actually occurred and about the police's role in the Harlem neighborhood. A Difference of Opinion
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: ''It could have happened either way,'' said Jerry Dover, 28, of 165 Edgecombe Avenue. ''But what I really think is that the police officer was just doing his job. He was just trying to bring the guy in when he fell.''
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: Mr. Dover said a 14-year-old boy with whom he lives was on the roof of 165 Edgecombe and saw the confrontation. He said it was unclear to the boy what exactly had happened.
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: ''He said it looked like he tried to jerk away from the police and fell,'' Mr. Dover said. ''He was trying to dodge the police.''
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: But Denise Lincoln, 18, had little doubt about what had happened. ''The police pushed that man to his death,'' she said.
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: Ms. Lincoln said she saw the confrontation from the ground in a causeway between 157 and 153 Edgecombe Avenue.
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: But from where she said she was, it appeared to have been a difficult, if not impossible, angle to clearly see the roof.
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: ''I saw it,'' she insisted. ''He got pushed.''
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: Ms. Lincoln said she watched a plainclothes officer frisk the man, identified as Trevor Francis, of 2031 Nostrand Avenue in the Kensington section of Brooklyn.
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: ''They had a little conversation and then boom'' she said. Then the officer, she said, ''pushed him in the chest.''
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: The man landed on his back between the two buildings.
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: The police said the incident began at 5:20 P.M. Wednesday when 20 officers from the Manhattan North Narcotics unit went to execute a search warrant at a basement apartment on West 145th Street near Edgecombe. Since October 1988, the police have made about 50 drug-related arrests at that location. Tried to Hide Behind Trash
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: Before conducting the raid, several officers were sent to an adjoining rooftop to prevent escape. As they were walking to the roof they passed apartment No. 7 on the fifth floor. Suddenly, Mr. Francis and another man opened the door, saw the officers and jumped through a window onto an adjoining roof.
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: The men fled to the street and ran into 219 Edgecombe. One of the men, identified as Kevin Johnson, 19, of 161 Edgecombe, was arrested.
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: Mr. Francis fled to 167 Edgecombe. He then led officers on a chase over several rooftops, the police said. On top of 157 Edgecombe, the police said, Mr. Francis tried to hide behind a four-foot mound of trash. But he was spotted and ran toward 153 Edgecombe.
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: At the ledge of 157 Edgecombe was a 6-foot chain link fence, topped with razor wire. Confronted with the fence, the police said, Mr. Francis ''apparently decided to escape by jumping across a 12-foot gap between the buildings, falling to his death.''
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: The police said investigators recovered 8 pounds of marijuana and 35 vials of cocaine from the apartment Mr. Francis had fled.
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: Yesterday, as he walked Edgecombe, Captain Martin said the area was infested by drug dealers and filled with hard-working people who cooperate with the police, despite ''the constant fear factor.''
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: ''We're not animals,'' he said. ''We're just trying to do our jobs.'' Then a little boy approached the captain. Captain Martin patted the boy on the head and smiled. The boy offered him a cracker.
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: ''No,'' the boy's mother said to her son, ''don't give him that.''
title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street

text: A 30-year-old suspected drug dealer fell six stories from the top of a Harlem tenement building last night while being chased by narcotics detectives, the police said.
title: Man Fleeing Police Dies in a Fall

text: The death of the man, who fell into an alley behind 219 Edgecombe Avenue, near 145th Street, attracted a large, angry crowd in front of the building between 6:30 and 7:30 P.M. The street was tense for more than an hour, with some people saying they saw the police push the man from the roof. The police denied their assertion.
title: Man Fleeing Police Dies in a Fall

text: The incident began at 5:30 P.M. when members of the Manhattan North Narcotics Unit executed a search warrant at a basement apartment at 342 West 145th Street, a known location for the sale of drugs, the police said.
title: Man Fleeing Police Dies in a Fall

text: Three men and a woman were arrested inside the apartment, and the police seized $14,000 worth of cocaine, marijuana and one thousand crack vials, said Assistant Chief Mario A. Selvaggi, commanding officer of Patrol Borough Manhattan North. From Rooftop to Rooftop
title: Man Fleeing Police Dies in a Fall

text: Two other suspects in the apartment fled through a window with the police in pursuit, he said.
title: Man Fleeing Police Dies in a Fall

text: The two suspects ran into 153 Edgecombe Avenue and up to the roof, where they jumped from rooftop to rooftop, with the officers in pursuit.
title: Man Fleeing Police Dies in a Fall

text: At 219 Edgecombe Avenue, one man surrendered. The second tried to jump either to the roof of the next building or through a window, but he failed and fell six stories to the ground, the police said.
title: Man Fleeing Police Dies in a Fall

text: The dead man was identified as Trevor Francis. No address was available.
title: Man Fleeing Police Dies in a Fall

text: The five suspects arrested were charged with criminal possession of an illegal substance. They were identified as Kevin Johnson, 19, of 161 Edgecombe Avenue; Thomas Hinton, 28, of 41-10 Parsons Boulevard, Flushing, Queens; Paul Walters, 25, 221 Lenox Avenue; Carou Agard, 26, of 32 Bradhurst Avenue, and Roy Jackson, 17, of 921 Hopkins Street, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyln.
title: Man Fleeing Police Dies in a Fall

text: At least 500 people gathered on Edgecombe Avenue as word of the raid spread through the community.
title: Man Fleeing Police Dies in a Fall

text: The crowd became angrier as people said the man had been pushed to his death. The crowd did not become unruly, the police said. There were no arrests or injuries reported.
title: Man Fleeing Police Dies in a Fall

text: Chief Selvaggi, when asked about the claim that the suspect had been pushed, said: ''We know nothing of that. We are in the middle of an investigation.''
title: Man Fleeing Police Dies in a Fall

text: He said that four officers who pursued the suspect were seeking legal counsel because of the claims, but he said they were ''not being taken off the job.''
title: Man Fleeing Police Dies in a Fall

text: The major role that drug or alcohol abuse plays in causing homelessness has emerged in recent comments by advocates for the homeless, who estimate that addicts constitute a higher proportion of the homeless than do the mentally ill or other identifiable subgroups.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: But the tragic human devastation caused by such addiction, driving working-class people into poverty and life in homeless shelters or on the streets, only becomes apparent by examining recent surveys and the case histories of people who have fallen from secure jobs because of drugs or alcohol.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: For example, in a study of men arriving at the Franklin Avenue shelter in the South Bronx, the anthropologist Kostas Gounis of Columbia University found that the vast majority had recently held jobs. Only 1 percent said they had never been employed, and 70 percent had been employed within the last year. Seventy-five percent of the men surveyed said they were addicted to drugs or alcohol. #25% of Homeless Are Employed Peter Smith, director of the Partnership for the Homeless, a New York-based advocacy group, found in a survey of homeless men and women in 24 cities that, on average, 25 to 30 percent were actually employed while they were homeless.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: People addicted to crack, a concentrated form of cocaine, typically spend at least $200 a day for the drug, and heroin addicts spend about $150 a day, said Kenneth Martin, program director at McKenna House in Washington, a residential program that helps homeless men re-enter society. Many sell drugs, steal or panhandle to help support their habit.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: At McKenna House, current and former residents told in recent interviews of how they got drawn into a downward spiral that ended, often after many years, in the shelters or on the streets. Their stories, and the views of the program's director, provide a glimpse of how and why men become homeless and why it can be so hard for them to come back.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: For Henry Pelham, a 31-year-old resident of McKenna House, homelessness was the end of a decade-long slide that took him from being what he called ''responsible and respected'' -a man with a job, a car, an apartment and credit cards - to a person who was utterly destitute, sleeping in crack houses, in the basements and hallways of buildings, ''wherever I could find shelter.'' The reason he fell so far, he said, is that his addiction to crack took over his life until he no longer cared about supporting himself. Life in 'Crack Haven'
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: Herman Epps, 28, is a former professional boxer who sparred with Sugar Ray Leonard and was an apprentice sheetmetal worker when he ''dropped out.'' He and a woman companion used crack, he said, and they and their baby eventually ended up at the Capital City Inn, a hotel for the homeless in Washington. ''It was a crack haven,'' Mr. Epps said, adding that his companion and baby are still there.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: Although crack is usually the culprit, other drugs have also led to the downfall of some homeless people.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: Gregory Parmenter, a former McKenna House resident who now supervises a crew that installs air-conditioning ducts in commercial buildings, attributes his problems to his extensive use of marijuana. He had been an assistant manager at a drugstore chain, but as his marijuana habit got worse, he said, ''I found myself not caring anymore.''
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: Mr. Parmenter quit his job and began working at various odd jobs, mostly construction work, until his drug habit got so bad that he could no longer afford a place to live. Three and a half years after he quit his job at the drug store, he ended up in a Washington shelter, where he worked as a janitor. But his money went for drugs. He said he was smoking 50 to 60 joints of marijauna a day. 'Fast Women and Drugs'
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: Norman Moore, 42, another former McKenna House resident who now works at a drop-in center, helping homeless men to stop using drugs and find jobs, became homeless when heroin took over his life. He said he quit his job as a mental health counselor for the City of Washington and spent his $10,000 pension in a month, using the money for ''fast women and drugs.'' He ended up on the streets, living in abandoned cars, then went to a shelter.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: Robert Means, also 42, who now does maintenance work for an apartment complex, was an alcoholic. After about 15 years of drinking, he said, he could no longer support himself. He had been living with his sister, but when she got married and asked him to move out he ended up in a city shelter.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: He worked almost every day he was at the shelter, mostly digging ditches as a temporary laborer. ''All my money was going to drink,'' he said.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: McKenna House is full of men who seemed to have a future, who often are articulate and highly intelligent, but who said they became homeless because of drugs or alcohol abuse.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: In 1984, when McKenna House was founded by three Franciscans, it was not conceived as the sort of second stage drug recovery program that it has become today. One of its founders, the Rev. Jack Pfannenstiel, a wiry, ebulliant priest who is now director of McKenna House, said he initially had no idea that substance abuse was so prevalent among homeless men. Young Men on the Streets
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: In the beginning, Father Pfannenstiel said, he and the two other Franciscans were struck primarily by the large numbers of young men living on the streets of Washington and in its shelters. ''We had expected more mentally ill and older men,'' he said. ''The numbers of young men struck us so vividly. We wanted to get together a program to help these guys get off the street.''
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: McKenna House, which has a capacity of 15 residents, is an immaculate brick town house on Park Road in Washington, situated halfway between 14th Street, a street of utter poverty, and 16th Street, a middle-class area.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: The McKenna House program gives homeless men a second chance by teaching them the skills they need to re-enter society, giving them a telephone number for prospective employers to call, helping them to write resumes, to learn how to look for a job and to find an apartment.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: But it started off as a failure. The men who stayed there could get jobs, but they soon ended up back on the street. After nine months of operation, the Franciscans closed McKenna House and began to re-think the problem. They decided that the only way they could help the men would be to insist that all McKenna House residents solve their addiction problems first. Success Rate Put at 60%
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: Now men who want to take part in the program must refrain from using drugs or alcohol for at least a month beforehand. Sixty percent of the more than 400 men who have been accepted make it through the program, get jobs that pay at least $6 an hour and find housing that they can afford, Father Pfannensteil said. Of those who make it through, only 15 percent fall back into homelessness again, he added.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: When the men lived in shelters, they said it was much easier to continue using drugs than to stop.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: Mr. Parmenter said the shelter where he lived ''was infested with rodents and pests and there were drugs all over the place.''
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: ''Men were committing homosexual acts out in the open, and there were crimes and even deaths,'' he recalled. ''I saw one man stabbed to death and another man beaten to death. Eighty percent of the shelter population and 50 percent of the staff were doing drugs.''
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: Still, he said he eventually looked at the people around him, saw ''the lost dreams, the wasted lives,'' and somehow managed to stop using drugs on his own while living in the shelter.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: Mr. Moore said he also stopped using heroin on his own at a city shelter. And Mr. Pelham stopped smoking crack while living in a city shelter. A Point of No Return
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: Father Pfannenstiel says he believes that a homeless person living in a shelter or on the street, in the company of other addicts, can reach a point of no return, a point where it is nearly impossible to return to society.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: After about three years, a man's social network, all of his friends, are other homeless people, the Franciscan said. He has cut himself off from the rest of society.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: ''The company that a drug user keeps is as important as the drugs he uses,'' Father Pfannenstiel said. ''To be part of that group, to belong, is also why people use drugs.''
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: On a recent Thursday night, when a new group of men had just come to McKenna House, Father Pfannenstiel told the men at an after-dinner meeting that they would face their most trying time when they left McKenna House and were alone in their apartments. ''You're going to sit in that apartment and your loneliness is going to say, 'I don't know if sobriety is worth it,' '' he said.
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: While the success rate at McKenna House is good, he told the new men: ''If I were to put down all the names of the guys here that we call a success and all the guys that we call a failure, do you know what the line is right down the middle? You know what it is. It's sobriety. It's staying clean. Gentlemen, it comes down to sobriety - a drug-free existence.''
title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'

text: Lieut. Eddie Cash parked his face just an inch from the nose of 18-year-old Heath Partlow.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: ''I don't like your attitude, boy,'' the corrections officer growled in a voice close to a whisper. ''I don't like it one damn bit. As far as I'm concerned, boy, you're history. I see no hope for you.''
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: Yet hope is a guiding principle behind the ''boot camp'' here for 17- to 25-year-old males convicted of non-violent, often drug-related crimes. Rather than sentence such first-time offenders to county jails or release them on probation, Georgia judges often send them to this paramilitary alternative 60 miles south of Atlanta.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: The aim is to frighten, humiliate and intimidate youths into going clean with a rigorous regimen of physical training, labor and spit-shine discipline. Sending a 'Clear Message'
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: William J. Bennett, the Federal narcotics director, has endorsed Georgia's six-year-old ''shock incarceration'' program, one of the nation's first, as a model for other state and possibly Federal prison systems. Such programs, he said recently, help rehabilitate impressionable young offenders and may be cheaper than sending them into crowded prisons for longer stays.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: ''Instead of putting the guy in the company of hardened offenders, we can put him in a boot camp,'' Mr. Bennett said. ''He gets a clear message that this is it: if he messes up again, he's going to be warehoused.''
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: Mr. Bennett's support for boot camps has sparked a national debate among correctional experts. Many say the concept is an ill-conceived fad that does nothing to turn young people from crime, let alone diminish the drug dependency of hardcore users.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: ''Boot camp programs are all for public image,'' said Jerome G. Miller, executive director of the National Center on Institutions and Alternatives, a nonprofit inmate advocacy group in Alexandria, Va. ''I don't think we've ever shown that treating people harshly - all the yelling and all the threats - does anything to make people feel better about themselves.''
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: Kenneth F. Schoen, who studies criminal justice for the Edna McConnell Clark Foundation in New York, said, ''It's just too simple-minded to think that these camps are going to have a great impact on poor black and Hispanic kids coming out of poverty.'' No Studies of Success Rate
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: At the Special Alternative Incarceration Unit here, Thomas D. Payne, the warden, conceded, ''Some people accuse us of making street Rambos into military Rambos.''
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: But Mr. Payne said that only good can come out of trying to shape up lazy, delinquent youths.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: While no definitive studies have tracked the success of the Georgia program or the newer camps in Alabama, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi, New York, Oklahoma, South Carolina and Texas, several other states are now deciding whether to establish them.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: Because the programs are relatively new, ''available data are not sufficient to determine if boot camps reduce prison overcrowding, costs or recidivism,'' the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, concluded in a report last September.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: While it said the camps could reduce prison crowding and costs if they housed offenders who would otherwise have been sent to prison, it noted that some states substitute the alternative programs for parole.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: Corrections officials in Georgia said the Forsyth center and another in Chester, each housing 100 inmates, cost about the same to operate per inmate as the state's regular prisons. Moreover, the estimated 38 percent of boot camp inmates who return to criminal behavior is comparable to the rate for the state prison system as a whole.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: Even so, Mr. Payne said the 90-day boot camp helps the already strained state prison system, if only by shortening sentences.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: Corrections officials estimate that less than 25 percent of young first-time offenders go to Georgia's boot camps.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: The moment the steel doors shut on the four young men who arrived May 23, Mr. Cash made clear he was boss.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: ''For the next 90 days, you do what you're told, when you're told, how you're told,'' Mr. Cash said. ''First word out of your mouth from this day forward will be, Sir! Last word out your mouth will be, Sir! Do you understand? Do you understand?''
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: The inmates were told to move ''like lightning'' and strip off their street clothes. Mr. Cash sprayed a delousing shampoo on their heads, groins and armpits and then ordered the young men to the showers.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: After the showers, the men had their hair shorn to a nub. Mustaches and other facial hair also had to go.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: Most of the youths' belongings were confiscated, although Mr. Cash allowed those who brought Bibles to keep them. Phone calls are forbidden, as are visitors until the seventh week. 'It Makes You Have a Grudge'
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: Inmates are yelled awake from their sparse, 5-by-8-foot cells at 5 A.M. and often they are not allowed back to them until just before the mandatory lights out at 10 P.M. During the day they are kept busy at a variety of chores, including grounds work and jobs at an adjacent correction institution's kitchen.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: Several inmates said they have benefited from the camp, but, like the experts, some have doubts.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: ''Discipline is one thing,'' complained Jerel Beal, 20, who was convicted of conspiracy to sell cocaine. ''But cussing you like dogs is another. It makes you have a grudge.'' But 22-year-old David Burdette, who was serving a sentence for selling marijuana, said: ''My life has completely changed since I came in here. It made me grow up a lot.
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: ''Some guys here, the way they talk, you hear them say they can't wait to do the same thing they were in here for. Some people, I don't think they'll ever learn.''
title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation

text: FOR at least one Rutgers senior, the road to graduation may have been unorthodox, but it represented a victory that was almost unthinkable a few years ago.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: Starting with marijuana at age 11, the senior was drinking and using drugs regularly by the time she enrolled in Rutgers. It was not until she had nearly killed a friend in an automobile accident while on an amphetamine binge and had watched another friend die of a cocaine overdose that she thought about getting help.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: By 1985, the year of her friend's death, the senior's college career and any hope of a meaningful future seemed to be over. The senior, who did not wish to be identified, had flunked out of school and was working at a series of odd jobs, trying unsuccessfully to overcome her addictions.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: Finally last spring, with the help of a Rutgers program for students with drug and alcohol problems, she re-enrolled in college, began university-based counseling, moved into student housing for recovering addicts and took a full load of courses to complete her degree. This spring marks not only her graduation but also her first anniversary of being drug-free.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: ''I used to think that part of growing up was getting wasted on weekends or having a pint of brandy in your pocket at a football game,'' she said in a recent interview. ''Why should that have to be considered a part of growing up?''
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: Concerned about a growing problem of alcohol and drug abuse on campus, colleges across the state are beginning to mount a wide range of programs to help students break the relationship between insobriety and their college years and help those who are on the road to addiction. Besides counseling services, schools are incorporating discussion of alcohol and drug abuse into their orientation programs for freshmen and are encouraging self-help groups like Alcoholics Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous to establish meetings near campus.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: Rutgers, which in 1983 became one of the first schools in the country to offer outpatient substance abuse treatment for students, expanded its services in September to provide an on-campus housing unit for recovering students.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: In April it officially opened the nation's first campus-based inpatient rehabilitation center. The 15-bed unit, which is open to all New Jersey college students who cannot be treated effectively through campus outpatient programs, is designed to allow students to continue their education with minimal disruption.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: College officials say that apart from the humanitarian aspects of such efforts, there are clear financial incentives for encouraging sobriety, as alcohol- and drug-related vandalism continues to soar on campus.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: To underscore the importance of the initiatives, the State Board of Higher Education has adopted an eight-point policy paper outlining substance abuse prevention measures that all public and private colleges should take. Among the measures are the establishment of counseling and intervention services for students, the opening of public awareness campaigns on the dangers of drugs and alcohol and the development of policies at each college to deal with substance abusers.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: ''During the past several years the problem has grown dramatically in New Jersey,'' said T. Edward Hollander, Chancellor of Higher Education, in releasing the paper. He said New Jersey's experience paralleled trends across the country.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: Last week, the Senate Education Committee unanimously approved a resolution urging the Board of Higher Education to require schools to adopt drinking policies and sponsor alcohol-free activities. Another measure would require substance-abuse coordinators at each college. The number of substance abusers in New Jersey colleges is estimated to be as high as 25,000, with less than 3 percent receiving appropriate treatment. College drug counselors say alcohol is the clear drug of choice for most students, followed by marijuana and cocaine. In many cases, students are cross-addicted to several different drugs. 'Party Atmosphere' Cited
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: Students say that life on campus, often associated with drinking and fast times, has become even more of a bacchanalia these days.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: ''The party atmosphere is very, very prevalent,'' said a Rutgers junior who first tasted alcohol after high school graduation and began outpatient therapy on campus 18 months ago for alcohol and drug abuse. She also did not wish to be identified. ''It's really acceptable to sow your wild oats and drink,'' she said. ''College is almost meant for that: get good grades, but have a really good time because after that you have to deal with the real world.''
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: As recently as five years ago, there were few options for students who wanted help in dealing with their addictions. Only a handful of schools had policies on substance abuse, and even fewer had services to help students regain control of their lives.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse
