text: For serious problems, there were private inpatient rehabilitation centers, but few students could afford them or could handle abstention from drugs and alcohol when they returned to campuses, many of which have a tolerant atmosphere toward drugs and alcohol.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: There was also little clinical experience regarding substance abusers in college. Researchers are just now beginning to acknowledge that students may need different coping skills to deal with their singular set of living and social circumstances. Lack of Stability Seen
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: At the opening of the new Rutgers inpatient unit, W. David Burns, an assistant vice president for student life policy and services, said: ''Students don't have the stability of life in a family or jobs to reinforce their sobriety. There is nobody the student has to return to in the evening or to cook for. So the specific treatment goal is to insure that we can maximize whatever is important in this unstable, transient time in a student's life.''
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: Despite the proliferation of counseling services on New Jersey campuses, it is often the dean of students, a professor or a friend who has to convince a student that he or she needs help.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: At the Rutgers opening ceremony, Riley Regan, director of the State Division of Alcoholism, said: ''Almost everybody volunteers because it goes like this: The individual asks what the alternatives are, and we say, 'We're going to take away your driver's license, you won't be able to make up your incompletes and you're probably going to be thrown out of college.' Then he says he'd like to volunteer.''
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: Because of his alcoholism, Mr. Regan himself was expelled from a Methodist-based college years ago. A number of tragedies at New Jersey colleges last year highlighted the need for aggressive action to combat substance abuse on campus. At Rutgers, a fraternity pledge drank himself to death and a football player died in an alcohol-related automobile accident. At Princeton, more than 40 students were hospitalized for alcohol-related medical problems during the university's sign-up weekend for eating clubs. Realization of Dangers
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: Kevin Ferry, director of Princeton's drug and alcohol program, said students were beginning to realize that drugs and alcohol could be dangerous. During this year's sign-up for the clubs, six students were hospitalized for alcohol-related problems. ''I don't think that means we're out of the dark yet, but things are changing,'' Mr. Ferry said.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: Besides coordinating peer education programs on the effects of alcohol on behavior and on intervention for substance abusers, Mr. Ferry has trained student bouncers to deal with unruly people and has presented workshops to all the eating clubs on responsible bartending. He also spends up to 30 hours a week counseling individual students. With the opening of its new inpatient unit, Rutgers has the most comprehensive substance abuse program for college students in the nation. Generally, a student will stay in the inpatient center for up to a week, followed by partial residential treatment and ultimately outpatient counseling.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: Rutgers officials say the cost of the inpatient program is about $150 a day, roughly half that of a private treatment center. The total cost of a student's recovery process would be from $3,000 tod $5,000, most covered by insurance.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: For some recovering students, the opportunity to attend college in a controlled environment is the only way they can continue with their studies.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: ''Rutgers was the best school for me to recover at,'' said a freshman who decided not to go to Boston University because it did not have the services he needed. He did not wish to be identified. The freshman, whose drug dependencies led him to attempt suicide twice last year, has been living for the last year in a dormitory reserved for recovering students and has been receiving outpatient therapy three times a week. Higher Success Rate Expected
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: Dr. William Frankenstein, director of the Rutgers inpatient facility, said he expected the success rate of the university's program to be higher than that of traditional rehabilitation programs because students would be reached earlier, when their disease was most treatable. He said that in most inpatient programs, about a third of patients were still abstaining after a year, a third had relapsed completely and the rest fell in between.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: ''College students are responsive to treatment, they're open to treatment, and they haven't developed a high level of chronicity,'' Dr. Frankenstein said. ''In terms of a clinician, they are a rewarding population to work with.''
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: While most college officials agree that drug use among students is on the rise, they say the popularity of campus substance abuse programs may have as much to do with the new frankness surrounding dependencies as it does with the growing abuse problems.
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: ''I think the problem is increasing, but there are a number of reasons for that,'' said Dr. William Fassbender, a professor of health education at Trenton State College and a certified alcoholism counselor. ''Alcohol abuse has always been on college campuses and it always will be, but we're certainly more open in terms of recognizing a problem now.''
title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse

text: LEAD: ''CRACK is very bad for you,'' Jon Draskovich, a first grader at Middlebrook Elementary School in Trumbull, wrote in his essay. For Jon and the 15 other children in Amy Traggianese's class, putting pen to paper that day was not part of a writing lesson. Instead, they were taking part in a curriculum aimed at preventing drug abuse.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: ''CRACK is very bad for you,'' Jon Draskovich, a first grader at Middlebrook Elementary School in Trumbull, wrote in his essay. For Jon and the 15 other children in Amy Traggianese's class, putting pen to paper that day was not part of a writing lesson. Instead, they were taking part in a curriculum aimed at preventing drug abuse.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: ''I've learned that drugs are bad for you,'' Jon said later. ''If you don't need them and you take them, they can kill you.''
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: Across the state, more and more school districts are increasing the scope of their substance abuse programs and shifting their focus to the elementary schools.'The Early Ages'
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: ''This is where you have to make your stand - at the early ages,'' said the principal at Middlebrook, Richard Witten.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: The Trumbull school district started its 15-lesson curriculum, ''Here's Looking at You, 2000,'' in the last school year. The program now has about 4,600 students in kindergarten through 12th grade.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: Under a 1969 state law, students at all grades are required to receive education every year about the effects of alcohol, drugs, nicotine and tobacco. But until recently, many districts concentrated their substance abuse programs on older students, particularly those in middle schools, said Veronica M. Skerker, a consultant at the State Department of Education.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: ''It's a change in the philosophy, because the society had changed,'' Ms. Skerker said. School districts had focused on middle-school pupils because of research done in the 1960's and 70's, she explained.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: ''Teaching middle-school students was appropriate 20 years ago because kids started using drugs in high school,'' Ms. Skerker said.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: Today, she said, younger students are experimenting with drugs and alcohol. And with the number of single-parent families increasing, she added, ''we have more and more children at risk because of societal changes.''
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: Trumbull and 139 other school districts in the state receive about $2.50 for each student under the Drug-Free Schools and Communities Act, a 1986 Federal law that will require programs for all grades in the 1989-90 school year, Ms. Skerker said.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: Despite the Federal and state laws, many districts systems have been slow in fashioning comprehensive drug and alcohol curriculums, Ms. Skerker said. None of the 40 school systems inspected by the State Department of Education since September had a program in place for all grade levels, she said.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: Ms. Skerker attributed the lag to several factors: limited funds, a perception in some communities that they do not have drug problems int heir elementary schools and a notion that resources should be allocated to older students.Making Decisions
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: East Hartford is another school system that has begun using the ''Here's Looking at You, 2000'' program in its elementary schools. The program, which currently focuses on fourth and fifth graders, is intended to ''empower kids to make decisions for themselves and decisions that are healthy,'' said Gary D. LeBeau, the substance abuse and dropout prevention coordinator for the school district.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: '''Saying No' works for people who aren't your friends,'' Mr. LeBeau said. ''You don't care what they think about you. The probelm is how do you say no and keep your friends.''
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: Elizabeth Cook, a fourth-grade teacher in East Hartford whose class used the curriculum this year, said: ''We can't expect them just to learn how to make decisions on their own. It's a skill.''
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: In teaching the program, Ms. Cook and other teachers try to develop self-esteem among their pupils. ''A person who is feeling really good about himself is capable of making a better decision,'' Ms. Cook explained.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: Of particular concern to Mr. LeBeau, Ms.Skerker and other educators around the state is the age at which students first use drugs or alcohol.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: Mr. LeBeau cited a 1987 survey by the East Hartford schools and the town's Youth Services Department Among the respondents in ninth grade, for example, the average age for first using alcohol was 11. For marijuana, it was 13.Programs in Other Districts
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: Besides Trumbull and East Hartford, districts using the ''Here's Looking at You, 2000'' program include Bridgeport, Fairfield and Stratford, Ms. Skerker said.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: Debra Gonet, the program leader for substance abuse prevention and intervention in the Trumbull schools, said she thought the program was particulrly effective at the elementary-school level. ''It's very natural,'' Ms. Gonet said. ''It's still fun for them.'' Ms. Traggianese, the first-grade teach at Middlebrook, said she hoped the six-week program ''develops a foundation and an awareness of what drugs are and what they do to your body.''A Puppet's Lesson
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: Using a puppet named Frog, Ms. Traggianese recently led her students through a lesson on the dangers of drugs. The puppet asked the children for advice on several unlabeled jars.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: ''You can't tell what's in those things because there's no label on them,'' one child said, pointing to the jars.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: In summing up, Ms. Traggianese cautioned: ''You can't tell what things are just by looking at them. You have to ask an adult you trust.''
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: The puppet then affixed poison labels to the jars, and the students followed suit, drawing their own labels with crayons.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: In teaching the program, Ms. Traggianese said she focused on several areas: imparting information, like the lesson about the dangers of substances, particularly unlabeled ones; joint activities and bonding to make the students feel part of a group, and decision-making, of which a key tenet is learning how to say no.Understanding Alcoholism
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: A videotape in the program focuses on an animal whose father is an alcoholic. ''It's a very hard concept for them to grasp,'' Ms. Traggianese said. ''But they do understand that the character has a problem that has to be solved.''
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: As Ms. Traggianese's pupils drew their poison labels after their lesson, they offered opinions about what they had learned from program.
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: ''I learned that even if they look like candy, they aren't,'' said Mark Fasano, 7 years old, referring to the similar appearances candy and drugs can have. ''Also, if you take bad drugs, you get really sick.'' He then named some drugs he has learned are bad: cocaine, nicotine and chewing tobacco.'Drug Can Kill'
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: Nicole Cross, 6, said Frog the puppet ''tells us to stay away from drugs.'' ''Drugs can kill you,'' she said. Another 6-year-old, Sarah Martinkainen, also discussing the dangers of drugs, said: ''It's dangerous, and you're not supposed to take it. And if you take it, you might die.'' Ms. Traggianese said she hoped to build a foundation to prevent substance abuse. ''I really want to see what happens when these kids are adolescents,'' she said. ''There always will be people abusing substances, but the more we can educate about drugs, I think the better off we will be.''
title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse

text: A 25-year-old unemployed handyman died of an undetermined cause early yesterday about 90 minutes after being arrested by housing police officers in the lobby of a public housing building.
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: Residents of the six-story building in Long Island City, Queens, said the man had been abused by the officers. He was thrown handcuffed into a squad car ''like a piece of luggage,'' one woman said.
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: But a spokesman for the Housing Authority police said the man was simply restrained by the officers, Alfred Cavanaugh, 25, and Michael Segarra, 30, after he assaulted them in a ''completely unprovoked attack.'' '' Taken to Hospital
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: The man, Richard Luke, was taken to a cell in a housing police station house nearby, where he began banging his head on the floor, the spokesman, Val Coleman, said.
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: He was then taken to the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst. Mr. Coleman said Mr. Luke had bruises on the forehead from striking his head on the floor but had no other visible injuries. He died at 12:35 A.M., the police said.
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: An autopsy was performed on Mr. Luke's body yesterday, but an exact cause of death was not determined, pending further tests, a spokeswoman for the Medical Examiner's office, Ellen Borakove, said. Pain and Anger
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: The police said two crack vials fell out of his pocket at the station house and he was charged with crack possession in addition to assault charges. Neighbors and friends said Mr. Luke smoked marijuana occasionally but was not involved with crack.
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: News of Mr. Luke's death spread quickly through the sprawling housing project, the Queensbridge Houses, prompting tenants yesterday afternoon to organize and hold a rally mixed with pain and anger. A hastily prepared flier announcing the rally was distributed throughout the housing project, a series of red-brick buildings a few blocks from the East River.
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: About 200 people left the rally site and marched to the housing police station, at 34-41 21st Avenue, and then to the Queensboro Bridge, briefly delaying early-evening traffic on both the Queens and Manhattan sides of the bridge, the police said.
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: Robert Harvey, who works with a neighborhood youth organization, the Activation Foundation, said the rally, attended by 250 people, was called because Mr. Luke was well liked in the community. Mr. Luke's mother and his fiancee said Mr. Luke supported himself through odd jobs around the neigbhorhood, most recently as a construction worker.
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: ''The mood right now is hostile,'' Mr. Harvey said. ''This isn't the first time the police have beat up somebody around here. But it's the first time someone has died.''
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: Mr. Harvey said it was still unclear just what led to Mr. Luke's death.
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: Late last night, hundreds of people milled around Mr. Luke's building, talking about the death and reminiscing about him. About 30 police officers kept watch near and around the building as two police helicopters hovered overhead with searchlights. Ran Into Apartment
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: The confrontation began to unfold shortly before 11 P.M. Sunday, when Mr. Luke ran into the apartment he shared with his sister and mother at 40-02 12th Street, said his mother, Patricia Garcia. Mrs. Garcia said he was clutching his chest and complaining that he was having difficulty breathing.
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: Mr. Luke, she said, had been an asthmatic since early childhood, but he had not had an attack in two years.
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: Mrs. Garcia said she asked him if he wanted to go to the hospital. He said no, and ran out of the apartment.
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: Meanwhile, her daughter had called an ambulance. A housing police unit was dispatched as a matter of routine to the scene to assist the paramedics, the police said. The police officers, Mrs. Garcia said, arrived first. 'Big Commotion'
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: Mrs. Garcia said she saw her son run out of the building and then run back inside, followed moments later by two police officers. ''Then the next thing I know,'' she said, ''I hear this big commotion downstairs.''
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: She said she ran down to the lobby and saw the officers struggling with her son on the floor. ''They had him pinned down,'' she said. ''I screamed, 'Don't hit him. He's sick. He needs help.' ''
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: One resident of the building, Trudie Huguley, 26, said the sound of screaming brought her out of her apartment into the lobby. She said she saw one of the officers place his nightstick around Mr. Luke's throat from behind him. 'He Looked Sick'
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: ''His mother was yelling, 'Get off my son,' '' she said. ''But the cop kept saying, 'He's resisting arrest.' He wasn't resisting arrest. He looked sick.''
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: Mrs. Garcia said the officers called for backup and about six additional officers arrived. Mr. Luke was taken to the lockup at the station house. Mrs. Garcia followed in a taxicab, she said.
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: She said at the lockup, she heard her son screaming from his cell. ''I asked them why was he screaming,'' Mrs. Garcia recalled. ''They said he had gone crazy and was banging his head on the floor. They were laughing.''
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: Mr. Coleman said the officers also called for an ambulance and for an Emergency Service unit from the City Police Department to transport Mr. Luke to a hospital.
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: ''By that time,'' Mr. Coleman said, ''we regarded him as an emotionally disturbed person.''
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: Mrs. Garcia followed her son to the hospital. ''As soon as I got there,'' she said, ''the doctor came out and told me, 'Your son is dead.' ''
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: The case is being investigated by the Housing Police Department's internal affairs unit. An Uneasy Relationship
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: Hours after Mr. Luke died, angry residents of the project stood on street corners or leaned against parked cars and discussed the events of the night before and what many described as the neighborhood's uneasy relationship with the men and women assigned to protect them.
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: ''That's a shame what happened,'' said Elizabeth Foles, 19. ''We call an ambulance and get beat up by some cops.''
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: Joanne Franklin, 31, said many residents of the housing project were angry because whenever the police entered the area, ''they come in here with negative attitudes toward us.'' 'We Want Drugs Out'
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: ''They think everything is drugs, drugs, drugs,'' she said. ''We want drugs out of the projects too, but we don't want our people killed.''
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: Mr. Coleman of the Housing Authority said the housing police had ''an excellent reputation throughout our tenant community as people who help, not hinder.''
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: At the rally at a neighborhood center in the housing project, Mr. Luke's fiancee, Sonia Munn, 25, said she and Mr. Luke had known each other eight years and had a 5-year-old daughter.
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: ''Richard had little odd-end jobs,'' she said. ''He tried to support his daughter when he could. I work full time. She's in a private school. But I'm worried about her. I told her that her father died and that he's in Heaven. She's not accepting it. She said: 'No, no. My daddy is going to come back.' ''
title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault

text: Drug and alcohol abuse have emerged as a major reason for the homelessness of men, women and families, complicating the search for solutions, advocates for the homeless say.
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Although poverty and a lack of affordable housing contribute significantly to the problem of homelessness, experts said alcohol and drug addiction can no longer be ignored as an important factor.
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: ''Substance abuse is one of the major issues causing people to be homeless and keeping them homeless,'' said Irving Shandler, who runs the Diagnostic and Rehabilitation Center in Philadelphia, a private group that has worked for 26 years to help people overcome homelessness.
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Drug and alcohol abuse ''is the nasty little secret of the homeless,'' said Ernest Drucker, an associate professor of social medicine and epidemiology at Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York.
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Advocates like Robert M. Hayes, director of the National Coalition for the Homeless, a group with headquarters in New York, say they have shied away from discussing the problem of addiction in the past, in part because they feared that the public would lose its sympathy for the homeless. But ''the bottom line,'' he said, ''is that we have to tell the truth.''
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Advocates for the homeless say drug or alcohol abuse send people who may have only a fingerhold on society into a tailspin. Eventually they deplete their resources, lose their jobs and alienate friends or family members who cease to want to help. They end up on the streets, destitute and hopelessly addicted. And once they are addicted and homeless, there are few opportunities for drug treatment.
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Just as there are no precise data on how many people are homeless, there are none on what percentage of homeless people are addicts. The answers homeless people give to questions about substance abuse can be unreliable. Estimates Vary
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Tom Taylor, who runs Joshua House in Washington, a residence that helps homeless men rejoin society, estimates that at least 90 percent of the men he sees are addicts. Others, including Peter Smith, director of the Partnership for the Homeless, whose group surveyed political leaders and providers of services for the homeless, estimate that the number for men and women combined is 30 percent to 40 percent. The mentally ill constitute 20 percent to 30 percent of the homeless population, and many of them are also addicts, experts say.
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Some experts contend that the reason for the lower estimates is that some advocacy groups fear that if they report high percentages of addicts among the homeless, people will no longer contribute money. Donald Hendrix, the interim executive director of Central City Concerns, a group in Portland, Ore., that helps house homeless people, explained, ''If you are trying to raise money, you depend very heavily on the public's perception.''
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: ''There is something to that charge,'' Mr. Hayes said, adding that television news programs and Congressional committees ''always want white, middle-class people'' to appear. ''They want someone who will be sympathetic to middle America.''
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: When the public contributes money, said Mr. Shandler, ''they want to spend it on the 'deserving' homeless - that nice family that worked hard all those years.''
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: ''I'm sure there are some families in that category,'' he said, ''but my guess is that a significant number of them have their problems exacerbated by drug or alcohol abuse. You can feel sorry for them without failing to recognize that they may be out there because they have problems.'' Crack Making the Problem Worse
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Whatever the number, ''addiction is a horrendous problem,'' among the homeless, Mr. Hayes said. Because of crack, ''the homeless population is going up quite dramatically,'' he said, adding, ''I think almost everyone longs for the good old days when they were only dealing with heroin addicts.''
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Experts who are finding a substantial drug problem among the homeless include Paul Koegel, an anthropologist at the University of California at Los Angeles who interviewed homeless men living on the streets in downtown Los Angeles and found that close to 50 percent were addicts. They also include Kostas Gounis, an anthropologist at Columbia University, who interviewed men arriving at the Franklin Avenue shelter in the South Bronx and found that 75 percent were addicts. Mr. Shandler found that the problem is just as severe among women as among men.
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Advocates who work with families find that addiction often puts poor families on the street. For example, John Fullinwider, director of Common Ground, a housing organization in Dallas that works with homeless families, said drug addiction ''is a real problem.'' Often, he said, a poor family becomes homeless because at least one member is an addict and ''the economy of the family collapses.''
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Dr. Peter Laqueur, director for AIDS programs at Woodhull Medical Center in Brooklyn, found when he was working in a Federally financed program to help heroin addicts that half of 290 addicts who came to the hospital for other medical problems had no homes.
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Mr. Hayes, who is a lawyer, said he is now going to court in several states, including New York, to sue for treatment upon demand for drug addicts. He said he sees drug treatment as at least as important as housing for the homeless.
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: The lack of low-cost housing, the issue that has gotten the most attention in the politics of homelessness, is still a factor, advocates say, but it too is related to drugs. Mr. Hayes likens the search for low-cost housing to the survival of the fittest. Those who are addicts lose. ''In a sense, crack is defining who will be the losers in that Darwinian competition for housing,'' he said. Shelters May Add to Problems
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: But even when housing is available, no one wants to live near drug addicts, those who work with the homeless are finding. Mr. Hendrix of Central City Concerns said that his group has 800 single room occupancy units but ''what we are seeing now is that the people who are coming into our buildings are people we can't house because of behavior problems.'' Crack abuse, he said, makes them ''aggressive and violent.''
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Experts say that shelters only make the drug problem among the homeless worse. Although shelters are supposed to be drug-free, drug use is often open and widespread, say shelter directors and advocates for the homeless. Many shelter residents actually have jobs, but they spend all their money on drugs, these experts say.
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Groups that try to help bring people back from homelessness are finding that they must confront the drug problem first. Jack M. White, executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless in Washington, which is not associated with Mr. Hayes's group, said that when he started a residence two years ago to help homeless men find jobs and apartments, he began by simply asking the men not to use drugs or abuse alcohol. Only 5 percent made it through the four-month program. He then decided to insititute random urine tests for the residents and staff and to evict anyone using drugs. His success rate is now 75 percent. Facing the Problem
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: The Rev. Jack Pfannenstiel, a Franciscan priest who runs six shelters in Washington for men and women and who also directs McKenna House, a residential program that helps men come back from homelessness, said that when he and two other Franciscans began McKenna House in 1985, they did not fully appreciate the substance abuse problem. They reasoned that homeless men can hardly apply for a job when they have no way of keeping clean, when they have to carry all of their belongings with them everywhere they go, and when they have no telephone number for employers to call. Shelter life was self-perpetuating, they suspected.
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: ''Our initial premise was that if you provide food, shelter and hygiene, then they will be able to help themselves,'' Father Pfannenstiel said. ''We were naive about the drug and alcohol problem.''
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Within a few months, they learned that ''we were able to help the men find jobs, but they would get into the same cycle of financial mismanagement,'' Father Pfannenstiel said. ''The big picture that we missed was that this was tied into the abuse of drugs and alcohol. We learned that sobriety maintenance was the big key.''
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Now men who come to McKenna House must refrain from using drugs or alcohol for a month beforehand. About half of the 400 men who have lived there have permanently rejoined society. Those who have failed, Father Pfannensteil said, went back to their substance abuse.
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: He added that a major reason the men became addicts again is that they were lonely. Part of breaking addiction is to end all contacts with drug-using friends. Many of these men had no one to turn to and ended up seeing their old friends again, joining them eventually in using drugs and becoming homeless once more. Drug Programs Are Few
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Simply asking most homeless men to solve their addiction problems can be an exercise in futility, advocates for the homeless say.
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Gary Blasi, who directs the homelessness project for the Legal Aid Foundation in Los Angeles and who is president-elect of the Coalition for the Homeless, said the drug treatment programs in Los Angeles are ''completely ludicrous.'' He said that there are 50,000 to 100,000 homeless people in Los Angeles County but only 20 to 25 beds available for them in residential treatment programs. ''It's as if treatment doesn't exist,'' he said. ''You'd have a bettter chance of winning the lottery.''
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Some homeless men have had to commit acts of desperation to get drug treatment. Earl McPherson, a Washington man who started drinking beer and smoking marijuana when he was 12 years old, found himself addicted to crack and ''any mood-altering substance'' by the age of 25.
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: As he found himself becoming unable to function, he lost his job, lost his apartment, sold his car, and moved in with his mother. When his mother finally kicked him out, it was a cold, snowy day and Mr. McPherson said he felt he could fall no lower. He had applied to a residential drug treatment program at D.C. General Hospital, but, he said, he was in 397th place on the list. So Mr. McPherson camped out in the hospital emergency room for five days.
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: ''I told them I wouldn't go back out there until I got help,'' he said. ''I told them I would kill myself if they didn't admit me.'' He got in.
title: Twins of the Streets: Homelessness and Addiction

text: Swarming over trucks at the Mexican border, drilling tiny holes in the ribs of cargo containers at ports and airports, members of the National Guard have begun carrying out a $300 million program that expands the role of the military in anti-drug efforts.
title: Guard Members Begin Anti-Drug Duties on Border

text: In California and 11 other states, National Guard members are being mobilized in support of Customs Service agents in a program that is expected to eventually involve Guard units all over the nation.
title: Guard Members Begin Anti-Drug Duties on Border

text: In the program approved by Congress last July and started this month, $40 million has been designated for support duties by the National Guard for this fiscal year. Of that amount, $25.2 million has already been allocated to specific projects proposed by the states, said Dan Donohue, a spokesman at the National Guard headquarters in Washington.
title: Guard Members Begin Anti-Drug Duties on Border

text: The rest of the $300 million is to finance support work by active-duty military units, which would be confined to secondary roles like providing transportation, training or lending vehicles and equipment.
title: Guard Members Begin Anti-Drug Duties on Border

text: The military has at times assisted with anti-drug efforts but usually been in conjunction with regular duties. The Pentagon in the past has opposed expanding the military's role in stopping the flow of drugs into the United States, expressing concerns that this role would interfere with traditional duties and questioning the propriety of the armed forces' becoming involved in civilian police activities.
title: Guard Members Begin Anti-Drug Duties on Border

text: The guard members have been given a narrow function which does not include making arrests or confiscating material, said Maj. Robert Dunlap at National Guard headquarters.
title: Guard Members Begin Anti-Drug Duties on Border

text: Last August, about 100 Guard members were involved in a test program along the Mexican border under state control but using Federal money.
title: Guard Members Begin Anti-Drug Duties on Border

text: In California, one of the first states to implement the program, Guard members in fatigues, many wearing Military Police armbands, carried out thorough searches of trucks crossing the border from Mexico at Otay Mesa, a small checkpoint near San Diego. The unannounced checks caused delays. Dogs and Drills
title: Guard Members Begin Anti-Drug Duties on Border

text: Other Guard members joined Customs agents at the ports of Long Beach and Los Angeles, checking cargo containers with the help of specially trained dogs and using drills and probes to inspect the metal reinforcements of 40-foot containers.
title: Guard Members Begin Anti-Drug Duties on Border

text: John Miller, a spokesman for the United States Customs Service in Los Angeles, said Guard members would work side by side with Customs agents who inspect more than 1.5 million of the containers each year at the two ports. He estimated that only 5 to 10 percent of the drugs entering through these ports were being seized.
title: Guard Members Begin Anti-Drug Duties on Border

text: Mr. Donohue said Guard members were transporting law enforcement officials to and from sites where drugs often come across the border, performing aerial reconnaisance and lending equipment such as night vision radar and flight jackets.
title: Guard Members Begin Anti-Drug Duties on Border

text: Customs and National Guard officials would give few details of the times and places of the joint searches.
title: Guard Members Begin Anti-Drug Duties on Border

text: ''If we told in advance which port is having 100 percent container inspections on a given day, the ships would avoid docking in that area,'' Mr. Miller said. He said he did not want to scare off drug dealers who might be waiting to receive shipments. Participants in the program said they were keeping their options open. ''If the seizure rate goes up 10-fold or 20-fold, there's reason to assume that the folks smuggling the drugs will find another way to get them into the country,'' said Maj. Steve Mensik, a spokesman for the California National Guard.
title: Guard Members Begin Anti-Drug Duties on Border

text: He said seizures of hashish at the ports rose from just 14 pounds in 1986 to 88,000 pounds last year, from 68,000 pounds to 125,000 pounds of marijuana, from 211 pounds to 1,200 pounds of opium and from 1,300 pounds to 18,000 pounds of cocaine.
title: Guard Members Begin Anti-Drug Duties on Border

text: Major Dunlap said National Guard operations had already begun in Alabama, Florida, Louisiana and Texas as well as California. Programs have also been approved for Arizona, Georgia, Hawaii, Mississippi, New Mexico, Oregon and the state of Washington.
title: Guard Members Begin Anti-Drug Duties on Border

text: For years, the rules of life for the residents of the Rockwell Gardens public housing project here were decreed by armed young men patrolling the corridors. They decided who came and went. Sometimes they charged a toll. Sometimes they issued a curfew to residents so gang members could make drug deals without being disturbed.
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: ''We had lost control,'' said Vince Lane, chairman of the Chicago Housing Authority. ''The gangs would not even permit our employees to come in and clean the building.''
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: So Mr. Lane decided to clean house. He sent a team of police and housing authority guards into the building to search apartments for weapons and to chase away anyone not authorized to be inside.
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: In eight such crackdowns since last fall, the authorities have ousted more than 400 people from Rockwell Gardens and other subsidized housing projects that are home to 140,000 people here, Some, found in possession of drugs or weapons, have been arrested; others were just routed from the premises. 'Operation Clean Sweep'
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: The crackdown, ''Operation Clean Sweep,'' has won praise from Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, who has urged housing officials in other cities to view the Chicago move as ''a model for the rest of the country.'' Mr. Kemp has pledged a crackdown on drug dealers and abusers in public housing projects, saying he will seek to deny them access to public housing and to evict those who are already tenants.
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: The Chicago effort is largely aimed at removing people who do not live in the public housing projects, people who, according to police estimates, commit about 80 percent of the crime there.
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: Chicago officials are also moving against residents of the housing projects whose apartments have been linked to drug use and drug dealing. Three families were evicted in March, after the police found cocaine, marijuana and heroin in their apartments, under the authority of a Federal law enacted last year that permits takeover of rental units ''used in any manner to facilitate drug offenses.''
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: The inspections here at first prompted objections by the American Civil Liberties Union, which charged in a lawsuit that the privacy rights of tenants were being abridged. But the housing authorities have largely quelled the objections by agreeing not to search drawers or medicine cabinets, as they had initially done. Under the agreement with the A.C.L.U., police officers must wait in the corridors outside an apartment during inspections, and not enter the homes unless the housing authorities find ''probable suspicion'' of criminal activity. A.C.L.U. Stress on Rights
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: ''Public housing residents are human beings, citizens with rights,'' said Jay A. Miller, executive director of the Illinois branch of the A.C.L.U. ''They should not be treated as a priori criminals.''
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: But there has been little objection to the sweeps among the residents in Rockwell Gardens, one of a cluster of concrete projects on this city's dangerous West Side.
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: ''Before the crackdown,'' said Mildred Worthem, ''kids couldn't sit on the playground for 30 minutes without having to scatter because of the gunfire.''
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: In the sweeps, the authorities found numerous instances in which gang members had forced residents to share their homes. Sometimes the gang members stayed in the apartments for an hour, sometimes for months.
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: After a sweep, gang members usually move to another building, turning more public housing residents into virtual hostages. But housing authority officials say they hope to curtail the gang activity in all of the projects eventually.
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: After a sweep has been conducted, the walls are cleaned of graffiti. Empty apartments, which gang members often use as their offices, are closed off. Broken light fixtures in darkened hallways are replaced. New security doors are installed at entranceways. And guards have been stationed inside the buildings around the clock. Living Still Not Easy
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: To be sure, it is still not easy living in Rockwell Gardens. Yoletha Woodard, whose children are the fourth generation to live in the project, said the sweeps did not catch all the troublemakers.
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: Just last month, she said, she watched from her kitchen window as a group of boys - ''they looked no more than 13'' - brutally kicked and punched an elderly man as he lay screaming for mercy.
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: The man, who had crashed his car against a building in the alley after suffering a diabetic attack, later died of the injuries, housing officials said.
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: Ms. Woodard, 33 years old, said she still sees the young men ''with their caps turned to the side,'' a sign of a gang affiliation, roaming the hallways occasionally.
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: ''But they used to be outside your door all the time,'' she said. ''They'd be drinking, smoking reefers. If you had somewhere to go, too bad. You stay inside. It's a lot better now.''
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: For years, Lynda Johnson slept on the floor with her baby. She had to stay low, she explained, in case bullets came through the window.
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: On the first night after the sweep at Rockwell Gardens, Mrs. Johnson said she had trouble falling asleep.
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: ''It was too quiet,'' said Mrs. Johnson, cradling her 10-month-old baby, Amandia. ''I was used to the gunfire.''
title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing

text: By Joseph F. Sullivan, Special To the New York Times
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: Through a grim form of ''show and tell,'' a group of Hudson County students is trying to counter the peer pressure that leads many of their friends to experiment with drugs.
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: The teen-agers are the stars of a film, ''Dead End,'' that tells about three students with problems at home who are led into drug use by their friends. The 23-minute film, produced for use in county schools, depicts the death of one student and leaves the future of the other two -even one who tries rehabilitation - unclear.
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: ''The message is not that everybody lived happily ever after,'' the producer, Ray Blanco, said. ''Nobody would buy that. But we're trying to say that no matter what problems there are in life, drugs are not an answer.'' 'Typical' Families Portrayed
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: The emotions that the film is apt to engender surfaced last year in casting. One student tearfully revealed that he wanted to be in the film because his mother had died from drug abuse. He was immediately surrounded and embraced by the other students.
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: All the actors are from high schools in the county and attend a three-year-old performing-arts program at the county's vocational-technical high school.
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: The families in the film, composites of ''typical'' Hudson families drawn by a committee of educators, health officials and alcohol and drug counselors, include a white middle-class couple who work and spend their weekends drinking. They often leave their daughter, who retreats into the music on her headphones, to fend for herself.
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: The second family has a loving Hispanic grandmother who dotes on her grandson, but does not recognize signs of his addiction, even when he eats dinner with heavy-lidded eyes and pokes at his food. The third family is black. Its turmoil is fueled by a drinking father and an older brother who is an addict.
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: The three students find drugs everywhere. Drug-using students, their baseball caps askew or backward, offer marijuana in a school bathroom, involve the students in a cocaine purchase on the streets, and, in the climax, lure two of them to a party in an abandoned building where a girl, Nancy, suffers a seizure and dies after smoking crack. No Happy Ending
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: The drug users flee, leaving Ramon, whose slow involvement in substance abuse began with sipping whisky in his bedroom, kneeling by his friend's side. Al, the black student whose brother is an addict and who began experimenting, too, did not go to the party. But he arrives on the scene as Nancy is dying and watches in disbelief through a window.
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: Ramon enters rehabilitation and is last seen playing basketball in the school gymnasium. When he looks toward the stands, he imagines he still sees Nancy sitting there.
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: Al returns home to witness a confrontation between his father and brother and retreats to his room, where he padlocks his dresser drawers to keep his brother from stealing his belongings to buy drugs.
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: Although the scenes involving drugs appear authentic and spontaneous, all the actors said they had not used drugs, but had known friends who were users.
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: Kevin Manjarrez, 16 years old, of Harrison High School, who effectively portrayed Ramon, said he spent time with drug-using friends ''to get the feel.'' Asked whether he tried to talk them out of drug use, he said:
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: ''It wouldn't do any good. I'm just hoping they see the film and it has some effect on them.'' 'Don't Smoke Cigarettes, Either'
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: Jennifer Giordan, 16, of Dickinson High School, who played Nancy, said: ''If you try to say something to anyone about drugs, they say you sound just like their parents. We hope they'll see the film and say, 'I don't want anything like that to happen to me.' ''
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: The crack she smoked was an ordinary cigarette. ''But the coughing and choking were real,'' she said. ''I don't smoke cigarettes, either.''
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: Joe Millroy, 18, of Harrison, who played a drug-using student, told of a former girlfriend who used drugs. ''I was afraid that if she got arrested, I'd get picked up, too,'' he said. ''So I told her she had to choose between the drugs and me. She stopped using the drugs.''
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: Raul Soto, also 18 and from Harrison, said the shock value in the film was important. ''We have to go beyond Nancy Reagan and Just Say No,'' he said. ''The kids out on the streets see the dealers with the gold chains and the fancy cars, and we have to make them see beyond those images and think about the consequences.'' Strong Scenes, No Preaching
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: The film was the idea of the County Coordinator of Alcohol and Drug Abuse Programs, Iris Done, who lobbied for more than two years for the $30,000 to produce it.
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: ''Youngsters today watch a lot of television and film, so we felt this would be the best way to try to get the message across,'' she said.
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: Because of the strong scenes - there is little dialogue, to avoid any semblance of preaching - the film will be shown in connection with a study guide, to help teachers lead discussions that the film is expected to generate. ''This film could open some wounds, and we wouldn't want to show it without being prepared to offer help to those who may need it,'' Ms. Done said.
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: Mr. Blanco, whose Cutting Edge Productions was hired to produce the film, said he tried to make action rather than dialogue carry the message to the audience. ''The ideal would have been a music video,'' he said. ''They understand images better than we do.''
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: The film, which had its premiere on Wednesday night before an audience of 200 at the Park Theater here, was made because films about drugs have been unconvincing, County Executive Robert C. Janiszewski said.
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: ''They all show adults - educators, psychologists and counselors - talking at kids, while everyone will tell you the biggest influence in a youngster's life is peer pressure,'' he said. ''This film is an effort to reverse or capitalize on the strength of peer pressure and turn it to our advantage.''
title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs

text: By Jeffrey Schmalz, Special To the New York Times
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: It's merely a television show. Yet when the last episode of ''Miami Vice'' is broadcast Sunday night, an important chapter in this city's life will close.
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: The end of the series, which ran five seasons, has been marked here with parties and an auction of its props. But most important, it has been marked by reflection on just how much one television show - and a fictional cops-and-robbers one at that - came to influence the perception that this city has of itself and that many elsewhere in the country have of Miami.
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: ''The show that redefined Miami's image,'' The Miami Herald called it recently in what many Floridians would not view as hyperbole.
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: From its start, in September 1984, the hourlong NBC show reaffirmed and exaggerated what was already in the news pages about Miami: crime and drugs. The world portrayed on ''Miami Vice'' was a world of cocaine cowboys and marijuana millionaires killing one another and being killed by two police detectives who wore expensive loafers (without socks) and chic European designer suits that no honest real detective could afford.
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: But the show also sent out to more than 19 million homes around the country what was not in the newspapers: that Miami was a city of suntanned youth, not solely of retired elderly people; that it was a city with a distinctive slick architectural style and sexy subtropical beauty.
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: As life imitated television, many here believe, Miami began to change, as if to live up to the screen's distilled image of it, an image that was conveyed by camera work of a rock-video style with background music to match. Suddenly the pastel T-shirts favored by the show's characters, in particular Sonny Crockett, played by Don Johnson, were de rigueur at cocktail parties. And as the show featured Art Deco buildings painted in pastel pinks, greens and blues - in effect anointing that as the official Miami look - more and more Miami buildings took on those hues.
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: The show's cameras repeatedly focused on South Beach, then a somewhat seedy enclave at the southern tip of Miami Beach's Art Deco area, and preservationists credit ''Miami Vice'' with stirring interest in the area and speeding its gentrification. So chic and trendy are the clubs and the outdoor cafes of this new South Beach that it has taken on an acronym, SoBe (pronounced SO-bee).
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: ''When we got there, the Art Deco district was somewhat threadbare,'' said Anthony Yerkovich, who came up with the concept of the show. ''Now it's up to its Ray Bans in espresso.''
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: Although some municipal officials were at first upset at the title ''Miami Vice,'' arguing that it put the city in a bad light, the name was later not merely accepted but also mimicked everywhere. Now there are Miami Mice (an exterminator), Miami Twice (a secondhand-clothing store), Miami Spice (a seasonings shop), Miami Nice (a chiropractor) and Miami Slice (a luncheonette).
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: So there is no disputing that ''Miami Vice'' had an effect on this city. But what is still disputed is whether, on the whole, the image of Miami has been burnished or tarnished.
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: Miami takes a perverse delight in being known as the new Casablanca, a city with an edge. But with a recent resurgence in crime and after a race riot in January, some Miamians say it is just as well that the show is ending, that maybe Miami is perceived as having a bit too much edge these days.
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: ''The show fell into a pattern of one gorgeous location shot after another, palm trees and architecture,'' said Michael C. R. Collins, vice president for marketing of the Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau. ''But if that beautiful moment turns into a bloodbath two out of five times, I'm not sure that imagery can any longer be deemed constructive for us.''
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: Nor could the imagery sustain the fad for more than half a decade. For the last year or so, the show, which in its peak season was one of the nine top-rated programs on the air, has fared poorly nationwide in the ratings, coming in third among the three network offerings for the time period. Even here it has been running third lately, with Miamians tuning in instead to the story of another town, the soap opera ''Dallas.''
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: This is not the first time that a television show has influenced the perception of Miami, a city that draws its livelihood from tourism and is therefore especially vulnerable to the vagaries of image. In the 1960's, Jackie Gleason's variety program opened with a shot from a helicopter zipping along Miami Beach and an announcer proclaiming the city ''the sun and fun capital of the world.''
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: But it has been different with ''Miami Vice.'' That the show was shot in rock-video style, offering a rapid-fire series of vivid images, made the settings not just backdrops for the scenes, but key to them. It was as if the city itself were a character in the show.
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: ''I wanted the city to serve as a protagonist, as a co-star,'' said Mr. Yerkovich, who created the show and was an early writer but has not been associated with it recently.
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: He said he had been drawn to Miami as the series' setting because of its reputation for drug deals and money laundering. ''I wanted a city in which the American dream had been distilled into something perverse,'' Mr. Yerkovich added. ''Before I get calls from the Chamber of Commerce, let me say that I wanted to use the city figuratively and metaphorically. I wanted to place an existential hero in a city based on greed.''
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: And has his portrayal of Miami been fair to Miami? ''I'm not a member of the Chamber of Commerce,'' he said.
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: Fair portrayal or not, reruns of ''Miami Vice'' are already in syndication in the United States and Europe.
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: ''I think,'' said Tony Goldman, the owner of more than a dozen South Beach hotels and restaurants, ''that it brought the image of the mystic and magic and even danger to Miami, sort of the old sense of Marseilles. Did you know that when you talk to Europeans, they talk about 'Miami Vice' before they talk about Miami?''
title: Miami Journal; Sun Sets on Show That Redefined a City

text: Columbia University completed its 235th academic year yesterday with a commencement that had two features conspicuously absent from the ceremony last year, a Polish dissident and sunshine.
title: Polish Dissident Given Degree One Year Late

text: Last year, as rain poured on graduates and forced the university president, Michael I. Sovern, to forgo his speech, an empty chair was left on the dais to protest Poland's refusal to allow a dissident historian, Prof. Bronislaw Geremek, out of the country to accept an honorary degree. Dr. Sovern pledged then that an empty seat would remain at each commencement until Professor Geremek was given the degree.
title: Polish Dissident Given Degree One Year Late

text: Professor Geremek was in the chair this year, under suddenly sunny skies, and he received a doctorate of letters. He is not only allowed to travel outside Poland, but he is also seeking office, as a candidate for a new parliament established under an agreement between the Polish Government and Solidarity. Mr. Geremek is an adviser to the union movement.
title: Polish Dissident Given Degree One Year Late

text: ''Professor Geremek's absence and now his presence reminds us forcefully of the alternating currents of futility and hope that run through our time,'' Dr. Sovern told the 7,300 graduates and 18,000 spectators in front of Low Memorial Library on Morningside Heights. ''In Poland and the Soviet Union, China and Afghanistan, Central America, Southern Africa, the Middle East, from year to year and day to day, the shining rays of optimism seem ready to brighten the darkness of old realities one moment, to flicker and die the next.'' 'Very Special for Me'
title: Polish Dissident Given Degree One Year Late

text: The words had particular meaning for Petre Petru Motiu, a former judo coach who defected from Rumania three years ago and was among the graduates yesterday. The Rumanian Government did not allow Mr. Motiu's fiancee, Mariana Ploscaru, to leave the country and attend the commencement, in which Mr. Motiu received a bachelor's degree.
title: Polish Dissident Given Degree One Year Late

text: After the ceremony, Professor Geremek said he was deeply moved by Columbia's pledge to maintain the empty seat. ''It was very special for me and I will never forget it,'' he said.
title: Polish Dissident Given Degree One Year Late

text: The graduation also included the first deaf student to graduate from the law school. The student, Michael Tecklenburg, recalled that in his first semester he had tried to read the lips of lecturers. But the legal language they used, he said, was barely intelligible, even to the unimpaired, and so he used an interpreter hired by the university.
title: Polish Dissident Given Degree One Year Late

text: Rick Leach, the Texas Rangers outfielder who disappeared in New York for 24 hours earlier this week and was issued a summons for marijuana possession, has been ordered to undergo drug counseling and testing, the baseball commissioner's office said yesterday.
title: Counseling for Leach

text: Leach agreed to undergo medical evaluation here after the incident. After studying results of the evaluation, the commissioner's office said he could ''participate as an active member of the Rangers as long as he cooperates fully with the counseling and testing requirements of the program.'' He will rejoin the Rangers in Kansas City today.(AP)
title: Counseling for Leach

text: Rick Leach, the Texas player who disappeared for 24 hours earlier in the week, underwent medical evaluation yesterday and, a baseball source said, he will begin a counseling program for an unspecified reason.
title: Evaluation For Leach

text: Leach declined to discuss any aspect of his disappearance or his treatment. ''I can't say anything at this point,'' said Leach, an outfielder-designated hitter. The source declined to say why Leach had to have counseling, saying only that the doctor thought it was appropriate.
title: Evaluation For Leach

text: After Leach failed to appear at Yankee Stadium for a game Monday night, the Rangers filed a missing persons report with the police. In investigating the player's whereabouts, the police found a packet of marijuana in his hotel room and issued him a summons for possession of a controlled substance.
title: Evaluation For Leach

text: Leach, who reappeared Tuesday afternoon, met Wednesday with representatives of the commissioner's office and the Players Association and agreed to remain in New York and undergo medical evaluation while the Rangers moved on to Kansas City.
title: Evaluation For Leach

text: Leach was to remain in New York until today while the counseling program was set up. He was expected to rejoin the Rangers tonight or tomorrow in Kansas City.
title: Evaluation For Leach

text: The House today impeached Federal District Judge Walter L. Nixon of Mississippi, who is serving a five-year sentence for perjury, and sent the case to the Senate for trial. The vote was 417 to 0.
title: Impeachment Voted; Federal Judge Faces A Trial in the Senate

text: The Senate will determine whether Judge Nixon will be removed from office and deprived of the $89,500 annual salary he has been collecting while serving his sentence at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida. A two-thirds vote by the Senate is required for removal.
title: Impeachment Voted; Federal Judge Faces A Trial in the Senate

text: The Senate is now holding an impeachment trial for Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings of Florida. He was acquitted in a criminal court in 1983 on charges of conspiracy to receive a $150,000 bribe, but lawmakers are seeking his removal, saying there is ample evidence of wrongdoing.
title: Impeachment Voted; Federal Judge Faces A Trial in the Senate

text: Federal District Judge Harry Claiborne of Nevada was impeached by the House in 1986 while serving a tax-evasion sentence and later removed from the bench by the Senate. Convicted of Perjury
title: Impeachment Voted; Federal Judge Faces A Trial in the Senate

text: Judge Nixon was convicted of perjury after denying in 1984 before a Federal grand jury and Justice Department investigators that he intervened in a narcotics case involving the son of a Hattiesburg, Miss., businessman.
title: Impeachment Voted; Federal Judge Faces A Trial in the Senate

text: Judge Nixon was acquitted of accepting an illegal gratuity, but evidence presented at his trial and developed in an impeachment investigation by the House showed that Judge Nixon discussed the marijuana case with the Forrest County District Attorney.
title: Impeachment Voted; Federal Judge Faces A Trial in the Senate

text: After Judge Nixon's acquittal, the Hattiesburg businessman, Wiley Fairchild, pleaded guilty to a charge of providing Judge Nixon with an improper gratuity in the form of an oil and gas investment in 1981. Judge Nixon paid with $9,500 in promissory notes, and he collected royalties totaling $60,000.
title: Impeachment Voted; Federal Judge Faces A Trial in the Senate

text: The written agreement between the two was backdated one year to a time before Mr. Fairchild's son, Drew Fairchild, the manager of the Hattiesburg airport, was indicted on charges of helping to smuggle a ton of marijuana through the airport. Envisions a Return
title: Impeachment Voted; Federal Judge Faces A Trial in the Senate

text: Judge Nixon's lawyers have argued that many of the answers that he gave to the grand jury were technically correct and that others did not constitute an impeachable offense.
title: Impeachment Voted; Federal Judge Faces A Trial in the Senate

text: Judge Nixon has collected more than $286,000 in salary since his conviction and has been saying he plans to return to the bench and preside over cases when he is released.
title: Impeachment Voted; Federal Judge Faces A Trial in the Senate

text: The three articles of impeachment said Judge Nixon ''has raised substantial doubt as to his judicial integrity, undermined confidence in the integrity and impartiality of the judiciary, betrayed the trust of the people of the United States and brought disrepute on the Federal courts and the administration of justice.''
title: Impeachment Voted; Federal Judge Faces A Trial in the Senate

text: He was hanged as a bandit on May 3, 1909, his death mourned by the poor he had defended and celebrated by the government that had placed a hefty bounty on his head. But 80 years after his death, Jesus Malverde is a source of civic pride here, venerated as a saint by common people throughout northwestern Mexico.
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: On the streets of this prosperous but violent city of 600,000, notorious throughout Mexico as the center of the country's drug trade, cars cruise with bumper stickers reading ''I H Malverde.'' Butcher shops, gas stations, laundries, even a baseball team, are named for him, and his deeds are celebrated in folk songs with titles such as ''First God and Then Malverde'' and ''Malverde the Miraculous.''
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: In his own lifetime, Malverde was regarded as something of a Mexican Robin Hood: a robber, yes, but one who shared his takings with exploited peasants. Over the years, however, the mustachioed brigand in the red bandanna has grown even larger in stature, as his rapidly growing legion of followers gives him credit for any number of miracles large and small.
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: ''I have heard of other cases in which a bandit becomes a popular hero,'' said Oscar Liera, author of ''The Horseman of the Divine Providence,'' a 1984 play about the life of Malverde that has been performed throughout Mexico and has just been made into a movie. ''But this is the only instance I can think of in which a bandit has been made into a saint.'' Crutches Are Left Behind
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: The center of the cult is the Malverde Chapel here, a gaudy blue and orange structure of cement blocks and plastic glass just a few feet away from a busy railroad yard.
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: Inside, the altars and walls are festooned with busts of Malverde, as well as crosses, coffins, human hair and other offerings. The once-crippled leave their crutches and trusses, fishermen grateful for a good catch leave bottles containing giant shrimp, parents leave pictures of their robust children, and farmers leave photographs of cows and horses that once were lost but now are found.
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: ''To the spirit of Jesus Malverde for interceding on my behalf, I give thanks for the two miracles conceded to me: my graduation and my marriage,'' says a note left by one Delia Maria Alvarez Castro.
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: With the rise of drug trafficking here in recent years, both in the form of marijuana and poppy grown locally as well as cocaine being shipped through from South America, Malverde has also become closely identified with the drug trade. Well-known traffickers are said to come regularly to the chapel to leave tokens of their appreciation after big shipments successfully elude the police and arrive in the United States. Visitors Arrive in Big Cars
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: ''I would not want to go so far as to say that Malverde is the protector of the narcos,'' said Mr. Liera, who teaches Latin American literature at the Autonomous University of Sinaloa here. ''But if you go to the shrine at night, you will see these guys in cowboy hats, full of jewelry, gold chains and fancy watches, pulling up in their big cars with the smoked glass windows.''
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: Eligio Gonzalez Leon, caretaker of the shrine, said indignantly that ''Malverde is not the patron saint of the narcos.'' But when pressed about the source of the donations that keep the chapel flourishing, he said: ''Malverde protects all of humanity. Any person can seek his protection.''
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: Since the chapel opened in 1983, 6,859 letters imploring Malverde for help have been received there. Mr. Gonzalez said that many of those requests had been answered with money donated by followers of Malverde and that he had also used donations to buy 500 wheelchairs and to pay the costs of burying hundreds of people too poor to pay for their own funerals.
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: The Roman Catholic bishop of Culiacan and other church officials were not available for comment on the Malverde phenomenon. But Mr. Gonzalez said, ''The church has never complained to me.'' The Source of the Legend
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: The real Malverde is believed to have been born in 1870 and to have worked as a shoemaker before taking to the hills and beginning his career in crime. His ability to outwit the police was widely admired here since, as a character in Mr. Liera's play puts it, ''venerating Malverde is a way of defying the bad government we have,'' and his death has similarly been transformed into a symbol of protest.
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: ''They hanged him from a mesquite tree after he was already dead,'' said Mr. Gonzalez, recounting one of several versions of Malverde's death heard here. ''He had told a compadre of his that once he died his body should be handed over to the rural police so that the reward could be collected.''
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: As legend has it, the authorities forbade the burial of the body, intending that it be displayed as an example to would-be lawbreakers. But the common folk began piling rocks at the foot of the tree, and continued to do so until the corpse was covered.
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: The site of the hanging remained the center of devotion to Malverde until this decade, when the state of Sinaloa decided to build the new Government Palace directly across the street. The chapel was shifted a few hundred yards away, and the original hanging ground became a vacant lot, in which people still pile stones and flowers.
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: But it is widely believed here that Malverde himself was not happy with the move and has placed a curse on the government offices. ''Even now, anytime we hear a strange sound, we say, oh, it's Malverde again,'' said Francisco Jalomo Espinoza, a state employee who works in the building.
title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo

text: Rick Leach, the Texas Rangers' designated hitter, who did not show up for the game with the Yankees Monday night, reappeared yesterday afternoon. When he did, he learned he had received a summons for having marijuana in his luggage.
title: Rangers' Leach Is Questioned

text: Tom Grieve, the team's general manager, heard from Leach around 2:30 P.M., and went to get him shortly afterward. They arrived at Yankee Stadium at about 7 P.M., a half-hour before game time.
title: Rangers' Leach Is Questioned

text: The police said that in investigating Leach's disappearance at the club's request, they had found a packet of marijuana in his luggage. They issued him a summons for possession of a controlled substance. Rich Levin, a spokesman for the commissioner's office said, when asked about the summons, ''It's something we'll have to review.''
title: Rangers' Leach Is Questioned

text: When Grieve was asked about it, he said, ''We won't have any comment on any police reports.''
title: Rangers' Leach Is Questioned

text: Grieve and Leach appeared at a brief news conference before the game. Neither would say where Leach had been or why he missed Monday night's game.
title: Rangers' Leach Is Questioned

text: ''I don't feel good about it,'' Leach said, ''but I'm going to be man enough to face up to what happens.''
title: Rangers' Leach Is Questioned

text: He had already appeared before the Rangers' manager, coaches and players. ''Having to go before your teammates and manager and coaching staff is never easy,'' he said. ''But anybody who knows my background knows I'm going to take it head-on.''
title: Rangers' Leach Is Questioned

text: Grieve said that the 32-year-old Leach would be disciplined, though he said he hadn't decided what action he would take. ''You don't miss a game when you're a major league player,'' the general manager said. ''That's a problem. But it's a problem between Rick and the ball club and will be handled internally.''
title: Rangers' Leach Is Questioned

text: Earlier in the day, Manager Bobby Valentine had called Leach ''a hard-nosed ex-quarterback at Michigan who is a good-time kind of guy.''
title: Rangers' Leach Is Questioned

text: By John H. Cushman Jr.
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: PRODDED by reports that the captain of the Exxon Valdez was drinking before the catastrophic oil spill, more people here are asking whether transportation workers should be randomly tested for the nation's most pervasive drug, alcohol, as well as illegal ones like cocaine and marijuana.
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: The proposals present legal, ethical and practical problems, even though alcohol contributes to far more accidents than illegal drugs do. While Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner has said he favors the expansion of testing, it would be sure to face opposition.
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: The department's rules calling for random drug screening of four million transportation workers are already being challenged in court, although the Supreme Court recently ruled that the Government could test workers for both alcohol and other drugs after accidents. A Wide Net
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: Still, the department is considering several ideas for testing, and Congress has taken up legislation that would expand random testing to include alcohol.
