Like the drug-testing rules, these proposals cover virtually every transportation worker, including private-sector employees like truck drivers, who are subject to Federal licensing regulations.
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: ''We simply won't tolerate substance abusers in public transportation,'' said Senator John C. Danforth, a Missouri Republican who is sponsoring the bill. It applies to airline pilots, air traffic controllers, truck and bus drivers and railroad engineers and brakemen. In the wake of the Alaska disaster, maritime workers are likely to be added to the list.
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: The Exxon Valdez captain, Joseph Hazelwood, has a drunken-driving record, and the Alaska authorities said that blood tests after the spill showed him to be legally intoxicated. But last week he pleaded not guilty to operating a vessel while drunk.
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: The fervor for testing is also based on unsettling statistics. For example, of the 6,208 fatal air accidents investigated by the National Transportation Safety Board from 1978 to 1987, 34 involved drugs while 294 involved alcohol. (None involved scheduled airlines.) In the accidents involving alcohol, 504 people died.
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: Among the issues raised by testing proposals: What kind of tests should be used, breath analysis or the more invasive blood testing? What constitutes a drinking problem: a single case of drinking on the job, a drunken-driving conviction, a record of missing work because of binge drinking? The issue is complicated by the fact that alcohol is legal off the job. And when is someone in treatment to be considered cured?
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: Despite the difficulties, the Federal Aviation Administration has taken several steps.
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: In 1987, the agency found that about 10,000 people still had flying licenses even though they had been convicted of drunken driving. Most had falsified their applications for medical certificates, which are required for flying, by failing to disclose the convictions. Many of the pilots have been prosecuted.
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: Several hundred pilots holding commercial licenses were among those who failed to report convictions. It is not known how many are employed by airlines.
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: The agency last month proposed a rule that would temporarily ground pilots convicted of drunken driving. They would have to appear before a medical examiner and prove their fitness to fly before being recertified. A second conviction within three years would lead to a one-year revocation of a pilot's license.
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: But a question that troubles experts on alcoholism is how to determine when someone has been cured.
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: Dr. Gary M. Kohn, the medical director at United Airlines, said that the company treats people with drinking problems, including pilots, and allows them to return to work under supervision.
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: ''The follow-up is critical in this business,'' he said. ''You can't just get somebody treated and return them to work, in any position, let alone a safety-related position. The most difficult part of treatment is not the month in the hospital or the first month after release. It is the first couple of years after release.''
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: Only occasionally is an employee asked to take a breath test, he said.
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: Although private employers are not subject to the constitutional restraints that the government must observe, Dr. Kohn said that in the absence of Federal regulations, the companies face a confusing array of state rules governing testing. ''It is not at all clear if we wanted to random test with breathalyzers that we could legally do it,'' he said.
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: In any event, Dr. Kohn believes testing is not the most effective way to prevent alcohol abuse.
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: ''It has been my impression, after 11 or 12 years, with actively employed or functional people, that the best way to deal with substance abuse is to educate and make a voluntary program available. Deterrence works if you have a choice in the matter. The people that are sick, alcoholics, don't have that choice, and deterrence doesn't work.''
title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers

text: CALIFORNIA still has the jump on the rest of the country when it comes to pioneering America's revolution in food and drink. Lately the state has turned its attention to beer; the repeal in 1976 of a Prohibition-era law against homebrewing has allowed a new generation of homebrewers and microbreweries to flourish. The revolution skyrocketed, however, in 1983, when California became the first state to repeal laws forbidding the sale of beer in breweries.
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: Within the year, the nation's first post-Prohibition brewpub opened, in Hopland, appropriately, where the Mendocino Brewing Company restored the century-old remnants of the Hopvine Saloon. Now, of the 100 brewpubs nationwide, 29 are in California, with more opening every month. Most are in the San Francisco Bay Area, running north to Mendocino, south to Santa Cruz and east to Sacramento. Pubcrawlers who venture from San Francisco to Berkeley, Oakland and Walnut Creek (the Bay Area Rapid Transit system, or BART, will take you there) can sample, compare and discuss the beers of a dozen brewpubs.
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: The beauty of brewpubs, according to Michael Lewis, known locally as the ''brewru'' who heads the School of Fermentation Sciences at the University of California in Davis, is the intimacy between brewer and drinker, brought together over a frothing glass. Just as the brew travels but a few feet from vat to tap instead of thousands of bottled miles, so the brewer has but to step from behind the glass wall that separates his copper tanks from the bar to chat up the customers for reactions to his latest work. Since many customers are themselves homebrewers, palates are as informed as the talk is heady with terms like ''peachy aromas'' and ''rich coffee and chocolate overtones.''
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: Most brewpubs regularly make three kinds of beer - usually a light ale, a medium ale and a dark porter or stout - with seasonal specialties where the brewer can flaunt his creative potential. Most of the Bay Area brewpubs brew ale, rather than lager, and good ale means beer that is fresh, natural and redolent of flavor, as opposed to standardized commercial beers designated for quantity consumption and eternal shelf life. Fresh means the beer is on tap as soon as the fermenting process is completed. Natural means no fillers like rice, corn and sugar and no chemical preservatives. Brewpubs boast that their beers contain only the elements prescribed by Duke Wilhelm of Bavaria in the 16th century when he enacted a purity of beer law, known in the trade as Reinheitsgebot - malted grains such as barley as well as water and hops - plus yeast. Flavor depends on the recipe and skill of the brewmaster in combining different roastings and dryings of malted grains with different temperatures and fermentation periods.
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: Since 94 percent of the beer consumed in America (and produced by the six giants) is light lager, more distinguishable by brand name than by taste, the brewpub offers not only variety and quality in its handcrafted brews, but also flavors and names as fanciful and quirky as the whim of its brewers - Deep Ender Dark, Hooker Oak Amber, Pelican Ale, Grail Ale, Earthquake Pale, Seismic Ale, Blue Whale Ale.
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: Legally what matters in a brewpub - and what distinguishes it from a microbrewery - is that food must be served along with drink. Just as California developed a food style to go with its native wines, now it's developing a style of beer cuisine. Most brewpubs began with simple hearty fare but stellar chefs like Alice Waters of Berkeley's Chez Panisse and Narsai David, a restaurateur and radio commentator, are now designing menus for local pubs. Wolfgang Puck of Spago in Los Angeles has promised to open his own brewpub later this year in Los Angeles.
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: GOOD beer and good atmosphere tend to go together in the Bay Area because of its abundance of old saloons. Barbary Coast atmosphere is what draws the crowds to San Francisco's first brewpub, the San Francisco Brewing Company, founded in 1985 by Allan Paul, and situated on Columbus and Pacific Avenues near North Beach and the Financial District. For his brewpub, Mr. Paul converted a classic turn-of-the-century saloon, the Albatross, with stained glass windows, brass ceiling fans and carved mahogany bar. The San Francisco Brewing Company is rare in these parts in that it offers lagers, or bottom-fermented brews, as well as top-fermented ales. The basic house brews are Albatross Lager and the light amber Emperor Norton Lager, in addition to specialties like Year of the Dragon Ale, a pale ale of medium body, with a malty, fairly assertive hop flavor. Food is mostly sandwiches and snacks, among the best of which is a broiled hot Louisiana sausage sandwich with peppers and onions.
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: Oldtime corner-saloon comfort is what draws students and others to Berkeley's major brewpub, Triple Rock Brewery and Alehouse, founded by John and Reid Martin in 1986 on Shattuck Avenue, heart of what's called the gourmet ghetto that encompasses Chez Panisse and the Acme Bakery. The alehouse is a neighborhood joint of pine and old brick, with chalkboard menu and walls of beer memorabilia to contemplate - posters, trays, bottles, ads - while sampling the house trio of the light and fruity Pinnacle Pale Ale, hearty Red Rock Ale and a dark, nutty Black Rock Porter. Specialty ales may include their Ollalaberry Wheat Beer, a light summer brew with a pinkish-red hue from the berries, which resemble blueberries, or Bug Juice Ale, which has a strong malt flavor, nicely balanced with hops. When you've had your fill of watching the brewmasters work at the front of the alehouse, you can climb to the beer garden on Top of the Rock to eat your bowl of black bean chicken chili or a sandwich of roast beef and Swiss cheese, slavered with blue cheese dressing, on a Semifreddi Bakery baguette flavored with anise and poppy seeds. Not exactly standard beer fare.
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: At Devil Mountain Brewery in Walnut Creek, founded in 1987, Greg Jones has gone all out for atmosphere in converting an 1891 Southern Pacific train station into a brewhouse and bar, and a 1919 Pullman observation car into a dining room. Appropriately, his regular beers include smooth and creamy Railroad Ale, full-bodied Iron Horse Ale, and a dark, rich, full-bodied stout called the Devil's Brew. Each of these was a winner at the Great American Beer Festival held in Denver last summer with 168 beers competing to satisfy the tastes of 6,000 drinkers. With live blues on tap on the weekends and a new chef from the Union Hotel, Lev Dagan, in the galley, Devil Mountain's menu is more extensive than most, featuring sausage, pasta and mushroom dishes according to the season.
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: One of the most recent brewpubs is the Pacific Coast Brewing Company, founded in 1988 in downtown Oakland by a trio of college roommates, Barry Lazarus, Steve Wolff and Don Gortemiller. They've restored the Victorian interior of the old Cox Saloon on Washington Street, refurbishing its stained glass windows and carved mahogany bar, adding a dartboard in the back and a rhythm-and-blues band on occasion. Their regular brews are a hearty, robust pale Gray Whale Ale, a hefty Orca Porter and rotating specialties like Yellow Jacket Ale, which has honey added. Menus suggest English pub fare with a plowman's platter of fruit, sausage and cheese, a daily specialty sausage and a Cornish pastie served with a salad. An outdoor beer garden is in the works.
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: At least five new brewpubs are supposed to be opening shortly; if you want to know where they are, ask any brewpub brewer as you sample his ale and discuss its peachy, raspberry or chocolate aroma. BREWING AND SAMPLING The Process
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: Brewing begins with malted barley grains, which have been partly germinated and then dried. If they are then lightly toasted, they produce pale beers; if heavily toasted, they produce dark beers such as stout. Unmalted barley is sometimes darkly roasted to produce nutty, dark beers. If the barley is soaked and dried a second time, it produces a red toffee-tasting beer.
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: The first step in brewing is mashing, where the malted grain is crushed and mixed with 170-degree water in the ''mash tun.'' Enzymes in the grain separate out the starch from a sweet liquid extract, now rich in maltose, called ''wort.''
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: The wort is then strained into the boil kettle for heating. Once the wort is boiled, hops are added for flavor and preserving. Hops are the dried green buds of a plant related to marijuana that contribute to a beer's distinctive aroma and somewhat bitter taste.
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: The wort is clarified at a boiling point called ''the hot break,'' where the brewer stirs the liquid with a wooden canoe paddle in order to create a whirlpool, with the debris collecting at the center and the liquor can be drawn off from the side. The wort is then cooled to around 70 degrees before yeast is added for fermentation in a stainless steel tank in the ''clean room.''
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: When the primary fermenting is completed (which takes from two to seven days), the tank of ''green beer'' is sealed to trap the natural carbon dioxide and then cooled to allow longer fermentation (about two weeks for ales). From here the brew is pumped straight from serving tank to bar to drinker's glass. Pubs to Visit
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: San Francisco Brewing Company, 155 Columbus Avenue, San Francisco; 415-434-3344. Open Sundays and weekdays from 11:30 A.M. to 12:30 A.M.; Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays to 2 P.M. Lagers at $2 a glass, $2.75 a pint. Sandwiches from $4.50 to $6.95, snacks $2.95 to $4.95.
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: Triple Rock Brewery and Ale House, 1920 Shattuck Avenue, Berkeley; 415-843-2739. Open daily 11:30 A.M. to after midnight. All house beers at $1.75 a pint, specialty beers sometimes higher. All sandwiches and chili under $4.
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: Devil Mountain Brewery, 850 South Broadway, Walnut Creek; 415-935-2337. Open Sundays through Thursdays, 11 A.M. to 11 P.M.; Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays to 1 A.M. House ales at $2.50 a pint, specialties at $2.75. Appetizers from $5 to $7, main dishes from $8.50 to $15.
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: Pacific Coast Brewing Company, 906 Washington Street, Oakland; 415-836-2739. Open 11:30 A.M. to 11 P.M. weeknights, to midnight on Fridays and Saturdays and to 8 P.M. on Sundays. House ales at $1.50 a glass, $2.25 a pint, specialty beers slightly more. Sausage of the day $5.95, sandwiches from $3.95 to $7.95, salads from $5.95 to $7.95.
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: Other brewpubs of note: Buffalo Bill's Brewpub, 1082 B Street, Hayward; 415-886-9823. The Tied House Cafe 7 Brewery, 954 Villa Street, Mountain View; 415-965-2739. Santa Cruz Brewing Company and Front Street Pub, 516 Front Street, Santa Cruz; 408-429-8838. Winchester Brewing Company, 820 South Winchester Boulevard, San Jose; 408-243-7561.
title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source

text: Rastafarian faith becomes liberation theology in the songs of Bunny Wailer. Mr. Wailer frames political questions in moral terms, naming Lucifer as the cause of human conflict and insisting that the struggle for human rights is the struggle of good against evil.
title: Reviews/Pop; Fighting the Good Fight To a 1970's Reggae Beat

text: Most of his concert Thursday at Radio City Music Hall was like a gospel service with a reggae beat. Wearing a robe decorated with the silhouette of Africa, a Star of David, the Lion of Judah (a symbol of the Rastafarian icon Haile Selassie) and marijuana leaves, Mr. Wailer delivered song after song with hortatory, urgent messages, preaching a little in between. Then, for the last 45 minutes or so, he switched to earthier topics, wearing stylized street clothes and singing about music, dancing and love.
title: Reviews/Pop; Fighting the Good Fight To a 1970's Reggae Beat

text: Mr. Wailer was, with Bob Marley and Peter Tosh, a member of the original Wailers vocal group. He stayed in Jamaica as Mr. Marley reshaped the Wailers and brought reggae to a worldwide audience; Mr. Wailer made his New York debut in 1986 (at Madison Square Garden).
title: Reviews/Pop; Fighting the Good Fight To a 1970's Reggae Beat

text: But Mr. Wailer is clearly no stranger to performing. He stalked the stage with easy assurance and sang out clearly, in an accent more comprehensible to North American ears than that of many other reggae performers. His 12-piece band knocked out reggae grooves in the full-toned, midtempo style of the mid-1970's Wailers, each song carrying a memorable musical hook or two. Although the troupe also included backup singers and dancers, Mr. Wailer wasn't upstaged. His calm conviction and ringing tenor carried a message of determination to ''struggle, struggle, struggle for your dignity.''
title: Reviews/Pop; Fighting the Good Fight To a 1970's Reggae Beat

text: Mr. Field's Daughter By Richard Bausch 347 pages. Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $18.95.
title: Books of The Times; Fathers, Daughters and the Terrors of Love

text: For Richard Bausch's characters, love means never having to let go. James Field, an aging widower, cannot accept the fact that his daughter, Annie, wants to leave home and marry the disreputable Cole Gilbertson. And when that marriage breaks up, Cole cannot accept the departure of Annie and their daughter, Linda. In each case, love leads to possessiveness and possessiveness to anger -and ultimately violence.
title: Books of The Times; Fathers, Daughters and the Terrors of Love

text: Like the people in Mr. Bausch's recent collection of short stories (''Spirits and Other Stories''), the characters in ''Mr. Field's Daughter'' inhabit a world whose very ordinariness conceals untold dangers and pitfalls. No doubt that sense of peril stems in part from their taste for alcohol, drugs and extreme behavior; but it also stems from a simple apprehension of the precariousness of life - our susceptibility to change and loss. Families have a way of fragmenting in Mr. Bausch's fiction, and those that do manage to stay together tend to find their security undermined by anxiety and doubt. Couples split up, children grow up and move away, accidents and illnesses threaten to erase love and hope.
title: Books of The Times; Fathers, Daughters and the Terrors of Love

text: ''She loved them all,'' Mr. Bausch writes of Annie's 9-year-old daughter, Linda. ''She'd spent many nights -while wind and snow blasted at the windows of the house and kept her awake - praying that nothing bad would happen to any of them. From somewhere before she could quite remember, she'd received the impression that everything was in a kind of jeopardy, though she hadn't known the word until recently. The first time she heard it and understood it, she had a small shock of recognition, as though it were a thing she had always known - or had known and then forgotten somehow.''
title: Books of The Times; Fathers, Daughters and the Terrors of Love

text: Given their heightened awareness of these perils, it's not surprising that Mr. Bausch's people suffer from nightmares, and cherish childish dreams of unconditional love and perfect safety. Clinging to domestic rituals, they ground their fears in the ''ordinary and simple.'' They try hard to protect those they love from the threats of the world beyond.
title: Books of The Times; Fathers, Daughters and the Terrors of Love

text: Certainly that's what James Field has tried to do with his only daughter, Annie, whom he has raised singlehandedly since his wife died - from a routine tonsillectomy - some two decades ago. He has dutifully followed the instructions in all the single-parent manuals, and he has tried to make up for the loss of her mother. As he tells a friend: ''I tried to be a good father, and give her everything she needed to grow up and be whatever she wanted to be, and the result of all that was that she ran off with the first pretty-looking kid who came along. I mean I did everything according to the books, and she just -well, she just ran off. It was like everything I'd tried to teach her and everything we'd been to each other -it just all - it - none of it mattered.''
title: Books of The Times; Fathers, Daughters and the Terrors of Love

text: From Annie's perspective, however, her father's love has been suffocating and authoritarian. His violent objection to her boyfriend, Cole, drives her into an abrupt marriage, and even when that marriage begins to sour - Cole turns out to be an ill-tempered ne'er-do-well, hooked on cocaine and dealing marijuana - she hesitates to ask her father for help. Only after Cole pulls a gun on her does she flee, returning to her father's house with Linda. It's a development that gratifies Annie's father: not only is he happy to have his little family reunited, but he also feels, to his chagrin, a triumphant sense of vindication.
title: Books of The Times; Fathers, Daughters and the Terrors of Love

text: Four years have passed, with the Field household settling into a calm, if somewhat stultifying, domestic routine, but now Annie is on the verge of marrying again. This time, her fiance is a middle-aged friend of her father's - a kind, self-deprecating man named Louis, who seems to elicit in Annie a feeling of security, rather than passion. She is worried about the effect of the union on her father and Linda, and she is equally concerned about how her ex-husband, Cole, will react to the news of her remarriage. Indeed, Cole soon comes to see himself as the victim of a predicament similar to that experienced earlier by Mr. Field: he feels he has been wrongly deprived of his daughter, and he vows to get her back - a decision that will set off a series of increasingly brutal confrontations.
title: Books of The Times; Fathers, Daughters and the Terrors of Love

text: Expertly moving back and forth from one viewpoint to another, Mr. Bausch delineates each character's perception of these events with both sympathy and unforgiving precision. He shows us the selfishness of love, and he shows us how anger, pity and resentment are factored into the equation of familial emotions: how Annie can rage against her father's strictures and yet marry a man much like him; how she can fear for her ungainly daughter's happiness and yet revile her for slovenliness and poor hygiene; how her father can yearn to make her happy and yet rejoice in the collapse of her marriage. As Annie says to her fiance, Louis: ''When I think of all the things he did because he loved me - what people visit on each other out of something like love. It's enough for all the world's woe, Louis. You don't even need hate to have a perfectly miserable time.''
title: Books of The Times; Fathers, Daughters and the Terrors of Love

text: Though much of the psychological action in this novel seems baldly Oedipal - we're told that Mr. Field sees an uncanny resemblance between his daughter and his late wife; that Annie looks for paternal reassurance in Louis - Mr. Bausch delineates the situation with such specificity, such fidelity to the anomalous personalities of Annie and her father, that we completely accept their behavior. In fact, even the more extreme reactions of the characters in this novel are made to seem plausible and real, and as Cole embarks on his quest to reclaim Annie and Linda, the reader feels a net of inevitability tighten around them all. Having created an entire network of relationships and emotional connections, Mr. Bausch simply allows fate, as embodied in each individual's character, to do its work - with predictably devastating results.
title: Books of The Times; Fathers, Daughters and the Terrors of Love

text: For the flight of the space shuttle Atlantis, the space agency selected an experienced crew, all but one of whom have flown on earlier shuttle missions. Here are sketches of the five astronauts aboard the Atlantis. David M. Walker, Mission Commander
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: Commander Walker, a 44-year-old Navy captain, is making his second shuttle flight. He logged more than 192 hours in space as a pilot aboard the second flight of the shuttle Discovery on Nov. 8, 1984.
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: In the Vietnam War, he completed two combat cruises in Southeast Asia, flying F-4 Phantom jets aboard the carriers Enterprise and America. He has flown 5,000 hours.
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: Born in Columbus, Ga., Commander Walker received his bachelor's degree from the United States Naval Academy in 1966 and became an astronaut in 1979. He and his wife, Stacy, have two sons, aged 20 and 17. Ronald J. Grabe, Pilot
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: Colonel Grabe, 43, was also a pilot aboard the first flight of the Atlantis, a secret mission for the Defense Department that began on Oct. 3, 1985.
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: After graduating with a bachelor's degree in engineering from the United States Air Force Academy in 1966, he studied aeronautics as a Fulbright Scholar in West Germany. A year later, he returned to this country o complete pilot training, and in 1969 he flew 200 combat missions in Southeast Asia.
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: Colonel Grabe, who was born in New York City, graduated from the Air Force's Test Pilot School in 1975. He spent three years as an exchange test pilot with the Royal Air Force. In 1981, he became an astronaut.
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: Colonel Grabe, and his wife, Marijo, have two daughters, 14 and 10. Norman E. Thagard, M.D., Mission Specialist
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: Dr. Thagard, 45, is the only crew member making his third shuttle mission. In June 1983, he served as mission specialist aboard the Challenger's second voyage, performing medical experiments and collected information on physiological changes that astronauts experience in space.
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: He was also a mission specialist on a Challenger mission in April 1985.
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: Born in Mariana, Fla., Dr. Thagard earned his bachelor's and master's degrees from Florida State University. He later received his medical degree from the University of Texas Southwestern Medical School.
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: In 1966, he entered the Marine Corps Reserve and became a fighter pilot two years later. He later flew 163 combat missions in the Vietnam War.
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: Dr. Thagard and his wife, Rex, have three sons, 20, 18 and 9. Mary L. Cleave, Ph.D., Mission Specialist
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: Dr. Cleave, the only crew member without a military background, is making her second shuttle flight. The 42-year-old biologist logged 165 hours in space as a mission specialist aboard the second flight of the Atlantis in 1985.
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: Dr. Cleave, who was born in Southampton, N.Y., received a bachelor's degree in biology from Colorado State University in 1969. She earned a master's degree in microbial ecology in 1975, and a Ph.D. in civil and environmental engineering in 1979, both from Utah State University. In 1980, she became an astronaut. She is unmarried. Mark C. Lee, Mission Specialist
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: Major Lee, the youngest crew member, is the only one making his first shuttle mission.
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: The 36-year-old Air Force pilot was born in Viroqua, Wis. and became an astronaut five years ago. He received a bachelor's degree in civil engineering from the Air Force Academy in 1974, and a master's degree in mechanical engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1980. After pilot training in Texas, Major Lee spent two and a half years as a fighter pilot stationed at Okinawa, Japan. He and his wife, Deidre, have no children.
title: 4 Shuttle Veterans and a Newcomer

text: The America of T. Coraghessan Boyle is a wild and crazy place, where anything can happen. In his most recent novel (''World's End''), a garrulous epic that chronicled the fortunes of several generations of a single family, ''the barbaric new world'' of America spawned ghosts and demons, not to mention every imaginable variety of human eccentricity and prejudice. His collections of short stories (''Greasy Lake and Other Stories,'' ''Descent of Man'') have also tended to pivot around the strange and the surreal: neighboring survivalists, holed up in the wilderness to await the apocalypse, come to blows; a group of hippies watches television and smokes marijuana as the skies begin to rain blood; a rowdy gang of teen-agers discovers a bloated corpse in the neighborhood lake.
title: Books of The Times

text: IF THE RIVER WAS WHISKEY
title: Books of The Times

text: Similarly disturbing events surface in his latest collection of stories, ''If the River Was Whiskey'': a couple receive a death threat from their adopted son, who suffers from the delusion that he's a killer bee (''King Bee''); a Hungarian circus performer achieves fame and fortune by scaling a skyscraper and by tying himself to the wing of an airplane (''The Human Fly''); a retired primatologist tries to settle down to a normal life in Connecticut with one of her chimpanzees (''The Ape Lady in Retirement'').
title: Books of The Times

text: On the surface at least, it appears as though Mr. Boyle has changed narrative terrain, trading the 60's backdrop of communes and crash pads that figured so prominently in his earlier fiction for a new yuppified world of suburban houses and upscale restaurants. His characters pay less attention now to the quality of their dope and stereo systems than to the brand names of their clothing (Fila sweats, Nikes, hand-knit hat-and-scarf sets imported from Scandinavia) and the purity of their designer food (forest mushrooms, sun-dried tomatoes, fennel sausage). One woman is so obsessed with cleanliness and health that she makes her lover wear ''a full-body condom.'' Another couple, who have quit their tenured teaching jobs to start a fly-by-night adoption agency, vote for Ronald Reagan, though they won't admit it to their friends.
title: Books of The Times

text: Indeed the acquisitive, image-obsessed values of the 80's permeate these stories. In ''Hard Sell,'' a press agent attempts to upgrade public perception of the Ayatollah. ''Tell him,'' he says to an intermediary, ''beards went out with Jim Morrison - and the bathrobe business is kinda kinky, and we can play to that if he wants, but wouldn't he feel more comfortable in a nice Italian knit?'' In ''The Devil and Irv Cherniske,'' a bond trader makes a pact with Satan, and goes on to become one of the wealthiest men in New York. And in ''Peace of Mind,'' a fast-talking young woman preys on her wealthy clients' worst fears in order to sell them elaborate burglar-alarm systems.
title: Books of The Times

text: Of course, neither they - nor the young woman, as it turns out - can buy real ''peace of mind,'' for in Mr. Boyle's America, one's worst paranoid worries have a terrible way of coming true. A prospective client turns out to be a psychopathic con man. A suburban neighbor turns out to be a madwoman, intent on flooding herself out of her house by turning on every available faucet. A man in a black BMW turns out to be the Devil.
title: Books of The Times

text: It's no wonder that Mr. Boyle's characters continually feel menaced. As he writes of one man, who has just seen a stranger in his backyard: ''Though he wasn't nearly the bruiser he'd been when he started at nose tackle for Fox Lane High, he was used to wielding his paunch like a weapon and blustering his way through practically anything, from a potential mugging right on down to putting a snooty maitre d' in his place. For all that, though, when he saw the size of the man, when he factored in his complexion and considered the oddness of the circumstances, he felt uncertain of himself. Felt as if the parameters of the world as he knew it had suddenly shifted. Felt, unaccountably, that he was in deep trouble.''
title: Books of The Times

text: As his previous fiction has amply demonstrated, Mr. Boyle is richly endowed with an old-fashioned storyteller's gifts (a hyperactive imagination, an exuberant way with language, a penchant for exaggeration), combined with the self-consciousness of a good, card-carrying post-modernist. In his strongest work, these talents come together to create a compelling - and often very funny -tale that's both a portrait of contemporary reality and comment upon earlier fictional forms. Some of the stories in ''Greasy Lake'' and ''Descent of Man'' stand as small satirical marvels; and for all its windy effusions, ''World's End'' evinces an admirable ambition - a desire to take apart and reassemble the clockwork of the American dream.
title: Books of The Times

text: In Mr. Boyle's weaker efforts -which this volume, unfortunately, seems to feature - his disparate talents are used, singly, for showy, but shallow effects. ''Me Cago en la Leche (Robert Jordan in Nicaragua),'' for instance, is a cynical parody of ''For Whom the Bell Tolls,'' transporting Hemingway's hero, Robert Jordan, from the Spanish Civil War to Central America, where he's supposedly engaged in fighting the contras. ''Sorry Fugu'' is a cutesy diatribe against critics, staged as a battle between an earnest chef and a stupid restaurant reviewer. And ''The Devil and Irv Cherniske'' is nothing but a tired retelling of the Faust legend, gussied up with contemporary references to insider trading, real estate and Krugerrands.
title: Books of The Times

text: Curiously enough, two of the more persuasive stories in this collection eschew Mr. Boyle's trademark pyrotechnics. The title story, ''If the River Was Whiskey,'' is a dark portrait of a family in disrepair; ''Thawing Out,'' a similarly somber examination of a romance gone awry. In the past, the author's efforts in this naturalistic territory have always seemed somewhat insincere and forced, but the deeply felt emotion in these two tales points to a new direction in the career of this gifted and highly versatile young writer. Pearsond(Viking)
title: Books of The Times

text: If the River Was Whiskey By T. Coraghessan Boyle 224 pages. Viking. $17.95.
title: Books of The Times; Stories in Which the Unusual Is the Usual

text: In Mr. Boyle's weaker efforts -which this volume, unfortunately, seems to feature - his disparate talents are used, singly, for showy, but shallow effects. ''Me Cago en la Leche (Robert Jordan in Nicaragua),'' for instance, is a cynical parody of ''For Whom the Bell Tolls,'' transporting Hemingway's hero, Robert Jordan, from the Spanish Civil War to Central America, where he's supposedly engaged in fighting the contras. ''Sorry Fugu'' is a cutesy diatribe against critics, staged as a battle between an earnest chef and a stupid restaurant reviewer. And ''The Devil and Irv Cherniske'' is nothing but a tired retelling of the Faust legend, gussied up with contemporary references to insider trading, real estate and Krugerrands.
title: Books of The Times; Stories in Which the Unusual Is the Usual

text: Curiously enough, two of the more persuasive stories in this collection eschew Mr. Boyle's trademark pyrotechnics. The title story, ''If the River Was Whiskey,'' is a dark portrait of a family in disrepair; ''Thawing Out,'' a similarly somber examination of a romance gone awry. In the past, the author's efforts in this naturalistic territory have always seemed somewhat insincere and forced, but the deeply felt emotion in these two tales points to a new direction in the career of this gifted and highly versatile young writer. Pearsond(Viking)
title: Books of The Times; Stories in Which the Unusual Is the Usual

text: Waving from an open Jeep, Domingo Laino smiled giddily as his balloon-festooned campaign caravan passed the Palace of Government here, command center for 35 years of the dictatorship of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner.
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: ''I feel like I am in a dream,'' the presidential candidate confided as the 19th-century Latin Gothic palace slipped from view. ''Only last December I was in one of Stroessner's jail cells.''
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: Paraguayans are to vote for President on Monday in an election that is expected to be the freest here in memory. Although the commander of the armed forces is expected to win, the elections are seen as a major step toward bringing democracy to a nation that has known only dictators since it won independence in 1811.
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: On Saturday, as candidates and citizens linked hands on the steps of the 19th-century cathedral here in a ''chain of hope,'' Ismael Rolon, Archibishop of Asuncion, said, ''On May 1, after long years of farce, the Paraguayan people will, God willing, for the first time freely and responsibly elect'' their leaders. Well Ahead in the Polls
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: Three separate polls conducted here in April gave the military candidate, Gen. Andres Rodriguez, victory totals ranging from 67 percent to 78 percent. The polls gave 17 to 21 percent of the vote to Mr. Laino, the only major contendor among five opposition candidates.
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: The general, an affable 65-year-old who campaigns in a business suit, enjoys a high standing among Paraguayans largely because he liberated them on Feb. 3 from the long and repressive dictatorship of General Stroessner, a 76-year-old man known here as the tyrannosaur.
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: After the Feb. 3 coup, General Rodriguez startled skeptics by ending all press censorship, emptying jails of political prisoners, welcoming home exiles, vowing to stamp out torture and throwing the country open to a competitive presidential race.
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: The general's open style was evident today when he visited a hotel where about 60 foreign election observers are staying. ''Nice to meet you,'' the general said, smiling jovially as he greeted each observer. ''Thank you very much for coming.''
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: One United States observer, Representative Bruce A. Morrison, said later that Paraguay's opening stood in sharp contrast to tension in Panama, where Gen. Manuel Noriega has made it clear that outsiders will not be welcome to observe elections on May 7. 'Other End of the Spectrum'
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: ''Panama is the other end of the spectrum,'' said the Democrat from Connecticut, who led Congressional opposition to the Stroessner Government. ''There, a system is closing down. Here, it is opening up.'' General Rodriguez, who for decades was General Stroessner's most important military backer, has surprised many people here with his skillful handling of civilian politics.
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: Reaching for national reconciliation, he has repaired relations with the Roman Catholic Church, made human rights a major campaign issue and used long-banned protest songs for the sound tracks of his television commercials, which call for creating a ''modern and democratic'' Paraguay.
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: ''He has stolen all the rallying cries from the opposition,'' said Luis Alberto Mauro, editor of ABC Color, a newspaper that resumed printing here in March, five years after General Stroessner ordered it closed.
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: On Friday, at a mass youth rally, the general announced between rock-and-roll sets that he was lifting a nationwide curfew on late-night parties and theater events. On Saturday, at a televised campaign finale for his party, the Colorados, he said that, as President, his first message to Congress would be a request for ratification of the Inter-American Convention on Human Rights. The Distrust Lingers
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: Despite his high rating in the opinion polls, many Paraguayans harbor a lingering distrust of the man they will probably elect President on Monday. In one poll, 44 percent of respondents said the general should be ''investigated.''
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: ''He was the strong arm of the dictatorship,'' Jacinto Orue Coronel said Saturday at the final campaign rally for Mr. Laino's party, the Authentic Radical Liberal Party.
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: Under the old regime, General Rodriguez became one of the richest men in this nation of 3.8 million people. He owns the nation's largest brewery, a chain of currency exchange shops, an import-export business, several ranches and a copper wire company.
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: In the past, there have been persistent, but never proved, allegations that he was involved in transshipping cocaine from neighboring Bolivia.
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: The closest public tie came in 1984 when Paraguayan customs agents seized 49,000 gallons of chemicals used in the manufacture of cocaine. The shipping papers listed the owner as Gen. Eduardo Sanchez, then Chief of Staff for General Rodriguez. After the coup, General Rodriguez appointed General Sanchez as Chief of Police.
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: The general has denied any link to cocaine trafficking. ''There is a great determination on the part of the Paraguayan Government to combat drug trafficking,'' Foreign Minister Luis Maria Argana said in an interview. This month, in the first such operation in Paraguay, American planes sprayed herbicides on 750 acres of marijuana.
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: Paraguayans are also skeptical of Monday's voting, which follows eight rigged elections by General Stroessner. According to two polls, only half of the respondents thought the balloting will be honest.
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: To cut fraud, the United States, through the National Endowment for Democracy, has begun a major civic education campaign here. Using $116,000 in American grant money, a local group has distributed 4,500 posters and 100,000 fliers outlining correct voting procedures and 8,000 workbooks for training poll watchers. Five hundred Paraguayans have been trained how to teach others to be poll watchers.
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: In addition, the United States has provided 11,340 bottles of indelible ink, more than enough to mark the fingers of voters expected to turn out at the 10,000 election centers.
title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION

text: KINGS OF COCAINE Inside the Medellin Cartel - An Astonishing True Story of Murder, Money, and International Corruption. By Guy Gugliotta and Jeff Leen. Illustrated. 391 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.
title: BAD THINGS CAME IN SMALL PLANES

text: On March 22, a Federal grand jury sitting in Jacksonville, Fla., indicted 30 people on charges of smuggling 44,000 pounds of cocaine, worth more than $1 billion, into the United States from 1974 through last February. Among those indicted were four chiefs of a drug cartel centered in the mile-high Andean city of Medellin, in Colombia, who were said to be responsible for up to 80 percent of the cocaine sent to the United States. The 12-count indictment also charged that one of the four cocaine barons had arranged the 1984 assassination of Colombian Justice Minister Rodrigo Lara Bonilla. After reading ''Kings of Cocaine'' one cannot help but wonder how this latest legal salvo in the war against drugs will fare in the face of such overwhelming power as these men hold in Colombia.
title: BAD THINGS CAME IN SMALL PLANES

text: As related by Guy Gugliotta and Jeff Leen, reporters for The Miami Herald, this extremely complicated story with its unwieldy yet fascinating cast of characters began in the mid-1970's, when a group of ruthless young Colombian thugs from Medellin prepared themselves to lead the rapidly expanding cocaine trade. Trafficking independently, these men included Pablo Escobar Gaviria and two brothers, Jorge Luis and Fabio Ochoa Vasquez (three of those indicted last month), and they realized that enormous sums could be theirs if they pooled their smuggling operations.
title: BAD THINGS CAME IN SMALL PLANES

text: The man who would make that possible was Carlos Lehder Rivas, a car thief and small-time marijuana smuggler who spoke perfect English and dreamed of organizing a transport system to bring hundreds of kilos of cocaine into the United States in private planes, using American pilots. The key to Mr. Lehder's scheme, the authors say, lay in the Bahamas, with its corruptible officials, its proximity to the United States for refueling and its heavy tourist traffic. Mr. Lehder's success soon surpassed any of the cartel's wildest dreams. Formerly, a good run was measured in kilos. Mr. Lehder began to measure their business by the ton, their profits in the millions.
title: BAD THINGS CAME IN SMALL PLANES

text: The web would eventually reach much further - into Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's Panama and even, according to one smuggler, into Nicaragua - and the cartel would develop unbridled power before authorities began to suspect that the cocaine trade was not scattered among hundreds of small traffickers. Between 1977 and 1982, United States drug agents concentrated on street sales and small timers. But in March 1982, Mr. Gugliotta and Mr. Leen write, agents of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration stumbled upon nearly two tons of pure cocaine hidden in a cargo of blue jeans imported to Florida from Colombia. Alarmed at the amount and at evidence that traffickers were banding together, agents began to redefine their efforts.
title: BAD THINGS CAME IN SMALL PLANES

text: By then the cartel members were bringing millions of drug dollars back to Colombia, buying them respectability, status, political power and private armies of machine-gun-wielding toughs. Their power and arrogance grew to overwhelm the irresolute President Belisario Betancur Cuartas, who pretended the cartel did not exist until 1984 when its gunmen assassinated his incorruptible Justice Minister, Rodrigo Lara Bonilla. Afterward, Mr. Betancur made a half-hearted show of force, but it was largely business as usual.
title: BAD THINGS CAME IN SMALL PLANES

text: Meanwhile, though the authors make absolutely no mention of it, the Reagan Administration was gutting its own drug enforcement budget even as its ''Just Say No'' campaign was under way. It is a surprising omission, especially as the efforts of drug agents and prosecutors both in Colombia and the United States (described in minute detail by Mr. Gugliotta and Mr. Leen) seem even more heroic when one realizes what limited support Washington gave them. After agents knocked over a huge complex of laboratories in the southeastern Colombian jungles in 1984 -thus proving the cartel's existence - the Reagan Administration began to look up a blind alley for evidence of a connection between Colombian leftists and the traffickers. Ultimately evidence would show that cocaine barons have no politics, only self-interest.
title: BAD THINGS CAME IN SMALL PLANES

text: That single-mindedness - the Reagan political agenda over law enforcement - was more than once to seriously affect the war on drugs. In ''Kings of Cocaine,'' the stories are muted of most of this irony. One case involved a confessed American drug smuggler, Barry Seal, who aided Federal prosecutors in their case against the Medellin barons. Mr. Seal ultimately testified in three major trials that brought 17 convictions. His effectiveness was ended by the Administration, though, when Lieut. Col. Oliver North was briefed on Mr. Seal's contention that the cartel had begun operating in Sandinista Nicaragua. The Drug Enforcement Administration had planned with Mr. Seal to capture the kingpins Mr. Escobar and Mr. Ochoa in Mexico, but it was forced to dump the plan when Colonel North, concerned about influencing a key Congressional vote on aid to the contras, leaked ''the Sandinista connection.'' (The Drug Enforcement Administration later said it had no independent evidence of Sandinista complicity.) The war continued, with more appalling bloodshed in Colombia as President Virgilio Barco Vargas succeeded Mr. Betancur. His feeble antidrug efforts were answered with the assassinations of the head of the Narcotics Bureau, Col. Jaime Ramirez Gomez, the crusading newspaper editor Guillermo Cano Isaza and Attorney General Carlos Mauro Hoyos Jiminez. The one effective weapon available to the Colombian President, one hardly employed by Mr. Betancur, was the 1981 American extradition treaty. Finally it was used against a cartel member - Mr. Lehder - in February 1987 when he was arrested in a remote area of Colombia. Quickly packed off to the United States before the cartel could mass its army of attorneys or even murder another justice official, Mr. Lehder was tried in Tampa, Fla., for smuggling, conspiracy and tax evasion and found guilty on all counts; he was sentenced to life without parole plus 135 years. Testimony at his trial was used, moreover, in the Federal indictments of his fellow drug barons this year. Whether they will be brought to justice or evade it as they have for nearly 20 years remains to be seen.
title: BAD THINGS CAME IN SMALL PLANES

text: ''Kings of Cocaine'' is admirably researched, overwhelming in detail. It is interesting that (beyond a brief reference) one thing missing from these reporters' exhaustive investigation is any mention of then-Vice President George Bush's role as head of the President's South Florida Task Force on Drugs, when all this phenomenal growth in the drug trade was occurring.
title: BAD THINGS CAME IN SMALL PLANES

text: Small quantities of illegal drugs were found in the home of Abbie Hoffman after his suicide earlier this month, the Bucks County District Attorney, Alan M. Rubenstein, said today.
title: Official Tells of Box of Drugs At Home of Abbie Hoffman

text: He said a box found in Mr. Hoffman's refrigerator contained 9.38 grams of marijuana, 0.31 grams of hashish, a cocaine residue and trace amounts of LSD and amphetamines. Toxicology tests completed last week confirmed the drugs, Mr. Rubenstein added.
title: Official Tells of Box of Drugs At Home of Abbie Hoffman

text: Mr. Hoffman, the antiwar protester and founder of the Yippie movement in the 1960's, was found dead April 12 in his home near New Hope. He was 52 years old.
title: Official Tells of Box of Drugs At Home of Abbie Hoffman

text: IN my neighborhood or in decent company generally, I would immediately be branded as a grump and maybe a subversive if I whispered even a single negative syllable against spring, now that it's here and at its peak.
title: Neglecting Spring: True Confessions

text: And in fact I have enjoyed my own garden with unusual zest this spring, thanks to having planted with a lavish hand last fall the little bulbs that so satisfy the soul when another equinox rolls around. Daffodils like Minnow and Chit Chat, botanical tulips like Tulipa tarda and T. clusiana, inch-high blue anemones with flowers over an inch across - these fill every corner of the garden with welcome color and no little charm.
title: Neglecting Spring: True Confessions

text: That said, I must also say that my garden pays spring a fairly stingy tribute. We have two dogwoods, both volunteers from chance seeds birds brought in 10 years ago. We have one flowering crab apple and a quince, but no weeping cherry trees or pink saucer magnolias. Someone gave me a rhododendron, and I passed it on to a neighbor. The three azaleas that were here when we moved in died in last year's drought, and I will not replace them.
title: Neglecting Spring: True Confessions

text: I take the view that there's no need for me to plant the shurbs and trees that flower so gloriously if briefly every spring. My neighbors have done it for me.
title: Neglecting Spring: True Confessions

text: I don't need forsythias, since a plant census would show three of them for every human inhabitant in town. They are fully on view in the front gardens of the neighborhood, and I see as many of them as I wish whenever I drive to the grocery store for milk and cat food. I see enough azaleas this way to do me for the year.
title: Neglecting Spring: True Confessions

text: One mass planting down the street is especially noteworthy for its combination of Popsicle shades of pink, scarlet and orange. I always wonder if it's a result of unusual verve on the part of their owner or of a severe need for him to have his eyes checked.
title: Neglecting Spring: True Confessions

text: In my neighborhood rambles, I can note each spring the slight variations in the onset of bloom of the Japanese cherries. This year I observed with pleasure that all the pink magnolias in town for once escaped the late frost which usually turns their petals to a disgusting brown mush. I borrow my neighbors' gardens, and the springtime joys they offer the passer-by.
title: Neglecting Spring: True Confessions

text: I have my reasons for neglecting spring. Once the swift tide of color sweeps through the neighborhood and the last rhododendrons have put in their annual say, everything changes to an unrelenting green the rest of the growing season, until autumn arrives with its rich palette of golds and reds.
title: Neglecting Spring: True Confessions

text: My garden is fairly small. By having planted very few of the woody plants for which spring tells the whole story, I save room for other plants, which are of interest in more than one season, or which bloom for months instead of days.
title: Neglecting Spring: True Confessions

text: One such plant is vitex, commonly known as chaste tree for reasons I do not profess to understand. Its leaves look so much like the leaves of marijuana that passing police cars sometimes slow down for a closer look. But the long spikes of blue flowers begin in July and continue until late September. The foliage is a pleasant gray tone, and the aromatic flowers are constantly abuzz with bees.
title: Neglecting Spring: True Confessions

text: Another shrub that I value more highly than all the azaleas in town is the purple smoke bush (Cotinus coggygria pupureus), which bears rich brown-purple foliage all summer and in the fall is covered with gray panicles of seeds which do indeed look like smoke embracing the plant.
title: Neglecting Spring: True Confessions

text: Buddleias are commonly called summer lilacs, though they aren't lilacs at all. And with all due respect to old-fashioned doorway gardens in New England and to Walt Whitman, if I had to choose between buddleias and lilacs, buddleias would win hands down. Lilacs bloom for just a few days, they have an unpleasant smell as cut flowers, and they generally spend most of the summer in a coat of mildew. Buddleias, which are very rapid growers and which will reach six feet or even more when chopped back severely in early spring as required, offer colors unknown in lilacs: apricot, wine red, deep blue, as well as lavender and white. The bloom goes on for two months or longer, and the plant has a graceful and airy habit.
title: Neglecting Spring: True Confessions

text: Then there are the berried plants of fall and winter, nandinas, pyracanthas, cotoneasters and evergreen hollies, to name the most familiar.
title: Neglecting Spring: True Confessions

text: Even better, in my opinion, are some of the lesser-known native plants. Red chokeberry or aronia is a prime example, especially the cultivar called Brilliantissima. Two other woody plants I admire enormously are the native deciduous hollies, Ilex verticillata and I. decidua. When their leaves drop in the fall, these hollies seem bedecked with huge numbers of rubies and garnets - and the display continues for four or five months, unless flocks of birds decide, as they sometimes do, that they are the making of a feast.
title: Neglecting Spring: True Confessions

text: I admire my neighbors' azaleas and pink magnolias. They may do the same with my vitex and my buddleias and my chokeberry and my hollies. I think I know who has the better in this transaction, but I wouldn't dream of saying it out loud.
title: Neglecting Spring: True Confessions

text: Edward Brecher, who recently ended his own life before cancer could take it from him, had a celebrated career as a writer on a variety of scientific topics. But in 1972 he left a monument as the author of the Consumer Union book ''Licit and Illicit Drugs.''
title: Drugs and Edward Brecher

text: That towering work of scholarship laid out most of what has been learned - and selectively forgotten - about heroin, caffeine, nicotine, alcohol, barbiturates, amphetamines, tranquilizers, cocaine, LSD and marijuana.
title: Drugs and Edward Brecher

text: But Mr. Brecher was more than a compiler of facts, and ''Licit and Illicit Drugs'' is more than a primer on addiction. He pierced the veil of moral righteousness and special pleading that still colors drug policy, offering sober prescriptions for limiting the damage that many Americans still don't want to hear:
title: Drugs and Edward Brecher

text: ''Drug-free'' treatment of heroin addiction almost never works. The only practical hope for addicts is to find a substitute addiction that has less harsh medical consequences and carries less social stigma. Mr. Brecher recommended methadone. By failing to offer most addicts that option, society drives many to alcoholism.
title: Drugs and Edward Brecher

text: Nicotine can be as tough to beat as heroin. Some people who do beat it suffer lasting side effects -anxiety, depression, even intellectual impairment. Many could be helped, Mr. Brecher argued, with a safe nicotine substitute or at least a cigarette that delivers nicotine without the carcinogenic smoke.
title: Drugs and Edward Brecher

text: Good or bad, marijuana is here to stay. The billions spent to fight it are wasted dollars. Indeed, they may be worse than wasted: properly regulated, marijuana might serve as a less dangerous substitute for alcohol.
title: Drugs and Edward Brecher

text: At least as important as Mr. Brecher's ideas was the compassion for addicts that infused his search for answers. If more Americans shared his tolerance for human frailty as well as his respect for science and history, the drug monsters might yet be caged.
title: Drugs and Edward Brecher

text: Two decades ago, a band of hippies and people active in politics unrolled sod on a muddy university-owned lot and transformed the area into what is an unofficial Berkeley landmark today, People's Park.
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: The story of how thousands of people - students and professors, hippies and fraternity members, families and elderly residents -came to the park and planted tomatoes, pansies and saplings has become a local legend that is reflected on a mural on the side of a nearby building.
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: The attempt to occupy the land led to a violent confrontation with the police, in which dozens of protesters were shot and a man was killed. The National Guard was summoned and for 17 days the streets were patrolled by jeeps and half-tracks.
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: Today the struggle over the land continues and People's Park still holds much meaning for many who live here.
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: The University of California at Berkeley, desperately in need of more student housing, recently rekindled these feelings by proposing to build a residence hall and dining center on People's Park. The recommendation for a 200-bed dormitory is part of a larger plan that calls for new housing for about 3,000 students.
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: Berkeley is proud of the role it played in the social movements of the 1960's, and while it is often ridiculed for its counterculture image, many residents say the heritage needs to be preserved.
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: ''We have the Vietnam Memorial for people who served, but there is no monument for the veterans of the internal war,'' said Richard Illgen, a Berkeley planning commissioner who says he wants People's Park to remain open space. ''We don't want people to forget.''
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: Even before the university's proposal to build on People's Park was made public last week, the City Council met to discuss the matter. Hundreds of people squeezed into the Council chambers; others sat on the steps outside.
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: So packed was the meeting that Mayor Loni Hancock was forced to move it to a larger hall. Then, for five hours, until 2 A.M., residents spoke out and compared the university's action to an ''elephant stepping on us,'' a ''tumor expanding and eating parts of our city'' and a ''bear crashing through the forest.''
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: At one point, a videotape was shown of the 1969 demonstration the day the university reclaimed the land. The people in the audience grew quiet and leaned forward in their seats as scenes of the police firing shotguns at demonstrators appeared on the screen. A few people wiped away tears. And then when the image shifted to a chanting group of protesters standing outside the park, almost the entire audience joined in with their cry: ''Seize the park!''
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: The City Council passed a policy statement calling for the university to leave the park open, by a vote of 6 to 1, with 2 abstaining. Ms. Hancock said later that the university's plan was comparable to putting ''a volleyball court on the battlefield of Gettysburg.'' She added that Berkeley, the 13th most densely populated city in the country, needs open spaces.
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: But People's Park, where several hundred people gathered Saturday to celebrate its 20th anniversary, is usually avoided by people here.
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: The 2.8 acres, less than a mile from the campus, consists mostly of a flat field of scruffy grass with a grove of trees at one end and raised flower beds and vegetable gardens at the other. Students rarely visit the site unless they are seeking LSD or a ''lid'' of marijuana. Most of the visitors are homeless, and there is a perception among many Berkeley residents that the park is dangerous.
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: University administrators and city officials agree that the park needs to change. The university has said the best way to do that is by building on a third of the site, thus drawing more students to use the remaining space. But the university chancellor, I. Michael Heyman, recently said that he was interested in exploring other alternatives with the city and that the university's plans were not final.
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: His tone represented a shift, university and city officials said, from his earlier stance, when he called a joint statement from the Mayor and the student body president a ''declaration of war,'' because it opposed any construction on People's Park.
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: Yet many residents and city officials do not trust the university. For them, People's Park remains a focal point of the strained town-and-gown relations embodied by the events 20 years ago. They remember the park as a magical place and the university as the institution that bulldozed it.
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: ''When you hear people describe what the park was like, it sounds hopelessly dopey,'' said Prof. Todd Gitlin, author of ''The Sixties: Years of Hope, Days of Rage,'' (1988, Bantam Books). ''In 1989, it's hard to take seriously that people thought they could create a zone of communal life tilling the soil.''
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: ''There's so little respect for history among us,'' said Professor Gitlin, who teaches sociology at the university. ''The park was a place of something so promising and wrenching that it deserves respect.''
title: Berkeley Journal; People's Park Struggle Resumes After 20 Years

text: Drug abuse grants totaling $118.8 million will be distributed to the 50 states, five territorial governments and the District of Columbia, the Attorney General, Dick Thornburgh, announced today.
title: U.S. Awards Drug Abuse Grants

text: The awards are intended to strengthen local efforts to curtail illegal drug trafficking and consumption. The grants, to be made before Oct. 1, are to be matched by a 25 percent contribution from local governments.
title: U.S. Awards Drug Abuse Grants

text: ''These grants will assist state and local criminal justice agencies in carrying out their part of the international war on drugs,'' Mr. Thornburgh said.
title: U.S. Awards Drug Abuse Grants

text: The Bureau of Justice Assistance, which allocates the grants according to population, will award about $30 million more this fiscal year. Supplements Existing Programs
title: U.S. Awards Drug Abuse Grants

text: Although Ronald Reagan's budget proposal for the 1990 fiscal year would have eliminated such grants, President Bush's proposal would restore $150 million to the program for that budget year, which begins Oct. 1.
title: U.S. Awards Drug Abuse Grants

text: A portion of the grants being distributed will be passed through to the local jurisdictions, which all submitted anti-drug strategies to the department to get the money.
title: U.S. Awards Drug Abuse Grants

text: The local governments will be able to use the money to supplement their existing programs.
title: U.S. Awards Drug Abuse Grants

text: The territories receiving money are American Samoa, Guam, Northern Mariana Islands, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.
title: U.S. Awards Drug Abuse Grants

text: California will receive the largest grant, $10,782,000. New York is in line for the next largest amount, $7,125,000; 61.7 percent of that will be passed through to local governments.
title: U.S. Awards Drug Abuse Grants

text: New Jersey will get $3,352,000, 60.7 percent of which will go to local governments. The figures for Connecticut are $1,693,000 and 45.1 percent.
title: U.S. Awards Drug Abuse Grants

text: Church experts see the recent dismembering of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese here, the world's largest, as part of an ongoing effort by the Vatican to dilute leftist influences in Brazil's church.
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: In March, the Vatican cut in half the flock of Sao Paulo's Archbishop, Paulo Evaristo Cardinal Arns, an outspoken advocate of liberation theology, a left-leaning doctrine. Under Cardinal Arns's leadership in the 1970's and 1980's, priests and lay workers here became active in struggles for human rights, for unionization of factory workers and for improving slum housing.
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: Under a reorganization announced by the Vatican on March 15, the archdiocese administered by Cardinal Arns was reduced to Sao Paulo's city core, a heavily middle-class area of 7.6 million residents.
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: Four new dioceses were created in Sao Paulo's impoverished periphery -an area of factories and, by one count, 1,000 slums. About 7 million people live in regions covered by the new dioceses of Osasco, Campo Limpo, Santo Amaro and Sao Miguel.
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: ''It's gerrymandering,'' said Ralph Della Cava, a history professor at the City University of New York, who has studied Brazil's church since 1964. ''Rome is trying to create a depoliticized Brazilian church.''
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: Cardinal Arns has had little to say on the reorganization.
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: At the Cardinal's ornate chancery here, Msgr. Sergio Conrado noted that when the Cardinal was appointed in 1971, he proposed dividing this city, Brazil's largest, into several dioceses. These new dioceses were to answer to the authority of a central archdiocese. After years of debate, the Vatican responded that such an arrangement would violate canon law guaranteeing the autonomy of bishops.
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: ''What we find strange is that there was no dialogue,'' said Monsignor Conrado, who is Sao Paulo's vicar general for pastoral affairs. ''The Vatican did not even acknowledge letters from priests and lay people here. None of the new bishops were on the list of the 12 bishops that Dom Paulo submitted.''
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: The Rev. Gilberto da Silva Gorgulho, a Dominican theologian, said that the new bishops ''were not as conservative as we feared.''
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: ''Our hope is that the hard reality of Sao Paulo will change the bishops,'' said Father da Silva, who is also a close adviser to Cardinal Arns.
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: Outside the church, the shrinking of Cardinal Arns's archdiocese was immediately interpreted politically.
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: On the day of the announcement, Luiza Erundina, Sao Paulo's new Marxist mayor, called the Vatican's move ''an authoritarian and irresponsible act'' that constituted ''a real blow to the consciousness-raising work of the church.''
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: Miss Erundina's party, the Worker's Party, has drawn strong electoral support from Catholics in Sao Paulo's slums. Previous Moves by Vatican
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: The trimming of Cardinal Arns's base in Sao Paulo appears to be part of a series of moves by Pope John Paul II in recent years to curtail the social activism of Brazil's church.
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: Starting in 1985, the Vatican imposed travel and speaking restrictions on two prominent advocates of liberation theology in Brazil: the Rev. Leonardo Boff, a Franciscan theologian in Petropolis, and Bishop Pedro Casaldaliga of Sao Felix do Araguaia.
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: The Vatican has also appointed conservatives to succeed liberals as archbishops in Brasilia, Recife and Salvador.
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: Last year, the Vatican started studying the curriculum of Brazilian seminaries. A report is expected here in June. In one back-to-basics move, the new Archbishop of Recife, Jose Cardoso Sobrinho, has purged liberation theology and stressed a return to traditional discipline in a Recife seminary.
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: Also last year, the Vatican transferred Luciano Mendes de Almeida, a bishop who worked here with Cardinal Arns, to the Archdiocese of Mariana in Minas Gerais, a conservative interior state. The bishop, who heads the powerful Brazil Conference of Bishops, now works in an isolated city of 35,000.
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: Until his transfer, Bishop Almeida was widely seen as Cardinal Arns's preferred candidate to succeed him.
title: Vatican Undercuts Leftist Theology in Brazil

text: The former lightweight champion of the world, the first man to beat Roberto Duran, is now 37 years old and weighs 90 pounds. His dark skin stretches over protruding cheekbones and his clothes hang loosely on his frame. His eyes are dull; his speech is slurred. Esteban de Jesus is living with AIDS.
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: ''You look into his eyes and you see sorrow,'' said Jose Abreu, another resident at the clinic where De Jesus is being treated.
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: The clinic is in an abandoned milk factory in Rio Piedras, Puerto Rico, that has been converted into a rehabilitation center for drug addicts. There, de Jesus lies on a bed in a room with 17 other men, all former drug addicts, all suffering from acquired immune deficiency syndrome. He gets medication-free treatment: vitamins, a high-calorie diet and rest. Sentence Commuted
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: Until March 28, de Jesus faced the possibility of dying in jail. He was serving a life sentence for first-degree murder, and was still four years away from possible parole, when his second request for a commutation of the sentence was granted by Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon. The parole board agreed to release him on the condition that he receive treatment at the AIDS clinic.
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: De Jesus was the underdog when he won a decision from Duran in 1972, in a nontitle bout in New York that was Duran's third fight after he won the lightweight title. That fight made de Jesus a celebrity in Puerto Rico, and the second time he fought Duran didn't tarnish that status. It was in Panama in 1974, with Duran's title at stake, and de Jesus lasted until the 11th round before being knocked out.
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: Later, de Jesus was the World Boxing Council lightweight champion, 1976-1978, and he defended his title three times. But he lost to Duran again in 1978, and with that, he lost his title and began sinking fast. His last opponent was Saoul Mamby, who stopped de Jesus in the 13th round for the W.B.C. superlightweight title on July 7, 1980. His record was 57-5 with 32 knockouts. From Marijuana to Cocaine
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: But even before his first bout with Duran, de Jesus was slowly burying himself under drug addiction. He began by smoking marijuana, then snorted cocaine, and by the end of his career, he was shooting up ''speedballs'' of cocaine and heroin. He, his older brother, Enrique, and their friends shared syringes of cocaine and heroin bought with de Jesus' earnings, according to his friends.
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: ''You start first with friends and you get so wrapped up with the drugs, that before you know it, you're hooked,'' de Jesus said last Feb. 12 on ''Pulso Preciso,'' a half-hour news program on Puerto Rican television. ''They take you to parties and you start using the stuff. The worst part is when you open your eyes, it's too late. You're already addicted.''
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: On Thanksgiving Day in 1980, de Jesus was dressing to attend a family holiday celebration when cocaine tempted him. ''I injected myself with it,'' he said on the news program. ''It hit me very hard. I felt the reaction very badly. Then I left in my wife's car.''
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: Somehow he got into a traffic dispute with 18-year-old Roberto Cintron Gonzalez, who was in another car. De Jesus jumped out of his car and shot Gonzalez in the head with a .25 caliber pistol; Gonzalez died Dec. 1, 1980.
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: ''I didn't even know that I was killing someone,'' because of the reaction to the cocaine, de Jesus said in the television interview. ''My wife told me that I had killed someone. I feel very bad for what I did.''
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: De Jesus was convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to life in prison. 'Didn't Use It to Fight'
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: Gregorio Benitez, the father of the former world champion Wilfred Benitez, trained de Jesus at the end of his amateur career and for part of his pro career. In 1974, before the rematch between de Jesus and Duran, the elder Benitez learned de Jesus was using drugs.
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: ''I knew that he used cocaine,'' the trainer recalled. ''He didn't use it to fight. An undercover cop came to me and said that Esteban used to be out at midnight with bad people, and they knew that he used the drugs. I told him that if he wanted to keep boxing, he should quit the drugs. He said, 'What?' He denied it.''
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: De Jesus, Benitez said, used to give money to a drug dealer named Louie, who would take de Jesus to parties where cocaine and women were plentiful. De Jesus and Louie bought a restaurant together, on which de Jesus lost $40,000, according to Benitez.
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: ''He was a good guy,'' Benitez said sadly of de Jesus. ''People made him bad.'' But, Benitez said, his frustration at de Jesus' continued drug use prompted him to sell the fighter's contract for $25,000 to Jose Santiago, another Puerto Rican-based boxing promoter. Santiago managed de Jesus and the boxer's trainer was Manny Siaca. 'A Very Big Thing'
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: In 1978, de Jesus lost to Duran for the second time, in Las Vegas, but he earned $150,000, the largest purse of his career. ''The loss to Duran was a very big thing to him,'' Siaca said, referring to the 1978 fight. ''He felt depressed, that it was the end for him, that he didn't have it anymore.''
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: Siaca and his wife, Nitza, had become close friends of de Jesus and his wife, Nelly.
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran
