text: ''He was very close with his family,'' Mrs. Siaca rcalled. ''He didn't like too much of a crowd. He was a very kind man, sweet and courteous. I never saw him angry. But as soon as he became champ, it was a new environment. He had new friends, big shots. Then he started using drugs.
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: ''When he was a champ, he had a lot of money, a lot of power. He was one of the kings of boxing in Puerto Rico.''
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: Over the course of 10 years, the Siacas and Nelly de Jesus several times prodded the fighter into receiving psychiatric help and other medical assistance.
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: ''He stopped taking drugs,'' said Mrs. Siaca. ''But he had a group that he went with. Nelly had no control over him.''
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: De Jesus was said to be very close to his mother, who died of a heart attack in 1980. ''He was affected very emotionally by her death,'' Mrs. Siaca said. ''He was very depressed.'' 'He Didn't Show Up'
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: After that death and the loss to Mamby a few weeks later, Gregorio Benitez tried to help de Jesus again.
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: ''I told him I wanted to make him a champion again,'' he said. ''Santiago said that he would give me Esteban free. I would put him in a fight for $15,000. He didn't show up. I said, 'Those people are going to kill you or you're going to kill someone.' ''
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: Four months later, de Jesus killed someone.
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: Sentenced to life in prison, de Jesus discovered the religious life, and he became a minister, preaching daily sermons in prison.
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: In 1985, he learned his older brother, Enrique, had died of AIDS. The brothers had shared needles, and Esteban de Jesus tested positive for the AIDS virus in 1985. Last January, the AIDS symptoms began to appear.
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: As he has lost weight and grown weaker, his faith in God has increased, his friends say. His wife and three children -Esteban Jr., 14 years old, Vivian, 16, and Lillian, 18 - visit him at the clinic regularly.
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: De Jesus may live for a month or two, or he may live for a year. ''I'm waiting to see what's to be God's will,'' he said in that Feb. 12 television interview. ''I'm in God's hands.''
title: This Foe's Tougher Than Duran

text: When Chris Antley gets a leg up on Unpredictable Lady in the first race at Aqueduct today, his many fans among the railbirds will start cheering for him to equal a hallowed record, one that has nothing whatsoever to do with horse racing.
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: When Antley and a 5-year-old gelding named Master Gene survived a stewards' inquiry to win the eighth race yesterday, it was the 55th straight day on which the jockey has won a race when he has ridden at Aqueduct.
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: With the exception of four programs on which he did not ride at all, he has won at least one race on every Aqueduct card since Feb. 8.
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: There are no official records kept on this sort of thing, but Antley's streak is believed to be the longest of its kind in modern racing history. The DiMaggio of Racing? Since no one knows exactly what to call this accomplishment, it has become known as a ''hitting streak.'' And once it got that name, and began to grow by the day, race-trackers began likening it to Joe DiMaggio's 56-game hitting streak for the 1941 New York Yankees.
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: When this strained analogy was first brought to Antley's attention last week, he responded quizzically to what he thought was a comparison to an ancient jockey.
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: ''Was this DiMaggio better than Steve Cauthen?'' he asked.
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: The comparison to DiMaggio may be bogus, and the streak merits a large asterisk: Antley was blanked during two out-of-town riding trips. But there is nothing counterfeit about Antley's dominance of Aqueduct racing over the last 10 weeks.
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: He is on one of those rare rolls that some rider hits every few years. He seems to get all the live mounts, and then does everything right in the saddle, which brings him more top mounts and more victories. Antley is riding an unusual number of favorites that any competent rider could win with, but he also is riding them flawlessly. Batting .307 on Mounts
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: Since beginning his streak on Feb. 8, he has ridden 129 winners from 419 mounts, a batting average of .307 in a sport where the nation's leaders rarely crack .250. At the Aqueduct spring meeting, which began March 15, Antley has ridden 67 winners. Richard Castillo is a distant second in the standing with 24.
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: Antley said yesterday that he was enjoying the streak, and would like to extend it if only for the gratification of the fans, who have made it an issue. That the streak is an issue to Antley as well was obvious at the finish of yesterday's eighth race.
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: As he crossed the wire a narrow winner, Antley raised his whip with a triumphant flourish, a gesture usually reserved for major stakes scores. He had lost with his first six mounts on the card, then went out and won with both Master Gene in the eighth and Crown Land in the finale.
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: Antley says he would be happy to have won only a race every other day this year - in fact, he says, he feels lucky to be riding at all. Just four months ago, the 23-year-old jockey thought his career was over. A Fast-Lane Reputation
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: Antley who began riding in Maryland in 1983 and moved to the New York-New Jersey circuit a year later, quickly developed a reputation for living in the fast lane. His career was surrounded by rumors of drug and alcohol use early in his career and in October 1986, he failed a Breathalyzer test at the Meadowlands.
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: He was taken off his mounts that night and fined $250, and the incident made Antley subject to probable-cause drug testing in New York. Fourteen months ago he tested positive for marijuana at Aqueduct. The test result was kept confidential and Antley promised officials to stop using drugs and undergo treatment. But last November, he tested positive for cocaine at Aqueduct, and was suspended pending completion of a 28-day in-patient rehabilitation program at the Smithers Institute in Manhattan.
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: Antley was released from the program Jan. 1, and began what he calls ''a new life.'' His agent and best friend, Drew Mollica, began lining up mounts for him again, and Antley returned to the saddle Jan. 25 at Aqueduct. He won the next day on his 10th mount back, and began his streak two weeks later.
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: Antley says he feels he is riding better now than when he was involved with drugs, because he is happier and more confident. He attends twice-weekly meetings at Smithers, as well as Alcoholics Anonymus and Narcotics Anonymous meetings, and is subject to regular drug testing.
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: He is riding for all his old customers and new ones such as the powerful D. Wayne Lukas outfit. But New York racing is just beginning to emerge from its long winter season of second-class racing. The competition will get tougher among the riders in the weeks to come, as many New York regulars who wintered in Florida or rode here only part time will be back in full swing when Belmont Park opens May 10.
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: Antley is facing a 10-day suspension for causing interference in a race last Thursday, but has appealed the ruling, staying it at least until a May 12 hearing. And on Tuesday he picked up a mount for the race he and every other rider wants to win most of all: he was named to replace Jose Santos aboard Dispersal, who will run in the Lexington Stakes at Keeneland next Tuesday and, if all goes well, in the Kentucky Derby 11 days later.
title: The King of the Winner's Circle

text: By Jeffrey Schmalz, Special To the New York Times
title: Copter Crash Foils an Inmate's Attempt to Escape

text: A helicopter swooped into the exercise yard of a Federal prison near here today and snatched up a waiting inmate, but it crashed seconds later when its blades caught in one of the prison's wire fences.
title: Copter Crash Foils an Inmate's Attempt to Escape

text: The warden, John Clark, said Benjamin Barry Kramer, a 34-year-old inmate, had apparently been expecting the helicopter. Mr. Kramer was serving a life sentence without the possibility of parole for heading a drug-selling ring.
title: Copter Crash Foils an Inmate's Attempt to Escape

text: The warden said Mr. Kramer was in the 50-by-200-foot exercise yard with a half dozen other inmates when the helicopter appeared about 10 A.M. He jumped up to catch the bottom of the helicopter as it descended. But when the 6-foot-2-inch inmate, who weighs more than 200 pounds, did so, the copter tipped slightly, and its blades hit the fence.
title: Copter Crash Foils an Inmate's Attempt to Escape

text: The craft than crashed nose first into the yard of the prison, the Metropolitan Correctional Center in South Dade, breaking Mr. Kramer's ankle. The pilot was critically injured with a broken neck. Pilot Just Learned to Fly
title: Copter Crash Foils an Inmate's Attempt to Escape

text: Federal officials tentatively identified the pilot as Charles C. Stevens. They said he had apparently learned to fly specifically for the escape and had taken lessons over the last six months, accumulating about 35 to 40 hours of flying time. Officials said the nature of the relationship between Mr. Stevens and Mr. Kramer was not clear.
title: Copter Crash Foils an Inmate's Attempt to Escape

text: No inmates escaped in the incident, and no shots were fired. The prison, which houses 1,000 inmates, is primarily medium security and holds prisoners awaiting trial. Mr. Kramer was in a special 50-inmate maximum-security section.
title: Copter Crash Foils an Inmate's Attempt to Escape

text: Mr. Kramer, a former champion racer of powerboats, was still in the prison because he was awaiting disposition of a marijuana smuggling charge and a gun charge. Officials said he would now be charged with escape, which carries a maximum penalty of five years.
title: Copter Crash Foils an Inmate's Attempt to Escape

text: The prison was the site of another attempted escape by helicopter that also failed. Three years ago, an inmate arranged for a helicopter to fly onto the prison yard. But his contact was actually a Federal agent, and agents in the copter arrested him when he entered.
title: Copter Crash Foils an Inmate's Attempt to Escape

text: Officials along the 1,960-mile border between the United States and Mexico say they are seeing a rising tide of violence as trafficking in drugs and illegal aliens flourishes amid grinding poverty.
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: Nothing thus far has approached the shock generated by the discovery of a mass grave at the Rancho Santa Elena 20 miles west of Matamoros this week and the disclosure of the drug trafficking and occult network behind the killings. Officials believe more bodies may be found there or at other sites. [ The authorities today discovered two more bodies buried on a collective farm two miles south of the ranch where 13 victims were found last week, The Associated Press reported. The A.P. quoted the authorities as saying that the bodies, of adult men, had not been mutilated as the others had been and that they apparently had been killed by the same cult in a soured drug deal. ] The nightmarish tale of drug smuggling and human sacrifice that unfolded over the past week at an isolated ranch near Matamoros, just south of the border, may have been the most grotesque. But to officials in both countries, it was only the latest incident in what has become a steady drumbeat of violence, most of it drug-related.
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: Just as drug-ravaged inner cities are seeing escalating violence, the border region, where north and south meet, is seeing better armed, better organized and more vicious criminal activity, the officials say. Some incidents are well publicized. Most are part of the daily fabric of the region and the illegal activities that flourish there. Violence: Organized and Random
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: Some incidents have rivaled the one in Matamoros. Just last month, Mexican officials found 12 mutilated bodies in a well and cesspool on a ranch near the Mexican town of Agua Prieta across from Douglas, Ariz. The killings are believed to be drug-related, as were the earlier shooting deaths of five people in Tucson.
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: Other cases have involved seemingly random acts of violence. In November, a Texas man was killed and his wife injured in a sniper attack as they were rafting along the Rio Grande in west Texas. The suspected assailants were caught, but last month another group of rafters had to swim for their lives after they were fired on by snipers on the Mexican side of the river.
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: The Rio Grande Valley has long been rife with rumors of occult and satanic activity, and reports of mutilated animals and occult observances surfaced throughout the border area after the discovery of the ritual murders. In the Shadows
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: Most of the violence, though, goes on in the shadows, where trafficking in drugs and aliens has transformed the border. Sometimes the victims are drug traffickers. More often they are hapless aliens trying to make their way north.
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: ''Shootings, stabbings, murder, rape, sodomizing - you name it, we see it,'' said Norbert Gomez, public information officer with the United States Border Patrol in San Diego.
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: ''There's more pre-demand violence - attacks that precede a robbery attempt,'' he said. ''It's not like someone walks in a liquor store and says, 'Put your hands up and give me your money.' Instead, someone sees a group coming down a trail, shoots one of them from behind a bush and then starts going through the others' pockets. The violence along the border is getting out of hand.''
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: Border patrol agents say their work has been transformed over the past two or three years.
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: Robert E. Wooten, patrol agent in charge of the Brownsville Border Patrol Station, recounted an incident a few weeks back in which an agent in a van pursued an alien near the border. The alien stopped, dropped to one knee in a military stance and fired nine shots at the agent's van with an M-16 rifle. The agent got out of the van just in time to escape injury, he said.
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: ''Our guys come in now better armed then they used to be,'' he said. ''Almost to a man they're walking out with a bulletproof vest. It's kind of ridiculous to go out against an M-16 with a six-shot revolver like I'm carrying. It's a more serious business now than it used to be.'' Lawlessness Not New to Border
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: Lawlessness and illicit pleasures are not new to the border. Smugglers brought tequila across the border in Prohibition much as marijuana smugglers do today. And the streets and shops of Matamoros, full of life late into the night, still seem safer than those of most large American cities.
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: One of the most obvious factors making crime increasingly vicious along the border is the ever-growing drug trade and the increasing competition among rival dealers. Stepped-up enforcement in Florida has led to a steady increase in drug trafficking through Mexico, and officials say smuggling enterprises continue to expand. Mr. Wooten said his officers recently seized 700 bottles of a codeine-laden cough syrup smuggled from Mexico that sells for $30 a bottle on the American side of the border.
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: ''In the past when we found a body along the river, it was someone who drowned,'' said Gus Garcia, assistant chief of the McAllen Border Patrol sector that includes Brownsville. ''Now you don't know what to expect - someone shot to death, someone decapitated, now this satanism.''''
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: The discovery of the bodies at the Rancho Santa Elena came at a time of increased police investigation generated by the disappearance on March 14 of Mark Kilroy, a 21-year-old University of Texas student. A chance marijuana arrest led Mexican law-enforcement officials to Rancho Santa Elena, which was strewn with occult paraphernalia and human and animal remains. The arrested man began describing the ritual murders at the ranch, and the story unraveled. Extraordinary Attention
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: Five suspects are now in custody. Officials are still searching for eight others, including the cult's suspected ringleader, Adolfo de Jesus Constanzo, 26 years old, who grew up in Miami in a family of Cuban descent.
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: The abduction and mutilation murder of an American brought extraordinary attention to the story. Dozens of missing Mexicans had generated no such concern, argued the Matamoros residents who gathered at city hall Thursday to berate city officials.
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: It was a reflection of the increased concern about drug-related violence on both sides of the border.
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: Mr. Garcia of the Border Patrol recalled how as a youth he and his friends used to play along the Rio Grande. ''Back then we would go swimming in the river with no thought of danger,'' he said. ''Now, people don't dare go near the river because there's so much junk being brought across.''
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: He sat at Mr. Wooten's desk, a sticker reading ''America's Frontline - U.S. Border Patrol - Promotes a Drug-Free Valley'' in front of him. But the credible goal on the river remains containment, not elimination of the drug trade and the mayhem that is coming with it. Threat From a Suspect
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: MEXICO CITY, April 16 (Reuters) - The Mexican police said they were on special alert today after receiving a threat that children in Matamoros would be kidnapped and killed if five suspects being held in the ritual murders were not freed.
title: Torrent of Violence by the Rio Grande

text: LEAD: I have been Hungarian for 38 years. I'll try something else for the next 38. I'll try to be American, for instance.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: I have been Hungarian for 38 years. I'll try something else for the next 38. I'll try to be American, for instance.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: North American, I mean. As an American, I'll speak English fluently. I'll make American mistakes instead of Hungarian mistakes and I'll call them slang.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: As an American, I'll have a credit card. Or two. I'll use and misuse them and have to pay the fees. I'll apply for other cards right away. Golden Visa. Golden American. Golden Gate. And I'll buy a car, a great American car. Then I'll sell my car and buy a smaller West German car because it's reliable and doesn't use so much gasoline. Later, I'll sell it and buy a smaller Japanese car with a computer aboard. Then I'll sell it and buy a camper. When I sell the camper I'll buy a bicycle.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: As an American, I'll buy a dog. And a cat. And a goat. And a white whale. And also some big stones as pets.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: I'll live in my own house. It will be mine, except for the 99 percent mortgage. I'll sell my house and buy a condo. I'll sell my condo and buy a mobile home. I'll sell my mobile home and buy an igloo. I'll sell my igloo and buy a tent. As an American, I'll be clever: I'll sell my igloo and buy a tent when I move to Florida from Alaska.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: Anyway, I'll move a lot. And I'll buy the best dishwasher, microwave, dryer and hi-fi in the world - that is, the U.S.A. I'll have warranty for all -or my money back. I'll use automatic toothbrushes, egg boilers and garage doors. I'll call every single phone number starting 1-800.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: I'll buy the fastest food I can get and I'll eat it very slowly because I'll watch TV during the meals. Of course, I'll buy a VCR. I'll watch the taped programs and then retape. Sometimes I'll retape first. As an American, I'll have an answering machine, too. The outgoing message will promise that I'll call you back as soon as possible, but it won't be possible soon.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: If I answer the phone as an exception, I'll tell you that I can't talk now because I have a long-distance call on the other line, but I'll call you back as soon as possible (see above).
title: How I'll Become an American

text: And I'll get a job. I'll always be looking for a better job, but I won't get the job I want. I'll work really hard since as an American I wanna be rich. I'll be always in a hurry: Time Is Money. Unfortunately, my time won't be worth as much money as my bosses' time. Sometimes I will have some time and I still won't have enough money. Then I'll start to hate the wisdom of this saying.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: As an American, sometimes I'll be badly depressed. I'll be the patient of 12 psychiatrists, and I'll be disappointed with all of them. I'll try to change my life a little bit. I'll try to exchange my wives, my cars, my lovers, my houses, my children, my jobs and my pets.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: Sometimes, I'll exchange a few dollars into other currencies and I'll travel to Europe, Hawaii, Tunisia, Martinique and Japan. I'll be happy to see that people all over the world are jealous of us Americans.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: I'll take at least 2,000 snapshots on each trip. I'll also buy a video camera and shoot everywhere. I'll look at the tapes, photos and slides, and I'll try to remember my experiences when I have time and am in the mood. But I won't have time or be in the mood because I'll get depressed again and again.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: I'll smoke cigarettes. Then I'll be afraid of cancer and I'll stop. I'll smoke cigars. And opium. I'll take a breather and then try LSD and heroin and cocaine and marijuana. To top it all off: crack. I'll try to stop then but I won't be able.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: I'll call 1-800-222-HELP. If nothing helps, I'll have some gay experiences. And swing. And if I am still unhappy, I'll make a final effort: I'll try to read a book. I'll buy some best sellers. I'll prefer James A. Michener. My second favorite will be the ''How to Be Rich in Seven Weeks.'' I'll try to follow this advice in seven years.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: I'll always be concerned about my health as an American. I won't eat anything but health food until I get ill. From time to time, I'll read in the paper that I should stop eating meat, sugar, bread, fiber, grains, iron, toothpaste, and that I should stop drinking milk, soda, water, acid rain. I'll try to follow this advice, but then I'll read in the paper that I should do it the other way around.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: I'll be puzzled. ''Hey, I don't even know what cholesterol is!'' Yet I'll stick to decaf coffee, sugar-free cookies, salt-free butter and lead-free gasoline. I'll believe that proper diet and exercise make life longer. I'll go jogging every day until I am mugged twice and knocked down three times. Then I'll just exercise in my room, but it will also increase my appetite. I'll go on several diets, and little by little I'll reach 200 pounds.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: As an American, I'll buy a new TV every time a larger screen appears on the market. In the end, the screen will be larger than the room. It will be difficult to put this enormous TV into my living room; thus, I will put my living room into the TV. Anyway, my living room will look very much like the living rooms you can see on the screen. My life won't differ from the lives you can see in the soaps: nobody will complain. I won't complain either. I'll always smile.
title: How I'll Become an American

text: After all, we are Americans, aren't we?
title: How I'll Become an American

text: The most notorious drug-trafficking figure in Mexico, Miguel Angel Felix Gallardo, is finally behind bars. But the culture from which he emerged, a virulent combination of violence and vast illegal wealth, remains deeply rooted here in his home city and state.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: Hours after he was arrested on April 8, army troops here rounded up the entire city police force - about 300 men - for questioning about possible links to Mr. Felix Gallardo, who American officials believe smuggled as much as two tons of cocaine into the United States each month. In the days that have followed, authorities say, as many as 90 of the officers have deserted.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: At the Sinaloa State Judicial Police headquarters on Emiliano Zapata Boulevard, another 15 to 18 of the 230 state policemen based in Culiacan are reported to have deserted. In addition, the state Public Security Director has been fired and his house seized, and the chiefs of the municipal and state police are in jail.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo, announcing Mr. Felix Gallardo's arrest last Monday, described him as the ''No. 1 narcotics trafficker in Mexico.'' He has been charged with drug trafficking and bribery, and the investigation of his activities continues. Rule by Intimidation
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: Many residents here are glad to see Mr. Felix Gallardo and his associates go, and hope the house cleaning continues. From bitter experience, they have come to look upon the police and many of their elected officials as allies, rather than foes, of the men with the flashy cars and flashier jewelry who have become an increasingly common sight around town in the last decade.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: ''For years, we have lived under the reign of the machine gun,'' said Norma Corona Sapien, director of the Human Rights Commission of Sinaloa. ''The narcos thought they had protection and could act with impunity, so that's what they did, kidnapping and raping young girls, getting into drunken fights on the street, killing each other and generally acting as if they owned the city.''
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: No resident, no matter how affluent or influential, can be said to be truly immune from the rule by intimidation that the narcotics trade has imposed on this city of 600,000. Manuel Clouthier, presidential candidate of the conservative National Action Party in the election last year, is a native of Sinaloa willing to testify to that.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: ''On Valentines Day three years ago, a group of narcos a couple of blocks away held a party and were firing shots into the air,'' he said. ''I went to the police post on the street to ask them to do something, and when they wouldn't act, I called the police station, which didn't do anything either. The police were afraid of what might happen.'' Trafficking in High Schools
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: With marijuana and cocaine in such abundance here, it is hardly surprising that Culiacan has developed a drug consumption problem of its own. A state education official acknowledged this week that there is a ''strong marijuana traffic'' in high schools here, and parent groups at elementary schools have made similar complaints, even marching in protest.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: Drugs were first cultivated commercially in Sinaloa during World War II, when the United States was cut off from its traditional Asian sources of the poppy flower used to make morphine.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: Marijuana entered the picture in a big way somewhat later, again in response to the demand of the American market, setting the stage for the appearance of cocaine little more than a decade ago.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: Most people here agree that the situation reached its nadir during the administration of Antonio Toledo Corro, who was governor from 1981 through 1986. The governor and Mr. Felix Gallardo were once members of the same wedding party, posing together publicly for pictures.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: According to American officials, Mr. Felix Gallardo also spent a time as the governor's house guest, which Mr. Toledo Corro has denied. When asked about his association with Mr. Felix Gallardo, the governor said he was ''unaware of any outstanding arrest warrants'' against the drug figure, though six such orders had been in effect since 1981.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: ''When the new administration took over in 1987, we found some police commanders to be narcos,'' said Eduardo Aispuro Beltran, a spokesman for the State Judicial Police. ''It was the most incredible and intolerable thing to find the police body to be completely infiltrated by narcos.''
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: But earlier governors also appear to have been at least partly aware of the problem - and to have failed to act. A business leader here tells of riding in a car with Mr. Toledo Corro's predecessor one day and having to pull to the side of a narrow highway to make way for a dozen or so open trucks hauling marijuana that was visible from the car.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: ''I didn't do anything,'' the business leader said when he was asked what his response to the incident had been. ''I wasn't the governor and I certainly am not the police.''
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: Thus, while Mr. Felix Gallardo's arrest was cheered here, many of the state's most prominent citizens say the action will lose much of its impact if it is not accompanied by other prosecutions.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: ''They have moved against the narco traffickers, but let's see if they are willing to do the same to the narco politicians,'' a journalist said. Anonymous Death Threats
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: When asked if the government contemplated legal action against Mr. Toledo Corro, who has extensive business interests in the Mazatlan area, State Attorney General Manuel Lazcano Ochoa said that ''we are sure the investigation now under way by the federal government will clarify many things.'' But he added that, as of now, ''we do not have the elements'' to make a case.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: The current Governor, Francisco Labastida Ochoa, campaigned on a law-and-order, anti-drug platform the traffickers appear to have taken seriously.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: He received anonymous death threats during the campaign, state officials say, and has twice apparently been the target of assassination attempts.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: In one incident, his official car was sprayed with gunfire as he returned home late one evening. Once an attempt was made to run his car off the road.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: Other prominent enemies of the drug bosses have been less fortunate. Jesus Michel Jacobo, a crusading lawyer active in the Human Rights Commission, was killed late in 1987 by four gunmen, followed a few months later by Manuel Burgueno Orduno, a journalist who had written of links between drug traffickers and politicians. Suspects Celebrated in Songs
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: ''He denounced things, he knew a lot, and he became an inconvenience,'' said Mr. Michel's sister, Carmen, of her brother. ''And the police have done nothing, and we don't have the means ourselves to investigate,'' said her father, Jesus Michel Salas, owner of an agricultural equipment business.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: In 1986, more than 1,400 people were killed in Sinaloa, a remarkable figure in a state with a population of 2.6 million. That figure declined to 506 last year, in part because drug violence has now spread to neighboring states: two nephews of Mr. Felix Gallardo's, for instance, were reported killed just over the state line last month.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: Mr. Felix Gallardo, like Rafael Caro Quintero and Ernesto Fonseca Carrillo, two other prominent cocaine-trafficking figures who are also in custody, lived in a humble part of town called Tierra Blanca when he first arrived in Culiacan from the countryside. Their rise is celebrated in songs played on radio stations here.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: ''I remember when he used to sell chicken and sausages from the back of his bicycle,'' Humberto Millan, an air-conditioning repairman who still lives in the old neighborhood, said of Mr. Felix Gallardo. ''He was very popular.''
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: The state government, Mr. Lazcano said, recognizes that ''here in Sinaloa a consequence of the drug trade has been a climate in which there is a high rate of common crimes'' and vowed to push ahead on all fronts. Many here, however, would argue that the government has no choice in the matter.
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: ''Everybody knew all of these things were going on, but nobody did anything about it because they did not dare,'' Mr. Michel said. ''The president of the republic has been very brave in confronting the narcos, but he faces dangers now because of what he has done. He can't afford to turn back, or we all will suffer.''
title: In Mexico, Drug Roots Run Deep

text: AFTER years of chafing at American complaints of its inability to catch any of the ''big fish'' of the drug trade, Mexico last week blunted such criticism by netting the biggest fish of them all. But even as law enforcement officials here were proudly exhibiting Miguel Angel Felix Gallardo and the policeman he is accused of suborning with monthly five-figure bribes, they were also cautioning privately against premature declarations of victory in the growing war against cocaine, heroin and marijuana profiteers.
title: As Mexico Moves On Drug Dealers, More Move In

text: Indeed, the capture of the 43-year-old Mr. Felix Gallardo, who is said to have earned hundreds of millions of dollars over 15 years by shipping as much as two tons of cocaine into the United States each month, is likely to provide yet another example of what Drug Enforcement Administration officials in the field and their Latin American counterparts refer to as ''the hydra-head phenomenon.'' For every drug boss jailed, two move in to try to take his place. For every area of cultivation brought under control, several more spring up. For every trafficking route blocked, an alternative eventually appears.
title: As Mexico Moves On Drug Dealers, More Move In

text: In the short run, the political will demonstrated by the Government in arresting Mr. Felix Gallardo is likely to disrupt trafficking patterns painstakingly built up over several years and to raise the morale of those comandantes here who in the past would have liked to act aggressively against drug dealers but felt they had no political support. But it also creates an opportunity for smaller-scale traffickers who aspire to become ''international drug kingpins,'' as a State Department spokesman described Mr. Felix Gallardo in discussing the United States Government's delight at his arrest. A Trampoline
title: As Mexico Moves On Drug Dealers, More Move In

text: The most likely candidate is El Cochiloco (the Mad Brute), a trafficker whose real name is Miguel Manuel Salcido and who like Mr. Felix Gallardo has been especially active in northwestern Mexico. ''Cochiloco is a notch or two below Felix Gallardo, but he is the logical suspect,'' an official here said. ''I'll bet you he is trying to expand his operations right now.''
title: As Mexico Moves On Drug Dealers, More Move In

text: The Reagan Administration learned a similar lesson about the resilience of the drug trade when it conducted an ambitious and somewhat successful drug interdiction program in the Caribbean several years ago. Colombia's Medellin cartel responded by stepping up its use of Mexico as a trampoline to the United States, an action that ultimately benefited Mr. Felix Gallardo and other Mexican traffickers.
title: As Mexico Moves On Drug Dealers, More Move In

text: Over the last two years, in fact, the Colombians have found the Mexican route so convenient that they appear to have given thought to dispensing with Mexican middlemen and operating it on their own. That is one possible explanation for stunning outbreaks of violence in towns near the Arizona border like Caborca and Agua Prieta. ''The very brutality suggests a Colombian hit,'' one officer said. ''They don't respect family, so wives and kids go down too.''
title: As Mexico Moves On Drug Dealers, More Move In

text: Drug routes and who controls them also appear to be behind recent turmoil in Haiti. State Department officials in Washington said last week that Gen. Prosper Avril, who took power in a coup last year, has in recent months made progress in cutting down on military involvement in drug transshipments through Haiti. That shift was considered a prime reason why other Haitian military officers sought his ouster. So now the South American drug lords are likely to focus their attention elsewhere. Shifting Operations
title: As Mexico Moves On Drug Dealers, More Move In

text: ''You can always count on them to look for the weakest link,'' one American official said, recommending increased vigilance in Central American and Caribbean locations that would make attractive staging areas for the Colombia cartel.
title: As Mexico Moves On Drug Dealers, More Move In

text: Authorities here and in the United States believe that they can frustrate Colombian efforts to operate in Mexico on their own in Mr. Felix Gallardo's absence. ''You're talking about long distances, with needs for support and landing,'' said one. But they are less confident about their ability to do the same with cultivation.
title: As Mexico Moves On Drug Dealers, More Move In

text: Mexico, for example, has had some success in recent years in its efforts to extirpate marijuana and poppy fields in the northern states of Sinaloa and Durango, thanks in part to the tenacity of the military commander in the area, Gen. Rodolfo Reta Trigo. But traffickers shifted some operations southward to Oaxaca, and eventually General Reta Trigo had to be reassigned to that state to try to repeat his success.
title: As Mexico Moves On Drug Dealers, More Move In

text: Much the same has occurred in South America with coca. Efforts to wean away parts of Bolivia and Peru through crop substitution or eradication have encouraged local drug lords to pop up elsewhere. Colombian middlemen have also encouraged Indians in Brazil's western Amazon to become growers. While they produce a weaker strain of coca, their production areas are closer to processing centers.
title: As Mexico Moves On Drug Dealers, More Move In

text: On Friday, the Colombian President, Virgilio Barco, delivered a speech in Washington in which he called for greater coordination of intelligence and greater police cooperation between the United States and the drug-producing countries it often criticizes. The same day, Mexico's Attorney General, Enrique Alvarez del Castillo, met in Washington with his American counterpart, Dick Thornburgh, to discuss ways the two countries might follow up on the arrest of Mr. Felix Gallardo. In neither instance, however, are the drug traffickers likely to stand still.
title: As Mexico Moves On Drug Dealers, More Move In

text: ''It's the same thing as with Carlos Lehder,'' one American official said, referring to the Colombian boss now serving a life sentence in an American jail following a cocaine trafficking conviction in Florida last year. ''They put him away, and it didn't put Colombia out of business,'' the official said. ''Getting rid of Felix Gallardo isn't going to put a stop to things either.''
title: As Mexico Moves On Drug Dealers, More Move In

text: Officials today found a 13th body on an isolated ranch west of here and stepped up their hunt for a Cuban believed to be the leader of a drug-smuggling and ritual-murder cult that was apparently responsible for the killings.
title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed

text: What began as a hunt for a missing University of Texas student, Mark Kilory, whose body was one of 12 found at the ranch Tuesday, turned into a spectacle as the police forced one of those arrested in the case to dig up the 13th body.
title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed

text: The body was found after one of the five arrested Wednesday told the Mexican police that he knew where another body was. With television cameras recording his efforts and sweat drenching his body, Sergio Martinez, 23 years old, was forced to dig with a pick and shovel until he found a badly decomposed body. Using a rope attached to the corpse's bare feet, he then tugged at it until he and another man hauled it from the moist, brown earth. Honor Student Implicated
title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed

text: The officials said six of the victims had been identified, one as a Matamoros police officer and another as a police informer. They also said officials believed that at least one victim other than Mr. Kilroy was a resident of the United States.
title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed

text: At a college in Brownsville, Tex., the report that a 24-year-old honor student had been implicated in the crimes stunned those who knew her.
title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed

text: Sara Maria Aldrete is a student at Texas Southmost College, a two-year institution in Brownsville with an enrollment of 6,500 students, where one of the five arrested Wednesday was also a student. Officials said they found occult materials at a house Ms. Aldrete frequented in Matamoros and said she was part of the drug network led by the suspected Cuban smuggler, Adolfo de Jesus Constanzo.
title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed

text: Officials said she had led a double life that included school on the one hand and clandestine activities with the smugglers on the other. But teachers and friends described her as a friendly, hard-working physical education major who had shown no signs of abnormal behavior or occult interests.
title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed

text: ''She's a model student,'' said Marvene Wallace, a physical education instructor at the college. ''We didn't have any problems with her, no tempers and no sulking or anything weird. I just cannot believe it unless I hear Sara say it happened.''
title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed

text: Ms. Aldrete was described as being about 6 feet tall and attractive. She was listed in the college's ''Who's Who'' directory that honors students with grade averages of at least a 3.0 and wide involvement in activities.
title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed

text: In crowded press conferences in Brownsville today, officials released descriptions of Mr. Constanzo, a 26-year-old Cuban national known as El Padrino, or ''the godfather.'' Officials said suspects described Mr. Constanzo as the leader of a major smuggling operation that operated in Miami and along the border. They said he lived in a flashy, expensive life style, paying cash for a 1989 Mercedes and owning several homes.
title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed

text: Mr. Constanzo was described by the police as about 5 feet 11 inches tall, with a solid build and long dark hair.
title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed

text: Officials now believe the drug operation is larger than they first thought, and that it smuggled about a ton of marijuana into the United States each week.
title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed

text: Suspects said Mr. Constanzo organized the ritual murders and personally picked victims from the streets and then executed them as part of ritual killings designed to protect members of the smuggling ring from harm.
title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed

text: Unlike Mr. Kilroy, whose disappearance on March 14 was widely publicized, most of those missing here disappeared in anonymity.
title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed

text: The ultimate mystery, however, remains the behavior of the cult members, most of them from relatively well-to-do, upper-middle-class Mexican families.
title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed

text: Mr. Martinez, dressed in blue jeans, a blue shirt and moccasins without laces and wearing a surgical mask to ward off the stench, showed little emotion as he dug up the body he said he had helped bury. When it was over, he calmly answered questions, but gave little insight into how the group operated. He said he was a minor player who did not take part in any murders. He showed no emotion as he answered questions, and then was placed in the back of a pickup truck and driven back to jail in Matamoros.
title: 13th Victim Is Found on Ranch Where Drugs and Occult Mixed

text: Officials from two countries told a gruesome story today of drugs, ritual murder and the occult that has begun to unfold at a remote ranch in the bleak, empty countryside near the United States border.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: On Tuesday, the officials found the bodies of 12 people, including a 21-year-old University of Texas student who had vanished here a month ago, in eight crude graves on the ranch. Today, at news conferences here and in Brownsville, Tex., the officials said that a drug gang, seeing human sacrifice as ''a magical shield'' that would protect it from the police, was responsible for the murders.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: Four young suspects have been arrested, and the officials said four more are being sought. They said the suspects had told them there were at least two more bodies.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: And the officials said they had found a bloodstained altar with clothing and pictures of small children in a vacant house in the city of Matamoros, 20 miles from the ranch.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: A Ringleader Is Sought Among the suspects still at large is an accused drug smuggler identified as Adolfo de Jesus Constanzo, a native of Cuba, whom the others call El Padrino - the godfather. The police said he ordered the ritual murders, pointing out young men at random on city streets for his followers to abduct, then murder and mutilate on the ranch. One of the victims, as yet unidentified, is believed to have been abducted from a street in Brownsville.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: The officials described the murders as a twisted blend of sacrificial and black magic practices from Haiti, Cuba and Jamaica. They said Mr. Constanzo told the other drug traffickers that the ritual murders would protect them from harm, even from bullets.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: At a crowded news conference here, the four suspects said they abducted Mark Kilroy, a 21-year-old pre-medical student on spring break from the University of Texas, from a Matamoros street as part of the group's occult activities.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: ''We killed them for protection,'' said Elio Hernandez Rivera, 22 years old, of Matamoros.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: Mr. Rivera and his fellow suspects spoke in nonchalant tones, and Oran Neck, a United States customs agent, said, ''They didn't demonstrate any remorse at all.''
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: ''They were laughing, giggling,'' he added. ''They didn't seem to have any reason to be ashamed. It was unbelievable.''
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: The officials are also trying to determine whether ritual murders of young children have been carried out in a blood-spattered house in the city of Matamoros, frequented by a woman identified as Mr. Constanzo's companion, Sara Villareal Aldrette, 24. They said they found pictures and clothing of young children in the house.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: Ms. Aldrette, Mr. Constanzo and two others are being sought in connection with the case. The police identified the suspects under arrest as Mr. Rivera, 22, Sergio Martinez, 23, and David Serna Valdez, 23, all of Matamoros, and Serafin Hernandez Garcia,22, of Brownsville. Mr. Garcia is a United States citizen.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: Rancho Santa Elena is at the end of a bumpy, mile-long dirt road on flat, empty terrain dotted by farms, ranches and an occasional hovel. The 14-by-24-foot shack where the killings allegedly took place stood like a ghoulish still life today, unguarded by police officers. On the concrete floor were scattered dozens of cigars and chili peppers, boxes of altar candles and empty bottles of cheap Mexican tequila.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: By the front door was a large cauldron in which a horseshoe, turtle, goat's feet and other animal remains floated in a dank soup with large sticks protruding from it. The police said human blood and body parts were mixed in and boiled as part of the ritual killing.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: In smaller pots nearby were the remains of animals, including a goat's head and a rooster.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: A single spent shell sat on a ledge. Around the compound, surrounded by cornfields and grazing cattle more than a mile off the main road, were empty graves, several of them in a crude corral. Teamwork Is Cited
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: The officials said Mr. Kilroy's March 14 disappearance, widely publicized throughout Texas, helped lead law-enforcement agents to the drug network. Texas Attorney General Jim Mattox said the investigation that led to the suspects took advantage of extraordinary cooperation between Mexico and the United States.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: The officials said the suspects told them that two of the killings were reprisal murders of associates of the drug traffickers but that the rest, like Mr. Kilroy, were utterly random.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: Mr. Kilroy had been drinking with friends on spring break in this border city, which is a favorite haunt of Texas college students.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: The officials said Mr. Constanzo told his cohorts that he wanted to kidnap and sacrifice an American student. The suspects said they called to Mr. Kilroy from a pickup truck and then dragged him inside.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: Mr. Mattox said there was no indication that they offered Mr. Kilroy drugs or that he had any history of drug use. ''There is no indication he was anything but a victim of circumstances,'' the Attorney General said. ''It could have happened to anyone in this room.'' A Failed Escape
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: The officials said Mr. Constanzo killed Mr. Kilroy with a machete chop to the back of the neck when he tried to escape about 12 hours after being taken to the ranch. The suspects said a number of the victims were dismembered.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: ''They clearly believed the human sacrifice and the animal sacrifice put a magical shield around them that protected them from evil or harm up to bullets,'' Mr. Mattox said.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: The authorities are still trying to determine the full extent of the sacrificial killings. They said there was no way to tell whether there were other killings or whether they had any link to several widely publicized drug killings along the border in recent months.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: ''They admitted to a total of 14 killings in a nine-month period,'' said Mr. Neck. ''There were indications from other people there could have been more. There could possibly be even more at this site. I wouldn't be surprised if there were more at other locations, but we don't have any way of proving or disproving that.''
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: Officials said Mr. Constanzo, who shuttled between here and Miami, presided over a substantial marijuana smuggling operation. He said the group had just shipped out 1,800 pounds of marijuana and apparently transported about a thousand pounds a week.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: At a press conference today in Brownsville, Mr. Kilroy's father, James Kilroy, said the underlying lesson in his son's death was that even casual drug users should remember that they are supporting criminal enterprises like the one that killed his son.
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: ''Mark never had any involvement in narcotics; he was afraid of narcotics, but it was narcotics that killed him,'' Mr. Kilroy said. ''When people sit there and tell you a marijuana cigarette doesn't hurt you, they're wrong. Marijuana is what killed Mark. These guys were marijuana smugglers.''
title: Drugs, Death and the Occult Meet In Grisly Inquiry at Mexico Border

text: They include police officers, engineers, doctors, teachers and former soldiers - a select group of men and women between the ages of 23 and 35 from large cities and small villages. At the National Institute of Penal Sciences here, this cross section of Mexican society is being trained as a new elite in the country's stepped-up war against drug trafficking.
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: By July, about 1,200 of these trainees, a mix of veteran officers and newcomers to police work, are expected to be deployed across Mexico in ''special groups'' of the Federal Judicial Police. In the months to come, they will be the shock troops commanded by the Mexican Attorney General's newly created Anti-Narcotics Investigation and Operations Division.
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: The new force is a direct outgrowth of a pledge to step up efforts against drug trafficking made by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari in his inaugural address on Dec. 1. Salinas's Vow to Fight Drug Traffic
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: ''I will create a new area in the Attorney General's office dedicated exclusively to its combat, with more personnel and greater training,'' Mr. Salinas promised. ''Narcotics trafficking has become a grave risk to the security of the nation.''
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: Some members of the new force have already been assigned to an anti-drug campaign along the United States-Mexico border, where in recent days they have made some major cocaine seizures and arrests.
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: Others will soon begin working with the veteran officers involved in the spectacular capture on Saturday of Miguel Angel Felix Gallardo, whom Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo described this week as the ''No. 1 narcotics trafficker'' in Mexico. Government Widens Training
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: As part of the same effort, the Government is stepping up its recruitment and training in other sections of the Federal Judicial Police, seeking what Fernando Ventura, commander of its Anti-Narcotics Operations, calls the ''standardization and homogenization of the force at higher levels.''
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: The current class of police recruits, who reported April 3 for four and a half months of training, includes 112 men and 8 women, more than double the size of previous classes, who were chosen from 2,030 applicants.
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: Federal police officials say that more than half of the new officers will be thrown directly into the war against drugs. The rest will be assigned to investigate other federal crimes, which range from bank robbery and kidnapping to contraband and illegal possession of arms. Training in Tough Terrain
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: The trainee's day begins early, with two hours of demanding exercise and drills. As joggers and dog walkers in the Glalpan Forest watch curiously, they run and crawl through terrain intended to duplicate the conditions they will find in remote and mountainous areas of Sinaloa and Michoacan states, where poppy and marijuana plantings are most common.
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: ''We're a group, and we work together as one!'' Mr. Ventura barked when a group of veteran officers, now responding to roll-call in a parking lot, failed to perform to his satisfaction one morning this week. ''Here, if you make a mistake, you die.''
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: ''In January, we revised our curriculum to give more emphasis to the battle against narcotics, so that more than a third of our material is now devoted to that struggle,'' said Ernesto Mendieta Jimenez, director of training at the National Institute of Penal Sciences. Corruption Poses a Problem
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: Mr. Felix Gallardo was arrested, along with officers of the Federal Highway Police, State Judicial Police and the Attorney General's Office, all of them accused of furnishing him with protection or intelligence in return for bribes.
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: Aware that corruption has greatly hindered the effectiveness of past drug campaigns, the Government is seeking to insulate the special group, and new recruits in general, from that temptation.
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: It has not yet been determined how much money members of the task force will earn. But the intention is to ''bring their wages more in line with their counterparts in the United States,'' a senior Mexican law enforcement official said, mentioning a base salary of about $1,100 a month as the likely figure.
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: Nevertheless, the Government is counting on something more than what is, by Mexican standards, a very good wage, to motivate the force.
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: ''We've got to instill a mystique, a code, a vocation to serve,'' said Mr. Ventura, who since January has devoted all his time to training and refresher programs for recruits and veterans. Spies Detected and Expelled
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: Mr. Mendieta said that narcotics traffickers, alarmed by the new resolve the Mexican Government has expressed in fighting the drug trade, have tried to infiltrate hirelings into the training program. But these spies were quickly detected and expelled, he added.
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: To avoid such problems, the special groups are following rigorous recruitment procedures. All the veteran officers have been recommended by their commanders, and both they and the recruits are subjected to physical and psychological tests to determine their fitness and dedication to duty.
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: ''I'm in this out of conviction, not out of obligation,'' said Ignacio Perez Orta, a 32-year-old former physical trainer who joined the police four months ago.
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: ''The drug trade is a plague that has to be exterminated one way or another,'' he said. ''If we don't combat it, it will take the reins and we will go down the road Colombia has taken.''
title: Mexico Using Special Squad In Drug War

text: A Federal agent and a former police officer whose acquittal in the death by beating of a black man led to race riots in 1980 were arrested on drug charges, the authorities said today.
title: Man Linked to Riot Is Arrested

text: The former officer, Alex Marrero, 34 years old, and an agent for the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, Jorge Villar, 44, were arrested over the weekend and charged with conspiring to distribute cocaine and to commit bribery.
title: Man Linked to Riot Is Arrested

text: Mr. Marrero's acquittal in May 1980 in the beating death of a businessman, Arthur McDuffie, set off riots that left 18 people dead and caused $80 million in property damage.
title: Man Linked to Riot Is Arrested

text: United States Attorney Dexter Lehtinen said Mr. Marrero and Mr. Villar had offered to protect a man who was posing as a smuggler bringing cocaine from the Bahamas into the Miami Beach area. The man was actually working with Federal agents. Sold Protection for $300,000
title: Man Linked to Riot Is Arrested

text: Mr. Marrero and Mr. Villar ''provided protection for this load of cocaine and in return demanded a fee of $300,000,'' Mr. Lehtinen said, adding that Mr. Marrero got 10 percent of the fee in cash.
title: Man Linked to Riot Is Arrested

text: ''Today we demonstrate no matter who you are or what you think you know, if you deal in drugs you can be caught,'' Mr. Lehtinen said at a news conference.
title: Man Linked to Riot Is Arrested

text: The United States Magistrate William C. Turnoff ordered Mr. Marrero and Mr. Villar back to the Federal Metropolitan Correctional Center, where they have been held without bond since Saturday.
title: Man Linked to Riot Is Arrested

text: Diane Cossin, an assistant to Mr. Lehtinen, said conviction on the conspiracy and bribery charges was punishable by an automatic 10-year term in Federal prison, and each of the two men could receive life sentences.
title: Man Linked to Riot Is Arrested

text: Maurice L. Hill, a spokesman for the Drug Enforcement Agency in Washington, said it was not the first time an agent on active duty has been arrested.
title: Man Linked to Riot Is Arrested

text: Mr. Hill said that the most recent previous case was last year, when an agent based in Atlanta was caught buying marijuana in the District of Columbia. He was arrested and sent to prison.
title: Man Linked to Riot Is Arrested

text: Mr. Marrero was suspended from the Metro-Dade police force early in 1980 after an investigation found that Mr. McDuffie had been beaten to death by police officers. Mr. Marrero, the chief defendant, was charged with second-degree murder.
title: Man Linked to Riot Is Arrested

text: An all-white jury in Tampa acquitted Mr. Marrero and three other officers of all criminal charges. Within hours, riots began in the Miami area, especially the suburb of Liberty City, and continued for three days.
title: Man Linked to Riot Is Arrested

text: LEAD: THE 1987 law that established stiffer penalties for drug sales and use within 1,000 feet of public and private schools throughout New Jersey resulted in 6,500 arrests last year, according to the Attorney General's office.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: THE 1987 law that established stiffer penalties for drug sales and use within 1,000 feet of public and private schools throughout New Jersey resulted in 6,500 arrests last year, according to the Attorney General's office.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: ''Pushers tend to congregate around schools and housing projects where there are children,'' said Lieut. Theodore E. Chapman of the Englewood Police Department's narcotics unit. ''While the law cannot eradicate the drug problem, it hopes to provide an around-the-clock, uncontaminated haven where children can be free of the constant barrage of the drug culture. It's a first stage which combines education and law enforcement.''
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: While lauding the law's intent, some law-enforcement officials, public defenders, educators and residents, however, say the law has added new strains to an already overburdened criminal-justice system. They also question its effectiveness in combating drug abuse. ''This law serves more political purposes than it is real,'' said Frank Wagner of the Bergen County Public Defender's office. ''Why should we be harder on those within a school area? It's like the old Prohibition laws. It doesn't reduce drug use. We have to spend more resources on solving the problem before we get to this point.''
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: Ronald Susswein, the Assistant Attorney General who oversees enforcement of the law, said the law was part of a larger effort against drug abuse that included stepped-up enforcement and a public education campaign. ''Although we are not naive enough to think we can win the war alone through police action, we want to allow educators to do their jobs,'' he said. ''We want to displace drug dealers away from the schools.''
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: The law creating the drug-free zones around schools was enacted as a part of the state's Comprehensive Drug Reform Act of 1987, which was intended to address the increase in drug abuse across the state, particularly the use of crack, the smokable and highly addictive form of cocaine. In addition to stiffer penalties for drug sales and use across the board, the act also called for the establishment of a fund that will use fines to finance drug awareness programs. In a related matter, a $198 million bond measure for prison construction was approved by the voters.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: Late last month, Gov. Thomas H. Kean signed into law a measure creating a 24-member panel to coordinate all public and private efforts to fight drug and alcohol abuse in New Jersey.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: Under the law on drug-free zones, anyone convicted of the sale or use of drugs within 1,000 feet of public or private schools, school buses or school property would received a mandatory sentence of at least three years with no possibility of parole, and fines ranging from $500 to $3,000. The state has already collected $3.7 million for the fund.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: Mr. Susswein noted that the law provided specific penalties for those convicted of drug use within school zones. He said, for example, that a person convicted of possessing a single marijuana cigarette, in addition to incurring the penalties imposed under the reform act of a $500 fine and the loss of his driver's license for six months, would be required to perform 100 hours of community service. He said that 9,600 licenses were suspended last year.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: Mr. Susswein said that the drug-zone law had resulted in 6,500 arrests last year but that he was still awaiting data on the resulting number of convictions. ''These numbers belie the notion that this law is some sort of gimmick,'' he said.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: The law has been welcomed by lawmakers, law-enforcement and school officials. ''There's no magic about 1,000 feet, but it is a safe margin,'' said Senator Frank X. Graves Jr., a sponsor of the legislation who is also the Mayor of Paterson. ''Now if people are caught within the drug-free zone they are faced with charges that mean higher bail and mandatory jail sentences.''
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: While skeptical of some of the early results, Larry Leverett, Superintendent of Schools in Englewood, concedes that the new emphasis on education will pay dividends in the campaign against drug abuse.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: ''There have been many examples of educational programs that have been effective in changing behavior of large numbers of groups, like cigarette smoking,'' he said. ''The media, communities, family and schools have to work together collaboratively.''
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: Putting the law into effect has not been without problems. Engineers, particularly in urban areas, had to resurvey the streets before the small blue and white signs designating the drug-free zones could be posted.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: Donald DiLorenzo, an assistant engineer and land surveyor, said the process took 18 months in Paterson.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: ''Before our new maps were finalized,'' he said, ''I testified three to four days a week in over 1,000 cases. I was subpoenaed an average of 30 times a week to testify as an expert witness. Attorneys contested our measurements, particularly on a fringe line.'' 'A Visual Aid in Court'
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: He said that police officers used the maps to pinpoint where an arrest took place. ''It's obvious now if locations fall within 1,000 feet of the school,'' Mr. DiLorenzo said of the maps. ''It's a visual aid in court.''
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: Lieutenant Chapman said the signs were also helpful in that regard. ''If a sign is behind you, you're in the zone,'' he said. ''The bad guys know where they are.''
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: Margaret Genero, a Haworth resident, took a different view of the efficacy of the signs. ''When you define one area as drug free, by default it implies that drugs are O.K. on the other side of the street,'' she said. ''We're playing games with those signs. We need to be vigilant in all areas. Illegal is illegal.''
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: In January, the state appeals court upheld the constitutionality of the law on drug-free zones. The decision stemmed from two 1987 cases in which a Superior Court judge had dismissed indictments against two defendants who argued that the law was vague and overly broad. The charges were reinstated, and the two defendants await trial.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: In one case, a man was arrested in Rockaway Township after the police received a tip that he and another man were selling drugs at a local business. As the two men drove away, they were followed by the police for two miles and pulled over in front of a public school, according to court documents.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: The police searched the men and the car and said they found seven grams of cocaine. In his report, the arresting officer said he had not pulled the men over sooner because the road was wider in front of the school.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: The second case involved a woman who was arrested while visiting an inmate at the Morris County Jail after a correction officer found her in possession of less than a half-gram of heroin, according to court records. The jail is within 1,000 feet of Morristown High School. Appellate Court's Opinion
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: In its opinion the appellate court wrote: ''Had the Legislature intended to exclude locations having no clear connection to schoolchildren, it could have done so easily.''
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: ''Simply put,'' the court added, ''if drugs are possessed with the intent to distribute, distributed or dispensed anywhere within the 1,000-foot zone of school property, the statutory proscription applies.'
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: Critics of the law seem especially concerned about its impact on the courts.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: ''The criminal-justice system is not prepared to handle the volume of cases,'' said William J. Rohr, a public defender for Passaic County. ''We're going to need a criminal-justice impact study. We could fill up a new state prison every year without getting any other New Jersey county involved. There are 1,000 backlogged appeals right now, and narcotics cases exacerbate the problem.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: ''We're going to have to use a tremendous amount of resources and fashion a system to deal with this problem. The real answer is to reduce the demand for drugs.'' 'There's Little to Lose'
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: Ronald S. Fava, the Passaic County Prosecutor, said: ''The system was overworked before, but under the new law, defendants are willing to take a shot at not guilty. If you plead guilty you get a mandatory three years anyway, so there's little to lose by going to trial. Before the 1,000-foot law, if a defendant pled guilty, he might get a short sentence with possibility of parole or just get a fine.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: ''This has created a situation where the courts are very backlogged, and New Jersey is far over its own guidelines about the amount of time between arrest and trial. It may mean that civil judges will have to be reassigned to the criminal courts to speed up the trial process.''
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: Mr. Leverett, the School Superintendent, points up another problem. ''We're hearing numerous stories about arrests followed by plea bargaining and downgrading of offenses, which dilutes the law's effectiveness,'' he said.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: But despite what critics regard as defects in the law, most support its intentions and agree that more time is necessary to assess its effectiveness fairly.
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: As Capt. Joseph D. Grossi of the Paterson vice and narcotics squad put it: ''We're making inroads, but it's hard to judge the effectiveness of the law. We're starting to get our first incarcerations now. People are still willing to take a chance dealing because the money to be made is seductive. But the word is getting out to students about the mandatory sentences.''
title: Effectiveness Of Drug Law Is Questioned

text: A suspected drug smuggler being chased by Federal agents set his plane on automatic pilot and bailed out Monday, letting the aircraft fly on for 180 miles before it crashed into the Gulf of Mexico, officials said today.
title: Smuggling Suspect, in Air Chase, Bails Out

text: A 43-year-old suspect, Ronald Cox of Miami, was arrested in the Sarasota area where he landed. The authorities recovered 19 bales of marijuana from the wreckage, said Michael Sheehan, a Customs Service spokesman.
title: Smuggling Suspect, in Air Chase, Bails Out

text: The plane was first detected by radar about 140 miles southwest of Key West flying very low toward Florida. Jets from the Customs Service and the Coast Guard followed the twin-engine Beechcraft Travelair for two hours, Mr. Sheehan said.
title: Smuggling Suspect, in Air Chase, Bails Out

text: After the plane's pilot bailed out, two Air Force F-15 fighters followed the craft, ready to shoot it down if it threatened to crash in a populated area. A Coast Guard cutter recovered the marijuana at the crash site in the Gulf.
title: Smuggling Suspect, in Air Chase, Bails Out

text: Dr. Norman E. Zinberg, a psychoanalyst whose research into the effects of drugs on individuals and social groups influenced the direction of drug-abuse treatment, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 67 years old.
title: Norman E. Zinberg, 67, Pioneer In Treatments for Abuse of Drugs

text: Dr. Zinberg, a clinical professor of psychiatry at the Harvard Medical School and a psychiatrist at Cambridge Hospital, had long been recognized as a pioneer in studying the ways in which marijuana, heroin and other drugs affect human behavior. He served for many years as a consultant to government agencies dealing with drug problems and testified frequently on legislation seeking to curb illicit drugs.
title: Norman E. Zinberg, 67, Pioneer In Treatments for Abuse of Drugs

text: He played an important role in Congress's passage in October of a comprehensive bill aimed at reducing drug use through treatment and education. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said yesterday that the legislation faced rough going, enacted only on the final night of the Congressional session, and that ''to a singular degree we acted on the advice of Norman Zinberg.'' 'Remarkable Impact' Cited
title: Norman E. Zinberg, 67, Pioneer In Treatments for Abuse of Drugs

text: Authorities in the field say Dr. Zinberg broadened the concepts under which drug addiction is treated by psychiatrists and other health-care professionals.
title: Norman E. Zinberg, 67, Pioneer In Treatments for Abuse of Drugs

text: ''He had a remarkable impact on our understanding that drug effects are not simply a consequence of biochemistry,'' said Dr. Howard Shaffer, a colleague at Harvard and at Cambridge Hospital. ''He showed that an individual's expectations, his psychological set and his social milieu interact to produce the effects on behavior that we observe. Equally important, Norman Zinberg helped us explain why an addictive drug affects a person differently at different times and how it affects various people in different ways.'' Named to AIDS Committee
title: Norman E. Zinberg, 67, Pioneer In Treatments for Abuse of Drugs

text: Dr. Zinberg, a native of Harrisburg, Pa., received his bachor's and doctoral degrees from the University of Maryland.
