He served in the United States Army Medical Corps for four years during and after World War II and joined the Harvard Medical School faculty in 1952. He also taught at Boston University and the Tufts School of Medicine before his appointment to an assistant professorship at Harvard in 1964.
title: Norman E. Zinberg, 67, Pioneer In Treatments for Abuse of Drugs

text: From 1971 to 1982 Dr. Zinberg was chairman of the advisory committee of the Vera Institute of Justice in New York, and since 1976 he had been a member of the Drug Policy Foundation, based in Washington. During the Vietnam War he was a consultant to the Defense Department, studying drug-abuse problems among troops in Southeast Asia.
title: Norman E. Zinberg, 67, Pioneer In Treatments for Abuse of Drugs

text: Earlier this year Dr. Zinberg was one of the first appointees to the National AIDS Commission, which will recommend ways to implement Federal policy in treating the epidemic.
title: Norman E. Zinberg, 67, Pioneer In Treatments for Abuse of Drugs

text: Surviving are his wife, Dr. Dorothy Shore Zinberg; his mother, Esther, of Baltimore, and two daughters, Sarah, of San Mateo, Calif., and Annie, of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.
title: Norman E. Zinberg, 67, Pioneer In Treatments for Abuse of Drugs

text: A blue cloud of marijuana smoke drifted over the University of Michigan campus today as about 1,000 high school and college students took part in the 19th annual Hash Bash, a rally seeking the legalization of marijuana. No one was arrested, but 15 people received tickets for possession of marijuana, a misdemeanor for which there is a $5 fine, said Capt. Gary Kistka of the Ann Arbor Police.
title: 1,000 Urge Legalizing of Drug

text: WILLIE An Autobiography. By Willie Nelson with Bud Shrake. Illustrated. 334 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.
title: FOR GOD, FOR GOLF AND FOR COUNTRY

text: Willie Nelson in print is a lot like Willie Nelson in concert - a captivating experience for the most part but something of a mixed bag. As a singer, Mr. Nelson has a repertory that encompasses not only his own compositions, which include some of country music's most enduring standards, but also a range of other material from ''Star Dust'' to ''Amazing Grace'' - all tied together and delivered in a casual, rambling style that has endeared him to millions, although it may seem sloppy to the uninitiated.
title: FOR GOD, FOR GOLF AND FOR COUNTRY

text: Similarly, ''Willie: An Autobiography,'' written with the help of the novelist and screenwriter Bud Shrake, keeps making quirky little detours from its more or less chronological path to deal with such subjects as God, golf, the music business and marijuana, mixing doses of metaphysics and philosophy with dollops of good-old-boy humor. If a particular section does not strike your fancy, keep reading - you are bound to get to something you like before long.
title: FOR GOD, FOR GOLF AND FOR COUNTRY

text: There is enough here about Mr. Nelson's eventful personal life, including three stormy marriages, to satisfy those with a hunger for gossip. There is almost, but not quite, enough about his music to satisfy those who are more interested in Willie the artist than Willie the personality. (Considering how prolifically he has recorded over the course of nearly 30 years and how many other performers have recorded his compositions, this book needs a discography.) As anyone familiar with his songs knows, Mr. Nelson knows how to tell a good story; he has plenty of them to tell here, and to his credit he does not hesitate to tell a few that place him in a less than favorable light. He emerges as both self-aware and self-effacing, confident in his own talent and smarts, but modest about flaunting them.
title: FOR GOD, FOR GOLF AND FOR COUNTRY

text: Arguing that anti-drug laws have stimulated organized crime without reducing narcotics abuse, a congress of politicians, lawyers, doctors, academics and police officers from a dozen Western countries has proposed the elimination of all prohibitions on drugs.
title: Europe Panel Favors Lifting Ban on Drugs

text: The idea itself is not new, but the creation of an International Anti-Prohibition League on Drugs here this week reflected the growing perception among narcotics experts that the traditional strategy of trying to stem the drug trade has failed.
title: Europe Panel Favors Lifting Ban on Drugs

text: The participation of experts from 10 European countries, along with specialists from the United States and Latin America, also underlined new awareness of Europe's inability to cope with the social consequences of its own escalating drug problem. League Issues Statement
title: Europe Panel Favors Lifting Ban on Drugs

text: ''The Mafia fears anti-Prohibitionism and not Prohibitionism,'' said Marco Pannella, a leader of Italy's Radical Party, which sponsored the three-day congress. ''If drugs were legalized, the Mafia would be badly hurt and Sicily would change dramatically.''
title: Europe Panel Favors Lifting Ban on Drugs

text: In a statement, the new league said law enforcement efforts had converted a question of personal choice into a worldwide drama.
title: Europe Panel Favors Lifting Ban on Drugs

text: ''The crime that results endangers ordinary citizens and threatens the stability of states,'' it noted. ''The modern version of prohibitionism has turned great cities into battlefields.''
title: Europe Panel Favors Lifting Ban on Drugs

text: Saying that no legislation had caused so much harm since the United States banned alcoholic beverages from 1920 to 1933, the league added that its objective was to give out information and coordinate efforts aimed at dismantling the system of drug prohibition around the world.
title: Europe Panel Favors Lifting Ban on Drugs

text: The 50 or so founding members of the league emphasized that they did not favor the use of drugs. Rather, they said, their participation was related to their direct experience of the failure of law enforcement. Officer Backs U.S. Control
title: Europe Panel Favors Lifting Ban on Drugs

text: Ralph Salerno, a former supervisor of detectives in the Organized Crime Unit of the New York Police Department, said mounting arrests of traffickers and seizures of drugs had not solved the drug problem. ''This is overwhelming evidence that the job can't be done by police alone,'' he said.
title: Europe Panel Favors Lifting Ban on Drugs

text: Wesley A. Pomeroy, a lifelong police officer who served as assistant director of the White House's Office of Drug Abuse Police under President Carter, drew an analogy with the Vietnam war.
title: Europe Panel Favors Lifting Ban on Drugs

text: ''We're also in a war we shouldn't be in and can't win,'' he said. ''The police are the victims of this war just as soldiers were the victims in Vietnam.'' Debate Among Police and Agents
title: Europe Panel Favors Lifting Ban on Drugs

text: Mr. Pomeroy said he recognized that the political mood in the United States was hostile to the idea of drug legalization, but he argued that a debate had now begun. ''Ten years ago in the White House, the idea was not mentioned,'' he recalled. ''But today police officers and narcotics agents openly discuss it as an option.''
title: Europe Panel Favors Lifting Ban on Drugs

text: Kevin Zeese, assistant director of the Washington-based Drug Policy Foundation, which was founded two years ago to develop a new approach to drug legislation, said his group favored legalization of marijuana but believed in restrictions on heroin and cocaine.
title: Europe Panel Favors Lifting Ban on Drugs

text: Lester Grinspoon, professor of psychiatry at the Harvard Medical School, proposed a tax on all drugs, including alcohol and tobacco, to finance the medical and social costs incurred by their use. ''This would allow people to use the drugs they want to,'' he said, ''but also eliminate the terror, chaos and attacks on personal freedoms.''
title: Europe Panel Favors Lifting Ban on Drugs

text: PROPOSALS for drug testing in any segment of American society have been encountering resistance, and, surprisingly, the opposition is especially vigorous on behalf of a population that is most prone to drug abuse: people charged with crimes.
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: Nevertheless, pretrial drug testing is an idea that is spreading, albeit with some resistance. Here in Washington, all those arrested are asked to undergo tests, and while they may refuse, most comply. There are a few similar programs elsewhere. And starting tomorrow, arrestees brought to the Federal courts in Manhattan and Westchester County in New York will be tested.
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: Advocates argue that the tests help predict the likelihood of a defendant appearing in court or committing crimes. They say judges can make better decisions about bail and, later, about drug treatment as part of the sentencing. Opponents say testing raises a host of legal and practical problems, may be coercive even while voluntary, and amounts to a particularly harsh invasion of privacy for a person whose guilt or innocence has not been determined.
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: One who is puzzled by the opposition is Eric D. Wish, a visiting fellow at the National Institute of Justice, a research arm of the Justice Department. ''If we are willing to test employees where serious drug abuse is rare,'' he asserted, ''we need to be willing to test criminals where serious drug abuse is common.''
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: The District of Columbia, with Federal grants, established a pretrial testing program in 1984, but only a few other jurisdictions have followed suit.
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: The Federal Government has sponsored testing of arrestees to spot trends in drug abuse, although, because the tests are anonymous and voluntary, results are not used by the police or courts. Those tests have generally shown that half to three-quarters of people arrested for serious crimes in major cities have recently used illicit drugs.
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: But the debate over testing will no doubt intensify as more jurdisdictions, frustrated by crime and drug abuse, turn to such programs.
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: Beginning tomorrow, people arrested on Federal charges in the Southern District of New York, which handles about 2,000 arrests a year, will be tested for drugs.
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: In their regular processing, arrestees will be asked for a urine sample to be tested for cocaine, marijuana, PCP, opiates and amphetamines. Results will be available in minutes. The Southern District is one of eight Federal court districts that are starting programs on an experimental basis as mandated in a little-noted provision of the comprehensive drug bill passed by Congress last year.
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: The program has two parts. Each person arrested will be requested to submit a urine sample. In addition, every convicted felon who has committed a crime on or after Jan. 1, 1989, and who is placed on probation or supervised release, will be required to submit to a drug test at least every 60 days.
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: Daniel B. Ryan, a probation division official at the Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts, said the results will be one of many factors that judges use to determine bail.
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: ''This information will not be given to a judge in a vacuum,'' he said. ''It is just another piece of the puzzle that we're providing.''
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: The intent is to test everyone who is arrested. But suspects will receive statements, which they must sign, advising them that they may decline to be tested, although the judge would be informed of that decision.
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: In jurisdictions that have pretrial testing, the authorities report that virtually every arrestee consents. ''You feel very vulnerable in a jail setting,'' said Barbara A. Zugor, executive director of the Treatment Assessment Screen Center in Phoenix, a drug treatment center that handles many arrestees. ''So there's a natural tendency to comply.''
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: Critics worry about coercion. Describing the Washington program as ''degrading and disgusting,'' David A. Reiser, a lawyer for the city's Public Defender Service, said, ''Most people don't understand that they have the right to refuse and, for many, a refusal to be tested might be treated as a reason not to release them or to post high bond.''
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: There are also practical concerns, such as the availability of treatment.
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: ''That's the real problem,'' said Catherine H. O'Neill, a lawyer for the Legal Action Center, a New York public interest group that specializes in drug abuse issues. ''In theory, it sounds fine to identify people who are drug users at an early point. But there's a dearth of adequate drug treatment facilities.''
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: There is scant precedent for testing people who have not been convicted, and legal challenges are expected. Prof. Yale Kamisar of the University of Michigan Law School, a Constitutional specialist, warned that the authorities should be cautious. ''Just because you have someone in custody,'' he said, ''doesn't mean he's the government's property and you can do whatever you want with that person.''
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: But those concerns are outweighed by the benefits of giving judges more information, said John A. Carver, director of Washington's Pretrial Services Agency, which started the testing here. ''The other option is to do nothing,'' he said. ''In a lot of cities, the judge is making decisions with no information at all.''
title: The Post-Arrest Drug Test Gets a Foothold

text: LEAD: Twelve years have gone by since Paul Zindel's last new play, ''Ladies at the Alamo,'' reached Broadway and then hurriedly departed. In the time since, he expanded a shelf of widely admired novels for teen-agers. He settled in Beverly Hills with his wife and children and wrote movies. He turned out a gory-sexy Hollywood novel for grown-ups in the vain hope of reaping the economic rewards of best-sellerdom.
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: Twelve years have gone by since Paul Zindel's last new play, ''Ladies at the Alamo,'' reached Broadway and then hurriedly departed. In the time since, he expanded a shelf of widely admired novels for teen-agers. He settled in Beverly Hills with his wife and children and wrote movies. He turned out a gory-sexy Hollywood novel for grown-ups in the vain hope of reaping the economic rewards of best-sellerdom. Occasionally, he took a trip to check out one of the frequent revivals around the country of ''The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds,'' the 1971 Pulitzer Prize-winner that made his name in theater. And he worked and he worked and he worked on the development of a story that he knew, someday, would be his next play for the New York stage.
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: It opens Wednesday at the Circle Rep under the fourth title it has worn since Mr. Zindel began circling around his narrative a dozen years ago. The play is ''Amulets Against the Dragon Forces,'' staged by Circle Rep's associate artistic director, R. Rodney Marriott. The principal players are Matt McGrath, Deborah Hedwall, John Spencer and Loren Dean.
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: Why has he been away so long? Only the other day Mr. Zindel found himself pondering the question and realizing the answer in a neat epiphany. ''It just dawned on me,'' he explains, ''that I'm a storyteller. I'll go anywhere that I'm encouraged to tell stories. For all that time, I was encouraged to tell stories in film, in television, in fiction. But three years ago I rebelled. I was not doing what I loved doing best: telling stories in the theater.''
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: This story inhabits familiar Zindel territory, recalling a place and people we have encountered before. The setting is Staten Island, where he was born and taught high school science courses until the inner pressures to write took over his life. The mother of ''Amulet,'' like Mr. Zindel's mother, is an abandoned wife, a bottom-wage practical nurse who tends terminally ill patients. She and her son are itinerants, always temporarily lodged in houses where someone is dying. The teen-age boy, Chris, as was the writer, is a friendless child with great longings for an absent father.
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: Zindel plays never have fathers; he is known for his portraits of strong, difficult women - but ''Amulets'' has more males than he has ever brought on stage before. There is Chris, the focus of the play, and there is the difficult Floyd, a shipyard worker with a mother dying in a back bedroom, a desperate man who stages wild parties for teen-agers and who prefers sex with young boys.
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: Mr. Zindel has nearly always mined his own life for themes and characters. But perhaps because ''Amulets'' is closer to the bone than much of his other work, he is dodgy speaking about it, careering between cozy loquacity and occasional skittishness. Early on a rainy morning, he had traveled down from his Lincoln Center neighborhood to the theater in Greenwich Village to talk about the play, and now he perches on a front-row seat with a commanding view of the set for ''Amulets'' - the dingy interior of a Staten Island bungalow in 1955 with a chandelier incongruously lighting the kitchen.
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: Time has had its way with the tall, skinny redheaded young playwright who was the darling of the 1970 season. It has added a good many pounds and deducted hair, and the stubble beard is entirely gray. He will be 53 next month. Having happily overcome the disabling depression that strikes him whenever he reaches a new decade, he exudes mature optimism: his best work, he announces, is yet to come.
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: ''Amulets'' began as a novel for adolescents, ''Confessions of a Teen-age Baboon,'' which appeared in 1977. Mr. Zindel has written 10 of these books for young adults since the first, famous work, ''The Pigman,'' appeared in 1968, and he is a stellar figure in the field, a writer who deals with the real pains and occasional pleasures of making it through adolescence. The rewards have included numerous prizes and sales of some 10 million books.
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: ''I think I always knew from the beginning,'' he said, ''before I began to deal with the material, that it was going to end up as a play. I knew I would be digging somewhere into myself in a way I couldn't fully explore in a young-adult novel. Do you know what I mean?''
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: The central incident of ''Confessions'' was a buried local news item recalled from his teaching years - the arrest on a morals charge of a Staten Island shipyard worker who entertained crowds of teen-agers and, on one such occasion, was said to have been intimate with 20 of them. Many of the book's characters appear in the play with the same names, but the focus and the action gradually changed over the years and, among other things, the arrest was dropped.
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: Almost as soon as he finished the book, Mr. Zindel began to make notes for a theater piece. By 1980 or so, he had a play titled ''The Party Begins at Midnight.'' He wasn't happy with it. ''I had submerged me, the nicest part of me. And I didn't know that.'' So he rewrote it, eliminated some of the theatrics and found a new title. As ''A Destiny With Half-Moon Street'' it was staged the following year by Jose Ferrer in Coconut Grove, Fla., with Danny Aiello starring as the roughneck homosexual shipyard worker.
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: ''Some backers emerged out of it and a lot of people wanted to move it forward,'' Mr. Zindel said. ''The only thing is there was no one in the play that you really cared about. It was noisy, bizarre, threatening, interesting to watch, but you didn't really care.''
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: In time, he brought ''A Destiny'' to Joseph Papp, the producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival. Mr. Papp had his play readers evaluate it. Their reports were unkind. He, however, proved to be sympathetic. ''I told him what I thought the play was,'' Mr. Zindel recalls, ''and Joe said, '' 'But that's what's missing. You. You're missing.' ''
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: More rewrites followed, and so did nibbles of interest from other producers. Gradually, the Chris character was fleshed out. Like the playwright at a younger age, the boy has a cast of carved figures and uses them to tell himself stories, his way of controlling the mean reality of his days. For his new title, Mr. Zindel reached out to a book by Joseph Campbell, the late, charismatic scholar of mythology. Chris's stories, like most folk tales, are his amulets against the demons of everyday life, a form of temporary salvation until he can find a real way to save himself.
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: Not surprisingly, Floyd, the shipyard worker, turned out to be yet another part of Paul Zindel. ''He comes from the greatest sadness in my own life and I think probably in everybody's life, other than nuclear war, that part of me that's unable to create intimacy with another person. That probably gives me part of my control. Where Floyd and I differ is that I do not use alcohol or drugs to move away from who I am. And my journey seems to be always toward truth. Do you know what I mean?''
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: From the evidence of Mr. Zindel's subconscious, the play may not be quite finished. As a former longterm analysand, he has useful dreams and no trouble remembering them. ''The little boy came to me in a dream last night,'' he reported. ''I had a loft and Chris wanted to move in with me. I was ashamed of it. It wasn't tidy enough. It was like the messy house from 'Marigolds.' I wanted him to have something better.''
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: It took ''Marigolds,'' the story of an embittered mother and her two tormented daughters, eight years to reach Off Broadway. After its success came ''And Miss Reardon Drinks a Little,'' which got mixed notices and had a modest run but did well on the road with Julie Harris and won the Los Angeles Drama Critics Award. The next two productions, ''The Secret Affairs of Mildred Wild'' and ''Ladies of the Alamo,'' failed to make the critics happy. Mr. Zindel says he is steeling himself against either the extreme elation or extreme disappointment that can follow good or bad reviews. ''I'm trying to protect myself,'' he says.
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: The best protection would appear to be the domestic tranquillity he has found in family. He has been married since 1973 to the former Bonnie Hildebrand, who is also a writer, and who helps steer him through what he calls the ''catatonic states'' that set in on the traumatic occasions of the beginning of his 40's and 50's. The last time around she determinedly walked him about Central Park every day for weeks until he recovered his interest in life. They have two teen-agers, a daughter and a son.
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: He moved his family back to New York about 1986 - he thinks. Mr. Zindel can probably remember what he had for lunch 20 years ago yesterday, but he's still terrible on significant dates. The Zindels lived for about six years in Beverly Hills. It wasn't all bad. He wrote screenplays (''Runaway Train,'' ''Maria's Lovers'') and teleplays (''Babes in Toyland,'' ''Alice in Wonderland - Through the Looking Glass''). He wrote that commercial adult novel, ''When a Darkness Falls,'' which was supposed to make him so rich that he would ever after write only what he chose. He calls the effort ''trying to nail down the stationary paradise.'' Unfortunately, it turned out that life doesn't provide parking spaces for a permanent paradise.
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: To explain his return to the East, Mr. Zindel swings into a confessional mode: ''There's something that's not very gracious about me. My system can only take so much of a bad thing. Like, I smoked, right? But when I stopped it was because my body didn't like it. I got sick from it. I tried marijuana, right? And I couldn't take it because my body didn't like it. I tried the screenwork and living out there but my mind couldn't take it.''
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: Still, the sojourn had its rewards. ''I think you end up being a little more respected here and you have a little more power here.''
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: One talent Mr. Zindel probably doesn't get enough respect for is a gift for confecting wonderfully baroque titles. Among the best are those that adorn his young-adult fiction, to wit: ''The Amazing and Death-Defying Diary of Eugene Dingman,'' ''Pardon Me, You're Stepping on My Eyeball,'' ''I Never Loved Your Mind'' and the latest, ''A Begonia for Miss Applebaum.''
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: While lavish phrases may continue to embellish the Zindel fiction line, we may have seen the last of them over his theater pieces. He is already making notes for a new play and, in terms of title, thinking small, one or two words. On the other hand, what comes after the title page could well be rendered on a grander scale.
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: ''I think that 'Amulets Against the Dragon Forces' is my last play that comes from Staten Island,'' he mused. ''I want to write very big plays. I hear big voices that want to play in Greek spaces. The next time you meet my people, they may be the Kennedys, they may be kings, they may be in the future, they may come down grand stairways.''
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: Nevertheless, we are not to imagine that some great transformation has taken place in Paul Zindel himself. ''It's not a brand new me,'' he insisted. ''I can't run away. That's right, there is no brand-new me. It's an evolving me.'' You know what he means.
title:
THEATER;
Beyond Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds

text: Raymond F. Akers Jr., co-founder of Drug Screening Systems Inc. of Blackwood, N.J., has received two patents for on-site drug-testing kits that work like litmus tests and cost about $5 apiece. The first kit detects traces of cocaine, heroin, amphetamines and PCP, and was cleared for marketing by the Food and Drug Administration in February. The second kit detects marijuana, and is still awaiting approval. The company said both tests were more than 95 percent accurate.
title: Two Kits Developed For On-Site Drug Tests

text: The key to both inventions is paper. Dr. Akers, a neurochemist, developed paper compositions that trap only metabolites of the drug being sought. Urine from the person being tested is applied to the paper. If traces of the drug are present, chemicals in the paper change color.
title: Two Kits Developed For On-Site Drug Tests

text: The test paper for narcotics is based on a wood pulp composition containing silica. The test paper for marijuana contains glass fiber.
title: Two Kits Developed For On-Site Drug Tests

text: Dr. Akers received patents 4,806,487 and 4,816,415.
title: Two Kits Developed For On-Site Drug Tests

text: We Find Ourselves in Moontown By Jay Gummerman 174 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.
title: Books of The Times; Disoriented, Desperate And Adrift in Moontown

text: In the title story of this wonderfully bizarre new collection, a security guard named Keepnews picks up a young sailor at the Las Vegas airport, and the two of them head for the desert, driving through the anonymous landscape, deep into the Nevada night. For no particular reason at all, Keepnews suddenly declares, ''We find ourselves in Moontown,'' then has the uncanny realization that ''he couldn't see the moon because this was the moon, just like he'd said, and that they were driving around in the Land-Rover looking for a place to put up the flag.'' It makes him think about his ''life back on earth,'' and how he ''could remember everything, the house where he lived, the color of its paint, the names of the people who lived there.''
title: Books of The Times; Disoriented, Desperate And Adrift in Moontown

text: In fact, sooner or later all of Jay Gummerman's characters find themselves in Moontown: they share Keepnews's sense of dislocation, his sense of watching his own life slip by. They are dismayed by the sight of their own faces in the mirror; startled by the sound of their voices, echoing across a long-distance line or bouncing off the walls of an empty house.
title: Books of The Times; Disoriented, Desperate And Adrift in Moontown

text: No doubt their disorientation has something to do with their fondness for marijuana - nearly all of them, teen-agers and grown-ups alike, are in the habit of lighting up joints - but it's also a reflection of a rather more general confusion in their lives. Most of them are in a state of transit, fleeing the past but uncertain of the future, caught between marriages or jobs, and vaguely desperate about their prospects. Distant relatives of Sam Shepard's drifters and Ann Beattie's space cadets, they tend to live in motels, unfurnished rooms or trailers - temporary places, where they can hang out, waiting for something else to happen.
title: Books of The Times; Disoriented, Desperate And Adrift in Moontown

text: In ''Lighthouse,'' two tour guides in a Nevada hick town pass the time together in a hotel, while they wait for phone calls (that may never come) from their respective spouses. In ''Russell's Honor,'' a con man, who's just escaped from prison, decides to seek refuge with his sister, whom he hasn't seen in a decade. And in ''The Painter,'' a man named Hurst has been fired for stealing a painting that his former girlfriend liked (''an impressionistic rendering of Jell-O salads. Five Jell-O salads in a lit deli case.''). He sits about his empty apartment, trying in vain to reach her by phone, when he's accosted by a door-to-door peddler - an importunate young girl who wants to sell him a magazine subscription, in hopes of herself winning an all-expenses-paid trip to Disney World.
title: Books of The Times; Disoriented, Desperate And Adrift in Moontown

text: Yet if these people spend half their time dwelling in a state of suspended animation, they spend the other half trying to cope with the sudden, unreasoned outbursts of love and disaster that periodically overtake their lives. As one character puts it, ''It was like what they said about the universe, that there was nothing in your life for years at a time and then, boom, you came up'' on something new, and ''it overwhelmed you, and you couldn't remember what happened in your life before.'' A collision with a truck kills a man and leaves his son, an aspiring baseball pitcher, without an arm. A poet drives out to the local recycling center and puts a bullet through his head. Another man tries to asphyxiate himself in a two-car garage, but finds his automobile has run out of gas - an event that his sister takes as a sign of God, Who has spared her brother because he looks like Jesus Christ.
title: Books of The Times; Disoriented, Desperate And Adrift in Moontown

text: Such incongruous details are prodigally scattered throughout Mr. Gummerman's stories, details that lend his tales a strange, almost surreal texture. We watch as a group of elementary school students dress up, for Flag Day, as various states: one student, who has covered herself with yellow spray-painted marshmallows, is supposed to represent Iowa, the corn state; another, dressed as a huge Mr. Potato Head, supposedly stands for Idaho.
title: Books of The Times; Disoriented, Desperate And Adrift in Moontown

text: In the title story, the hero notices a group of women at the Las Vegas airport carrying ''gift-boxed gambling sets: cards, dice, miniature roulette wheels,'' and he imagines ''them playing poker with their grandchildren, taking them for what little they had, and compensating them with hollow chocolate bunnies at Easter.'' And in ''Pinocchio's,'' a man and a woman, waiting for the arrival of the woman's boyfriend, gaze out the window at ''the faded brick back of the Italian restaurant where someone had spray-painted REINVENT THE WORLD, and above this on the roof, a neon sign in the figure of Pinocchio with his nose growing long, then short, then long again.''
title: Books of The Times; Disoriented, Desperate And Adrift in Moontown

text: Children dressed as vegetables, old women clutching miniature gambling paraphernalia, neon cartoon figures blinking in the night - these phenomena do not seem particularly odd to Mr. Gummerman's characters; rather, they are accepted as everyday manifestations of modern life. Indeed, the people in these stories all speak in a loopy collection of jokes, non sequiturs and cliches that perfectly mirrors the off-kilter world they inhabit. ''I might as well get on to whatever havoc I had left in me to wreck,'' says one character. ''I think everybody should live outside and have their backyards inside,'' says another. ''You know, like a big terrarium.''
title: Books of The Times; Disoriented, Desperate And Adrift in Moontown

text: Mr. Gummerman's ear for the absurdities of contemporary speech, combined with his eye for the eccentric detail, gives these stories an immediacy and hipness that counterpoint the sadness and desperation that lurk beneath the giddy surface of his characters' lives. By turns funny and disturbing, weird and recognizable, ''We Find Ourselves in Moontown'' marks the debut of an immensely gifted and original writer.
title: Books of The Times; Disoriented, Desperate And Adrift in Moontown

text: President Bush today named a prominent black lawyer in Boston as his choice for United States Attorney for Massachusetts, replacing a conservative Republican who was forced to resign after a series of politically charged issues.
title: Replacement Is Named For Boston Prosecutor

text: The lawyer, Wayne A. Budd, 47 years old, is a Republican who has been appointed to state posts by Democrats and Republicans and has experience both as a prosecutor and in private practice.
title: Replacement Is Named For Boston Prosecutor

text: Mr. Budd's credentials as a political moderate with bipartisan appeal and an extensive legal background are in contrast to Frank L. McNamara Jr., the conservative who served as United State Attorney for two years before his resignation on Jan. 30.
title: Replacement Is Named For Boston Prosecutor

text: Mr. McNamara, who served as vice chairman of President Ronald Reagan's Massachusetts campaign in 1980, had been accused of politicizing the United States Attorney's office here.
title: Replacement Is Named For Boston Prosecutor

text: Mr. McNamara became the target of an internal Justice Department investigation into whether he made up allegations that his predecessor, William F. Weld, had smoked marijuana. Mr. McNamara later admitted experimenting with the drug himself.
title: Replacement Is Named For Boston Prosecutor

text: They take team sports seriously at the Alpha Delta Phi fraternity house on State Street, in the heart of the University of Michigan campus.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: Just last week, several Alpha Delts drove six hours to Lexington, Ky., to watch the Wolverines beat North Carolina and Virginia in the Southeast Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament to qualify for the Final Four.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: Early this week, during the balmy noon hour, a dozen Alpha Delts stood on the big upper porch of the frat house, sipping beverages and looking down on the lawn below, where a dozen shirtless brothers played volleyball.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: The students on the porch spoke of Michigan's semifinal Saturday against Illinois in Seattle and why the Wolverines' fourth trip to the Final Four has sparked only a moderate level of visible enthusiasm around the campus. 'Football, Football, Football'
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: ''Before I got here, everyone said this campus is football, football, football,'' said John Klise, a 21-year-old senior French major from Winnetka, Ill. ''I guess it must be true. If this were the Rose Bowl, you'd probably see a lot more banners and stuff.''
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: It isn't as if the campus is ignoring the basketball team, whose coach, Bill Frieder, quit right before the tournament to take the coaching job at Arizona State.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: All student tickets are sold for Seattle and the biggest challenge for some is to get plane reservations. Stop most any student on the ''Diag,'' the main pedestrian mall on campus, and you'll get an opinion of Frieder, probably negative, and reflection, usually positive, on the team's recent success, which has spread like a grass fire under the interim head coach, Steve Fisher.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: It's just that the basketball team, even a potential national champion, must take its place alongside football and everything else at Michigan, a diverse, major university of 35,845 students, located about an hour's drive west of Detroit. 'Big Assignments'
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: ''We're very proud of the basketball success, especially coming on the heels of an ambiguous and disappointing Big Ten season,'' said James A. Winn, professor of English, director of the Institute for the Humanities and a season-ticket holder for Wolverines basketball. ''But it is coming at a time of the term when people are very buckled down. Some big assignments are due.''
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: Life goes on in ways other than sports and classwork. While there aren't any basketball banners on the Diag, you can see signs for the Progressive Zionist Caucus and the Conservative Coalition and the Women's Glee Club Spring Concert. And the semifinal Saturday coincides with the annual ''Hash Bash,'' a demonstration of marijuana and hashish smoking on the Diag that has been an April Fool's Day tradition at Michigan since the late 1960's. Different strokes for different folks.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: ''I would describe the basketball mood as a 'quiet excitement,' '' said Joe Owsley, director of the university's news and information service. 'Alumni Love It'
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: He suggested that enthusiasm might be more obvious over in sports-oriented Detroit or among graduates who have moved away. ''The working people who didn't go here know us through our teams,'' Owsley said. ''They care a great deal. And the alumni love it; it's something they can relate to.''
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: They relate especially to football, played here since May 30, 1879, 12 years before the invention of basketball. Heck, Michigan taught Notre Dame how to play football, back in 1887.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: ''You wonder what it is like at Kentucky or at some other place where basketball means more,'' said Scott Keough, a 20-year-old junior who works at Moe Sport Shop on campus. He said there have been inquiries at the shop for Final Four T-shirts, which are expected to arrive Wednesday. But customers aren't lined up at the door, the way they are on a football Saturday. ''Around here,'' Keough said, ''football is king.''
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: During the basketball tournament, one of the most visible Michigan fans has been Bo Schembechler, the veteran head football coach and rookie athletic director. Schembechler took breaks from spring football practice to fly south for the regional games. Television cameras have shown him giving locker-room pep talks. Fisher rolled his eyes earlier this week when recalling how Schembechler said on camera how much he wanted to play the Illini in the semifinals.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: Illinois is one of Schembechler's favorite football foes. No doubt, Fisher said, Illinois basketball coaches will screen that the tape of Schembechler's comments for their players. Team Seems Giddy
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: The closer you get to the Michigan basketball team, and especially to Fisher, the more you sense its giddiness over the improbability of the Wolverines' tournament roll.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: Although they were picked to be among the nation's best teams before the season, the Wolverines struggled during a 24-7 regular season, with many of their victories coming against weak teams. In the Big Ten Conference, they were 12-6.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: The crowds at Crisler Arena, criticized for being quiet much of the year, booed the Wolverines when they lost their last regular-season game, 89-73, to Illinois. Under Fisher, their unexpected success - blending confidence, speed and 3-point shooting - has hit like an unexpected inheritance from the will of a distant relative.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: ''It's like a fairy tale; it's not even Cinderella, it's like the prince just kissed Sleeping Beauty,'' said Bruce Madej, the sports-information director. ''When the tournament started, we were in a fog. We didn't know if we were ready. For the first two games, we didn't bring the band and cheerleaders. At the press conferences, writers were asking Bo about spring football.''
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: Fisher, a candidate for the job next year, seems slightly befuddled, if not pleasantly overwhelmed. He told reporters of feeling guilty when he sits at home and listens to friends leave good wishes on his telephone-answering machine. He wants to pick up the phone and talk, he said, but if he did, he wouldn't have time to coach.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: A year ago, he was helping Frieder recruit and worrying about his seat at the Final Four, in a distant corner, high above the court. He was also concerned about his future, wondering if, at the age of 43, he would ever get a chance to be a head coach in a collegiate program. Looking for Full Effort
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: ''The world twists in a lot of turns,'' Fisher said Monday in his office. ''Right now, our kids are as confident a group of players as could be playing anything. They probably think they can beat the Pistons.''
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: Shortly after he spoke, players began to arrive for practice. If anyone on campus has Final Four fever, it is this bunch. Glen Rice and Loy Vaught cruised up in a sporty white car. Blaring through a window was a rap song by Big Daddy Kane called ''Ain't No 1/2 Steppin'.'' It's all about giving full effort.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: Into the locker room walked Demetrius Calip, wearing a custom-made Final Four shirt with his portrait on it. Terry Mills, who stopped to chat with reporters, said that, from his perspective, the campus mood was focused totally on basketball.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: ''It's hard to get anything accomplished in terms of school work,'' he said. ''It's like you're the president of campus.'' It Can't Hurt
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: SEATTLE, March 28 (AP) - The Michigan Wolverines will have a homecourt advantage for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Final Four in teh Kingdome this weekend.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: The floor, 6,720 square feet of hardwood maple, was made in Dollar Bay, Mich., by the Horner Floor Company.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: ''We painted the lane blue, because Michigan's going to win,'' Bill Gappy, company director of portable sales, said. Actually, the court colors, graphics and other details are all determined by the N.C.A.A.
title: FINAL FOUR: Michigan Takes Success in Stride; Mood on Campus 'Quiet Excitement'

text: FOR millions of government workers facing drug testing, as well as those who work in industry, the Supreme Court's decision last week raised more questions than it answered.
title: The Government Still Waits to Test Millions for Drugs

text: In its first rulings on the constitutionality of mandatory drug testing, the Court gave the Federal Government broad discretion to impose tests on all workers, public or private, whose duties involve public safety or law enforcement. But the decisions, involving railway workers who have been involved in accidents and Customs officials who work in drug interdiction, cast doubt on the constitutionality of the more far-reaching Federal proposals aimed at eliminating drug use on the job.
title: The Government Still Waits to Test Millions for Drugs

text: ''The decisions suggest that Government policies should be written in pencil,'' said Mark de Bernardo, the author of ''Drug Abuse in the Workplace,'' and director of the United States Chamber of Commerce's Labor Law Action Center. ''While the decisions were victories,'' for those favoring testing, he added, ''they were not sweeping victories.''
title: The Government Still Waits to Test Millions for Drugs

text: Such drug tests, favored by many conservative Republicans, are harshly criticized by civil liberties groups, which say the tests are ineffective in reducing drug use and often violate constitutional protections.
title: The Government Still Waits to Test Millions for Drugs

text: ''Hysteria about the drug culture has led to draconian and senseless measures that not only undermine civil liberties but may not really address the problem,'' said Janlori Goldman, an attorney with the American Civil Liberties Union project on privacy and technology.
title: The Government Still Waits to Test Millions for Drugs

text: But supporters of drug testing argue that constitutional guarantees of privacy must be weighed against a drug abuser's potential to destroy the lives, health and safety of others.
title: The Government Still Waits to Test Millions for Drugs

text: Especially uncertain is the fate of random testing programs that have been proposed initially for more than 400,000 Federal employees - about 50,000 tests have been conducted so far - and are expected to cover half the Government's 2.2 million civilian employees. Forty lawsuits have been filed seeking to block the testing on constitutional grounds. The Treasury and Agriculture Departments test applicants; the Transportation Department and the Army conduct random tests. All are being sued.
title: The Government Still Waits to Test Millions for Drugs

text: Mr. de Bernardo of the Chamber of Commerce said that an estimated 10 million Americans use prescription drugs without an appropriate medical prescription, 500,000 are addicted to heroin, 22 million have used cocaine, and 10 to 23 percent have used ''dangerous'' drugs on the job. The Government has estimated that drug abuse costs the economy nearly $100 billion a year in lost productivity.
title: The Government Still Waits to Test Millions for Drugs

text: In private industry, where workers have no constitutional protection against drug testing, most large companies do some sort of screening. Sixty percent of companies with 5,000 employees or more test all job applicants, and some also test employees whose behavior is suspect. A typical drug urinalysis can detect the presence of cocaine, heroin, marijuana, amphetimines, barbiturates, LSD and a variety of ''designer drugs.'' A 'Go-Ahead' on Tests
title: The Government Still Waits to Test Millions for Drugs

text: Dr. Michael Walsh, head of the workplace drug-testing programs for the National Institute on Drug Abuse said, ''A lot of people in the private sector will see those decisions as a signal to go ahead with drug testing.''
title: The Government Still Waits to Test Millions for Drugs

text: Last January, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that about four million pre-employment tests had been conducted in the private sector, with 11.9 percent of the employees testing positive. An additional one million tests have been done on people already on a company's payroll, with a positive rate of 8.8 percent.
title: The Government Still Waits to Test Millions for Drugs

text: Civil libertarians were pleased that the Supreme Court decision viewed drug testing as search and seizure, but dismayed that it was sanctioned by the court even in the limited circumstances defined in the decision.
title: The Government Still Waits to Test Millions for Drugs

text: ''We are concerned that this may mark the beginning of the Court's expansion of drug testing throughout the work force,'' said Ms. Goldman of the American Civil Liberties Union.
title: The Government Still Waits to Test Millions for Drugs

text: Certainly it is unlikely that Congress will stand in the way of employers who want to test their employees.
title: The Government Still Waits to Test Millions for Drugs

text: ''Drug testing has the support of Congress,'' said Representative Don Edwards, a California Democrat and chairman of a judiciary subcommittee. ''There's a panic about drugs, and we don't want to face up to the real causes: the growing underclass and the growing disparity between rich and poor.''
title: The Government Still Waits to Test Millions for Drugs

text: This ain't no party, this ain't no disco . . . this ain't no Mudd Club or CBGB's. . . . - ''Life During Wartime,'' Talking Heads
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: The Wetlands Preserve is really a 60's preserve. More than a bar and certainly no disco, this earthy hangout in TriBeCa is a nightclub in a time warp - complete with psychedelic lighting, incense, pamphlets on ''planet care'' and visits from Wavy Gravy and Timothy Leary.
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: Whether the spirit of the 60's is flowering again on the cusp of the 90's is debatable. But since the club opened in mid-February in a former food warehouse at 161 Hudson Street, near Laight Street, the sounds of the Doors, Bob Marley and the Grateful Dead - and a tie-dyed brand of environmentalism - have been drawing crowds.
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: Larry Bloch, the club's 35-year-old owner, is a former Greenpeace volunteer and a self-proclaimed ''Deadhead.'' His aversion to what he calls ''urgent music'' means that disco is not heard in the club. ''You know, none of that stuff that goes bomp-de-bomp-de-bomp,'' he said. ''I think that makes people too uptight.''
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: Mr. Bloch, who started the club with the financial backing of his father, added, ''You got to have fun to make a difference in this world.''
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: Environmentalism is the heart of the club, and there is no mistaking it. At the entrance, Mr. Bloch's motto, ''We Labour to Birth Our Dance With the Earth,'' is engraved on the wooden portico. Immediately inside is the Earth Station, where patrons can sample literature on subjects like recycling and energy conservation, and pick up applications for Greenpeace, the Sierra Club and the Audubon Society.
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: One of the main attractions is a psychedelically painted Volkswagen bus that Mr. Bloch found abandoned in a field in New Hampshire and converted into an indoor concession stand. There customers can buy tie-dyed shirts, antiwar bumper stickers and buttons that say things like ''Question Authority.'' New York City residents can even pick up voter-registration forms.
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: On an adjacent wall, the club's calendar lists coming events, which include everything from Green Party meetings to a lecture by Timothy Leary on April 9.
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: In the short time it has been open, the club has attracted an eclectic crowd of people mainly between 21 and 40. The attire is uniformly casual, with many patrons in tie-dyed shirts and jeans dancing to the sounds of the late 60's and early 70's. Dim, Cavernous Room
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: Downstairs, in the Inner Sanctum, the pace is mellower. Here customers lounge on pillows and sofas in a dim, cavernous room. On a recent visit, it was imbued with the aroma of marijuana. Asked about this, Mr. Bloch declared: ''You will find fewer drugs here than you will at any other club in New York City. You'd never find anyone here doing crack, heroin or cocaine.''
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: Sunday evenings there is the Eco-Saloon, a social hour run by Remy Chevalier, who Mr. Bloch calls an ''earth activist.'' About 50 people have been attending these informal exchanges on ecological issues, which is followed by either a film, lecture or music.
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: Some visitors suggest that the club has something of a theme-park quality to it.
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: ''I think it is very contrived,'' said Kurt Schneider, a 23-year-old advertising account executive who has twice visited the Wetlands, as most patrons call the club. ''The essence and idea of the club is great, but the execution has failed.'' He suggested that Wetlands was on the way to becoming another ''trendy nightclub.''
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: Mr. Bloch rejects such a possibility. ''Trendy implies ego perks, like a door policy and a dress code,'' he said. ''You'll never have to look a certain way to get in. We would never be as cutthroat as that.'' For others, the Wetlands has filled a social void. ''I have been looking for a place like this for the last couple of years,'' said Arthur Kraft, 28, who visited the Wetlands for the first time last Sunday night, when the club held a concert by four rock bands to benefit efforts to save the world's rainforests. ''It's so hard to find a cool place to hang out and do more than just sit at a bar stool and drink.''
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: Gail Weisman, a 24-year-old patron from Clifton, N.J., said she relied on the Wetlands to keep her informed about protests and marches.
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: ''I'm going to a pro-choice rally in two weeks,'' she said. ''I wouldn't know about events like that if it wasn't for the Wetlands.''
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: Only a smattering of clubs, like the Caravan of Dreams in Fort Worth, seem to champion environmentalism and other social issues so elaborately. Mr. Bloch said he had been dreaming of starting one for years. It finally came to fruition after he sold a printing business in Los Angeles in 1985 and moved back to New York, where he grew up, with his wife, Laura.
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: Despite the club's heavy emphasis on social activism, Mr. Bloch said he hoped everyone could feel welcome at the Wetlands.
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: ''We don't want to exclude anybody,'' he said. ''No one is being preached to here. We want to transcend politics and get all people together to improve the health of the Earth.''
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: The Wetlands opens at 5 P.M. and never closes before 2 A.M. Its light menu includes home-made individual pizzas, cornbread and vegetable kabobs. The bar serves nine kinds of beer, for $2.50 to $3.50, and harder drinks are $3.25 to $4.75. The club also plans to serve organic wine, without sulfites, at $16 a bottle.
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: There is no minimum and the cover charge varies, averaging between $5 and $10, depending on the entertainment. The club features live bands on Wednesday and Saturday, and reggae music on Monday. Not surprisingly there is a Dead Night, each Tuesday.
title: What a Trip! Good Vibrations and Activism at a TriBeCa Club

text: I HOLD the envelope in my hand. Even before I open it, I know the contents. The same letter comes every five years when my college reunion years roll around. Mostly I consider myself to be leading a happy and active life, so why do I delay opening this correspondence from my alma mater? Because I know it will shake my self-esteem and will make me question what it is that I'm doing with my time when it seems that there is never enough of it for all I want to do.
title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets

text: Finally, I take out the alumnae office questionnaire fully determined to fill it out quickly and be done with it. It's a no-nonsense request for information. I write down my name and address - easy. Next is room for employment data (as in a paid job). I may work long hours, but as I receive no monetary compensation, I leave the space blank and go on to post- graduate education. Another box left empty. College involvement follows. Well, I've given every year and I've helped occasionally with fund-raising, but this doesn't seem to fit any of the categories listed.
title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets

text: There is a section to write up my civic and board positions. Baking cookies and selling tickets for benefits doesn't seem to qualify. Nor does helping out in school or garden club work. I'm sure the college doesn't want to hear about my tennis game. The next box is for honors and awards - nothing to add there.
title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets

text: Admit it, I tell myself, you are a total nonentity. You're nothing but a name and an address; the sum of your life is an empty page. You've been out of college for 25 years and you're a complete nonachiever. As I went to a women's college, I can't even delude myself that these questions were put in primarily to be answered by the male members of the class.
title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets

text: Of course, alumnae should have a chance to list their accomplishments and certainly the college should know about them. But I find it too demoralizing to continue and I place the paper in the ''to do some day'' pile.
title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets

text: Several months later, a longer questionnaire from my class arrives. I glance through it. It doesn't look too difficult. ''What is my current weight compared to 25 years ago? Am I for, against, or ambivalent about things like the proposed equal rights amendment, legalization of marijuana, gun control, nuclear plants? Have I had an extramartial affair, a tubal ligation, an abortion?'' It looks interesting and I can answer anonymously, so I sit down and turn to page one. ''Do you have an advanced degree?'' No. ''Are you working on one?'' No. ''Are you employed?'' No. The sinking feeling starts again. Haven't I heard of the women's movement? Don't I know that I am supposed to be ''having it all?'' Did my personal development really stop in the 1960's?
title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets

text: ''Do you consider yourself to be primarily a homemaker, a career woman, both equally?'' I write down homemaker. Here I am, I think, stuck in my mother's generation. Perhaps I should join the 50th reunion class, but they're probably all Gray Panthers or something.
title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets

text: Could I handle a job and a family? Perhaps, but I doubt it. I don't have the personality that could leave the care of my house and the raising of my children to others. I may not get a thrill out of changing beds, but when I do at least the sheets aren't on the floor the next morning. When I pick up I know where to find things the next time. I would consider a stranger in the house intrusive and I'd probably end up waiting on the help. I'm too critical and I like to be in control, so mostly I do it myself.
title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets

text: Children can be trying and tiring. My energy and patience often are stretched to the limit. I haven't loved every minute, or even every day, of childrearing. The rewards and satisfaction I have derived, however, have made it worthwhile. Perhaps, by being there, I've been able to correct some behavior and instill some value that would otherwise have been overlooked. Maybe my children would have been better off being brought up by someone else. But they got stuck with me because it is what I choose to do. It's hard, challenging, fulfilling and important work. And it's a labor of love, because the pay is lousy.
title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets

text: ''If you don't have or don't want a career, do you feel defensive about it? (Please comment)'' Yes. And if I answer one more questionnaire of this nature, I'm going to become either downright belligerent or despondent. Is being a full-time wife and mother some sort of deviant behavior that needs an explanation? Should I hang my head in shame for not living up to the expectations of my college degree? Have I let down my sex?
title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets

text: ''Do you consider yourself successful, to this point, in achieving your goals?'' Yes. But my goals were so uninspired: only to get married and have a family. Was I lucky or unfortunate that the hand which reached for my diploma had an engagement ring on it? I worked for three years until the birth of the first of our three daughters, but I considered it a stopgap until we had enough money to live on one salary, not a career.
title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets

text: Maybe I would have had a career if life had turned out differently: if I hadn't met ''Mr. Right,'' if I hadn't been able to have children, if my marriage hadn't held together, if my husband's salary hadn't been more than adequate to supply our needs. But I consider these things blessings and wouldn't change any of them.
title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets

text: I applaud all the strides women have made since I graduated. Job opportunities are practically unlimited now. I admire the successful career woman. I'm in awe of the woman who can handle a family and a job. If my daughters elect to reject my life style, I'll support them with a whole-hearted ''go for it.''
title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets

text: ''Are you basically happy with your life?' Yes. Mostly I don't even think about it. It's only every five years that I get a bad case of the doubts.
title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets

text: I finish the class questionnaire and pull out the one I had put aside from the alumnae office. On the back is a request for family information. I can fill in every blank, even all three spaces provided for children. Perhaps as my daughters leave and start their own lives, I'll have more time to pursue other activities and some of the spaces on the front page will get filled in also. The back page, however, is what I've been doing.
title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets

text: There is one more piece of pre-reunion business to complete, a page summarizing my life since college. What should I say? That three weeks after graduation I married the man I had been in love with since the age of 16. That as my children reach for maturity and independence, they show signs of being decent human beings. That the road traveled from there to here has had some potholes, but, for the most part, the journey has been pleasant. I've done what I wanted to do and as much as I thought I could handle. In today's world that may not seem like much and feminists may scorn my decision. Yes, I'm ''only'' a housewife. No apologies.
title: As a Reunion Draws Near, a Housewife Determines That She Has No Regrets

text: When he was growing up, there was little to set Robert Golub apart from the other children of Horton Road, a tiny, friendly street tucked in a corner of this Nassau County village. He haunted the usual haunts with his high school friends; his passion was lifting weights at the gym on Merrick Road.
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: But while most people his age moved away from the neighborhood and went on to college, Robert Golub remained at home with his parents. He worked as a messenger for a while, then lost his job when his employer discovered he was driving with a suspended license.
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: And today, at the age of 21 - as he stands charged with killing and mutilating a 13-year-old neighbor named Kelly Tinyes - hardly anyone on the block seems to know much about him.
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: In the way that neighbors often explain events and people they do not understand well, residents of the street said Mr. Golub was a loner who spent little time in the neighborhood, seeking friends elsewhere. 'Seemed to Be Just Drifting'
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: Indeed, many residents said the entire family acted a little too aloof on a street where children grow up together and where everyone goes out of his way to be friendly to everyone else. This perception perhaps helps explain why the neighborhood so easily erupted in rage when Robert and his family returned to Horton Road last weekend, even though no one had been charged in the murder.
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: While neighbors said that Robert's parents were polite enough, and that they often saw Robert's brother, John J., up and down the block, they said Robert was not around much.
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: ''I've lived here all my life, and I've never spoken to the boy,'' said one man, who asked not to be identified. ''And I know all the kids on the block.''
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: The Golubs' next-door neighbor, whose daughter, Nicole, was very close to Kelly, said: ''I didn't even know he lived there. I very rarely saw him.''
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: Elsie Milano, whose house is across the street from the Golub house, said, ''He seemed to be just drifting.'' Grew Up 5 Doors Apart
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: Robert Golub grew up at 81 Horton Road, five doors down from where Kelly Tinyes grew up, and was the second of three children of 57-year-old John A. Golub, owner of a gas station in nearby Hewlett, and his 47-year-old wife, Elizabeth, who works in an office in Valley Stream. The couple have lived on Horton Road for 23 years.
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: The oldest Golub child, Adele, 23 years old, graduated from college and works and lives in Battery Park City in Manhattan. John J., 14, is a ninth grader at Hewlett High School and was friendly with Kelly Tinyes.
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: Friends of John J., who has not been to school since the killing, said he dated Kelly, who was a grade behind him at Woodmere Middle School, from time to time. Some students, like Marcella Gonzalez, a ninth grader who said she had known John J. since elementary school, also said that he was a bully who bragged of killing animals.
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: John J. - who was originally named, with his brother, as a chief suspect in the killing - told the police he had spent the afternoon of Kelly's death playing Nintendo with two friends from school; the friends, Steve Bataan and Glen McMahan, later told reporters the three had smoked marijuana in the Golub household. The police ruled out the friends as suspects early in the case. Not Active in High School
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: Robert Golub graduated from Hewlett High in 1985 and did not go to college. A former classmate said in an interview at the school library, where he was doing research for a paper during his spring break from college, that Robert had not participated in many school activities. In the 1985 school yearbook, there is nothing listed under Robert Golub's name.
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: Like many teen-agers in the neighborhood, Robert played video games and sometimes went to a local gym to lift weights. A small man, just 5 feet 3 inches tall, who looks extremely young, Robert is muscular and strong. He was a regular at the Whitehall Fitness Center in Lynbrook, now called the Maximum Health and Fitness Center, until it changed management about eight months ago.
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: It is unclear how often Robert worked after he got out of school. At one point, he drove a delivery van for Major Messenger Service in Lynbrook, but he seems to have left that job in 1987.
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: Between 1984, when he got his driver's license, and January 1989, Robert amassed a number of traffic tickets. On 13 occasions, his driver's license was suspended. Relationships Unclear
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: It is also unclear what his relationship to his parents and brother was, but family members' statements to the police suggest a young man who lived with his parents but, like others of his age who have never left home, was removed from the activities of the household.
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: According to the police, Kelly was killed shortly after 3:15 P.M. In separate statements, Mr. and Mrs. Golub contradicted each other about whether Robert ate dinner with them that evening. Mr. Golub told the police that Robert joined them for the meal. But Mrs. Golub said that Robert was asleep in his room, lying face down on the bed, when she went to speak to him about dinner.
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: Mrs. Golub told the police that Robert had gone out for the evening; Mr. Golub said he did not know whether he had remained home or not.
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: Nassau County prosecutors said today that the physical evidence in the case, including a bloody handprint found near the body, showed without a doubt that Robert was responsible for Kelly's death. But even though he was told he was a suspect in the case, neighbors and law-enforcement officials say, Robert displayed no public anxiety in the three weeks between the murder and his arrest.
title: On a Friendly Street, Suspect Is Called Aloof

text: The largest and most conclusive study of drug use in pregnancy has found that the use of cocaine or marijauna impairs fetal development.
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: The study, which used urine samples to ascertain drug use by pregnant women, found that when women used cocaine while pregnant their babies weighed less, were shorter and had smaller heads than babies of mothers who did not use cocaine. Women who used marijauna while pregnant had smaller, lighter babies, the researchers found.
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: As a result, babies born to women who used cocaine or marijauna while pregnant ''are potentially more likely to suffer health and developmental problems,'' said Dr. Barry Zuckerman of Boston University School of Medicine and Boston City College, lead author of the report.
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: The study, published today in The New England Journal of Medicine, involved 1,226 women who had prenatal care at Boston City Hospital. The findings were inconsistent in previous studies of marijuana and cocaine use in pregnancy. Reports Not Always True
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: For instance, several marijuana studies showed a decrease in birth weight, but several other studies showed no effect, Dr. Zuckerman said. One difference with the new study is that it used urine samples to assess marijuana use. In the previous studies, researchers relied on women's answers to questions, and the information may not have always been reliable.
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: The study was also the first to examine cocaine use by all pregnant women in a particular population, rather than by women already known to be addicted to drugs or by women whose babies were found to have cocaine in their urine after birth.
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: While several of the previous cocaine studies indicated that the drug is harmful to fetuses, those studies involved small numbers of women who often were using other drugs, like heroin, as well.
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: ''This is the first study with a large number of women that controlled for potentially confounding variables,'' Dr. Zuckerman said. The effects of marijuana and cocaine on the babies were comparable to the effects of cigarette smoking on babies' birth weights, the researchers said. All Who Sought Care
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: Dr. Zuckerman and his colleagues asked all women who came to Boston City Hospital for prenatal care if they used drugs and if they would permit the researchers to detrmine drug use with confidential urine analyses. All but 7 percent of the women agreed.
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: The women who came to the prenatal clinic were ''predominantly poor, minority and single,'' Dr. Zuckerman said. Evidence of marijuana was detected in the urine of 16 percent of the patients and 9 percent showed evidence of using cocaine.
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: An additional 11 percent of the women reported using marijuana but had negative urine tests, while an additional 8 percent reported using cocaine but had negative tests.
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: A urine test would be positive if a woman had used marijuana in the past week or if she had used cocaine within the past two to three days, Dr. Zuckerman said. The researchers speculated that the urine tests probably identified the women who used the drugs more often.
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: The babies of the marijauna users weighed an average of 2.8 ounces less and were one-fifth of an inch shorter than the babies of women who did not use the drug. On average, the babies of women who used cocaine were 3.3 ounces lighter, one-third of an inch shorter and a had a head circumference one-fifth of an inch smaller, the researchers said. Effect of Cigarettes
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: Cigarette smoking in pregnancy decreases babies' birth weights by an average of 2 to 4 ounces, Dr. Zuckerman said.
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: Proportionately, Dr. Zuckerman added, more babies of cocaine and marijuana users were seriously under weight than the babies of women who did not use drugs.
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: Moreover, the researchers said, the drug-using women were also more likely to smoke cigarettes and have inadequate diets while they were pregnant. As a result, the combined effect of drugs and other factors was a decrease in birth weight of about one pound, compared with babies born to well-nourished women who did not smoke or use drugs.
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: The researchers found no effect of marijuana or cocaine among pregnant women when they considered only the women's own reports of drug use and disregarded the urine analyses.
title: Study Ties Drugs to Impaired Fetuses

text: By Bernard Weinraub, Special To the New York Times
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: Just before President Bush appeared in a packed high school gymnasium in Lancaster, Pa., today, Thomas Hipple stood up and recounted the grim downward spiral of his life.
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: The 23-year-old, once an honor student who worked part time at a fast-food restaurant, recalled how he plunged from marijuana to cocaine and other hard drugs to the desperation that led him to put a .30-caliber rifle to his head and pull the trigger.
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: ''I was desperate,'' said the dark-haired young man, who was left blind in the suicide attempt.
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country
