text: Mr. Bush's trip to the Conestoga Valley High School, in the heart of the rolling Pennsylvania Dutch countryside, was intended to underscore not only his commitment ''to ending this scourge of drugs'' but also the fact that drugs afflict middle-class rural youths, like Thomas Hipple, as well as those in urban ghettos. Not Only the Poor
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: ''When drugs come here,'' Mr. Bush told the high school audience, ''that's proof that the drug epidemic is a national problem.''
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: ''The rising problem here simply shows how vulnerable every American city and town is to the menace of drug abuse,'' Mr. Bush told an enthusiatic audience of 3,500 students, teachers and local families.
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: ''It isn't just the impoverished,'' Mr. Bush said. ''It isn't just those who are fighting trauma in their lives. We have got to make people understand, whatever walk of life you're in, that drug use is bad, it's death, it is degradation.''
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: Although Mr. Bush addressed only the issue of drugs in his speech in Lancaster, the Superintendent of the Conestoga Valley School District, Daniel C. Witmer, said in a telephone interview after the visit that alcohol abuse seemed a far more serious problem in the area than narcotics. But drug use seems to be growing, Mr. Witmer said. Weekend Beer Parties
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: ''Our major problem is weekend alcohol use, weekend alcohol parties, beer parties,'' he said. ''We do have a drug problem, but it's not as pronounced as the alcohol problem.''
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: Mr. Witmer said that, as far as he knew, the drug problem was largely restricted to ''marijuana and pills, uppers and downers.''
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: ''I'm not aware of much cocaine or crack,'' said Mr. Witmer, who added that the district was probably selected for a Presidential visit because ''we have some drugs, we do have a problem. And it tends to be increasing.''
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: Accompanied by William J. Bennett, the head of the Administration's anti-drug effort, and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, Mr. Bush flew by helicopter from the White House to Lancaster and then to Wilmington to speak to state law enforcement officials at the Radisson Hotel. Questions From Children
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: Upon arriving in Wilmington, the President watched a martial arts demonstration by youngsters involved in a ''drug awareness'' program at the Walnut Street Y.M.C.A.
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: Seated with the children 8 to 12 years old, Mr. Bush responded easily to their informal questions, including one in which the President was asked if he had ever been offered drugs.
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: ''No,'' the President said. ''They had drugs around when I was a little guy. It wasn't as much, There wasn't the pressure on the kids in schools.''
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: Later he was asked, ''What do you do to keep drugs out of your life?''
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: ''Now, like I'm President, it would be pretty hard for some drug guy to come into the White House and start offering it up,'' Mr. Bush said. ''You know? It's different. We've got a lot of Secret Service guys there.'' He told the children that, if drug sellers appeared at the White House, ''I hope I would say, 'Hey, get lost. We don't want any of that.' '' The Message Is Blunt
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: Mr. Bush also told the children that ''permissiveness'' in society was hardly new, and cited the opium wars in China and the fall of Rome. ''Rome got corrupt with a lot of alcohol abuse,'' he said.
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: Mr. Bush's overall message today was a blunt one. He was seeking $1.1 billion in the next fiscal year for drug prevention and education, an increase of 16 percent over 1989, and he was committed to ''sending a clear message that using drugs isn't fashionable, isn't fun and above all, isn't safe.''
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: In Wilmington, Mr. Bush drew applause when he reiterated that he wanted ''increased prison sentences for drug-related crimes'' and the ''death penalty for drug kingpins and those who commit drug-related murders.''
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: Terming himself a proud member of the National Rifle Association, Mr. Bush said he was convinced that the ''vast majority'' of members agreed with his decision to temporarily ban the import of five different types of semiautomatic weapons. A Commitment Reiterated
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: Through the day, Mr. Bush stessed his determination to deal with the nation's drug epidemic. ''I feel driven by this commitment,'' he said in Lancaster. ''I am committed to ending this scourge of drugs.''
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: ''We must get the message across that drugs are not a form of entertainment or a helpless, harmless means of escape - drugs are a poison, to users and to our community,'' Mr. Bush said.
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: To sustained applause, the President added that he hoped that ''the movie producers and the movie directors and those involved in the entertainment business will stop, will put an end to the glorification or a humorous treatment of narcotics.''
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: Mr. Bush's focus on drugs was also marked by several informal meetings. In Lancaster, he met 13 leaders of the Amish and Mennonite communities, and he saluted their communities for staving off drugs aamong the young. Deep-Rooted Values
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: One elderly Mennonite, who sat with the group at a classroom table in the Penns John Elementary School, said the reason the community's children had no real drug problem was because they were taught values of self-discipline and obedience and deep-rooted religious and family ties.
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: ''We do not have television and radio,'' said a Mennonite leader, adding that those media portray ''sexual things and robbers.''
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: Another Mennonite said rock music is a bad influence. Mr. Bush praised Susan Baker and Tipper Gore, the wives of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Senator Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, for condemning what the President called ''really bad lyrics.''
title: Bush Takes Fight Against Drugs To Pennsylvania Dutch Country

text: By Thomas George, Special To the New York Times
title: N.F.L. Players Face Ban for Steroid Use

text: Steroid testing results of National Football League players will be announced in late August, and those who test positive will be suspended for 30 days, Commissioner Pete Rozelle said today at the league's annual meetings.
title: N.F.L. Players Face Ban for Steroid Use

text: All players will be tested during a 7-10 day period when they report to training camp. Those who test positive will get the 30-day suspensions, which will mean they will miss one preseason game and three regular-season games. A second positive test after reinstatement will result in a player's supension for the season, including post-season play.
title: N.F.L. Players Face Ban for Steroid Use

text: ''We've tried to educate the players for two years and at the same time learn more about steroids,'' Rozelle said. ''We know now that it gives a strong competitive advantage and has severe medical effects. This is not a program designed to simply try to catch people but to get them off this harmful drug.'' Estimates of Steroid Use
title: N.F.L. Players Face Ban for Steroid Use

text: Steroid testing over the last two years has indicated that 7 to 8 percent of the league's players have been using the drug, Rozelle said. In other violations of the league's drug abuse policy, primarily for marijuana, alcohol and cocaine use, 25 players were suspended last season.
title: N.F.L. Players Face Ban for Steroid Use

text: Players involved in a first positive test for using those substances are forced to seek outpatient treatment and are subject to random testing; those found testing positive a second time are suspended for 30 days.
title: N.F.L. Players Face Ban for Steroid Use

text: Rozelle, in defense of what appears to be stiffer penalties for steroid use than cocaine abuse, said: ''We would have liked to have had a stronger program but as you know we have already been told by the courts that we cannot have random testing for drugs. That policy must remain the same until we have a new collective bargaining agreement that will make the penalties stiffer.''
title: N.F.L. Players Face Ban for Steroid Use

text: Rozelle said that each player will be notified about the steroid testing policy by letter in the next 10 days. That, he said, should provide ample time to those that might be using steroids to get off the drug. He also said that masking agents used to hide steroid use can be detected in this testing method, which will be coordinated by Dr. David Black of Vanderbilt University.
title: N.F.L. Players Face Ban for Steroid Use

text: Players using masking agents prescribed by doctors must present a letter from their physicians detailing the usage and why, or they will be subject to penalties as if they produced a positive test. Noise Rule Approved
title: N.F.L. Players Face Ban for Steroid Use

text: In other developments, the teams voted by 21-7 in favor of a new crowd noise rule effective this season. When an offensive team cannot hear its quarterback calling signals because of crowd noise, he can appeal to the referee, who in turn will use a wireless microphone to ask the crowd to quiet down.
title: N.F.L. Players Face Ban for Steroid Use

text: If the noise continues and the offense still cannot run a play, the home team will lose a timeout and will continue to lose them until they are all consumed. When no timeouts remain, the home team will be assessed a 5-yard penalty for delay of game.
title: N.F.L. Players Face Ban for Steroid Use

text: A rule was also passed that prohibited teams from feigning injuries on the field to stop the clock when they have no timeouts.
title: N.F.L. Players Face Ban for Steroid Use

text: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Constitution permits prosecution of those who use illegal drugs as part of religious ceremonies.
title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions

text: The case at hand is an appeal by the State of Oregon growing out of a dispute over unemployment benefits for two male adherents of an American Indian religion that makes ritual use of peyote, a hallucinogenic cactus. The men were dismissed from their jobs as counselors at a clinic for the rehabilitation of those using peyote and were subsequently denied state unemployment benefits on the ground that their own ''misconduct'' had led to their dismissal.
title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions

text: The Oregon Supreme Court ruled in 1986 that the denial of benefits violated the mens' constitutional right under the First Amendment to the ''free exercise'' of their religion. The state appealed that ruling to the United States Supreme Court, which last year sent the case back to the state court with instructions to consider the legal status of peyote under Oregon law.
title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions

text: In the decision the Justices agreed to review today, the Oregon Supreme Court ruled that although peyote was an illegal drug under Oregon law, the Constitution's free-exercise guarantee barred prosecution for the religious use of peyote. State Court Is Faulted
title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions

text: In its appeal, Employment Division v. Smith, the Oregon Attorney General's office is arguing that the Oregon Supreme Court gave inadequate weight to the state's law-enforcement concerns.
title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions

text: The two men, Alfred L. Smith and Galen W. Black, are members of the Native American Church, in which peyote is used regularly in religious gatherings to induce a hallucinatory condition. Members believe that peyote itself is sacred, embodying the Holy Spirit. Peyote is a cactus from which the hallucinogenic drug mescaline is made.
title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions

text: The Federal Government, as well as a number of Western states with substantial Indian populations, exempt the religious use of peyote from criminal narcotics laws. Other religious groups have been less successful in seeking similar exemptions. The Ethiopian Zion Coptic Church, which uses marijuana in religious ceremonies and has failed to obtain an exemption from Federal narcotics laws, is now in litigation with the Federal Government over the issue.
title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions

text: Beyond the question of drug use, the peyote case could have constitutional implications for other cases in which religious practices conflict with government policies. Such cases regularly reach the Court, often involving challenges to Federal land use decisions that threaten sites that are sacred to various Indian tribes. The Court has rejected most such challenges. Related Illinois Case
title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions

text: Earlier this month, in Frazee v. Department of Employment, the Justices heard arguments in an appeal brought by an Illinois man who was denied unemployment benefits after he lost a job for refusing to work on Sunday. The man argued that, although he belongs to no organized church mandating a sabbath observance, the Constitution's free-exercise clause should protect his right to interpret the Bible his own way.
title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions

text: The Court also dealt with the following matters today: Administration to Argue Abortion Case The Court granted a request by the Bush Administration to participate in the oral argument on the constitutionality of Missouri's restrictive abortion law. The Administration is urging the Court to uphold the state's law and use the case to overturn Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision that established a constitutional right to obtain an abortion.
title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions

text: The Court is often sparing in granting argument requests from those who are not actual parties in a case. When the Court was last considering an abortion case three years ago, it denied the Reagan Administration's request to participate in the argument. That time, the Court rebuffed the Administration's request to overturn Roe v. Wade.
title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions

text: The Missouri case, Webster v. Reproductive Health Services, will be argued April 26. The early date raises the question of who will represent the Administration in the most politically charged argument of the year.
title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions

text: The position of Solicitor General -the official who ordinarily would make such a high-visibility argument - is vacant. Senate confirmation hearings have not yet been scheduled for President Bush's choice, Judge Kenneth W. Starr of the Federal appeals court here, who has not been officially nominated.
title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions

text: Unless Attorney General Dick Thornburgh is willing to argue the case himself, which is thought unlikely, one of the career Justice Department lawyers who work in the Solicitor General's office will probably make make the argument.
title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions

text: In another abortion action today, the Court turned down without comment an appeal by a group of anti-abortion demonstrators who were convicted of trespassing on a Philadelphia abortion clinic in 1985.
title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions

text: In their appeal, Markum v. Penna., the demonstrators argued that by refusing to let them present a defense of ''justification'' for their actions, the Pennsylvania courts had denied them the due process of the law. They said they knew they would be arrested and hoped to create a case that would reach the Supreme Court and persuade the Justices to overturn Roe v. Wade. Denial of Permit To Shopping Mall Stands In Bersani v. E.P.A., the Court turned down an appeal by a large shopping center developer, Pyramid Companies, which sought Federal permission to fill in a swamp in Attleboro, Mass. to build a shopping mall. The Environmental Protection Agency denied the permit under the Clean Water Act, overturning a decision by the Army Corps of Engineers to let the project proceed.
title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Hear Case on Drugs in Religions

text: LEAD: WESTCHESTER County has joined the ranks of countless other governmental bodies in considering a local law that would limit smoking in public places. The county proposal, said to be a compromise plan, would require restaurants serving 75 or more people to set aside half the seats for nonsmokers and require employers to adopt written smoking guidelines and establish smoke-free work areas ''to the extent practical.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: WESTCHESTER County has joined the ranks of countless other governmental bodies in considering a local law that would limit smoking in public places. The county proposal, said to be a compromise plan, would require restaurants serving 75 or more people to set aside half the seats for nonsmokers and require employers to adopt written smoking guidelines and establish smoke-free work areas ''to the extent practical.''
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: The City of Yonkers, meanwhile, was recently selected as one of 10 in the United States to be the focus of an intense anti-smoking campaign financed by the National Cancer Institute and carried out by the American Health Foundation. As part of the program - known as Commit, or the Community Intervention Trial for Smoking Cessation - Yonkers residents will be exposed over the next four years to intensified anti-smoking messages.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Karen J. Fersht, the project director of the program, says she has never been a smoker. But she has run many smoking-cessation clinics and has done research in the field as well. Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Ms. Fersht.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. What makes a good anti-smoking program?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. A lot depends on the person who comes to the program. A person needs to have a commitment to want to quit smoking. Regardless of what program, this commitment has to be increased for the program to be successful. It's also important that the person has social support - encouragement from their families and friends - maybe having a buddy system set up.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: It's interesting to point out that most people who quit do so on their own. Some people can't quit on their own and seek support from other avenues - going to support groups, participating in the American Cancer Society's adopt-a-smoker program, for example. Most people who do smoke want to quit but it's a difficult thing to do. According to the Surgeon General, nicotine is an incredibly addictive substance.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. Is the problem mainly physical or is a psychological dependence - a habit - also involved?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. It is definitely both. People smoke regularly at certain times of the day and when they are stressed. An approach that works is changing that automatic habit of reaching for a cigarette by making life-style changes. With each quit attempt, you learn more and more, which is why subsequent quit attempts are more likely to be successful. Some people keep a diary and see that they smoke after their morning cup of coffee, or when in the car. They can rearrange their day, so they're not having their breakfast in the same place; they have it perhaps at their office where they can't smoke. We had a guy who always shaved and smoked in the morning. So what he did was shave at work, where he couldn't smoke. Everyone is different.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. Is smoking like dieting in that people stop and start again and again?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. Even with dieting, some people diet for the first time, lose the weight and never have a problem again. That's true with some smokers. But with a smoker, it's not uncommon to have multiple attempts to quit. The more attempts the smoker makes, the more likelihood he will succeed. If he keeps on falling back on smoking, this does not mean that he is a failure. He has to keep trying and he will be able to do it. That's indicated through research. A lot of people think that if they have a cigarette they are failures and don't want to try again. But there is a difference between a slip and a relapse. Having one cigarette does not mean a person is a smoker again. He has to say, ''I am a nonsmoker but I had that one cigarette, but I'm still a nonsmoker.'' Similarly with dieting, ''I'm a dieter and just because I had an ice cream sundae doesn't mean I'm not a dieter.''
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. Why do so many people go back after giving it up for a long time?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. I guess it's the old thing - once a person has been a smoker, they always have that tendency toward being a smoker, and with stress tend to fall back on old things. It's something very ingrained; it doesn't go away. Like biting your nail. I used to do that. If I feel under a lot of stress, all of a sudden I find myself biting my nails. It's an immediate, unconscious reaction. The single most effective technique for stopping smoking is to replace the habit with something positive, like an exercise program, not with more eating. Most people who quit do gain a little bit of weight; smoking appears to speed up the metabolism. It's also good for people to identify with a role model, someone who has quit smoking.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. If a person stops smoking, should they try to not have even one cigarette?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. That's up to the individual person. What's more important is maintaining a positive attitude that ''I'm still a nonsmoker.'' A slip does not have to lead to a relapse.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. Is it better to go cold turkey or to cut back gradually?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. Different things work differently for different people. If you stop gradually, you are still bringing nicotine into your system. It's incredible that since 1964 there's been a tremendous increase in how many people have stopped smoking. One thing highlighted in the Surgeon General's report is that between 1964 and 1985 three-quarters of a million smoking-related deaths were postponed or prevented from decisions to stop smoking; 51 million adults are still smoking so we still have a way to go.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. Large numbers of teen-agers keep starting?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. A lot of that is attributable to peer pressure.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. Is there a link with marijuana use?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. If they smoke, they are more likely to use illicit drugs also.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. Is marijuana equally unhealthy for the lungs?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. We don't have enough thorough research yet; but it is considered a causative agent in lung cancer. You're breathing in a lot deeper and holding it in your lungs. We'll be seeing a lot more research done on this link.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. Are there cultural, gender and social differences?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. Yes. Smoking is greater by blacks, blue-color workers and the less educated. They are really the target of the tobacco industry. The decline of smoking is lower among women than men. It's worth noting that more women now die of lung cancer than breast cancer. A lot of the tobacco industry targets women with brands such as Virginia Slims showing slim, attractive women smoking. I remember when I did a smoking cessation clinic I'd say to a man, ''You don't have to quit smoking, but you have to smoke Virginia Slims'' and they wouldn't do it.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. Does peer pressure, where more and more people won't allow smoking in their homes, help press a smoker to quit?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. Smoking is not a social norm any more in our society. But there is a lot to overcome. The tobacco industry is spending $7 million a day on advertising and promotion. You're looking at a lot of money.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. Do anti-smoking laws help?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. It's a message to people, a covert message that smoking is not good. It is saying that we care about your health.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. What goes on at anti-smoking clinics?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. Different kinds of programs have different approaches. They all talk about strategies. Some programs may have diary logging, a way of self-monitoring. They're effective in helping people help themselves, helping people deal with stress, learning what their own triggers are.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. What is special about the Commit project in Yonkers?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. The Commit project is the largest effort of the National Cancer Institute of a large-scale community-based smoking cessation project designed to look at how to help smokers stop smoking throughout North America. It is based on the premise that smoking is a community problem and therefore the community needs to unite and take action. With the project, we have a board and four task forces that will help us carry out our work.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. What will you do?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. We will build and strengthen the existing programs in Yonkers, help get voluntary programs known. There will be a hot line set up for referral information, if people want to quit smoking and don't know where to go. There will be a saturation of different kinds of smoking messages. We will be working with physicians, so they'll be involved.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: It will involve public education, getting health-care providers to set a policy, having employers provide smoking-cessation programs. There are a lot of different programs already out there. We want to let people know what's out there.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. How will you assess the success of the Commit project?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. We will survey 500 heavy smokers and compare the results with 500 people from New Rochelle. The hypothesis we're testing is that at the end of four years Yonkers will do 10 percent better than New Rochelle.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: Q. Is there anything else you would like to add?
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: A. Yes. People can call the American Cancer Society, the American Lung Association and the American Heart Association - all three of them have Westchester offices - for information about smoking-cessation programs, about self-help programs or about starting up a program of their own. People can call our field director, Mary Ann Stangl, at 965-9649. The office is at 201 Palisades Avenue in Yonkers.
title:
Westchester Q&A;: Karen J. Fersht;
A Focus on Helping Smokers Quit

text: THE CARIOCAS, AS THE NATIVES OF Rio de Janeiro are known, have marvellous qualities - an infectious joie de vivre, a refined sense of the ridiculous, the most sophisticated and beautiful popular music in the world - but the ability to handle money isn't one of them. So it came as no surprise to learn last fall that the city had declared bankruptcy. The reason was partly that the Federal Government was squeezed by a foreign debt of $115 billion, by heavy obligations to the private sector and by the highest inflation rate, 900 percent, in Brazilian history. It had no money to spare for Rio. So it cut the city off.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: Another factor in the Government's refusal to bail out Rio was that the city is the black sheep of Brazilian politics. It has few friends in Brasilia, where President Jose Sarney's Government is dominated by Nordestinos, people from the northeast, who tend to look upon Rio resentfully, as a self-indulgent hedonistic place whose problems aren't real.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: The cutoff would have happened anyway, because the Federal Government can't give funds to a municipality during the last three months of a city's administration. Mayor Saturnino Braga should have planned for this, but he had overcommitted himself to social programs, and Rio had actually been coasting since last May. The verdict on Braga was that he was a decent, honest man, but way over his head.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: But the real problem, a Carioca economist explained, was ''the bloated public sector, the cannibalization of public revenues by clientele politics'' - a problem in Brazilian cities large and small, where everybody works for the Mayor. Braga had been a particularly easy touch. In one of his last interviews as Mayor, he admitted shamefacedly that no one even showed up for 20 percent of the jobs he had handed out, and that 5 percent of those who showed up did nothing.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: AS I BOARDED THE PLANE IN NEW YORK I WONDERED what Rio's bankruptcy meant in real terms, whether the city would seem any different from the way it had been before it went bottoms up. If the sanitation department had joined the 103-day-old strike of unpaid city workers, it could be a very unpleasant stay.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: I sat beside a young Brazilian-American stockbroker who told me about the wild action on Wall Street of late in the secondary Brazilian debt market. Shares of the country's debt, reduced to say 40 percent of face value, had been selling like hot stock. ''If you didn't make a killing, you were stupid.''
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: The plane wasn't full, which was strange, considering that it was Dec. 30, and New Year's is Rio's biggest attraction after Carnival. Apparently many tourists had been scared off by the fear of street violence and AIDS. The sexual safari to Rio was for all but the most reckless a thing of the past.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: For the Cariocas, New Year's is a joyous catharsis, a chance to unload oneself of needless baggage and to start anew. A few days earlier, the traditional blizzard of superannuated paperwork had drifted down to the streets of the Centro, the business district, as people chucked the invoices and receipts of 1988 out their office windows. With a new mayor, Marcelo Alencar, taking office on Jan. 1, 1989 was going to be a fresh start for Rio.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: It was also a fresh start in my 12-year personal relationship with Brazil. The last time I was down, I almost had my head blown off by a masked gunman who burst into a beach house where I was spending the weekend. But he bungled the holdup and fled into the night empty-handed. ''Where else could you find such an incompetent assailant?'' my host asked, making light of the incident in classic Carioca fashion. The experience turned me off on Brazil, but after a while I began to feel a terrible longing for the place - the pangs Brazilians call saudade, and here I was back, like a lover ready to make up after a violent quarrel.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: RIO DE JANEIRO IS UNQUESTIONABLY ONE OF the most beautiful cities on Earth. It grew up at the foot of the Serra do Mar, a jagged chain of mountains that plunges into the magnificent Bay of Guanabara. Smooth granite peaks set off Rio's famous beaches: Flamengo, Botafogo Copacabana, Ipanema-Leblon. Watching over this glistening city is the immense statue of Christ the Redeemer. But this is only the Zona Sul, the Rio of the postcards. Seventy percent of the Cariocas live in the Zona Norte, on an unbeautiful plain behind the mountains. This is perhaps the real Rio.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: The first order of business for someone who hasn't been to Brazil for a while is to figure out the money. The banknotes that were in circulation during one's last visit are invariably worth a lot less and there are usually a few new ones. This time there were two: a 10,000-cruzado note and a 5,000-cruzado note. The higher denominations of the cruzeiro, Brazil's previous currency, were still in circulation, but they were more of a nuisance than anything. The 100,000-cruzeiro note, for instance, worth $6.50 at its debut in 1986, was now worth only a dime.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: I always stay in Copacabana. The water is oilier than at Ipanema and Leblon, but the scene is livelier. In the 1940's, it was the Brazilian dream of paradise, and it now has a deteriorated Fellinian Miami Beach quality. There is a nostalgic segment of the population - dowagers who take tea and pastries on the Barao do Ipanema, white-haired gentlemen with marvelous mustaches reminiscing in the bars.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: The Avenida Nossa Senhora de Copacabana is lined with the tables of camelos, street vendors selling digital watches, electronic devices and other contraband from Paraguay. With the failure of the Government to provide goods and services, the informal sector is becoming increasingly important. Thirty percent of the money thought to be in circulation in Brazil is off the books.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: This visit, I check into a new hotel, the Windsor Palace, a block from the beach, and, slipping on my swimsuit, head for the water. The city's pickle isn't immediately apparent. The orange-uniformed sanitation department sweepers are still on the payroll (they have to be because of the tourists) and the streets are actually quite clean. The real effects of the bankruptcy are that the emergency hospitals are virtually closed (their staffs are skeletal, and there isn't a Band-Aid to be had), and the schools are shut, depriving many children of their only square meal. Forty thousand streetlamp bulbs are out and there are 130,000 potholes in the streets - a damning reflection on the Braga administration. In Brazil, potholes are metaphors of performance. No matter what town you pull into, the cabbie always says, ''Look at these holes. What kind of a mayor is this, anyway?''
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: THE SEA IS THE MOST IMPORTANT thing in many Cariocas' lives, and going to the beach is like going to the theater. When I get to Copacabana, several astounding volleyball games, in which players can only kick or head the ball, are in progress. A group beside a beverage tent is laying down the intoxicating rhythm of the samba as a mulata swivels her hips and does some flashy footwork while tapping a pair of cowbells. The 10,000 bodies laid out on the sand or frolicking in the foam bear witness to how seldom the ideal of human beauty is realized, but a few of the young women are 10's. The dental-floss bikini - a tiny triangular pubic shield held up by straps that widen to cover the nipples, then go over the shoulder and down the back, converging in the crevice of the buttocks - is still in vogue.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: There is a new element - large families of poor, dark-skinned people from the city's arid Zona Norte, for whom direct bus service to the beaches has recently been provided for the first time. Many of them don't have bathing suits. Just to sit on the sand and have a picnic is a wonderful new experience.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: This being the last afternoon of the year, growing numbers of people are drifting down to the sea. By midnight, two and a half million people have converged on Copacabana Beach in a collective rejoicing that has no modern parallel. The African traditions of Brazil preside over the event. Afro-Catholic candomble and umbanda services are going on in marquees, kneeling devotees are being blessed by fat black priestesses, offertory candles are blazing in the sand, little boats are being launched into the waves with bottles of champagne and other gifts for Iemanja, the Goddess of the Sea.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: At 11:55, everyone heads down to the spotlit breakers. They seem unusually, even dangerously, tall tonight. As midnight strikes, most of the crowd steps into the surf. Strangers hug, lovers clutch, lone women weep in private pain. Sixty tons of glorious fireworks are shot up into the sky from nine separate sites.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: Elsewhere in the city 17 people are being violently murdered, including a waiter killed in his apartment by a transvestite - a typical Zona Sul crime. Rio is a mecca for gay people, who are cruelly persecuted elsewhere in Brazil. Many of the passive ones become transvestites, so that they can go out in public with their lovers or tryst at motels like the Lipstick and Trampolime on the outskirts. For career transvestites, Rio is a stepping stone to Rome or the Bois de Bologne.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: In the Zona Norte, the typical crime is what is known as the queima de arquivo, the burning of the archive: You have someone killed, then you have to kill the person you paid to do it so he won't tell and the person you got to kill him and everyone else who knows.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: On New Year's Day, the city awoke to the news of a ghastly tragedy. Ten minutes before midnight, an overloaded boat, called the Bateau Mouche IV, taking 124 revelers out to see the fireworks, sank and 53 people drowned. The flat-bottomed vessel wasn't designed for the open sea, especially that night, when a distant tempest sent in seven-foot waves. The port police had ordered the boat back to the harbor, but a bribe of $125 had overcome their objections. Several other craft passed the boat as it swamped but hadn't stopped because their passengers didn't want to miss the fireworks.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: It was the worst accident on the littoral in some time, and its resonances weren't lost on Millor Fernandes, The Jornal do Brasil's trenchant cartoonist, whose drawing of the foundering ''Brazil Mouche'' was captioned: ''No genius of police fiction could ever have conceived such a succinct image of the moral, social, economic, cultural, in sum total deliquescence of Brazil.''
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: The accident provoked uncharacteristic soul-searching and pessimism among the Cariocas. ''The foreign debt, the fires in the Amazon, the murder of Chico Mendes [ leader of the Amazon's rubber tappers ] and now this,'' a friend said gloomily. ''What must the world think of us?''
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: THE MORAL DELIQUE-scence of Brazil, if it is indeed happening, can be traced to the first colonists, Portuguese known as bandeirantes, who came not to build a society but to take what they could. This has been compounded in recent years by a modern syndrome that the psychoanalyst Jurandir Freire Costa calls ''narcissistic panic.'' Several years ago, he began seeing a new kind of patient, in a perpetual funk, with low self-esteem, not healthy physically or sexually. After analyzing a number of them, Costa published an essay last year called ''Narcissism in a Dark Age,'' which is the talk of Rio. Its thesis is that without ideas that give hope, with no cultural referents to give direction to one's life or to protect one from existential anguish, the human being becomes like an animal; when a man's confidence in his culture is ruptured and he loses faith in the future, he falls into a state of ''narcissistic panic'' in which because nothing matters anymore he is capable of doing anything.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: At about the same time, the British author Robert Moss's book ''The Collapse of Democracy,'' which explores the connection between collective self-esteem and inflation in the Weimar Republic, was a best-seller. ''Moss's thesis is that the Germans took hyperinflation as such a personal devaluation that they had to devalue someone else - the Jews,'' a bright young Carioca writer named Julio Cesar Martins Monteiro explained. ''Popularist totalitarianism grew out of the chaos. I can see how inflation is beginning to produce the same sort of demoralization and desperate selfishness in our society. Get it now because it won't be there tomorrow. The inflation is so bad that by the time your check clears it's worth 6 percent less.''
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: Martins had recently written an essay on AIDS in which he argued elegantly that Eros would end up defeating Thanatos through the rediscovery of committed monogamy. But monogamy is a lot to ask of Cariocas. Male friends assured me they were playing it safe; they were still seeing three or four women, but the same women. Women told me they were doing their own hair and nails now rather than entrust them to gay barbers and manicurists. There were stories about holdup men who threatened their victims with syringes saying, ''Give me your money or I'll give you AIDS.''
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: As in New York, the disease has taken a terrible toll in the arts. Of the three hemophiliac de Souza brothers who were infected by contaminated blood, the musician and the cartoonist are dead, and only Herbert, the sociologist, remains. He has dedicated himself to the city's moral rejuvenation through a highly successful campaign called Se Liga Rio, Turn on, Rio.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: The hottest rock star of the moment, Cazuza, who admits to being a bicha louca, ''a screaming queer,'' is visibly wasting away although he hasn't yet said it's from AIDS. In his song ''Brazil,'' Cazuza sings of his lacerated love for a country in decomposition, and of his own panicking narcissism: ''My heroes die of overdose/ My enemies are in power/ Ideology - I want one to live by.''
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: One evening I took a stroll past the hotels on the Avenida Atlantica, where the gringos stay. Girls come down from the hilltop slums to give them a good time. The asking price is $100. There is still plenty of action in spite of a blitz television campaign warning about the danger of sex with strangers. Incredibly lush young things, not all of them female, were coming on to Swiss and Canadian boys on package tours and blond Norwegians from oil rigs up the coast.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: Two girls fell in with me. I invited them for a beer in an outdoor bistro. Esmandina was a striking mulata. Already at 23 an old pro, she'd been hustling for six years. Patricia was only 16. A shy black girl with trusting eyes, she was moonlighting from her job as a salesgirl in a department store.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: ''I can make as much in one night doing this as I do in a month at the store,'' she told me proudly. ''Aren't you worried about AIDS?'' I asked. ''Eu nao,'' [ Not me ] Esmandina said, ''I rush to the bidet, and there's a pomade the Indians where I come from make. It cleans everything. And besides,'' she said in one of those fatalistic aphorisms the Brazilians are fond of, ''when you gotta die, you die.''
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: I GOT A LOT OF HELP ''DEMYSTIFYING the postcard,'' as he put it, from Jose Augusto Ribeiro, who writes Lardneresque stories about Rio. ''The typical Carioca is an improviser,'' he told me, ''a man who is asystematic, because of the sea. The samba is his religion. There are no set steps to the samba. Everyone has his own way of doing it. Some shuffle their feet, others lift them.''
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: ''There's nothing a Carioca takes seriously,'' Jose went on. ''He jokes about everything. It is a philosophy, a way of life, and thus is dead serious. This same satirist can sit down in the middle of the street and cry.''
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: Walking along the Praca das Paraibas, we ducked into a nondescript building. Behind a panel there was a small casino. A bookmaker with a visor was taking bets on the horses and a card game was in progress. On display was a vase with a sprig of rue, which is believed to protect from the olho grande, the eye of the envious. On a wall hung a picture of St. George slaying the Dragon. In the pantheon of candomble religion, St. George is the Warrior, the Ogum spirit, and he watches over the jogo do bicho, the illegal lottery that dominated the action in the casino. People kept coming in from the street to buy little strips of paper with 25 bichos, or animals, printed on them. Each bicho is associated with a number. The idea is to pick a winning combination. ''The jogo do bicho sells hope,'' Joao explained. ''It is very powerful. There's a big symbiosis between the Government and the jogo do bicho. No politician gets anywhere without its support. It stabilizes the system. But it is more of the problem than the solution.''
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: IT TOOK SOME TIME TO find a taxi driver who was willing to take me to Rocinha, the largest of Rio's more than 450 favelas, or slums, with 2,500,000 souls. Rocinha is like a gigantic pueblo, with thousands of little masonry room-blocks and shacks, threaded by a labyrinth of narrow zigzagging lanes and alleys that honeycombs the slopes of Two Brothers Mountain. In Rio, the poor have been pushed up the hillsides, where they have the best views, if little else.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: The arrival of the international drug trade four years ago made the favelas ever more dangerous than they were before. The wars between the various gangs that control the flow of cocaine and marijuana to the affluent areas can last for weeks. When the hilltop stronghold of one gang is finally taken by a rival gang, there are mass executions. The police don't get involved.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: ''Organized crime here is not a crime but an institution,'' Martins explained. ''In the last few years, political candidates have been going into the favelas to get the support of the biggest pushers and pimps, so when they are elected there is some commitment to leave them alone. The symbiosis is like Chicago in the 30's, and this vicious circle keeps Rio violent.''
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: At last I found a taxi driver who agreed to take me to Rocinha, as long as we parked in front of the police station and didn't go past the residents' own security checkpoints: the first post is said to be manned by marijuana dealers, the second by coke dealers, the third by car thieves.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: I left the driver in his taxi and walked up to the end of a steep lane, where I struck up a conversation with a woman leaning out of a window. Her name was Maria das Dores and she had come to Rio 13 years earlier from the parched northeastern state, she told me, ''in search of a better life. I thought it would be better than this.'' Actually, she was quite well off. She had running water and electricity, a television set, a refrigerator, even a washing machine. She worked as a housegirl for some rich people down below and had five children who were all beautiful. Her oldest daughter was already wearing lipstick - a 12-year-old vamp, who in two decades would probably be as worn and haggard as her mother.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: As I returned to the car, an unsavory man asked if I wanted to score some marijuana. A group of his wasted pals began to close in with indolent curiosity. If the police station hadn't been 100 yards away, I would have been in trouble.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: ALONG WITH A dozen exuberant talents in Rio's movie, music, ballet and fashion worlds, I went for Sunday lunch at the home of the actress Lucelia Santos, who played her most important role 13 years ago in a telenovela - one of Brazil's incredibly popular and well-crafted prime-time soap operas - ''The Slave Isaura.'' It's about a woman who helped free the slaves in Brazil in the 1880's, and has been seen in 52 countries. The role radicalized Lucelia, who is now a militant member of the Workers' Party and the Green Party. Some believe that Lucelia, who comes across as Joan of Arc, will become a big political force in the next century, perhaps the Eva Peron of Brazil.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: Her vision of Brazilian society is apocalyptic. ''Ja era'' -it already was - she said. ''What we need is a cultural transformation through the youth.'' We ended the afternoon listening to her sister Christina's new record, a heartbreaking song for the aideticos, the AIDS victims, and another about the queimadas, the fires in the Amazon, which were compared with the out-of-control political/economic situation: ''The fires are spreading in an inflation of red screams of saguis [ tamarin monkeys ] / In the bonfires the vines writhe like anacondas, then everything turns to ash.''
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: I DIDN'T WANT TO bother the new Mayor, who on top of all his other problems had the unexpected headache of the Bateau Mouche scandal to deal with, so I discussed his administration's emergency plan to bring Rio back on its feet with Vice Mayor Roberto D'Avila.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: As we sat talking in his office in the city's enormous administrative building, politicians kept popping in and D'Avila would have to get up and give them the ritual hugs and hearty backslaps. In between these visits, D'Avila explained that Rio had been short of funds ever since the capital was moved to Brasilia in 1960, and he confirmed that this had been aggravated by Braga's overhiring: ''The first step is to prune the organograms [ personnel charts ] of the phantoms and the idlers. We have begun by firing the 17,000 people Braga hired in the last six months. This alone will save us two billion cruzados. We have also launched an aggressive campaign against the 130,000 potholes and the 40,000 blown streetlamp bulbs; 320 men and 32 trucks have been commandeered for this emergency operation. Plugging the holes is a very important psychological palliative.''
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: Then D'Avila, a television journalist, told me that when Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York City was on his show ''International Connection,'' he asked how, based on New York's experience, a big city could avert imminent bankruptcy. D'Avila said Koch replied, ''Take drastic measures immediately, centralize decisions, privatize services, incentivate development.''
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: HELIO JAGUARIBE De Mattos, the dean of the Institute of Political and Social Studies, spent more than an hour patiently explaining the foreign debt and the inflation and their indirect but distinct bearing on Rio's bankruptcy.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: The inflation rate, he said, was approaching hyperinflation, ''and if the disequilibrium becomes daily, then hourly, it will produce absolute chaos in Brazil. There will be pillaging, looting of supermarkets and houses, paralysis of public services, general strikes. Within a week the country will become unlivable. To stop this, something drastic is needed.''
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: A week after our meeting the Government declared the cruzado ja era, and announced the birth of the new cruzado, whose relationship to the dollar would be frozen at 1 to 1. New cruzados are simply old cruzados with the last three zeroes knocked off. Brazil's money has lost 12 zeroes since 1942.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: The problem with freezing currency, prices and wages is that it creates a consumer frenzy, so that before long inflation springs back with a vengeance. But the important thing, a Carioca economist explains, ''is not what the plan does but what it prevents from happening. When the inflation returns, we'll come up with another plan.'' The strategies for controlling inflation are limited: reduce the public sector, reduce the foreign debt. Every political candidate must rail against the debt, but none of them has seriously proposed not paying it, because that would stop the flow of further loans.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: After our talk, Jaguaribe gave me a lift to a taxi stand. ''Look,'' he said. ''They're filling in the potholes. Ea engracado.'' I'll be damned. The new Mayor had been in office for only a day, and already the repair crews were at work.
title: RIO IS THE CARNIVAL OVER?

text: Mike Norris pitched 15 minutes of batting practice today, but he did not face Reggie Jackson and Bert Campaneris, both former teammates, or Jose Canseco and Mark McGwire, who play for the Oakland Athletics today.
title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol

text: Norris, who nine years ago had a 22-victory season for the Athletics, pitched to Jose Mota and Kevin Ward, who most likely will never be players of the stature of Jackson and Canseco. Norris will most likely never attain the 22-victory level again, but if he reaches the majors again, he will have succeeded in that quest.
title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol

text: ''I'm not thinking this way,'' the pitcher said, ''but even if I don't make it to the big leagues, I can count this as a successful effort. This is one heck of an ordeal to go through, but it's worth it. I could go out and kiss the grass every morning. That's how much I love this game.'' Ordeal for 6 Years
title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol

text: Norris will be 34 years old Sunday. The ordeal he endures in his comeback attempt this spring is a picnic in the park compared with the ordeal he has suffered the past six years. The shoulder operation in 1983 was the least of it. He has been in drug rehabilitation five times, he encountered a series of arrests and he stopped drinking when, while playing in Mexico two summers ago, he drank himself into the realization that he was an alcoholic.
title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol

text: ''I was off drugs when I went down there to pitch,'' Norris said, sitting on a bench in the shade at Scottsdale Community College, site of Oakland's minor league camp. ''But the environment there . . . well, I was having a hard time adjusting, but I had to be there if I wanted to get back because I was banned from A ball because of the drugs. That was my only option, playing in Mexico. Alcohol was my only crutch and it was legal.
title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol

text: ''I always had a problem with alcohol, but I never thought I was an alcoholic. I was drinking every night there. I would start out planning to have only one drink, but I would end up closing the bar. Finally, I thought about what I was doing, and I decided this wasn't any way to live either. It was as bad as the drugs.'' 'My Final Relapse'
title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol

text: Norris said he has not had a drink since that day. He has not used drugs, he said, since New Year's Day 1986.
title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol

text: ''I woke up that day and I wasn't at home,'' related Norris, who said he began using marijuana when he was 15 or 16. ''I was wearing the same clothes that I had on the night before. I had had one continuous party. My pockets were empty and my soul was empty. It was just a real ugly scene. I just looked at it and said no more. That was my final relapse.'' Norris had undergone drug rehabilitation five times, but he had not faced his last encounter with the law. That occurred in December 1986, when he was arrested in California on a charge of drunken driving. The arrest came as the Yankees were considering an invitation to spring training. The invitation was not forthcoming.
title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol

text: ''That was my own mess-up,'' Norris said. ''I hadn't gotten my life under control at that point.''
title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol

text: Is it under control now? ''Very much so. It's manageable at least. I've come to grips with my life. I can't do drugs and once I stopped drinking there were no more D.W.I.'s and D.U.I.'s. My life got to the point where I was embarrassed financially, spiritually, mentally, physically. All these characteristics led me to understand where I was. I also developed a sound relationship with a woman. I've had the continued support of my mother and I had an obligation to my nephew to be a man.''
title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol

text: Norris said he attends two meetings of Alcoholics Anonymous each week.
title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol

text: ''You don't use A.A. to better yourself,'' he said. ''You use A.A. as a constant reminder. You go and see people trying to get well and stay well and it makes you appreciate where you are. There's no A.A. program in the world that's going to stop you when you go to take a drink.''
title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol

text: Norris, who pitched for the Athletics for nine seasons, pitched in the minor leagues in 1985 and 1986, in Mexico in 1987 and nowhere last year.
title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol

text: He called the Athletics last December looking for a winter-league pitching job and they invited him to throw for them at the Coliseum. They invited him to spring training, and now his aim is to win a steppingstone job with Tacoma of the Class AAA Pacific Coast League.
title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol

text: ''If he keeps throwing like he has been, he'll have no problem,'' said Chuck Estrada, the Tacoma pitching coach.
title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol

text: ''I can still throw the heck out of the ball and I still have the stuff,'' Norris said. ''Mentally, I'm right, too. It just makes me wish I could've appreciated what I had when I was younger. Now I have an opportunity to do it the right way.''
title: Norris Tries to Make Comeback After Ordeal of Drugs and Alcohol

text: IN this quaint town where simplicity reigns, where traffic is seldom a nuisance and patrons dine at diners and chat for an hour afterward without a hint of rush, the locals gather and puff their chests while boasting about Indiana basketball.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: ''Naw,'' they begin. ''We never doubted the Hoosiers could do it this season. It was the media that picked 'em to finish seventh in the Big Ten Conference.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: ''Us fret when we were 3-4 and had been shredded for 100-plus points in three of those losses? Uh-uh. We believed. You outsiders didn't.''
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: But Joe Hillman, the Indiana guard, explained the Hoosiers seemingly unflinching following this way: ''Everybody was supporting us when it looked like the season was going to be long and heartbreaking, but you could tell they probably felt more sorry for us than anything. I guess to put it the best way, when I was deciding if I was going to come back for a fifth year, my mom said, 'Oh gosh, why? You're not going to be a very good team, and being a senior, you're going to have to take most of the pressure and blame.'
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: ''I just told her and myself, let's just see. You never know what's going to happen.'' Here is what has happened: Indiana (25-7) won 22 of its last 25 games. It is seeded second in the West Region of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I basketball tournament. It swiped the Big Ten championship with a 15-3 conference record. Jay Edwards was selected by The Associated Press as the Big Ten player of the year, and Eric Anderson as the Big Ten freshman of the year. Bob Knight, the Indiana coach, posted his 500th career victory and became the coach with the most victories in the conference, 227.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: All of this in what was arguably college basketball's most menacing conference this season. All of this with a team with only two returning starters, which now features a first five of two seniors, two sophomores and a freshman.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: When skeptics say that Indiana does not have talent, what they likely mean is the Hoosiers simply do not have as much talent as teams that razzle and dazzle and play the game from baseline to baseline at full throttle. The Hoosiers may not have break dancing mastered spin for spin, but they've got a meticulous waltz that's sheer elegance.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: Sure, there are moments they produce flair and high-wire-act baskets, but over 40 minutes they rely on execution, intelligence and hustle. They play ugly, they play pretty, they play patiently - sometimes slow, then slower. Teams that know they have more ability and know they should be winning keep peering at the scoreboard and finding numbers that are tough to swallow. In the end, somehow, the Hoosiers keep winding up with more points.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: New York will show you what you're made of, the saying goes. Back in November, when Indiana strolled into Madison Square Garden for the Big Apple National Invitation Tournament, there was every reason to believe this bunch of Hoosiers simply did not have the right stuff. Syracuse trounced them, 102-78, and North Carolina did the same, 106-92. Two games later in Indianapolis, Louisville smacked the Hoosiers, 101-79.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: Only once in Knight's 18-year Indiana coaching career had a team scored 100 points against his team. It sent Knight back to the chalkboard and film room.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: Knight had employed a lineup that featured size, but cumbersome Indiana was stumbling trying to keep pace with quicker, faster teams, and was dreadful at handling the basketball.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: Knight opted for a three-guard offense: Edwards, Hillman and Lydon Jones. That trio as starters now have a career record of 28-4.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: From there, Knight kept emphasizing the staples that have made Indiana basketball so successful.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: Defensively, it is man-to-man pressure with plenty of help from teammates. When the ball is on a certain spot on the floor, the Hoosier player has to be in a certain position relative to the ball. Offensively, the Hoosiers set up in relation to the defense, screening and cutting relentlessly for open men and open shots.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: This team has trouble rebounding, but when you're playing solid defense and getting good open shots from sharp shooters, there's not much to rebound.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: The Hoosiers have developed an enviable knack for going after opponents' star players and getting them into foul trouble. They make the star play defense when he's thinking of his offense; before he knows it, he's on the bench and the Hoosiers are at the free-throw line.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: Take Wisconsin. In clinching the Big Ten title Thursday night against the Badgers, Indiana went right at Danny Jones, the Wisconson backbone at forward, and Jones fouled out late in the game, having played only 20 minutes, scoring 4 points fewer than his 20-point average. Indiana went to the free-throw line 39 times and converted 30 in its 75-64 victory.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: The Indiana players are no different from their peers around the country. They read their point totals, know their percentages, and want minutes and points. Badly. The difference is that they have made those desires secondary to Knight's teaching and a loftier goal: the team.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: Indiana has six fifth-year seniors: Hillman, Todd Jadlow, Magnus Pelkowski, Mike D'Aloisio, Kreigh Smith and Brian Sloan. Hillman and Jadlow, who has become an active force at center, are starters. Sloan averages nearly 15 minutes and 3.0 points a game, but the other seniors play little. What they have given Knight, however, is a dedication to his principles that filters throughout the team. This is a team on one page, with one player that shines like a glistening rose in a bed of dandelions.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: It is nice to have role players, but any coach will tell you that to win championships you have to have the guy who puts the ball in the basket in the clutch, and helps everyone else elevate his level of play. For Indiana, that is Edwards.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: He is a sophomore, 6 feet 4 inches and 185 pounds of silk. He makes the game look easy because he moves so fluidly and shoots so wickedly, seldom grimacing, seldom grinning. He leads Indiana in scoring, averaging nearly 20 points a game. The Hoosiers won six conference games by 4 points of fewer, and in the waning moments of each, Edwards provided the finishing touch. Everyone here will long remember his 24-foot 3-point shot as the buzzer sounded that beat Michigan, 76-75, on Feb. 19.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: ''Sometimes I surprise myself,'' Edwards said. ''I guess the thing is, I'm never afraid to try and suprise myself. Playing here at Indiana is not always easy. There can be so much restriction that you wonder if you are really growing the way in the game that you should. And then when you sit back and you look it over, you see it's a system that works. It's like an eerie truth.''
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: His scholarship was taken away twice by Knight, once for marijuana use and once for academic problems. But Edwards bounced back, and now shows every sign of character and class to accompany his court brilliance. Knight chides him for not working harder without the basketball.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: ''A lot of what you see in the passing game is totally Jay,'' Hillman said. ''His creativity and passing carries over to everyone.''
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: Hillman has already earned his degree in finance and is an academic all-American. He is also a prize first-baseman in the Oakland Athletics' minor leagues. Knight argues that Hillman is the guts of Indiana's Big Ten championship and the league's most valuable player.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: ''There hasn't been anybody in the 18 years I've been here that has done a better job of getting a team ready to play than Joe Hillman has,'' Knight said. ''There are better players in the league than Joe Hillman and there are better players on this team than Joe Hillman. But he's the m.v.p. Together, each of these kids have come back to give us all one of the great treats I've ever seen given to a group of people.''
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: A treat indeed, the locals say. This unusual mix, plus Knight pushing the right buttons, has Indiana poised for its sixth N.C.A.A. title, Knight's fourth and his third in the 1980's.
title: Indiana Draws Strength From Setbacks

text: SINCE May 1985, when Francis C. Hall was named commander of the Police Department's 1,300-member narcotics division, drug arrests in New York City have risen steeply, to 3 of every 10 arrests, and the number of armed attacks on police officers has risen to unheard of levels.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: ''Drug suspects don't surrender any more,'' the assistant chief said. ''They fight, they grab you, and a lot of them will kill you if they can.''
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Last week Chief Hall retired after 36 years on the force; he is to meet in Washington soon with William J. Bennett, head of the new Office of National Drug Control Policy, who is looking for deputies.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Last Wednesday, a few hours before he left his office in lower Manhattan for the last time, Chief Hall talked with David E. Pitt, a New York Times reporter, about the war on drugs.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Question. What kind of role do you think you might be able to play in Washington?
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Answer. What really interests me is strategy and prevention. There's been entirely too much emphasis on enforcement as the solution to the drug problem. Enforcement has a very, very important part to play in the picture, but that's only because we're really the only game in town at the moment.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Q. That seems to be the public's impression.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: A. You can't blame the public for that. But no intelligent person would ever suggest that the police should eliminate murders or robberies or burglaries. Yet people expect us to eliminate drugs. Some of them use expressions like drug-free zones, drug-free communities. Unrealistic! Totally unrealistic. It's certainly not going to happen in my lifetime.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: I like to remind people that the war on drugs was first declared by Teddy Roosevelt in 1907. And here it is 1989 - that's 82 years. If we're still fighting a war after that long, you would think that prudent people would take a step back and look at whether we're fighting the right enemy.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: There have been peaks and valleys. In the 1960's it was heroin and marijuana and LSD. But the past three years have been something else again. I've been around a long time; not much surprises me or shocks me any more. But crack is really devastating.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Q. Do you think that any of the new tools, like property forfeiture or saturation arrests, have significantly improved drug enforcement?
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: A. I know of no tool that's any kind of magic wand. Forfeiture is a very valuable way to go because you can whack traffickers in their assets.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: You can't be too grandiose, you know. You pick an area that has a deeply entrenched drug problem, such as the Pressure Point One area on the Lower East Side, and you say, ''Let's see if we can sanitize it. And after we sanitize it, let's see if we can maintain it.'' Well, it's been five years now, and if you walk through Pressure Point One, you don't see blatant street sales of drugs.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Now, we certainly have not, by any stretch of the imagination, eliminated drugs in that area. But it appears to be cleaner than it was. And appearances are very important when it comes to narcotics enforcement. It's a quality-of-life issue.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Q. You have likened police narcotics work to the job of the Sanitation Department, which picks up garbage day after day, knowing that every morning there's going to be more of it.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: A. What is the alternative? You know the kind of recommendations I get? I get these every day. Things like, ''Why don't the police start whacking the drug dealers around? Why don't you do what they do in China to drug traffickers?''
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Well, summary executions would be very effective. But we have impediments - they're called the Constitution and due process. And we have a responsibility to uphold the Constitution.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: You know what's interesting, when I look back on my 36 years in this job? That the police have become the civil libertarians of the 80's. The police! If you were to listen in on these high-level conferences that I've sat in on every day, you'd hear, starting with the Police Commissioner: ''We don't step over the line.'' Because the first time you do step over it, you're going to have a problem. We saw it in Queens with those cops who were using stun guns to question suspects. Easy to understand: frustrated cops, locking up these same mutts day in and day out. Some of them lose control - and you know the rest of the story.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Q. What's your assessment of the country's overall commitment to fighting drugs, especially in view of complaints that there's not nearly enough money to do the job?
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: A. Look at the South Florida Task Force; an enormous amount of money was spent. Now ask me what impact that had on the availability of cocaine in New York, and my answer is: none, zero.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Yet they made some massive seizures. They've had some great press conferences. They've patted a lot of people on the back. But these press conferences don't represent success. They represent failure. Why the Demand?
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Here I am looking at 5,000 pounds of cocaine [ from a single recent seizure in New York City ] . All right, we did a good job, but it represents failure. Who the hell wants all of this cocaine? Why is it there are so many people in this country who want drugs? That's the issue that has to be addressed. Why do these people want drugs?
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Years ago in the 60's, if you made, say, a 30- or 40-kilo seizure of heroin, there would be a period of time when it was difficult to buy heroin. You don't see that any more.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: There is so much cocaine in New York today, it is beyond measure. Beyond measure. When I look at 5,000 pounds, I say to myself, how many more of these stash houses are there around here?
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Q. Well, how do you stave off total despair?
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: A. You have to put things in perspective. Take cancer. Scientists have been working on a cure as long as I can remember. They have not cured cancer. They have made some progress. There are certain cancers they have cured, others they have put into remission.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: And that's what we do. We can put areas of the city into temporary remission by a commitment of law-enforcement people. But we shouldn't kid anybody that we've cured anything. Now, no one's going to criticize the medical profession: ''Holy cow, you've been at this 50 years now, when are you guys going to come up with a cure?''
