And I don't see any cure for the drug problem on the horizon, either.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Q. How serious a threat are the synthetic drugs and the designer drugs?
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: A. Synthetic drugs are a potential threat beyond most people's imagination. They're cheaper to make than botanical drugs, and more potent; the experience in California with ''ecstasy'' is absolutely frightening. They're here now - amateur chemists can duplicate the properties of most drugs in labs at home. We haven't seen them to any significant extent in New York because we have so much of the other drugs.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: That's one of the reasons I've never been a big fan of interdiction. Let's imagine for a minute that we could stop all drugs coming into the United States - all heroin, all cocaine. Synthetic drugs would take over within two months.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: So we really have to stop and say, ''Holy cow, is the problem really in Colombia?'' Well, no, the problem is here.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: And no one really knows anything about drug education. Education tends to work with the more affluent. I think that in the past few years, you've probably seen some decline in illegal drug use among the middle class and the upper classes. In the entertainment business, cocaine use is now a no-no. That's encouraging. But when you get into the inner cities, it's a serious problem.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Q. If there is, as you seem to be suggesting, a correlation between drug use and poverty, what difference is education going to make?
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: A. It's a damn good question, and I don't have the answer. I hope someone can come up with it, because I know of nothing more important to this country right now than reducing drug use in the inner cities. The social problems associated with drugs are mind-boggling - crack babies, babies born with AIDS. The death rate in Harlem among infants is as high as it gets in third world countries. It's outrageous, a national disgrace.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: It never really occurs to me that I need anything to get high. I have other things in life.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: But if you're some kid who lives in the South Bronx, or Harlem, or Bed-Stuy, particularly when they can watch television and see an awful lot of affluence that they don't share in - if you want to feel good, crack will make you feel good. It'll do terrible things to you, too, but these kids don't have the insight to realize that. When you take a puff out of that crack pipe, you feel good for maybe 10 or 15 minutes. So when you come down, it's only natural to want to feel good again.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: But here I'm talking about the user, not the guy who sells the drugs. The average person doesn't realize the viciousness of people involved in trafficking, and the total lack of fear they have of law enforcement. My biggest fear in leaving is that I'm going to see more cops shot, and I'm concerned not only as a retired chief, I'm concerned as the father of two cops.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: If you recall LSD, it did wacky things to people. But it seemed to peter out in about two years. The thing about crack is how sustained it's been and how active the entrepreneurs who sell it are. You know, you can buy an ounce of cocaine for $900 -twice the value of gold - and in a few hours convert it into 437 vials of crack.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Q. It's kind of a nightmare form of free enterprise.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: A. Yes, a cottage industry, free enterprise gone mad. And now they're all organized, with so many different groups involved in it - Jamaicans, Hispanics, blacks, Palestinians. We had a major case in Brooklyn involving Israelis. Among all of them, the common denominator is profit. I know of nothing you can sell where you can make a greater profit than drugs - if you survive.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Narcotics enforcement is like the Vietnam War to this extent: If you recall, in Vietnam we kept pouring in resources. I think when we finally decided that the war was lost, we had better than half a million people in Vietnam. We had body counts in Vietnam; we used to measure our success by how many Viet Cong we killed. We measure our success here by how many arrests we make - 90,000 last year. That's our body count.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: But there comes a point when you have to say, what is the optimum number of people we should have directly involved in narcotics enforcement? We may have reached it. If we continue to pour in resources, it may not make things much better.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Unless people who are arrested for selling drugs receive some meaningful punishment, you are going to encourage other people to sell drugs. Kids are not stupid. They see a guy in their neighborhood who's earning upward of $500 a day selling drugs, and they see the cops grab him. And then they see him back on the steet tomorrow. There really is no deterrent there. They'll think, why shouldn't I do it? He drives a Mercedes, he wears that nice jewelry.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Q. What do you mean by meaningful punishment? Do you think the death penalty would make any difference?
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: A. No, I don't. I am not philosophically opposed to the death penalty. I don't believe in draconian punishment because it's rarely imposed, and when it is, it takes too long to impose it.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: I think we have to give serious thought to a totally different form of incarceration. The individual-cell prisons cannot accommodate as many people as I think should be accommodated. You have to get to the camp-type prisons.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: Overall, there has to be a reduction in the demand for drugs, and enhancement of the risks in using and selling them.
title: THE REGION - Q & A: New York's Drug Commander; Report From the Field On an Endless War

text: A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY By John Irving. 543 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: Our Presidents continue to pour the soothing syrup. But some of our most talented novelists see the political condition of American society as a disaster, the temper of many Americans as correspondingly dangerous. In ''A Prayer for Owen Meany'' John Irving makes it all too plain, and with positive rage, that in his eyes American society has been a moral disaster since the 1960's. He instances the America that snickered at President Kennedy's amours in the White House, the Vietnam War that sacrificed more than 58,000 of our young men, the moralizing and piety of national leaders who refuse to hinder the traffic in weapons of every kind, to say nothing of a widespread appetite for drugs and the ''junk food'' of television, which ''gives good disaster.''
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: Desperate conditions invite desperate remedies. In ''A Prayer for Owen Meany'' this takes the form, originating in a town very like Exeter, N.H., and in a school that pleasantly caricatures the old regime at Phillips Exeter Academy, of sainthood - and perhaps something more than that? The center of the book is a little squirt who reminds me, at least, of Truman Capote (outwardly) and has a peculiarly faint voice to match. To be understood, he talks in what Mr. Irving represents as oversized capital letters. Part of his cuteness is that he even writes his diary in LETTERS BIGGER THAN THESE without ever deviating.
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: In Puritan Massachusetts there was a staunchly independent Congregationalist minister, John Wheelwright, who supported his famously independent sister-in-law, Anne Hutchinson; because of his own mental freedom he was also banished from godly Boston by the ayatollahs of the day. He founded a congregation in Exeter, where John Irving was born and went to school at Phillips Exeter. I have always been fascinated by the destiny of the Puritans' descendants. I remember with relish the poet John Wheelwright, who was a follower of that overconfident, unfortunate prophet Leon Trotsky and was rumored to don a tuxedo to read his poetry in the Boston streets.
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: The narrator of ''A Prayer for Owen Meany'' is another John Wheelwright, also a descendant, but a good deal of a conscious and unapologetic wimp. Although he had half of his right forefinger amputated by Owen Meany so he could stay out of the Vietnam War (more about this later), out of disgust with his native land he emigrated to Toronto, where he teaches English literature in an Anglican academy for young ladies. (He has abandoned his ancestral Congregationalism for the Episcopal Church in America, the Anglican Church in Canada, and his constant companion is the Book of Common Prayer.) The book is as discursive as an undergraduate bull session, and the plot, simplicity itself, raises as many questions as stories of miracles usually do. Owen Meany, the little saint (the scene in which he is left hanging on a coat hook also suggests a ''Christ figure''), is unrecognized by all in the school town except his straight man and adoring disciple, the narrator John Wheelwright. Strange occurrences: Owen ''accidentally'' kills the narrator's mother (more about this later), and not only feels no guilt but manages to persuade the son that it was all foreseen (which means desired) by God. Since the narrator is illegitimate, her death seems necessary to our comprehending the inner perfection of a woman outwardly ''immoral.'' Strange occurrences: Owen foresees the exact day of his death as a martyr. His ''inside'' knowledge convinces him that he is God's messenger. Because he is so odd-looking and odd-sounding, he acts out the necessary paradox on earth suitable to men altogether holy within, though he can drink beer to excess and sleeps with the one girl in town unconventional enough to appreciate his stern disapproval of contemporary goings-on. Owen foresees everything in his life; in the startling climax he achieves martyrdom in the most exemplary way. But will this be really understood and appreciated by this damned generation?
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: What makes John Wheelwright the narrator important to the book is that he reports Owen's - and clearly John Irving's - raging displeasure with such American phenomena (and these are only a few) as Kennedy's inception of the Vietnam disaster; Johnson's helpless expansion of it; teen-age idiots in camouflage uniforms who are stupid with rock music and marijuana; television sought as a solace and acting as a drug. There is much, much else on the burning subject of America's moral failures, political chicanery high and low, the cant common to officialdom, the failure of the churches.
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: John Wheelwright is a lifelong virgin because of his spiritual fascination with the tiny saint-hero, Owen Meany - who, interestingly, is not a virgin. And then there is the mystery of good in an evil world that lies at the heart of the novel: Owen Meany at the age of 11 killed Wheelwright's mother, a ''perfect'' woman he adored, when, at bat in a school baseball game, he managed for the first time in his life to get a ''decent hit'' - a foul ball. This foul smashed into the left temple of the dear woman as she strayed onto the field and turned around to wave to someone in the stands.
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: I find it preposterous that John Wheelwright not only bears no grudge against the (accidental) killer of his mother but learns to reverence him because Owen is so sure that the death was foreseen, in God's hands. Does she have to die in order to make the point that there is a mystery to this our life that we have to accept if we are to believe in a providence? This may be true in general, but here in New Hampshire the point is so forced that it is repellent. And does Owen Meany ever believe, because his parents (in some confusion) told him, that his was a virgin birth? Is it really a proof of spiritual powers that Owen Meany, while acting in a school production of ''A Christmas Carol,'' should see on the stage tombstone the exact date not only of Scrooge's death but of his own? Does the corpse of a pet armadillo have to be deprived of its claws, as the Indian founder of the town is pictured without arms, in order to make the point that the world is besotted with weapons? This seems to be an argument not for peace but for impotence, as is the grisly episode, bearing still another symbol, in which John Wheelwright has half his right forefinger amputated by Owen Meany (with a saw used for cutting granite) in order to get him out of the Vietnam War. He gets to Canada anyway, so why not with a whole forefinger?
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: I do not know the answers. What I do know is that John Irving favors ''characters,'' not character, and has an obvious taste for featuring oddballs, zanies, freaks, ''originals.'' In this novel they remind me not of the lives of saints but of George Price's wonderfully distorted cartoon families, their members forever eyeing one another suspiciously in their own homes. John Wheelwright and Owen Meany love each other almost as much as John Irving loves them, the ''good'' characters, to the death. Clearly, Mr. Irving has come to such a point in his revulsion from our disorder that he has decided (this is hardly novel in ''religious'' fiction) that the true saints and even ''Christ figures'' are the oddballs, and that only such can do anything about this gashed, violent, yet morally torpid society. And unlike us conformist sheep, who are all too comprehensible and classifiable, they test and provoke us not just beyond endurance but beyond our comprehension. Traditional enough! But it is what we do comprehend here that makes for a problem.
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: The essence of ''A Prayer for Owen Meany'' - he dies on the date foretold to him, but in a way totally unexpected (I can say that he dies because of the Vietnam War and because of what it did to the American temper) - is that though we cannot understand Owen Meany's life and death in ''ordinary,'' rational terms, we are expected to understand both as a miracle.
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: My problem is that John Irving's obvious excitement with all this does not translate convincingly as fiction. It is just pushed at us enthusiastically. There is something much too cute about Owen's conviction that since he can foretell so much he must be God's instrument. It never seems to occur to John Wheelwright, the devoted Anglican in Canada, that his prophet Owen is caricaturing Calvinist predestination in the role of fortuneteller. To believe that everything is in God's hands hardly entitles anyone to believe that everything is determined in advance and that he knows exactly what will happen. This is astrology and denies the principle of free will.
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: John Irving, whose six previous novels include ''The Cider House Rules'' and ''The World According to Garp,'' is an abundantly and even joyfully talented storyteller. He is a natural crowd pleaser, not least because his values are simplistic, brilliantly cinematic in the way he positions good against evil. He can be very funny, as in the delicious scene of a student rebellion against a tyrannical headmaster. It is already so perfect for the movies that I laughed as one does only in the movies. But Mr. Irving is terribly in earnest most of the time, politically and sacramentally, with the same easy sense of virtue. The book is as cunningly contrived as the most skillful mystery story - that is the best of it. But there is absolutely no irony.
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: Our land is in such a state that a miracle man is a necessary symbol of a new kind of thinking among us. Mr. Irving shows considerable skill as scene after scene mounts to its moving climax. But the thinking behind it all seems juvenile, preppy, is much too pleased with itself. There is something appropriate in the fact that so much of the book takes place in and around a New England academy. The heavily emphasized ''religious'' symbols at the center of the book - the contrast to American aggressiveness offered by the clawlessness of the armadillo, the armlessness of the Indian founder of the town, even John Wheelwright's imbecile joy at being mutilated as still another symbol of his sacrifice of sex to right thinking - all this reminds this long-tried teacher of all the ''Christ symbols'' his students find in everything and anything they have to read.
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: I am told everywhere that we are undergoing a religious revival. Maybe so. What I, at least, seem to see is a lot of hopeful language and a frightening, intolerant fundamentalism when it is not, as it is in official Washington, the most chilling public relations. I shuddered when Mike Wallace, interviewing President Reagan just before he left the White House, addressed him as ''a spiritual person.'' Franz Kafka, who respected religion but like many of us was not altogether certain about what goes on in heaven, said to a Christian admirer in Prague: ''He who has faith cannot talk about it. He who has no faith should not talk about it.'' There is lots and lots of talk about ''religion''in this book. John Irving is a talented man and politically more outspoken than most of us, but the talk is on a level with the examples Mr. Irving gives of American superficiality, shoddiness, frivolity.
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: Flannery O'Connor, one of the few American novelists of my time I am sure will be read well into the next century, was an absolutely, tyrannically believing Roman Catholic who made life difficult even for her parish priest (he told me so) because she disapproved of his literary tastes. In a letter to a friend in 1955, she described a conversation with Mary McCarthy in which Miss McCarthy, who had left the church at 15, said she had come to think of the Holy Ghost ''as a symbol and implied that it was a pretty good one.'' O'Connor: ''I then said, in a very shaky voice, 'Well, if it's a symbol, to hell with it.' That was all the defense I was capable of but I realize now that this is all I will ever be able to say about it, outside a story, except that it is the center of existence for me; all the rest is expendable.''
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: I have long had the feeling that the passion of that statement has something to do with the steely precision with which Flannery O'Connor indicated her dissatisfaction with human character. Her own character, as she often said, was not so hot. She did not ''love'' her characters. There are so few ''good'' ones! But then, she was not a ''spiritual person.'' Casting Doubt on Atheism
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: ''Jesus has always struck me as a perfect victim and a perfect hero,'' said John Irving, explaining the genesis of his seventh novel, ''A Prayer for Owen Meany.'' The story about a freakishly diminutive self-proclaimed prophet and his effect on the religious belief of his lifelong friend represents ''a natural progression'' for Mr. Irving.
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: ''Like most teen-agers, for 19 years I sat in church and hated every minute,'' said the 42-year-old writer during a telephone interview from his home in Grafton, Vt., ''but that accumulated time takes a toll or leaves you with images that cast a doubt on one's former atheism.''
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: It was the element of precognition in the Gospels that appealed to his artistic imagination, Mr. Irving said. ''One event that always got me was that Jesus told his disciples that they were going to betray him.'' In the novel, Owen Meany issues a series of prophecies - including one of his death - that find an often ironic fulfillment.
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: ''Owen Meany does seem to possess a kind of moral certainty and acts as one who is in possession of one piece of information that cannot be explained in the natural world,'' Mr. Irving said. After a lifetime of witness, the novel's narrator comes to believe in God.
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: ''What degree of religious belief I can manage owes as much to personal experience as it does to all those years of conscious and subconscious training within church,'' Mr. Irving said. ''When I am moved to see beyond my usual doubt, when I am moved to something that approaches real faith, it seems to me, I am basing those instincts for belief on personal experience as much I am on any formal religious training.'' MICHAEL ANDERSON
title: Article 623189 -- No Title

text: The Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, which found itself in a national spotlight yesterday as President Bush kicked off an anti-drug crusade, is the nation's primary agency - but far from the only one - in a diversified war against cocaine, heroin and other illegal drugs.
title: Federal Drug Agency Takes Center Stage

text: In an effort to pull together ill-coordinated Federal drug efforts, President Richard M. Nixon in 1973 created the agency as part of the Justice Department by merging five anti-drug agencies from that department, the Customs Service and the White House.
title: Federal Drug Agency Takes Center Stage

text: Since its inception, when it had 1,423 agents and a budget of $74.3 million, the agency has grown - along with the drug problem - into an organization with 2,882 agents, a budget of $535 million, field offices in 19 American cities and agents in 44 countries abroad.
title: Federal Drug Agency Takes Center Stage

text: While the agency is reluctant to discuss the size of specific field offices, the biggest office is in Miami, where cocaine and other drugs from South America and the Caribbean have become epidemic. Other major field offices are in New York City, Los Angeles and Houston. Inquiries and Arrests
title: Federal Drug Agency Takes Center Stage

text: The agency's mandate - to enforce Federal drug laws - is carried out in a broad range of activities, including investigations, the gathering of intelligence, the interdiction of drug supply lines, the arrest of drug traffickers, the seizure of assets used to facilitate drug trade and the training of state, local and foreign drug agents.
title: Federal Drug Agency Takes Center Stage

text: The D.E.A., whose administrator, John C. Lawn, reports to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, coordinates investigations and intelligence with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which since 1982 has had concurrent jurisdiction to enforce Federal drug laws, and with customs agents and the United States Attorneys who prosecute suspects.
title: Federal Drug Agency Takes Center Stage

text: Joseph Keefe, a spokesman for the agency in Washington, said that D.E.A. agents last year seized $655 million in assets - the homes, cars, boats, stocks, bonds, bank accounts and cash of suspects - that had been used to facilitate the drug trade. The sum was well in excess of the agency's budget, he noted.
title: Federal Drug Agency Takes Center Stage

text: Mr. Keefe said that the agency arrested 23,972 drug suspects last year, compared with 13,266 arrests in 1981, an indication of growing drug abuse and expanded enforcement efforts. More Drugs Seized
title: Federal Drug Agency Takes Center Stage

text: He noted that patterns of drug seizures by D.E.A. agents in the last decade provide a broad picture not only of the agency's activities, but also of the kinds of drugs that have plagued the nation.
title: Federal Drug Agency Takes Center Stage

text: Last year, he said, D.E.A. agents seized 794 kilograms of heroin, 55,897 kilograms of cocaine and 532,014 kilograms of marijuana. In 1981, the agency seized 204 kilograms of heroin, 1,937 kilograms of cocaine and 1,149,462 kilograms of marijuana.
title: Federal Drug Agency Takes Center Stage

text: While the large increases in heroin and cocaine seized reflect the explosion of trade in those drugs, particularly the smokable cocaine derivative crack, Mr. Keefe said the decline in the amount of marijuana seized conceals another phenomenon: the spread of a far more powerful form of marijuana from domestic sources.
title: Federal Drug Agency Takes Center Stage

text: Although the agency was created to draw together sprawling Federal anti-drug efforts, those efforts have once again proliferated. While the agency and the F.B.I. focus on investigations, many Federal agencies - involving health, agriculture, military services, customs, transportation, corrections, research, to name a few - all play roles.
title: Federal Drug Agency Takes Center Stage

text: The D.E.A.'s $500 million budget for the 1988 fiscal year was only a fraction of the estimated $3 billion that the Federal Government spent last year in the fight against drugs, Mr. Keefe noted. The largest share, $962.2 million, was allocated for interdiction, while $568.5 million went for investigations.
title: Federal Drug Agency Takes Center Stage

text: Robert Dick and Marielana Arizpe, two flutists, are to play new-music solos and duets at 9 P.M. tomorrow at Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street (219-8242). Tickets are $6.
title: 2 Flutists

text: A new breed of street-corner confidence men has joined the purveyors of counterfeit Gucci bags, Rolex watches and Chanel No. 5, say law-enforcement officials in New York City: fake-crack peddlers.
title: The Latest Swindle: Peddling Fake Crack

text: ''It's referred to as 'beat,' '' Assistant Chief Francis C. Hall of the New York City Police Department said of the bogus drug. ''There are several substances they use to make it.''
title: The Latest Swindle: Peddling Fake Crack

text: The authorities say the phenomenon first became apparent about a year ago, when they began noticing a sharp rise in shoplifting cases involving a widely advertised over-the-counter product sold to soothe toothaches and denture pain.
title: The Latest Swindle: Peddling Fake Crack

text: ''They boil the stuff down, dry it out and bottle it for $5,'' said a prosecutor familiar with the practice. ''It looks just like crack.''
title: The Latest Swindle: Peddling Fake Crack

text: In one recent shoplifting case, police officials said, two young men were caught outside a supermarket in Manhattan with 38 packages of the toothache drops between them, most of it stuffed in pockets and tucked under their jackets. A third companion was arrested nearby with a large quantity of antiperspirant deodorant sticks and jars of medicated salve.
title: The Latest Swindle: Peddling Fake Crack

text: ''The toothache pharmaceutical has a mild anesthetic in it, so I suppose some people get a little something from smoking it,'' said Chief Hall, who retired yesterday as the head of the Police Department's narcotics division. ''God knows, maybe some of them actually get high from it. The power of suggestion can be very strong.''
title: The Latest Swindle: Peddling Fake Crack

text: In addition to solid deodorant and antiseptic creams, white bread is also popular as a crack look-alike, officials say. Balled up and artfully rolled between the fingers for effect, it has exactly the same whitish, lumpy appearance of the real thing, a smokable, highly addictive cocaine derivative whose effects have ravaged whole neighborhoods in New York and other major cities.
title: The Latest Swindle: Peddling Fake Crack

text: ''We had a lot of cases in Washington Square Park not long ago where they were selling soap in crack vials,'' the chief added. ''There's no limit to people's imaginations. But once we seize it, we don't know what it is until the lab looks at it, because we don't go inside the vial. All we know is that it looks like crack. And of course, once the lab says, 'Not a controlled substance,' we have to release them.'' 'High Degree of Risk'
title: The Latest Swindle: Peddling Fake Crack

text: Theoretically, fake-crack salesmen in New York City could be charged with a misdemeanor known as ''fraudulent accosting'' - but prosecutors point out that few crack customers bilked of their money are likely to move things along by filing a complaint with the police.
title: The Latest Swindle: Peddling Fake Crack

text: ''I would say there's a high degree of risk here,'' Chief Hall said, recalling the 1960's and 70's, when people commonly substituted oregano for marijuana and talcum powder for amphetamines. ''Not from the police, but from the people you sell it to, who are not going to tolerate it. Who knows how many people may have been injured or even killed doing that? It's not a prudent thing to do, in my estimation.''
title: The Latest Swindle: Peddling Fake Crack

text: The chief, who estimated that ''several hundred'' of the 90,000-odd narcotics arrests the police made last year were thrown out because of bogus crack, said the phenomenon did not, unfortunately, strike him as ''a growing trend.''
title: The Latest Swindle: Peddling Fake Crack

text: ''It doesn't have to be,'' he said. ''There's plenty of the real stuff right here in the city.''
title: The Latest Swindle: Peddling Fake Crack

text: Last summer a group of ethnic Chinese from Vietnam threw a bomb loaded with .22-caliber bullets at a police car on Canal Street in Chinatown, slightly injuring two officers. The bomb was retaliation for the arrest of several local merchants for selling counterfeit Rolex watches, the authorities said.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: Since then, the Vietnamese, who belong to a new gang called BTK, or ''Born to Kill,'' have committed a wave of robberies, assaults and murders that have alarmed residents of Chinatown, law-enforcement officials say. In one incident, the robbery of a massage parlor, a BTK gunman shot a customer in the head.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: ''The Vietnamese have suddenly become our biggest problem,'' said Nancy Ryan, chief of Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau's Oriental gang unit. ''Even the other Chinese gangs say they are wild and unpredictable and are afraid of them.''
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: The Cantonese-speaking Vietnamese, who range in age from 13 to 25 years old, have been in Chinatown for several years as members of established Chinese street gangs like the Flying Dragons and Ghost Shadows, the authorities say.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: But only since last summer have they emerged as a force of their own, taking over Canal Street and part of Mott Street. On Canal Street last October, gunmen from the BTK killed two Flying Dragons, reportedly for trying to encroach on their territory, Ms. Ryan said. No arrests have been made in the case.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: A major reason for the new power of the Vietnamese is that the leaders of the Chinese gangs have moved into a lucrative new field, heroin smuggling, the police say.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: Chinese involvement in heroin was underscored by the seizure last week of 820 pounds of heroin from three houses in Flushing and the arrest of a 71-year-old Chinatown liquor store owner, Peter Fok-leung Woo, as a major figure in the drug ring.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: The amount of heroin confiscated stunned the Federal Drug Enforcement Agency and raised new questions about the scope of Chinese underworld operations and whether the vast amount of heroin is creating more drug addicts. ''It was by far the largest seizure of heroin on record and far outweighs any estimates or predictions for what we thought the Chinese are bringing into the United States from Southeast Asia,'' one Federal official said.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: By comparison, said Robert M. Stutman, the head of the New York office of the Drug Enforcement Administration, a well-known heroin case, the so-called French Connection in the late 1960's, involved only 150 pounds of the drug. ''These Chinese make the French Connection look like second-raters,'' he said. Attraction of Riches
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: The Chinese move into heroin, replacing traditional Sicilian organized-crime families, has happened quickly, Mr. Stutman said. In 1983, Chinese dealers accounted for only 3 percent of the supply in the city. They now provide 75 percent, Mr. Stutman said.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: Mr. Woo is only one of several Chinatown figures attracted by the sudden new riches of the heroin business, law-enforcement officials say. Another, Johnny Eng, known as ''Onionhead'' or ''Machinegun Johnny,'' was named in a confidential Justice Department report last year as one of the five major heroin dealers in New York.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: Mr. Eng, 31 years old, remains the nominal head of the Flying Dragons, the gang that works for the Hip Sing Tong, one of the two major traditional Chinese associations that have controlled extortion, gambling and loan sharking in Chinatown, according to the police and other specialists.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: But Mr. Eng, who had at least five arrests in the 1970's on charges including assault, possession of a machine gun and promoting gambling, has now ''graduated'' into being an apparently legitimate businessman, Ms. Ryan said. He has purchased a home on Staten Island, invested in several restaurants, and he makes frequent trips to Hong Kong. Many More Chinese
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: Mr. Eng could not be reached for comment. He does not maintain an office under his name and has no listed telephone.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: These changes in the nature of organized crime in Chinatown have occurred as the number of Chinese in the city has soared. Since the passage of the immigration law of 1965, which ended the old quotas restricting Asians, the number of Chinese in the city has climbed to 300,000 from 20,000.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: This vastly larger Chinese population has eroded the authority of the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association, long Chinatown's informal government, said Prof. Peter Kwong, the author of ''The New Chinatown.'' But at the same time, this very erosion has created new opportunities for the tongs and their affiliated street gangs, said Professor Kwong, who teaches political science at the State University of New York at Old Westbury.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: ''Extortion still is the standard,'' Professor Kwong said, with the gangs collecting payments of $300 to $1,000 a month from most businesses in Chinatown. To disguise the nature of the tongs, which have tried to become more respectable in recent years, they have ''subcontracted out the dirty work to their gangs,'' he said. Role of Tongs
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: To Professor Kwong, the heroin bust last week, in which 18 suspects were arrested in New York, with 13 more in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Chicago, Detroit, Hong Kong and Singapore, ''proves that the tongs are a serious problem and getting bigger.''
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: He and law-enforcement officials believe that Mr. Woo is a member of the On Leong Tong, the other major tong in Chinatown, which he used as a source of contacts in the smuggling operation. Mr. Woo was only a mid-level operative in the network, the officials say, with the top leader probably living in Hong Kong.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: Professor Kwong said the tongs are at least partly responsible for the emergence of the Vietnamese gangs, by hiring them to take over extortion and protection rackets previously run by the older gangs. ''Their image among Chinese is that they come from the war and they aren't afraid to fight,'' he said.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: Another reason why the Vietnamese seem more menacing, said Sgt. Michael T. Collins, the head of a police task force in Chinatown, is that ''they have no associations, no ties to adults, so they have no sense of shame and no qualms about using violence.'' Status of Refugees
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: He estimates that 50 to 70 of the Vietnamese have conducted a series of robberies on Canal Street, often stopping people on their way to restaurants, garment factories or massage parlors. Citing a study of the Fifth Precinct, Sergeant Collins said the presence of the Vietnamese had sharply raised the crime rate in Chinatown in the last year.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: The Vietnamese gang members are particularly difficult to deal with, he said, because they came as boat people and have the status of refugees. Unlike illegal aliens, they cannot be deported. When arrested, they often give the address of group shelters where they do not live, he added.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: Gangs of Vietnamese, or ethnic Chinese from Vietnam, first appeared over the last four or five years in California, and then in Texas and New Orleans, where there are large settlements of Vietnamese.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: Because some of these gang members often show up in different cities, law-enforcement officials at first speculated that they had a nationwide organization. That theory has been largely discredited. The police have found that the gang members have no real homes and simply travel from city to city by car after committing a crime.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: Lounging in front of a shopping arcade on Canal Street, a 19-year-old Vietnamese who called himself ''Joe'' described his odyssey. His father was a merchant in Ho Chi Minh City, he said, and he had been able to go to school for only a few years before he was drafted by the Communists and sent to fight in Cambodia. 'All I Know Is Guns'
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: There he learned to smoke marijuana, with other Vietnamese troops, and eventually escaped to Thailand by bribing a Vietnamese official. He was able to get to the United States because he had a brother in San Jose, Calif., Joe said, but because he could not speak English and had no job skills, he soon found himself mingling with other young Vietnamese in a street gang.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: They took up robbery to support themselves, each time driving on to another city until some reached New York.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: ''People say I am bad, but what else can I do,'' said Joe, who has long spiked hair that spills over the collar of his leather jacket. ''All I know is guns.''
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: Despite the presence of the Vietnamese and the new heroin business, the old street gangs remain a problem for many Chinatown residents, said Robert Lee, the director of the Asian American Arts Center, a nonprofit agency that runs classes in Asian dance and sponsors exhibitions of contemporary Asian artists.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: Mr. Lee said young men connected to the Flying Dragons had tried to frighten him into leaving his center's headquarters at 26 Bowery so that a new landlord could convert it into a multistory restaurant. Asking for Damages
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: The gang members threatened him and later tracked down his father, a retired waiter who lives in Chinatown, Mr. Lee said. In their talks, the gang members invoked the name of ''Onionhead,'' the head of the Flying Dragons, which Mr. Lee took as a warning.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: Some gang members also stood outside the six-story arts center, intimidating the young girls who came for dance classes, Mr. Lee asserted. As a result, enrollment has dropped to fewer than 50 from 200, he said.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: When Mr. Lee refused to give in to the threats, the new owners tore off the old brick front wall of the building anyway, disrupting the center's work. Mr. Lee has now taken his case to the Loft Board, a city agency, charging harassment and asking for damages. Documents on file with the Loft Board show that the owner, listed as Bowery Mansion Inc., denies any threats.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: ''I see this as a way to encourage other people in Chinatown to stand up where they usually remain silent,'' Mr. Lee said. But he believes the American system is partly to blame for the gang's power because government officials for years ignored Chinatown, forcing generations of immigrants to protect themselves.
title: A New Gang's Violent Role in Chinatown

text: ''Heart of Midnight'' is a suspense melodrama that makes even less sense than its title. It's about - and seen through the eyes of - a young woman who may or may not be crazy. This gives the director license to be bizarre without having to justify anything.
title: Review/Film; Melodrama, 'Heart of Midnight'

text: The setting is a rundown nightclub-brothel, inherited by the heroine from her beloved uncle who died of AIDS, a detail that is offensive for being of no particular point.
title: Review/Film; Melodrama, 'Heart of Midnight'

text: Among the things that may or may not happen in the movie are a rape, the sexual molestation of a child, a murder, some conventional sadomasochism and a couple of manifestations of the occult. The dialogue is clumsy and the suspense is nil. Matthew Chapman, the writer and director (''Stranger's Kiss''), attempts to tart things up with fancy camerawork, but the film remains inert.
title: Review/Film; Melodrama, 'Heart of Midnight'

text: The cast includes Peter Coyote, Jennifer Jason Leigh, Sam Schact, James Rebhorn and Frank Stallone.
title: Review/Film; Melodrama, 'Heart of Midnight'

text: ''Heart of Midnight'' opens today at the Embassy 2 and Manhattan Twin. A MYSTERY - HEART OF MIDNIGHT, written and directed by Matthew Chapman; director of photography, Ray Rivas; edited by Penelope Shaw; production designer, Gene Rudolf; produced by Andrew Gaty; released by the Samuel Goldwyn Company. At Embassy 2, Broadway and 47th Street, and Manhattan Twin, 59th Street, east of Third Avenue. Running time: 96 minutes. This film is rated R. Carol Rivers...Jennifer Jason Leigh Sharpe/Larry...Peter Coyote Sonny...Gale Mayron Fletcher...Sam Schacht Mariana...Denise Dummont Ledray...Frank Stallone Richard...James Rebhorn
title: Review/Film; Melodrama, 'Heart of Midnight'

text: Global production of coca, marijuana, opium poppies and hashish increased sharply in the last year, partly because of political and economic instability in drug-producing countries, the State Department reported today.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: American policymakers ''were confronted once again in 1988 by world events that can and do have a devastating impact on efforts to reduce the global supply of drugs,'' the report said.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: Despite a directive issued by President Reagan in 1986 that made drug trafficking a national security issue, the new report concluded that ''political and economic instability in drug-producing areas around the world have resulted in the subordination of our drug control agenda to other pressing concerns.'' Limits on U.S. Action
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: Civil strife in Burma, war in Afghanistan, the death of President Mohammed Zia ul-Haq in Pakistan and the declining economy in Peru were cited as examples of events that signaled possible setbacks for the United States in its war on drugs.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: Administration officials acknowledged that the drug issue has often been subordinated to other American interests, from support for insurgents fighting Communist regimes to the belief that punishing drug-producing countries like Colombia and Peru might destabilize them.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: Most discouraging, it said, was the failure to curb the production of coca in the Andean countries, where a new generation of traffickers has emerged that threaten both the streets of America and the stability of countries long friendly to the United States. Also cited as disappointing was the inability of the United States to convince the Andean Governments to agree to aerial spraying of coca, which the report said is the only way to significantly curb cocaine production.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: ''We will have only limited success in battling cocaine until we forge a comprehensive, multifaceted strategy which recognizes that cocaine is not simply a law enforcement issue but is also a complex foreign policy matter, requiring a long-term approach,'' the report said.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: It added that the United States needs to explore ways of using third world debt as a lever in gaining cooperation on drug control.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: The report estimated that from 1987 to 1988, the production of coca increased 7.2 percent among the four coca-growing countries: Bolivia, Colombia, Peru and Ecuador. Over the same period, the global marijuana crop increased by 22 percent, the opium crop by 15 percent and the hashish crop by 11 percent.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: Despite the pessimistic tone of the report, the accompanying actions by the Bush Administration were rather mild, as they were during the last years of the Reagan Administration.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: Under a law passed in 1986, it is up to the President to certify by March 1 that countries where major drug trafficking occurs are ''fully cooperating'' in cracking down on the drug trade.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: There is a growing sentiment in Congress and the State Department that the law is flawed and applied selectively because it does not take into account the complexities of relations between drug-trafficking countries and the United States. Half-Steps Used
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: Although empowered to impose sanctions against drug-producing countries that do not qualify, President Bush announced mostly symbolic penalties against six countries with which the United States has no relations or severely strained relations: Panama, Afghanistan, Iran, Syria, Laos and Burma.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: Mexico, Colombia, Bolivia, Peru, the Bahamas and Paraguay, all major drug-producing or drug-transit countries - which were described by Ann B. Wrobleski, Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters, as ''close friends and allies'' -were also cited as needing to ''do more'' to cooperate with the United States. But they were fully certified under the law and will not be penalized.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: Lebanon was again faulted for not doing enough to combat the drug trade, but was certified because of overriding ''national interests.''
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: A preliminary decision to certify Laos and Burma because of national interests, reported today by The New York Times, was altered to decertify them completely, White House officials said. Troubled by the Futility
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, transmitting the President's certification to Congress, was quoted by Ms. Wrobleski as saying that he and Mr. Bush ''are deeply troubled by the state of affairs upon which the President based his certification decisions.''
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: ''Despite the hard work and dedication of many public servants and private citizens both here and abroad, the international war on narcotics is clearly not being won,'' he said.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: The report in effect has become an annual admission of the inability of the United States to singlehandedly fight narcotics. This year's report details increases in arrests, record drug seizures and eradicated acreage, new international treaties of cooperation, cooperative raids and the successful extradition of a small number of drug traffickers, while acknowleding an increase in both global drug production and demand.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: The report said that continuing turmoil in Afghanistan, where the production of opium poppy and heroin trafficking increased in 1988, could lead to an even bigger increase this year if refugees returning home after the nine-year Soviet occupation turn to opium as a cash crop. Rebel Agriculture
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: Much of the opium poppy grows in areas controlled by the United States-supported Afghan guerrillas or on territory where they have influence, according to the report.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: The collapse of order in various parts of the country after the Soviet troop withdrawal, favorable weather and the destruction of some traditional agriculture all make the cultivation of opium extremely attractive.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: ''As we see refugees moving back into a war-torn country where there is no central government, we see them turning to a fairly easy, quick, profitable means of supporting themselves,'' Ms. Wrobleski said. Perhaps the most dramatic shift in this year's report concerns Mexico, which was criticized last year for ''endemic'' corruption in the highest levels of government. Although this year's report expressed concern over continued government corruption, it emphasized a commitment by the newly elected President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, to intensify anti-drug efforts.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: As for the Bahamas, which has emerged as a major transit area for much of the cocaine and some of the marijuana entering the United States, the report says ''drug-related corruption continues to be a problem, making the country attractive to drug smugglers.'' It also faults the Bahamas for stalling extradition requests in the courts. Debate Expected
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: Congress, which has 45 days to rule on the Administration's decision on certification, is likely to challenge Mr. Bush's conclusions on Mexico and the Bahamas.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: These were among the report's other conclusions:
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: * The demand for drugs outside the United States, particularly in countries involved in production and transportation like Pakistan and parts of South America, has contributed to increased production. In Pakistan, for example, there are now between 670,000 and one million addicts, who consume more opium than the country produces.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: * In Panama, even though the United States no longer recognizes the leadership of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, American law enforcement officials continue to work with the Panamanian military in fighting drugs.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: * Officals in Laos are involved in opium and marijuana production, refining and smuggling. Although Laos won certification on grounds of American national interest last year because of its cooperation in helping to recover American remains from the Indochina war, corruption in the small Southeast Asian nation is so severe that it was decertified this year.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: * In Colombia, drug kingpins have so thoroughly corrupted the criminal justice system by threats and bribes that is it is ''virtually impossible'' to arrest and convict them or to significantly damage their organizations.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: The report was printed in a small quantity and will not be available to the public.
title: DRUG PRODUCTION RISING WORLDWIDE, STATE DEPT. SAYS

text: Global production of several drugs, like coca, marijuana, opium and hashish, increased in the past year, partly because of political and economic instability in drug-producing countries. Page A1

text: Acknowledged use of crack by high school seniors fell in 1988 for the first time, part of an overall downturn in drug use by young people in the United States, a national study reported today.
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: The annual survey, conducted for the Federal Government by the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research, attributed the decline in drug abuse to new attitudes about the dangers of drugs.
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: While use of other drugs had begun to level off in recent years, the survey of more than 16,000 students in 135 high schools nationwide showed that for the first time the number who said they had used crack at least once fell from 6 percent in 1987 to 5 percent in 1988. The number who said they had used crack in 1988 was 3 percent, down from 4 percent the year before.
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: In those same years, the proportion of seniors who said they believed experimentation with crack, a potent, smokeable derivative of cocaine, involved great risk rose from 57 percent to 62 percent.
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: For a sample of students the size of this survey's, the margin of sampling error is less than plus or minus one percentage point. Cocaine Use Continues Slide
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: Last year's survey found a decline in the use of ordinary cocaine, and the report today showed that trend continuing. The number who reported using cocaine other than crack at least once in their life declined from 14 percent in 1987 to 12 percent in 1988. The segment who said they had used cocaine during 1988 was 7 percent, down from 10 percent in 1987.
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: ''We can safely say that this decrease suggests that high school seniors, a very important population to the future of our country, are hearing the messages about cocaine's dangers and avoiding drug use in general,'' said Charles R. Schuster, director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse, which commissioned the survey. ''While crack cocaine is available, seniors appear to be concerned about its addictive qualities and toxicity and are less likely to try it.''
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: Lloyd D. Johnston, of the University of Michigan, the project's principal investigator, said the findings have important implications for the nation's drive to curb drug use. Efforts to reduce demand, he suggested, may be more effective than trying to cut supply.
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: President Bush has said that largely because of budget restrictions, he wanted to do more to diminish demand than to reduce supplies. Senate confirmation hearings open Wednesday on William J. Bennett, the president's choice to lead the drug war. More Than Half Have Tried Drugs
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: Despite the encouraging findings, the report warned that drug use is still rampant in high schools, with 39 percent of the students saying they used some illicit drug in 1988, and 54 percent saying they had tried such drugs at least once in their lifetime. The 39 percent is a decline from 42 percent in 1987, and 54 percent in 1979, the peak year.
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: As part of the study, about 1,200 college students who had taken the survey when they were in high school were also surveyed. The researchers found a similar pattern in declining drug use among those older students.
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: Titled ''Monitoring the Future: A Continuing Study of the Lifestyles and Values of Youth,'' this 14th annual survey has been one of the nation's major sources of data on drug abuse. Although it was administered confidentially by University of Michigan researchers, there is no way to judge whether the respondents were fully candid.
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: The study does not taken into account high school dropouts, who make up an estimated 15 percent of the target age group. ''We really can't say with much certainty whether a similar decline in crack use is occurring among the high school dropout segment of the population,'' Mr. Johnston said, noting that crack use is widespread among that population, particularly in inner cities. Marijuana Use Still Falling
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: The study did not include drug use trends in specific cities or among specific racial groups. Mr. Johnston said he was still completing a fuller report that might include such data.
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: Among other findings about high school seniors were these:
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: * Marijuana use continued its long-term decline, falling from 11 percent in 1978 to 3 percent in 1988.
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: * The use of hallucinogens, stimulants, tranquilizers, opiates other than heroin and nitrite inhalants all declined by statistically significant amounts last year. The number of seniors who say they have tried heroin at least once in their life remained at less than 1 percent percent after a decine a decade ago.
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: * Alcohol is clearly the most widely consumed of intoxicating substances. But for the first time in several years, the proportion of students who say they had one or more alcoholic drinks in the previous 30 days fell significantly, from 66 percent to 64 percent.
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: * One area in which there was no decline was in cigarette smoking. The segment of seniors who said they were current smokers was 29 percent last year and 18 percent said they smoked daily. These figures have remained fairly stable since 1984.
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: The survey also found use of all drugs was generally higher among boys, although girls reported slightly higher use of stimulants and tranquilizers. Regional trends were also evident, with crack and cocaine most popular in the West.
title: Student Survey Detects Decline In Use of Crack

text: A State Department report on drug trafficking has praised the three-month-old Government of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico for substantially increasing its anti-narcotics efforts, senior Administration officials said today.
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: Last year's report said there was widespread evidence that Mexican officials have been involved in drug-related corruption.
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: But in the new report, a wide-ranging annual study by the State Department that will be submitted to Congress on Wednesday, the State Department has noted Mexico's recent cooperation with the United States in combatting drug trafficking and has recommended to President Bush that Mexico should not be penalized under an American law, the officials said.
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: The new report, by the State Department's Bureau of International Narcotics Matters, has also recommended that no sanctions be imposed against the Bahamas, where drug-enforcement officials say there is growing evidence of official drug-related corruption.
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: No recommendations for censure of Haiti and Honduras are in the report because of disagreement within the Administation on whether to define them as major drug-trafficking countries.
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: The State Department has previously called both nations important transit points for drugs. Key lawmakers have said they have evidence of links between drug traffickers and political, governmental or military forces in Haiti and Honduras. Senate Opposition on Mexico
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: Under a law passed in 1986, it is up to the President to certify by March 1 that countries where major drug trafficking occurs are ''fully cooperating'' in cracking down on the drug trade. Countries that do not qualify lose American military and economic aid, trade preferences, loans and several other economic advantages.
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: In its report for 1987, the State Department called corruption in many branches of the Mexican Government ''endemic'' and the single most important factor that undermines meaningful narcotics cooperation.
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: After that report, the Senate voted, 63 to 27, to ''decertify'' Mexico, labeled in the report as the largest exporter of marijuana and heroin to the United States, for its lack of cooperation. But the move was killed in the House, which agreed with the Reagan Administration's opinion that such penalties damage larger interests between the two countries.
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: The Administration should expect the same opposition in the Senate this year, said a number of lawmakers and their staffs. Pact on Drug Trafficking
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: ''There will be a fight on Mexico,'' said one key aide to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ''We are deeply concerned about continued reports of corruption and the appointment of senior law-enforcement officials with alleged ties to drug trafficking.''
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: But other lawmakers said they may not challenge Mr. Bush's recommendation on Mexico, although they question conclusions about other countries.
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: ''I remain troubled by the Bahamas and the question of transit countries like Honduras and Haiti based on information that military personnel in those countries are involved in narcotics trafficking,'' said Senator John F. Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who has taken the lead in investigating drug-related corruption in Latin America. ''But in the case of Mexico, the new President most likely deserves the benefit of the doubt.''
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: The State Department report notes that Mexico and the United States signed an agreement on cooperation on drug trafficking last week, and details an increase in drug seizures and arrests. Laos and Lebanon Faulted
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: But some Bush Administration officials, lawmakers and current and former law-enforcement officials say they remain concerned about the appointment of people suspected of past or present links to drug traffickers to senior posts in Mexico's new Government.
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: The State Department report also recommends the decertification of Iran, Afghanistan, Syria and Panama, the same four countries singled out for censure last year, according to senior Administration officials.
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: Burma, Laos and Lebanon were faulted for not doing enough to combat the drug trade, but were certified because of overriding ''national interests.'' Trafficking Surges in Brazil
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: Administration officials said the report gave unqualified approval of Paraguay, which last year was certified only because of ''national interests,'' in order to give the new Government of General Andres Rodriguez a chance to make good on its promises. General Rodriguez has denied he has any ties to drug trafficking and has pledged to adopt tougher laws as part of what he called a ''firm and intransigent war'' against drugs.
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: All other countries where major drug trafficking occurs have fully cooperated with drug-enforcement efforts, according to the officials.
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: Among those countries are Colombia, where drug barons have long been reported to have bought up huge tracts of land, sided with local farmers in their battle against leftist guerrillas and emerged as a powerful political force.
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: The report also approved Bolivia, where drug-enforcement officials say cocaine trafficking has surged for the second year after the conclusion in 1986 of an American military operation to help authorities shut down cocaine labs.
title: U.S. Study Praises Mexico's Drug Moves

text: Recent calls for developing a ''methadone clone'' for cocaine are altogether right. We have a public health emergency on our hands, and there is no prospect of an effective response without some pharmacological treatment.
title: Yes, We Do Need A 'Methadone Clone'

text: May I offer two comments in the context of the Anti-Drug Abuse Act, which passed in the closing hours of the 100th Congress? The basic thrust of the legislation was to get beyond the definition of drug abuse as a law enforcement problem. It is surely that. But it is also, and more importantly, a public health problem.
title: Yes, We Do Need A 'Methadone Clone'

text: Conceptually, we spoke of reducing ''supply on the one hand and demand on the other.'' Supply is the realm of law enforcement: smuggling, dealing. Demand is finding a way to reduce drug use. We put these ideas in the statute. There was to be a ''Director of National Drug Control Policy.'' The celebrated czar William J. Bennett has been confirmed in this post. He is to have two deputies: Deputy Director for Demand Reduction and a Deputy Director for Supply Reduction. Note that demand comes first.
title: Yes, We Do Need A 'Methadone Clone'

text: The central policy initiative embodied in the act calls for ''treatment on request.'' Specifically, Section 2011, entitled ''Purposes,'' calls on the Federal Government ''to increase, to the greatest extent possible, the availability and quality of treatment services so that treatment on request may be provided to all individuals to rid themselves of their substance abuse problems.'' [ My emphasis. ] This was and is a sweeping proposal. We understood this. And we had no illusion that large-scale treatment could be provided by existing therapies. A pharmacological block for cocaine will be indispensable. Until one appears, ''treatment on request'' must remain an aspiration rather than a program.
title: Yes, We Do Need A 'Methadone Clone'

text: I believe we also understood that a ''methadone clone'' for cocaine, while absolutely necessary, would not in itself be sufficient. Few cocaine addicts, it should be noted, use cocaine alone. For them, overcoming addiction means swearing off alcohol, heroin, PCP, marijuana. Drug addiction is a chronic relapsing disease.
title: Yes, We Do Need A 'Methadone Clone'

text: But crack is the most vicious form that the species - us, that is - seems ever to have encountered. It appeared in the Bahamas in 1983, in New York in 1985 and has since spread in a classic epidemiological pattern. From first use to debilitation takes only about six weeks. At that point victims are likely to look for treatment or at least to be prepared to try treatment if it's offered. A pharmacological block will be needed to mount any effort proportionate to the size of the afflicted population.
title: Yes, We Do Need A 'Methadone Clone'

text: And the size? No one knows, but responsible estimates put the number of crack users in New York City alone at as many as 600,000. The city has only 1.1 million inhabitants between the ages of 15 and 24. That much I offer as fact. What follows comes under the heading of conjecture. Important, as the saying goes, if true. It has to do with prestige in science.
title: Yes, We Do Need A 'Methadone Clone'

text: Treatment in the form of methadone maintenance was developed by Drs. Vincent P. Dole and Marie Nyswander in New York City in the early 1960's. The drug works by
title: Yes, We Do Need A 'Methadone Clone'

text: ''blocking'' the effect of heroin - a trade name, incidentally, of the Bayer aspirin folk. Tested on employees in Germany a century ago, it made them feel ''heroisch.''
title: Yes, We Do Need A 'Methadone Clone'

text: Once a patient is taking methadone, the various ''talking'' therapies have a chance. The medication works. Arguably, it broke the heroin epidemic of the 1960's. Were Dr. Dole and Dr. Nyswander thanked? Shall we say, sort of? The medical profession cared little about the disease, and correspondingly little about its treatment. Last year, Dr. Dole received a Lasker Award, his partner (and wife) having, in the meantime, died. That's about it.
title: Yes, We Do Need A 'Methadone Clone'

text: There is such a thing as prestige in science and it tends to allocate resources. The person who cracks the AIDS puzzle will get a Nobel Prize. We should make clear that we will be just as appreciative of those who discover a pharmacological block for cocaine. There is work in progress. And some clues. But no guarantee.
title: Yes, We Do Need A 'Methadone Clone'

text: In the meantime, Ronald Reagan's last budget cut the research funds available to the National Institute on Drug Abuse.
title: Yes, We Do Need A 'Methadone Clone'

text: A high school teacher at a Roman Catholic preparatory school in the Bronx was arrested with a companion for possession of heroin yesterday by officers from the New York City Police Department's special anti-drug unit, the police said.
title: Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase

text: The teacher, Lynn Schiowitz, 25 years old of 336 Central Avenue in Scarsdale, was arrested at 2:45 P.M. in an automobile driven by her companion, Eric Juers, 23. who was also held. The two arrested at the corner of Bruckner Boulevard and Hoe Avenue in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx.
title: Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase

text: Sgt. Peter Berry, a police spokesman, said Ms. Schiowitz, a ninth-grade mathematics teacher at Mount St. Michael Academy, was seen buying what appeared to be drugs at the intersection, which the police said is a known drug-selling location.
title: Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase

text: After the purchase, officers surrounded the car and arrested the couple, Sergeant Berry said. Arrests by Anti-Drug Unit
title: Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase

text: He added that 14 other people were arrested in the area yesterday by officers from the anti-drug unit, called the Tactical Narcotics Team.
title: Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase

text: Ms. Schiowitz had in her possession two glassine envelopes that appeared to contain heroin, while Mr. Juers, of 20 Lakeside Drive in Highland Hills, N.Y., had one glassine envelope that appeared to contain the drug, Sergeant Berry said.
title: Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase

text: They were charged with possession of a controlled substance and taken to the 42d precinct in the Bronx.
title: Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase

text: The police confiscated a car, a Ford Escort, belonging to Mr. Juers, Sergeant Berry said. Operations Began This Month
title: Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase

text: Ms. Schiowitz teaches at the all-boys high school in the Wakefield section, which borders the Mount Vernon city line. The police said she started teaching at the school in September 1988.
title: Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase

text: The 117-member narcotics team began operating in the Bronx this month.
title: Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase

text: Its goal is to disrupt and decrease drug trafficking by saturating a neighborhood with undercover officers who make dozens of arrests.
title: Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase

text: In the last few years, more than a dozen teachers, mostly from public schools, have been arrested in connection with illegal drugs, the police and Board of Education officials said.
title: Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase

text: But the drugs have usually been crack, a cocaine derivative, or marijuana.
title: Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase

text: In December, a fourth-grade teacher at a public school in the Mott Haven section was arrested after police officers saw him buy heroin and cocaine at Garrison and Bryant Streets, near where Ms. Schiowitz and Mr. Juers were arrested.
title: Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase

text: The issue of drug use by teachers and principals was highlighted when a principal at a Bronx elementary school, Matthew Barnwell, 55, was arrested in November after police saw him buy two vials of crack hear his Harlem apartment.
title: Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase

text: State mental health officials are investigating charges that adolescent patients at Kingsboro Psychiatric Center in Brooklyn used abandoned rooms on the aging 28-acre campus to have sex and to use drugs.
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: The allegations come less than a month after an investigation by the State Commissioner of Mental Health found that staff members at a New York State psychiatric center near Buffalo had had sex with young children and that children had been pressured by older children into having sex with each other.
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: The Commissioner's office called the practices at the West Seneca, N.Y., institution an ''anomaly'' limited to that institution.
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: Steve Osborne, a spokesman for the State Office of Mental Health which operates Kingsboro and other state mental health centers, said yesterday that the Kingsboro investigation shows ''close to 40'' incidents of heterosexual sex and drug use among some of the adolescent unit's 27 patients, who range in age from 12 to 17. Suspensions and Transfers
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: Thus far there are no reports that adults were involved, but some of the sexual activities were apparently known to the staff, Mr. Osborne said. He said two mental health therapy aides have been suspended with pay, the director of community services of children and youth has been reassigned to the Manhattan regional office, and a unit chief has been reassigned to a division treating adults.
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: ''Obviously, the supervision was not adequate if this was going on,'' Mr. Osborne said. ''The activity was going on for several months, especially in the summer.''
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: ''The sexual activity was consensual, but they're adolescents,'' he said. ''It was children having sex with children. We found condoms, we found drug paraphernalia -crack and marijuana, crack mostly.''
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: Investigators acted on an anonymous tip to the state child abuse hot line and the State Commission on Quality of Care for the Mentally Disabled.
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: An article in The New York Post yesterday that described the state investigation said the informant was a staff member.
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: Mr. Osborne said the state mental health department and Kingsboro officials began their investigation on Feb. 7 in the wake of the discovery in January that children between the ages of 5 and 12 had been involved in a ''sex club'' at the Western New York Children's Psychiatric Center in West Seneca. Children in the ''club'' had sex with adult staff members or were intimidated into performing sex acts with each other to become members, investigators said. Scandal Prompted Surveys
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: That inquiry, focusing on the period between March and September last year, revealed 19 incidents of sexual abuse, 15 involving 36 children and four involving three staff members. The management of the center was aware of the activity but took no steps to stop it, the chairman of the State Commission on Quality of Care said.
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: That scandal prompted Dr. Richard C. Surles, State Commissioner of Mental Health, to conduct two daylong surveys at three of the state's six children's psychiatric centers and at five of the seven children's units connected to adult psychiatric centers. ''Thus far, I've heard of no parallel to what was happening at Western New York,'' Dr. Surles said at the time. ''We believe it's an anomaly.''
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: The state investigators came to Kingsboro ''and none of these youngsters reported any of these incidents,'' Mr. Osborne said yesterday. ''Then we got them in and questioned them and one youngster said this and another youngster said that.''
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro
