text: Then, in January, an informant reported 11 incidents of drug use and sexual activity in Building 10 on the 28-acre Kingsboro campus in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, a spokesman for the State Commission on Quality of Care for the Mentally Disabled, Gary Masline, said yesterday. Locks Were Picked
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: Investigators soon discovered more incidents, he said.
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: ''There were a couple of the original 11 incidents that were known to staff, apparently,'' Mr. Osborne said. ''I believe they were sexual incidents. That's being gone over now.''
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: The children at Kingsboro eat on the first floor of Building 10, which also has a medical unit and a legal services department. The upper floors of the 17-story building, full of old beds and dormitory furniture, were supposed to be locked. Mr. Osborne said the locks were picked.
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: Kingsboro last made headlines last August when a state of emergency was declared after crowding reached what state officials called ''crisis proportions.'' Patients slept in hallways and in four-hour shifts to accommodate the overflow. In October of 1987, a dozen employees were arrested on charges of selling drugs and abusing patients.
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: ''This hospital is very old, this plant is very old and the staff is working in miserable conditions,'' Mr. Osborne said. ''They're working very hard and this last incident sort of shook the unit up.''
title: Drugs and Sex Investigated At Kingsboro

text: A woman who was given the option of losing 100 pounds to wipe out a fine on a marijuana conviction has failed to do so and must pay $500. Judge Michael Fisher told the woman, Tina Usinger, last year that she could reduce her fine by $5 for each pound she lost, but when she returned to court this week, she still weighed 265 pounds. Ms. Usinger's probation officer had recommended the option, saying that with a better self-image she would be less likely to turn to crime.
title: Weight Costs Woman $500

text: Louis Gossett Jr., the new, improved, sober and unresentful Louis Gossett Jr., was talking about freedom. The freedom that ticket-buying audiences have given him to play roles he calls colorblind, and the freedom he feels now from the drug and alcohol addiction that beseiged him after his Oscar-winning performance in ''An Officer and a Gentleman.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: He was drinking herb tea and killing time in his trailer, parked on Manhattan's East 23d Street, waiting to finish the autopsy-room scene in an episode of ''Gideon Oliver,'' the new series of two-hour television movies in which he stars. The show makes its debut tomorrow night at 9 on ABC.
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: Mr. Gossett was musing that his recognition as an actor ''has now transcended color.'' Although he is the first black male lead in an original network dramatic series since James Earl Jones starred a decade ago in the short-lived ''Paris,'' Mr. Gossett believes that his role as Gideon Oliver, a crime-solving Ivy League professor of anthropology, ''has nothing to do with black or white,'' he said. ''I am so grateful that the public has given me this gift. They look at me as a person - not as a race, or a color. The word for it is freedom, to be accepted as - me.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: At 6 foot 4 and 220 pounds, Mr. Gossett is the sturdy third support of the tripod that is ABC's new Monday Mystery Movie, which is rotating Mr. Gossett with Peter Falk in a season of new ''Columbo'' episodes as well as Burt Reynolds in his detective series, ''B. L. Stryker.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: After more than 20 movies and hundreds of roles on television and in the theater, the 52-year-old Mr. Gossett won his position in the Mystery Movie starting lineup thanks to the string of critical and box-office successes that began with his 1982 Academy Award-winning performance as Sgt. Emil Foley, the chew-'em-out-while-you-build-'em-up drill instructor in ''An Officer and a Gentleman.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: Since then, he has had major roles in the smash hit ''Iron Eagle'' and its inevitable sequel, ''Iron Eagle II''; ''Enemy Mine,'' in which he played the alien-being buddy to Dennis Quaid; ''The Principal,'' with Jim Belushi, and in the mini-series ''Sadat,'' in which he played the slain Egyptian leader.
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: Recently he appeared in three much-promoted television movies, ''A Gathering of Old Men,'' ''The Father Clements Story'' and ''Roots: The Gift,'' wherein the actor reprised the role of Fiddler, which had won him an Emmy and made him something of a cultural icon when the original ''Roots'' mini-series was telecast in 1977.
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: The same year that Mr. Jones played a detective captain in ''Paris'' - 1979 - Mr. Gossett also starred in his own series, ''The Lazarus Syndrome,'' the ABC show in which he played the chief of staff at a hospital. Mr. Gossett said that, since then, he could think of only one other black male starring in a dramatic series without being teamed with a white co-star: Avery Brooks of ABC's new ''A Man Called Hawk,'' in a part that is only a spinoff from a role as sidekick to the actor Robert Urich in the canceled ''Spenser: For Hire.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: As for ''Gideon Oliver,'' ''there were practical, monetary, commercial reasons for casting me - none of them having to do with whether I'm black,'' Mr. Gossett said with some satisfaction.
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: ''We know that 'Columbo' and Burt have a built-in audience, and we feel that Lou does too,'' agreed Dick Wolf, co-executive producer of ''Gideon Oliver,'' which is based on a series of mystery novels by Aaron A. Elkins. In the books, the protagonist is a white anthropologist, as is the author.
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: ''In this case it was an established star creating a role tailored to him,'' said Mr. Wolf. ''It was, 'Here is this guy who can carry the series, and we want him.' With the enormous commitment of money, you have to have an actor who's a sure shot. If you're going to roll the dice, this is as safe a roll as you can get.'' The network is gambling more than $3 million on each two-hour show, for a total of more than $50 million for this season's 18 episodes of ABC's Mystery Movie.
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: Mr. Gossett believes that ''there's been a new ballgame when it comes to blacks on television,'' he said, citing Bill Cosby as the person who forever proved to entertainment executives and advertisers that race did not have to be a factor when they bet the house in Mustique on a bankable star. Mr. Gossett hopes that the brainy, swashbuckling Gideon Oliver ''will help children to know that they have a role model - not just for black kids but for all kids,'' he said.
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: However, Mr. Gossett also believes that at the sub-star level, minority actors in Hollywood face the discrimination that he confronted for most of his career. ''If I were to put myself in the body of the rank-and-file black actor, then the situation in the industry isn't looking so good,'' Mr. Gossett said of both television and feature films. ''For the average black actor, the situation isn't that different than the way it used to be.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: The way it used to be: Mr. Gossett, ordinarily a man of irrepressible wit on a movie location, loses his smile when he begins to talk about what he termed ''Hollywood's stereotypes about blacks.'' During nearly four decades as an actor, he has collected some of the more outrageous statements that white directors have made to him, including, he said, ''Things like, 'Try to act black, would you?' and 'You're not black enough' and 'Use those black phrases' and 'Use that walk.' Or they'd say to me, 'But that's not hip enough.' ''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: Hollywood ''still has such a limited vision of what blacks are,'' he added. ''The hip-talkin'-fool parts, the cop-movie parts, the black-exploitation-movie roles, the con-man types, all the black stereotype characters, the parts for blacks in white hats and dark glasses and chains around their necks.
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: ''There were times I wanted to quit altogether,'' he said of his years as a Hollywood character player. ''Our employment was basically fulfilling Hollywood's stereotypes about blacks, and the whole mocking mentality of the crews - well, I wanted to leave the business.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: Eventually, he decided ''that I'd keep trying to find some dignity in those parts,'' he said. ''But I carried a hot ball in my stomach for a lot of years.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: The trailer door cracked open, the temperature in the room plummeted, a production assistant yelled, ''The picture is up,'' and in a moment Mr. Gossett was bounding cheerfully into the freezing winds of East 23d Street. All morning, blasts of Arctic air had iced all hopes of shooting exterior scenes that the director, Alan Metzer, had planned. And so, Mr. Gossett headed through the doors of the Veterans Administration Medical Center on First Avenue and was soon hitting his mark on the tile floor of a steambath-like autopsy room, impervious to the rush of disinfectant that set some crew members' eyes to tearing.
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: It was a scene where Gideon Oliver accompanies his star anthropology student to the city morgue, and Mr. Gossett stood before a wall of refrigerated body trays as the cameras began rolling. An actor playing a detective turned back the white sheet covering a body, revealing the grisly sight of the student's murdered brother.
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: ''Did you have to show him that?'' Mr. Gossett said his lines, scowling at the detective, who shot right back:
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: ''Think of it as a lesson you couldn't teach him.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: When the scene was over, Mr. Gossett talked quietly about the most painful lesson that he, not unlike the anthropology student, had learned for himself: how to survive his triumph in ''An Officer and a Gentleman,'' which led not just to the Oscar but also to the worst depression of his life.
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: ''After the Academy Award - well, I was left with a lot of time on my hands,'' he said. ''I thought I'd get a lot of offers - and they didn't come.'' It was as if he'd broken through the level of stereotypical parts to a new level where Hollywood had nothing to offer him, he said. ''I expected a lot more to happen - I mean, the first black since Sidney Poitier to win an Oscar.
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: ''Well, nothing happened. I let myself become bitter, resentful. I was my own worst enemy. I said to myself, 'What more can I do? Where's the light at the end of the tunnel?' I started to self-destruct.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: The pace of his unravelling was matched by his increasing use of drugs and alcohol, he said: ''All my life I'd been healthy, straight, responsible. And I'd never got high when I was working.'' But that hot ball in his stomach that he'd carried for so long ''became a hole in the soul,'' he said, adding that he used ''cocaine, marijuana, alcohol. I had an Oscar, an Emmy, and yet I had this big hole in my soul. I was in a pit of self-pity and resentment.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: Ultimately, he entered a residential drug-treatment program in Los Angeles, he said, in an acknowledgement of his addiction that was ''very humbling and necessary, a very positive time. I reassessed my life. And I stopped drugs.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: In the program, Mr. Gossett learned for the first time that children of alcoholics are especially vulnerable to addiction, ''and I realized it's part of my family history. My uncles - all of them associated joy with alcohol, when they let their hair down on Friday night. My dad died of it,'' he said of alcoholism. ''And my other heroes in the business, they got drunk and got high.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: ''To keep my disease in remission,'' Mr. Gossett said, he has been going to Alcoholics Anonymous meetings ''all over the world, in lots of different languages.'' In the process, he rediscovered the spirituality that he set aside after the years of his Baptist upbringing, and he credits his faith as the only thing that ''can take away resentment,'' he said. ''Now, I know I have the innate spirit to survive and be happy. I know now I could make it, even if I had to get back to driving a taxicab.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: These days, Mr. Gossett tries to reject resentment in favor of gratitude: He is especially thankful for his Brooklyn childhood, which ''expanded my horizons.'' He was raised in Bath Beach, ''and I attribute my childhood in Coney Island to being here now,'' he said. ''Average black children in the city, they had no peripheral vision, and being a blue-collar guy was the most you could aspire to. Where I lived, it was a ghetto, I guess, but we always had jobs, we coexisted with the Italians in the neighborhood, and we had a bunch of great teachers who nurtured us.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: At Mark Twain Junior High School, Mr. Gossett was the student body president, and in Abraham Lincoln High School he was senior-class president. ''You know, we are born with freedom and hope, but often that's dashed because of our color,'' he said. ''But in school I'd already been taught that no one could tell me that you can't do something because you're black.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: Mr. Gossett's high-school English teacher, Gustave Blum, had been a director on Broadway; he told his student about an open casting call for the 1953 production of ''Take a Giant Step,'' and ''he said to me, 'What have you got to lose?' So, my mom brought me to the Lyceum Theater,'' Mr. Gossett said. He beat out 445 others for the part, and came to Broadway at the age of 17.
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: Subsequently, he created the role of George Murchison in the original 1959 production of Lorraine Hansberry's ''Raisin in the Sun,'' and then acted in the 1961 movie version. He became an Actors Studio regular, and on the New York stage, his credits included ''Desk Set,'' ''Telemachus Clay,'' ''My Sweet Charlie,'' ''The Blacks'' and ''The Blood Knot.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: His career led to Hollywood and to performances in dozens of movies and TV shows, including starring roles not only in ''The Lazarus Syndrome'' but also ''The Powers of Matthew Star'' (NBC). Although he had vowed that he would ''never go back to a series because of the burnout rate,'' Mr. Gossett said he took the Mystery Movie title role because ''Gideon Oliver is able, intelligent, highly respected, dashing, facile, funny. He uses his brain, he's a professor, but he's also a man of action. I mean, who wouldn't want to play this guy?''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: In the future, Mr. Gossett hopes to make some feature films with his third wife, Cyndi James-Reece, the actress who plays an undercover detective in the NBC soap opera ''Days of Our Lives.''
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: Like Bill Cosby, Mr. Gossett believes that one effective way to increase the number of nonstereotypical acting roles for blacks is to produce his own movies. His production company, LoGo Entertainment, has the rights to Cab Calloway's biography, and Mr. Gossett is after Lionel Ritchie to play the part, ''not played as a Hollywood stereotype,'' he laughed.
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: Suddenly, a production assistant was calling Mr. Gossett to the set again, and since he'd just used the words ''Hollywood stereotype,'' he paused to do his own parody of just that: He braced the lapels of his double-breasted suit and assumed an exaggerated street-dude strut. ''Hey, wass up!'' Mr. Gossett said in his most resonant uptown voice.
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: Whooping with laughter, he continued: ''Look's like I'm about to be steppin' out!'' And so he did - right back out to the set, and into the role of Gideon Oliver.
title: Lou Gossett Jr. Battles the Hollywood Stereotype

text: A long, graying ponytail and a fondness for marijuana are all that remain of Eddie Dodd's 1960's idealism - these, and a reflexive tendency to stick up for the underdog, no matter how disreputable the underdog might be. So Eddie, who once had the reputation of a brilliant and courageous lawyer and is still thought of as a very clever one, makes it his business to defend the constitutional rights of drug dealers - drug dealers who are apt to drive away from the courthouse in their sports cars, smiling. Some part of Eddie knows this is wrong. But another part is trapped in a time warp, and can't get free.
title: Review/Film; 60's Ideals Gone Awry, In Taut 'True Believer'

text: ''True Believer,'' which opens today at the Beekman and other theaters, is about the case that shakes Eddie out of his doldrums and brings him back to the top of his form. It is also about the transformation of James Woods, who plays Eddie, from the kind of psycho-killer he formerly portrayed into a fierce and formidable leading man. What it isn't really about, once it gets past preliminaries, is the legacy of radicalism that has supposedly shaped Eddie and set him in such stark contrast to the values of the 1980's. Eddie's past is only one of the many and effective hooks ''True Believer'' uses to grab hold of the audience's attention and never let go.
title: Review/Film; 60's Ideals Gone Awry, In Taut 'True Believer'

text: ''True Believer'' has made a powerful impression even before the opening credits are over. It starts out with a Chinatown gang murder filmed in slow, dreamy black-and-white, then cuts to a prison where the man convicted of this crime wakes out of one nightmare and finds himself, eight years later, in the midst of another. This breathlessly paced opening shows that Shu Kai Kim (Yuji Okumoto) has now become part of a prison gang, and it involves him in a second murder before the audience has got over the impact of the first. To defend her son, Kim's mother then hires Eddie Dodd, whose credo is ''I'm willing to defend the cases other lawyers don't want.''
title: Review/Film; 60's Ideals Gone Awry, In Taut 'True Believer'

text: The film's director, Joseph Ruben, and its screenwriter, Wesley Strick, have a particularly good time establishing Eddie Dodd's bedside manner. Though ''True Believer'' never offers much evidence of Eddie's courtroom brilliance, it does let him show plenty of bravado. The character of Eddie, though narrow and even incomplete, is nonetheless a wonderful invention, poised halfway between his own instinctive defiance and a desperate urge to make good. He's the kind of lawyer who can say ''Sorry, no comment'' to a reporter as they get into an elevator, then emerge seconds later talking conspiracy theories and chattering a blue streak. An imposing district attorney can fill Eddie with contempt yet also make him a nervous wreck.
title: Review/Film; 60's Ideals Gone Awry, In Taut 'True Believer'

text: The Chinatown case into which Eddie throws himself follows a convoluted route, and it unfolds to reveal an elaborate cover-up scheme; among its more piquant particulars are a case of mistaken identity involving baldness and the question of whether the telephone company played a role in the John F. Kennedy assassination. (''What you say in the mouthpiece is never what comes out the other end,'' confides the character who believes most fervently in the phone company's diabolical side.) If the film never makes these details terribly plausible, neither does it fling them about so recklessly as to insult the audience's intelligence. The mystery plot is, on its own terms, tightly knit and free of gratuitous touches. In fact, much of the screenplay's humor grows out of the very far-fetchedness of its story. Mr. Ruben shapes a particularly winning episode out of the trial scene in which the phone-company theory comes to light.
title: Review/Film; 60's Ideals Gone Awry, In Taut 'True Believer'

text: Mr. Ruben, who also directed ''The Stepfather'' and ''Dreamscape,'' has a lot more to work with this time. He has a better supporting cast (featuring Robert Downey Jr. as Eddie's clean-cut young protege, and Margaret Colin as the spunky private investigator whose flirty banter with Eddie gives the film a 1940's aspect, too). And he has more durable material, a story that doesn't wear thin once its premise has been established. He also has a more mobile and exciting camera style this time, and his direction remains lively and surprising to the end; touches like the half-hallucinatory crime re-enactment that ends in a real gunshot are sure to keep viewers on their toes. But most of all, what Mr. Ruben has here to make ''True Believer'' thoroughly gripping is Mr. Woods.
title: Review/Film; 60's Ideals Gone Awry, In Taut 'True Believer'

text: There was a point in his career when Mr. Woods seemed destined to be strictly a character actor, and the seedier the character, the better. With ''True Believer,'' it's clear that those days are gone. The film's view of Eddie Dodd is occasionally on the facile side, but Mr. Woods's performance is crackling and passionate enough to give the character depth despite that; it's also laced with snappish, self-mocking humor that Mr. Woods delivers particularly well. This performance is so razor-sharp that Eddie can be seen coming alive with each little triumph, reveling in each little maneuver and taking each little disappointment terribly hard. His enthusiasm is irresistible. Shyster With Ideals TRUE BELIEVER, directed by Joseph Ruben; written by Wesley Strick; director of photography, John W. Lindley; edited by George Bowers; music by Brad Fiedel; production designer, Lawrence Miller; produced by Walter F. Parkes and Lawrence Lasker; released by Columbia Pictures. At the Beekman, 65th Street and Second Avenue, and other theaters. Running time: 104 minutes. This film is rated R. Eddie Dodd ... James Woods Roger Baron ... Robert Downey Jr. Kitty Greer ... Margaret Colin Shu Kai Kim ... Yuji Okumoto Robert Reynard ... Kurtwood Smith Cecil Skell ... Tom Bower Art Esparza ... Miguel Fernandes
title: Review/Film; 60's Ideals Gone Awry, In Taut 'True Believer'

text: Even moderate drinking by women in the first month or two of pregnancy, often before they realize they are pregnant, can impair the child's intellectual ability upon reaching school age, a new study indicates.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: The researchers found significant effects for women who consume a daily average of one to three drinks each containing half an ounce of pure alcohol. That is equivalent to one to three daily cocktails, bottles of beer or glasses of wine.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: The scientists interviewed 491 Seattle women in the fifth month of pregnancy and followed up with assessments of their children, measuring intelligence, reaction time and attentiveness.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: The study took into account factors such as parents' incomes and educations, which are known to affect a child's intelligence, and found that drinking had an effect apart from these influences. The impairment was noticed even when the pregnant woman cut back her drinking in the first or second month of pregnancy. Lower I.Q. Scores
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: The most recently published finding from the research involved 53 mothers who had on average three drinks or more a day in the first month or so of pregnancy. Their children were found at age 4 to score substantially lower on intelligence tests than other children. Specifically, the average score on I.Q. tests for these children was 105, 5 points below the average for all children in the study.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: In a separate report, based on the same study of 491 Seattle women, the researchers found that children born to mothers who had as little as one to two drinks a day in the first months of pregnancy had slower reaction times and difficulty paying attention by their early school years.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: While previous studies have indicated that very heavy drinking by a pregnant woman can cause retardation in her children, the Seattle research is the first to show serious effects to the intellectual capacities of children at school age whose mothers drank at moderate levels while pregnant. It is also the first to distinguish the effects of alcohol from that of other factors such as smoking or caffeine use.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: ''We recommend that women who are trying to become pregnant or might become so do not drink alcohol at all,'' said Dr. Ann Streissguth, a psychologist at the University of Washington School of Medicine, who directed the study. ''The effects on children occur even at the social drinking level. The women in our study did not see themselves as having alcohol problems.'' 'First Good Study'
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: Experts in the field see the two reports from the Seattle study as particularly significant.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: ''This is the first good study of the relationship between normal drinking levels in pregnant women and intellectual effects in their children,'' said Dr. Claire D. Coles, a psychologist at the Human Behavior Genetic Research Laboratory at the Emory University medical school in Atlanta. Dr. Coles is conducting similar research but was not involved in the Seattle study.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: The Seattle researchers asked the pregnant women about drinking, smoking and the use of marijuana, as well as the use of aspirin, caffeine and other substances. Their children have been assessed regularly since the initial interviews.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: The latest findings, which detected the differences on I.Q. tests, were reported in the February issue of Developmental Psychology. The findings on attention levels were published in 1987 in the journal Neurobehavioral Toxicology and Teratology. (Teratology is the study of substances that can harm the development of a fetus.) Individual Effects Not all children whose mothers drank had problems. The study found that while there is a strong relationship on average between drinking while pregnant and the child's intellectual development, there is no certainty that a given child will show negative effects.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: ''The effects vary greatly in individual cases,'' Dr. Streissguth said. ''There are many children who were exposed to alcohol who were not affected at all.''
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: But of all the substances thought to have ill effects on children, the studies indicated that alchohol had a more severe impact than tobacco, caffeine, aspirin or marijuana.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: ''The worst effects by far were from alcohol,'' said Helen Barr, one of the study's co-authors and a statistician in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Science at University of Washington. Question of Smoking
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: The findings call into question earlier studies that seemed to show impaired cognitive development in children born to mothers who smoked. The researchers said those studies failed to take into account the effects of the mother's drinking, which they said was a serious mistake since many mothers who smoked also drank.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: The report noted that some of the heaviest drinkers in the study, and thus the mothers of the children most at risk, were the most highly educated professionals.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: ''Many career women seem to assume the drinking habits of professional men - a few glasses of wine at dinner, some drinks over lunch or at a cocktail party,'' Dr. Streissguth said.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: Some of the least educated women in the study were also among the heaviest drinkers, the researchers said.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: Studies with animals have shown that alcohol crosses the placenta and can intefere with the normal development of an embryo's nervous system. Still, the effects detected in the study were relatively subtle in comparison with the effects of fetal alcohol syndrome, which occurs in some children of alcoholic mothers. In the study, 10 children had the syndrome, in which flawed physical growth accompanies mental impairment. On the intelligence tests, their scores averaged more than 15 points lower than the other children in the study, but their results were excluded from the sample used for comparison. Stopping at 4 Weeks
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: Average alcohol consumption for all women in the study was one drink a day until they knew they were pregnant, and half a drink a day afterward. Many of the mothers stopped drinking when they found out they were pregnant, but that was typically not until four to six weeks into the pregnancy, Dr. Barr said.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: The negative effects of alcohol on the children still prevailed when the women stopped or sharply reduced their level of drinking. ''The effects on neural development seem more profound the earlier in the pregnancy'' the mother drinks, Dr. Barr said.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: Although the five-point drop on intelligence test scores was found in children whose mothers drank three or more drinks per day during pregnancy, that does not indicate that any less is safe, Dr. Streissguth said.
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: ''Three drinks is an arbitrary cut-off, not some biological threshold,'' she said. ''There is no safe minimum level of drinking for a pregnant mother.''
title: Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks

text: Howard Armstrong, the 79-year-old violinist and mandolin player who stole the show on Sunday afternoon at the World Music Institute's blues festival at the Triplex, is in total control of his environment.
title: Reviews/Music; Violinist Plays the Blues

text: Mr. Armstong, who played with his longtime partner, the guitarist Ted Bogan, is a consummate performer, someone whose entire show indicated an understanding of subtle social nuances, of eccentricity and the power of humor and control. Together, the two played a series of jazz standards, including ''Oh, Lady Be Good'' and ''Summertime,'' and some original tunes. Mr. Armstrong sang a version of ''La Cucaracha,'' in Spanish, with references to marijuana smoking and requests for money to buy more beer. He sang an original song using Hawaiian names. He used an English accent to mock pretensions. He went into a long explanation about how where he came from (South America, Tennessee), people pronounced ''Baby'' as ''Baaaybee.'' And between tunes, he kept up a series of mock put-downs with Mr. Bogan.
title: Reviews/Music; Violinist Plays the Blues

text: The two men make a fine team, musically as well. With Mr. Bogan laying down a steady rhythm guitar accompaniment and Mr. Armstrong sweeping up the melodies and using them to his advantage, the group sounded a bit like the guitar-violin teams of early jazz.
title: Reviews/Music; Violinist Plays the Blues

text: The show was meant to illuminate the black string-band tradition, and it featured, along with Mr. Armstrong and Mr. Bogan, a trio from North Carolina: Joe and Odell Thompson on banjo and violin, and John Dee Holeman on guitar. They whipped through such country dance tunes as ''Old Joe Clark'' and ''Alabama Girl,'' turning them into exercises in sandpaper minimalism, full of repeating melodies and rhythms, all grittily played.
title: Reviews/Music; Violinist Plays the Blues

text: When Mr. Holeman performed some blues tunes by himself, the sound of Mississippi coursed through the auditorium. By the time he stood up and did some buck-dancing, which had the audience cheering loudly, the set had become an occasion.
title: Reviews/Music; Violinist Plays the Blues

text: Last week's election in Jamaica did credit to both the new Prime Minister, Michael Manley, and the man he defeated, Edward Seaga. In 1980, when the two men last fought it out, 750 people died in a brutal campaign that Mr. Seaga won. Three years later, farce replaced chaos: Mr. Manley boycotted the election over procedural issues and Mr. Seaga won all 60 parliamentary seats.
title: A Second Chance for Michael Manley

text: This time, the old rivals waged a tough but far less bloody campaign. Mr. Manley, who now commands a solid left-of-center majority, says he has moderated the doctrinaire socialism and confrontational style that marked his earlier term in office and antagonized the United States. He and his struggling country merit Washington's support.
title: A Second Chance for Michael Manley

text: Continued collaboration on drug traffic is especially important. Mr. Manley, like President Bush, wants to cut marijuana production, reverse rising domestic abuse of crack and end Jamaica's unfortunate role as a way station for Caribbean cocaine.
title: A Second Chance for Michael Manley

text: Mr. Seaga worked hard to stir a slumbering economy. He agreed to the harsh strategy prescribed by the International Monetary Fund, slashing deficits and devaluing the Jamaican dollar. Still, there was no surge in exports. Now it's Mr. Manley's turn to cope with a $4 billion foreign debt and to reassure the private sector while trying to deliver on campaign promises to help the poor.
title: A Second Chance for Michael Manley

text: The last decade has taught hard lessons about Jamaica's vulnerability to trade winds it cannot control. Tourism has displaced bauxite as the island's main industry, and a mellower Mr. Manley, now 63, no longer thunders against Washington and multinational corporations. As the anger of the 1970's gives way to desire for stability, Mr. Manley earns the right to a second chance.
title: A Second Chance for Michael Manley

text: Along with the economic rebirth that casinos have brought to this resort area, social and mental-health workers are finding growing personal problems that they link to the intense round-the-clock style of the gambling industry.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: Twelve casinos employ 40,000 people, and employment in surrounding Atlantic County has mushroomed, to 123,000 in 1987 from 74,000 in 1977. Prostitution and drug traffic have also soared, and violent crime increased 250 percent.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: Mental-health workers are convinced that the gambling industry leads to social problems among its employees, including alcohol and drug abuse, marital friction, depression and, even, eating disorders.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: ''It's a very specific industry that has certain hazards attached to it,'' said Donald H. Parker, director of the Atlantic Mental Health Center, where 40 to 50 percent of the cases involve casino employees and their families.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: ''I think it's like coal mining,'' Mr. Parker said. ''You're not going to close a coal mine down because it causes black lung disease. You're going to establish ways of handling those kinds of problems.'' 'Very Opulent Life Style'
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: Casinos, which operate under strict licensing laws, have been reluctant to acknowledge alcohol and drug abuse among their employees. A few have programs to assist employees with personal problems.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: Mr. Parker said no systematic study had been conducted on the effects of the casino environment, a study he and others maintain is sorely needed. Mr. Parker said his belief that the casino environment contributed to personal problems was based on experience and the nature of the industry.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: ''It produces a very opulent life style, a lot of discretionary cash, tremendous stress, crazy hours, nights and weekends,'' Mr. Parker said. ''You can't have a normal life style. It's very difficult to have a family.''
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: Husbands and wives who both work in the industry often have different shifts, weekend work is the norm, and many children of casino couples seldom see both parents at once, Mr. Parker noted.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: In the casinos, he said, ''you're in an environment that's completely closed out from the outside world.''
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: ''It's glitzy, it's flashy, it's noisy,'' he said. ''The constant buzzing of the slot machines, the flashing lights. What does that do to an individual?''
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: Joanne Drane, director of Contact Atlantic, a 24-hour telephone counseling and crisis-intervention service dealing with problems like child abuse and suicidal depressions, said the number of calls had dramatically increased in the decade since gambling began, from 12,545 in 1978 to 45,733 last year, far outpacing the county's population growth, which has increased from 190,000 in 1978 to 210,000 today.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: Ms. Drane said that some of the increase in calls might flow from greater awareness of problems and the availability of her service. But she added that she believed many calls related to casinos and fell into a pattern.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: ''We receive the largest number of casino-related calls not from casino gamblers, but from casino employees, calls that involve alcoholism, drug abuse, marital- and interpersonal-relationship problems, eating disorders,'' she said. ''There is a large number of eating disorders - the emphasis on thinness, the showgirls, the waitresses who have to wear the skimpy costumes.''
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: As does Mr. Parker, Ms. Drane links casino problems to the style of life, ''the odd hours, the association with people who are into, say, cocaine, where it is more accessible to them, and they have money.''
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: ''We have a lot of people,'' Mr. Parker said, ''who get out of high school, go to gambling school, learn how to deal cards, get involved in a casino and make $22,000 a year. In five years, they're making $30,000 to $40,000. They realize they don't want to do it anymore, but they only have a high school diploma and can't go anywhere.''
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: A casino employee told a counselor at Jewish Family Service of Atlantic County: ''I make a lot of money in the casino. I want you to teach me to hate it less.'' 'Not Happy About Their Work'
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: Steve Rosen, a counselor for the service who worked in a casino arranging high rollers' banquets, said, ''The money was incredible, but it was obscene.''
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: ''You're in an environment that's chock full of short-term pleasures,'' he added, ''and you buy into it. And I see people just get eaten up by it.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: ''They're not happy about their work. They tend to abuse substances which will relieve them of the responsibilities. But very few have the energy to develop positive habits because the work is so hard and the stress level is so high.''
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: Drug use is difficult to track in the industry because it endangers an employee's license. Patrolling the Lounges
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: Xavier Mercado, 37 years old, a former casino security guard who is now a child-guidance counselor, said, ''Alcohol, drugs and divorce, that's the effects of the casino life style.'' In seven years as a guard, he said, he became aware of heavy drug use among casino employees, ''marijuana and cocaine mostly.''
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: ''You would see it in the dealers' lounges,'' he said. ''We had a patrol at one time in the dealers' lounges for that.''
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: Michael Frank, an associate professor of psychology at Stockton State College in nearby Pomona and director of the Governor's Advisory Commission on Gambling, said casinos were very reticent to share data on employees' alcohol use and definitely drug use, largely because of the strict licensing.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: Mr. Frank said he worked as a dealer last summer and ''did, in fact, perceive a far greater incidence of alcohol and drug abuse'' than would be considered normal in other workplaces. Efforts by Casinos
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: The industry has been reluctant to acknowledge a problem. Edward McGuignan, executive director of the Consortium for Service to Industries, which was founded three years ago to counsel and refer employees, said casinos had been reluctant to contract for assistance.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: Some casinos, in part because employees are in increasingly short supply, are instituting programs to help those with problems.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: At the Sands casino hotel, employees volunteered 18 months ago to urge fellow workers with drug or other problems to make them known to management, to obtain help.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: ''They wanted to make it O.K. for somebody who was afraid, afraid to approach management,'' said Ellen Duffy, human-resources director at the casino, which has an in-house counseling and referral program. 'Nothing Was Being Done'
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: Caesars has an assistance program for its 4,000 employees. ''We're quite proud of it,'' said Roland H. Coleman, assistant vice president for administration, who started the program 18 months ago. When he began at Caesars five years ago, he said, ''I found that nothing was being done.''
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: The industry, he added, might feed frustrations. ''We provide fantasies for people,'' he said, but because of prohibitions, employees cannot participate.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: ''Who was going to provide them with a sense of well-being?'' Mr. Coleman asked. He said employees wondered, '' 'Where am I going to get my high from?'
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: ''Well they get it from other stimulants, rather than from the work place,'' Mr. Coleman said.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: He said that 164 employees had used the program, which, he added, is in its pilot stage, and that 140 were still employed. ''With the traditional way of doing things,'' he added, ''we would probably have fired 164 people.''
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: Caesars hired a consultant, Pamela Falk-Singer, a former casino worker who is a counselor and social worker.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: Of those counseled and usually referred to other agencies, 63 suffered from substance abuse with drugs and alcohol, almost always together, Ms. Falk-Singer said. Thirty-nine suffered marital and family problems, and one had psychological problems, including severe depression. Other workers sought help for medical, financial, legal and other day-to-day problems.
title: For Casino Employees, Pace Takes a Personal Toll

text: By David S. Wilson, Special To the New York Times
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: In Southern California, where aspiring screen writers are as thick as rush-hour traffic, some of the people spending time behind typewriters are also doing time behind bars.
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: And now that a cash prize has been established for inmates to be novelists and screen writers, more prisoners may soon be pounding out scripts across the country.
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: ''The big money isn't doing crime, it's writing about it,'' said Harry Houperman, a convicted marijuana dealer enrolled in a writing class at the Federal Correctional Institution on Terminal Island. The prison is south of Los Angeles, just a short trip away in prisoners' Hollywood dreams.
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: The volunteer instructor, Robert Dellinger, is a former Terminal Island inmate who went on to become a television writer and story editor on ''Starsky & Hutch'' and ''Serpico.'' His past students include G. Gordon Liddy of Watergate fame, the would-be Presidential assassins Sara Jane Moore and Lynette (Squeaky) Fromme and Dr. Timothy Leary, a figure from the drug culture.
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: Now, after 17 years as a teacher on Terminal Island, Mr. Dellinger is hoping to spread to other prisons his message of self-discovery and discipline through writing. Announcements will go out soon to adult and juvenile prisons across the country, inviting prisoners to enter the first Lotus Writing Awards competition to recognize screenplays, plays, novels and short stories by inmates.
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: Early next year, prizes of up to $500 will be awarded by the Lotus board of directors, which includes other inmates who have become professional writers, along with Hollywood producers and agents and the judge who sentenced Mr. Dellinger to prison.
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: The name for the awards was derived from the saying, ''Out of the swamp grows the lotus.'' The project, long in the planning, was delayed after another prison writer, Jack Henry Abbott, the literary protege of Norman Mailer, killed a man shortly after his release from a New York prison in 1981.
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: ''It was suddenly not fashionable to be a convict writer,'' Mr. Dellinger said. ''Things have softened a bit now.''
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: By encouraging inmates to write fiction, the Lotus committee hopes to avoid conflict with about 30 states that have followed New York's lead in enacting ''Son of Sam'' laws, which prohibit convicts from profiting from stories about their crimes.
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: ''If one guy in a thousand ever sells a script, we'll be lucky,'' said Bill Nuss, a writer and producer of ''21 Jump Street,'' a television show depicting police officers working under cover in a high school. On the other hand, said Mr. Nuss, one of the board members: ''Writing can help them get in touch with who they really are. And producers might listen to them. There are a lot of people who can write dialogue, but few who can tell good stories. And these guys have interesting stories.''
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: At a recent study session, the class included bank robbers, drug dealers, mob figures and a former policeman who turned to crime.
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: In front of the class, the inmates read and analyze their writing assignments, brief imaginary profiles of people, some of them real. Of Mike Tyson, the boxing champion, one inmate wrote, ''This hard and rugged body of a man can do more harm than good.''
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: Mr. Dellinger quickly puts at ease inmates who are nervous about sharing their work. Referring to the Watergate figure who boasted that he overcame his only fear, being scared of rats, by cooking and eating one, Mr. Dellinger said, ''The first time G. Gordon Liddy faced the class to read, his paper was shaking.''
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: Mr. Dellinger, a former advertising executive, began his writing career at the prison newspaper after he was convicted of extortion. He also sold stories to magazines and began teaching writing at the prison.
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: Days after his release, he returned to teach his regular class out of gratitude for finding a new career. ''Some of the guys thought I'd stolen my clothes,'' he said. ''And they all thought I was crazy for coming back.''
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: Mr. Dellinger, who says his work is his hobby, is currently writing a television movie, an episode for ''21 Jump Street,'' his autobiography and a play about his prison writing class.
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: ''It's a lot of fun, these are great guys,'' he says with a laugh. ''But, needless to say, I've never dared flunk anyone.''
title: Terminal Island Journal; Writing Contest Gives Inmates an Escape of Sorts

text: LEAD: ''I liked expressing the idea that there are second acts in American life,'' says 34-year-old Wesley Strick, who began his professional career as a music critic for Rolling Stone and has now written the script of ''True Believer,'' which opens on Friday.
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: ''I liked expressing the idea that there are second acts in American life,'' says 34-year-old Wesley Strick, who began his professional career as a music critic for Rolling Stone and has now written the script of ''True Believer,'' which opens on Friday.
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: ''When I wrote about rock, it was fun at first; I was straight out of college. People were interesting, in that kind of 'Spinal Tappy' way,'' he says, referring to the satirical film about heavy metal boorishness. ''Eventually, though, I got too corrosive, contemptuous, cutting. I got burned out. And I stopped.''
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: The burned-out feeling is very much there in ''True Believer,'' which portrays a cannabis-hazed defense lawyer, Eddie Dodd (played by James Woods), whose heyday was the 60's. Still sporting a ponytail (now grizzly), Dodd now defends drug dealers and counts mounds of cash in his back room. But a challenging murder trial, involving Chinatown warfare, a defendant who - for once - may be innocent and a rigid, authoritarian opponent revive the lawyer's not-so-anachronistic ideals.
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: In creating Eddie Dodd, says Mr. Strick (who worked with the film's producers, Walter Parkes and Larry Lasker), ''we applied Robert Towne's screenwriting dictum: You have to ask what is it that he fears most. And what we determined was that Eddie's most afraid that his vision of the world may be obsolete, or worse - that he doesn't really have a vision of the world anymore. That he's really a hack.''
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: These worries do not seem to trouble J. Tony Serra, the attorney on whom the film makers based the character of Eddie Dodd - very loosely, by his account: ''All the people I respect and love in this world are drug dealers, and I don't wear my hair in a ponytail!''
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: A few years ago, Mr. Serra was profiled on ''60 Minutes'' as one of the nation's top defense attorneys, known for his flamboyant courtroom style and remarkable acquittal rate.
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: Descriptions of his way of life border on the tall tale. ''He delivered all five of his children,'' says Mr. Strick. ''In a chicken shack.'' ''Their names are Ivory and Chime and Wonder,'' says Mr. Woods. (Actually, the boys' names are Shelter, Ivory and Chime Day; the girls are named Wonder Fortune and Lilac Bright). ''There's no phone in his house,'' says Mr. Serra's secretary, bemusedly. ''His clothes,'' says Joseph Ruben, the director, ''they come from Goodwill, and they're too small or too tight.'' ''He's like a magician,'' says the writer, ''a genius or a fraud.'' ''Vaguely clownish,'' says the director. ''And then he goes to court and beats the hell out of you.''
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: Everyone seems to agree that Mr. Serra is a true believer. The film's title was based on one of his maxims: ''In the courtroom I'm a true believer, and a true believer's the most dangerous man alive.'' But what does he believe? According to Mr. Woods, ''Serra's values have never changed - that's a departure we made in the movie for dramatic reasons, to allow the possibility of growth and change in Eddie Dodd. Serra was a child of the 60's; now he's a man of the 60's transposed to the 80's, with all the possibilities of pragmatic solutions that the 80's entails. It's a more complex and, in a way, more challenging era.
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: ''It's basically a Hegelian dialectic,'' says the actor, whose speech is peppered with words like ''Hegelian'' and ''dialectic.'' ''You take the euphoric idealism of the 60's, its values, its lack of materialism,'' says Mr. Woods. (Mr. Serra, who says he got ''no bread'' from this film, claims to be worth ''minus $50,000.'') ''Now add the utterly self-aggrandizing pragmatism, the practical techniques of the 70's and 80's, and what you have is the possibility of a really lionhearted courtroom lawyer,'' says Mr. Woods.
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: Unlike the character of Eddie Dodd, who is resurrected by the rare phenomenon of an innocent client, Mr. Serra does not believe in the reality of innocence or guilt. ''I hate that mea culpa bull that's been imported into law to give lawyers and judges the control that priests have. None of us is capable of guilt.''
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: ''Tony will tell you that he has to achieve total empathy with a client before he can defend him,'' says Mr. Strick. ''He has to convince himself. He loses objectivity. He wills himself to. Tony won't ask a client what really happened. He'll just listen to his version of the events, and he'll help create a scenario, within ethical limits, that would stand up to cross-examination. He goes through a process, much like an actor will, until he becomes a man who believes in his client, or even becomes the client himself.''
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: Asked how he convinces juries of his clients' innocence, Mr. Serra, speaking from a ''freezing phone booth'' in San Francisco, says, ''The warrior goes to battle knowing he's going to die. I'm not some lawyer with my hands full of paper, man. I look that jury in the eye, two feet away, and I start SCREAMING!''
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: In that sense, says Mr. Strick, the lawyer and the actor who portrays his fictional counterpart may be more than spiritual kin. ''Woods loves combat, too,'' says the writer. ''It's fun for Tony Serra, and it's fun for him. That's where they intersect. They both like to regale people with their rhetoric.''
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: ''I wish I had a face like Woods, man,'' says Mr. Serra, who says he hasn't looked up at an actor's face on the big screen (or small) in 25 years. ''Movies and TV are shadows of shadows. I kiss them off. But I love Jimmy's face, those pockmarks. If I had 'em, I'd win even more cases.''
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: Says Mr. Woods, whose career in Hollywood has not followed the traditional leading-man trajectory (''The cigar-chomping men always wanted Robert Wagner''): ''All of us involved in the movie are kind of the renegades of Hollywood. We've tried to infuse values into our work. 'True Believer' is entertaining; it's an action picture, so we felt here's a chance to reach a mass audience and at the same time sneak in food for thought.''
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: Walter Parkes, whose documentary ''The California Reich'' depicted American neo-Nazism, agrees: ''Larry Lasker and I are guys that went to college in the 60's - and we're also guys who know popcorn movies.''
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: ''It's the way Eddie Dodd would do it, you know?'' says James Woods. ''Give 'em a great story, make them come into the theater, give 'em the popcorn and the Coke, and hope that while they're sitting there, they might actually think about something.''
title:
FILM;
'True Believer' Makes a Case For Idealism

text: Michael N. Manley, a social democrat who presided over Jamaica for eight tumultuous years in the 1970's, swept to victory tonight in national elections.
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: With 65 percent of the vote counted, the Government television station declared that Mr. Manley's People's National Party had won 39 of the 60 seats in Parliament, giving it the majority that will make Mr. Manley Prime Minister again.
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: The Jamaica Labor Party of the incumbent, Edward P. G. Seaga, had won 7 seats and 14 remained undecided. 'A Second Chance'
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: Surrounded by cheering supporters at his headquarters tonight, Mr. Manley said he was ''deeply grateful to the Jamaican people.''
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: ''It is not given to many people to be given a second chance to serve a nation,'' he said.
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: Mr. Manley noted Jamaica's history of political violence and the relative peacefulness of this election, and thanked the security forces for helping to maintain order, ''without which there cannot be free and fair elections.''
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: He also appealed to his supporters to take their victory with ''dignity and humility'' and not to provoke or ''crow over'' the losing party.
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: As Jamaica's leader until 1980, the 64-year-old Mr. Manley challenged United States policies and flaunted his friendship with Fidel Castro. But in his campaign this year, he promised to follow a moderate course and said his first priority would be to meet with President Bush, the State Department, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. #1 Reported Killed and 6 Hurt There was scattered violence today, but most of the country was orderly as voters turned out in large numbers. It was a far cry from the last contested national election, eight years ago, in which more than 750 people died.
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: The police said one woman had been killed and six people had been wounded. There were a few reports of thugs stealing ballot boxes and trying to prevent people from voting.
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: ''This is going to mark a new phase in our politics,'' a Government official said, ''because things are going rather calmly. People will finally be able to stop talking about how violent our last election was. This is an important milestone in our political development.''
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: Mr. Seaga, a 58-year-old Harvard graduate who had been President Reagan's closest ally in the Caribbean, voted this afternoon at a Jesuit high school and accused his opponent of ''intensive fraud.''
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: But Mr. Seaga made no mention of the accusations in his concession statement tonight. ''The people have spoken,'' he said, ''and we abide by their decision.''
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: ''We can hold our heads very high as the previous government and will hold our heads high as an opposition,'' he added. ''On that basis, therefore, we shall take our defeat with a smile.'' Scale of Problems Is Disputed
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: A spokesman for Mr. Seaga, George Ramocan, said earlier that he had received reports of ballot stuffing in 8 of the 60 parliamentary districts and that the results in those districts could be affected.
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: But an official of Jamaica's bipartisan electoral commission said, ''We have have nothing to indicate that the election has been unfair.''
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: A spokesman for Mr. Manley, Ralston Smith, said that Mr. Manley was satisfied that the system was working and that Mr. Manley thought the irregularities that had been reported were ''not sufficient to upset the overall results of the election.''
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: Late this morning, Mr. Seaga shoved a cameraman from the Cable News Network in a polling station and a Seaga supporter took the cameraman's videotape.
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: Mr. Seaga later apologized, saying that he ''very much regretted'' the incident and that there had been ''nothing in malice.'' Aides to Mr. Seaga said the Prime Minister had been in the midst of trying to quell an argument between two election officials when he turned and saw the television camera pointed at him.
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: ''He lost his temper,'' said Senator John Issa, a member of Mr. Seaga's Party. ''It was most unfortunate.''
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: Mr. Manley voted about 9 A.M. at a probation office near his home. He laughed and joked with reporters and said he felt confident of victory. Agreement to Resist Violence
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: The Government deployed a force of about 10,000 soldiers and police around the country in jeeps, trucks, armored cars and helicopters. Units were dispatched throughout the day in response to reports of gunfire, rock throwing and raids on voting places, mainly in Kingston and nearby areas.
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: Political violence is deeply engrained in Jamaica and has flourished in a two-party system in which the victors have traditionally ignored the vanquished and monopolized jobs, housing and other Government benefits.
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: In the past, political leaders have condoned or encouraged armed gangs. Some of their combat rifles and submachine guns have been flown into Jamaica on planes that smuggle marijuana, one of the island's cash crops, to the United States.
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: Mr. Manley boycotted a 1983 election in a dispute over voter registration. Since the 1980 election, tourism has become Jamaica's leading industry and both candidates had expressed concern that it might be damaged by continued violence. Last August the two leaders signed a peace agreement, promising to refrain from armed attacks and intimidation.
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: By late afternoon, there had been no reports of violence in Ocho Rios, Montego Bay, Negril and the other towns on the northern coast where Jamaica's hotels and resorts are concentrated.
title: Jamaican Vote Sweeps Manley to Power

text: Administration officials said today that persistent questions about John G. Tower's private life and campaign finances were extending the Federal Bureau of Investigation's background check of the nominee to head the Pentagon.
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: C. Boyden Gray, the White House counsel, said that five allegations dealing with Mr. Tower's sex life and drinking habits have proved to be largely unsubstantiated, but that there are still some loose ends.
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: But other officials said a sixth allegation, that a campaign contribution to Mr. Tower in 1984 may have been illegal, was still being investigated. They said the allegation involved a former aide to Mr. Tower, who announced in 1983 that he would not seek re-election to the Senate from Texas in 1984. The aide was said to been the intermediary for a $1,000 contribution from a corporation; campaign contributions from corporations to candidates for Federal office are illegal.
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: One of the officials confirmed a CBS News report that the allegation grew out of the investigation into fraud in weapons procurement. Bush Defends Tower
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: The almost daily disclosure of allegations against the Defense Secretary-designate has forced the White House to ask the F.B.I. to extend its investigation of Mr. Tower.
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican who is on the Armed Services Committee, which is considering the nomination, said White House officials had told him they favored postponing a vote on Mr. Tower's nomination until the F.B.I. completes its investigation. The committee is not scheduled to consider the nomination again until after next week.
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: President Bush defended Mr. Tower today. ''This frenzied air of speculation doesn't help anybody,'' Mr. Bush said. ''It doesn't help the national security of our country. It doesn't help Senator Tower. It doesn't help the standing of the United States Senate.''
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: But senators on the Armed Services Committee questioned the adequacy of the report on Mr. Tower and criticized the White House for failing to provide the committee with all the facts turned up in the investigation.
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: The complaints follow similar criticism of past F.B.I. background checks. The misgivings reached a peak in 1987 after the F.B.I inquiry into Douglas H. Ginsburg, a Federal appeals court judge nominated by Ronald Reagan for the Supreme Court, failed to disclose that the nominee had smoked marijuana. Ex-Neighbors Not Interviewed
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: Conversations today with about a dozen people who reside in the suburb of Washington where Mr. Tower lived in the late 1960's and early 1970's indicated that they were not interviewed by the F.B.I.
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: Pat Holt, a retired Congressional official, and others who live on Moorland Lane in Bethesda, Md., said the agency had not interviewed them concerning Mr. Tower, though it had in the past about other nominees. ''The F.B.I. comes around every once in a while,'' Mr. Holt said. An F.B.I. spokesman conceded it was possible that some people who knew Mr. Tower were not interviewed in such a broad investigation.
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: Administration officials today defended the F.B.I., noting that a lengthy and varied public and private career such as Mr. Tower's complicated an inquiry. They added that F.B.I. must cope with up to 2,000 background checks for the new Administration.
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: Senator Sam Nunn, a Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said today that the scope of a background inquiry was determined by the White House. ''When the F.B.I. comes in with their initial report,'' Mr. Nunn said, ''the question of what additional information they get is up to the White House counsel and the President's direction.''
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: The F.B.I. completed a background report on Mr. Tower in early January. Since then, the White House has asked the bureau to investigate six allegations not uncovered in the original review, Mr. Gray said.
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: The check into the $1,000 campaign contribution to Mr. Tower began when an unidentified person under investigation in the procurement scandal told Federal authorities about it, other officials said.
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: The allegation prompted a Tuesday night meeting between White House officials and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. It was regarded as a serious charge, though there is no evidence that Mr. Tower was aware of the actual source of the contribution, the officials said.
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: The officials said that they were concerned because such an allegation, if made after Mr. Tower was confirmed, would be sufficient ground for appointing a special prosecutor to investigate. Inquiry is Defended
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: Mr. Gray defended the handling of the F.B.I. inquiry. ''If the charges were baseless why would they have known about them,'' he said. ''They have run as thorough an investigation as they could possibly run.'
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: As evidence of the F.B.I.'s wide-ranging inquiry, Mr. Gray said that investigators had interviewed senators to determine whether they knew of any activity that would disqualify Mr. Tower. ''The answer that came back was, 'no,' there was nothing.
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: Mr. Gray said the report was voluminous but held nothing that would disqualify Mr. Tower. He added that the report included a medical statement showing Mr. Tower had not abused alcohol.
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: Senator Carl Levin, a Democrat of Michigan who also is a member of the committee, said that the White House had failed to turn over information from the inquiry promptly, and that Mr. Gray had provided a briefing to Republican committee members on the status of the investigation into Mr. Tower, but had not briefed Democratic members of the committee. Mr. Gray said that he had provided Mr. Nunn with a full report on the investigation.
title: Finance and Behavior Questions Prolong F.B.I. Background Check

text: Michael N. Manley, the front-running candidate for Prime Minister of Jamaica, called today for the formation of civic patrols to assist security forces in preventing violence on election day Thursday.
title: Jamaica Front-Runner Urges Steps to Avert Election Strife

text: Mr. Manley denied assertions by Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga that the Manley forces plan to disrupt the voting, but said he had alerted supporters to possible attempts of armed intimidation by Mr. Seaga's backers.
title: Jamaica Front-Runner Urges Steps to Avert Election Strife

text: Scattered violence in three weeks of campaigning has left 8 people dead. More than 750 deaths occurred in the 1980 elections in which Mr. Seaga defeated Mr. Manley. Predicting a Victory
title: Jamaica Front-Runner Urges Steps to Avert Election Strife

text: Mr. Manley, who frequently challenged United States policy as Prime Minister in the 1970's, said in a news conference that he was ''heading for a huge victory'' and that he was ''absolutely confident of a positive and creative relationship'' with the Bush Administration.
title: Jamaica Front-Runner Urges Steps to Avert Election Strife

text: Mr. Manley also said he would wage a strong fight against narcotics and narcotics trafficking.
title: Jamaica Front-Runner Urges Steps to Avert Election Strife

text: The incumbent, Mr. Seaga, says that his administration has destroyed 75 percent of the island's marijuana crop over the last two years and that this has cost him support in the election.
title: Jamaica Front-Runner Urges Steps to Avert Election Strife

text: Mr. Manley, who is 64 years old, said he remained a dedicated social democrat. But he said he had abandoned ''all thoughts of nationalization'' and now believed that the way to maximize productivity was to ''release the spirit of entrepreneurship.''
title: Jamaica Front-Runner Urges Steps to Avert Election Strife

text: He said he hoped to encourage the ''democratization of industry'' by persuading owners to offer workers shares in their companies.
title: Jamaica Front-Runner Urges Steps to Avert Election Strife

text: Mr. Manley acknowledged his intentions to restore diplomatic relations with Cuba. But he said that that did not indicate approval of Communism any more than did President Reagan's reconciliation with the Soviet Union.
title: Jamaica Front-Runner Urges Steps to Avert Election Strife

text: ''I don't think Mr. Reagan approves of Communism,'' Mr. Manley said. ''Incidently, neither do I.''
title: Jamaica Front-Runner Urges Steps to Avert Election Strife

text: Mr. Manley, leader of the People's National Party, proposed the civic patrols in a letter to Mr. Seaga and suggested that they be organized by clergy and business leaders. He also suggested that both sides indicate areas in which they expected trouble.
title: Jamaica Front-Runner Urges Steps to Avert Election Strife

text: Mr. Seaga was campaigning outside of Kingston, the capital, and did not immediately respond.
title: Jamaica Front-Runner Urges Steps to Avert Election Strife

text: The election violence so far has been limited to the Kingston slums and rural areas to the west. No incidents have been reported on the north coast, where most of Jamaica's resorts are located.
title: Jamaica Front-Runner Urges Steps to Avert Election Strife

text: Mr. Manley's transformation from radical to moderate was reflected in his choice of clothing. As Prime Minister, Mr. Manley often wore military-style bush jackets.Today he chose a dark blue business suit Asked about the ''new Manley,'' he said, ''I don't think I'm new. I think I'm evolving.''
title: Jamaica Front-Runner Urges Steps to Avert Election Strife

text: It seemed to be all downhill for Frank L. McNamara Jr. after his appointment as the United States Attorney for Massachusetts in 1987. The Senate Judiciary Committee held up his confirmation because of questions about his income tax returns. Some of his staff complained that his decisions on key personnel matters were politically motivated. Then a Justice Department report concluded that he had falsely accused his predecessor, William F. Weld, of smoking marijuana. The department began an investigation to determine whether he deliberately lied, and 28 of his 39 assistant attorneys signed a letter to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, seeking Mr. McNamara's removal or resignation. Last week, Mr. McNamara resigned, saying, ''The work of this office is far too important to be sidetracked by any controversy.''
title: Ending Sidetracks

text: By Clifford D. May, Special To the New York Times
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan complained today that plans to build new Federal courtrooms in Manhattan were moving too slowly and that the city's war on drugs was sure to suffer as a result.
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: ''It is too soon for alarm, but not for concern,'' Mr. Moynihan said at a Senate hearing. ''On further thought, it is not in the least too soon to express something like alarm.''
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: Two new office buildings that would contain courtrooms are planned for the Foley Square area to relieve overcrowding in the United States Court House and other Government buildings nearby. The old court house was designed for 17 judges but now holds more than 60.
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: In an interview after the hearing, Mr. Moynihan said that without additional courtroom space it will be ''impossible even to pretend we can enforce the drug laws.'' Not Just Drug Enforcement
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: The Democratic Senator said that a United States Attorney recently told him that he cannot prosecute cases at Kennedy International Airport involving anything less than a ton of marijuana because ''they just don't have the space.''
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts
