text: A Deputy District Attorney for the Southern District of New York, Louis Freeh, agreed that new courtrooms were badly needed, although he said it is not only drug enforcement that suffers, since civil cases, immigration, tax, bankruptcy and other matters are also heard before Federal courts.
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: ''There is a space crisis in the courthouse,'' Mr. Freeh said. ''It affects all of our business, civil and criminal. It's not just drug cases - but certainly drug cases are a large part of what we do.''
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: Mr. Moynihan said the New York City bureaucracy was the main reason the project has not progressed.
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: Construction of the buildings was authorized in a provision of the catch-all spending bill signed by President Reagan in December 1987. A contract with the city was signed on March 11, 1988.
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: The time elapsed so far, Mr. Moynihan noted, is already longer ''than it took Al Smith to build the Empire State Building.'' 'Friendly Condemnation'
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: Robert Esnard, New York's Deputy Mayor for Policy and Physical Development, today promised to try to speed things up by approving a ''friendly condemnation.''
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: Instead of selling the Federal Government the property needed for a nominal sum - a transaction that would require reviews that could take as long as a year - the city will agree not to challenge a Federal condemnation of the property.
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: Mr. Moynihan said he was encouraged by Mr. Esnard's pledge.
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: The two buildings are to have 1.6 million square feet of space with room for courts, Federal and city offices, restaurants and retail stores.
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: The buildings have not been designed yet, but Mr. Moynihan said they ''will meet far higher architectural standards'' than the present Jacob K. Javits Federal office building, which he called ''all too typical of Federal office projects.''
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: The estimated $200 million cost is to be financed through a ''lease to own'' arrangement under which private developers will be selected through bidding competitions. The developers will own the buildings and lease them to the Government for 30 years, at the end of which title passes to the Government. ''This won't cost the city a penny,'' Mr. Moynihan said.
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: Mr. Moynihan said he was particularly alarmed by the ''seeming lack of interest in this enterprise in New York City.'' He singled out in particular New York lawyers' organizations, saying, ''You would suppose at the very least the bar associations might bestir themselves. Not even them.
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: ''If because of our incompetence nothing is built at Foley Square and the Square itself is not redesigned and revived, have no fear,'' the Senator grumbled. ''No one will notice.''
title: Moynihan Criticizes Delay in Building Courts

text: In a sport as conscious of public relations as auto racing, John Paul Jr. would seem to be a pariah.
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: Paul is attempting a comeback at age 29 after serving 28 months in prison on Federal racketeering charges. If he races in the International Motor Sports Association Camel GT series this season, Paul will have the support of IMSA and some of his competitors.
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: He was scheduled to ride in the first race of the series, driving Bruce Leven's Porsche 962 in the Sunbank 24 at Daytona International Speedway this weekend.
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: ''Pretty much everyone has been great,'' Paul said recently from West Palm Beach, Fla., where he lives with his wife and their 4-year-old daughter. ''Obviously, they can't come out and say things on my behalf, officially. A lot of it is because of sponsor conflicts and the fact that it's a negative subject. But privately everyone's been very understanding.'' Received Support
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: When Paul faced trial in 1985 on five counts arising from his involvement in a drug-smuggling ring that operated from 1975 to 1983, the racing community was ready to help, too.
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: ''A lot of people wrote letters on my behalf to the judge,'' he said.
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: The case never went to trial. Paul pleaded guilty to one count in exchange for the Government's agreeing to drop the other charges.
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: IMSA's support of Paul is rooted in two factors: his formidable driving talent and his relationship with his father, John Paul Sr. Despite having a racing career interrupted in his mid-20's, Paul has won a Camel GT championship. He also won the 1983 Michigan 500 Indy-car race in a year-old car. Although he could be hard on equipment, Paul's great ability to go fast needed to be tempered to make him one of the top American road racers.
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: The elder Paul, who is serving a 25-year sentence in Leavenworth, was considered by the Government to be the leader of the smuggling operation. (Each had a previous conviction for marijuana possession.) But the perception in the pits was that John Paul Jr., a dutiful son at the track, was brought along for the ride in the drug ring and had to pay for his loyalty. Rough Driver
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: Even if his son didn't possess a soft-spoken, modest manner, competitors' memories of John Paul Sr. would flatter almost anyone by comparison.
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: Bob Akin raced against the Pauls in the early 1980's. ''His father was at the very best a very, very difficult guy to be associated with,'' Akin said. ''He would have fits of temper and wild swings of mood.''
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: Akin said that on the cool-off lap after one race, Paul Sr. deliberately drove into his car, forcing both men to crash because he perceived, mistakenly, Akin said, that Akin had blocked his son's car.
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: ''I remember John tried to patch up situations that his father had created,'' Akin said. ''John was just the opposite of his father. John is a nice kid.''
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: ''I know a lot of people disliked him and a lot of people hated him,'' Paul said of his father. ''But that was just the way he did things. He was very quick-tempered in some respects, and I can't blame people for their attitude toward my dad. But he's still my dad, and I love him in that regard.''
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: Asked whether he resented his father for the troubles he was drawn into, Paul would only say, ''I feel resentment toward the situation.'' Bad Memories
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: Akin said that an unfortunate aspect of Paul's return was that it would refocus attention on a period a few years ago when a number of top drivers were also drug merchants, particularly on the Camel GT circuit. Besides John Paul Sr., Bill and Don Whittington, who won a number of Camel GT events and competed in Indy-car racing, were sentenced for smuggling, and Randy Lanier, the 1984 Camel GT champion and 1986 Indianapolis 500 rookie of the year, is appealing a life sentence.
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: John Bishop, the president of IMSA, discussed why the sanctioning body allowed Paul to return.
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: ''Whatever his past complications with the law, he's paid his debt,'' Bishop said. ''He was a magnificent athlete, and we still hope he is. He never got crossways with us in any way.''
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: Bishop noted that before IMSA made its decision, it notified its chief sponsor, RJR Nabisco.
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: John Frasco, the chairman of Championship Auto Racing Team, said that CART had not been approached by Paul and had not given any thought to whether he would be allowed to return.
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: ''If we got a request, we'd consider it,'' Frasco said.
title: Auto Racing; Paul Returns From Prison

text: The United States said today that it hoped the military coup in Paraguay was a step toward democracy, but American officials expressed grave concern about reports linking the leader of the coup to narcotics traffic.
title: Concern Voiced on New Chief and Drug Trade

text: Charles E. Redman, the State Department spokesman, noted that the new leader, Gen. Andres Rodriguez, had said in a radio broadcast that he led the uprising ''for the initiation of democratization in Paraguay and for the respect of human rights.''
title: Concern Voiced on New Chief and Drug Trade

text: Mr. Redman said, ''We would welcome any genuine movement toward a more democratic form of government in that country.'' Paraguay was ruled by Gen. Alfredo Stroessner for almost 35 years. But experts on Paraguay saw little chance that General Rodriguez would be a force for democracy. A 'Really Bad' Reputation
title: Concern Voiced on New Chief and Drug Trade

text: John Hoyt Williams, a professor of Latin American history at Indiana State University in Terre Haute, Ind., said tonight: ''General Rodriguez has an exceedingly unsavory reputation. I mean really bad, and that's an understatement. He has been implicated time and time again by U.S. and international drug organizations as a kingpin of the drug trade.''
title: Concern Voiced on New Chief and Drug Trade

text: ''Rodriguez has reportedly provided protection, airfields and an air taxi service to people smuggling drugs northward,'' Professor Williams said. ''That's an allegation, but it's common knowledge on the streets of Paraguay, and I have read about it many times in reports published by authoritative reserach organizations.''
title: Concern Voiced on New Chief and Drug Trade

text: Professor Williams said he saw the coup as an attempt by the Paraguayan Army ''to stave off democracy and maintain a privileged position.''
title: Concern Voiced on New Chief and Drug Trade

text: He said General Rodriguez was widely believed to have provided protection and assistance to Auguste Ricord, a French-born heroin trafficker who was deported to the United States and returned to Paraguay in 1983 after release from an American prison.
title: Concern Voiced on New Chief and Drug Trade

text: Mr. Redman, the State Department spokesman, and Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, declined to comment on reports that General Rodriguez had been involved in drug trafficking. But another American official said that in 1985, the Drug Enforcement Administration received a document produced by the Paraguayan narcotics police identifying the general as a drug trafficker.
title: Concern Voiced on New Chief and Drug Trade

text: In 1985, The New York Times reported that American officials suspected that senior Paraguayan military officers were involved in drug trafficking. American officials said today that General Rodriguez was one of the officers under scrutiny.
title: Concern Voiced on New Chief and Drug Trade

text: Paraguay is a major producer of marijuana, shipping much of its crop to Brazil. American officials say they believe that large amounts of cocaine are grown in or shipped through Paraguay.
title: Concern Voiced on New Chief and Drug Trade

text: In its annual report on international narcotics activity, the State Department said last year: ''Paraguay appears to have become a significant money-laundering location for narcotics traffickers due to lax Government controls. Foreign narcotics money reportedly is being used to purhcase land and property in Paraguay.''
title: Concern Voiced on New Chief and Drug Trade

text: In 1984, the Paraguayan customs service seized 49,000 gallons of chemicals used to manufacture cocaine, but rebuffed repeated United States requests to destroy the chemicals.
title: Concern Voiced on New Chief and Drug Trade

text: The death of a young black man in police custody has prompted complaints by many blacks of police brutality and raised tensions in this historic town, which has long prided itself for being progressive on social issues.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: John (Tony) Jackson, 22 years old, died in Morristown Memorial Hospital last Saturday shortly after being arrested for failing to appear in court for a motor-vehicle violation. The officers who arrested him had spotted him outside a bar, chased him on foot and handcuffed him.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: Preliminary reports by the Morris County prosecutor and medical examiner said there was no indication that excessive force had been used. The police say drug use may have been a factor. They say Mr. Jackson was carrying an inhalator for his asthma and small amounts of cocaine and marijuana, and tests found traces of cocaine in his blood and urine.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: But in this town that calls itself ''the military capital of the Revolution'' because George Washington had his headquarters here, recent nights have seen marches through the town square, candlelight demonstrations and chants of ''We want justice.''
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: As blacks and whites in this county seat of 17,000 people nervously await further reports, Justice Department officials have arrived to mediate problems, and the F.B.I. is investigating to see if Mr. Jackson's civil rights were violated.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: The demonstrations have been peaceful and orderly to the point that on one evening protesters were careful not to cross streets against a red light.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: But there have been telephoned threats to police headquarters aimed at the arresting officers, and the rear window of a patrol car was shattered, creating a sense of uncertainty and sadness among many of the town's residents, about 20 percent of whom are black.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: ''There is no doubt in my mind that this young man was not abused physically by officers,'' Police Chief Robert Jay White said after an internal investigation by his department. ''This was a routine arrest that had a tragic ending due to some cause that has yet to be determined.''
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: The houses here have a prosperous look, and the town green is bordered by specialty shops and office buildings, including Headquarters Plaza, a huge hotel, office and shopping complex. But Mayor David V. Manahan said the complex had not produced the good jobs promised for black residents, including those who live a short distance down the hill in public housing, where Mr. Jackson lived.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: Black elected and civil rights officials have had to walk a tightrope between disputing the police report and disputing the accusations in the black community as they have talked with the police chief, mayor and black residents. Some Are Angry and Outspoken
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: The president of the Morris County Chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Reno Smith, said Mr. Jackson's death had caused resentment over a lack of affordable housing and jobs to surface among black residents, but she said she would reserve judgment on the police brutality complaints.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: ''After getting a final report from the prosecutor and the toxicologist, if the N.A.A.C.P. is not satisfied, then we'll continue the investigation,'' she said.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: Others, however, are angry and outspoken. Mr. Jackson's uncle, Frank Osborne, one of the leaders of the protests, said his nephew's death was part of a pattern of police brutality involving blacks. He said the suggestion that Mr. Jackson's death was related to drug use and his asthma was an effort at ''diverting our attention.''
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: Leading marchers past quaint shops and restaurants around the town green on Wednesday night, Mr. Osborne said: ''That's why he's dead. Yes. They shoved him, they put their famous chokehold on him, cut off his wind. They banged his head on the car.'' Mr. Osborne said he had not seen the incident but had talked with the dead man's mother, Everdeane Jackson, and other witnesses. Chief's Account
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: Mrs. Jackson has not made any public statements, but Mr. Jackson's sister, Thelma Edwards, has joined the demonstrations.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: Chief White, a 26-year veteran who was named to his post 16 months ago, gave the following account of Mr. Jackson's arrest:
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: At 1:17 A.M. last Saturday, two officers, Kevin Muholland and Mark Meehan, saw Mr. Jackson outside a tavern in a predominantly black neighborhood. They knew there was a warrant for his arrest for failing to appear in court to answer a charge that he had abandoned a car.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: Mr. Jackson bolted and they chased him a few blocks to his apartment building on Clyde Potts Drive. A third officer, coming from around a building, collided with Mr. Jackson. Mr. Jackson was bruised on the forehead; the officer was cut.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: After being handcuffed, Mr. Jackson continued to struggle, and his mother, who had come out when she heard a noise, told him to stop resisting. As he was being put in the patrol car he went ''limp.''
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: At 1:27 a sergeant directed an officer to take Mr. Jackson to the hospital because he had complained of an asthmatic condition. At 1:31 two officers driving Mr. Jackson to the hospital found that Mr. Jackson was unconscious. He was pronounced dead at the hospital at 2:30 A.M. Others' Views
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: Mr. Osborne and others dispute that account, saying Mr. Jackson was unconscious before being put in the car and charging that the officers had a chokehold on him and repeatedly banged his head on the car.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: The prosecutor's office said Mr. Jackson, a 1984 graduate of Morristown High School who last worked in a cafeteria, had a history of arrests on drug and trespass charges, but the authorities did not provide details.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: Chief White said the 54-member department, which has four black officers, has been praised by black residents for arrests of drug dealers and suppliers in the last year.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: The Mayor called Morristown ''a community with a social conscience'' and said that two of seven Council members were black, that principals of three of the six schools were black and that he and other officials were trying to provide more housing and jobs.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: One black resident of Morristown, Charles (Big Newt) Wilfong, 58, who joined in the demonstration, said he did not believe that the police usually employ excessive force but that there might have been ''a mistake'' in Mr. Jackson's death.
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: Certain social issues have to be addressed, said Mr. Wilfong, a truck driver for the regional water authority, but he added, ''This is a good town, a good town - for whites and blacks. Then something like that has to happen to stir it all up.''
title: Cries of Police Brutality Follow Death

text: A 23-year-old black motorcyclist whose fatal shooting by a police officer touched off three nights of violence had traces of cocaine in his system and was carrying a small amount of marijuana, The Miami Herald reported today. The man, Clement Anthony Lloyd, was shot to death by a Hispanic officer, and his passenger died the next day of injuries suffered in the ensuing crash. Homicide victims are routinely tested for drugs.
title: Drug Issue in Riot Raised

text: The damage done to the country's institutions in the Reagan years will be a long time in the reckoning. But a drama that has just played out in Boston provides a telling example.
title: The Price of Reagan

text: It is the story of President Reagan's appointee as the United States Attorney for the District of Massachusetts, Frank L. McNamara Jr. He got the job in April 1987. He resigned this week. In between, he managed by single-minded folly to do severe injury to the most important law enforcement office in New England.
title: The Price of Reagan

text: What makes the episode significant is the role that Federal prosecutors have come to play in American criminal justice, one quite unanticipated by the Framers of the Constitution. They assumed that criminal law would be almost entirely a matter for the states, and that was so until well into the 20th century.
title: The Price of Reagan

text: The increasingly national character of the economy, the growth of organized crime and other transforming changes in our society in the last 50 years have brought a vast enlargement of Federal criminal law. Federal prosecutions have also become the main weapon against corruption in state and local governments.
title: The Price of Reagan

text: For those reasons Federal prosecutors - the United States Attorneys around the country, and their staffs - have become key figures in law enforcement. Accordingly, some of the major offices, such as those in Massachusetts and the Southern District of New York, have developed a tradition of legal excellence. U.S. Attorneys were of course usually of the President's party, but they ran their offices on a nonpartisan basis.
title: The Price of Reagan

text: That tradition was broken when Attorney General Edwin Meese selected Mr. McNamara. His most important legal position had been as assistant general counsel of the Boston Gas Company. His sole visible qualification was political. He was an extreme-right Republican who had performed the sacrificial task of running against House Speaker Tip O'Neill in 1982.
title: The Price of Reagan

text: There were curious features in his background. He did not file his 1983 and 1984 income tax returns until 1986. He turned in his 1982 campaign financial report two years late, and it showed that he had used campaign money to pay himself $4,000 in consulting fees and to cover $1,554 in mortgage payments.
title: The Price of Reagan

text: In short, nobody could have believed that Mr. McNamara got the job on his merits as a lawyer or the meticulousness of his personal record. And after he became U.S. Attorney, he was involved in a number of bizarre incidents.
title: The Price of Reagan

text: He told Justice Department investigators that he had seen his predecessor, William Weld, smoking marijuana at a wedding party in 1982. A department inquiry concluded that the charge was contradicted by ''overwhelming evidence.'' When questioned by the F.B.I., Mr. McNamara said that he had used marijuana himself as recently as 1984. The head of the Drug Enforcement Administration in New England reported that Mr. McNamara had urged an investigation of marijuana use by Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, the Massachusetts Democrat. Mr. McNamara suggested that his own wife, Elizabeth, would be a good witness because she had smoked it with Representative Kennedy.
title: The Price of Reagan

text: Partisan politics ran through Mr. McNamara's tenure. Last summer he tried to stir up an investigation into the groundless charge that Gov. Michael Dukakis had tipped off land dealers to the site of a proposed new prison.
title: The Price of Reagan

text: The result was predictably disastrous for law enforcement. The principal assistants in the U.S. Attorney's office left. The professionals in the F.B.I. and other agencies were estranged.
title: The Price of Reagan

text: Just before finally resigning, Mr. McNamara blamed his troubles on ''Cambridge elitists and bow-tie liberals.'' He said that to The Boston Herald, a conservative-oriented paper that as long ago as last November called on him to leave.
title: The Price of Reagan

text: Frank McNamara was the perfect embodiment of the radical right that has appropriated the word ''conservative'' in this country. He did what Ed Meese wanted, with at least Ronald Reagan's passive support: to make everything turn on ideology, to wipe out the past and wipe out the opposition.
title: The Price of Reagan

text: The irony is that law is by nature a genuinely conservative profession. Most lawyers want to preserve the tradition of Federal law enforcement. In Massachusetts, rebuilding that tradition out of the wreckage will be difficult. What happens will tell a good deal about President Bush and his Attorney General, Dick Thornburgh.
title: The Price of Reagan

text: By Steven V. Roberts, Special To the New York Times
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: Hearings on Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, President Bush's choice for Secretary of Health and Human Services, were postponed indefinitely today at the request of the White House.
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: The request was made, officials said, because the Federal Bureau of Investigation had not completed its background check of the nominee and because Dr. Sullivan had not completed his financial disclosure forms. Administration officials said the delay represented no softening in Mr. Bush's support for his selection.
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: Asked if the Sullivan nomination was in trouble, A White House spokesman answered no. He added that Bush advisers continued to maintain a ''unanimous feeling of support'' for the nominee, who has found himself enmeshed in the emotional issue of abortion.
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: Dr. Sullivan has twice been quoted as saying that he opposes reversal of Roe v. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion. After protests from anti-abortion forces, he has twice changed his view, and said he supports the position of President Bush, who favors reversing the ruling. Democrats Skeptical
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: Democrats on Capitol Hill expressed skepticism about the White House explanation for the delay. The hearings were supposed to begin Wednesday before the Senate Finance Committee.
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: ''I'm surprised,'' said Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the committee chairman. ''It seems to me they had plenty of time.''
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: Senator Thomas A. Daschle of South Dakota, a Democratic committee member, said the White House probably wanted more time to prepare Dr. Sullivan for the questioning from Senators, which is expected to be rigorous. Shaky on the Issue
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: ''He probably doesn't feel quite ready,'' said Mr. Daschle, who met with Dr. Sullivan recently. Asked if the nominee sounded shaky in answering questions about abortion, the Democratic Senator answered, ''Yeah.'' He added that Dr. Sullivan seemed relieved when the discussion shifted from abortion to rural health care.
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: According to Mr. Daschle, the nominee said he would uphold the current law that permits abortions, and would be just as careful in abiding by any court decision that changed the law. Dr. Sullivan refused to be drawn into a more detailed discussion of his views, the Senator added.
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: Dr. Sullivan spent three hours Saturday practicing for his hearings, as White House advisers fired questions at him. One White House aide who attended the session said the nominee had given a ''good, solid performance'' but added: ''He's got to be very careful what he says to Senators about something as volatile as abortion.''
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: Representative Vin Weber, a Minnesota Republican and a leader of the anti-abortion forces in Congress, agreed that Dr. Sullivan needed more thorough preparation before facing a hearing. 'Very Badly Prepared'
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: Mr. Weber said the nominee had been ''very badly prepared'' by White House officials before his nomination, and as a result he ''ventured opinions on a lot of things he didn't have to.''
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: If Dr. Sullivan had been better prepared, the White House ''could have avoided some of the embarrassment we've seen,'' Weber said.
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: Alarmed at the deteriorating situation, the Administration has now called in professional political consultants to advise Dr. Sullivan. White House officials also are protecting him from press inquiries. Repeated calls t o Dr. Sullivan's office at the Department of Health and Human Services today were all referred to the White House.
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: White House officials insisted the delay was bureaucratic, and pointed out that the F.B.I. was taking a long time in checking Administration nominees in an effort to avoid past mistakes. Lance, Ginsburg Recalled
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: ''The F.B.I. is paranoid,'' said a White House adviser. ''They don't want to be Bert Lanced, and they don't want to be Ginsburged.''
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: Bert Lance, Director of the Office of Management and Budget under Jimmy Carter, was later accused of banking irregularities. Douglas Ginsburg, President Reagan's nominee to the Supreme Court in 1987, withdrew his name after reports surfaced that he had smoked marijuana in law school.
title: Sullivan Hearing Is Delayed At Request of White House

text: Special to the New York Times
title: U.S. Attorney in Massachusetts Quits Amid Inquiry

text: Faced with a Federal investigation of his conduct and overt hostility from his staff, the United States Attorney in Massachusetts, Frank L. McNamara Jr., resigned today, saying, ''The work of this office is far too important to be sidetracked by any controversy.''
title: U.S. Attorney in Massachusetts Quits Amid Inquiry

text: Jeremiah O'Sullivan, chief attorney for the Justice Department's Organized Crime Strike Force in New England, was named interim successor.
title: U.S. Attorney in Massachusetts Quits Amid Inquiry

text: State officials and lawyers in the United States Attorney's Office have been urging Mr. McNamara to resign since November, when the Justice Department released a report concluding that he had falsely accused his predecessor, William F. Weld, of smoking marijuana. The department opened an investigation to determine whether Mr. McNamara had deliberately lied, and staff members said the events had undermined public confidence in the office to the point that justice could not be carried out properly.
title: U.S. Attorney in Massachusetts Quits Amid Inquiry

text: Mounting pressure against the Republican appointee reached a peak last Friday, when 28 of his 39 assistant attorneys sent a letter to Dick Thornburgh, the Attorney General, seeking Mr. McNamara's ''immediate resignation or removal.'' No Malice Toward Staff
title: U.S. Attorney in Massachusetts Quits Amid Inquiry

text: Announcing his resignation this morning, Mr. McNamara said he would return to private practice ''with great enthusiasm,'' adding that he bore no ''malice or ill will'' toward those who clamored for his resignation. Mr. McNamara, 41 years old, refused to answer any questions from reporters.
title: U.S. Attorney in Massachusetts Quits Amid Inquiry

text: Bad feelings between Mr. McNamara and some of his staff members date from his appointment in April 1987. His confirmation by the Senate was delayed until November 1987, because of questions raised by the Judiciary Committee over his income tax returns and over the use of campaign funds from his unsuccessful bid to unseat Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Massachusetts Democrat who was Speaker of the House. At the time, the Justice Department, the Federal Election Commission and the Joint Tax Committee assured the senators that his finances were in order.
title: U.S. Attorney in Massachusetts Quits Amid Inquiry

text: After his confirmation, Mr. McNamara angered some of his staff members by making decisions that they said were motivated by partisan politics. He demoted Richard Stearns, a liberal Democrat who was his top deputy, and replaced him with a conservative.
title: U.S. Attorney in Massachusetts Quits Amid Inquiry

text: Mr. McNamara told the Justice Department that he had seen Mr. Weld, a former United States Attorney who is now in private practice in Boston, smoking marijuana at a party in 1982. A report by Mr. Thornburgh concluded that there was no truth to the allegation and said Mr. McNamara himself had admitted using the drug as recently as four years ago. Mr. McNamara's colleagues said they could not understand why he would have made such an allegation. The Justice Department began an inquiry, which is continuing.
title: U.S. Attorney in Massachusetts Quits Amid Inquiry

text: Last week, Justice Department officials said they would expand their review of Mr. McNamara by examining his decision to close an investigation of a downtown real estate development known as 75 State Street. According to reports in Boston area newspapers, a developer of the office building, Harold Brown, told Federal authorities that a lawyer, Thomas E. Finnerty, had coerced him into paying $500,000 to insure government approval of the project. Mr. Finnerty is a business associate of William Bulger, president of the Massachusetts Senate, who had lobbied for Mr. McNamara's Congressional confirmation.
title: U.S. Attorney in Massachusetts Quits Amid Inquiry

text: INTERNATIONAL A2-12 A severe Nicaraguan austerity plan that cuts the national budget by almost half, was announced by President Ortega in an dramatic move to shore up the nation's rapidly deteriorating economy. Page A1

text: A far-right gain in West Berlin sent shock waves across West Germany. About 10,000 protesters demonstrated against the unexpected success, in which the rightists captured 11 seats in the city's parliament. A3

text: The Yugoslav military warned the nation's leaders against ''pushing our Yugoslav ship toward the rocks.'' The statement marked a break with the military's traditional distance from political affairs. A3

text: Calling blacks African-Americans, a proposal by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, has met with approval by some blacks and with skepticism by others, who have seen earlier name changes and do not identify with Africa. A1

text: Congress's views on a pay increase for members are being collected by the Speaker of the House. He distributed a 12-question survey about the controversial issue. A19

text: President Bush will not testify at the criminal trial of Oliver North, set to begin today, but former President Ronald Reagan may be asked to appear, a Federal judge ruled. A20

text: A lower capital gains tax rate and other tax incentives backed by President Bush during the election campaign will almost certainly be proposed to Congress next week, Bush aides said. A17

text: WASHINGTON TALK A20 Congress purrs under Bush's strokes REGIONAL B1-5 Joel Steinberg was convicted of first degree manslaughter after eight days of often stormy jury deliberation in Manhattan's State Supreme Court. He faces from eight and one third to 25 years in prison. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The charge against Mr. Steinberg of second-degree murder was rejected because several jurors had doubts about a critical element of the count: that he acted with ''depraved indifference'' by failing to get medical help. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: The city payroll needs to be reduced in New York City by 12,000 employees if Governor Cuomo's proposed state budget is not changed, Mayor Koch said, pursuing a strategy to shift fiscal blame to Albany. A1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: >Officials oppose staff cuts by Koch B4
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: People who know an accused sniper, charged Sunday in five sniper attacks in two Long Island towns, describe him as a quiet, playful and devout man. To police in the Middle West, he was known as a one-man crime wave. B1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Major New York City zoning changes were proposed to preserve the shape, size and nature of housing in that half of the city dominated by one- and two-family homes, two or three stories high. B1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: Plans for a new hotel on East 57th Street in Manhattan that would vie for an internationally elite clientele, charging more than $400 a night, are being drawn by developers backed by $300 million from Japan. B1
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: A comatose woman in Connecticut may legally be put to death by her family, the state's highest court ruled, in the first major challenge to the state's right-to-die law. B3
title: NEWS SUMMARY

text: At his last four jobs, the 27-year-old blue-collar worker quickly made friends with a crowd that liked to snort cocaine or smoke marijuana on lunch hours and coffee breaks.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: When they worked, he worked. When they rested, he rested. When they got high, he took mental notes.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: The worker, who agreed to be interviewed on the condition that his name not be used, is actually a spy. He has spent the past three years searching for drugs - and drug dealers - in corporate America. An investigator and training consultant at the 1st Security Corporation, a private security agency here, he has recently posed as a new employee at a luxury hotel, a hospital and two military contractors.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: At each of his four assignments as an undercover agent, he found extensive drug use. In bathrooms and parking lots, he says, he consistently found employees using substances - mostly cocaine and marijuana - that would send them back to work in a condition referred to as ''on-the-job absenteeism'' in his business.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: At a time when undercover operations are being highlighted as part of the Chicago futures markets investigation, they are also becoming corporate America's latest weapon in the battle to reduce illegal drug use in the workplace.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Private investigators say these operations have proliferated over the past few years. ''It would be impossible to figure how many there are, with so many agencies,'' said Rick Newman, co-chairman of the substance abuse committee of the American Society for Industrial Security, a 25,000-member professional group in Arlington, Va. ''But as a result of urine testing in the early 1980's, more companies are aware of drugs in the workplace. As a response, some use tests, some use dogs - and some use undercover.''
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Mr. Newman, president of Security Associates International in Houston, says his company conducted 16 undercover corporate operations last year, compared with 9 five years ago. William L. Taylor 3d, president of Professional Law Enforcement, a Dayton-based agency that is a division of Business Risk International, has 40 under way, up from 7 in 1983.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Mr. Taylor said his client list includes several Federal agencies. ''Uncle Sam has a drug problem,'' he said, though he declined to name any agencies involved.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: The cost of drug abuse is difficult to calculate, though policy makers and consultants keep trying. A recent Congressional report estimated that alcohol and drug abuse add up to a $177 billion drain on the economy. Marsh & McLennan Companies Inc., based on its 1988 survey of the 1,000 biggest companies, estimates the cost of illegal drug use to corporations at $52 billion annually.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Individual corporations offer some staggering estimates: The General Motors Corporation says that substance abuse by some of its 472,000 employees and their dependents cost the company about $600 million dollars in 1987. General Motors - which three years ago conducted a controversial and chaotic undercover operation at 10 Middle Western plants - says it would not hesitate to use such investigations in the future, even though charges against some workers were dismissed because of irregularities in the operation.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: On Wall Street, undercover drug investigations are widely used and considered ''extremely effective,'' according to a top security official at a leading investment banking firm. Wall Street began using secret operatives before other industries did, this official said, because of the tremendous amount of money involved in daily transactions. ''If you have someone who is handling million-dollar transactions, you are looking for any unusual behavior,'' he said. In 1987, a three-year undercover operation run by the Drug Enforcement Administration culminated with the arrest of 15 Wall Street employees, including several high-level brokers, on drug trafficking charges.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Until recently, most companies were reluctant to plant drug spies for fear of antagonizing employees. Now, say the private investigators, such operations are increasingly tolerated by employees who think drug abuse is a hazard to other workers.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: ''Employees are going to management, telling them about the drug problem and demanding management do something,'' said Larry Curran, vice president at 1st Security, which ran 25 undercover drug operations last year, up from 10 in 1983. Such incidents were ''virtually unheard of'' five years ago, he said.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: The agent from 1st Security, too, says he finds that employees who do not use drugs are very scared. ''Here they've got someone standing right next to them, working on a piece of machinery that could easily kill or cripple somebody, and the guy is stoned out of his mind,'' he said.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Still, many people disapprove of undercover operations. J. Michael Walsh, director of the Office Workplace Initiative with the Government-run National Institute on Drug Abuse, says that such investigations ''don't work very well.'' Mr. Walsh, a vocal proponent of drug testing, says companies that treat substance abuse as a health problem - and offer rehabilitation - are far more successful in curbing illegal drug use.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: And many employee-rights and civil-liberties groups, while conceding that employers have a right to seek a drug-free workplace, say undercover operations are unwarranted in most circumstances.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: ''No damage caused by drug abuse in the workplace is close to being as dangerous as the consequences of institutionalized, indiscriminate surveillance as a matter of routine in the workplace,'' said Ira Glasser, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union. Such secret operations ''so basically alter the basis of associations in the workplace,'' he said, ''it is astonishing that it's even being discussed seriously.''
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Mr. Glasser views with alarm any growing acceptance of undercover agents on the part of employees. ''Eventually workers become used to the idea that when you go to work Big Brother will be watching you and it doesn't seem outrageous,'' he said.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: With his tailored blue pinstriped suit, the agent from 1st Security blends in easily with the corporate atmosphere of his agency. When he is planted in a company at a blue-collar level, he dresses accordingly and blends in just as well. He will not specify what work he performs while undercover, but says the factory jobs he held in college gave him a feel for the work.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Blue-collar placements are easier and less expensive, say those in the private-security business. ''You have to be realistic,'' said Mr. Taylor of Professional Law Enforcement. ''It is tough for me to get an undercover and bring him in as vice president.'' One upper-level investigation, he recalls, was canceled when company managers calculated the cost of simulating a single executive's life style.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: This is not to say that the 1st Security agent has never contributed to white-collar arrests. Once, he says, his work led to the arrest of someone at a ''considerably'' higher level.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: His usual blue-collar placement, he says, lasts from four to six months. The idea is to ''observe everything you can,'' beginning with the initial job interviews and orientation - ''make mental notes, see where people congregate and what they're doing.'' Once, a supervisor taking him on a tour pointed out the best places to use drugs or to escape from work. On another tour, he heard workers repeatedly ask the whereabouts of the same person. ''It could have been nothing,'' he said. ''But it turned out this guy was dealing.''
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: The personnel department that hired him and the supervisors who evaluate him are rarely notified of the new employee's true role. That is usually known only to the chief executive and the head of security.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: If co-workers question him about his life, he lies by omission. ''Most of the time, when people start asking me about myself, I answer vaguely, I turn it around. Most people like to talk about themselves.'' To cultivate an image as a frivolous worker and serious drug user, he adopts a lackadaisical style, measuring his success by the number of times he is ''told to do more work'' by supervisors.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: He tries to make friends with drug users and drug dealers as quickly as possible without raising suspicion. It is the drug dealers he is after. The policy at 1st Security is to pursue multiple-occurrence dealers, since it makes a stronger case. Typically he spends several months in an office or factory before observing drug buys or setting up his own buys.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: He likes his work, and does not deny that he finds the intrigue exciting. ''You go two or three months with nothing happening, but when the case comes together like you want it to, it's very exciting,'' he said.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: If he hears people talking about getting high outside of work, he considers it out of his jurisdiction. He would pursue, however, related workplace crimes - theft to finance drug use, for example.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Private security companies vary in how far they stray from the focus on drugs. ''We report activities such as time-clock theft,'' said Mr. Newman of Security Associates. On the other hand, he says, his company's contracts preclude any reporting on organized labor activities or attempts to organize a union.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Mr. Taylor of Professional Law Enforcement says that drug investigations are ''like turning over a rock. We have found everything from murder-for-hire to organized prostitution - all in a corporate setting.''
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Like operatives at most of these security companies, the agent from 1st Security bases his case on detailed notes. He does not write anything down at work. Indeed, he does not bring his notebook. He writes up his observations every night as soon as he gets home.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: It is all part of the 10-hour days he puts in for an annual salary that ranges from $25,000 to $30,000. He is paid by the client company for his blue-collar job, and this is supplemented by 1st Security, which charges an average weekly fee of $1,000 for an undercover operation.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: A few times a week, the agent is debriefed by 1st Security, which also reviews and types his notes. The diary - usually about six to eight pages for every week on the job - becomes an evidentiary report to be used later in court if any arrests are made. Typically, his debriefings are limited to 1st Security personnel, but ''that is not to say there won't be a meeting in a hotel between the investigator and the client,'' Mr. Curran said.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Aside from the details, the agent has come to some general conclusions. Why people take drugs on the job, for instance: ''In large part, to break up the monotony of going in day after day.'' Where they do it: ''The men's room is the biggest place. You walk in, close the stall and you're all by yourself.'' (For the most part, his investigations have led to arrests of men. He can recall only one prosecution involving a woman.) If he obtains drugs without actively looking, the agent avoids some dangers, including being charged with entrapment. But if the investigation is slow or if he needs hard evidence, he is provided with drug money and sent to make a buy. ''I would go to somebody I knew was dealing and say 'there's a party coming up, I could really use some stuff,' '' he said.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Paydays were the big days for drug trafficking, he says. On a typical payday in one military plant, he would watch $20,000 change hands in a flurry of cocaine deals.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: To make drug buys in Massachusetts, an agency must be licensed and must seek the ''supervision and instruction of law enforcement,'' said Mr. Curran. Law enforcement officers seem happy to help. Their own resources are far too limited for corporate undercover work, they say. ''There is no way the local police could do this job,'' said Scott Harshbarger, District Attorney for Middlesex County in Massachusetts.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: The agent at 1st Security almost always bought small quantities of cocaine - the most prevalent drug at the places he infiltrated. Usually he spent $50 to $100, money provided by the client company or 1st Security.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: He sometimes faced the bane of every drug agent: the prohibition against taking the drug himself if he wanted to make his case stick later. Many dealers know this rule and require buyers to consume a small quantity of the drug as proof that they are not undercover operatives.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: The agent has been trained to simulate drug use, by breathing in through his nose while holding a marijuana cigarette to his lips, for example. The drug simulation exercises were part of four six-hour lessons provided to the agency, free of charge, by state police, the Boston Police Department and the Drug Enforcement Agency.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Before he joined 1st Security, the agent's perception of detective work was drawn from the distorted lens of television. He believed the cliches of trench coats, shootouts and car chases. He thought private investigators spent their days ''chasing somebody's wife because she was having an affair.'' He grew up dreaming of becoming a police officer, majoring in sociology at a New England state college, with a concentration in criminology.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Now, as an internal training consultant at 1st Security - the promotion came a few months ago - he spends most of his time training other agents. Among other things, he looks for applicants who can withstand the pressure in a natural fashion. ''You can't bring in somebody who is going to cry at the drop of a hat or somebody with the attitude that they are tough as nails. You need somebody in between,'' he said.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Mr. Newman of Security Associates would add another ingredient, namely ''the personality and character to do this.'' He looks for ''do-gooders,'' he said, ''people who feel they are contributing to the good.''
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Many recruits at 1st Security are ''lost by the wayside'' because of past drug use, Mr. Curran said. But limited past use does not disqualify an applicant.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: When the agent was asked if he had used drugs before working for 1st Security, he declined to answer. ''I'd rather not say, I'd just rather not,'' he said. Mr. Curran said former drug use by current employees is ''a very intense subject'' and that all personnel are instructed to avoid comment on the subject.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Caution is the agent's constant companion now. ''It's just a habit,'' he says, about his practice of scanning a room before entering. ''I always scan the area.'' If somebody calls and asks for him by his first name only, even at home, ''I ask who they're calling and why. If I really don't recognize them, I say it's a wrong number.''
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: He shreds his mail. ''Even if I get junk mail, I shred it and throw it away, because everything at work is shredded.'' A stranger on a plane would hear that he works as a commercial real-estate broker. ''I second-guess anybody who asks me about myself,'' he said.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: It is rare that he confuses his two lives, he says, but fully separating them is not an easy task. ''It is like acting. You always keep thinking who you are with,'' he said. His double existence is known only to his colleagues and his closest relatives.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: A couple of old friends from his youth in New York are his only intimates outside of his undercover-agent network. He doesn't socialize with co-workers at placements (his own rule) and doesn't date women he meets there (1st Security's rule). When a co-worker asked him for a date once, he invented a story of a fictitious girlfriend in a distant city and politely refused.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: He says he is content not to make friends with the crowd he cultivates at his placements. ''No one I was ever involved with was a great guy and just slipped to that one point of dealing drugs.'' Most of his friends, he says, ''are people from 1st or people who used to work for 1st.''
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: And that's the way his supervisors planned it. Private undercover investigations are not years long, like some Government operations, where investigators may come to sympathize with their targets, Mr. Curran says. One reason the company puts a time limit on operations, he said, is to allow agents ''to bond to their peers in our company rather than the associates in the place of employment.''
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: The agent is confident about his ability to maintain his cover at his placement. He doesn't carry a weapon. ''If you're always afraid of that, you couldn't be in this business,'' he said.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: But dangers arise. Four days into one assignment, the agent was confronted by a group of suspicious co-workers who accused him of being a ''narc.'' He laughed, he said, and talked about how he had ''had a wild weekend, did a lot of coke, smoked a lot of dope.''
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: He also directly denied the accusation. ''A lot of people think if they ask you if you're an undercover cop, you have to say yes,'' he said. ''That couldn't be further from the truth.''
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Four months later, the agent's supervisors determined that he had gathered sufficient evidence. Police and 1st Security supervisors rounded up the suspected workers and charged them with drug trafficking.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: To allay suspicion, the agent was also arrested. But once jailed, he was quickly separated from the others under the pretense that he had outstanding arrest warrants for more serious charges in a different state. If the co-workers were unsure who was spying on them, they learned in court, where the agent was the star witness for the prosecution.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: Punishments differ widely from company to company for those identified as drug users and drug dealers. In the cases the agent has handled, dealers have been prosecuted while users have generally been allowed to retain their jobs if they attend drug counseling sessions.
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: The agent says he has no qualms about testifying against people who believed he was their friend. ''I keep in the back of my mind that I was not put in there to be somebody's best friend,'' he said. ''I did not feel bad at all for what I did. If anything, I feel sorry because they got themselves in that predicament.''
title: Undercover in Corporate America

text: LEAD: JANET W., who is pregnant and has a history of drug abuse, is typical of many young women in their late teens or early 20's showing up in increasing numbers at the Island's major hospitals.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: JANET W., who is pregnant and has a history of drug abuse, is typical of many young women in their late teens or early 20's showing up in increasing numbers at the Island's major hospitals.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Local health care professionals are troubled by the growing number of such women, now estimated at 11 percent of those giving birth in urban areas. Some say the figures are even higher in areas where crack, cocaine's cheap and abundant derivative, is common.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: While it is difficult to document the exact numbers of affected births, hospital authorities say that about half the newborns screened for controlled substances test positive. In the last three years the number of infants considered at risk and screened at Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow, one of the island's major referral hospitals, has more than tripled, from 72 to more than 250 of the nearly 3,000 babies born there each year.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Hospital authorities screen all infants considered at risk, based upon mothers' histories or infants' behavior.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Women like Janet often say, ''The minute I found out I was pregnant, I stopped doing drugs.'' But Valerie DiPalma, a Suffolk County public health nurse, said that these women say whatever is useful at the moment, often despite evidence of many different drugs in their urine.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: She said that at least 80 percent of the 35 referrals she makes each month from Stony Brook University Hospital for newborn follow-up visits involve mothers with a history of drug use.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Dr. Harriet Boxer of Nassau County Medical Center said that about half the mothers of infants on her 28-bed unit are referred to the county's Department of Social Services, either because they have a history of drug abuse or their baby's urine tested positive for drugs in the first 24 hours of life.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Physicians, nurses and social workers at the Island's major hospitals are concerned not just for the women but for their infants, many of whom are born addicted. Since heroin's replacement by cocaine as the major drug of abuse, addiction is harder to detect, with the result that hospital personnel frequently learn of a woman's drug abuse too late in her pregnancy to intervene.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Many addicts' babies are put into the hospitals' neonatal intensive care units. Dr. Harriet Boxer of Nassau County Medical Center said that about half the infants on her 28-bed unit either were born to a woman with a history of drug abuse or tested positive for drugs in the first 24 hours of life.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: ''We're having too many surprises,'' said Dr. Joanne Woodle, a specialist in prenatal and postpartum problems, who spoke of the difficulties of identifying and handling addicted mothers and their newborns at a recent Child and Family Studies seminar at SUNY Stony Brook.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: She described cocaine's damaging effects during the final months of pregnancy, when it disrupts blood flow from the mother through the placenta, causing strokes and other neurological damage in the baby.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Once cocaine crosses the placental barrier it becomes more concentrated, circulating through the fetus and its amniotic fluid until birth. In this form, the drug takes longer to clear the newborn's system than the mother's. ''By the time of birth, the baby is much more addicted than the mom,'' said Dr. Woodle.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Although methadone is less harmful than heroin to pregnant women, babies whose mothers used it may suffer more severe withdrawal symptoms. In extreme cases, methadone and heroin addicts' babies suffer tremors and sometimes seizures. ''Unless treated, they literally crawl up the walls of the isolettes,'' said North Shore University Hospital neonatologist, Dr. Rita Harper.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Babies born to untreated addicts show signs of withdrawal within a few hours of birth. Cocaine and heroin addicts' babies are usually wide-eyed and very irritable. They cry or scream often, sleep little and may have trouble gaining weight because of excessive activity.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Addicts' babies are also much more likely to be premature, undersized and have difficulties in sucking, swallowing and breathing.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: They tremble constantly, unless wrapped securely in blankets and maintained on a high dose of a sedative such as phenobarbital, from which they are later gradually withdrawn.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Long after withdrawal they are likely to remain irritable and fussy. And while no one can yet predict the end result of drug-taking during pregnancy, many fear a generation of developmentally delayed children in the offing.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Early intervention is the key to protecting children from the short-term and possibly permanent damage that may result from mothers' drug use. But during the first three months, when the fetus is most vulnerable, a woman may be unaware that she is pregnant. Unless drug use is eliminated or reduced early in pregnancy, it must be maintained until delivery because of the hazards that drug withdrawal poses to the unborn child.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Most pregnant drug abusers get little or no prenatal care. Rosemary McNerney, a nurse practitioner at Nassau County Medical Center, said a woman's arrival at the obstetrics clinic late in pregnancy often signals suspicions of drug abuse.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: She told of one patient, 30 weeks pregnant, who awoke from heavy cocaine use to find that she was hemorrhaging. ''She thought she was dying, so she came to the hospital,'' she said.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Hospitals attempt to screen clinic patients by asking direct questions about past and present drug use during the intake process, viewing even those who disclaim it with skepticism. In a sentiment echoed by others Dr. Boxer said, ''We're suspicious of everyone who walks in.''
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Richard Zano, child abuse coordinator at Stony Brook, said some women conceal drug use in pregnancy out of shame, or because their drug habits make them less than truthful. They may also fear removal of the child by the county's Child Protective Services, because of publicity about such removals in Nassau County.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: For in addition to giving care to pregnant drug abusers and their infants, hospitals are involved in the process of assessing the women's potential for child abuse or neglect.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: State law requires hospitals to report a newborn's positive drug test to a child abuse registry. Local child protective services then have 24 hours to investigate whether the child is in ''imminent danger'' because of the mother's drug use.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Confusion over the counties' concerns for the safety of such children has resulted from a lack of uniform policy on Long Island. Nassau County, like New York City, considers drug use in pregnancy as evidence of potential for child abuse or neglect and immediately asks the mother to grant emergency custody of her newborn, pending a hearing and investigation.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: If she refuses, the county petitions family court for such custody. Nassau County conducted about 60 emergency removals in 1988, touching off several lawsuits and much publicity.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Suffolk County's policy, on the other hand, is first to conduct an investigation, making physical contact with the mother to determine her situation, rather than automatically asking for emergency custody.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: The county tries to work with the woman if she is at all motivated to seek help for her addiction. Social Services Commissioner William Bartsch said, ''We prefer to have the infant bond with the mother in the first crucial weeks.'' However, he acknowledged the county is removing more children as a result of drugs than 10 years ago, particularly because of crack.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: ''We have cases where a baby's addicted to crack and the mother's not accepting services,'' said Meg O'Regan, Suffolk County deputy attorney. ''Then we petition to remove.'' But she said that automatic seizure is ''mother-blaming'' and doesn't give the mother an opportunity to respond to help.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: In addition to the threat of losing custody of her child, the parenting ability of a mother who has abused drugs in pregnancy is also adversely affected, especially by cocaine, which Dr. Woodle said ''poses the need to challenge not just a drug but a lifestyle.''
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: She added that many women are multidrug users, abusing anti-anxiety drugs such as Valium, as well as alcohol, marijuana and ''whatever's the designer drug this year.''
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Harry Simeon, who runs a Nassau County drug and alcohol addiction program at Nassau County Medical Center, said in contrast to heroin addicts, cocaine users get extremely depressed, rather than sick, when they're not using the drug.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: One worry is that an addicted mother who leaves the hospital before her drug withdrawal is evident may develop a serious, even suicidal, depression once she is home with the baby.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: While pregnant women addicted to heroin can be maintained on controlled doses of methadone, no such substitute exists for cocaine.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: The situation is aggravated by the lack of publicity about the effects of crack on the unborn and the tendency of drug abusers not to consider the consequences of their drug use, or to disbelieve warnings. Dr. Woodle said that although such women express concern for their infants and are distressed to see them in withdrawal, their impulsive, escapist personalities and lack of coping skills make them at risk for child abuse, especially when they must deal with irritable, damaged babies.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: While early identification and intervention is recognized as one way to prevent child abuse and other consequences of mothers' drug problems, few programs exist that address these women's needs.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: One exception is North Shore's 15-year-old Family and Maternity Development Program, directed by Dr. Harper, which attempts to identify addicted mothers as early in pregnancy as possible and follows them for two years after the child's birth. The women receive individual counseling as well as assistance with housing, transportation and family problems.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: But Dr. Harper cautioned against comparing the 40 to 60 women in her voluntary program with those for whom treatment is mandated. She was referring to what Mr. Simeon and others called the ''carrot and stick'' approach, which requires mothers whose babies test positive for drugs at birth to seek treatment, or risk losing custody of them.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Even supporters of this approach acknowledge its flaws. Once a woman agrees to go for drug counseling and shows up for an appointment, Mr. Zano said, the legal requirement is fulfilled. However, there is no guarantee that she will continue, he said.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Mr. Simeon said that the ''carrot and stick'' effect of mandated treatment was weakened by time lags in investigations by child-protective workers and by confidentiality restrictions on communications between drug-treatment and social workers.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Others pointed to the inconsistency of using hospital test results to threaten removal of a newborn, but not of other children the woman may have.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: By law, hospitals must report positive test results to the state's Child Abuse Registry. Local child-protective services have 24 hours to investigate whether concerns for the baby's safety warrant a petition to Family Court for emergency removal of the child.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Many concerned caregivers said that hospitals should routinely screen all newborns for drugs to identify mothers in need of help. But even those who support the idea cautioned that it was not the ultimate answer.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: ''It might open a real Pandora's box,'' Dr. Boxer said. ''The Medical Examiner's office would be overwhelmed by 3,000 tests.''
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Some feared that universal screening posed a threat to women's rights and might produce misleading test results in babies whose mothers had smoked marijuana to hasten labor, a common practice, or had eaten poppy seeds, which produce a substance that can cause a false-positive test result.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: While Long Island's major hospitals play a limited role once an addicted mother is identified, many professionals said there was a critical need to get pregnant drug users into prenatal care and drug-treatment programs.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: The biggest problem is the lack of programs both for pregnant addicts and for the women whose newborns are so vulnerable.
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Citing long waiting periods, Paul McCrans, Suffolk County's director of Child Protective Services, said, ''There is an acute shortage of in-patient treatment programs anywhere on Long Island, even when the woman is motivated.''
title: Mothers on Drugs, Addicts at Birth

text: Twenty-eight Federal prosecutors in Massachusetts urged the resignation or removal of their boss, United States Attorney Frank L. McNamara Jr., today in a letter to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh.
title: Assistants Urge the Removal Of U.S. Attorney in Boston

text: The letter's signers are among 39 assistant United States attorneys in the Boston and Springfield offices under Mr. McNamara's command.
title: Assistants Urge the Removal Of U.S. Attorney in Boston

text: Mr. McNamara, 41 years old, a Republican appointed by President Ronald Reagan in 1987, has come under criticism since November when the Justice Department said it could not substantiate his assertion that he saw his predecessor, William F. Weld, smoke marijuana at a party. 'Loss of Confidence'
title: Assistants Urge the Removal Of U.S. Attorney in Boston

text: ''Mr. McNamara's conduct and performance while United States Attorney is resulting in a loss of confidence in the administration of justice on the part of the courts, the bar, law enforcement agencies and the public,'' the letter said. ''Because Mr. McNamara will neither resign nor step aside temporarily, the credibility and operations of this office will continue to be damaged, perhaps irretrievably, unless he is removed.''
title: Assistants Urge the Removal Of U.S. Attorney in Boston

text: Mr. McNamara did not return telephone calls to his office. In the past he has refused to comment on the accusations, although he has denied impropriety in his remarks about Mr. Weld.
title: Assistants Urge the Removal Of U.S. Attorney in Boston

text: Boston newspapers have said Mr. McNamara has been the subject of several Federal investigations.
title: Assistants Urge the Removal Of U.S. Attorney in Boston

text: Citing anonymous sources, The Boston Globe said today that the Justice Department is looking into whether a relationship between Mr. McNamara and the President of the state Senate, William Bulger, had any effect on an investigation of real estate development in Boston.
title: Assistants Urge the Removal Of U.S. Attorney in Boston

text: The Boston Herald, also citing an unidentified source, said Mr. McNamara's staff did not tell him about the case because they were afraid he would use it to embarrass Gov. Michael S. Dukakis during the Democrat's Presidential campaign. 'Embarrassment for Months'
title: Assistants Urge the Removal Of U.S. Attorney in Boston

text: On Thursday, The Globe reported that assessments by two Federal agencies of Mr. McNamara's performance have led Mr. Thornburgh to conclude Mr. McNamara should resign.
title: Assistants Urge the Removal Of U.S. Attorney in Boston

text: Governor Dukakis said today: ''The situation has been an embarrassment for months and months and months. I don't think this appointment should ever have been made.''
title: Assistants Urge the Removal Of U.S. Attorney in Boston

text: Governor Dukakis himself has been a target of Mr. McNamara. According to published reports, Mr. McNamara pressed an investigation into possible conflict of interest in the state's purchase of land for a new prison in New Braintree even after his staff told him there was no evidence.
title: Assistants Urge the Removal Of U.S. Attorney in Boston

text: Representative Barney Frank, a Massachusetts Democrat, suggested that if the Justice Department did not act, ''then I think hearings will be necessary'' in Congress.
title: Assistants Urge the Removal Of U.S. Attorney in Boston

text: The Supreme Court ruled today that the police do not need a search warrant to conduct low-altitude helicopter searches of private property.
title: Supreme Court Roundup; Copter Search Without a Warrant Is Upheld

text: The 5-to-4 decision allowed Florida prosecutors to use evidence garnered by a police helicopter that flew 400 feet over a greenhouse in which marijuana plants were visible through a partly dismantled roof. The ruling overturned a decision by the Florida Supreme Court, which had held that the flight was an unconstitutional search.
title: Supreme Court Roundup; Copter Search Without a Warrant Is Upheld

text: The decision today was an extension of a ruling three years ago, in which the Justices permitted a warrantless search by an airplane flying at 1,000 feet. The rationale then was that since aircraft commonly fly over private property at such altitudes, no one could reasonably expect property visible to the unaided eye from such a flight to remain shielded from view.
title: Supreme Court Roundup; Copter Search Without a Warrant Is Upheld

text: Since low-level helicopter flights are a less common occurrence, the question for the Court today was whether a landowner could reasonably expect privacy from that type of aerial intrusion. No Majority on Rationale
title: Supreme Court Roundup; Copter Search Without a Warrant Is Upheld

text: While five Justices agreed that the flight was constitutionally permissible, there was no majority agreement on a rationale.
title: Supreme Court Roundup; Copter Search Without a Warrant Is Upheld

text: Justice Byron R. White, in a plurality opinion joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy, relied primarily on the fact that the flight was within the airspace legally available to helicopters under Federal regulations.
title: Supreme Court Roundup; Copter Search Without a Warrant Is Upheld

text: While fixed-wing aircraft may generally fly no lower than 500 feet, there are no lower limits for helicopters. ''There is no indication that such flights are unheard of in Pasco County, Fla.,'' Justice White said. He also noted that the flight had revealed ''no intimate details'' of life on the property.
title: Supreme Court Roundup; Copter Search Without a Warrant Is Upheld

text: In a separate opinion, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor agreed that the search was constitutional but said Justice White's opinion placed too much emphasis on the fact that the helicopter was in legal airspace. Flights at lower altitudes than the 400 feet in this case, she said, ''may be sufficiently rare that police surveillance from such altitudes would violate reasonable expectations of privacy despite compliance with F.A.A. air safety regulations.''
title: Supreme Court Roundup; Copter Search Without a Warrant Is Upheld

text: In a dissenting opinion, Justice William J. Brennan said that under the plurality's approach, ''the expectation of privacy is defeated if a single member of the public could conceivably position herself to see into the area in question without doing anything illegal.''
