He said there was a ''lack of any meaningful limit'' to the type of search the opinion would authorize.
title: Supreme Court Roundup; Copter Search Without a Warrant Is Upheld

text: Justices Harry A. Blackmun, Thurgood Marshall and John Paul Stevens also dissented in the case, Florida v. Riley. The Court also took these actions today: Tanker Operators Lose Suit on Bombing Raid The Court ruled that the Liberian owner and operator of an oil tanker could not use the Federal courts to sue the Government of Argentina for the tanker's loss in a bombing raid in the 1982 Argentine-British war in the Falkland Islands.
title: Supreme Court Roundup; Copter Search Without a Warrant Is Upheld

text: The decision, which was unanimous in most respects, overturned a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York. That court ruled that the ship's operators were entitled to invoke the jurisdiction of United States courts, even though the United States was not involved in the case, because the Federal courts are authorized to hear certain international disputes.
title: Supreme Court Roundup; Copter Search Without a Warrant Is Upheld

text: The Justice Department had urged the Court to overrule that decision on the ground that there would be ''substantial adverse foreign policy consequences'' to opening Federal courthouses to such cases. In an opinion by Chief Justice Rehnquist, the Court agreed with the Justice Department that a Federal law, the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act, barred this type of lawsuit. (Argentine Republic v. Amerada Hess). Court Refuses to Hear Vanessa Redgrave Appeal Without comment, the Court refused to hear an appeal by Vanessa Redgrave, the British actress, of a lower court ruling that dismissed her lawsuit against the Boston Symphony Orchestra. The lawsuit stemmed from the symphony's cancellation, in 1982, of a contract calling for Miss Redgrave to narrate several performances in Boston and New York. The actress has been an outspoken supporter of Palestinian rights, and the symphony said it received threats of violence and a possible riot if she appeared.
title: Supreme Court Roundup; Copter Search Without a Warrant Is Upheld

text: Miss Redgrave received a $27,500 fee for the broken contract but had sought potentially far higher damages under a Massachusetts civil rights law. But the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit ruled last August that the law did not permit courts to second-guess ''the aesthetic judgments of artists,'' a reference to the symphony's argument that it had the right to cancel the concerts as a matter of its own ''artistic integrity.'' (Redgrave v. Boston Symphony).
title: Supreme Court Roundup; Copter Search Without a Warrant Is Upheld

text: CONNECTICUT Q & A: CAPT. JAMES M. MOONEY
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: CAPT. JAMES M. MOONEY of the State Police, has headed the Statewide Narcotics Task Force, a cooperative effort between state and local police officers, for the last five of its 11 years. In that time he has seen some dramatic changes in drug use in Connecticut.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: For instance, the first time crack was found in Connecticut was in Stamford, in October 1986. Since then, it has become one of the most widely used drugs in the state.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: In an interview at his office in Meriden, Captain Mooney, who is 47 years old, discussed his work, the increase of drug abuse and the difficulties in controlling drug trafficking. Here are some excerpts from the conversation:
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: Q. What is the drug of choice in Connecticut these days?
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A. Cocaine, absolutely. We're seeing more. We're seizing more. We're seeing some pretty dramatic changes in the marketing of it. The price has come down considerably at the wholesale level, and the quality of the drug at the street level has gone up quite dramatically.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: We've seen cocaine go from $2,500 an ounce down to $1,200, and in lower Fairfield County we've paid as little as $600 an ounce. And the gram size, which is the size of most street sales, used to be 16 or 18 percent purity. Now we're seeing 30 or 32 percent purity.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: Q. Are you seeing more overdoses as a result?
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A. That's what started us on it. A year ago in May, Wayne Carver, the Deputy State Medical Examiner, picked up on an increase in overdose deaths. He did some toxicological work and called us all together. We looked at 27 or 28 deaths, and all but three of them had cocaine and heroin in their blood. We think they were recreational users, mixing heroin and coke, what we call a speedball. None of them were classic street junkies.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: Q. Where do Connecticut's drugs come from?
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A. Our major supply comes right out of New York City. It's a major import area for the East Coast, and our close proximity is what makes our job so difficult. Every guy here with $1,000, he makes a run to New York City and he's a drug dealer. You can buy a vial of crack in the city for $6, and here it's selling for $10 or $15. He can easily double his money, depending on who he's selling to. If it's a local street kid, he isn't going to pay $15. If it's a kid driving a BMW, he might pay $18.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A big problem we're having in New London is they jump on Amtrak down in the city, come to New London for the day, then get back on the train and go home.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: Q. Are drug dealers getting younger?
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A. We're seeing them 14, 15 years old. One guy we grabbed for the third time recently, had 30, 40 vials of crack on him. He's 15. What the dealers are doing is they're sitting inside and putting the juveniles on the street. Either they give the juvenile nothing or they give them a real small stash. The problem is, with our system, the juveniles are right back out, and of course the dealer knows that. And these kids are making $100, $150, $200 a day.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: Q. Is there any estimate on the extent of the drug market in the state?
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A. I don't have any kind of a handle on it. The Feds have made some estimates, and their estimates are it's as much as a $100 billion a year retail business in the country.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: Q. How much are seizures up?
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A. Pretty significantly. We're up over $12 million in street value last year, compared with $8 million the year before. We had a 50 percent increase in new cases, a 20 percent increase in arrest warrants, and our cash seizures jumped from $641,000 to more than a million dollars.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: Q. How much of the drugs are either grown or manufactured synthetically in Connecticut?
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A. So far, we haven't run across the synthetic heroin in the state. It started out in California and so far there have been only some minor seizures of it coming in as close as Pennsylvania.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: How much is grown? Well, the price of marijuana has gone up. Two years ago we were buying domestic marijuana for $450 a pound. Today the wholesale price for marijuana is $1,200 or $1,400 a pound. I think what's happened is the big Federal push in the southeastern United States has had a serious effect on marijuana importation. That's put pressure on the market, and we're starting to see a cottage industry. We can show you huge hydroponic systems and artificial lighting. You get a decent plant and you can pull a pound-and-a-half off. You sell in wholesale lots and you can make a couple thousand dollars off one plant.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: Q. Are the price and availability of other drugs, like hallucinogenics and amphetamines, increasing?
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A. We're seeing very little in hallucinogenics for the last three years, although in the last year we've seen a resurgence of it in the Norwalk-Fairfield area. We've worked with the Westport Police Department on a case. Acid was hot years ago, but that generation saw what happened, their friends got burned out and they got turned off. But now that generation is over 30, and the college kids today don't believe them, so we're starting to see a slight increase. Speed - it's out there, but we're seeing very little.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: Q. Is drug use on the rise on college campuses?
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A. No, I don't think so. Our experience is it's going down and the reason it's going down is public awareness, public education.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: Q. Speaking of public awareness, are drug users turning away from self-injected drugs because of the fear of acquired immune deficiency syndrome?
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A. We haven't noticed that. Unfortunately, the bulk of the IV drug abusers in the urban area is the hardest audience to get to.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: Q. Do you tell children to ''Just Say No?''
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A. It's more complicated than ''Just Say No,'' but I truly believe education and awareness are the answers. We have our own public education section we developed on a grant about three years ago. We supply departments with a book that has information on dope, and we keep updating it with changes and trends. All kinds of audiovisual material, handouts.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: We've got display kits with paraphernalia in five locations around the state. They reached almost 60,000 people last year. And this year, we took on responsibility for DARE training, for Drug Abuse Resistance Education. It's hot, it's the premier substance abuse program, including alcohol and cigarettes.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: Q. How are most of your cases developed?
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A. From informants. You get information from mothers and others, but you can't call me up and say ''my name's Jennie Mullane and the guy next door, Bob Smith, is selling dope.'' That's not enough to get a search warrant on. We need to get an undercover officer in to make a hand to hand sale, or get an informant to go in. We search him before he goes in, grab him as soon as he comes out, and if he's got dope he didn't have when he went in, we know where he got it.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: The motivation for informants is across the board. The best informant in the world is an ex-wife. There's money, there's trying to knock out the competition, there's revenge by the guy who got beat up in a bar by a dealer.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: Q. Why are there so many crimes associated with crack?
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A. That's a question for a sociologist. But what we see on the street, when you're talking about the violent crime, you're usually talking about the user who becomes paranoid and violent. Drive-by shootings, now, have been to establish turf, to settle who sells on what corner.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: Q. Are you frustrated by the early release programs that let drug dealers out?
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A. A drug dealer is usually a nonviolent guy. If it's a question of letting a mugger out, or a murderer, or a rapist, or a drug dealer, I have to agree with them. And we have to let them out.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: Q. Are we winning the war on drugs?
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A. I don't think so. I think it's going to take a real long-term, multi-faceted program. The analogy I always use when I'm talking to the General Assembly or the public is look what we've done with cigarette smoking. Look what we did with drunken driving. We started what, 20 years ago with cigarettes? And we're making progress.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: You're never going to eliminate it entirely, but maybe we can reduce the percentage of our public that abuses substances to the point where we can deal with it. It's going to take a lot of education, with programs geared to those as young as kindergarten through grade five. We have to reach the parents. And at this point in time we've got to continue enforcement. That doesn't mean that at some point we shouldn't look at decriminalization, but for now we've got other things to do. And if we stay with enforcement, it should be targeted at the dealer.
title: 'We've Got to Continue Enforcement'

text: A 12-year-old girl who was talking with a group of friends less than a block from her home was shot and killed Friday evening when she inadvertently walked into a drug-related dispute on a sidewalk in Brooklyn, the police said.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: The block where she was shot is known in the neighborhood as ''a crack-infested shooting gallery,'' a resident of the Flatbush section said yesterday.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: ''We hear shooting almost every night,'' a woman said. ''If I could move, I would.''
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: The girl, Kashaine Green, was shot in the neck about 7:20 P.M. when someone suddenly opened fire with an automatic weapon in front of 531 East 22d Street. She was the third innocent bystander to be slain on New York City streets in the first three weeks of 1989. Gunman Apparently Missed Aim
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: On Jan. 3, Jeffrey Vilain, 14, was caught in the middle of a gun battle between a police officer and a suspected robber in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: And on Jan. 13, Tondelayo Alfred, 18, was accidentally killed by a gunman in a McDonald's in Flatbush.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: When Kashaine and a 14-year-old boy, also a bystander, were struck, the police said, the gunman was apparently shooting at someone else.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: The boy, who was identified by Kings County Hospital Center officials as Stephen O'Neill, was hit in the mouth. He was listed in fair condition. Stumbled Into Apartment
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: Neighbors said yesterday that they heard as many as 10 shots. Somehow after being hit, Kashaine was able to stumble away from the shooting scene and into a friend's apartment around the corner at 2215 Newkirk Avenue.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: The police arrived and took the girl to the hospital, where she died at 10 P.M.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: The 14-year-old boy, neighbors said, ran into 531 East 22d Street, banging on doors for help, leaving a trail of blood.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: Drug dealers and their customers frequently gather in front of the six-story building and on cold days even do business inside the lobby, said the building superintendent, Delinor Benoit, 31.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: ''I'm leaving this place,'' Mr. Benoit said yesterday, as he swept up a pile of trash in the lobby. Among the trash were several packets used to hold marijuana.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: At least four bullet holes were in the building's heavy front door and inside its yellow lobby.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: Kashaine, a junior high school student who lived at 2225 Ditmas Avenue, was on her way to a friend's house on Ocean Avenue when she walked into the gunfire.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: The friend on Ocean Avenue, Felix Avila, 15, said Kashaine usually avoided East 22d Street between Ditmas and Newkirk Avenues because of the trafficking in drugs, mostly crack.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: Felix said he was playing basketball, waiting for Kashaine to arrive, when he heard the shots.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: ''It sounded like a Tech-9,'' he said, referring to a small machine pistol. ''It's a baby Uzi.'' The police recovered an Uzi submachine gun from the scene.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: Friends said Kashaine and her friends were walking on Newkirk Avenue when a girlfriend asked her to step around the corner - onto East 22d Street - for a moment of gossip. Then the shooting began. ''When the shooting started, they were so nervous they didn't know which way to run,'' said a neighbor, Barbara Williams, 21. ''So they ran right into it.''
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: Moments later, a police officer arrived. Kashaine tugged on his pants leg as if reaching for a life jacket.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: Felix, who said Kashaine had dreamed of becoming an artist, pulled out two color snapshots of Kashaine, smiling, a book bag slung over her shoulder.
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: On the back of one picture, Felix had printed in large black letters:
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: ''I LOVE YOU. 1-20-89 FRI.''
title: Bystander, 12, Shot and Killed In Drug Dispute

text: AIDS has come to Long Island. It's been here since nearly the beginning, of course, but much like the early turn of autumn leaves, few took notice. Indeed, the first Long Islanders who developed the disease had the good taste to be diagnosed in the pernicious anonymity of the Big City, only to return home for the family support most never received.
title: Aids Victims Suffer Enough Without Hostility

text: Now Long Island has its own AIDS population, the largest suburban group of this kind in the world. Unfortunately, its rank swells and gathers statistics like a wartime body count.
title: Aids Victims Suffer Enough Without Hostility

text: To those of us who treat these patients on a daily basis, the nightmare ended long ago. It is an all-too-sad reality that one of this earth's most prosperous and progressive enclaves has joined arm in arm with the shooting galleries of the South Bronx, the steam baths of San Francisco and the back streets of Kinshasa in Zaire.
title: Aids Victims Suffer Enough Without Hostility

text: Much like the 8 A.M. westbound L.I.E. or a closed South Shore beach on a humid July afternoon, AIDS has become another dragon on the flat landscape of our island. To call this progress is at best fatalistic, at worst a summoning of Armageddon.
title: Aids Victims Suffer Enough Without Hostility

text: As physicians specializing in the field of infectious diseases in the County of Nassau, we have seen hundreds of these mostly young people come to us, ride their personal roller coasters, and often - at times abruptly, most commonly in an agonizing danse macabre - disappear from this planet.
title: Aids Victims Suffer Enough Without Hostility

text: When I was growing up on Long Island, not that long ago and not very far from where I now work, the mere act of ''growing up'' often seemed like such a difficult task. Obstacles such as first dates, junior proms and final exams appeared next to insurmountable.
title: Aids Victims Suffer Enough Without Hostility

text: When the smell of marijuana began to permeate the classroom, many of us had acquired the psychosocial tools to deal with the immediate impact of decision-making. Unfortunately, many of us had acquired nothing, and it was this very void that later would be stuffed with all the misery and heartache that life could dish out.
title: Aids Victims Suffer Enough Without Hostility

text: Condoms were mere wallet ornaments meant to protect the ''bearer'' from little other than the powerful, though sadly imaginary, forces of sex. Their expiration dates came and went. Syphilis and gonorrhea (herpes had yet to enter our lexicon) were ills one earned, much like medals, by Army grunts out on some third-world furlough, to be treated and cured and bragged about while nursing a beer and caressing a tattoo in a Main Street tavern.
title: Aids Victims Suffer Enough Without Hostility

text: To say that times have changed would be too simple, for times always change. To say that we were innocent would be a tragic mistake. No generation is more innocent than the one that preceded it and no time, in and of itself, is better, or for that matter worse, than the time which came before it. Were it so, then our parents and their parents would have spawned a more evil, a more guilty generation.
title: Aids Victims Suffer Enough Without Hostility

text: In continuing this dark logic, we are destined to produce offspring who will continue to befoul this pure land we have left them. Perhaps the most dangerous aspect of this philosophy is that it would permit us (as it does many of us already) to label people with AIDS as guilty: recipients of their just deserts, paying their dues. How clean our consciences must be! But people with AIDS are no more guilty or innocent than we are, than we were when we smoked our first cigarette or drank our first can of beer.
title: Aids Victims Suffer Enough Without Hostility

text: Make no mistake, shooting drugs is not an innocent activity to be confused with having a drink. It must be condemned, prevented and treated. The issue is one of dignity. Many of the patients we see have long ago kicked their habits, cleaned up their lives.
title: Aids Victims Suffer Enough Without Hostility

text: What they most seek is support, compassion and the wish to keep the thin thread of hope intact. What they most often get is ostracism, rejection and indifference. With time they begin to condemn themselves, perhaps to be accepted, perhaps as a final act of confession. Having fulfilled the role of executioner, they now belatedly complete the role of jury as well.
title: Aids Victims Suffer Enough Without Hostility

text: And while some of these patients are not model citizens - unlike the rest of us - most are money earners, churchgoers, parents and children. They are the Long Islanders who people our streets, with whom we grew up and sat next to in class, with aspirations of split-level homes, box seats at Shea and riding down Jericho Turnpike in a souped-up convertible with the warm wind blowing through their hair and sending the rock tunes from the car radio to high heaven. But for an uncontrolled virus, cousin to the common cold, they could be us and we them.
title: Aids Victims Suffer Enough Without Hostility

text: Question: Can you give some indication to what extent snowboarding is allowed at ski areas in the Northeast and name some in Vermont? - R. J. P., Philadelphia
title: Q and A

text: Answer: About 70 percent of the Northeast's ski resorts now permit snowboarding (which is akin to surfboarding), and while some limit use of the boards to specific trails, many allow them on the entire mountain. Some no longer require certification of snowboarders by an instructor, and several offer lessons and packages that include rentals. Snowboard skiing made its first major impact in the East at Stratton, Vt., and the resort is among those offering races and instruction - a 90-minute group lesson is $18; board and boots rental, $22. A four-day snowboarding championship was due to be completed at Stratton today. Snowboard users are required to buy lift tickets, and among other Vermont areas that welcome snowboarders are: Bolton Valley, Bromley, Jay Peak, Magic Mountain, Maple Valley, Okemo, Pico, Smugglers' Notch, Stowe and Sugarbush. At Stowe, Mount Mansfield's four trails designated most difficult are off-limits to snowboarders. Stowe's Winter Carnival includes a snowboarding event for the first time; it is scheduled for today.
title: Q and A

text: In New Hampshire, the ski area attracting most snow boarders is Waterville Valley, where a package combines lift ticket, board rental and 90-minute group lesson for $32. Other resorts in the state offering lessons include Attitash, Gunstock, Loon and Mount Cranmore. Hunter Mountain in New York's northern Catskills introduced the sport this season, permits boarding all over and has just hired an instructor. Butternut Basin in Great Barrington, Mass., is among areas where snowboarders are required to obtain certification before taking to the trails. Europe's Trains
title: Q and A

text: Question: Is there an American agency that sells tickets for travelers who want to make train journeys in Scandinavia and other places in Europe that do not have railroad offices here? - E. A., Cleveland
title: Q and A

text: Answer: The railroads that have offices in the United States (in New York and other cities) - the French National Railroads, Germanrail, Italian State Railways and Swiss Federal Railways - issue tickets for journeys in Scandinavia and other countries in Western Europe. The French and German offices will issue tickets for Eastern Europe, but do not make reservations or book sleeping accommodations for journeys starting there. For Western Europe, the four offices point out that reserving seats is scarcely necessary because of the frequency of trains, generally ample space and computerized reservations systems. (Reservations are necessary for sleepers.) They say travelers might just as well make reservations on the spot. Indeed, in Switzerland for many years passengers could not make seat reservations, although recently the system introduced them on some inter-city lines. BritRail has an office in New York but, aside from its own network, it makes books journeys across the Channel to only a few places, including Channel ports and Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam. Along the Amazon
title: Q and A

text: Question: I'd like to tour the Amazon in May. Could you direct me to an agency that manages such tours? - S. M. S., Brooklyn
title: Q and A

text: Answer: Among many tour operators that can arrange such a trip to Brazil, Peru or Colombia or one combining the three countries is Ladatco Tours, 2220 Coral Way, Miami, Fla. 33145 (305-854-8422). Iquitos in Peru and the jungle town of Manaus in Brazil have the most options for stays in lodges and river trips, most of which are on Amazon tributaries. A 16-day Jungle Explorers' tour with Ladacto that includes a cruise from Iquitos to Leticia, Colombia, and a flight from there to Manaus and a cruise on a riverboat costs $1,789 a person for the land portion and cruises, with several meals and sightseeing included. The air fare, from Miami to Iquitos, from Leticia to Manaus and from there back to Miami is an additional $628.
title: Q and A

text: The Amazon programs of Brazil Nuts (79 Sanford Street, Fairfield, Conn. 06430; 800-553-9959 or 203-259-7900) concentrate on Manaus and Belem, Brazil. Most travelers, unless they have a scientific interest, find that four or five days are sufficient for an Amazon visit, a member of the company says, although it can arrange longer trips. A three-day, three-night cruise with Brazil Nuts from Manaus costs $450 a person, double occupancy (with a single supplement of $300), on a boat with cabins. A similar trip with passengers sleeping in hammocks has one rate - $295 a person. The rates include all meals for the three days and excursions from the boat, some in motorized canoes.
title: Q and A

text: Air fare is extra. Varig has a nonstop flight from Miami to Manaus every Wednesday and another from Miami to Belem every Sunday. A tour-based fare, bought in connection with land arrangements, is $458, round trip, in both cases. Regular fares are $650. But these two flights are not necessarily convenient for some tours. In Manaus, for example, the riverboat named Tuna leaves for three-night trips every Tuesday, the day before the Miami flight. However, there are daily flights from Rio de Janeiro.
title: Q and A

text: Similar programs as well as tours starting from Iquitos and in Ecuador are available with CanoAndes Expeditions (310 Madison Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017; 212-286-9415). Among the trips available from Iquitos is a seven-night river cruise to Tabatinga on the Brazilian border and back at a cost of $895 ($475 in a cabin without air-conditioning). In the Pacific
title: Q and A

text: Question: I believe there is a West Coast company that arranges visits for groups of veterans to World War II battlefields in the Pacific. Can you supply the name? - J. M., Brooklyn
title: Q and A

text: Answer: In the past 14 years many veterans' groups have visited the Marianas, Papua-New Guinea, the Solomons and other islands with Valor Tours, Schoonmaker Building, 10 Liberty Ship Way, Sausalito, Calif. 94966 (415-332-7850). Valor specializes in group tours that focus on the Pacific battlefields and also arranges travel for families. It organizes an annual visit each June to the Normandy beaches.
title: Q and A

text: An article on drug-testing technology in The Week in Review on Nov. 20 included an erroneous reference to ibuprofen, a drug used in some over-the-counter pain remedies. Manufacturers of drug testing equipment say that there is no indication that the drug can cause a false positive reading for marijuana.
title: Correction

text: The lawyer representing William Lozano, the city police officer whose fatal shooting of a black motorcyclist on Monday set off three days of racial violence here, said today that the officer acted in self-defense when the 500-pound vehicle came roaring toward him.
title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense

text: The lawyer, Roy Black, also said Mr. Lozano is not cooperating with the city authorities because he believes the city administration wants to use the officer as a scapegoat to appease blacks and salvage the city's civic image as thousands of visitors arrive for Sunday's Super Bowl game. Black Leaders Critical
title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense

text: ''Watching the way the wind is blowing, I can see him being set up as a scapegoat to take responsibility for this,'' Mr. Black said of race-related violence and looting that left six people injured, nearly 30 buildings fire damaged or destroyed and 351 arrested.
title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense

text: Mr. Black's comments drew almost immediate criticism from some of the city's black leaders, who have been urging calm since the violence broke out on the national holiday honoring the slain civil rights leader, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. ''The attorney's description of what happened is in direct conflict with eyewitness accounts that have been on television,'' said Dewey Knight, who recently retired as deputy Dade County manager and who was once the highest ranking black official in the Miami area. ''Witnesses have given statements that the motorcycle was proceeding on the road and not heading toward the officer, that the officer shot as the guy was passing by.''
title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense

text: Mr. Black, who successfully defended another city police officer who shot and killed a black man in 1982, touching off race-related violence, said he had yet to speak to witnesses of the shooting.
title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense

text: He referred to the driver of the motorcycle, Clement Lloyd, quoting a reference in The Miami Herald, as a twice-convicted drug dealer.
title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense

text: An examination of city records and those in Broward County, just north of Dade County, show Mr. Lloyd, a co-manager of a car wash, was convicted on cocaine and marijuana possession charges in 1985 and 1986. He served just over four months for both convictions, records show.
title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense

text: Today, life in this city of soaring skyscrapers and swaying palm trees began returning to normal. The police said there no reports of rock throwing, looting or arson. There were also no arrests. Many residents were quick to tell visitors that ''the trouble'' was isloated and the work of young hoodlums.
title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense

text: A computer check by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement of the 351 arrested in the violence found that 106 had police records. The computer check disclosed a total of 1,165 charges against the 106, many of them felonies, including murder, robbery and aggra vated assault, said a police spokesman, Ray Lang.
title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense

text: In the aftermath of the violence that occurred in the section of Overtown, Liberty City and black sections of Coconut Grove, four independent investigations are looking into the shooting that led to the violence and the underlying cause of the disturbance. But Mr. Lozano remains in his home, refusing to speak to anyone about the case except his lawyer.
title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense

text: The Colombian-born four-year veteran of the department, has refused to give senior police officials a statement detailing the shooting, a decision supported by Richard Kinne, the president of the Fraternal Order of Police. He said it is the group's position that a police officer, after using deadly force, first consult with a lawyer and then decide if he will speak with police investigators.
title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense

text: Based on police reports, Mr. Lozano fired a single shot at the speeding motorcyclist from his service-issued pistol. Mr. Lloyd, 23 years old, was struck once in the left temple and died immediately, Mr. Lang said.
title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense

text: A second man, Allan Blanchard, 24, also black and a passenger on the motorcyle, died a day later from injuries he sustained after being thrown into the path of an oncoming car when the motorcycle went out of control, the police said.
title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense

text: Mark Rubin, a lawyer representing Mr. Blanchard's family, called Mr. Black's assertion that Mr. Lozano acted in self-defense ''irresponsible.''
title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense

text: ''Nobody has a full understanding of the facts,'' he said in a telephone interview. ''I think it is irresponsible for any attorney to make such a statement before anyone knows what actually happened.''
title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense

text: Mr. Rubin said he is conducting his own investigation on behalf of Mr. Blanchard's family but refused to comment on what he had learned.
title: Attorney for Miami Officer Calls Shooting Self-Defense

text: By Robert Reinhold, Special To the New York Times
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: The 24-year-old man who opened fire on children in a schoolyard here Tuesday was a troubled loner full of hate who could not keep a job and had alcohol and drug problems, according to the portrait that is emerging from investigators and family members.
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: But nothing in the picture so far gives a good clue to what led the man, Patrick Edward Purdy, into the murderous rampage at the Cleveland Elementary School. He killed five Indochinese children and wounded 30 other people with an AK-47 assault rifle before committing suicide.
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: ''He did not leave us a message,'' the chief investigator, Capt. Dennis Perry of the Stockton Police Department, said today. ''Without that we'll never know exactly why he did what he did. In a way, he beat us because we'll never know.''
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: Investigators disputed suggestions that Mr. Purdy nursed a special dislike for Asians, saying that interviews with family members and co-workers showed he disliked everybody, particularly authority figures like police officers. He Drifted From Job to Job
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: ''Through his lifetime, Mr. Purdy developed a hate for everybody,'' Captain Perry said. ''He was a loner, had no friends, no particular girlfriends. As far as dislike for any one race, that is not a pattern that shows up.''
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: Federal records show that Mr. Purdy, sometimes using the alias Eddie Purdy West, had bought five new pistols since 1984, a period in which he was drifting from job to job in many cities. His most recent purchase was the 9-millimeter Taurus brand semiautomatic pistol that he used Tuesday to kill himself with a shot in the right temple.
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: An autopsy showed no signs of intravenous drug use, no tumors of the brain or thyroid. A toxicological report on possible drug or alcohol use was not expected until next week.
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: The 9-millimeter pistol was purchased at the Hunter Loan pawn shop in Stockton on Dec. 28, 1988, and picked up after the required 15-day waiting period Friday, four days before the shooting. A Long Arrest Record
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: He bought the assault rifle last Aug. 3 in Sandy, Ore., using the alias Patrick E. West. Apart from the use of the alias, the purchase was legal, since Mr. Purdy has never been convicted of a felony. Conviction of a misdemeanor does not disquality a person from purchasing a weapon in California.
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: But he had a long arrest record, dating to 1980 when he was arrested in Los Angeles on charges of soliciting a sex act from a police officer. Two years later he was arrested on a charge of possession of hashish or marijuana in Los Angeles County. The record does not show which of the two substances he was charged with possessing and the police said they did not have the disposition of the cases. 30 Days on Reduced Charge
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: In 1983, the police in Beverly Hills, Calif., arrested him on charges of possessing a dangerous weapon, a misdemeanor; he was convicted and put on probation. The same year, the Los Angeles County Sheriff's deputies arrested him on a charge of receiving stolen property. The charge was dismissed for lack of evidence.
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: On Oct. 1, 1984, Mr. Purdy was arrested in Woodland, Calif., on charges of attempted robbery and criminal conspiracy. He pleaded guilty to reduced charges of being an accessory to a felony and served 30 days in jail.
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: His most recent arrest occurred in April 1987 when he was apprehended in El Dorado County, Calif., on the Nevada border, where he was charged with firing a 9-millimeter pistol in the El Dorado National Forest and with resisting arrest.
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: District Attorney Ron Pepper said that Mr. Purdy acted in a bizzare manner, telling officers that it was his duty ''to overthrow the suppressers.'' Mr. Pepper said that Mr. Purdy kicked deputies and kicked a window out of a patrol car.
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: He was originally jailed in a section for intoxicated prisoners where he attempted suicide by hanging and then by trying to cut his wrists with toenails and fingernails, Mr. Pepper said.
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: Mr. Purdy was then taken to the county psychiatric health center, Mr. Pepper said. A spokesman for the center declined to comment on Mr. Purdy's examination, citing patient confidentialiy. A Danger to Others
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: Mr. Purdy pleaded guilty to both charges and spent 45 days in the county jail.
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: The El Dorado County probation report described him as a danger to himself and others.
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: Mr. Purdy had been drifting around the country, never holding a job for long, for several months. He frequently clashed with his supervisors.
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: He worked as a security officer in Glendale, Calif., near Los Angeles, leaving after an incident in which he failed to act when somebody was being beaten up, Captain Perry said. He next showed up in Key West, Fla., working as a laborer at a nursery and a construction company until the summer of 1984.
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: That fall, he returned to California, working near Sacramento, and then taking courses in welding in Stockton, where he had attended the Cleveland School as a youngster. For the first month of 1988 he worked here at the Numeri Tech Machine Shop and later at the FR Manufacturing Corporation. He Worked in Connecticut
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: Last summer he drifted north to the Portland, Ore., area, where he took occasional work in the shipyards through the boilermakers' union, then traveled to Texas in a vain search for work, spent a month working at the DuPont Company in Memphis, and then a month, from mid-November to mid-December of 1988, at the Thames Cogeneration Company in Windsor, Conn., before returning to Stockton He was born in Fort Lewis, Wash., on Nov. 10, 1964, according to the birth certificate the police found in his automobile. Mr. Purdy spent a youth full of turmoil. His father, Patrick Benjamin Purdy, was divorced from his mother, Kathleen.
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: The elder Mr. Purdy served on active duty in the Army for more than three years, all of it in the United States, after entering the service in April 1963, The San Diego Union reported today, quoting a spokeswoman at the Army Reserve Personnel Center in St. Louis. Mr. Purdy spent most of his last year in a hospital for psychiatric evaluation, then was put on temporary medical disability for five years before being honorably discharged in 1971, the spokeswoman told the newspaper. Other newspapers in California had quoted members of Mr. Purdy's family as saying he served in the Army in Vietnam and was discharged on mental grounds.
title: Killer Depicted as Loner Full of Hate

text: By Joseph F. Sullivan, Special To the New York Times
title: Trooper Kills Man in Struggle On Jersey Road

text: A man riding in a car that was pulled over for speeding on the New Jersey Turnpike was killed today while struggling with a state trooper over a gun.
title: Trooper Kills Man in Struggle On Jersey Road

text: The man, who the police discovered later was a convicted bank robber, had tried to flee when the trooper became suspicious that he was carrying drugs, the state police said.
title: Trooper Kills Man in Struggle On Jersey Road

text: They said the man had moved to Hackensack from North Carolina in October and was 47 years old, but they said they would not identify him until his relatives were notified.
title: Trooper Kills Man in Struggle On Jersey Road

text: The incident began when Trooper Robert K. Henig, 26, stopped a 1983 Lincoln Continental with North Carolina plates for speeding at 12:30 P.M., just south of Exit 11 here, said Capt. Thomas Gallagher, a state police spokesman. Three men were in the car. Men Acted 'Very Nervous'
title: Trooper Kills Man in Struggle On Jersey Road

text: As the trooper asked for the driver's license and registration, he noticed the occupants of the car acting ''very nervous,'' the captain said.
title: Trooper Kills Man in Struggle On Jersey Road

text: The trooper then asked the passenger in the front seat to get out and show identification. As the man removed papers from his wallet, Captain Gallagher said, the trooper saw what appeared to be a bag of marijuana, which the man quickly put back in his pocket.
title: Trooper Kills Man in Struggle On Jersey Road

text: The trooper then began a pat-down search of the man and felt what he suspected was a weapon under the man's pants, the captain said. A packet of cocaine was later found to be hidden there, he said. The man then broke free and ran for a grassy incline with the trooper in pursuit, his automatic 9-millimeter pistol in his hand.
title: Trooper Kills Man in Struggle On Jersey Road

text: Trooper Henig subdued the man, who fell to the ground and agreed to submit to arrest, the state police said. But as the trooper began to return his pistol to his holster, the man, still on the ground, kicked the trooper in the groin and grabbed for the weapon, the police said. A Shot Is Fired
title: Trooper Kills Man in Struggle On Jersey Road

text: With both men holding on to the gun, the man on the ground twisted it toward the trooper. A shot discharged, but it did not hit either man. Trooper Henig then twisted the gun back toward the man and fired a shot into his chest, Captain Gallagher said.
title: Trooper Kills Man in Struggle On Jersey Road

text: The trooper then handcuffed the man and ran back to the car. The driver, identified as Bernard Hicks, 37, of Greensboro, N.J., had remained near the car. But the second passenger, who has not been identified, had fled. He was being hunted by troopers and the Woodbridge Township police, aided by a state police helicopter and a dog team.
title: Trooper Kills Man in Struggle On Jersey Road

text: The man who was shot was pronounced dead at the scene. Capt. Thomas Carr, commander of Troop D, said a plastic packet containing 5.6 ounces of cocaine was found tucked into the man's pants. A background check revealed that he was on parole from two bank-robbery convictions in North Carolina in 1976.
title: Trooper Kills Man in Struggle On Jersey Road

text: Captain Carr said a total of three shots were believed to have been fired. He said Trooper Henig joined the force three years ago.
title: Trooper Kills Man in Struggle On Jersey Road

text: The driver of the car was charged with speeding at 70 miles an hour in a 55 mile-per-hour zone and driving with an expired license.
title: Trooper Kills Man in Struggle On Jersey Road

text: The Fords section of Woodbridge was cordoned off and traffic was disrupted while the police searched for the third man, a black male described as wearing sneakers, jeans and a beige jacket. At 5:45 P.M. a man was taken to troop headquarters in handcuffs, but he was released 30 minutes later after satisfying the police that he lived in Woodbridge. He had been picked up a block from his home by Woodbridge officers.
title: Trooper Kills Man in Struggle On Jersey Road

text: LEAD: Minutes before the start of the New York Knicks game Saturday night, Alex Sumner stood outside Madison Square Garden, desperate.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: Minutes before the start of the New York Knicks game Saturday night, Alex Sumner stood outside Madison Square Garden, desperate.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: ''I need one for tonight! I need one for tonight!'' he shouted, as fans for the sold-out game streamed past him and scalpers darted around, hawking tickets for up to $100.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: That left Mr. Sumner, a 24-year-old education student at New York University, with $30 in his pocket, standing in the cold.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: ''It's very disheartening, to say the least,'' he said. ''Two years ago, buying a ticket was much simpler.''Hottest Tickets in Town
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: Today, the Knicks - with the help of several hometown heroes, a coach who looks like a choirboy and aggressive marketing in the front office - are once again one of the hottest tickets in town.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: The team, in first place in the Atlantic Division of the National Basketball Association, is averaging more than 17,200 people a game, up more than 4,000 from two years ago. Sell-out crowds, like the one that watched the Knicks beat the Atlanta Hawks Saturday night, are common.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: Last Tuesday, on the first day the seats were available, 38,411 tickets were sold for games in the second half of the season, marking the largest one-day sale in the team's 43-year history.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: What's more, after years of hapless play in front of dwindling, often truculent crowds, the Knicks have returned the luster to the Garden as both a basketball mecca and a social hub.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: On game nights, fans - a wide range of people but with a decided emphasis on Wall Street lawyers, garment-industry executives and young professionals on dates - descend upon the midtown area.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: Bars and restaurants near the Garden, like Beefsteak Charlie's and Charlie O's, teem with rowdy customers, and celebrities like Dustin Hoffman and Mr. T are requesting tickets.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: These images stir memories of the Knicks' championship years of 1970 and 1973, when stars like Woody Allen and Robert Redford, cheered Walt Frazier and Bill Bradley, and well-heeled fans wearing tailored suits and fur coats made basketball fashionable.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: ''It's 1969 to 1973 all over again,'' said John Condon, the public address announcer at Knick games since 1947. ''It's the same fever, same reaction, same enthusiasm.''
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: And as far as Knick fans are concerned, it's about time. In recent years Knick games at the Garden had become funereal affairs. The team had losing records 10 out of the last 14 years. Fans booed the Knicks, cheered the opposing teams and left early. The arena was often less than half full.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: While fans could not hear a pin drop, ''there were games that were so quiet you hear the players calling out defenses at the other end of the court,'' said George Lois, a Manhattan advertising executive who has had season tickets behind the baseline since 1968.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: There were also complaints about the Garden itself: marijuana smoke hung in the air, fights broke out in the stands, the ushers were rude.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: ''I thought it was a nasty place,'' Mr. Lois said. ''People would take you to your seats and yell at you. Now the atmosphere is much better.''Rebuilding the Knicks
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: The fortunes of both the Knicks and the Garden began to change in 1987. The Madison Square Garden Corporation, which owns the Garden, the Knicks and the New York Rangers, was restructured by its parent company, Gulf & Western Inc. What emerged was a company with four operating groups, including one in charge of rebuilding the Knicks and one responsible for improving the building.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: The rebuilding of the team began in the summer of 1987 with the hiring of Al Bianchi as general manager and Rick Pitino as coach, both of whom grew up in New York.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: Mr. Pitino, an intense, animated man with boyish looks, was hired in part because his wide open style of play - with a pressing defense and fast-break offense - would generate excitement in what had been moribund basketball games in the Garden.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: Fans also quickly embraced hometown players as local boys made good - Mark Jackson, from Southeast Queens, Rod Strickland, from the Bronx, and Sidney Green, from Brooklyn. These players, and starters like Patrick Ewing and Charles Oakley, have not achieved the same celebrity as players like Willis Reed and Dave DeBusschere from the Knicks' championship teams, but this team's connection to New York is often evident.Uniforms Were Stolen
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: Last week, for example, Mr. Green announced he would buy uniforms for the basketball team at Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn, where he went to school. The team's uniforms had been stolen several weeks ago.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: The fans' favorite player appears to be Mr. Jackson, who went to college at St. John's University, won the Rookie of the Year award last year and delights crowds with playful on-court antics, like wagging his forefingers at fans after a good play.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: ''Everyone loves that,'' said Howard Seidman, a Parsippany, N.J., resident, who noted that Mr. Jackson also gets high marks as a family man. ''Last year he was still living with his family in Queens.'' (Mr. Jackson has since bought a home for his parents on Long Island and a condominium for himself in New Jersey.) The Knicks have been virtually unbeatable at home this year, with 13 straight victories, and their overall record of 24-11, the second-best in the N.B.A. But Garden officials say the team is not the only thing that has improved. In the last two years, these officials say, the center has also gotten better, often in subtle ways. More lights have been installed outside the Garden, the floors are swept more often, and ushers have received new red tapered jackets.Crackdown on Unruly Crowds
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: The Garden, which has seen the Meadowlands Sports Complex in New Jersey steal some big events, has also tried to crackdown on unruly crowds. In 1987 all season ticket holders received a list of rules prohibiting excessive drinking, fighting and abusive language. Violators receive one warning, then have their tickets revoked. Garden officials say last year 21 people lost their tickets for violations.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: Of course, the fans are paying for the success. Ticket prices increased this season; the best seats went up from $22 to $25. Still season-ticket sales jumped from 5,800 to 8,300. In addition to a better team, the Knicks are now marketing themselves more aggressively, using telemarketing, direct mail, print advertising and more promotions on the score board and on the Madison Sqare Garden Television Network.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: How much longer the Garden will be in its current location is uncertain. In 1986 Gulf & Western announced it would build a $1 billion Garden between 31st and 33d Streets west of 11th Avenue. Construction, which was to start in late 1987, has not yet begun.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: The Knicks won Saturday's game, 132-122. Before it started, in front of the Garden on Seventh Avenue between 32d and 33d Streets, taxis blared their horns as fans weaved through the streets. Scalpers prowled the grounds shouting ''who's buying? who's buying?'' as customers cursed - and paid - $100 ticket prices.
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: ''It finally feels as if you're at an event,'' said Cliff Chenfeld, a 28-year-old Wall Street lawyer who paid $1,600 this year for two season tickets. ''When I used to go, it felt as if you were there with only certified basketball freaks.''
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: He attended Saturday's game with his wife, Chana Gandal. ''Now when I give her Knick tickets for her birthday, she no longer gets mad at me,'' Mr. Chenfeld said. ''It's become a legitimate present.''
title: At Garden, a Fast Break for Knick Tickets

text: Special to the New York Times
title: Judge Rejects Boat Searches

text: A Superior Court justice in Maine has ruled that game warderns' searches of boaters along the Saco River last summer were unconstitutional. Game wardens conducting the searches cited rowdy and potentially dangerous behavior by some boaters. But Justice Donald Alexander said there was ''no significant connection'' between the behavior the wardens sought to stop and the charges that were subsequently filed. Many charges involved fishing without a license, marijuana possession and not having enough life jackets.
title: Judge Rejects Boat Searches

text: Ray Morehart, a reserve infielder on the 1927 New York Yankees, died at home Friday. He was 89 years old.
title: Ray Morehart, Yankee With Ruth, Dies at 89

text: ''He was sitting in his rocking chair and had been reading the newspaper,'' said Mr. Morehart's daughter, Mariana Koontz, of Lewisville, Tex. ''I guess his little heart just played out.''
title: Ray Morehart, Yankee With Ruth, Dies at 89

text: Mr. Morehart's death leaves Mark Koenig, the starting shortstop, as the only surviving member of the team that featured Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig.
title: Ray Morehart, Yankee With Ruth, Dies at 89

text: Mr. Morehart, a career .269 hitter in three major league seasons, the first two with the Chicago White Sox, batted .256 in 73 games in 1927. On Aug. 31, 1926, while with the White Sox, he got nine hits in a doubleheader, a record that has been matched but never broken.
title: Ray Morehart, Yankee With Ruth, Dies at 89

text: Besides his daughter, Mr. Morehart is also survived by his wife, Mary; another daughter, Betty Nelson of Garland, Tex., and five grandsons and two great-grandsons.
title: Ray Morehart, Yankee With Ruth, Dies at 89

text: Federal agents yesterday arrested 14 people, four of them Customs Service employees, in a crackdown on drug trafficking at Kennedy International Airport.
title: 4 Customs Workers Are Among 14 Held In Drug Crackdown

text: One Customs employee was charged with stealing duty fees from airplane passengers. The others were charged with distributing narcotics or conspiracy to distribute narcotics. They face maximum penalties of 20 years in prison and $250,000 fines.
title: 4 Customs Workers Are Among 14 Held In Drug Crackdown

text: United States Attorney Andrew J. Maloney said that the group was not a drug ring and that although the defendants knew one another, they often acted independently, obtaining narcotics for personal use as well as for sales. The drugs included cocaine, marijuana, hashish and opium, and sales ranged from $2,500 to $3,000, Mr. Maloney added.
title: 4 Customs Workers Are Among 14 Held In Drug Crackdown

text: Although the quantities of drugs were relatively small, the case showed corruption among Federal employees, an assistant customs commissioner, William Green, said at a news conference in Brooklyn about the arrests.
title: 4 Customs Workers Are Among 14 Held In Drug Crackdown

text: Among those arrested were a Customs inspector, two Customs aides, a specialist who checks international mail and two plant and quarantine inspectors of the Agriculture Department. The others included baggage handlers, other airport workers and a physician's assistant from Queens General Hospital.
title: 4 Customs Workers Are Among 14 Held In Drug Crackdown
